4SJS_m-JXc0oASx6x5Mjkw.review_text: Within hours of my trip to SF, I had already eaten at Ike's and stuffed myself with macarons from Paulette. But I like to think I don't do things in half-measures and it was cocktail o'clock.  I ordered up a La Floridita and some oysters. My friend restrained herself to a cocktail and a salad. The oysters were quite nice! My cocktail was a bit icy though. I hate when people don't double-strain. I don't like chips of ice in my cocktails that are served up (ah, bar snobbery).  The early afternoon hours contained the lunch stragglers and an odd man or two at the bar. We opted to sit at the bar to take in the French decor. It kind of reminded me of my fave Figaro Bistrot back in L.A. but on a grander scale.

9FOrsYpBwOIHvTzqBpe0Qw.review_text: I loved everything about this place and I was just there for drinks! The bar is an amazing sight to behold and the staff is 100% professional. The drink menu is epic and the selections are a wonder. I can't wait to come here and eat a meal to get the full experience!

0nQoPutppgbUjW68rDBzTg.review_text: Great food and service, but really needs to make reservation, otherwise you will have to wait for at least 30mins to one hour to get a seat.  True French Atmosphere but the cuisine is a bit mixed American and French, been there a few times, once was with my Dutch friend who thought he was in Pairs for a moment. The absinthe just added more to it after the awesome duck confit. The bar is always packed, so many selection from absinthe, wine list, mixed drinks, It is a cool, trendy like with culture mixed restaurant, not even mention about the food...   I give 4 stars because it is a bit $$$, but surely worthy it :-)

K5aopx51l0zQ1WAzU-TDAg.review_text: Totally stealing words from the Frenchies: c'est magnifique! Came here for the first time this past weekend for Sunday brunch. I spent the weekend with the parents and god family, and typically when I'm in the city on Sundays I do brunch in the Castro. However, that really isn't the whole family's sort of scene.   Being the Greeks that we are, we're a very impatient group and this place was able to seat the six of us right away. Note: we got there around 11:15-11:30-ish, right after it opened (and it was already pretty full). They scooted two tiny tables together and I sat in the crack, which after I tasted my mimosa was quite fine with me. Their bloody marys also looked really delicious. The place has that quaint chic french cafe look to it inside, which I love.   Now here's the best part- the food! I had THE most amazing banana blueberry souffle pancakes. I am the queen of pancakes, mainly because I love carbs (and who doesn't), and these guys did not disappoint. I skipped the whipped cream, and I'm so glad I did. The pancakes were were very sweet all on their own. Add bacon to the side and you could call this a meal for two. Everyone else had something different and no one had a bad thing to say. My dad's a diabetic and he was the happiest camper in the group.   I'm not gonna lie, I never saw the check. I don't even think it came to the table- someone did one of those sly "here's my card on the way to the bathroom" moves. But I know that my meal, which did i mention I could've split with someone, was maybe $15-17 with the bacon.   This place is the perfect hangover brunch locale, even if you have to walk a block or two to get there (we did). But on a perfect San Franciscan day... no one minds walking, esp if this is where you end up.

xVndjy6wsAxGlOxPjBbZxw.review_text: There is no love sincerer than the love of food.   Life would be flavorless if there were no spice of excitement, no quickening of the heartbeat, no thrill of anticipation. Absinthe Brasserie is the place to inject some flavor and romance into your life.   *Sip on their famous Galapagos Cocktail, savor some wine.  *Sample the creamy Castelbelbo cheese from Piemonte, Itlay with earthy marcona almonds and crusty raisin bread...so good that it enticed my carb-loathing date to go for seconds and thirds.  *I absolutely adored my choice. Roasted Rack of Lamb with zucchini-yogurt purée; squash, eggplant, pepper hash; crispy squash blossom. The lamb was perfectly medium rare, the outside surprising crispy while the inside was juicy and succulent. The sauteed eggplant and squash was perfectly seasoned. I tried a bite of my date's Manchego & Chorizo stuffed Mary's Chicken...flavorful and tender, but I'll let him yelp that. :)   *For dessert, the Gianduja Soft Chocolate and whiskey parfait with almond molasses toffee sauce was surprisingly complex in flavor. Separately, the chocolate mousse, whisky parfait, ice cream and toffee sauce were all quite good. Together, the flavors mingled together into an orgasmic explosion of flavor in your mouth.   Tip: If you are on a date, be sure to request booth seating. To touch, feed, whisper, share delicious morsels...that is the art of seduction.

lyoWem09mR1q9VBFMCG3VQ.review_text: Came here after a concert near Davies and wanted to get light fare. Weather was perfect, and got a table outside. Had some drinks, and snacked on fries, spicy pork meatballs, and steak tartare. The smoky ketchup went beautifully with the fries. The bread and butter was also very good.  Would very much enjoy coming again for drinks, or dinner. Nice place with great service.

2rgzUE9BagBMWMFlcSKM8g.review_text: The boyfriend and I came here the other night for a much needed date night.  We got there at about 10 (late night date night!) for dinner.  We started with the soft garlic pretzel.  YES PLEASE!  I'm still thinking about these and I want to go back just for these.  We then had the country pate, which the boyfriend wolfed down all the pickled deliciousness that was available.  We also got steak tartare because I kind of have a thing for raw beef.  Then our stonefruit salad came out which I loved.  We have a thing for fruit salads, so this was right up our alley.  Lastly we shared the lamb sugo.  This was probably the weakest part of the meal for me, but it was still pretty tasty.  Oh, and I forgot to add, get the Ginger Rogers.  I had one and it was DELICIOUS.  So delicious that the boyfriend had to order one for himself too.  So delicious that I may have gotten a bit drunk and had to drunk text messages to my best friend telling her that she was my absolute bff in the world.  Yeah....that was fun.

lbm7jIrSNcFeowlXqBKrNg.review_text: My friend and I recently had dinner here before heading to the symphony.   We actually got into the city a little earlier than planned and made it to the restaurant early. We asked if we could be seated earlier and the hostess was a bit put off.  That was sort of a turn off, but once we got past that, it was a fabulous experience.  Our waiter was very personable, knowledgeable and friendly. He answered all of our questions, helped us select our drinks and even asked if we were seeing a show and at what time.  Onto the food. I had the skirt steak and can I just say....is it bad form to the lick the plate? Just kidding, but it was that good! My friend had the chicken and I'm pretty sure she felt the same way I did. Before our entrees, we split a beet salad. I don't even like beets, but the salad was fantastic.   I would recommend this restaurant to a friend! Yummo.

veyBYho3I1RgEcuph7rc1Q.review_text: I've gone to this restaurant at least 4 or 5 times.  It has consistently had really good food, service, and drinks.  It's tough to get a seat usually, but I've gotten in fairly easily later in the evening around 10.  They are open until 2AM and serve really good food.  The prices are a little on the pricey side, but worth it for a nice evening out.  The fries, chicken liver mousse, and octopus entree are really good.  My favorite drink here is definitely the Spanish coffee.  I thought the sazerac was pretty gross.

hUrHuea6XkUXJ-kV7kE3gw.review_text: OK, I don't give these out so much, but it's a 5...  First of all, I am one of those people that looks at the descriptions and rarely the price, if you are price conscious, don't come here.  This is not a value priced restaurant.  I have been here a number of times for brunch, and it is really stand up.  But this is the first time in years....that I have been back for dinner.  And wow.  From the fries, to the french onion soup, to the slow cooked pork on collard greens, this is French Bistro with its own flair.    My pick, on the drink menu is the sleepy hollow..or something like that...last choice on the cocktail list...wow.  So good I forgot its name..  now if i could just make that happen with some of my lovers....

bIt7A8ooqfjvP-2SQ_RUFw.review_text: I'm reviewing this as a bar spot, but the food is good.  I like the scene here.  It's chock full of crazy glasses people.  For those of you who don't know me (i.e., everyone), that's what I call people wearing super expensive avant garde glasses -- I think they're usually advertising execs or art gallery owners.  Anyway, I like those people!  They look interesting and generally don't bother me, which means that I can be more interesting while in their presence without actually having to converse with them and thereby reveal that I never read my New Yorkers and couldn't point out Minsk on a map.  The illusion of our mutual sophistication remains undisturbed.  That makes for a great drinkin' atmosphere.  Great cocktails, heated outdoor tables, good service.

No4wQP-qXe5DNNy7MR5kaw.review_text: Best breakfast burrito I'm aware of!

gWeDN34DADPbbPzkU1Mi-g.review_text: This has become a favorite hangout for us, great atmosphere, fun lively crowd especially in the bar area, the back is a little too quiet, more formal which is fine. The food has been consistently very good and inventive the Bar has some great talent and new drinks all the time. Bar crowd fun to strike up a conversation with, check it out.

IxQrE6BuM_QKnjSq6kVglg.review_text: Stopped by last month with 2 girlfriends after happy hour to grab some food before one of them needed to drive back to San Mateo. There were no seats at the bar, so we decided to get a table.  Ordered a burger and a salad to share, both were amazing. The waitress on the other was the opposite... It's our choice to not get drinks late on a Wed night, don't give us attitude! I'll come by next time to the bar hopefully for better service.

PU2sJGUSJzMUFiZrmV519Q.review_text: Very crowded and fairly loud - the place was popularized after their head chef, Jamie, was on Top Chef.   What we tried:  *Ginger-scented squash purée ($8ish) *Liberty Farms duck confit ($18)  *Grilled scallops ($30) *herb stuffed Mary's chicken ($28) *Scharffen Berger chocolate Pot de crème ($9) *Cocchi Barolo ($9ish)  I remember the ginger-scented squash puree being excellent, but I don't quite remember the other dishes (I was there months and months ago haha).  What I do remember is that I enjoyed the food and service overall, but for that price, I'd rather try some place new next time.

jIZqQ6JUHDH0GJHW9RM0jA.review_text: Our go-to place any time we attend an event at the Opera House or Davies Hall.  If you want to eat either before or after a performance, you need to plan ahead and book your table.  Also a great spot for a beverage.  It can get crowded and noisy, but the quality of the food and drink makes the hassle worthwhile.

nZB33t0RFtq_jTxJJJ6wfA.review_text: This is a must place to dine in the city! We  had a reservation, I would recommend, we were seated right away. The cocktails came quickly and our service all evening was great. The carrot soup is fabulous, watch out for the spices on the top though. We shared the escargots and lamb sausages for appetizers, yes amazing! I had the pork confit it was the most tender and flavorfull I have ever had. My husband had the burger, very good, my son ordered the Beef Cheeks they were tender and full of flavor. The seasoning is well thought out and really a pleasure!  I am lucky my son lives just around the corner from this amazing resturaunt we will be back! Cheers

WTxT5jwRLYazV87u_7zBwQ.review_text: Food was great (Brunch - some of the best pancakes ever). Service could have been better. Heard good things about their Dinner Menu so my gf and I may come back sometime to see for ourselves. I will re-rate once we come back but for now a 3.5/4 Star Rating.

mpm9olv35gqQePUdQvK62g.review_text: 8 girls came here for our monthly restaurant splurge and had a really fun time. Our waitress was very friendly and knowledgeable of drink list and menu, and gave us good recommendations. We started with the chickpeas - really good spicy crunchy snack. French fries were good too, and also shared an order of the garlic pretzels. I was originally not about ordering the pretzels, but I was wrong to have doubted. They were buttery, garlicky, melt in your mouth delicious, and I would order them over and over again!   I ordered a cup of the french onion soup and the steak tartare for my entree. Neither were best in SF class but very good overall. Waitress was friendly but not overbearing, and the meal was orchestrated nicely but not forced.  Would love a reason to come back!

AZXJJ8BdKbV1wtdDj9XwfQ.review_text: Loved every thing that showed up on our table.  Hearty, great flavors, perfect proportions.  Must-haves include: the hamachi sashimi appetizer (with some spicy jalapeno oil and peppers - I think this is the purest form of the dish that is now all over the Katsuya's and sushi restaurants everywhere), which was just incredibly fresh and textured; the lobster and beet salad, which trumped a similar dish at Aqua the night before; the scallops (a Jamie speciality based on her Top Chef performances); and the rib eye, which was juicy, tender, and chock full of flavor.  If you're feeling ambitious, the oyster shooter w/ vodka is a nice starter, and add on a side of the fries with 3 dipping suaces (including malt vingar, yum...).  Great service.  A little loud in the dining room, but a great dinner experience.  Worth it.

3ydG8dwXw2gytUkqEHR6Tw.review_text: Absinthe is perhaps one of the most elegant and stellar restaurants in the city. Everything about the restaurant is outstanding and well worth the price.   Parking can be difficult as the Hayes Valley area has become a very busy and up-scale neighborhood.

wwgXWXzSmcTh_mk8QHsGXg.review_text: I lived in this area and for years, we went by and saw the long line came out of this restaurant almost every weekends. And because of that we avoid the long wait and restaurant all together.    Finally last weekend my uncle who lived out of town heard a lot of good things about this place and insisted we had to have brunch here. So he made a reservation and it was a good idea as we didn't have to wait in a long line. And it turned out that the food here were great. Six of us had different thing on the menu and we all loved what we ordered. The service was nice as you would expected. It's not cheap here but worth the money.      I am thinking of coming back here again for I have guests visit me or special occasions as the price here is a bit high for us for everyday dinning.

8ZWYZwYjO9vrfmdhDLc4TA.review_text: This review isn't a normal review I would write...enough people have raved about it and they're right.  This review, however, is about the fact that I've tried a lot of their menu over several visits and everything is very good.  I highly recommend coming here après-show.  They serve a comprehensive and very good bar menu all the way until 11pm...including the croque monsieur, french onion soup, cheese plates, oysters, etc.  Absinthe is a great restaurant in general, but it's even better considering the consistency of the food at any hour and the proximity to the War Memorial and Symphony Hall.

NpU44ANnUUNQWY4U0eUGvA.review_text: we decided to do a valentines day brunch here because we had heard good things about it.  i heard at the door that it was an hours wait.  good thing for reservations!  i had a bellini but their other cocktails sound very interesting.  their wild mushroom omlette was AQ for some reason.  when the bill came it was just $13.  i guess it depends on what mushrooms there are.  bf had the biscuits and gravy with eggs and grits.  he finished the plate but said the biscuits were a bit dry.  my omelette was pretty good.  i didnt really need to put anything on it.  it had gruyere cheese in it along with the mushrooms.  i couldnt really finish it though since we also split the banana blueberry souffle pancakes.  i didnt think they were that good at first bite but i couldnt stop eating them.  we came again for mothers day brunch.  for reservations or 8 or more they cant take you until after 2pm!  kinda of weird. i realized while we were eating that the restaurant was pretty much clearing out by the time we were done.  even with our 2pm reservation we had to wait about 30 minutes to get seated.  i think we were 10 minutes late but we didnt sit down until 2:30.  my mom got the dungeness crab that is sautedd with garlic and parsley, almost chinese style. half a crab is $18.  not really worth it in comparison to the chinese style ones.  i had the croque madame, basically a griled ham and cheese, topped with egg.  i only ate half because the egg only covered half of the sandwich.  the egg was a $1 add on.  maybe they couldve put 2?  to covere the whole sandwich?  i dont know.  i didnt really like how the oil/butter was dripping. i like my grilled sandwiches buttered but not dripping.  the duck confit has was ok.  others had burger which they said was really good. omlette which they said was overdone.  crab sandwich whic they said was good.  again we finished the pancakes.  we walked out of there in a food coma

Ady3w3K2Ie1PrJReAtTQiw.review_text: This review is for brunch; never been for dinner.  I've been known to get more than a little tipsy off of their delicious cocktails (Ginger Rogers and Fame are favorites).    Service could be better for the price (sometimes it appears that waiters forget you exist and you have to flag them down to get, like, water), but that's the only reason for 4 stars instead of 5.     Favorite brunch items:   -Steak Frites -Burger -Duck confit eggs benedict   They also have delicious cheeses and good bread, though you have to ask for the bread.   Overall, one of my favorite brunch standards.

BBTFyjdgWSEdzhQFEQx65g.review_text: Absinthe used to be my go to Sunday Brunch spot. After a hard spinning/boxing class that is nothing more satisfying than a ricotta stuffed French toast. However, the last time I dined at Absinthe, we had an intolerably rude waitress who spilled ice water in our eggs and just shrugged like, "shit happens. Deal." While I'm pretty laid back, when I'm paying $12 for an omelet, I'd like to actually eat it; not test its buoyancy. To their credit, Jeff, the GM, apologized profusely, sent me a gift certificate and offered to buy me and my friends a round of drinks the next time I was there.   After a year and harboring a mildly obsessive girl crush on Jamie Lauren (second only to Elizabeth Faulkner), I decided to venture back for dinner. From the moment I opened the door I knew I was home. I missed the fabulous bar, the gorgeous tiles, the comfy banquettes and the retro cocktail menu.   I'm also glad to report that the menu has been vastly improved. Jamie (we are on a first name basis) has broken out of the classic Brasserie mold with some surprising additions and new presentations while retaining the hearty satisfaction of bistro food.   The beet salad was an absolute dream: roasted beets with burrata and micro greens. My dining companion, who incidentally doesn't eat beets b/c he doesn't like them, devoured half the dish. Did I mention it has burrata?   Since Jamie just won her last challenge on Top Chef using scallops, I decided to try her grilled scallop entree. I was definitely impressed with the texture of the scallop none of the chewy stringiness that I normally associate with scallops. The sun-choke puree with it was creamy and delicious as were the baby artichoke hearts.   For dessert we shared the warm chocolate tart with salted caramel sauce, macadamia brittle and bruleed bananas. It was good but there definitely was not enough macadamia brittle.   I am definitely back to being a regular at Absinthe. Thank you Jamie for making an oldie a goodie. And for being the hottest girl on TV!  swoon!

oPW-LM0pXja0lDwZybXd9g.review_text: Basically, I went here because after hearing that my idol Henry Rollins had eaten lunch here the week before.  I sure hope he enjoyed his lunch more than I enjoyed my drinks.  Overpriced, and the surrounding prettiness doesn't make up for it.  Also, half the special drinks menu is comprised of poorly contemplated mixes.  This place draws a crowd because of location and their pretty decor.  Substance is utterly lacking.  The two stars are for service alone (those folks really do a great job of taking care of you).

POmyqedLjt06Gfajf1of5Q.review_text: Very intimate place- that I have always wanted to try. Made our reservation for a Sunday night, and we were seated right away. I like the way the seating is set up in the restaurant you don't feel super close to other diners. The pretzels are delicious as well as the pork chop and the Coq Au Vin.  Also of course they have a huge variety of tasty drinks which are all beautiful and very tasty.  Great for a special evening or just drinks and a quick bite.

NDH7N_TqW7uZPqLBuGTWqA.review_text: Do yourself a favor and order the french onion soup.  It's so good, it reminds me of Paris.  Had brunch here, and I ordered the scrambled egg burrito.  By god, they were not kidding about the scramble egg.  My whole burrito was filled with eggs to the brim.  Sadly, I was unable to stomach it.  It was overwhelming.  My friend ordered a basic breakfast.  The sausage that came with the meal were patties.  The potatoes were good.  Ordered a ginger dessert and it was excellent, but still a little too rich for me especially if I'm trying to recover from the night before.  Quite frankly I'm a little disappointed, perhaps because I've heard so many great things about this place and I really wanted to like it.  I do plan on coming back for dinner the next time around.

KNP8AJ_FWh6Y9eUTkbeE2w.review_text: It was my parents' anniversary earlier this week, and they were kind enough to invite my sister and I along for the celebratory evening. (I know. They must really love us.) We celebrated over dinner at Absinthe Brasserie & Bar in Hayes Valley, before walking over to The Orpheum to see the Broadway rendition of Billy Elliott.   Absinthe, which serves upscale French-American and Northern Italian cuisine, is a definite gem in the San Francisco dining scene. The soft lighting and the fun Belle Epoque decor give the place the vibe of a trendy and sophisticated French bistro. I've been there for brunch before, and the service has always been friendly and attentive. There's a nice bar in the front of the restaurant, and while we stuck to white wine the other night, Absinthe also offers an impressive selection of creative and whimsical cocktails.  When it comes to eating out at San Francisco restaurants, I pretty much just do whatever 7x7 tells me to do. Therefore, I was thrilled to try out two Absinthe specialties that have been featured on 7x7's various "Best of San Francisco" lists. First, we ordered the soft garlic pretzels with Vermont cheddar mornay sauce (#36 on the 2011 Big Eat San Francisco: 100 Things to Try Before You Die) as an appetizer. I was admittedly kind of surprised that something as simple as pretzels made that exclusive list, until I took my first bite, and realized that these pretzels, soft and fluffy and topped with garlic and sea salt, are not just simple pretzels. Trust me. Just try them.  We also ordered a shared plate of Black Mission figs with cheese, toasted walnuts, and arugula. Our waiter told us that this dish had just been added to the menu this week, now that figs are at the peak of their season, and the combination of flavors was superb.  After the pretzels were such a success, we decided to trust another recommendation from 7x7 when it came time for our individual orders. Absinthe's French onion soup was listed on 7x7's 2010 list of The Best Bowls of Soup in SF, so everyone at the table ordered a small crockpot filled with a perfectly-executed blend of broth, onions, bread, and melted Gruyere. Definitely one of the best bowls of French onion soup I've ever had!  For my entree, I ordered the halibut, which came with a jalapeno-basil corn pudding and a succotash-esque combination of fresh corn, red potatoes, and mushrooms, all in a brown butter vinaigrette. The fish was cooked expertly, and the summertime corn was sweet and flavorful. The rest of my family ordered the pork loin with black truffle jus, the coq au vin, and the potato-crusted arctic char. All of our dishes featured fresh, local, seasonal ingredients, and let's just say that there were a) no complaints and b) a lot of clean plates.  We had our hearts set on sharing a slice of German chocolate cake to round out the meal, but we sadly realized that we were running late for Billy Elliott, so we had to hightail it out of there and head over to The Orpheum. I guess we'll just have to go back soon...  All in all, Absinthe Brasserie & Bar is the perfect place to stop for dinner or drinks before strolling a few blocks over to the Symphony Hall, the Opera House, or the Ballet. With the delicious food, the attentive service, and the classy ambience, Absinthe is one of those restaurants that makes any night feel special.

nwKsR5_epCypSzGPsMn0HA.review_text: My friend took me here for my belated birthday dinner.  We came here on a Tuesday.  We made the reservation at 8:30pm and we got the table right the way.    I really like the atmosphere of the restaurant.  It was more on the romantic side because of the dim lights.  We were so lucky to have a corner table because it was more intimate with your date.    The service was excellent here.  Everyone was so professional and attentive.  Our server was so sweet and friendly.  She always comes to check on us and refill our water and bread.   I was impressed by their long wine list and creative cocktails list.  All the cocktails had interesting and unique names.  I got the one called PERFECT PEAR.  It was Vodka, pear brandy, lemon juice, sugar, & a splash of orange juice ($9).  This one was more like a girly drink.  Not too strong and tasted very delicious.  My friend got the one called SWEENEY ($11).  It was Whiskey, walnut liqueur, & quince saba.  I sipped it and it was strong........  For the food, we started off the Fresh Onion Soup ($8.5).  OMG, it tasted so good.  It was so rich, flavorful, a lot of melted cheese (even more than the soup).  Since the soup was kinda thick and heavy, I recommend to share with your date.    Then I got the DUCK with wild rice hash and spinach ($30).  The presentation of the dish was nice.  The duck was amazing.  The meat was juicy, tender, moist and well-flavored.  The sides were also tasted good.     My friend got the 10oz Rib Eye Steak ($35).  It served with mash potato and greens.  The portion was perfect for a guy.  I did not taste this one but my friend finished the whole dish within 15 minutes.....I can say the taste must be good too.  Too bad we did not have rooms for dessert....hopefully next time I can try it.    Overall, I had a great dining experience here.  I would definitely to go  back to try the brunch there.

b3hrLxsfcORcG5Ri75oqbg.review_text: The food was good, the cocktails were "meh," the service was TERRIBLE!   SERVICE: Our waitress came to ask us if we were ready to order dinner within two minutes of sitting down-  we had yet to order drinks or even get waters at the table so we said we could order drinks and oysters at that moment, but we needed a few minutes to look at the menu before we ordered dinner. Generally, when this happens the server returns in a few minutes to see if you're ready to order. The first and second time she walked by our tables (our menus were neatly put to the side of our table to indicate we were ready to order) I assumed she'd be back- on the fourth, fifth, and sixth time in the next 25 minutes I could only chuckle. Finally, I flagged her down and ask her if we could place an order for dinner. There was no "sorry I kept you waiting" or "it's crazy in here tonight." Her cold presentation didn't help matters. Once we got our food she never returned to ask how everything was. Though she was absolutely around- just didn't actually acknowledge us.   FOOD/DRINK: Cocktails- I had heard very good things about the cocktails here. They were WAY too sweet. I was so excited for a great cocktail- it was just disappointing. I took a couple sips and had my fiance finish it- he'll put anything away.   The oysters were good- though only came with mignonette- I like with horseradish and cocktail sauce.   My fiance got grilled swordfish- EXCELLENT! Fresh fish, with fresh summer vegetables that we perfect cooked- just the right about of crisp to the veggies- where they taste cooked, but not mushy.   I got a Cesar salad- nothing fancy here, but that happens to be the way I like a Cesar- cold, crisp, anchovy-y dressing.   We got a blue cheese with honeycomb for dessert- oh my god. Freaking awesome!  It's a shame the service sucked- and frankly, I think it was a tad over priced. Yes, we got cheese and oysters. But, I didn't even get an entree and we didn't have a bottle of wine, just two cocktails- our bill was about 150$ (that may have been after the tip, but still).  I am giving two stars because even though the food was great- I really wouldn't go back because of the service- and for the price, the service should have been impeccable.

IgzFM7LQ9e2ZC0GfuxFxAg.review_text: Our dining experience was absolutely beyond my imagination.   My husband had been wanting to go to Absinthe for a long time. With his mother in town for Mother's Day, we finally made a reservation. We started off with the antipasti plate with cured meats, pickles and delicious toasted bread. Perfect to share with three people as a starter.   Drinks: Pimm's Cup, Manhattan and Mojito.   My main was seriously one of the best meals I have had in my life: Duck breast on red curry carrot puree with sauteed spinach (I asked to replace the Swiss chard) and black garlic farro risotto. The meat was so tender and juicy and its seasoning simply delicious. The combination of flavors and texture - risotto vs. puree - was genius. I indulged in every bite and was almost crying that I couldn't finish it all.   We'll be back!

JzmJ6U20uJ9pZonwKGvMuA.review_text: When I arrived at Absinthe last night the place was a madhouse.  It was impossible to get to the bar to get a drink because of all the annoying amateur drinkers.  You know the type, slightly older crowd, may get out to a bar once a month and know nothing of proper bar behavior, hog the bar even though they're not drinking, etc etc.  Anyway, after about 10 minutes I managed to get a drink, (a very tasty Sazerac) and proceeded to wait on my friend to arrive.    Then around 7 something magical happened.  All of the annoying people left, and what remained was a nice lively atmosphere filled with a cool crowd that was totally different than the cacophony that existed only 10 minutes prior.   As I was sitting down on a barstool one of the waitresses came up and thanked me for being so patient.  She informed me that it was the evening for the Nutcracker at the opera house which explained the huge crowd.  I found this not only useful, but highly professional.  (Absinthe management, the waitress with the very short hair in the bar area last night should be commended for her professionalism)    Shortly after my friend arrived and we got a table in the bar area.  I had been craving a good croque madame for a while, so that's what I ordered.  I was then informed that the croque madame was on the  bar menu, which was only available after 8 PM.  I found this pretty annoying since A) I was sitting in the bar, so what's the point of having a bar menu if it isn't always available in the bar and B) how hard could it really be to throw a croque madame together 30 minutes prior to the "official start" of the bar menu being available.  Looking over the normal menu, I settled on a NY strip and fries.  The steak was cooked a perfect medium rare and was an excellent cut of meat.  The fries were ok, but left a little to be desired.  At $29 I felt the price was about right for what I got.    So to recap, Absinthe is a great place to grab a drink assuming you don't arrive during the pre-opera or symphony rush.  Their bartenders make an excellent cocktail, their cocktail menu is full of great classic cocktails that have long since been forgotten by most places, their bar is stocked with one of the best liquor selections in the city, the staff are highly professional, and the food is top notch.  Were it not for the bar menu situation, this place would easily receive 5 stars in my book.

sQNvAkxrmk39AxRf5UvhZQ.review_text: We have been coming here every two weeks or so for ten years. Always great food, one of the truly great bars in the a City. Just go, you'll love it.

rsuL4w3U-V8opiyV4iwPBA.review_text: Visited for restaurant week. Food and service was delicious! I ordered the Roasted Mary's Chicken Breast. Amazing!

YAG90mceVFQLdvl4wndvQg.review_text: this place is one of my favorite restaurants. if i had more yelp posts, you would know that this is quite an accomplishment.   disclaimer: the bf and i went there hoping to see top chef jaime there (which we did!); however, the sighting definitely doesn't bias my review.   we originally wanted to get the escargots and scallop & clam chowder as our appetizers, and then the pork confit and lamb shank for our entrees. however, our wonderful and attentive waiter actually gave us his suggestions when we asked his opinion, as opposed to the generic "oh, everything is wonderful" answer. he told us not to get the escargots because the plate would be too heavy with the chowder; instead, he suggested the oysters, which we went for...they were heavenly. who says that about oysters?   then, the waiter suggested that we only get the pork confit as our entree as opposed to both the pork confit and lamb shank since the pork confit was enough to share. i've never had a waiter advise me to get less food, especially at an expensive restaurant! he wasn't concerned about his tip amount, but about our experience! he definitely helped make our experience great, which i hope was adequately reflected in the tip. the pork confit was good.   the place was great. loved every moment of it.   one more thing, as i am a fan of the original 90210, i was excited to see ian ziering there with a date; he seems to be more of a talker than a listener - just a little observation

r3UmPWmn_e62xJpEngrAxg.review_text: beautiful simple food with a WOW factor.  OH my GOSH. the pasta I had with beautiful mushrooms, AMAZING brussels sprouts (my first time..I literally closed my eyes everytime I bit into one..why does everyone hate em?!) butternut squash and HEAVENLY sauce...like I can't.  The pasta was fresh and warm, never lost it's warmth and every bit was just honestly spectacular... happy tears.  I was so absorbed in my first entree that I forgot I had a desert coming...  My boyfriend had the french dip and it was AMAZING too. The bread was soft, the dip was salty and flavorful without having a layer of grease on top.  Service was wonderful, our server was so sweet and attentive.  Can't wait to come back :) yum yum!

41Z70MtOy9ZyhVtnLemJ_w.review_text: Woah. Delicious. Great food and service. Super clean. Awesome cocktails. Lovely space/ambiance. Great for brunch on a Sunday....  Duck Confit Ragout is AMAZING! Highly recommend it. Tender duck meat served on a potato patty with a poached egg on top. Then some Hollandaise added to it all. Oh. My. Goodness. The Croque Monsieur is delicious as well, try it!  Only problem: PRICEY. Super pricey. Yeah, I'm a student. But still, most people will agree, expensive. So save it for a special day or when you wanna impress someone!

DuPV4MXp9jYwlx1eUiPjxg.review_text: Sit at the bar and watch the bartenders do their magic!  The drinks are creative and good.  I have not dined here, yet.

JeS7ciQNAY6seqFVrhsIuw.review_text: really liking the new chef -- if you've not been back since Jamie headed out for LA, check it out as new.  Cocktails are as good if not better than ever (love love LOVE the vintage cocktails).    nothing beats a weekend brunch or pre/post theater quick dinner here.

Rgxe6btTSPFvVVgLtaLncw.review_text: This is a fabulous restaurant, absolutely impeccable menu, and my favorite post-ballet or post-opera spot.   But to be completely honest, it's the burgers and frites that I love. Oh.My.God. It's SO GOOD! Best burger in San Francisco, hands down. And the fries are amazing almost as good as (read: so damn close it might be a tie) to Bouchon's fries.  Drinks are excellent too, so come thirsty and hungry!

tUD-oKF8v0FGJD9PwNk3Nw.review_text: I came here for the food, not the drinks, which is probably why I'm only giving it 3 stars.  Basically, it's ok but not worth coming here to eat. Ambience is pretty old school and service is decent.

uOKiL4bOOlMvjNdSQJW4og.review_text: Awesome place for oysters and a few cocktails. Great food and service!

awBlguCcD8DpkvBi7kwMqg.review_text: Came here late on Thursday night after we all got off our flights for a quick bite to eat.  It was packed and the hostess said it was going to be a 1.5 hour wait.  When we mentioned that we were going to go somewhere else, she then said that there was a table about to get up.  So we stayed (ha, you tricked us!)  Well, we ordered some drinks as we waited.  I can't remember the name of my drink, but it involved ginger and mint and it was delish!  My friend ordered something with Jameson in it, and it was way too strong for her... when she asked the bartender to add more something in there to make it easier to drink, he was a little rude and didn't accommodate, unfortunately.  We finally got seated by the door and ordered up a feast.  Definitely try the curry chickpeas, the mac&cheese, ahi tuna, and pear salad.  The food was great and our waitress was really accommodating.  My friend ended up just sending her drink back and ordering another... and they still charged her for the first drink :(

CP7ECIG5MXbZ18LKN2mzrA.review_text: It's been a long time since I've been and I need to go back to remember if I liked the food or not.  I think it was pretty good but my notes are pretty neutral on food but the drinks were pretty awesome.  10/07

aN9zAzlBFmmIVm7j64ZViw.review_text: Was here for a late lunch; an ideal time because we were seated immediately. Enjoyed a tasty pisco cocktail; shared the garlic pretzel appetizer; the croque monsieur as main; and strawberry tarragon Pavlova for dessert. All food and drink were exceptional. Would come back for food and/or drink if in the area. (Note: this was sitting as a draft on my phone from April 2013)

Kf6WtGf8LPjxM3hV9mKwwQ.review_text: This was the first stop on my husband's and my culinary tour of San Francisco and the Napa Valley for our first wedding anniversary.  We chose it for the obvious reason as we are huge Top Chef fans, and the food definitely showed why Jamie made it so far!  We started with a cocktail each, he chose the Ultimate Manhattan with incredible port soaked black cherries that had a diner next to us green as my absinthe cocktail with envy.  Since all of their listed Absinthe cocktails were mixed with either whiskey (blech) or tequila (which made my bachelorette party a blur), the bartender graciously made me something new with Gin, Chartreuse, bitters, and maraschino liquer.  The anise aroma filled my senses with every sip!  SO delicious!    For dinner the hubs chose a pork confit (how can you go wrong with pork cooked in pork fat and served with house made bacon?) and I went with the halibut with cauliflower puree, which Jamie made at least once on the show and always looked amazing.  Well, if possible, it tasted even better than it looked.    The fish was cooked perfectly with a crisp, golden brown sear and sweet, tender flesh.  The cauliflower puree was thinner than I anticipated, more like a cream sauce, but divine nonetheless.  The vegetables were crisp and perfectly steamed, giving a great contrast to the smoothness of the puree.    I wish I had a better description of the pork entree, but he was too busy enjoying every bite to put the experience into words!  Overall, it was an incredible meal and a perfect way to begin our culinary adventure!

m-q18lAVSe6rKVLCpmebSQ.review_text: Duck confit hash? Scrumptious. Service? Fantastic. Ambiance? Lovely (very Hayes Valley).  But. All I hear about this place is cocktails, cocktails, cocktails... yet my Bloody Mary - I hate to say - was sub-par at best. Shocker!  I'll be back soon to give the drinks another go, and since friends seem to be raving about the coq au vin, I'll have to try that too! ***update: I have just been informed that the coq au vin is no longer on the menu. Dammit!

JADdo9NEeO5Az9aOYbyvZA.review_text: ************* REVIEW 238 ****************  I've always love Absinthe for the awesome brunch, but I love more was their cocktails menu here. The former mixtologists here won many prizes in the country for their talents. But they left & so the last chef!  I came back anxiously to see what the new chef Micheal Keough has on the menu, a Michael Mina vet & a CIA graduated, I was hoping for a lot more changes on the menu. To my surprise, only a few addition to the AUG menu.  - Fried Chick peas - spicy & a great snack. - Garlic Pretzel - Butter-poach halibut, chanterelle crust, sweet shrimp, peas & carrots, shellfish broth - delish!  The 85% of menu stays the same, French Onion soup, Duck confit, chicken pasta, etc. The cheese selection is still there.   I would definitely wait till late Fall to see what the chef is going to cook up in the new kitchen!

XkVYiiB4Ms8pXn97bixBUQ.review_text: Came for my anniversary and we ordered away! The food was great, the service impeccable and surprisingly the bill was a LOT LESS than we anticipated. I cant wait to go back now that we know we can order just like that and not be hit with a crazy bill. Oysters were very fresh and the hostess even got us in early when we arrived before our reservation. Very accommodating! You have my vote!

A-ssYWVCa69I8n2YP4X1Eg.review_text: Just. Delicious. Our server, Becky (?), was wonderful. I have a food allergy and she knew all of my options off the bat , and took me through each one on the menu. She even double-checked with the chef to be sure I'd be okay. She was helpful, knowledgeable and sweet.   We sat in a beautiful booth, shaped like a corner love seat. The outdoor tables made me think of Europe. It is a bit loud - but the decor is beautiful and very old world French. Check out the ceiling in the bar area, and notice the detail on some of the beautiful mirrors throughout.  My husband had a delightful cocktail, the Galapagos, to start which was sweet, sour and light. For starters, he ordered the garlic mini pretzels, which smelled and tasted wonderful - he loved the way the cheese sauce brought out the garilc and crunch of the pretzels. I had the fried chickpeas, which were hea-ven. Salty, slightly spicy, smelled just a little of curry. Eating them by hand was a treat.  We both chose beef for entrees, but it was a hard choice - the swordfish and lamb also looked wonderful. But it was also AN AWESOME CHOICE. His Wagyu beef was so tender it broke apart with a fork. They braise it for 24 hours so it melts apart. Imagine a delicate, slightly sweet, caramelized-on-the-outside brisket - but then imagine it so much better. I had the Angus filet, which is the best filet I've ever had. It was tender, a little sweet even, perfectly medium rare. I saved half, mostly so I could enjoy it a second day. Both came with beautiful compliments of potatoes and broccoli rabe that balanced and enhanced each flavor of the dish, bringing out the subtleties in everything on the plate.  We had no room for dessert, but were so satisfied and impressed with what we had that we didn't feel cheated. Highly recommended.

ebEdADIJIOWN-pkxwrJr8w.review_text: Brunch was good, not outstanding. Bill was definitely outstanding, and not in a good way, primarily due to mimosas at 9$/glass (which they offer before you even get the chance to see their price from the menu.)

W09mMO5ZJEhSvTsvo1LZlg.review_text: The best thing about the restaurant is the ambiance during dinner time. There is an area that is good for group and can be pretty loud but as you walk through the restaurant, there are intimate settings as well in an area a little quieter. The lights are very dim and can be romantic if you're into that.   Spicy Fried Chickpeas: this crunchy garbanzo bean snack is decent but I will probably go with a different appetizer next time if I come back.   I had the Rock Cod entree and it was just okay - nothing to scream about. But it did go well with my glass of Albarino wine ;)   For dessert, I had the Chocolate Pot de Creme and Caramel Panna Cotta. Both equally delicious... so creamy and very filling! I was completely stuffed after this meal.   All in all, I probably won't go back but there was nothing wrong with this restaurant, it just didn't leave me begging for more.

3ar6_7WAk3dt6pqO1sG5Zw.review_text: I just recently came to Absinthe for the first time in my 6 years of living in SF. In the past two months I have been there three or four times; below are the highlights:   1) Me and the bf wanted something different for breakfast. READ: not dim sum (I do love you, Good Luck Dim Sum). We considered it a brunch date and were willing to spend up. We started with the French onion soup. Sigh, it was beautiful. I also had the grilled cheese portabella sandwich and he had the breakfast sandwich. Mine was a bit greasy on the bread, but his breakfast sandwich was fantastic. I instinctively ordered a bloody mary and neglected to explore the extensive cocktail menu. Note to self, don't show up with a hangover. The bloody mary was spicy; just the way I like it. Added bonus, picked onion garnish. Mmmm. Brunch was a little pricey, but worth it.   2) The second time I was here was at the end of a day-drinking escapade. Me and my compadres saddled up to the bar to explore that cocktail menu I bypassed the first time. Collectively we had the Galapagos, Wonderlust, and and Joy Ride. They were perfect. Then, there was the differentiator...the pretzel bites. I heard they were named as one of the "top 100 dishes to try in SF", or something like that. I believe it. They were heaven. Melting, buttery, salty, deliciousness. HEAVEN!!   3) Brunch again. The good sir ordered the Croque Monsieur. It was okay for me, a standard open faced sandwich. I had the duck confit ragout. It was beautiful. The flavors were not impressive, independent of each other. But this is one of those circumstances where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.   So, while Absinthe should be treated as a rare treat because of the price, I can see why you would keep coming back. The menu doesn't change often (not at all since I have been here) but if you came here for the French onion soup alone, it would be worth it. Needless to say, I will be back.

sPFTOKEFkFomfc4Mi9uY7w.review_text: We randomly showed up here after the Opera 2 blocks down for drinks. I fell in Love with this neighborhood of bars, lounges, restaurants. Vibrant scene, mature crowd (although a Santa pub crawl was going on). This restaurant on the corner can be visited for cocktails, appetizers or night out for dinner. The absinthe drinks were enjoyable to have. Great GREAT service. Lively scene. We ordered the Persimmons salad, French onion soup, Beef Tartare & raw oysters. Loved it all. The bread was delish as well. Would definitely come back and recommend it to all friends!!

nJtM4IIu8LKq-EJ5sZyrWg.review_text: Let's see.. Cute on the inside. Decent drinks. Could use more champagne on the list (by the glass anyways). We ordered an aged cheddar to start out with. Fantastic it was. The walnut bread was pretty awesome as well.  We ordered the cauliflower soup.. but it came about 30 minutes too late and by that time, I just wanted to get to the entree. Had to flag down a bus boy to find out what was going on with the soup and told the server we didn't want it. 5 minutes later it comes out and they practically try to force it on us. Talk about uncomfortable. Can't really fault the waitress since she was on her break, but her backup could have done something.  Oh, and no refill of water for the 30 minutes between the cheese plate and soup fiasco.. Good gosh.  The burger was.. not good. I don't understand how a burger is pink throughout and so horribly dry. I may as well add bland to that too. We also had the rib-eye. Pretty good in its own right though a tad over-sauced and a touch salty. At least it was cooked medium rare as ordered. Loved the potatoes and asparagus though.  The chocolate pot de creme was good. Better that it was free but it still couldn't right the previous wrongs.  Food 2.5. Service 1.5.

y_jl-bErj1mnb4KF04F74Q.review_text: Fabulous cocktails and cool bar, great service. A favorite for brunch.

axRg9Gsbq5-JznPkSGYlUQ.review_text: Pre-dinner, having reviewed and practically memorized the menu, I planned to go easy during the actual meal and order an entree (pancetta and herb stuffed chicken) and a glass of wine. I had one too many pastries and lattes that week and decided that I was going to be 'good.' Later that evening, sitting at the table with my foodie glutton crew at a restaurant whose very name has been tied to anything from a psychoactive drug to poison, that intention quickly went astray.   Soup: I wanted to order the french onion soup which everyone seems to love, but I couldn't resist the ginger scented squash puree. It was your typical squash soup with a twist. The spiced creme fraiche and the toast almond shavings were a nice touch !   Shared Plate: Green garlic flatbread.  With meal item contenders such as roasted bone marrow and escargot, this was probably one of the most mundane shared plate items that could be ordered. Instead, this item ended up being one of the highlights of the night. The fava leaves, ricotta (tastier and saltier than expected) and olive/lemon oil made this appetizer so delicious !  Entree: Grilled Hereford ribye (so much for the chicken). Cooked medium rare and served alongside vegetables and celery-root puree, this was very good. I also had a taste of the famous grilled scallops which were great. I also enjoyed tasting the pan-seared Char (like a cross between Salmon and Trout) which came at a surprise as it looked like a Salmon but tasted more buttery and delicious than any Salmon I've had. I liked the Char more than my ribeye.   Dessert:  I was bummed out that they did not have the pear sorbet (I love all things pear) that night but I got to try the chocolate-banana tart and the panna cotta. I would definitely recommend the choc-banana tart as it was heavenly. The panna cotta was just okay; upon my first bite, the lemon gelee and thyme were overbearing and it was just a burst of  unexpected sourness ....if you order this, make sure to really dig into the panna cotta.   Drink: Blain-Gagnard, Chassagne-Montrachet '04. Selected by my foodie friend Alexei S. who has since made me a lover of white burgundy! They have quite an extensive wine list here.  The service was excellent! Very helpful and attentive waitress.   Would definitely like to return for brunch or a late night snack !

2nWVcXlxdPogLzJoth4uaA.review_text: Have been here three times and have thoroughly enjoyed every time. The bar and wait staff are on it! The menu prepared by Chef Adam Keogh is nothing short of outstanding! If you're anywhere close to Haye's Valley stop by and enjoy, but have patience looking for a parking spot.

DFENl5W4GgwGshWSgP3vbA.review_text: I have very mixed feelings about this place.  In the afternoon or early evening a drink at the bar is great.  Good list of house cocktails and friendly bartenders.  In the evening, for dinner, I think it pretty much sucked.  I was really looking forward to the food since the menu looked so nice.  The frisee salad was mediocre.  This is a dish so many places are doing, that to stand out you have to really execute it well.  They did not.  The escargot were pretty good.  Honestly, it's hard to screw them up.  The pork confit was okay.  My husband liked it, but I wasn't thrilled.   The fries were tasty:)  Service was poor.  Still not sure who my server was.  Our first 10 min of being seated we were passed by on numerous occasions by servers and bussers alike.  I mean can I get some water, I'm parched over here.  I hear the burgers are great so here is my suggestion, go to the bar and order burger and fries with stellar drinks and friendly service.

fwxdqTwMTH8o4S_br3Jb3g.review_text: Had been previously for brunch, dinner was equally as good. Recommend the Arctic char and the coconut corn soup.

EXkO-gR8EjkFWRbebHtxSA.review_text: I could literally eat their soft garlic pretzels all day EVERY DAY. Imagine the butter and toppings that come on your typical garlic fries, except now they're smothered all over five mini pieces of warm pretzels, paired with a side of vermont cheddar mornay..a warm and gooey cheese sauce. For $8, Absinthe will be my go to for bar snacks and quality mixed drinks. Try the 21 Hayes, it's refreshing and goes down like water (dangerous?).   Rest of the Apps: - Meatballs- only ok, nothing too special--I'd skip them next time.  - Poke- nice, fresh flavors and I liked the crunch of the macadamia nuts too.  Entrees: - Duck with coffee crust,wild rice hash, parsnips, spinach, huckleberry jus- so moist, so tender! I honestly forgot about the coffee crust until writing this review, so clearly the coffee flavor was not very apparent. The duck skin was crispy and the sides were good, but nothing to write home about.  - Burger- didn't get to try the actual burger but my friend said it was awesome. You can add on a bunch of toppings (fried egg, caramelized onions, gruyere, etc.) and it came with a big side of fries (mm, carbs).   Dessert: - Meyer lemon tart- not very tart, and the basil meringue was an odd topping. I wasn't too much of a fan of the pairing, but the tart itself was good. - Winter squash cake- the cake itself was not very sweet, but the brown butter ice cream added just the right amount of flavor. I enjoyed it! - Vanilla cheesecake- actually went very well with pineapple. We couldn't taste a hint of the cilantro mentioned on the menu, but it was okay. To be honest, I'm not very much of a dessert person so I'd probably skip on the course the next time I come.  I'll be coming back just for those pretzels!! Well deserving of their 7x7 spot.

NlzeW5bsRfBOXSoJNvecmg.review_text: I love the atmosphere here - the bar, the warm and cozy lighting. A major plus is getting to try a rather large sampling of Absinthe. The food is pretty good as well. My friend and I came here for my birthday and had the Appetizers (french fries, Rabbit Meatballs - loved these by the way, and Fried Garbanzo beans), I had the ceasar salad (Loved it - was probably my favorite cause it was served traditionally - whole leaves of romaine with dressing and whole Parmesan) and the mushroom pot pie.  Our waiter was helpful, and while it was a little bit pricey, it was still worth it.

aD-rsDe2S0e7jTkYD6ULaQ.review_text: Decent restaurant bar spot that seems to be all about gin.   Highlights: - Wasn't party party 21ish crowd on a Friday night. Good place when you're in the grab a cocktail and just chat it up with friends mode. - More historically classic cocktail menu with drinks like sazeracs and sidecars. They even note dates of the original cocktails: ex. classic Absinthe cocktail from Famous New Orleans Drinks (1940), by Stanley Clisby Arthur - Bartenders are professional and old school as well - Ginger Rogers: like a mojito but with gin. I'm a bit scared of gin but asked the bartender to give me a gin starter drink and this is what he poured me. No overwhelming junipery taste so was ok with me. - Huge location: spanned a few big windows when we were passing by. The bar is only in one of those big rooms, but nice to have some space.  Lowlights (my flip side to highlights): - Menu has predominately gin drinks: If you're not a gin (or absinthe) person and you want a specialty drink, you may be hard pressed. I'm a vodka girl and asked for a drink with vodka and they said they didn't recommend it. ;-)  OK location to stop into if you're in the neighborhood.

_M_WlecbhiHG80opD0AEQA.review_text: Food was excellent! My wife ordered the Portobello Mushroom grilled cheese and I ordered the Ricotta French Toast. Both vegetarian, both delicious. My kids shared the bowl of fruit and the scrambed eggs. They enjoyed it. So, YES, this place is kid-friendly and the staff accomodated for them. Our server was friendly and accomodated some odd requests that they probably don't often get (ie: Non-glass cups for kids, Straws, etc).  Anyway, this place makes getting 5 star reviews look easy!

CYETSpkDwjCrcg_hHwtEYA.review_text: Fun place, nice ambience, good selection of absinthe, drinks in general, dessert and cheese. Pot de creme was delicious. Caramel panna cotta was good, but did not knock my socks off. We got a cheese plate and all were nicely paired with fruit compote. The bartender was very helpful and knowledgeable. Really liked his service.

Zj1KIhZSaZhCMVjux6ih4w.review_text: We went to a private lunch here and it was absolutely delicious, from the mimosas to start, to the dessert (the parfait, a must!) and coffee. Their fish was cooked perfectly, and the cauliflower puree to die for. Service was well staffed and with our group the dishes came out in a timely manner - I liked that we had our own bathroom, staff, coatroom, and entrance - the personalized menus added a nice touch for a memorable lunch.

pbFIcKknRHjLj1aKi6WAhg.review_text: Had dinner here and it was excellent! I tried absinthe (the drink) for the first time, and was surprised to find myself not seeing a fairy...?   The Onion soup was excellent as well as the duck entree. And of course, the dessert was delicious (I think we had the pot de creme).

K1mas1AjV3K2Dao2N6hKiA.review_text: The main reason I came here was to knock the garlic soft pretzel with vermont cheddar mornay (#36) off the big 100 eats list. I didn't have a reservation on a Saturday night but was able to grab a table in the bar area.   The pretzel was well over-priced, $8 for 5 small pieces. Don't get me wrong, it's good but I rather have a bigger pretzel from Auntie Annes or Wetzel Pretzel for less than half the price.  Another item on the menu that gets rave reviews is the french onion soup. Yea, it's good but not out of this world.  The wife ordered the shellfish stew. This had very good value because the prawn was huge and stacked with mussels and clams. It's kind of like a cioppino but no fish.   My dish was the burger with the fried egg. I order it medium rare and I guess it came out right but my main problem is that it wasn't hot and the patty didn't seem charred enough. Also, my fries were all stuck together in a ball.  Can I say OVER-YELPED.

7A9USrvW_ziStOB2W7bjaA.review_text: French bar or restaurant?  Whatever it is, I dislike.  Service was attentive, but the wine sommelier didn't know what we were looking for.  Some expert.  Ordered their Absinthe burger and was deeply disappointed.  Thought the name would live up to their restaurant and it is a brasserie, but I was so displeased.  Well, who orders a burger from a french joint anyways?  What are spicy onions?  Tasted like grilled onions to me.  Pan-seared Scallops?  Ew so disgusting.  Tasted fishy.  Was it not fresh?  I don't know.  Sunchoke puree was like watered down mashed potatoes.  Presentation was sloppy and disorganized.  Very loud in here, I had to yell at my date the entire time.  Close quarters dining provided no privacy at all.  If I wanted to, I could've placed my arms around some other guy's date and eat his coffee cake bites.  That's how close we were.  Over $80 for a burger, scallops, and a glass of wine.  Not worth spending here.  No sir.  2nd try?  No thanks.  Brasseries aren't my style.  On the other hand, thank you kind waitress for running out to the street to hand me my wallet +1 star for you :]

XZeFJAOFwmkw9rCeu-R4Gw.review_text: I liked the food for brunch on a Sunday. But the service felt rushed and the air in the back room was totally stale (like the back of a locker room with insufficient air flow). The stink kind of ruined the meal.

xqe8QcpRryKuK2wn5TZJYg.review_text: Chose this place for lunch for two reasons - Dine About Town and Jamie.  She rocks on Top Chef and she was cut way too early.  The food here was good but the service was a little slow.  I'm not sure if it was getting close to quittin time for the lunch staff or something, but I swear we were the only table on our side and our server barely approached our table.  I think we had to ask for him several times.  Now, on to the good stuff... the food.  Salad and french onion soup were good, though there's hardly a french onion soup that I don't like.  I had a tagliatelle dish with peas (which I raised my eyebrow to in suspicion but turned out good).  Mussels were nice with a heaping pile of frites on top.  Fresh sorbets were a perfect ending.  All in all, good french style food with fresh, seasonal ingredients as promised.

c7czxxeGJorF3w0nvCh7Og.review_text: decent cocktails, food is eh. Ambiance, average

cRZco0B0WNGpxhiUgUMRRQ.review_text: This has been one of favorite eateries in San Francisco for many years. It is always in my "must do" list when I visit the city.  The ambiance is perfect for a wonderfully romantic evening. Food is consistently high quality and the specialty drinks are a wonder to try.  I've tried pretty much everything on the menu and I would honestly recommend it all. No matter what you try, you are more than likely going to be happy with your choice.  I recommend reservations as the restaurant and bar always seem to be packed.

0gpFaPgAeR78Cxeo9gd4KQ.review_text: A  nice dinner but nothing I will need to revisit. The cocktails were interesting and refreshing. We shared a Perfect Pear, Absinthe Champagne and a drink perhaps called Hotel 78. I'm still a bit lightheaded from dinner and then a bottle of champagne after.  We wanted to try a few things so started with chickpeas and olives. Both tasty and went nicely with the cocktails. Then onion soup (fantastic) and gazpacho (fair). For dinner we shared the fish with current reduction and roasted vegetables. Actually bland. Except for the onion soup, we didn't enjoy anything enough to finish our plates.  I actually left the review when I got home last night and still feeling the effects of the drinks. Given some time to think about it it, without the drinking it was pretty mediocre.   I enjoy visiting Hayes Valley and it was a close walk to the symphony. So the location is perfect. The waitstaff was efficient and friendly. Maybe we ordered the wrong things or the menu needs an update. Pretty boring selection.  As far as the atmosphere, it was fine but again, nothing to rave about. So after my morning coffee and a clear reflection, I'd say this was it for me. Not wowed.  Finally, having dinner with my two childhood friends was wonderful and nothing horrible happened.

Yi56cVP8PUHcYj4axIOrlA.review_text: We dined at this wonderful restaurant (we've been there many times before) Absinthe Brasserie and Bar on Saturday night 10/4/2014 before the Opera. It was a very nice meal and had very good service throughout the meal. However, we ordered a bottle of white wine that tasted a sour to us. My husband and I are wine enthusiasts and since we have had the wine previously we knew what to expect. The bottle we received was not stored properly and since it had been an extremely hot week in San Francisco I'm sure it soured due to improper storage. Our server was very agreeable as we suggested  to try the wine herself. She removed the bottle of wine right away.  Within a few minutes the sommelier came to our table and proceeded to tell us in a very loud voice so the surrounding tables could hear that  the wine was O.K and that we probably did not know what we had ordered but that perhaps we needed to explain what we wanted and expected in a bottle of wine. We were very surprised at her reaction and felt her aggressive manner was misplaced. My husband said he had ordered the bottle before and that this particular bottle tasted sour. He then suggested giving us the wine menu and that we would order something else. She did promptly did just that. Towards the end of our meal our server said the wine glasses had not been washed properly and that that might have been the reason we tasted a sour taste. I don't pretend to know if that's the truth or not but we know the situation was not handled properly as one might expect at a fine dining establishment.  My suggestion to the restaurant is that I think it's rather silly to accuse your patrons of being ignorant on any topic. Rather apologize for the inconvenience and move forward. It's better than leaving a sour taste in anyone's mouth so to speak.

c1TZj4ycuImrQoXTNE948w.review_text: Came with a few coworkers to get some drinks before an event, and this place was packed. To get a table the wait was more than an hour. We stayed at the bar for about 30 min, ordered drinks and some apps.  It was ok but nothing to rave about. Maybe dinner here would be a lot better. But next time I rather make reservations

zsSgZzgN3oCE8RNLSHLVkw.review_text: Our meal here was delicious.  We started with the garlic pretzels.  I could not get enought of the cheese dipping sauce.  I ordered the duck breast for my main dish.  I was not sure if I had ever had duck breast so I was a little nervous about liking the dish but it came out excellent.  The presentation of the meal was also very visually appeasing. I thought the slaw on top of the duck breast added a nice texture when combining bites.  I took off one star for the bit of slow service we experienced.  The waiter came by the table next to ours a number of times after we were seated before stoping by ours to asked about our drink and/or appetizer order.  The food did come out at a good speed once we had placed our order

2e7h0LdZjyCLcpBa9UwBaw.review_text: We went on a Saturday night.  The bar in the front part of the restaurant was hopping.  We had dinner reservations and were shown our table in another room.  Nice room, quieter and easy to have a conversation during dinner.  We enjoyed warm chickpeas and also ordered one of their cheeses as appetizer.  for dinner I had their french onion soup (yummy) and also their pasta dish with vegetables (very tasty ...lots of variety).  We enjoyed their cashew nut chocolate mousse for dessert - it was stellar.  Drinks were good....  All in all a nice dinner out in San Francisco.

_0B_wpfO0FQa6b7c2CfN_A.review_text: Attentive and friendly staff! Warm atmosphere  Request to sit in the next room for a more intimate or quiet dining without having to yell over the bar noise.  Very inventive and delicious cocktails.  Good selection menu for all tastes.  I had the shared place of hawaiian hamachi - which was plate of buttery yellowtail with microgreens, mandarin oranges, watermelon radish with a ponzu sauce.  Delish!  My friends and I all ordered the 7oz steak which was cooked to perfection (and to order, 1 medium well, 1 medium rare, and 1 medium rare more on the rare side).

RFjRloxVppg9ITGMG7-SlQ.review_text: I have quickly been making my way through all of the best rated restaurants in the Bay Area.  When I friend was visiting from out of time, I thought taking her to Absinthe would be a lovely treat.   I knew it wasn't particularly veg friendly, but the vegetarian option looked too good, as well as some of the appetizers.    While the abidance is nice, it isn't knock your socks off.  It looks a little outdated to me and kind of oddly laid out.   We started with the garlic pretzel knots with the cheese dipping sauce.  Now, those were very delicious.  I know go there just to gnosh on those.  The vegetarian option as a "market vegetable platter."  Now, I REALLY REALLY love the creativity that went into this dish... it's just that the flavors weren't spot on.  It all just sort of blended together... nothing popped.   There was no acid, no salt... and it all had kind of a mushy consistence.  Was it good?  Absolutely.  Just a) not worth the price and b) I could totally make better at home.   Per Yelp recommendations, I had the chocolate pot de creme for dessert... which was luscious and yummy, but got a little bit too sweet by the end.  All in all, I probably wouldn't go back, especially not with all the better restaurants SF has to offer.

BwFEjsr9yLqdszAmAxFYQg.review_text: A friend and I stumbled in here at around 11pm on 11/17/10 after watching Madama Butterfly.. and I completely fell in LUST with the place. Absinthe offers a great intimate ambiance with lavish colors and cozy booths. Friendly helpful servers that accommodate your requests with an ever-present smile = cherry on top.  Now, on to the cocktails and food (off the limited bar menu since it was late): * GALAPAGOS         - [4/5 - Lubricious. I love citrusey cocktails, so my taste buds caressed this one with zeal.] * SAZERAC         - [3/5 - Comes highly recommended, but I'm not much of a whiskey person. My friend, however, loved it.] * SPICY FRIED CHICKPEAS         - [4/5 - Fun bar food! I was kind of hoping for chickpea french fries like the ones at One Market, but this was good to munch on while chatting over cocktails before the real food finally arrived.] * FRENCH ONION SOUP GRATINEE         - [4/5 - It's french onion soup.. not hard to fail this one - was good.] * SPICY RABBIT MEATBALLS         - [5/5 - Rabbit Meatballs, Rabbit Meatballs, Rabbit Meatballs. Who'da thunk those fluffy little furballs could produce such soft, juicy, succulent meatballs that tickled the senses.] * SKIRT STEAK FRITES         - [5/5 - After a series of rather bland/jaw-gnawing steaks at random other places, I was uncertain. Gotta admit, I'm not usually so thrilled to be wrong... but yes, yes I was. Delicious!] * TAHITIAN VANILLA CREME BRULEE         - [4/5 - Yum!]  Of course, we ended the night with two absinthes. I had a classic emerald green French, and my friend a brownish-toned Californian (I think?).   Had an excellent night! Definitely looking forward to going back to explore the dinner menu.  NOTE: I asked about the hot dogs mentioned in 7x7's list of things to try and they informed me that they have a new chef, so they're no longer on the menu.

wP_suL5hXCL6G8cG7fJVPw.review_text: Amazing food and service. Went on a Saturday night with a reservation and were seated promptly. The atmosphere is lovely - low warm lighting, rich deep hues, and upscale cozy.   We had the french onion soup (divine - better than Paris! ), beet salad (deeelish), french fries (crispy and perfect), coq au van (sublime) and osso buco (tender and flavorful). We also had an assortment of tasty and unique cocktails.   The food was truly fantastic, and the service made it that much better. Our server was kind enough to suggest the order of our courses and split the large french onion soup into two lovely, bubbling ramekins for my husband and I, as we planned to share. The evening went off without a hitch, each course and cocktail arriving at the perfect moment, and full water glasses all night. In addition, the server was there when you needed him, but in no way hovering. I can't recommend this place highly enough.

wG9d5TxOKKgbd8O08-kntA.review_text: 5/5: The French onion soup is superb.  Maybe the best broth I've had in a French Onion soup, and the browned cheese on top is great: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi… 5/5: The Perfect Pear cocktail is perfect: Vodka, Clear Creek pear brandy, lemon & orange juices, sugar. Very strong pear flavor, but perfect balance: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi… 4.5/5: The "crispy skin pork belly" lives up to its billing: it has a crunchy top "crust" layer: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi… It's the second best pork belly I've had (first would be Trokay in Truckee) 4/5: The soft garlic pretzels are over-hyped.  Fresh out of the deep fryer.  Good, but not as insanely good as 7x7 would have you believe: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi… 4/5: The 21 Hayes cocktail is a good mix of Gin and Pimms.  Dry gin, Pimm's No. 1, cucumber, lemon juice: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi… 3/5: Why is it that San Francisco just can't do impressive desserts? The Caramelized squash cake was OK, but it does not live up to its ingredients: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi… The full cocktail menu is missing from the website, so here it is: yelp.com/biz_photos/absi…

3t4quRiIPz_3r0zvsthfng.review_text: This place was great. I loved the vibe, the food was amazing. We had a group of girls who were celebrating a bachelorette party next to us and they were super nice.   The service was sub par. Our waitress seemed busy, which i understand. I was a waitress all throughout college, but she was a bit lackluster. Besides that, everything was perfect. I recommend the oysters, the cocktails (i don't remember which one) and the pork!

neX8bl1YBZkg7W6kRVhA5g.review_text: This is my neighborhood bar/restaurant, and I love it.  The food has always been good, drinks also, and the staff have always been attentive and prompt.  So far I have been here for drinks, dinner, and brunch.  Each time, I and whoever I come with have been happy with the experience.  I love the spicy chickpeas, and pretty much everything else on the menu makes me hungry just reading it.  And it's always delicious.  Many good memories here. :)

iOjwFYpHWo7P0rqmIfLm9g.review_text: I have been here quite a few times- for the food and often for the drinks...the drink menu is so big it is fun to play drink roulette with the menu...where ever that finger lands gets you a drink you probably never tried.   I have never been brave enough to come here and "Chase the Fairy"- no we are not talking about my Ladysitter- we are talking about the Absinthe....  A great little place in Hayes Valley.

Fz8PYtSTfdM2gIIHIzwCPQ.review_text: Dropped in pre-Nutcracker for a light snack.  Absinthe is always packed on weekends, and we weren't up for a 45 minute wait, so, spying a couple tables outdoors, and it being a mild evening, we decided to dine al fresco.  Caught a few fumes courtesy of the SUV running while parked in the valet spot out front, loading patrons.  Seriously, this is 2009 in SF.  Let's not sit in our SUVs spewing noxious fumes, k?  Ordered a couple Galapogos cocktails-$9 (top 100 item consisting of pisco, lime, and grapefruit juice), and were quite impressed. Vibrant, bright, yet deep flavor, with a sweet finish from the brandied cherries. I Ethan-ized the drink by muddling the cherries even further.  French onion soup gratinee was superb ($8.5 for lg), and the baby romaine salad ($11) was reminiscent of a Caesar with black peppercorn dressing, and anchovies.  Very creative touch adding fried cheese to this dish.  I used to make fried cheese growing up, and despite being such a simple thing, this is one of my favorite flavors--wonderful connotations and very evocative.  So the cheese really put it over the top.    Fries were...ok....served in a glass, and with tri-sauces: malt vinegar, dijon mustard, and rouille.  Sauces were good save for the rouille, which was bland, and needs to be replaced by a house-made ketchup.  Fries are also cut too small, tiny in some cases, making many of them more difficult to eat.    Service was adequate at best. We had a server who apparently found it difficult to crack a smile on that gorgeous Friday night, and went to great pains in explaining to us why the speciality hot dog would not be available until late that evening (it apparently takes up so much room in the kitchen preparing the dog, that it would just be too difficult to offer it for dinner).  Who knew hot dogs could be such trouble-makers!  All in all, a very good experience, and I will most definitely be back to try many of their intriguing dishes and cocktails, although I doubt I'll be getting the scallops (only 2 in the dish for $30).  Food: 4 (5 for drinks) Value: 3 Service: 3 Ambiance: 4.5

Xq-0cU_ipugXOubJ0ITkmg.review_text: What I ate: Pot de creme Visit date: April 11, 2012 First time? Yes.  This place is classy. I definitely want to come back for food and drinks; this visit was strictly for dessert! The pot de creme was smooth and sweet, but not too rich. It had a hazelnut/macadamia essence. This place has great service and the waiter made jokes -- he's ok by me!

XiVlH054UZ3A964ZIrBkPg.review_text: 1091 reviews and only one person has mentioned the strawberry gazpacho? Seriously?   I had scoured Absinthe's menu online prior to going and while I was undecided about my entree, I knew that the gazpacho would be mine. And it was magical: cool and sweet, with a nice crab and cucumber salad nestled on top to offset the flavors. I loved it. I dreamt about it. I am genuinely tempted to go back and get a larger portion of it in the next week.   My pork confit was equally as impressive. I had been waffling between the pork and the risotto entrees, but our server was great at the big sell: "Order the confit, and I guarantee you'll leave with a smile on your face."   I did. Imagine the most tender ribmeat that you've had, without the bone. It was the sort of pork that dissolves on the tongue, and it paired extremely well with the corn and fava bean garnish.   My roommate was comparably happy with her dishes. She declared her french onion soup the best she had ever had, and she had a bit of a dilemma with her entree. Upon seeing her large portion of chorizo and manchego stuffed chicken, she decided she would only eat half. Twenty minutes later, she joined me into Hall of Fame status of the Clean Plate club.   I was a bit surprised that the only (minor) misstep was the much-touted Galapagos cocktail. For all the hoopla surrounding it, we both found it to be much too sour and overpowering to be enjoyed with food. The Ginger Rogers made up for it, as it was refreshing and light and paired nicely with my gazpacho especially.   We came for our monthly girldate and we definitely were the minority among business dinners and slightly awkward romantic dates. I'm not overly concerned though, my date still came home with me. Suckers.

f2vy2XFVSLn60rVyuU0Aqg.review_text: Coq au vin gets 5 stars, but overall dining experience was LOUD, and I don't normally care about volume. If you are on a date, ask to sit in the main dining room instead of by the bar.

yW-GBoKnzyduaG86Y1NLzw.review_text: If I only came for the appetizers, it would have merited a 4.  Came with a couple of friends, and shared a few things. Best thing about eating with fellow foodies is...well, food. Duh.  We started with the Mac and Cheese, French Onion Soup, and Beef Tartare.  All of them were pretty good! Mac and Cheese was creamy with a bit of bread crumbs on top to give texture. French Onion was ok...we probably shouldn't have shared it. But it was gooood! Beef tartare I could eat a bowl of that.
