I'd probably die from something, but I'd eat a bowl.  Then came our main courses. Maybe I'm just not that great with French food (doubt it!), but it was overly salty and heavy. We had the duck confit, coq au vin, and steak. That steak is HUGE dude. No doubt. If you're hella hungry, fill up on that. The duck confit had very little duck, but a lot of pasta. Coq au vin was very well portioned, but the sauce was really, really salty.  If I were to come back, I think it'd be for appetizers at the bar and then go elsewhere. Not bad...just not great.

4lPsxyR8W73pbebQnFW-lw.review_text: I had initially given this place a 5 star review. But when I went in March 2012, I was shocked to find that the head chef was different and the dinner menu was completely different too. No more beef cheeks. The food was greasy and not sure if I'm willing to go back and try it out again.  My favorite in San Francisco. The soft pretzels are wonderful! The beef cheeks tender and tasty. The caviar definitely a splurge but worth it. The food is wonderful and so are the staff.

JO9CPEwBjV3UJuIOgs8Zzw.review_text: Pernod Absinthe - 135 proof.   Make sure to sit at the bar and have a nice chat with Eric the bartender. He was a really cool guy that was patient when we sat down. Here we were, 4 young college kids sitting at the bar of a really bougy restaurant...of course we didn't know that much about drinks! Though we were clueless about everything, Eric was really patient and really helped us in deciding what drinks to get. He clearly explained the subtle differences between scotches, absinthes and beers. Listed below are the drinks that I ordered:  *Pernod Absinthe - 68% from Paris *Duplais Absinthe - 68% from Switzerland *Chimay Draft Beer - 5oz.  The main reason why I suggested to come here was because 1). I wanted to try Absinthe and 2). I wanted to see Absinthe made by drip. "Drip" meaning that the bartender uses a tank of water with a small faucet attached at the bottom that allows water to be dripped on the sugar cube that is placed right above the poured Absinthe. The dissolved sugar from the dripping water makes the initial color of the Absinthe go from green to a cloudy green/yellow. I've got to say, I preferred the Pernod over the Duplais. The Duplais had a stronger herb and licorice taste than the Pernod. The Pernod was smoother, which is something that I prefer even if the flavor wasn't as strong.   Among the drinks that I ordered, I also got the Homemade Hot Dog which was one of 7x7 top 100 list. The hot dog wasn't that spectacular. I had it with a 5 oz. glass of chimay beer which is what they had on tap that night. The beer was a nice amber color with great body. I only wanted a taste, so I thought having a 5oz. option was perfect!  But anyway, whether you want to try Absinthe or just go to a nice place to grab a drink, definitely come here, sit at the bar and ask for Eric. He'll take care of you.   Eric alone would've gotten this place 5 stars from me - only a 4 because I didn't expect one serving of Absinthe would be $15-19!

dUl_mgWbnYhGHUDaklLUdg.review_text: Go for the cocktails.  Go.  For the cocktails. Especially if Raul is making them. I love their French 75; my lady loves the Wonderlust.  I once asked for a South Side which is neither standard nor on their menu, but is on the menu for sister saloon Comstock, and they did well by me there, too.  Their menu is extensive and diverse.  Everything is superbly mixed. Anyway, YES, the drinks are STRONG, but they don't taste strong, they taste DELICIOUS!  The food?  The food is also delicious, though I've mostly tried the starters/sides. -My favorite mac & cheese in the neighborhood -My favorite burger in the city -Addictive shoestring fries -Yummy pork meatballs and garlic pretzels -Chocolate pot de creme -BRUNCH!  Duck confit, all the way.  So - for brunch, lunch, dinner, or an afternoon pick-me-up, I'm always happy to go to Absinthe. Unless it's like a Friday or Saturday night, when they get rather crowded.  At least they are spacious enough that it's never painfully loud in there. Oh, also, it's beautiful.  You feel classy just to hang out there.

x0i6NgHySrXWgb17gVMTuQ.review_text: Lovely place, not too crowded for dinner after a certain hour (we had just gotten out of a show), as everyone hovered in front of the bar. It's not a myth that this place serves really good drinks, but on this particular day, I was famished and was in the mood for some delicious treats.  Their garlic soft pretzels were very delicious, but also massively greasy. They are more like pretzel bites, and you would want to pick them up with a fork. The crispy skin pork belly was like a thick-cut bacon, pairing perfectly with the apple-turnip purée. It's a dish that fatty pork lovers cannot miss.  They also had a special dungeness crab menu, and we ordered something off of that. Unfortunately I forgot to snap a picture and can't remember for the heck of me what it was; but it was delicious.  We didn't eat a whole lot of food, but what we had was good. The main plates, as we could see from other people's tables, are rather large-portioned, so we opted for a couple small plates to share. However, if you're a large eater, I don't think you need to worry about emptying your wallet here for food -- it would be the drinks that break your bank.

DDj0eXwlwIhhTYi9-yZ5Kg.review_text: We had a St. George absinthe drink for the first time. The drink is served like a concoction...you have to check out the website and look at the drink for yourself. It was an experience in intself...interesting and fun drink. We ordered a couple of appetizers and they were deeeelish! The spicy chick peas were unique, tasty and healthy. The drink selection is so long, you can spend an evening trying to figure out what to drink. The crowd was sophisticated, edgy and fun. We were lucky to have good seating at a small table in the bar area (not the dining area) where we faced everyone and got to do some people watching. Service is great too...knowledgable staff that knew their drink and food menu!! Highly recommended.

yL1y7s9oVnNAwi_vo8Ypcg.review_text: I happened upon this brasserie just after one of my fittings at Dark Garden.  This place is a Francophile's delight!    I tried the Absinthe burger (hey, it was lunchtime!) with smoked Gouda and heirloom tomatoes, with a side of the just crispy enough shoestring potatoes with a wonderful side of aioli.   Also had the French onion soup....best I have tasted outside of France, bar none!   It was just perfect!!    They also had the most AMAZING iced tea I have ever had;it tasted like blackberries!  Unfortunately, that tea was served in a glass that was MUCH too small!  My glass was never empty for more than 30 seconds, but the refills included way too much ice. It was the tea glass of diminishing returns,one might say!  Still have to give them 4 stars for impeccable service, great meal and prompt seating.  I will definitely be back, corset fitting or not!

hFvLaKDNHMxHze13Hd-FZQ.review_text: Do you LOVE delectable food and cocktails? Are you a foodie with money to burn? If so, then you'd probably enjoy a meal at Absinthe.   I've been on 2 first dates here, and both times I was very impressed. The menu has something for everyone, and bustling/busy feeling of the restaurant made me feel sorta special that he went out of the way of making a reservation.   My suggestion: start with some cocktails (21 Hayes for example), then do a wine pairing for dinner. We started with the hamachi crudo (amazingly sensual and seductive), and the Maine scallops (good, but a rip off). I thoroughly enjoyed my arctic char (topped with potato chips to seal in the moisture and add a crunchiness), and he had the t-bone (scarily big). We were totally stuffed.   YUM.   Don't forget to dress to impress.

RFrbO24rb2ynhznF11cPfA.review_text: My family and friends made it out here a few days ago. I have been wanting to try this place for about a year- I'm very glad I did.  We had a reservation for 8PM, but they seated us as soon as we arrived- which was 7:20! We got one of the best tables in the house- tucked away in a corner, right next to the window. It was so much quieter and intimate. One of the hosts was not very kind. I am a host myself, so I understand that sometimes other things are going on- but this woman did not speak a word to us. Whatever, I wasn't going to let that get to me!   We sit down and begin to inspect the myriad of dishes! We could NOT decide. Our server took about ten minutes to get to our table which is pretty bad for a restaurant, but it was fine since we were so indecisive. Also, I empathized since I saw she had an entire section to herself.  She finally made it to our table and she was pretty nice. We ordered so many damn starters. 1. Beef Tartare: 2 stars. I'm sorry, but this was probably one of the worst things I've ever had. Ever. 2. (Mexican) Ceviche: 5 stars- and this is coming from a Peruvian. This was DELICIOUS. Why so small?! the chips and guacamole were perfect as well. 3. Crispy Pork Belly: 4 stars. Once you get over the texture, you kind of die in the best way possible. 4. Olives: 5 stars. These were like.. the best olives ever. I don't know how. 5. I'm pretty sure I'm missing something. Drinks:  3 Pisco sours: 3.5 stars. A little too watery, but they were strong enough. We were pretty annoyed that the server failed to mention how they charge for the eggs they use to make this concontion.  G&T: So strong and good.  ENTREES/SIDES: 1. absinthe burger- I HAVE FOUND IT-- the BEST burger I have ever eaten. I'm not kidding. the patty was huge and fresh. I split this with a friend- a very good call, since we were on the verge of pregnant bellies by this point. 2. French onion soup: 4 stars. split this one too. so damn good. 3. Mac and Cheese:5 stars. You need to get this! the cheese combinations are spectacular. 4. Salmon: 4 stars.  5. Duck: 3.5 stars  Desserts were okay. I would pass. All in all, I'm glad I visited. we all left five pounds heavier and lighter in our wallets. I can't say I'll come back for more beyond the mac and cheese and the burger, but it was a fun and drunken experience.

zXh-6sb-Nc1l4WbMEKRFqQ.review_text: Love the dining experience here. Came here for brunch and LOVE their French Toast and drinks. Definitely coming back soon.

79wEtgRrV8GzDTp4PSDsqw.review_text: Absinthe definitely lived up to all the hype that I've heard about it and it wasn't even that pricey!  I got: Croque Monsieur with an egg - to die for Bloody Mary - lots of horseradish  All of the above were amazing, I definitely recommend it for any foodie lover!

gXSX-HK0KFDBKRCs5gfmPA.review_text: Came here for dine-about-town lunch with a few coworkers and got (1) Grilled Pork Tenderloin and (2) "Apple Pie" Panna Cotta. The food quality was solid. The tenderloin was cooked medium and the dessert wasn't too sweet.  The atmosphere is light, refreshing environment with lots of natural light during the day. I was seated immediately and both the hostess and waitress had great customer service skills.

swmrfBnaqU0nyJ3pFBfNgQ.review_text: There's an active bar scene here. They have 3 doors and the only one which allows you in is the one right on the corner.  Huge amt of cocktails and they're generous with the booze, not watered down.   We tried the Yellow Jacket on the chalkboard and it was citrusy with some absinthe.  Midway thru the drink, the ice cubes have diluted out the citrus flavor and you 're left with the licorice taste of the absinthe.  It was strong enough to make me and BFF's hubby (who's double my size) a bit dizzy. BFF's hubby tried the Perfect Pear & hubby had the French '75.  I didn't like either one.  The French bread was delicious with a nice crunchy crust.  Hubby asked for 2 more servings of it and needless to say, by the time our entrees arrived, he was stuffed as was I.   We tried: 1. French fries, $6.  Slivers of delicious skinny fries served with ketchup and a garlicky aioli (yum) 2. Poke $17.  A timbale shaped round of chopped poke with topped with orange roe.   3. Onion soup - a thick, gravy-like soup.  Lots of onions, not too salty.  BFF's hubby wanted more cheese & thought this soup at Cafe Jacqueline's was better.  Entrees: 1. Blk Angus rib eye $35. The meat was tender and very tasty.  The serving didn't look very big 'tho.  Came with vegts and whipped mashed potatoes which were 'OK". 2. Arctic Char $27.  Came topped with one thin layer of sliced potatoes. Cooked to perfection, very moist.  Served with leaves of Romaine, dressing.  I didn't like the olive sauce with it 'tho.  3. Duck breast $30.  Tender and tasty.    Desserts: Only the boys found room for dessert even if not all finished their entrees. Choc pot de creme $9.  The waitress told us it's their most popular and easy to see why. Milk choc flavor with a spoonful of creme on top.  I thought I was too full but managed to eat 1/2 of hubby's dessert.  It was that good! Panna Cotta $9 - pear flavored with crunchy stuff on top.  It reminded me of almond jello.  Preferred the pot de creme.  Our water glasses were constantly filled but staffed needs more training as the water person would reach across the table for our glasses when it would've been better to come from behind you.

nVwyhZ6f5F-rcK78A1ILtA.review_text: I am in love with this place!! The food is wonderful. The menu changes from time to time but I know it will always be tasty. The crowd is a little older and upscale but great place for a dinner date or ladies night out. The oyster shooters are so yummy!!  The steak is a must try!! Call in advance for a reservation

JG2-Z87cVoVQRiCaTtc7jw.review_text: Absinthe is a favorite spot for a couple of my friends. I wouldn't call it my favorite, but it's a solid go-to for several things:  - Date night - Late night - Drinks  I typically order off the bar menu when I'm here because I'm either too lazy to make dinner after a long, long day, or I'm ... at the bar. I've never had a problem getting a table for two at any time (late Friday night, after work, and on a Wednesday evening).   I highly recommend their martinis. Great flavor, and they use a great olive, which is key. I like 'em dirty, and they do it well. Also recommended: their Parmesan popcorn and their mussels with frites. DE-lish.

U0E1WmRNLa3_x7U91MczLA.review_text: Absinthe is delicious.  I was here last night for a post symphony snack.  We tried a few wines and a selection of cheeses.  This is a great place to have cocktails, a few real Absinthe drinks, dinner, or post show dessert.  The atmosphere is muted and sexy, a great place for a date.  It feels like a South American art Deco hot restaurant.  It is inspired by France, I believe, but the atmosphere is nothing like anything I have seen in France.  It is very ornate and beautiful compared to the quiet simplicity of Parisian restaurants.  The wine list is extensive and there is a great glass list, as well as a bottle list that is a book.  I've had superb oysters here.  I think the most unique thing is the cheese list which has its own page.  Each cheese is served with a fruit or nut pairing which is inspired.  Eating here is comfortable and sexy.

pypZb3V5TXHOnlTj-qLSrw.review_text: A "brasserie" is formally defined as "an unpretentious restaurant...that serves...simple or hearty food."  Hayes Valley's Absinthe fits the bill for the most part,  though I was left a little bit disappointed with certain parts of the meal.  The beef tartare was absolutely wonderful and the perfect way to start off.  Loved the texture, plus it was nicely chilled and the finely chopped green apples, red onions, and cornichons added a delicate crunch.  The seasoning was just enough, not too overwhelming.  Good plating too.  My wife had the Mediterranean Sea Bass and since we tend to make every dish "family style," I was able to try a fair amount.  The sea bass  was also wonderful.  Yep, I'm actually saying this, but the brussels sprouts were delightful (egad, I'm slowly learning to like brussels spouts).  I can't say enough about the sunchoke purée.  It was creamy, smooth, and sweet.  In short, totally awesome, the wipe your plate clean variety.  The sea bass, of course, was nicely done as well.  Crispy on the outside and soft and flaky inside.    Sadly, the Absinthe Burger fell well short of expectations, so much so that I contemplated downgrading my rating to three stars.  On the plus side, the burger was cooked perfectly.  Very few places actually get it when you ask for a "medium rare" burger.  Absinthe does.  My burger was perfectly bloody and juicy.  Also, the meat was loosely packed.  The softness reminds me of Marlowe's burger.  Unfortunately, thats where the comparison ends.  The meat itself lacked that meaty, "beefy" taste and aroma that I like.  I'm not sure if Absinthe's cows are grass fed, but I find grass fed cows to lack a certain element, so you have to add the right amount of seasoning to make up for the loss.  Unfortunately, the burger just did not have that "wow" factor.  The egg on top was pretty dry and uninspiring.  Actually, the meat had a prevalent "white vinegar" aftertaste that I didn't really care for.  As my better half explained after she had her share, "That vinegar taste, I think it's something people will either really like or really dislike, nothing in between."  I guess I just don't get it.  The Earl Grey Pavlova dessert brought me back in.  Very subtle flavors with the appropriate level of sweetness.  Nicely done.  Still, a very good meal overall.  Add to that good ambiance (a little bit too noisy) and good service, then that's a winner in my book.  Good to see that the relatively new Chef Keough used his Michael Mina background to maintain Absinthe's overall quality.  I'm aware of Absinthe's solid reputation for weekend brunch, so I will make it a point to come back for that at some point.

J33uckf092i8QGMFfJhWlQ.review_text: Good for brunch, bloody marys, cheese and oysters.  Obviously not all together at once... that sounds gross just having written it.  I had a killer dinner here in 2003 haven't come back much except for weekends or for drinks, partly because it's pretty pricey.  Great place to go with friends/family after you get married at city hall - lots of room.

sq8kwwTs9RaiYjfh97ljeQ.review_text: I love this place!! I had my birthday dinner here and their French onion soups are to die for...  And their drinks!! List full of amazing drinks x) if u don't have any reservation, just stand by...it's worth the wait!

1i4UHcmnbCgOeBWj4FdZjQ.review_text: Hostess was a little snotty.... but hot.   Otherwise gerat brunch place! Had the sangria and pork belly... awesomoooo! would definitely come back for dinner next time.

010pekBIqnWFg-wnN0W2HQ.review_text: Absinthe is still my first thought when a classy special occasion is being planned. I had my 40th birthday dinner here and also chose it for friends who flew into town just to elope here, for their celebration lunch. The staff here is top notch and the food is solid- classic and delicious. I also come here now and then to meet friends at the bar for cocktails. I've never been disappointed, always treated like a VIP.

IuU1TM_rTx2Z_UCn7qR6kw.review_text: One of my favorite places in San Francisco by far. The cocktails are truly spectacular and definitely not disappointing in strength. It is pricey but worth every dollar. I have not sampled much of their entree list but their appetizers like the homemade pretzel bites are delicious.

zyJcQykmwmjx1YrNQHb8dA.review_text: I went to Absinthe with a few friends before an opera, we had to sit in the bar section as we didn't make dinner reservation, happy to see a Top Chef Master there hiding in the corner, thinking how bad can this place be? it wasn't a disappointment, everything was delicious! I love the soft garlic pretzels, the croque Monsieur was awesome, we had so many little dishes, these 2 were my favorite, I can't wait to go back & try more things!

Dn2gtoQnMgf261kIXpjLvA.review_text: came here the other night for a glass of wine and had a great time...  wine list was good.  food was good as well.  ordered up the spicy pork meatballs and the beef tartare. both were excellent. 5 or 6 pork meatballs served up all hot and bathing in a salty tomato sauce...perfectly cooked and super tender...loved these and could easily have ate 2 orders (although there was a couple small pieces of foil in them...not a biggie as i finished them and ate AROUND the foil because they were so good...not to mention that the waiter took them off the bill as well)  the beef tartare was one of the better ones that ive had around...ive always been a huge fan of the tartare at Oola, but Absinthe definitely gives them a good run for their money...roughly chopped pieces of raw steak and packed full of plenty of capers for that salty, pickled goodness along with whatever else they seasoned it with...all topped off with a quail egg yolk...great flavors going on there.  although those were the only 2 dishes i had there, the other dishes on the menu all looked pretty solid and the prices were pretty reasonable as well...will definitely coming back for the same dishes and then some the next time around.

TZlbqylhw1wTBmSB0TP_sQ.review_text: This is one of my very favorite restaurants in San Francisco!  I've celebrated many birthdays and other special occasions here. It's one of my fav spots to have lunch alone.  Absinthe somehow manages to consistently be great for either casual or upscale dining experiences.  The food is always outstanding and the service as well as the overall vibe are cozy warm and friendly.  Eat here, you won't regret it!

rq3S_5Yg0E8ur0xWyZBczw.review_text: Yum. I have to say the rosemary potatoes here were amazing. They were buttery, crispy on the outside, with a hint of rosemary that was not overpowering. I loved them. Had the carmelized onion and mushroom omelet, the cheese was great and creamy and the mushroom and onion mix was a perfect compliment to the fluffy egg. I usually don't review a place until I have eaten there twice or have more than one dish to review, but it was pretty dang good. Would love to try more dishes, maybe for dinner?  Yummilicious Factor = A

49n0zAbDjKJ5sqxvKnAbqQ.review_text: What a beautiful day it was in Hayes Valley! Can't say the same in terms of weather where I live; it was foggy and full of gloom.  Had brunch with my cousin, and made a reservation for Absinthe.  Once you walk in, it felt like being in France; really upscale, clean, ambiance was wonderful, and it smelled amazing! We were seated against velvety red seats, and along the walls is a mural of people eating and having a good time in a restaurant (i assume it would be a restaurant in France).   Our waiter was the only waiter that was servicing our area (towards the back eastern side of the restaurant), and didn't really have happiness in his smile, but was overall very courteous and attended to our needs.   I begun with a champagne cocktail, Bucks Fizz (orange and strawberry juice with champagne). I tasted more of the orange, citrus, and yes CHAMPAGNE! Looking at the menu, everything sounded delicious - my cousin viewed the pictures on YELP to help decide on what to get.   We ordered the Stuffed Marscapone French Toast to share, separated in three stuffed wedges; it was divine - it was not overly sweet, cinnamon made it somewhat like apple pie, the sliced almonds added a crunch, though - I did not really taste the marscapone come through, and it felt like bread pudding after a while as it sat. Overall, a really delicious dish. I ordered the Duck Confit Ragout (poached eggs on top of a bed of potato cakes with duck breast and toast on the side - somewhat like eggs Benedict); there wasn't that much duck breast, I sliced a piece for my cousin and she noticed how little duck there was - overall a really tasty dish. My cousin ordered the Crab Omelet (omelet stuffed with shredded crab, with fried potato cakes that were really crispy and toast on the side); it was very filling, but did not have enough crab meat.   Though there were minor flaws in the food that I ordered, taste and service was exceptional. Will I revisit Absinthe? Of course!

jipgimnSNp3qdK2dKUQvBg.review_text: Some things are really worth the wait..the first kiss with a new love, the perfect proposal... I know that a meal may not compare to those two awesome things, but I do believe that Absinthe was worth the wait!  I have been wanting to go for forever, and finally go the chance to on Wednesday night.  I have to admit, though a handful of friends have been way before me and liked it, I thought that it may have lost its touch as other players have come onto the scene since Absinthe's presence years ago.  But boy was I wrong!  We both went with cocktails which were perfectly made.  I loved my Citron Vokda Lemonade, so refreshing with a hint of ginger (like a fresh ginger ale).  We were little piggies with our starters and ordered the Soft Garlic Pretzels & Spicy Pork Meatballs.  The garlic pretzels were my fave!  I'm normally not a pretzel girl but these were like little pillows, not salty at all and just the right amount of garlic and butter.  The mornay sauce wasn't rich either.  The meatballs were moist and delightful but weren't spicy.  I liked how they provided crostinis as well.  I was starting to get a little full, but had to attack my 10 oz. Ribeye as much as I could.  I requested medium rare, but got more medium.  It was still grilled well and juicy for medium.  I usually get filet mignon but god did I miss the fat flavor from ribeyes!  The potato puree, creminis, roasted romano beans and bordelaise sauce was a great compliment, but I think I would have preferred a different veggie to the beans, but still wonderfully done.  He go the Braised Wagyu which was packed with fatty flavor and the braised taste of course.  It was fork tender, but for me, I preferred the grilled ribeye.  So I had to give him a lot of my steak, but no birthday would be complete without dessert, right?  So, we mustered up some courage and gained some stomach room to try the Buttermilk Panna Cotta.  It's not like a traditional one, as it's parfait style with roasted strawberries, basil meringue and strawberry crumb, but it was amazing!  I never thought about basil in dessert, and it worked so well.  Loved the light parfait twist on this.  So it was an amazing dinner...so much so...that we made reservations for that Sunday for brunch as well!  Same great service and we actually sat at the table next to the one from Wednesday night..a corner side by side booth-ish seat..loved it! It was a hard choice to choose what to get, as all the dishes sounded amazing.  He got the Absinthe Burger and I got the Duck Confit Eggs Ragout.  No garlic pretzels as a brunch app tho..aww man!  The Duck Confit needed to be cooked longer as it was a teeny bit tough, but it was still very good.  Loved the potato chive cake the duck and eggs were placed upon.  And the eggs, perfectly poached!  Loved the wild mushrooms and the light bernaise sauce.  His Absinthe Burger was cooked well..with an egg as well (no need for cheese then).  It was so juicy and flavorful.  Nice little frites to go with it as well.    The indulgent week has ended, so a little more dieting now.  But I had two amazing meals at Absinthe and can't wait to go back.

1WfaAbWC06QDnb59vqnEZw.review_text: I have a love-hate relationship with dinner dates. They are a terrible choice for first dates. Frankly, it's uncomfortable to sit across a table from someone and have forced conversation and awkward pauses.  However, if I've been seeing someone a while, I think a dinner date lends itself to creating a shared, intimate experience. If that's what you're after, then Absinthe is a good choice. The ambiance is sophisticated but laid back, with enough chatter to know you're in a popular, busy restaurant.  We were originally seated at a standard table for two, but I kept eying the semi-circle booths that seem perfectly designed for couples. It's just like me to really want something I can't have, so as soon as I saw a couple leave, I asked the server if it was okay to switch tables. He obliged; I tipped him well later.   As for the food, well, it's like being on an episode of Top Chef. My scorecard would note the fancy presentation and give extra points to the Manchego and Chorizo-stuffed Mary's Chicken. It comes with these shelling beans on the bottom. I have no idea what those are, but they taste great and have less filling.

dpEtyfB2o7MH1Mc_Ygoolg.review_text: I came here for the first time tonight inspired to try the $12 house made hot dog on the menu. A blend of American Kobe beef, pork shoulder and Benton's bacon, it melted in my mouth. The bun is brioche with ketchup, Guinness mustard and sauerkraut. The bun and all the condiments are also house made.  It's hard to put a value on great food but it was definitely the best hot dog I've ever had and I was not disappointed. I could see myself bumping Absinthe up to five stars if my future experiences are as good as the first one was.

oHxAydGnUxwd1BlFr51f4Q.review_text: I've been here a few times, because it turns out that its a great place to meet up with friends after work. ("Where should we meet?" "Absinthe?") It's also the home of Jamie, one of the chef's from Top Chef - which is kinda fun. (BTW, Absinthe:  I  love the policy of being able to put in my name, then give you my cell number and have you call me when you are 5m away from seating. It's a simple idea, easy to execute, and I've never seen another restaurant do this... )  I've never had the wine here, strangely enough for me, so I can't comment on the cellar or the stock - but I have had quite a few cocktails at this place. (Alright, shush!) The Manhattan's were perfectly executed, just the right amount of bourbon, and my barometer (BAR-o-meter, get it? haha....oh, never mind), the dirty martini, was as good as I would make myself...tremendous way to end a work week.  Food was, as expected, brilliant. For a starter, the deconstructed oyster shooter was flavorful and fun, and every entree I've had there so far has been grilled, baked or tossed to near perfection. The wait staff is fun and friendly, and (as I found out the other week) can take a joke, so that's key.   The atmosphere was fun - but a little too fun, which is why I subtracted some points. The place is tiled and paneled, and the end result is an echo chamber - even a moderate crowd makes the place disturbingly loud and noisy, and on a Friday and Saturday night you may as well break out those noise canceling headsets. I never complain about s**t like this, btw, but it's really over-the-top here.

1Zg07UoTLTHbOfvdH__UDQ.review_text: This is what a restaurant is meant to be.  All the staff members were superb.  The food was painstakingly sourced art.   I went with the most difficult to please crowd that I know, and they were all impressed.  Not only that it is a swanky trendy popular well dressed place.  Made for a delightful night.

DsnXCbkyEha6cJp2JqpflA.review_text: My cheese-head girlfriend loved the cheese platter here. A bit too noisy due to the bar, but that was to be expected. The duck was alright, with the best part being the toasted outside. Overall, this place should be visited for the cheese alone, dinner is ok.

6E8D63dCyWNcZIacMe1rcQ.review_text: I'm a big fan of brunch and I was really happy with my experience here.  Went for an early Sunday brunch and luckily there wasn't a wait.  I had the ricotta stuffed french toast, which had almonds and berry preserves served with it along with some kind of cream.  I liked it, although i wish they would have put a little bit of cream cheese mixed with the ricotta as the filling.    My favorite highlight was the brunch potatoes, omg, loved them!! One of my friends got them as a side, so tasty, crispy on the outside with just a hint of salt, and perfectly cooked on the inside.   Would come back for brunch!

f0ZeT8901onMYPQRdSWuUg.review_text: It is a very special restaurant to me. One of the fanciest that I have been to. But that is not the reason why it is special-- not that all of you have to read this... Lol.  But the first time I went there, I ordered their burger. It is no regular burger-- I guess when you are here, nothing feels regular or it is marked with regular price--if you know what I mean. It is outstanding!! The meat is grilled just right--juicy but easy to bite into. The fries are so cute: cut into small pieces--smaller than any fries I have seen. But it is not like hash browns if that is what you are thinking about right now.  The second time I went there for celebrating my graduation! See? Special!! We ordered a lot this time: including the burger:)) haha! I like their platings-- not pretentious but still with taste. I will post some photos because it's been half a year since the meal, i don't remember all the names of the dishes we had.   I would definitely recommend this place for dating, celebrations of some sorts with a small-ish group of people, or just self-indulging dinner:)

TNo1aPj4p9mXkHBR0uHfEg.review_text: Old world charm and ambiance in SF...Great food...deliciously mixed cocktails and a nice wine list...I always forget how good Absinthe is for any occasion, any day of the week!

PEp5ytDnZ34r4KQuab-aog.review_text: Ate at the bar... friendly atmosphere and all that, but I'm here for the home made hot dog.  ::HOT DOG:: Decent. Some good flavors, special made mustard, kraut, and bun.  The sausage wasn't juicy though... :*(  Comes with chips that taste a bit chalky.   ::FRENCH ONION SOUP:: Dinky but decent.  If it was filled to the top and going over the edge with the bread and cheese, it would hit the mark.  ::SMOKED STURGEON:: Uhh... well... it tastes good, and is billed as "hearty" and "meaty"... but what you get is four of the thinnest, tiniest, slices off fish you ever didn't want to be served.  OVERALL Maybe better to stick to the main menu.  Nice place, overpriced, decent food, friendly bar area.

bxr54WBqDH_xsGs3GtKHeQ.review_text: An excellent Hayes destination prior to the Symphony.  Made a reservation at 5:15 on OpenTable to make the pre-symphony presentation at 7.  We were immediately seated near the windows, no waiting. The dining room was quiet enough for conversation. Service was exceptional, both from our waitress Ting and from the rest of the staff.  At this early hour clientele was primarily older symphony goers.  A treat was one of the many absinthe cocktails before wine by the glass.  Shared the Roast Beet and Burrata Salad, the Pan-Roasted Monkfish, a side of Grilled Asparagus and the German Chocolate Cake. Food was tasty and presented attractively.

A28JSW8X2efZxfgiC6w_HQ.review_text: Nuffin special. Solid restaurant with some nice absinthes and a medium romantic if somewhat tacky vibe.

Z9z36JyDri-P4oR9eyd4LA.review_text: Very good Coq au Vin, fun atmosphere. Service was great, we were late because of a flight delay (after10:00) but they let us order from the dinning room menu. Awesome spot in Hayes Valley.

dB11NQfvGM-cv-05YV_SGQ.review_text: Friend and I planned to have lunch at Absinthe for a pre-symphony lunch.  We called two days ahead but there were no reservations during the lunch hour.  We took our chances and decided to see if we could walk in.  No tables were available around noon but two seats opened up at the bar after a little wait.  This place gets really busy!  I noticed a steady stream of patrons the entire lunch service.  If you're set on eating here, make sure you have a ressie or plan on enjoying a drink at the bar while you wait.     The brunch menu looked slightly pedestrian aside from a few selections.  Naturally, friend and I both chose the entree that sounded the least ordinary: Duck-confit ragout with wild mushrooms, chive-potato cake, poached eggs, béarnaise sauce ($15.50).  I'd highly recommend this dish as it was a unique take on eggs benedict.  Both friend and I really enjoyed it.  The eggs were poached perfectly.  Duck confit ragout delicious as was the potato cake.  It was rich and filling.  Two slices of levain toast completed the dish and we requested a jam for it.  The strawberry preserves tasted homemade.   Service at the bar was spot on.  Hostess was also very hospitable.  Ambiance was lively and interior provided cozy vibe.  Ladies room was well kept.  Can be hip but also family friendly.  Great choice for a meal if you're in the performing arts area!  Would return again and try dinner next time.

Te1qFrUAzF4hy57I_hf-Ag.review_text: Let me say to start that their bar Rocks, fantabulous selection as well as bar tenders.  I'd never had a sit-down meal before at Absinthe and was pretty excited to finally get there boyfriend in tow, on a Thursday evening, with reservations.  We began our meal with a waiter who seemed fabulous, unfortunately it was time for him to take his lunch and we were stuck with another.. Service, for me, is a Huge part of any dining experience, literally, McDonald's or Fleur de Lys, could be ruined or championed by their service. I dont like any dining experience (aside from the longish Coursey McCorseyson snooty ones) to take more than 2 hours.  As for the Foodstuffs;  For our starters I got the French Onion Soup and it was the *best* I've ever had.. my boyfriend had the chilled corn puree which was very nice.   For our mains we had the pork confit and stuffed baked chicken.. both we fairly.. fair.   After our mains were finally cleared, we didn't have the patience to wait another half hour to an hour for desert, which I've heard, is quite good.  I may have built the place up too much before getting there.. I will go again for their bar, and will have to give it another go for brunch, but the dinner service for me is out.  Sadly.. "Meh".

9qyLpg3JTVUZXS4XrQgZkQ.review_text: In a nutshell:  Food: 4 stars Service: 4 stars P/C: 4 stars  Let me just say, my SF symphony experiences would have been dull if Absinthe were not there to satisfy my hunger, quench my thirst, and just overall need to relax at a joint that is hip, casual yet with such history.  My dining experiences have been different - in terms of occasion, ambiance, and the dishes themselves - but there were all good, I've never been disappointed with this joint.  It's reliable, cozy and always satisfy my needs - whether it be just to catch a drink, go for a mimosa/brunch, or sit down for a good bistro-type meal.  Higlights:  1. I really love their bubbles and french wine (especially the Rhones) selection - seems pretty appropriate for a french-style bistro. 2. The absinthe burger - always fresh and hearty - make sure you had the fries to go with. 3. When it comes to the onion soup, Absinthe's onion soup is in the leading pack.  To me, it combines all of the tastes that I look for in onion soups - silky and sweet with a bit of nuttiness and tang. 4. I know that 7X7 raved about the Galapagos, but my real favorite is the sazerac.  I think that Absinthe does a better job than the Alembic... 5. The bar area - you just meet a lot of crazily interesting people there, including Eric the bartender himself. 6.  Attentive staff - they are so efficient and have deep knowledge on food and all the drinks that they serve.  Absinthe is a true institution in the Hayes Valley area.  It's a shame that I can't go as often as I want to (anybody has a vacancy that I can rent near Hayes Valley?)

-GDdBOfhrxn7lAGblLSoqA.review_text: We decided to have a late meal after a concert at Davies recently.  We all opted for small plates, appetizers, and salads.  My husband had the country pate and said it was excellent.  Our friend ordered French onion soup minus the cheese and remarked that it had a great flavor.  I opted for the Lyonnaise salad which consisted of greens, fried pancetta strips, and a fried egg on top.  It was really good and was perfect for a late night meal.  The only complaint I have about this restaurant is the noise level but then I guess that's sometimes a good thing because it shows that people are having a good time and enjoying the food.  People next to us cleaned their plates if that's any sign!

zRKXivafaD2qhKigwGBotg.review_text: A classy, and more importantly delicious brunch place in the Hayes valley. I heart! My hubby and I did a pre-valentines day sunday brunch here, making reservations through opentable.   Between the two of us, we had: - cocoa butter pancakes with carmelized bananas- we were torn between the french toast and this, and the hubby wanted pcakes so i gave in. Normally i am not a huge fan of pancakes but we ate the whole thing! the pcakes were really light n fluffly and with 3 pcakes on a plate this was really filling. the carmelized bananas were delicious, although i could have used a few more (they only give you a few thin slices) and the cocoa butter on top made it slightly sweet. A drizzle of their syrup and you are good to go! -virgin bloody mary- really good, I can tell they use clam juice. Part spicy and salty, one of the better ones ive had- garnished with my favorite, green olives and picked mini pearl onion -french onion soup- really good, nice n hot- we were both fighting for this! -duck confit over poached eggs- really delicious, although the hubby complained it wasnt hot enough. the duck confit wasnt salty and paired really well with the crispy potato pancake beneath it and the richness of the runny poached eggs.  Overall, done very well, service was prompt and friendly, I think ambiance and food even better than zazie for almost the same items, I will come again!

JA7CPc8BTrEMES9GCc90dQ.review_text: Back to Back five star reviews, am I losing my mind!!?  Had to give Absinthe the five stars just based on the menu, consistency and staff.  We always seem to end up at Absinthe for one celebration or another and they have never let us down!  New Years brunch was killer, oysters, meatballs, little gem salad, dungeoness crab omelet and the burger.  Plus a few cocktails of course.  I love it here because theres something on the menu for everyone, great cocktail service and its good for out of towners or locals.  Thank you Absinthe for continuing to be a great go to place.  Also the food has much more soul than when it was cooked by the former top chef chick...

Da62XGMfcBmeFzYxqfM2OA.review_text: Went here tonight for dinner thanks to a friend.  I suppose it's a little easier to feel good about this place since I didn't pay for dinner.  Nonetheless, on to the review.  Got here very early, surprisingly, well before our reservation time.  Place was packed, so we waited for some time to be seated.  But we were seated before our 7:15 reservation, so no problem.  Service was generally very good and quick enough.  Prices were in line with what I guess you would call a somewhat finer dining experience.  Started out with the hamachi crudo.  Fish seemed very fresh, and the vinaigrette on top brightened it up nicely, with the greens on top giving a nice crunchy contrast to the tender fish.  And then onto the liberty duck breast for the entree.  It was a coffee crusted duck breast cooked to a very nice and even medium rare.  Accompaniments were the apple-turnip puree, duck jus, sage and miscellaneous veggies.  This duck breast was fantastic.  Cooked just right, if you hadn't told me it was duck, I might've thought it was a well cooked piece of beef or lamb.  Very tender and juicy.  Puree was good, if maybe there wasn't enough of it.  Veggies were standard, I guess, but good.  All in all, a nice experience.  It can be a little loud for taking a potential date, but it's not terrible.  Will definitely return at some point.

B5fZxBSecRRJEUZJds6P6Q.review_text: + Polenta was amazing and paired well with pork belly + Croque Monsieur was tasty as well ~ French toast was pretty good, stuffed with marscapone but a little too rich for me - Ginger mojito cocktail thing I ordered was interesting at first then just turned into sourish water

m3f1x02-81PfN-3LnIzOlg.review_text: Just came back from dinner a couple hours ago...but already miss the beef cheek...it just melts in your mouth with no hesitation.   The frisee salad was seriously amazing. I've never thought that frisee would make a good salad by itself, but wow, the runny yolk makes a fantastic salad dressing, and the house bacon goes so well with the whole salad.  The pan seared arctic char is just perfectly prepared and delicious. The skin is crispy, the meat so tender.   The dessert was kinda weird I must say....the mission fig crostata with fennel icecream. First of all, figs are out of season, not juicy and sweet anymore, so this dish is not successful because the figs are not great. The pastry shell was nice, but the whole pastry lacks of flavor. The fennel icecream was new to me, very interesting, my indian friend loved it.  If you like girl, sweet kind of cocktails, Citron lemonade is probably the only option you have here. All other cocktails are pretty strong, both in alcohol content and spicy flavors. Somehow most of them have some extra kick. So people either love them or hate them. Citron lemonade is the safe way to go.  Our waiter...he needs to sober up. The dude was weird from the beginning to the end.

7igYjtQ2kI166vtqCBRnhA.review_text: Overall drinks were good if a little on the "lite" side - I think I ordered ones that were too refreshing & not boozy enough!..they have a range of cocktails & their mixologists/bartenders know their stuff. Range b/w $10-11 for the ones I drank!  Soft garlic pretzels w/ Vermont cheddar mornay ($7) are amazing! A total of 5 delicious, 2-bite sized pretzels with a golden crust & fluffy, chewy inside. They're topped with flakes of garlic & sea salt. Scrumptious eaten by themselves, oh-so-delicious when dipped in the cheddar sauce. Pure Vermont cheese melted to a rich, thick, creamy consistency that holds up to the pretzel very well. The cheese has its own flavor and I could have eaten what was left in the ramekin with a spoon but I didn't want to scare everyone at the bar!  The small portion of Dungeness crab was good - lots of meat & enough for a friend & me to share. 2 types of butter - 1 completely melted & 1 soft.   I saw quite a few menu items I'd go back to try, but I'll always get those garlic soft pretzels! (thanks SF Chronicle EAT list for turning me on to these!)

1DHYtixjnvWw9C4OU8ba9Q.review_text: My boyfriend's brother and sister-in-law gave us a gift card to Absinthe for Christmas and we were more than thrilled to have the opportunity to take a one night vacation from our broke-ness to enjoy expensive dinner and drinks. We arrived a little early and had drinks at the bar which was pleasant and then we were escorted to our table promptly. We ordered the roasted chickpeas as an appetizer which are a MUST. For dinner I ordered the Coq Au Vin which was perfectly cooked and the sauce was wonderfully rich. My boyfriend ordered the Duck Breast and Mac and Cheese on the side and he could not stop raving about both. The service was pretty good but nothing over the top and the atmosphere is quaint and not too loud  (the restaurant was only 3/4 full though) but basically the best part of the experience was the excellent food. Definitely recommend.

-Om96MJFxBwYDQ7RoEP6-g.review_text: Skip everything else and get the French Onion soup. Indescribable!

p7PoKtHEQ0AeFxumvS8OMw.review_text: I was there for Brunch had the smoked salmon and trout app.. very tasty and came with a cucmber,fennel citrus salad. The place is always busy but its a must dine place in Sf !! I had the Duck confit with eggs and paotato cakes.A perfect choice eggs were cooked to perfection and the duck confit was great as well. The service was very good !!

W46UkrAvPokkWfXno1cD6g.review_text: My luck must be changing for the better since my last review, because the last 2 times I have been to Absinthe, not only has there been a table (or spot at the bar) available, but the ideal table has been available! I think all the hostesses read what I wrote last year and are on a mission to make my life better.   That being said, on top of what I wrote last year, I've had more opportunity to try a variety of drinks from the cocktail menu, and have been impressed each time. Any establishment that makes up original cocktail creations and has numerous items that satisfy my every cocktail need and desire is a place I'm going to enjoy. It's also a place I should probably avoid on weeknights. In any case, the bar is stunning, and this is a perfect spot to get fancy, delicious drink with a friend, which is the primary reason for giving it the additional star.   I also was very impressed by their cheese selection. Cheese is kind of my thing. For the last 4 years I've carried a cheese list with me in my wallet at all times so that if I ever try a great new cheese, I can write it down. When I saw 2 of my top 4 favorite cheeses on the list at Absinthe (epoisses and la tur), I'm pretty sure I squealed. Loudly. Not only was the cheese delicious, but it was served with plenty of great bread and nuts so you actually felt satisfied by the end of it.   Again, my only complaint is the price. Great atmosphere and good food is certainly worth paying for, but c'mon absinthe, $16 for asparagus and burrata? Well, I guess if you have enough cocktails, you stop caring as much.

RftkjKDgQHJXlQdXCOcD4w.review_text: I was really impressed by the taste of their food. This is definitely a place I would recommend to friends. The price range for entrees are reasonable (b/w $20-30 per dish). I tried two of their entrees:  1. Grilled Steak Frites(mixed green salad, green peppercorn jus) 2. Roasted Mary's Chicken Breast (mascarpone polenta,rainbow chard, whild mushrooms, sweet onion jus).   My favorite is the Grilled Steak Frites. The marination of the meat blended so well the peppercorn sauce. They work together so well that stimulates your taste buds, at the same time, the meat was tender and juicy.   If I have to say one bad thing about this place is probabily gonna be its location. Parking is definitely a concern. So plan accordingly.  Besides that, I am looking forward to going back and try more food from the menu.

dVHL4K-c50SgSDkawlZeVw.review_text: I really wanted to love this place...especially since my hubbie and I came for an anniversary.  The food was good, but I don't know that it would be enough to entice me over all the other similarly-priced restaurants.  What we had: - best french onion soup! not too salty, very oniony - white asparagus soup was good - mild asparagus flavor in a creamy soup - country pate was good, but really not that spectacular - had better from Market Hall's deli - duck breast - tasty with the perfect amount of crisp and fat on the skin, halved instead of sliced - meaty and delicious! - sea bass - nicely cooked with skin-on, nice crisp on the skin - my favorite part of the dish was the sunchoke puree

lQ86cFpq8EnK_C81c8COXw.review_text: Excellent service!  We came here for a pre-theatre dinner and was running late.  We called in and they have pleasantly agreed to hold our reservation for 15 minutes.  They still seated us although we arrived 20 minutes after the time of reservation and even thanked us for calling in!  I made the mistake of any starving person ordering and ordered too much.  I started off with the cheese platter with the Clisson served with peach jam, the Robiola Bosina served with almonds, and one which name's escaped me served with olives.  The bread that comes with it was an amazingly good compliment baked with raisins.  All of the cheeses were good, but my favorite was the Clisson.  Very flavorful and works well with the peach jam.  Next we had the garlic pretzel, French onion soup, and grilled scallops.  The soup was excellent for a person like me who was feeling under the weather.  My favorite is the grilled scallops which came with only 2 scallops.  But it was done perfectly well, maintaining its tenderness but with a wealth of flavor.  We finished it up with the Rib Eye and Butter-Poached Halibut.  But by that time, we were stuffed.  The halibut was a little too rich in flavor in my opinion.  But then again, I was too full to fully appreciate it.  Overall, a great meal with excellent service.  A++!

DaV92559xQgG_-sRddBHYg.review_text: I've only been here once and I must say I was pleasently suprised. I had the most amazing scallops ever. They were huge, juicy, and done to perfection. I have yet to find another palce in SF that compares. Absolutely mouth watering. I had quite a few other things when I was there but nothing that was too memorable.   It gets quite crowded and the bar area tends to be loud so you got to be in a boisteruous mood or else youll just be irritated. Its pretty small and dark and the decor is very well done.  The drink menu is quite extensive and they obviously have an array of Absinthe, which I indulged in quite a bit :)   If your a scallops fan. Get them! I'll be heading back soon enuogh.

1gaMMnVEMp3kTDF6AwA6MA.review_text: If I could make a 0-star, I would.  My tip is DON'T GO. The hostess tonight was incredibly rude and condescending to our party. We were told it would take until 8pm to get a seat for our party of 9. We received 1 text that our table was ready, almost an hour earlier than we were told at 7:03. We bolted back to the restaurant, and got there by 7:09, but the hostess said she had called and texted 30 minutes prior. 1) this was 90 minutes earlier than we were told we could be seated, 2) we received NO CALL and the text was at 7:03. Even if it was a technology mishap, she acted as if we were lying even when we showed her our phone log. Neither hostess was willing to try to accommodate us, in particular they refused to put us back on the list. Maddeningly rude, and we took our $$$ ticket to a restaurant that is staffed with sweet and welcoming people. I'm sure Absinthe doesn't really care that we left and made their night easier by getting rid of a large party, and likely (unfortunately) they will do just fine in the future, but they lost 9 customers permanently tonight, and everyone we can tell about them. I work in food service and there's a lot of things that can be difficult or out of my control on a given day, but how I treat customers is fundamental to my job and there is never an excuse to be condescending the way this woman was. We weren't even being difficult, demanding or rude.

0i1z0_K9_2PMWIISzgg-fw.review_text: Big Eat SF... (2009) #45. Galapagos cocktail  (2010) #68. The housemade hot dog  note: You can get food at the bar after 8pm. So it's easy enough to swing by and try both of these at once.  Cocktail - really bland/sour. not sure what's so special. In fact, the hit of the evening seemed to be the Spanish Coffee - it required a lot of fire so people kept noticing and ordering it!  Hotdog - very home made. Soft. No plastic stiff rubbery texture like store bought. In fact, if you're not careful, the casing comes off very easily! Lovely bread. White thick sauerkraut with dijon and mustard on the side.

6k8LzDkDFOx8hwBw3qxVqQ.review_text: Amazing cocktails!  The DARB is my reccommendation. So good!

h5l-yj_8_IxOr02ERrw5cQ.review_text: My partner loves this place so we come somewhat often but I really don't get it. Granted we've only had their brunch, the food is really so-so. The vibe, however, is really great and enjoyable. Next is to try their dinner.

IwZOjxYo2p8olromlfFMsg.review_text: Great, great, great establishment.  My girl friend and I came here for her birthday a few months back.  They gave us one of the corner tables in the back!   Atmopshere is extremely romantic, service is extremely professional, and the food is to utterly delicious!!  The escargot and lamb shank really stood out from our order.  We also had a bottle of Coplon Pinot Noir... such a good recommendation by the wine staff.  I'd be a regular if I could afford it!

ZdY3VTgSHaLgCfnRZEeosQ.review_text: I've been here on 2 occasions.   The most recent was on a Thursday afternoon around 1:30pm for lunch. It wasn't busy at all surprisingly. We were seated immediately. They weren't serving brunch :(, a bit disappointed, but I guess they only serve that on weekends. We ordered a bowl of their french onion soup ($9) , a side of their brussels sprouts and squash with feta ($7), and we shared the Absinthe Burger ($15) with mushrooms and gruyere chese ($1.50 additional each).   Food was amazing. The french onion soup is absolutely delicious and a must order. The brussels and squash were a perfect side, and a side it is, portion is extremely small. But the brussels and squash were cooked to perfection and the feta cheese was a great touch. There was a puddle of oil left at the bottom of the dish when we were finished, a bit unappetizing. The star was the burger. Since they knew we were sharing, they cut the burger in half and served them on separate dishes for us and even split the fries. A very nice gesture. The burger was extremely juicy and cooked to a perfect medium rare. What I hate most is a dry overcooked burger patty. But this was the complete opposite. The bun was soft yet toasted just on the outside. The mushrooms and gruyere cheese were a perfect touch.  The food was delicious, but when we received the bill, this meal was $44 for 3 dishes, 2 of which were sides. Pretty pricey. Expect to splurge a bit. It is definitely not a daily dining place.  They do offer an entire list of drinks. It's a great place to dine and drink.  Service was just as amazing as our food. Our waitress was very nice and informed us of all the specials of the day. She was very friendly and brought us waters immediately. She checked on us frequently especially since it took us a while to decide what to eat. She brought out the soup and side first. When we were done with our appetizers, she brought out our burger. Our waters were never left empty and refilled very often. When we went to go to the bathroom, she would come by and fold our table napkins.  My first time dining here was a brunch experience. We came later and I guess we beat the brunch rush since we were seated immediately. I remember ordering a benedict which made an everlasting impression, which led me to revisit Absinthe another time.   They have seasonal pancakes on their menu. Which I will definitely have to try next time for brunch. I definitely would recommend coming for brunch as they have more appealing dishes on their brunch menu than their lunch menu in my opinion.

rXxY-02UsZH6tWJrW5rGeA.review_text: Here on a Saturday night (pre-Valentines) and the place is packed.  A couple of foo-foo drinky poos at the bar with some steak tartare and their fries and I am a lit up happy girl with the sudden mood to want to dance.  Hubby gets in a couple of Manhattans and we are ready for our table.  Both happily lit and browsing the menu.  Hmm, duck, chicken...wait...burger.  Yes, BURGER...that sounds hella good right now.  It turned out to be the best burger I've ever had - soft bun, juicy meat, and just the right amount of all the other stuff.  Can't remember what the hubby had, who cares?  haha

E0dUiiS4HzdmL6Cd2SvmgQ.review_text: Ok like really are you kidding me??? Ive been here since 2pm and havent even gotten our appetizer and its now 320...  but why is it that the two tables by us ALREADY has their meal??? I hate to think it's because we're asiant but come on! geez... ugh the worst service ever!!! BUT i gotta say, the food was superb!   1. Smoked salmon was SOOOO good... mmm, just melts in your mouth... 2. Croque Monsieur, smoke ham panini type of dish, omg, soooo yummy!   and of course i had some drinks... tried Bellini... not so good, should've just stuck with mimosa... overall food itself i give 5 stars! But their service, a no-no... 1 star!

EzXDaJjdCwMtWdBJiRcC6Q.review_text: Went here prior to before seeing the musical band Phish-band at Bill Graham...  I think we frightened some of the customers as they werent use to seeing long haired hippies.  I also felt quite a bit under-dressed as I had on a T-shirt and hoodie.  I was expecting to get some push-back from the Staff and got none!  I had a couple of their specialty cock tails which went down real good, the lamb balls and pretzel apps and all was delicous.  A little pricey, but still good.  It's a nice, clean, fresh atmosphere  You're a nice, clean, fresh atmosphere.

_V6qMBCSzhwx96FLB3CJRw.review_text: Oh Absinthe, how you have teased me.  I have longed to come visit you, but not yet had the opportunity.  Why, you ask?  I can't really say, although it is all my fault.  For one thing, I live across the bay, so to see anyone, even a green fairy, is not always easy.  For another, I guess no one has beckoned me to join them before.  It's not for lack of wont.  I did get to see your maker, Jeff at the Cocktail Smackdown...and shockingly got to meet him (and by "meet", I mean stop him on his way back from the bathroom at a restaurant in OAKLAND, of all places).  And yet still I never came.  Until...one sunny (albeit chilly) Sunday morning (okay, afternoon) when a gorgeous friend of mine asked if I wanted to tag along for brunch.  Although my intention was to go to the gym and work out, the lure to see you was too great.  After wall, some of my favorite people are fans, so why shouldn't I be?    As I was delayed on route by the demon we will call "MUNI", I did not get to peruse your cocktail menu- which I was dying to see.  No matter, said gorgeous friend ordered me a bellini under the instructions of "fruity" and "champagne".  What to order, you ask?  Well, as I think a restaurant on a first try cannot only be judged on their creative dishes, but also by the basics, I opted for the 2 eggs, over medium, with potatoes, toast and BACON.  How I longed to try your bacon.  The eggs were perfect; the toast, although on the small side was good; the potatoes were divine...but the bacon was SALTY.  I like lip puckering stuff as much as the next siren, but this was too much.  I actually- gasp- left a strip of bacon on my plate.  I could not take it.  The service was pleasant but not memorable, and I didn't really get to see the decor because I was facing the window.  The booze selection, however, looked voluminous...which always earns points in my book.  Will I be back?  Perhaps  One of my "friends" finds your burgers delectable, and I trust him...sometimes.

-HPWfTPt1cAu155OX6Ym2g.review_text: Family Vacation Part XIII  Title: I really should have used regular numbers instead of roman numeral ones...  The day before the family was exhausted from dealing with the Big Bus Tour and Sausalito. I hooked up with a friend that I know from World of Warcraft. We were heading to Lers Ros Thai but we got across the bridge way faster then we were expecting and need to burn time while we wait for him to show.   I am a fan of Absinthe youtube videos. And that makes me a fan of Absinthe. So while walking and seeing a bar called Absinthe I was sold!!  First thing I noticed was the smell. It smelled like old feet. Or Cheese.... old cheese. Or maybe feet cheese if that is a thing. I am not looking it up to find out. Smell and all it is the kind of place you want to go if you like the bar atmosphere. Unfortunately I had the kids and wife with me so there was no tomfoolery this time. At this point I was realizing that I have to make a road trip with the crew to San Francisco.   It seemed that everywhere you look there was a bar. And bar serves beer, and I drink beer. That is a match made in something... I am sure  But back to this place, you don't go to a Bar called Absinthe and not order Absinthe. Family with you or not, you have to bite the bullet!!!  I do not know what I ordered. It was good, a mix drink with absinthe I am told. I doubt it was the worm wood kind... but it was tasty. I didn't get a buzz though, and I can't find the drink in the menu that is listed online, so I can't tell you what it is called. Wifey ordered the Perfect Pear and enjoyed it. We ordered apetizers since we were eating somewhere else.   **Update** While looking through my phone I realized that I actually took a picture of my drink and the Absinthe Cocktail menu. (I couldn't find the Absinthe Cocktail drink menu on the website) I got the Corpse Reviver #2. They don't have #1. Maybe the drink was too strong, or maybe they got better at making the Corpse Reviver and called it #2... or maybe they don't have all the ingredients to make Corpse Reviver #1. And probably the obvious option, there never was a #1!!! It was good, I like lemon juice so I chose this one. The menu had over 14 Absinthe to use from. I figured the mixed one was safe with family.... i will be back!!!***  French Fries with smoky ketchup. It was good. Hard to ruin fries really. It happens but not here.   Soft Garlic Pretzels with Vermont Cheddar Mornay. Also a good think to eat with a beer. I didn't get a beer.... I really need to make a return trip. Will bookmark this place for a return visit for sure.

ef_cOqHQxl2a6R0zxxKIsg.review_text: One star for the superb water guy; we never had an empty glass of water!  Besides that, the service was one of the worst I have ever experienced! The hostess tried to fit us into a middle table that obviously could at best accommodate 2 people. Next was a corner table that wasn't any better. Finally we waited for a table with sufficient room to seat the 4 of us. And the sun was directly in my eyes! If you are going to have big windows, either invest in some curtains or pull down the drapes for the customers!  We ordered and the pretzels came a good 40mins after being seated. SERIOUSLY!?!? Once we reached an hour and we still didnt get our food...I said out loud how irritated I was where upon our waitress might have overheard us and told us our food was being plated. Lies. 10-15 minutes later, it finally came.  And the burgers were disappointing. Bland pretty much sums it up. Super Duper and In n out was better than this $14-15 burger, sadly.   Needless to say, I won't be coming back here ever; I will be discouraging my friends from coming here too. If you want to be treated poorly, then this spot is for you. What a total disappointment. Absinthe, I expected better.

1Ovc9AAx3tykyDRUZuRbdA.review_text: GOOD - Asparagus burrata salad, reallllly rich wild mushroom risotto, and warm olives.  BAD - The wines-by-the-glass list shows pricing in columns. The first column is A HALF GLASS, NOT A FULL GLASS. BEWARE. It just might save you $50.   Try and get a table in the back of the restaurant as far from the bar as you can because it certainly won't be dead silent but you'll be able to talk and think.   Nice bathrooms, nice service, and nice atmosphere!

VciAMIPRUENsPEAHO5izVA.review_text: goat cheesecake was amazing but I'm not a dessert person so if you like things sticky sweet you may not like it everything else was delicious too

7KT60ooaB-Fm4wgKn---6A.review_text: Delicious food and great atmosphere. Great cheese. Our server was attentive and knowledgeable. Pricey yet worth it.

eSHzKLdf6-iHHzJyb8rNKA.review_text: After reading about this place and driving past it so many times, I finally ventured in one night this past week.... planned for a nice girls night before heading to a show at the Herbst.  The ambience inside is great, and the staff was very organized and friendly, even helpful with menu recommendations (I appreciate a good honest answer when asked about the food!).   On to the menu - the drink list, of course, is beyond exceptional, so much to choose from! Even with that, however, I opted for a glass of wine, and with that was blown away, an exceptional glass with a very reasonable price. For dinner I had the french onion soup, which lived up to what everyone has said about it,  really perfection, and again, reasonably priced, I had the $4 cup, which was perfect as an appetizer.  I then had the scallops with chanterelles and gnocchi - again, to die for.  They were perfectly rich, not too rich, and they were also able to make it in a sauce that was more vegetarian friendly (rather than the prosciutto stock), which didn't seem to sacrifice the taste at all.   After dinner we had some dessert wines and tea, and relaxed since we had a fair amount of time before the show.  Not once did we feel we were imposing, or lingering too long, which definitely happens at some popular/trendy restaurants these days.   Overall, I was very impressed and will definitely go back the next chance I get!

Ed8JmiYnZYMe86vyKpcEwQ.review_text: Came by the area with my friend to pick up chocolates from Christopher Elbow's and all of a sudden, our stomachs started to growl. Looking around, there were sooo many options so I pulled out my handy-dandy YELPbook aka my phone! Seeing as this place had over 2k reviews, why not?! Upon walking by, I see (I really do mean SEE, not TASTE) really fancy looking drinks in cute glasses (IT LOOKS SO GATSBY-like to me, I lahhhh it!) and of course, I knew I wanted to order that pretty looking drink.. Waited about 15 minutes for a table and then the shenanigans began....  1. GALAPAGOS - A guava flavored cocktail. Much to my tastebuds, it was quite refreshing but you can tell the alcohol was hidden in there SOMEWHERE. Ended my sips with 3 brandid cherries at the end, yum.  2. GINGER ROGERS - If you like Gin and Tonic, this is definitely the way to go. Taste just like a soda with a minty, lemon flavor!  3. PERFECT PEAR - A delightful, sweet tasting cocktail. Almost as if I was drinking a dessert wine.  4. CORSPE REVIVER #2 - DEAR GOD, NO. No. No. What a pretty looking drink, but ehhh, my taste buds and liver was not feeling it. The taste was just disgusting to me but I guess you can't always get a nice, sweet, tasting, cocktail...  As for our food order, we went with many appetizers...  1. THE SOFT GARLIC PRETZEL - Really strong garlic flavor.. tiny but hey it's pretzel. BRING ME MORE.  2. FRENCH FRIES - Honestly, you can't go wrong with french fries... it was thin cut shaped fries served with 2 sauces: the aioli and a bbq ketchup flavored sauce.  3. BEEF TARTARE - MMMMS, the garlic bread chips served with this was YUMS. Not spicy to my tastebud, but my friend thought it was a little.  4. PEI MUSSELS & MANILA CLAMS - MMMMMS, LEMON & CHARDONNAY sauce... DEFINITELY must get!!! The mussels and calms were savory and absorbed the sauce really well.  Overall, I had a good time but looking at the menu, I probably would not come back for dinner. Just happy hour/the bar area/ and to try their breakfast menu.

Vq73g5hdDBdxdBOfkEYqyw.review_text: What a great place for a late night bite. We had an old gent waiter, he was efficient and pretty funny. I have always enjoyed my meals here over the years, classic SF eatery. Cozy place for any type of gathering. Great food and menu.

UXGlno5B0H05ZhUU3g9ZAA.review_text: Food is amazing! Drinks are hit or miss.  -Drinks: The 21 hayes and galapagos were okay but the sacred heart came out very nicely.   -Pretzels: super yummy and I love garlic, great chewy texture but still light -Arancini: again great flavors maybe a little greasy  -Burger: always good, perfectly executed, but its a burger -Duck breast with coffee etc... super tasty, perfectly cooked, well balanced flavors -DESSERT always a success: the meyer lemon tart came with a delicious basil meringue that overall made it very intriguing and kept me coming back for more. The atmosphere is great and there service is really fantastic I have to say-not that I care too much about that, but it just makes the overall experience more pleasant. -Their croque monsieur and french onion soup make the most comforting, nummy lunch SO good.  - I've had a couple dinner dishes however where the flavor profiles seemed out of balance, like too much orange zest in i believe the lamb ragout etc...

cHdSQISeMpp8HlCWgNb1QQ.review_text: Absinthe has awesome decor from the moment you walk in. It has that old world charm and an unassuming air.  When I arrived with my boyfriend for brunch one Sunday, there was no host there to greet us. Whatever, I figured we could wait. It got awkward though the longer we stood there - you'd think that one of the servers or busboys or other staff wandering around us would say something! Even something small like "someone will be right with you". That was annoying... and awkward, but I already said that.  When we were finally seated, the man who served us was very friendly and attentive, and he was knowledgeable about the menu. There were some terms I was unfamiliar with since they were in French, so it was nice to see that he knew what he was talking about.  I opted for the squash pancakes, which were really good, but very sweet. The portions seemed a bit smaller than expected at first glance, but this was not an issue since the food was very full of flavour. The duck ragout - which my bf got - was also very tasty.  All in all, some parts of the experience were fab and other parts I would hope to omit next time. I've heard this place is good for dinner so I think I'll be back sometime to try it out. Bit pricey, but that's fine since this probably isn't a place I would frequent very often - I like the atmosphere more for "special-er" occasions :)

7oWU5ObJjMJ4AloSe_qE5w.review_text: first time last night...and the food was great but what won me over for the 5-star rating was the service. everything was pretty much on point. nice, helpful waitress, efficient support staff, and food came out in a timely manner.   there was only two of us, but we tried to sample as much as we could stuff ourselves with...starting with a wonderful FRENCH ONION SOUP GRATINÉE  that is probably in my top 3 possibly top 2 FOS ever. The FRISÉE baby leeks, lemon vinaigrette, house-smoked bacon,fried duck egg, fines herbes, caviar was also very good with the bacon chopped chunky enough to really have a bite to it. The FENNEL & MARINATED ARTICHOKE FLATBREAD shaved onion, Persian fetta, cerignola olives, roasted garlic was probably the only miss that night. While okay, I felt the artichoke overwhelmed everything else.   For our entrees, I had the much talked about ABSINTHE HAMBURGER Marin Sun Farms ground beef, aïoli, baby lettuces, red onion, house-made pickles with smoked gouda and fried egg added for $1.50 ea. And my friend had the LIBERTY FARMS DUCK BREAST black garlic farro risotto,swiss chard, red curry carrot purée. We both enjoyed our mains, and I have to say that I really appreciated the chargrilled flavor on the burger. It is probably the first restaurant burger where I got that taste of a burger cooked on an outdoor grill. That being said, it's not my fav burger of all time, but I'd put it in my top 5 at the least. The bun, while tasty, couldn've held up better. I was reduced to putting it down and eating it with my fork and knife before the half way point.   We had to also have dessert so we got the CHOCOLATE BREAD PUDDING Candy cap mushroom ice cream, Nutella, coffee gastrique and a fruitier dessert that I can't remember but also liked. The Chocolate bread pudding wasn't quite what I expected and while I thought the whole flavor composition was good, it was more cakey than I was hoping. I guess I just prefer a more traditional approach to bread pudding.   Absinthe definitely deserves a return trip. I'm hoping to try their brunch next which my co-worker raves about.

l3HfLnoT5j9WLHe461MAwA.review_text: Went for food before the Opera.  Ordered from the Bar menu.  OMG.  The cheeses, the pate, the salad, the cocktails, all fabulous.  What a nice atmosphere!  Would go again.

Kmiu0dzeWTBbp_HZomF5KQ.review_text: Came here for a friend's birthday a couple weeks ago. It was packed on a Saturday night, and valet was worth it (when is it NOT worth it in SF?!).   We were served a couple of a couple of amuse-bouches. One was curried chickpeas and olives. Oh, we were also served bread with olive oil and balsamic vinegar, but tell me why they only dropped off a plate each of oil and vinegar to ONE side of the table? By the time it made its way to our side, there was nothing left.   First course: pretty much a Caesar salad or French onion soup. Both were delicious and I really liked the salad--even with the anchovy on top! My only qualm was that they only served the salad with ONE anchovy! They were actually pretty good and I ended up eating the whole thing before trading with my SO and then realizing there was only one...whoops. The French onion soup was good. Nothing to write home about.  Second Course: (So...I don't remember exactly since none of the dishes really stuck out to me, but...) there was a Vadouvan risotto (vegetarian), halibut, and pork. I was able to try all three (I got the halibut for myself), but the pork was the best, I think. It was very tender and delicious.  Third Course (dessert): A some sort of deconstucted cheesecake or some nectarine or peach sherbets. I ordered th cheesecake, which was OK. It had a taste that wasn't too my liking. The sherbets were not so good. I'm glad I didn't order it, but people at our table liked it. *shrug* They were a little too tart for me and the scoops were huge.  This was a lame review, but it's because I honestly didn't really like the place that much and if I did, the dishes would stick out in my brain much more.  Again, nothing to write home about, but it's worth a try...

Ieh-Swex83RqQvdmehLStQ.review_text: O.V.E.R.R.A.T.E.D.  I'm giving two stars for the sommelier and the food runners. The sommelier might as well have been our waiter. He was helpful, accommodating and nice.   Our waitress was non-existent and cold. She spoke a total of 20 words to us. We were both upset that we tipped her 20% afterwards. We had some of the most recommended raved about dishes (beef cheeks and pork) and were really underwhelmed.  Spend this sorta money at other places, plenty of nice joints in SF deserving your hard earned cash more!  Came here because of Top Chef but won't be back.

_Epzez0z5YxPp6lbwiespw.review_text: A fifth star, well earned!  In my first review of Absinthe I talked at length about the quality of the food versus the price. The food was great, but not so great as to warrant such a steep bill. Well... I went back with friends on Friday and, either something has changed /or/ I was desperate for a good meal, because gosh-darn-it if that wasn't totally worth every penny.  In addition to two delightful cocktails and some friend chickpeas, I ordered the Slow-Cooked Pork Confit. The pork was flavorful and tender, no knife required, place atop a gooey bed of cheese grits with house made bacon. I inquired just how /house/ made the bacon really was, and it turns out they do not butcher on site... but the bacon was good enough that I am prepared to forgive them.  My fellow diners each order amazing dishes as well, but perhaps the dish most raved about were the Beef Cheeks. This particular diner tried them at my urging and after tasting remarked "I didn't know meat could be this tender." Such is the amazing power of the beef cheek.  Absinthe, you've won me over... I shall be back.

Ip8ztdExo0hy_ErKr9WoNQ.review_text: I have been here a few times for lunch and dinner and I've had a pleasent time trying out their French cuisine.   The only thing that left a good impression are les frites.  Other than that, its an okay place to have a nice Sunday brunch.  TIP:  Parking is a pain in the A.  Avoid bringing your car.

hfbLfqLmBEKQAfHw-pydcA.review_text: If you're a scotch connoisseur then it doesn't get any better than this place. The food and service is also outstanding.
