Did I already mention that they have one of the best scotch and bourbon menus that I have ever seen? Great ambience! Definitely one of my favorite places in the city

zPvo9z9yDT1Ls9z31a6uzg.review_text: Wow! I had the most amazing gnocchi dish. It was perfection. My partner had a monkfish dish. Both dishes rate 5 stars. Even the beet salad was lovely. But...bringing the total rating down to 4.5 stars is the intensity of the noise level. We arrived at 6:15 and it didn't reach a decent decibel until 7:30 pm which is when most people head off to their "performance." Not us...we just eat earlier. We were asked at the beginning of the meal if we had a performance to attend and our "no" turned into a rather long wait for the food. C'est la vie! The food was still delicious.

b6_gR3caZcaf3PIein5ktA.review_text: We decided to eat here before heading to a show because they are speedy and sensitive to time if you tell them your headed to a show.  The oysters were perfection.  Those damn Pretzel bits should be illegal! They violate my scene of self control. After having one I wanted to cancel my main dish and order 3 more of them plus one to go.   Good thing I didn't because when my Sole came it was beautiful and a balanced feast of flavors. Perfectly cooked rings of potatoes on sole? Why yes, any girl would accept that scrumptious proposal!   In liu of dessert we decided to do a cheese plate. Which I personally love doing. We had the blue farm,a Brie, and a more sharp cheese I can't recall. Each came with its own pairing of seasonal jams and nuts and the whole thing gave me an opportunity to eat more of their amazing wheat bread!  I loved this place and it's great service, amazing food, and fun cocktail list makes it one of my regular pre show food stops!

2gKNH5K-9bHOIe48P3dN5A.review_text: Pretty solid. The food was good and the atmosphere was good for a date. I had the pork chop and french onion soup. The soup was fantastic and the pork chop was pretty good. MY date had the local greens salad and pasta both of which were good. Didn't exactly blow me away with how good it was but it was an overall positive experience. I would come back.

mGReOSJOmZwKu6hMd9kkFQ.review_text: This place is just Overrated, we didn't like the food either the cocktails, one start, only because our cocktail waiter was very friendly.

43fN6ok_fwbGtWr0LfH0wQ.review_text: I was very underwhelmed. From the pictures on the website and neighborhood I expected much more. This place gets packed and there is little space between tables and for people to walk.   The absinthe is not served 'authentically' with spoon so you mix sugar with herbs yourself and I was shocked at that because of the name. I doubt I'll return.  The absinthe burger was the best part of the experience but definitely not the best in town.

Yds7PD0kfECChQmu2HT0Wg.review_text: CAN WE GET 4 SMALL BOWLS OF FRENCH ONION SOUP PLEASE? Would you like to try the Cauliflower Soup, it's delicious? - waiter NO thank you!!!   French onion soup - NO REGRETS!!!!  Beef Cheeks - Soft, flavorful, and moist  Pork - salty, better in the inside, and fatty Duck - tender and yummy.  I had a great time with long time friends at Absinthe.

ybJkYYEBvFGVb-or4i9_oA.review_text: My French onion soup was delicious as always.  I didn't get to eat my Croque Monsieur because my 3 month old decided Absinthe was a delightful place to unload in her pants.  The staff was very kind, put a chair in the bathroom so I could change her on it rather than the floor (don't worry, I put down a changing pad and toilet covers on the chair first).  By the time she was changed we needed to leave.  I ate my lunch at home, even cold it was fantastic!  Absinthe remains one of my favorite restaurants with great food and service!

_rg_b5TVPBy1sWAYXEM-Vw.review_text: Came here last Wednesday for dinner,  I loved every minute of my experience here!   This place was recommended by a friend who joined us,  we shared all the apps and the main courses, so we got to sample everything!   Appetizers  The roasted chickpeas- Good, light, very nice to munch on while we waited. Beef tartare - Bold Flavors, VERY delicious, man, I wanted to lick the plate, it was that good. We actually considered ordering another. Pork Belly - Can't go wrong with a good pork belly,  perfectly cooked, melt in your mouth good. Nom.   For dinner: First: Pork Skirt Steak - This ..it was good. It came with beans,  honestly pork and beans is a bit boring to me.  I'm glad we shared plates, this as my entree would have bummed me out.   2nd: Roasted Leg of Lamb: I HIGHLY recommend this dish,  I cannot put to words how HEAVENLY this plate was. The lamb PERFECTLY seasoned,  cooked to a perfect medium rare,  the black garlic jus realllllllyy added to the lamb,  this was phenomenal.   3rd: Wagyu Steak : Already you know you are getting a high quality dish, but man this was cooked to perfection, it didn't even need the sauce the meat had that much flavor. Apparently there was bone marrow,  I didn't see any so it must have been in the sauce. Either way,  a great way to end the entrees.    For dessert, we  ordered the sorbets, the pot de creme, and the goat cheesecake.   Okay, so I got the pot de creme, but i had a bite of the goat cheesecake,  and damn, I wanted that immediately. Don't get me wrong the pot de creme is delicious, rich, and perfect for the chocolate lover, but the moment I got a bite of the cheese cake that was it.  Sold.     The ambience was dark, very intimate,  I loved the decor and the dark finishes.  I had a great, great, time at this restaurant and will definitely come back for more the next time I find myself in San Fran :)

As3PGConLtPOKgfGtAizNQ.review_text: 3 other friends and I were originally planning on grabbing some burgers for dinner but randomly ended up here instead... don't know how we went from burgers to French food but I can say i'm glad that we did. The interior of the restaurant was adorable, dimly lit with christmas lighting around the windows.  We ordered:  Appetizers: - Olives - Garlic pretzels: on the 7x7 list, sounds simple but it's really good - Oyster shooters  Shared Plates - Salmon ceviche: loved this dish, can't go wrong with ceviche - Beef tartare: a little salty, but goes well with the chips they serve it with - Mussels & clams: this was one of my fav appetizer dishes, very well flavored  Entrees - Duck with coffee crust: would recommend, very tender and flavorful, the coffee crust sounds a bit odd to pair with duck but you really cant taste it - Wagyu steak  Dessert (don't judge.) - Almond quince cake: BOMB. I was blown away by this dessert, must try - Ice cream: eh, nothing special - Apple tart: too sweet - Butternut squash bar: pretty good but after the almond quince cake nothing really compared - Cheese platter  Pretty much ordered half of the menu... but for the most part I was very pleased from everything from the food to the service.

wZG2xlICfUkJiY1NdPJH2A.review_text: Very pretentious dinner crowd. It looked a little more upbeat and fun on the bar side. Tried the lamb meatballs,  flatbread appetizers and a selection of three cheeses, all which were quite filling. They ran out of one of our selections, but the Le Wavreumont (light creamy), La Tur (earthy), and Agour (firm, mild for goat) were all delicious and paired nicely with the accompaniment. The waiter was nice, kept winking at me, but I thought it was a little unprofessional when he moved some plates out of the way to put a dish down, he accidentally touched my fork. We both saw it and perhaps he was too embarrassed, but he did not bother replacing them. Watch out as you walk back from the bathrooms, there's a blind corner where servers come out of the kitchen and they get pretty angry if you get in their way. It's convenient to the symphony, but if you aren't going there, it makes parking a little difficult on those nights.  I would definitely go back for drinks. Voluptuous had just the perfect amount of absinthe for flavor, but not overwhelming. The ginger rogers was good too, but I'd highly recommend a drink with absinthe, after all, its the namesake.

zXO3h3X4yfJyyynWV8lhzQ.review_text: Contacted Absinthe after a disastrous attempt at another restaurant to organize a memorial for our son.  I e-mailed them an inquiry for the private dining room on  Saturday evening and the event coordinator, Vanessa Harris, responded that night.  We worked with Vanessa to organize what turned out to be a fantastically successful celebration of life.  She was always immediately responsive and professional.  While not everyone is going to use the private dining room, I highly recommend it for any private event.  The room is beautiful, the servers who circulated with passed appetizers were discrete, professional and pleasant.  The private bartender was fantastic and the drinks and food were out of this world.

mun8HtTyHk8RKpic5cbB8Q.review_text: damn delicious pear cocktail, but i drank it so fast there wasnt enough liquor taste in it. my husband got a pomegranate/absinthe type drink that was DELICIOUS as well. worth the $13 for 4 sips? I dont think so. worth it for once in a life? yes.

lrp5aQP31ar3JDlbwccfHQ.review_text: I officially went to Absinthe for the first time after the symphony.  Before heading over there with my bf, I made reservations via OpenTable.  I'm guessing Absinthe is the go to place after the symphony because it was busy.  And even though we made reservations, it took us awhile to be seated, but the manager was very attentive with us, which was nice.  I ordered the scallops, which one was slightly raw, but they took it back to fire it up again.  Other than that, the scallops were delicious.  I ordered a cocktail that was so yummy.  My bf ordered some fish that was very good.  I'm looking forward to going back soon.

8wHKhb9wqIHca43Xr1xJZQ.review_text: 11:15AM Reservations, 5 girls, Brunch.  Enter.  11:15AM, the place is pretty much empty sans maybe 2-3 tables of diners.  The place is fancy schmancy and all of us admit to never coming here because of that.  Throw a couple of heavy velvet curtains up and make your wait staff wear collared shirts and somehow we believe we can't afford to dine here.  I'm used to the surly waitresses in jeans and obscure punk band t-shirts throwing bad coffee and fried potatos my way.  I sorta like it like that too.  But it's good to break free from the trend.  Yes, let's go have brunch at a fancy place where we usually see old rich people eating in the window.  Waitstaff was courteous and attentive.    Beverages came, all alcoholic, very quickly.  Food came in a reasonable time frame.   Tamie's biscuits and gravy looked excellent.  The deviled eggs looked nice, though I'm not a deviled egg kinda gal.  The Fried Green Tomato Benedict was excellent.  This was just the tasting from my friends plates!  Jessica P. and I shared an assortment of goodies.  The butter lettuce salad, not bad, standard simple salad.  The frites were excellent, light and crispy and not in the least bit greasy.  The fruit plate was good, it's pretty damn hard to mess up a fruit plate, and I liked how they had figs and papaya as well as the standard berries, grapes and pineapples.  The vanilla bean creme fraiche was an excellent touch and I wished I could order a tub of that stuff to bring home to bathe in it.  Seriously.    I had the soft boiled egg with sage croutons and that too, was excellent.  We also split the Wild Mushroom Goat Cheese Flatbread which, as well, was nice, crisp, non-greasy and delicious.    I left brunch feeling not as disgusting as I usually feel after brunch.  This ain't no "Chicken Fried Steak at the Pork Store " kinda feeling.  There would be no food baby later.    This was great news as we went to the 'burbs afterwards so I could try on bridesmaid dresses for my sister's wedding without feeling pregnant.  I have nothing bad to say about Absinthe.  I'm sad it took me 6 years of living in the city before going in and devouring a gourmet meal at reasonable prices.  Brunch, of course, is cheaper then dinner, so for a measly $3 more then Stacks down the street, you can get a better quality breakfast.

OduqSeGbg8StiXTyqZnFBQ.review_text: This place had me intrigued from the get go,   After a couple of weeks I finally decided to make a reservation there.   They serve food late,  which is always a plus, and were able to accept my reservation at almost 11pm  The cocktails are exotic,  delicious,  and a definite must have.  I would recommend the French onion soup,  and beef tartare as starters.    All the beef they serve is extremely delicious,  and grass fed.   So good.  We were too full to sample their dessert menu,  even though it looked quite tantalizing and delicious.

EVaW-GGDEbYrYhgGUmO0DQ.review_text: This is for brunch.  DEVILED EGGS with smoked salmon, salmon caviar, capers-only get 3 pieces, but really good  Onion Soup-it's hard to find good onion soup in the city, but it was really yummy here  DUCK-CONFIT RAGOUT wild mushrooms, chive-potato cake,poached eggs, béarnaise sauce-delicious!!!!  OPEN-FACE SMOKED TROUT "BLT" brioche, citrus aïoli, bacon, butter lettuce, heirloom tomato, avocado, pickled onion-the trout was way too salty and dry  CROQUE MONSIEUR Black Forest ham, gruyère, Dijon mustard, toasted levain, béchamel, mixed greens-also very good  CRISPY POTATOES onion jam, rosemary-can't go wrong with these.  Service was excellent.

Licx63IGtNDPvhMIBqmOww.review_text: Stopped here for before a Musical. The place is on a corner lot, meaning a nice 90 degree window view of the neighborhood. The decor was trendy. A friend wanted to try the Absinthe, in short little details it tasted like black licorce and strong. A big no-no, was having my friend leaving 1/3 of it on the table. Brunch: I had the DUCK-CONFIT RAGOUT, for such a small dish it was very heavy. The waitress was kind enough to split the entree so me and my girlfriend didn't have to share a plate. The burgers here were thick and juicy. If you are a fan of burgers maybe you should strike up a order. The service was fast and attentive. I definitely like the feel of the place and the atmosphere. A come back is on the books.

UdGows31OnUBz_7yDlvNJA.review_text: I've been threatening to go to this place for long time. I was in the mood for some french fries so I grabbed the missus and we headed out to Hayes Valley.  We frequent their little sister Arlequin and they have some awesome fries, so I had high hopes.  The fries met and exceeded my expectations. Very different than the fries at Arlequin. Arlequin has some sort of coating on them that makes them crunch and I don't even know how to describe them. They're divine.  Absinthe's fries are more of the shoestring variety, but are very potatoey and crunchy, yet there is some softness inside. Double fried, I'm guessing. You just want to plow through the whole bowl without stopping.  Oh, but they have other food, too. I had what I thought was a uniquely prepared chunk of rib meat from a cow (it was braised) and I scarfed that thing down like it was my last meal. I don't even recall what the wife had but it was also top notch. Their mac and cheese was delicious, despite the lack of truffle oil. Ha ha.  Absinthe is a bit pricey, but then everything in San Francisco is pricey. Absinthe won't be an everyday place for us, but despite the high price it is also high value. One of the best meals I've had in the city.  PS I see that some people here complain about the service at Arlequin. I can report that on our visit it was perfect. Attentive but not pushy. Our waiter was very knowledgeable about the menu. I also noticed that service is a real team effort. A server delivered some dessert to a table near us and on the way out she glanced at our table and took some empty dishes with her on the way out. They were performing like a machine that night.

-rZj3pLAolT6weY8VsrGaQ.review_text: great food, creative cocktails along with traditional cocktails, fun but can get noisy,

2TKdAc7ywov_8gpLctxO5Q.review_text: I want to give Absinthe 4 stars, but I can't seem to go above 3 after what we experienced.  We drove 3 hrs to Absinthe on a Sunday afternoon because our friends keep telling us about their famous pretzels.  After driving 3 hrs and another 30 minutes looking for parking, we were greeted promptly by the hostess and we sat at our table. Now this is where its an up and down review for this great place. Our waitress informed us that they don't serve their famous pretzels on Sundays until after 5:30, even after we explained to her how far we drove, she said no. None of the people in our party had a good vibe about the waitress, she would talk to us, but never smile and while talking she would just look somewhere else, it seemed like she didn't want to work that day, we noticed she was the same way with other guests.  We ordered the 3 different raw oysters (2 ea), they only have two, but they are SO GOOD. We ordered the spicy fried chick peas and the rosemary jam crispy potatoes, our waitress forgot the put in the orders, half way through our brunch, we reminded her about the chick peas and potatoes, she brought out the potatoes at the end of the meal, but not the chick peas. I had the open face sandwich with a fried egg, this was ONE OF THE BEST sandwiches I've ever eaten, UNTIL a fruit fly came crawling out of the sandwich. Now, its understandable that this does happen in restaurants, not their fault. Our waitress asked if I want to replace with something else, I didn't lose my appetite, but was on the borderline of being full and didn't want to waste another meal.  The manager apologized and took the sandwich off the bill. Our guests also had the Duck Confit, French Toast, and the Croissant, along with several cocktails.  Our brunch was outstanding, but after walking away, our guests had the same feeling, we wished our dining experience was a bit better, the food was great, but we don't like to pay for subpar services.

LTI86BSXBclY6UsZXqKYXw.review_text: Came here on Valentines Day!  The restaurant has two atmospheres to it. There is the bar side where everyone gathers and has drinks and there is the quiet restaurant side.  There was a special valentines day menu during the day.   FOOD: The highlight was the lobster bisque soup. It was flavorful and creamy. The soup came with a fresh piece of lobster tail which was moist and flavorful.  SERVICE: The service was impeccable. The waiters were constantly attentive and came by regularly to see how the food was.  Overall, I would definitely come back again and try dining around the bar.

PS80V0SCQiTtyt_hVuIsyA.review_text: #45 of 100 on 7x7's The Big Eat SF 2009: Galapagos cocktail at Absinthe bit.ly/1VmqYA Ugh so there's a 2010 list, which kind of messes up this list that I started. But alas - that means we have 200 items to go off of, minus the duplicates. Anyway - came here on Valentine's Day for the Galapagos cocktail. We were at the bar. The bartender was friendly and promptly made our drinks. The Galapagos cocktail is the following: Pisco, Kaffir lime leaf muddled in pepper syrup, lemon-lime juice, and a splash of grapefruit juice. Shaken & served up with sunken brandied cherries. So yes, based on the ingredients it's quite tasty and I can confirm that it's a good cocktail. Will be coming back for their hotdog, which is on the 2010 list.

ASsznAAjSCiQMhDR2OJOfQ.review_text: Review for brunch.  What a pleasant surprise! Went here for brunch on Saturday since I wanted to do some shopping in the Hayes.  They have a great menu but please  do not miss these dishes... House cured smoked salmon, fruit plate comes with an amazing vanilla bean creme fraiche, and the basted eggs which comes with the most unique and smooth tomatillo salsa you have ever had.  I am so happy to find a great brunch place in the Hayes to start off my day of Hayes shopping!

mXYVc5jgShblQZKfGf4DmQ.review_text: My bf and I came here for brunch on Saturday. We made reservations and were seated very quickly in a cute u-shaped booth.  Our server introduced some specials, and also a few of his own favorites. We ended up sharing a sweet roll, cup of french onion soup, strawberry rhubarb french toast, and the breakfast burrito.  The sweet roll was sweet! I'm not a big sweet tooth person, but my bf loved it  The soup was delish. Definitely one of the favorite french onions that I've had-- it wasn't too salty and the gooey cheese was perfect!   Our main dishes-- Burrito was very well made, loved the pico de gallo and the crunchiness of the pork.  My french toast was very soggy for some reason, it had wonderful flavor, but a bit too soggy for my tasting.    My bf didnt like their bloody mary either-- way too spiced up! =*(  Overall, great experience.  4 for experience 3.5 for food

OIkdMTc9uoE_Sy4uA7XdQQ.review_text: Not sure what happened...aside from the caviar and my macchiato, everything was way too salty.  Actually, the texture of the blinis were off...  We went in for lunch.  My caesar salad was a bit of a surprise.  There was a distinct tabasco connection...not sure where it came from, but needless to say, we were surprised.  A bit disappointed...

eNdwoG_LU53J1Nq94XLa-A.review_text: We ate brunch here on a Saturday. Onion soup was very good. Bread at table was just so-so -- very disappointing for a French restaurant. My husband had the burger with gruyere and onions.  The burger itself was incredibly delicious, but it was smothered in absurd amounts of aioli, making it a wet mess. He scraped off about 2 tablespoons of the stuff before eating the burger.   The big fail of our meal was my open-faced Smoked Trout BLT. Again, someone was going crazy with the aioli in the kitchen. The trout itself was swimming it, creating a really unpleasant sloppy texture to the star of the dish. Under the trout was a so-so fried green tomato, then some tasty bacon, then lettuce, then a layer of avocado, then a slice of bread which got completely lost underneath all that stuff. And, oh yeah, there was a little pickled onion on top of everything, and the sandwich was accompanied by a nice salad of fresh greens -- also overdressed. Overall, there was too much going on, and it just didn't work.   With so many other great dining choices in Hayes Valley, we will not be visiting Absinthe again.

FCBwo8TsxYnUgFguRfIVUA.review_text: This review only pertains to the bar. We didnt sample any of the food at this location..  Given that, this place is pretty cool. The drinks were great, the atmosphere was perfect (not to full or empty) but best of all the service was spectacular. I dont remember the name of the bartender, but he was tremendous. It was slowing down by the time we showed up so he gave us his full attention, recommending various types of gin's and whatnot.. he also convinced us to taste their absinthe.  I am interested in coming here one day to eat dinner... but for now, i strongly recommend coming to this place for a few exotic drinks and a cool atmosphere...  p.s.... not good for big groups. or "bigger" people like myself. :(

0XXIv9a0LWiaCjAkurjMMQ.review_text: A great First Date venue.  The First Lady was dressed to the nines, and aching for a dinner out.  I'm telling you, when the girl you want to hit on is already married to you, it's suh-WEET!  As we walked past the window she pointed to an empty table inside and said, "There's our table."  Stepping up to the maitre d' station and announcing ourselves, the host led us directly to THAT table!    All I can say is it turned out to be very fine dining.    Those enumerated invoices are good not only for expense account reimbursements, but also for Yelping!  Here is ours:    Antipodes Sparkling Water.  All the way from New Zealand!    French Fries. An Absinthe favorite.  Tricky surprise flavors in the sauces.  Make sure you get some.     Oysters Rockefeller.  Tasty!  Caesar Salad.  Gotta watch the diet.  (Hehe.)   Coq Au Vin.  She let me try some.  Rich, dark, substantial sauce. Bluenose Sea Bass.  All the way from New Zealand!   Cooked just right.   Plate of little cookies.  Next to chocolate, this could make your date orgasm at the dinner table.   Gen mai cha.  Mighty Leaf, her favorite green tea with rice.   Chocolate pot de creme.  See note about cookies.   Consideration:  $150.    Yowza!  May there be many more First Dates!    Note to self:  What I ordered was nearly the same as the prix fixe dinner, and nearly the same price.    Bottom line:  Will I come again?  You bet.  Didn't you read the review?

lwUK5WUhnxMKVpYHkdFUwg.review_text: As a group, we had the beef cheeks, bass, frisee, scallops, chick peas, mussels, chowder & celery soups.  All were excellent.  On the pricey side, but we would definitely come back.

8MeD1D70MC-0dIK2Lr11WQ.review_text: Dine about town 2011 lunch:   First of all, worth doing. Most of the DAT participating restaurants are not offering you a great deal, but Absinthe did. For $17.95 you can get their Fulton Valley chicken dish... and the white chocolate panna cotta, when the chicken alone is normally $19.   The food was great, much better than my brunch experience. Tender, flavorful chicken. Amazing mascarpone polenta on the side. I am not a white chocolate person, and even that was delicious. Prompt yet unobtrusive service.   Why not 5 stars? In the end, this is never going to be one of my favorite restaurants. It lacks the character for that. It's a nice French place, with prices to match.   But will I be back for more? In the words of someone whose words don't often cohere, you betcha!

LDxGB8GDYZ71AY1qHQt_Rg.review_text: A great night with friends sampling a lot of food. It's very dark in here, for some romantic feel.  We had a wig wearing birthday party so it was a more quirky feel for us.  The only thing questionable was their olive oil cake. Service great.

_J4D9oHjNCkkWaYU98IYaQ.review_text: Excellent service, attentive without being in the way.  Food was great fom appetizers to dessert.  My wife's Martini was perfect.  Especially  liked the filet of sole.

X1aNFEhZ0LNADfOH-SdflA.review_text: Yelpers are right on again! This restaurant has great energy, great service, and most of all, great food. We took our out of town guest here for brunch and they said this is their best meal in the city so far on their trip. I ordered the onion soup and Duck Confit Ragout and they are both really good. We have other people in the parties who ordered Rice & Egg and Oysters and they all liked it a lot. A minor side note, their food is a little bit on the salty side, so if you normally eat a low sodium diet, you might want to keep that in mind when ordering.

jpMn8Nm39-eeTlbGNL3szA.review_text: My wife and I went here for our anniversary last month.  To begin, getting a reservation was quick and easy. We ran late due to an accident on 280, but they were nice enough to hold our table.  We were seated in a quiet corner. It appeared that the bar area was a bit more "happening," but we were happy to be away from the action.  I convinced my wife to try absinthe (the beverage). She was more than eager to share. I'm glad to have tried the licorice-flavored beverage; however, it will be my last time.  We had a cheese plate appetizer that was delicious. I can't remember what my wife ordered for a main course, but my medium-rare fillet was fantastic!   From the hostess to our waiter, the service was as good as the food.  My wife and I left fat, drunk, and happy. We've been recommending this restaurant to friends ever since.

04JttCeiTpGmy-7XJtn2Gw.review_text: Our server Juan did an amazing job recommending cocktails and providing top level service. I'm a fan of bourbon and Juan brought over a concoction that was rich in smokey flavor with a hint of citrus to balance out the bourbon - great stuff.  Our table was a party of 3 and we came mostly to enjoy some post work cocktails and possible share some light food. We had the deliciously simple pretzel knots, which were great. I had the french onion soup, which was incredibly rich with flavor and perfectly served.  For my entree I had the Sole - the fish was light, fluffy in texture and not dried out and was not covered in a ton of oil/butter, which is a huge pet peeve of mine for fish.  Our experience was great and I'll definitely be back!

xwGQDwmWMRuzy2TxLKPXRA.review_text: While my friends were recovering from the previous night's shenanigans, I somehow rallied and walked to Absinthe for a late Saturday afternoon lunch. It was busy but I was seated right away, probably because I was dining solo. The cocktail menu looked great; after a quick perusal I went with the Pegu Club, which was perfection in a glass. From the Brunch Menu I ordered the Wild Mushroom Omelet with caramelized onions, gruyère cheese, and fresh herbs. It was delicious and *exactly* what I needed. As I was eating, Jamie stepped out of the kitchen and sat down at the table behind me to chat up some friends. I wanted to compliment her (for Absinthe as well as her run on Top Chef) but didn't want to intrude.  By the time I left (around 3:45 or so), the line for tables had grown quite a bit. I can't imagine the wait later on, reservations seem to be a must. Looking forward to future SF trips and working my way through the dinner and cocktail menus!

VpREWOjt5Pna6OIgXI9Jcg.review_text: *This review is for the bar only*  I like cocktails and complaining/affirming awesomeness with girlfriends. This is a good place for that.  I became a pretty big fan of Absinthe bartender Jeff Hollinger, whose beautiful recipe book and sound advice at a Commonwealth Club forum on cocktails piqued my interest in the ye-olde art of the bar.  Cocktails are pricey ($10-12), but standard hereabouts for these types of drinkies. They're all (mostly) original takes on classic recipes. I had a French 75 (champagne and gin, I think) as well as a couple rounds of Scarlett O'Hara (bourbon, Southern Comfort and...cranberry juice?) We kept the hunger at bay with their signature skinny fries and dipping sauce. I didn't have any absinthe; not a big fan.  The evening out cost me a bit less than $30, and I'll definitely be back to take advantage of the speakeasy-like atmosphere and quality drinks.

1hVPMnVp3-r1X8Nrv_T3dw.review_text: The food is delicious and it isn't impossible to get a table, phew San Francisco, you left us a place without a week's notice needed.  The beef cheeks when on the menu are my favorite, followed with some Bullet!

VCROW1kVZhf1XYzBwQ8B-w.review_text: I died and went to cocktail heaven here, I would like to drink nothing but French 75 for the rest of my life if I had to. I'm not even a big gin drinker. The food here is great, french bistro fare and so is the wine list that is the length of a novella. The service is incredible, and the vibe of this place is poppin'. I could live here, really. Oh, and don't forget desserts... make room for the desserts... and dessert wines, really. And don't come here if you're stingy.

426IAYOuscDp4KzKa1_mcg.review_text: Technically, I would give this Absinthe Brasserie & Bar 3.5 - 4 stars.  Located in Hayes Valley, you can find locals and tourist enjoying meals on the sidewalks. Absinthe menu items scale between the $10-25/plate (above average). I would recommend this place for drinks and brunch because the social atmosphere and how close the spot is to other bars and other cool venues.  But back to Absinthe, I've like to note their brunch menu especially since it is so liked by locals and tourists alike!  I've had their french toasts, pancakes, and eggs and bacons - all excellent choices.  What I enjoyed about Absinthe was the attentive customer service and how the interior of the restaurant reminded me of a French Bistro in Paris- just lovely!  In conclusion, Absinthe is a great solid brunch option!

3928NBSrZ0cbVfdmhi-R-Q.review_text: This place is a second home. I come about every two weeks. Their drink menu is my favorite in San Francisco. Try all of the drinks.  I love the theme and the atmosphere.  Usually the wait is so long that we just sit at the bar (of course, it might not be so long if I ever called in advance).   Butternut squash soup is the best I've ever had, and this winter I tried butternut squash soups at over 10 different restaurants. Kale salad is also wonderful. My boyfriend had a steak or a pork loin or something that was also very good.  I can't say that the wait staff is the best I've ever experienced, but I like to sit and have long dinners so it's nice not having someone pestering us every 5 minutes.

iYzbRy7B_Ho3NX-1rXvRLQ.review_text: Brunch: Medium Rare Hamburger with an egg, onions, and gruyere cheese.  I tried my best to leave the last 1/3 of the burger for my diet's sake, but I couldn't resist.  Wash it all down with a glass of Absinthe Lemonade and then you can breathe a little better!  Blueberry lovers should will enjoy the scone.  Its like a ton of blueberries held together by a small amount of dough.  If burgers aren't your thing, I recommend getting the smoked salmon dish for those looking for the lighter meal.  Absinthe is a great French Brunch break while doing your shopping on Hayes!

_kSbuZlcen8sjeiVhKj4Fg.review_text: A perfect spot for a relaxed, classic drink.    Three of us ducked in one Sunday afternoon and were transported back to the golden era of cocktails.  I locked eyes with a concoction on the specials chalkboard and knew it was the drink for me.  The Jitterbug Perfume: beet-infused gin with a balsamic reduction and some other fancy things--booze'n'borscht, as the bartender called it.  The drink lit up every tastebud in my mouth, with notes that were sweet, salty, and full.  I may be beet obsessed, and you couldn't drink too many of these things in a row, but I was floored.     We also ordered a beautiful pile of shoestring fries, which came with three dipping sauces, and although I remember my drinking companions enjoyed their masterfully mixed drinks, but I was too obsessed with my own to remember what they were.

c0ZyFzvAoBpH0MATNUWSJg.review_text: After living and eating in Los Angeles all my life -_- , coming to a restaurant like Absinthe is like "AHHHH" (choir sound effect).  Here's a list of what my friends and I loved:  Snacks: Yup they call it snacks :) -Soft Garlic Pretzels: my eyes lit up when i saw these 3 words on the menu. Definitely a winner! -Marinated Mixed Olives: Sounds simple but the flavors were so delish!  Raw Bar: -Chilled Shellfish Platter: AH-mazing!   Other:  -Hamachi Crudo: Perfection.  The pickled strawberries on top = heart -Absinthe Burger: Friend had this and it looked amazing. Had a few bites of the fries and they were yummy.  Dessert! -Chocolate Pot de Creme: Really chocolate-y but not overwhelming. Loved it. -Buttermilk Panna Cotta: really enjoyed this.  Service was excellent.

phyyo3kbdL4iVoyLy7lNpg.review_text: I like this place. It's a "brasserie" but has nothing to do with the brasseries you'll find "chez moi" in Brussels or Paris, Absinthe is more classy. I do understand why other Yelpers say there's a European feel to it. Lovely ambiance, great, great cocktails. Food's good too, not cheap though.

fR6bUB3KSE_1QqTMo-2oNQ.review_text: A beautiful day, beautiful company, and the most beautiful strips of bacon I've ever laid eyes or teeth on.  We grabbed a spot for brunch this Saturday before the rush and ordered up some sparkling cocktails (the bellini is excellent, btw) and futzed over the menu.  We made our selections and checked with our waiter to make sure we had chosen..... wisely.  We had!  We shared a cinnamon sticky bun that was buttery, flaky pastry covered in candied sticky walnuts.  YU-HUM.  My ricotta-stuffed french toast with berries and cream was amazing.  The two-and-a-half inch thick toast was brioche-y and had just enough crisp on it to withstand the syrup accompaniment.  The ricotta was perfect with the berry compote and spoonful of cream on the side.  I cleared my plate completely, carbs be damned!  My friends opted for the savory and their breakfast sandwich (huge slices of toast cradling an over-easy duck egg, spicy andouille, and salty cheese) and two eggs any style (with potatoes, toast, and bacon) were great to sample.  The duck egg sandwich was CRAZY rich.  The bacon, OH DEAR GOD, THE BACON.  This bacon was thick, chewy, crispy, and done just right.  It tasted like a campfire.  So perfectly smoky.  Best bacon I've ever had.  Ever.  Write that down.  Absinthe, I'll give you another star after I come back for my next meal (and more bacon).

klLZFhfRHOaRb0EQphgD9A.review_text: Been here only twice - once for brunch and once for a late night dinner after the symphony. I really like the neighborhood and the vibe of the restaurant and I think meeting friends here for drinks might be the most enjoyable of experiences (yet to do!)  Being vegetarian, I definitely preferred the brunch menu over the dinner (which was definitely not veggie friendly and they don't have the ability to whip something up either).   Went with friends for brunch and amongst we got the Croque Madame, Egg white omelet, Croque Monsieur, some mimosas. There was definitely some butter indulgence in the food :) Overall good vibe and a good brunch experience. But nothing spectacular (probably for a vegetarian)  I believe for dinner we got the spicy fried chickpeas (good), the risotto (decent) and the halibut (good). I am not convinced the food quality is up to par for the price. The dining experience at other French restaurants in the city is much more appealing.

aFO_yCma7PImpdPkA8ZC-A.review_text: Though I ordered a Sacred Heart which contains absinthe, there was no imbibe-induced sighting of the green fairy during my most recent visit here.  I did, however, experience one of the best meals I've had in the city in awhile.  If I were to incorporate a salad course into my last meal on Earth the salad would very likely be the friseé from Absinthe.  It was that sensory-overloading good!  Everything about this salad was perfect, from the leeks and vinaigrette to the crisp and savory house-smoked bacon, fried duck egg and caviar topping.  Nothing within the rest of the meal disappointed either.  The hamachi crudo was very good.  The slow-cooked pork confit on a bed of cheese grits and collard greens with more bits of the house-smoked bacon was excellent.  I also sampled some of the braised beef cheeks which were very good as well and seriously tender.  For dessert, the blood orange creme brulee and cookie plate which had a delicious chocolate hazelnut sticky bun put the finishing touches on this great meal.  I've also been here once before for brunch and brunch here is pretty popular.  I ordered the popular blueberry-banana soufflé pancakes which were quite good and filling though they kind of short you on the syrup.

Kb8qPRwk45SqLCV4Mpw5QQ.review_text: I was expecting a lot from Absinthe, and it just didn't deliver.  The restaurant is extremely loud, and very cramped.  My companion and I could barely hear each other over the noise.  By the time our entrees arrived, I was so ready to escape! The ceviche is..... not what we expected - its an interesting take on ceviche, and was tasty, but not our fave.  I had the octopus, which was kind of bland, save for a spicy sauce on the plate, Idk, it just seemed to be missing something.  Companion had the duck, and that seemed kind of blah as well.  Companion loved the duck mousse, though, it was the only thing he really liked. Absinthe has such a great reputation, but its menu seems just like half the other menus of the same tier restaurants in the city - I swear I see the same things at half of the "Brasserie style" establishments in SF!  Maybe if this is your cup of tea, then its great, but I think that there are a lot more interesting dining options in SF

Zs5g4zF48mL54WOWjK4PVw.review_text: Every single aspect of this meal was spectacular.   The cheese sampler plate was great, the drinks are extremely well-made, and the entrees were fantastic. Great pace, great experience.

cQCNoZnQWQ_Lz8uojk9EXQ.review_text: I loved the french vibe! really lively dining/bar area - but not too loud or crowded feeling  we received fantastic service from start to finish. so attentive but not annoying or interrupting at all.   I found this place to be a true gem! everything on the menu looked great but we just ordered some small plates to accompany our lovely bottle of wine.   the beef tartare was awesome  all the cheeses were to die for - served with delicious thinly sliced, hot bread   everything was super flavorful and tasty!   will be back soon :)

v_Z8hMEgqZM3ONRCTbCejA.review_text: Best pancakes ever! The omelet was very good too. Overall, a really good brunch, though somewhat expensive.  Great ambience. Definitely a place for a classy dinner. I'll be back. :)  Also check out the Arlequin cafe / wine store next door.

REGjppkq2IkDLRQVmRj_Bg.review_text: Absinthe Brasserie is just as good, if not better than the drink itself.  Once you eat here you'll hold your taste-buds to much higher standards.  I would give this restaurant 5 stars but the price keeps me thinking it's a bit too steep to be a perfect score.  Try to get a few things and split them with your friends at the table.  This is a great location for a nice date - kind of romantic but more of just a nice dinner to get away from the rest of the world going on around you.  The Spicy fried Chickpeas are the first item on the menu and fabulous. My guests had the onion soup and loved it, and I tried the white asparagus soup which was a great way to wet my appetite. The cheese plates are spectacular and the Fulton Valley chicken, although great, is an SF regular so go for something different.  Perhaps the Lamb shank?  I think so.

XkLK2iBsgqF6mWwDfRgqqQ.review_text: We went for brunch on a Saturday, and while everything was tasty, there was nothing special about it.  We had the breakfast burrito, mushroom and cheese sandwich, shrimp roll and the croque.  The mushroom and cheese sandwich was greasy so I didn't enjoy that much.  The shrimp roll had plenty of shrimp but could have used more Tabasco or something flavorful in the aioli.  The potato chips that came with our meals were probably the best part.  My bloody marys were full of ice so they were not as satisfying as they could have been.  My friends' cocktails looked much better.  It was fine overall, but not someplace I'd hurry back to.

o3PGs0t2a8ORb0gUXFr0bQ.review_text: I've been eating here for so many years but never reviewed it.  Why bother, it's almost too popular.  I really love a late Sunday brunch here. As Reese would say, it's "so French".  You would swear you are in Paris while sitting outside if it weren't for the horrible traffic and the bat shit tranny parading by every five minutes.   Otherwise always solid cuisine and delish cocktails. Hey they wrote a book.  Salut!

UyIY70WUem0Ka3o0Hjqtqw.review_text: Came here for Saturday brunch with some good friends of mine for the first time. We got there about 11:15 and it was really not crowded, which was awesome because by time we left, it was pretty packed. if you can, come early.   We got seated and the ambiance was great. The menu looked great so we decided to share a sticky bun and ordered fries for all of us to share. The sticky bun was nice and tasty, but the fries were cut very short that it was close to being hash browns. They came with 3 dipping sauces which was cool, but when you dipped these fries into the sauces, you are close to dipping your fingers in them. Did I tell you that we were sharing the fries? One thing they can change is have longer fries - knocked one star down.   We then ordered our meal...duck confit hash, griddled corn cakes, croque monsieur, and 2-egg any style with sausage. Everything tasted yummy, but nothing really stood out. It was like we could have gotten the meal from somewhere else. Also, they kinda messed up on one of the orders - my friend ordered the 2 eggs any style with the toast and potatoes, but he only brought out the egg and the sausage. Wish the server verified the order, ya know. Another star down.   It was just okay.

ZPI5G5f9KORdqntheECUUQ.review_text: Went here for brunch with the bf today and it was fantastically delicious!  My absolute favorite was the duck confit ragout.  The potato pancake on the bottom was perfectly cooked, with a crispy outside.  It was topped with a beautifully poached egg  over a mound of duck that was flavorful and not dry.   We also enjoyed the breakfast sandwich, which was onions, black forest ham, and a fried egg on top of an onion bagel.  This dish was also delicious, though not as good as the duck confit.  My only complaint is that the plate it was served on was wobbly, so whenever i tried to fork something my plate tipped over.  Thank goodness nothing spilled onto the table.  We wanted to try some absinthe at Absinthe, but it felt a little too early in the morning to start hallucinating.  Instead, we opted for some bloody marys, which were also nicely balanced - sweet, salty, tangy, spicy.  Exactly what I want from an early morning alcoholic drink.  Overall, it was a great experience.  I would recommend getting there early because the place gets packed on the weekend.  Also, be prepared to wait for the food - the waiters like to take their time with service.

rqSxYeg7oA7vA9KC49wfPA.review_text: I'll admit right here, right now: I'm not an uber fancy gal. I don't usually get super dressed up in my girly heels and head to a shmancy spot in Hayes Valley. But when I do -- and head to a place like Absinthe -- something about the ambiance, food, drink and overall company find a way to perfectly complement one another. Also, I'm a Top Chef groupie, so I'll wear my girly heels if it'll please the likes of Padma Lakshmi/Tom Colicchio & co. ;-)  Food:  Ordered spicy fried chickpeas (cute, not out of this world), garlic pretzel (wish it was bigger! so good) and fries (OK but could have done without) for starters. Entree: 1 ordered coq au vin (good but super heavy, should have gone with a lighter choice), and date got the sole, which he devoured before I made a dent in my dish -- apparently, it was awesome!  Drinks:  Ginger Rogers and Sazerac, FTW. I'm a bit of a lightweight, but if you can handle yours, go for both, and date to try a third.  Would love to come back and work on some smaller plates, especially that mac n cheese.. gimme..

qWOqPXPcaz_vz_ki2n1I8A.review_text: Let me just say that I've been trying to eat healthy and exercise and all of that good stuff. I needed to drop some fat and look good in general but the driver was my 20 year high school reunion. I've been so good at watching my treat intake that I've even surprised myself.  So, when my friend brought me here for brunch as a surprise, my initial reaction was "Oh no! There goes my self restraint!" But that quickly changed to, "I should treat myself for being so good!" And that was the start to a great day. I completely enjoyed and had whatever I wanted. It was all so delicious... One would think we were having dinner by how many courses we had: drinks, a starter, our entrees and then dessert and coffee.   We had reservations on OpenTable and were seated promptly in a cozy corner booth. I like the space, very airy despite the dark wood all around. The table was a little small and we were close to our neighbors--cozy but we didn't need to talk over eachother either.  Oysters with some bubbly was a nice way to get our appetites going. I was definitely ready for my Croque Madam (with the egg) -- oh it was so good. The bread itself was to die for. I don't even remember what the bf ate because I was so focused on my own plate. We also ordered fries (due to peer pressure) since everyone else had them on their table. Well worth it.  After savoring and eating all of my breakfast sandwich, I was ready for dessert. I had the figs and ice cream and bf had some cheeses. He was sooo happy. We both were.  So why 4 stars and not 5? Well, we had our dessert and then were kind of "dropped". People forgot about us and we had to call to someone to get water and coffee refill. It's like dessert didn't matter. And we had a show to go to, so we needed our check and couldn't find anyone--our waitress had disappeared.  Overall, the meal took about 1.5 hours with most of the lag from the dessert point on... Would go back, but when I don't have a show to go to.

rVs5Ttf3TcjX952G289c9w.review_text: I probably don't need to add to Absinthe :-), but I loved my experience here. Great food and great service. I got the Swordfish and it wasn't too heavy. I highly recommend the Galapagos drink though - quite delicious and featured in 7x7!  My one quip (which they have no control over) is that none of the servers are French :-(. I came for Bastille Day, expecting to celebrate with fellow Frenchies (which I did within my party), but not with the servers. Oh well, I'll still be back for you, Absinthe!

sZCLIvqhKPXZimcpey5p7g.review_text: Hubby and I have had Absinthe on our list of places to eat for a while now. Imagine my delight when I saw they were participating in Dine About Town 2009! Hooray!  We came for lunch today and were greeted by a very friendly hostess. We sat at a small table in a corner near the bar. We each ordered the french onion soup. Hubby got the mussels and fries and I ordered the croque monsieur. The DAT Menu included seasonal sorbet for dessert.  Our soup was fantastic- piping hot, with delicious melted cheese and  a sourdough crouton on top.  Mmmm... Our entrees were amazing as well. The portions were GIANT- but we managed to finish every bite. The fries that came with the mussels were perfectly crispy and managed (somehow) to not get soggy in the broth from the mussels. I honestly said, "This is CRAZY food" (and I mean that in a good way).  The only downsides were that the service was slightly slow and, we didn't see Chef Jamie. Nonetheless, I'm dying to come here again- the food is crazy- not kidding!

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: Does Absinthe make the heart grow fonder? Not particularly but maybe absence does since I haven't been back to Absinthe in close to a decade. Funny thing is I pass by it all the time and see how packed it is with the pre-symphony crowd. Either them or the garden variety douches into volume level contests like a room full of Rob Fords. The bar scene is hopping even on a weeknight but with a discernibly older crowd like the mouthy overweight woman behind me wearing a beret. With her diffident male companion in tow, she kept wondering out loud when I was going to vacate the bar stool and kept heaving vodka-infused sighs hoping I'd leave. I didn't. Yep, I was at the bar not drinking but looking to grab a bite since it's been such a long time. The menu didn't look hugely different from my last visit, standard French bistro fare with West Coast twinges of flavors (photo: bit.ly/1aLCnN7). I wasn't looking for anything fancy really, and I've had the burger once before, so... But before that, I was in the mood for a little starter thinking some mixed greens would be nice until my gaze targeted the $9 Crispy Skin Pork Belly, which were pan-seared slices with a maple glaze and a green apple & Bosc pear chutney (photo: bit.ly/17DFKv0). It was good eating and ever so small a portion to justify being in the "Snacks" category on the menu. As I was fending off the predatory breath of the woman with the beret,  I received the $15 Absinthe Hamburger, which got bumped up to $18 due to a couple of extra toppings I ordered, a fried egg and melted Gruyère cheese. The medium-rare Angus beef comes from Storm Hill, and it came with baby lettuces, red onion and a slathering of aioli on a soft bun (photo: bit.ly/181BeXA). It was pretty satisfying for a bar-bite dinner, and it was surrounded by a passel of bistro-style French fries that were irresistible to finish (photo: bit.ly/181BeXA). In the local burger wars, I would still rank this slightly below the $11 Basic Burger just across the street at Chez Maman partially because Absinthe charges for a tomato slice, heirloom of course. Kudos to the ever-patient bartender. FOOD - 4 stars...the 2nd-best burger in Hayes Valley & the pork belly is tasty, too AMBIANCE - 3 stars...nice bar (photo: bit.ly/18GINxh)...quite a torrent of tourists and locals come into this darkened place, so the douche factor can be high SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive despite the distractions TOTAL - 4 stars...Absinthe may not make the heart grow fonder but it makes the belly grow fatter

N8wsEh3_NTUwm4kNp1pLHA.review_text: I am really into the 7x7 Big Eats and Absinthe is home to the garlic pretzels. Which may I add are worthy of being on the list. They were delicious. Unfortunately, they give you 5 which really annoys me when I am at a dinner of 2. THEY SHOULD GIVE YOU AN EVEN AMOUNT SO YOU CAN SPLIT IT EVENLY!   Also, the garlic pretzels are delicious and you will definitely remember them...especially when you are going home to make sexy time and the aroma of garlic pretzel is in your face. So get the garlic pretzels with a mint mojito.

Qumkkx8MXTkBBxkYNxoozw.review_text: I've been to Absinthe many times over the years, and love that it's such a reliable standby, and that it serves late. This past visit seemed better than ever all 3 of us loved our entrees (delicious gnocchi with mushrooms and ramps, leg of lamb, and mac n cheese), and the two salads we had were also fantastic (mixed greens with rhubarb, the other with apricots and burrata). Look forward to many more visits ahead!

OO7v2zxAQbkj432uve08ow.review_text: For those obsessed with the latest and trendiest places to visit on friday nights, might find Absinthe to be a true goldmine.  Besides being located in a hip neighborhood, it's one of the most posh places (relative to the others you'll find in Hayes Valley) you can find.  The food is more than enough to satisfy even the most food obsessed junkies.  Stop by and check it out if you're in the neighborhood.

7cFFt45RmuXHgimgP3PgUg.review_text: I was, admittedly, basking in the glow of a recent engagement and 4 days in San Francisco when we came here... But even 3 month later two things stand out. The Ginger Rogers cocktail was a little too good, and the beef tar tare was an excellent introduction to a dish that neither my fiance nor I had ever tried. Service was just fine, and we were happy to pay what we did sharing several items and drinking as much as we felt like.

rsusUomr1--LF_3qE3EN2A.review_text: A great dining experience. Love the wine and cheese selection. A classy place to have a drink and snack before going to see the symphony or opera. Make a reservation because its hard to get a table for dinner. I went for lunch, recently, and really enjoyed it. Had these deep fried chickpeas, some amazing paté, and these really unique pretzel with this crazy cream sauce.   I recommend the Lamb Ragu or the potato crusted cod. Steak tartar is awesome.

jwsHpBdMMhYkzv3B81s9vg.review_text: The hostess was AWFUL and rude for a Saturday brunch. We came in because of the gorgeous atmosphere and menu and was looking at the menu on the door... She came out and yelled "watch out" as if she didn't care if she hit us with the door.   We then tried to get a table - she said do you want the tall table with stools? We said no - can we had a regular table or sit outside... Silence. Ignored. She went on with her computer like she never asked us anything and we didn't answer.   She the proceeded to say "did you see any tables empty outside? Go out there if you want to sit out there". You're the hostess, help us out. Do something.   Rude and doesn't care if youre alive let alone helping you find a table. Avoid the petite blond with black glasses. She'll ruin your meal before it is even started.   I assume the foods good but we'll never know.

cCsSUhyHaTuC1QoxuigVyw.review_text: Looks like lots of reviews were about brunch and not dinner. Maybe brunch is a different story but dinner? There's nothing to rave about. My dinner experience was mehhhh. I had dinner with a group of friends for a birthday celebration on a Friday night. The place was packed but we had reservations and did not have to wait long to be seated. I ordered a corn soup that was way too sweet (tasted more like dessert), sea bass that was over cooked and a chocolate dessert that tasted like it was from a buffet line.   For the price I paid, I would've expected better.

o_TYuE5dgTRk8arQQpEroA.review_text: For brunch I am usually a fan of the sweet stuff (French Toast, Waffles, Pancakes, etc.), but for some reason when I came to Absinthe my eyes naturally gravitated towards the savory.  Started off with the French Onion Soup Gratinee ($5). Definitely savory. This soup would be magical for a hangover (at least for me, since I love ingesting sodium if I am recovering from a night of drunken debauchery). Wonderfully onion-y. Then I ate a Grilled Cheese & Heirloom Tomato Sandwich ($14). One word: pesto. Pesto + mozzarella, who could hate that combination? Comes with a side of arugula salad. Ate the whole thing. We also had a side of Fries ($6) to share between three of us. The smoky ketchup was unique. In a good way. Ended the meal with a gorgeous Pumpkin Pudding (forgot the price). Pretty sure it was seasonal, and it definitely tasted as beautiful as it looked.   'Twas a wonderful dining experience, and I love Hayes Valley so the loc is a cherry on top.  I'll be back.

lIHjiSHyUg6NlCciaw-CCA.review_text: I had been to Absinthe many times for drinks but was never fortunate enough to eat there.  Finally happened last night, and I'm kicking myself for not eating here sooner!  First of all, their drink menu and wine list are phenomenal.  But that's not surprising with a name like Absinthe.  Ambiance in the dining room was trendy without being pretentious, and service was great.  We started off with the pretzels (heaven!) and then followed up with a few of the share plates.  To be honest, the entrees didn't really appeal to me, so I'm glad we went this route.    Hamachi crudo - soo good and fresh.  The pickled strawberries were unexpected but totally made the dish. Beef tartare - better than when I had it in Paris! Burrata - hands down our favorite dish of the night.  The burrata was super creamy and was complimented so well with the figs and flat bread it came with. Scallops - sauce on this was so good, but a little to salty for my taste  That being said, this is a great spot for a date or nice dinner out with the girls.  The pretzels, tartare, and burrata will have me coming back here for sure.

O_2kV9sxczt8yxkjpdXO0g.review_text: A little Pricey but great with friends.  Initially I thought it was a place for an older crowd (55 and above) but I was surprised to see a lot of  younger( 28 -35ish) people for Friday dinner. We were a group of  8 people and we all ordered the classic Absinthe drinks, the girls ordered a cocktail and the guys went for the slowly dissolving sugar block over a glass. We ordered a round of starters- cheeses and share plates The bill was 400 (50 per person) and the chit-chat over dinner lasted for 90 minutes..was fun!

CeIbx69_FGn4QCb-7u5R7g.review_text: Came here for brunch a couple of months ago.  I had a pretty traditional breakfast of eggs, meat and biscuits and gravy.  A fruit plate on the side completed the feast.  The food was fantastic and the drink the bartender made was tasty even if I can't remember what was in it.    Hopefully I'll make it back for dinner some time.

OmnFXovjCVVlqhPt9TU2gA.review_text: I've been here twice and my first experience with the place with place was perfect. Totally a five star evening. The cocktail list leans to the tad daunting side, but there's history about them, which makes it fun. The food in a single word was "superb". Done properly, great plate presentation and texture was fantastic. I wish I could remember exactly what I had off the top of my head what we had to eat that evening to tell more about it.   The reasoning behind the quartet of stars comes from my most recent experience with the place. It was an afternoon of soaking in what little sunshine we get here in the city, and in our stroll my friends and I decided to stop in for a bit of a cocktail hour before we went our separate ways for the day.  To be succinct, visit the restaurant for the cocktails they do, not for something you've had before. I thirsted for an Aviation, and my friend Wanted the Corpse Reviver No. 2. For the both of us, they were failures. I'm by no means a cocktail snob, but both of these are classics, with very distinctive profiles to them. I did contemplate the idea of sending the drink back, but in watching the bartender make it, their process was questionable at best. Creme de Violette is a finicky spirit to begin with, so a little goes a long way.   On a more positive note, our server was fantastic. She has the patience of Job, and our group really needed it.   Nevertheless, I will be back again, but for wine, lunch and dinner. Only on a night where I'm looking for a touch of absinthe to my drink will I give the bartenders another go.

8Z9ugoA4MGwiJVh-CB8bhQ.review_text: Absinthe is one of those places that we have passed up a zillion times while always meaning to try out. Well, we finally got around to doing just that the other weekend for brunch.  Brunch options were pretty solid and they had the standard offerings; French toast, grilled cheese, buttermilk pancakes, omelets but also offered raw bar of oysters and plates of various cheeses.  Service was a bit slow but perhaps that was because we kept peering through the menu when we were in fact ready to place our orders.   I ordered the Heirloom Tomato Grilled Cheese w/ macadamia nut pesto which had a side of house made potato chips and a cocktail. He decided on an order of 2 Eggs Any Style. My grilled cheese could have used a bit more cheese and the potato chips were crunchy, oily and cooked just the way I like it.   I'll need to come back to try their dinner menu.

o2-AfewuBHYfSDBVfs13tg.review_text: As a repeat patron to Absinthe, I just fall in love with the restaurant over and over again. The food is superb, the ambiance is inviting and a bit mysterious, with the green devil on the mural giving a nod to your enjoyment.  My dining experiences here have been nothing but fantastic - my favorite entree on the menu is the decadent duck breast. Even the french fries here have a special kick to it. The lunch menu is similarly satisfying - the plate I get often is butternut squash pancakes - so buttery and rich with flavor.   If you are just hanging out for a drink, try the Spanish coffee, and watch their skillful bartenders set it ablaze, and afterward you can still taste the smokey aroma from the drink.   When I have an out-of-town guest, I always bring them to Absinthe to demonstrate the quality of SF cuisine.

wCtf5_zG8EpWiBp_Oi7P0g.review_text: Pernod Absinthe & Champagne to start your meal off??? I mean come on, with a restaurant named after that magical green elixir, would you expect anything else???  Well all of the decor and pictures inside this place all have a touch of green or absinthe in them, and I am a big big fan of themed restaurants and bars, especially now that absinthe is finally legal in the US!!  And why else should you go here??? BEST FRENCH ONION SOUP EVER. I mean that. After going to Paris, and having what they call there "onion soup" because duh, you are in France, so you wouldn't call it "French Onion Soup" there! I thought I could never come across French Onion Soup that compared to the ones I had there, but Absinthe, you are now my one stop shop to bring me to French Onion Soup heaven. It is pure bliss. That cheese just melts in your mouth...every single morsel you want to savor...you even find yourself picking off some of the cheese that got baked onto the soup dish because it just is that amazing. I could eat their French Onion Soup every day if cheese didn't have that many calories. And the onion amount and flavor of the soup itself was just spectacular. If I had only had one bite of that soup that wouldn't be enough because once you start eating this soup, I promise you, that you not only will need to be prescribed some sort of medication because you will form an instant addiction to this soup, but you will find yourself completely content the rest of the day just for having tried this soup.  I feel like I don't need to say much more than that, but since I love food, and obviously you do too for reading yelp reviews here it goes. My Dad after biting into one of their in-house made pickles said, "WOW" and just stared at the pickle, thinking that maybe the pickle would do something magical since it tasted to magical in his mouth. He said it is the best pickle he has ever had, and let me tell you, he LOVES pickles. He was however, pretty disappointed in their crab salad sandwich...even saying that it deserved 2 stars which is pretty low for my dad....  BUT my french onion soup and my croque monsier sandwich definitely picked up the slack the crab salad sandwich left. My dad ate half of my sandiwch because that soup and sandwich had so much delicious delicious cheese in it, I got full pretty quickly! My brother LOVED his hamburger as well, but really fell in love with their french fries which have to be ordered on the side, but with different dipping sauces those bad boys are almost as addicting as the French Onion Soup is!  My mom got the crab legs and a salad and she left brunch that day saying how incredibly prefect that brunch was for her. How it was exactly what she wanted, and exactly what she envisioned. Although after one of those Death in the Afternoon absinthe cocktails, maybe we all enjoyed are food a bit more than the average person :-)

li85I9BtJme3KAmN02CzEQ.review_text: Lovely place for romantic dates to after theater cocktails. With lots of tasty snacks it is a place that is hard to beat, though I am sad they of all places in SF does not have a proper chocolate soufflé.  Best: location, ambiance and champagne list Not Best: Friday and Saturday nights, stake and parking

XrzkP-EPpql8cis-GlQ57A.review_text: Absinthe was just as good this time as it was the first time I ate here-- which was a few years ago.  The bar itself is casual too with a great selection of wine, champagne and cocktails. It's a cozy spot with a friendly and welcoming staff in trendy Hayes Valley.

3yE70xRQlAaEMKTT2SbpQQ.review_text: A delicious cocktail completely ruined by a self-absorbed pretentious arrogant bartender.  The kind of guy that would prefer to be called a mixologist instead of a bartender.  Good old fashioned jerk who successfully managed to lose customers with his bad attitude.

cZNFT2n8nNNOG8z-OTKTMA.review_text: came here for cocktails & desserts, so I can't vouch for the food.  I had an amazing cocktail there, if only I could remember what it was called, what it tasted like, or what the hell was in there?!  tried to go on the website but they don't have their cocktail menu posted... sigh  Also had the warm chocolate banana tart, which is absolutely orgasmic (and I rarely use this word, so that's saying something.)  I would come back just for this alone!    Plan on going back to try more nameless, absinthe laced, delicious cocktails and the food, as I hear it's amazing.  ps, my experience there was slightly tainted by this super stuck-up couple that was sitting at the next table & kept shooting us annoyed "holier than thou" looks.

vQ6VAfbyEnanyJaBKZqQBQ.review_text: The place is packed on Saturday nights. Reservation would most certainly help!  The bar area is pretty busy and loud, but the restaurant is pretty cozy and romantic. This makes the restaurant a perfect spot for a date.  The menu has only a few items. This is usually the case for good French restaurants. However, no matter what you order will be delicious!  And, if you have never tried Absinthe, this is a place to do so.

-OU03Zo-XY4f-IUu0opnOg.review_text: We had amazing service and every bite was delicious!

qiHO6hv6CMI7B-e6g1ewRA.review_text: Had lunch here the other day: pulled pork sandwich.  Wow!  It was a taste sensation.  It came with super yummy housemade chips that had the right amount of crisp, salt and taste.  Also had the lemonade.  I'm always reluctant to get lemonade because it's usually way too sweet and once in awhile too tart.  Just like Little Red Riding Hood, this lemonade was just right.  I'll definitely be back.  Oh, service was excellent, too.

eIJ4nVGAPzawxkVDY3-v0w.review_text: We had Opera tickets and decided to have a drink at Absinthe first and come back for dinner after. We left our car with valet. It was lucky we did as there was a problem with our car, it wouldn't turn off! The valet, Adam,  when way over and above what you would expect and really helped us out. It was a stressful evening but when we finally sat down to eat around 11:00  we were delighted with our dining experience. The Swordfish was the best I have ever had, not dry the way it often is. The quality of the cheese on our Hearts of Romaine salad was exceptional. The restaurant was very busy and our waiter had his hands full but still made us feel well taken care of.  The drinks, naturally, are very good. Mine was potent and pleasing.

aIFbo8WaP6SCuOFnj_v9kA.review_text: We had dinner here last night and every dish from starters to share plates to dinners and desserts was impeccable. Great care has been taken to present beauty on the plate and to present the highest quality ingredients and flavor combinations. The drink menu is creative to say the least and their selection of single malt scotches is most impressive.  Congrats to the kitchen!

ohaDoWFHHEv3Z2uM5SJpUw.review_text: Absolutely, hands down, my favorite place to eat in San Francisco. Whether you get a table in the dining room or get food service in the always busy bar, you'll be treated to the best food and drink in town. My wife swears by the freshest, cleanest oysters she's ever had along with their signature Galapagos drink, while I have never had the same meal twice. Just the best.

BtJDvVNwHVGrWy5qzhE4Ow.review_text: Driving around Saturday looking to grab a bite and a drink. Trying to get from downtown to La Mission. Now we normally don't drive around in a car. We are either on bicycles or the motorcycle so when I get caught up what I can only assume is regular SF Saturday traffic I start to freak. Working our way around I saw a parking spot in Hayes Valley and was at my mild breaking point so when I saw a spot I grabbed it. Not knowing where we were going all I knew was I would rather be walking. BAM, good old Absinthe. this place has been though many changes (chefs) over the years and I have had some not so great meals (but never terrible) and some incredible ones. Well a few cocktails, two killer apps, their famous burger and a roasted chicken breast plate, topped with a Pot de crème and all traffic anxiety was gone. Window seat, Great service and excellent food. Cant go wrong at this old standby.

K-PtK3gDicUeLXYoJmDKWw.review_text: Went here for cocktails and snacks. The cocktails were delicious. The meatballs had a nice kick to them. The pretzels and cheese plate were tasty too. We'll need to go back for a proper dinner.

f7e96Iodfmapqm3C_lrDcw.review_text: Lovely little French bistro with a delicious brunch menu. Started with the seasonal salad and had the pork belly with spinach and mushrooms.  In my fantasy world when I dream of moving to SF, this is my new brunch spot.  Someday.

JA4Rw3qdKuGDCFbexnbN5w.review_text: Came here for drinks.  Got lucky and was able to snag two seats at the bar as two other people left.  Unfortunately, I can't recall the two drinks I ordered, but they were good.  I did order something w/ absinthe in it, and as the bartender warned, it did taste like black licorice.  I'm not a fan of black licorice, but it had other flavors as well.  They have a very extensive menu of liquors, including whiskys from Islay.  My friend ordered one called Ardbeg Uigeadail (I think it was $21 a glass!), which she really liked.  It's a very smoky whisky.  She liked it so much that she ordered another one for our second round.  Bartenders are constantly moving and busy but still give good service.

Xm2ffEJ4xkZxThiCX6IsRA.review_text: service is great. Food was overall very good. The French onion soup was best I had in a while. The steak frites was pretty good, could use more sauce. The Coq Au Vin was delicious that my boyfriend ordered and the cocktails were good as well, nice and strong! I would definitely come back, I want to try it for lunch, especially the burgers

LoRQeclsYws6ysbjHG4bUw.review_text: My husband and I came here the night before New Year's eve and it had a wonderful, energetic vibe,despite the fact that it was only 6:00.  We enjoyed everything about our experience here.  We lingered at our table for quite a while, had a couple of drinks and appetizers, and our waiter couldn't have been more accommodating. He came to our table often enough, but not too frequently.  He was a nice, mild-mannered man who had great suggestions if we had any questions at all.  The cocktail list was amazing, my Atlantic char was cooked to perfection, and the sides accompanying both of our dishes were just as flavorful as our entrees.  Absinthe is my new favorite restaurant and I can't wait to go back. If you're looking for a less expensive night out, I've heard that their burger is one of the city's best.  The lively bar scene is also reason enough to come here - check it out.

WGVRnbgyxQL4FLZpXf7uXw.review_text: Simply put: each of the other 4 star yelpers and their reviews of Absinthe are spot on. I agree. I take away 1 star only in that the DB level, at times, can overwhelm the attention to service, presentation and selections.   Indeed, the restaurant called us a day before to remind and confirm our reservation at 7:45 pm last week.  Understated elegance - farm to fork quality! Charming.

04uthiThQnJo1fDI2bJlVg.review_text: What a treat to stumble upon. After a day at the museums, then parks and some shopping in the neighborhood this old school bar hit the spot. Unique and classic cocktails plus a basic menu that can cater to any palate. It's 5 o'clock somewhere, right?

ISmg-wBIqe6v09ShLN1-uA.review_text: A great pick for a saturday brunch spot. It was obercool! Hubby and I tried: Warm biscuits, buttermilk-sausage gravy, sage, fried eggs & Grilled marinated vegetable sandwich (with) eggplant, onion, red pepper, zucchini, goat cheese, olive spread. The biscuits and grits were exceptionally good!!  Definitely making this a brunch staple from now on! Oh and not to forget this place is such a great date spot :)

Gm9oaB6ps0CK27Hr4FT-Pg.review_text: Went here on my birthday a couple of years ago. Very nice place, with a very friendly and courteous staff.  I had the beef cheek which was good, but not excellent. Also tried the actually liquor, Absinthe for the first time. I think it's slightly over-hyped, but not bad. The rest of my party reported high reviews for their food.  Although my food experience here wasn't AMAZING, it was certainly good and the overall experience was thoroughly enjoyable. I would definitely recommend this place.

gNo9-GB5vSy2yS7wBP-8AA.review_text: The food here was delicious (seriously, my duck was amaaaaaazing and the drinks were pretty good. However when I went the service was shit.   The hostess called my sister's phone, but she was standing right next to her and didn't notice her. My sister didn't hear her phone because we were inside RIGHT NEXT to the hostess, but she gave our table away anyway. I'm sorry, how do you miss a 5'11 woman with bright purple hair? We had to wait another 20 minutes or so just to get a table ready and by then it was 5pm and we had to leave by 6:15 to catch "The Book of Mormon" on time. The hostess didn't even say anything and she kept talking to the blonde lady with the side bun who continuously kept looking over at our table. Yes lady, you are not very slick when looking at people.   The waitress we had told us she would rush everything for us and would give us the bill after everything was put in. We waited about 15 min for appetizers and then it took another half hour for our meal to come. In the meantime my friend and I had ordered another drink after placing our food order, but it hadn't arrived even after we demolished the appetizers. We inquired about it and she blatantly forgot our drink order. She seriously said, "Oh yeah..do you guys still want them?" Well no shit we want them if our food wasn't there yet. By this time, my brother was not the most gracious, but that ticked him off even more.   I understand the restaurant was busy and that we had to be in and out very quickly, but I have never been so annoyed with people in my life. I'm the type of person who tries to be nice at restaurants 'cause you should never piss off people working with you food, but holy shit was I irritated.

x0gL91jGCsbUqyGoaEmlEw.review_text: Oh dear, when I think of this restaurant my heart just melts.  I went here two nights ago with my girlfriends to celebrate my friends' 25th birthday, and we ordered a couple of things. I tasted the: -cup of white asparagus soup -whole-roasted golden trout -beef tartare (the whole table shared this)  I have to say ever since I left this restaurant I haven't stopped thinking about the beef tartare. I'd never had it before, so I was a little unsure of eating raw beef, as well as tasting a bit of the quail egg yolk that topped the beef slivers, but oh. my. goodness. It was phenomenal! Really well seasoned, and had a stack of crostinis on the side. I'm sure beef tartare is generally really tasty, but Absinthe just steadied this standard.   Now, for the soup I got- so so creamy!! I'm not someone who normally orders asparagus, but this was off the charts! It was just perfect! The oil drizzled over the soup was a great complement, as were the delicious, perfectly toasted croutons that were placed in the middle. Just so warm, and creamy, but not too creamy. It really gave me the feelings a warm fireplace would.   The trout, erm...eh, was not great. Honestly, the trout on the plate wasn't really delicious but it was just blah..just okay. Everything else on the plate was the only thing that kept me eating the trout. Basically, there was a huge flavor imbalance between the trout, and the other things on the plate: the tasty mushrooms, haricots verts, (I believe it was asparagus) puree, and zingy lemon-beurre noisette. If not for those, I don't know how I would have been able to eat the bony, bony trout alone.   To add, I had a spoonful of the risotto, and that tasted pretty good too.  So. Order the beef tartare, but steer clear of the trout -very clear. Its not worth the mercury or the money.

IG9oulUO-tprUZOY4jfG3g.review_text: Why are my only celebrity sightings culinary figures?  Hubert Keller, Alice Waters, and now Jaime from Top Chef.   She over to say "hi" to my friend and I at the bar when she saw how excited we were to see her.    Oh yeah, we got food there too.  Frisee salad, flatbread with ricotta and greens, and spicy fried chickpeas.  All delicous.

dFOrIGfOz50GVFJfRRxqjg.review_text: Was in San Francisco for the first time last week. After a long day we had reservations here and was very excited to go.  I started out with the French Onion Soup which was amazing. On this alone i would give it 5 stars.   My GF had the fried Chick Peas which weren't that great. Very bland and not much taste to it.
