I had the Coq Au Vin for dinner and it didn't disappoint. It was excellent.  My GF had the Veggie platter, which I didn't think would be a great choice and it wasn't. It wasn't bad, but not mouth watering.  The waiter was awesome. Very nice, informative and caring about how our meal and experience was.  The only downside was how slow they bring your next course..  This is why I didn't give it a 5. I would def go back again if i Lived there.

lfp_Wa0GCjgpInSpBB9Jsw.review_text: The hostess was lovely; our server, Natalie, was uber professional; and the table busser was great.  Unfortunately, however, our brunch experience at Absinthe fell short in the food, beverage, and sanitation categories.  We both ordered a dungeoness crab sandwich and shared the dandelion green flatbread.  The flatbread was yummy, but the sandwiches were lackluster at best.  The fresh, flavorful heirloom tomatoes were the best part.  The fact they were more or less devoid of crab-yumminess was a bummer; but they were served on dry haogies, which was more disappointing.    My boyfriend inhaled hoagie particles (from the inside of the bread) twice... you know, because it was the sort of bread that doesn't have enough substance to hold itself together or toast in a way that would yield a slight crunch or resistance as teeth meet crust.  Correct, there was no crust to speak of.  We agreed perhaps the downturn in the economy has forced Absinthe to Safeway's bread isle.   We both had a Bloody Mary. (No, we don't always order the same thing; he had coffee and I didn't ;)  The drinks came in 8-10oz glasses and must have been filled 3/4 with ice before they were poured.  There could not have been more than 4oz of liquid in them.  And for $9 each, that's kind of a joke.  But, more importantly, they were watered down.    In my opinion, a Bloody Mary should be flavorful, meaty, and packed with a punch (flavor-wise) - not necessarily super spicy, but its gotta have zing!  And when it's the first thing I've had all day, I kind of expect a tiny buzz in my head or in my knees.  So, they were weak... and flavorless, and if you don't want to take my word for it, my boyfriend was equally disappointed and he's in the know... tended bar for 10 years at two well-known establishments in the city; and worked with Marco, who was the original bar manager and wrote the cocktail menu for... you guessed it... Absinthe!  Oh, and the Guardian voted one my man's cocktails Best in the Bay in 1998.  I digress...   The drinks were disappointing.  And so were the remnants of red lipstick on my water glass.  Ick.  Sorry Absinthe :(  Oh!  I should add, we did say something about the bread... and our drinks were taken off the bill.  We were very impressed - good business, but given 2 stars = "meh, I've experienced better," we can't add a third for that.  We have definitely experienced better.

RQ2ZkfsL4C-5G449Qrv_Ww.review_text: I've always been a fan of Absinthe for good, strong, drinks and fine wine. Having never ventured past the bar, I went here for dinner with my brother and father. My brother and I started with 7x7's 2011 ranked "soft pretzels"- which were nothing short of amazing in my mouth. They're great with or without the dijon-like dipping mustard, which proves the sauce isn't too powerful because I usually HATE dijon.  My father had the french onion soup and romaine hearts salad for dinner. He devoured them and claimed it was delicious! My brother, too, loved his  Absinthe Burger, and needed to be reminded that we were in a nice restaurant and to "slow down!" He seemed less impressed though with his fries, as he left most of them on the plate- which is rare for a boy of 19.  I ordered the duck with apple-turnip puree and a side of brussels sprouts. It was excellent! Tender, flavorful, and the puree was a true original. My sprouts were a solid size accompaniment and grilled up perfectly. Not only did I coax my brother to try the duck, but he exclaimed it was "awesome!" A true compliment from a boy who would only order "the burger" in the world's finest establishments.  This place gets hoppin' with an older crowd, and reservations are probably recommended. We arrived around 5:30 without one and waited a mere minutes before we were seated, however had we gotten there a half hour later I doubt we would have found a table.

qkreXL6AorI19QA3f2wvlQ.review_text: I went here for brunch and ordered their breakfast sandwich-duck egg with bacon on a pretzel roll and a butter salad.  It was delicious!  Their Absinthe Lemonade was something I've never tasted before.. Who would have thought that lemonade with cranberry juice and ginger ale could taste so pleasant!  As far as service, they were informative and for the most part friendly.  My friend had some questions about their menu, which included substitutions.  The waitress said that this was a "fine dining" establishment and they don't really do that.. Which in that case, they shouldn't have "Brassiere" in their name as it stands for establishments that are casual and moderately upscale.  But, I'd come here again for lunch or dinner to see what other items they have.

q24tuTbr2MuvbYT5eHSG9g.review_text: My fiancé has been trying to find time from our busy schedule to surprise me.  Unfortunately, I beat him to the punch and said, "oh since we're in the area Absinthe is around the corner we should check it out, and he said, I have been planning to take you here".  Our original plan was to try a German  pub around the corner before we head out to our planned mini concert.     With no reservations we walked in to see if there was any seating available.  Host sat us right away.  Service excellent.   Got also a recommendation for drink of choice: sacred heart,  great cocktail not sweet, tart taste - tequila with lemon flavor after.  Fiance - COQ AU VIN  he was not pleased with his order.  He called it chicken stew.  Took a bite of his order.  I conquer that it is chicken stew.   Myself - BISTRO FILET my order was the winner.  Pre sliced filet with mashed green potatoes with grilled asparagus.    The fav was the appetizer  Soft garlic pretzel and marinated olives.     I think if we were to come back we would try the cheese and the famous absinthe burger.

jsT60G6Jqtj30vGkGercvQ.review_text: I had dinner at Absinthe Brasserie & Bar with some of my friends. It was a wonderful dining experience. The staff is friendly and the food was great.   I started my meal with French Onion Soup Gratinee. ($5/cup) I had the Market Vegetable Plate for my entree. It was comprised of  a phyllo-crusted sweet potato,  porcinis, yellow corn, sugar snap peas and roasted-onion buerre blanc  ($26). Generally I am not a fan of vegetarian plates but I thought this was a delicious entree.   For dessert, I share the Black Forest Cake. $10. It was an amazing dessert. It has dark chocolate mousse, poached cherries, whipped yogurt and almonds. My friends and I also had the Peaches and Coriander Cream, $9. The presentation was lovely. It has poached peaches in jam, a yogurt cake and coriander granola.    If you enjoy Port. I would suggest having "Quinta do Infantado", $8.

33kf1WtP9CaUjr9BwSLWiQ.review_text: Food was absolutely great! Oysters were good, as was the chickpea appetizer. Butternut squash soup was very good, as was the burger and sole. For dessert, Lemon tart was great flavor and texture combined, as was the pot de creme. Server was very attentive and personable.

dTcYw_RuYUm-j83emwDnUQ.review_text: We came here with reservation for Sunday brunch. Immediately recognizing it is a popular spot we were willing to take the chance on waiting for our eagerly anticipated entrees. We ordered a starter which came out promptly, but as far as our mains it took a long time. But none of us minded the wait because we were in a great atmosphere with great conversation.   Once the food arrived, it was well worth the wait. :)

bz_0BMpBUbc5gytIZY-URQ.review_text: Very enjoyable dinner.  Good service, and the foods was delicious.  I had friends in town from Dallas, and they they thought the food was fabulous.  We had a very nice table in the back room.  If I could give 4 1/2 stars, I would.   We didn't have a reservation so we had a wait, but the bartenders were very accommodating, so we didn't care about having to wait!

H2xQ1WAfb5FkFXW-ESc6AA.review_text: We had duck ragout again which was excellent as before and tried pork belly. Similar to duck ragout, the slice (yes a single slice) came with eggs. The slice was wonderful, crisp skin and soft, right amount of fat and flavor. It's pricey for the quantity obviously so I'm torn.  Got bergamot tart which had wonderful presentation. It tasted like lemon pudding with mint granitas (crushed ice) on top and earl grey (bergamot) . Good but not that special.

oPtRDUZ64wIMn7DAgHynwg.review_text: This place was an very high energy spot when you walked in through the bar.  Vibrant, Great Ambiance, The bartenders and waiters are moving fast, so you have to keep on your toes.   Then if you are lucky enough to get a table in the far Street Window side of the restaurant all of the sudden it becomes a comfortable quiet little french bistro, its great to have the choice. They are dedicated mixologists there, so expect to be informed, which is good. The Food was quite clever, I couldn't quite put my finger on what the exact Fare was. ...... Menu items like Rabbit Stew and Skirt Steak at first confused me.  Then As I was walking out the door I came up with the description "Fancy Faux French Peasant"   Its a good place

nos7eU-naFk32w15RwvDRA.review_text: Delicious food and great atmosphere. Can be a little loud, but there are 2 separate rooms and I think one is quieter.

X-Gbr9BbEKYebFndMCkGyA.review_text: Food is yum but a little generous on the salt!

fdpFROzbxlCCSIo-xrkEsQ.review_text: Kinda the worst service. Seated for 10 minutes before we had to ask for a server. Twice. We finally rose to go elsewhere when a waiter showed up. He gave us attitude for not being patient. On our way out, the Hostess asked us why we were leaving and made us stay to tell the manager, who did not care at all.

16q6Ck6_WIlq3L0WTaODkw.review_text: Oh Absinthe.   You'll now be in my memory for the rest of my life since you're the location my man and I told my parents we were affianced.   After learning of this, the staff was cute - there was champagne, and special congrats written in chocolate on our dessert dish.   Besides the service, the food is great. Menu changes regularly, but their delectable snacks remain the same. If you go, you MUST try the spicy fried chickpeas. Hear me? MUST.TRY. Their fries and pretzel are also good munchies. All perfect appetizers, or an after-show bite for the post-symphony/opera/ballet crowd.  Just thinking about those spicy fried chickpeas makes me want to run down in my PJs and get some (it's almost 11pm).   Mmm.

yuf6wR5yEE2fsp_plpGHGQ.review_text: If I lived here, this would be a go to spot.  We decided to go here on a whim, just looked at what was nearby and amongst a few choices decided this looked good.    It was a Saturday night, valentine's weekend and there was an hour wait for cafe seating, reservations for the more formal areas were booked.  The cocktails sounded amazing so, we decided to wait.  The cocktails were excellent.  I had two different bourbon based cocktails the first was a special and delicious.  The second was the scarlet o'hara. no complaints and they also have a great absinthe selection.  We lucked out after only a half hour and got a table in the more formal dining area.  The ambiance is great, lots of red in the seating, wood and tin ceiling.  The food was almost to perfection.  To start we had the Hudson Valley Camembert.  The maple walnut bread they serve with the cheeses is almost candied and excellent.    I had the coffee crusted seared duck breast.  It was cooked perfectly, full of flavor and the apple-turnip puree cut it nicely.  My date had the niman ranch skirt steak, also cooked to perfection.  Both meals were just the right portion sizes.  The black garlic mashed potatoes with the steak were a nice take on potatoes.    We shared two deserts: The Chocolate Pot de Creme and the German Chocolate Cake.  I think we are both picky desert people and we had no complaints, and definitely some praise.  The German Chocolate Cake was a wonderful mix of textures, cakey on the outside, molten in the middle and a wonderful almost crunchy layer of pressed coconut on the bottom.  Service was excellent, our waitress was clearly knew but if she didnt know something she handled it beautifully, checking on a few things she was unsure of and was also very attentive.

JjqDGZUwz0aCAPG8PjmFqA.review_text: It's all about the Absinthe Burger!  Usually this place is packed and there is a 30 minimum wait. We got lucky tonight and got seated right away.   My other half loves to be seated in a warm area and he was quite happy with the choice of seating area.  Brb dessert has arrived!

ZS_SiPpiLocKfYNjRZTeww.review_text: Popped my snail: the escargot was fantastic.    The wine was excellent, service friendly and the Absinthe burger enjoyable, especially with the spicy mustard I requested normally reserved for the special dog.

l_Ryvd4KwvqtoMKxNclj_g.review_text: Not bad at all!  I went for brunch and I had blueberry pancakes-which I thought were seriously amazing, and an omelet...forgot what was in it :0)  I also had the absinthe lemonade and it was actually very bitter and sour, not sweet at all. The food came in a timely matter and hardly anything was noticeably bad.   BUT I had to park far and there's a convenience store close by with homeless people outside asking for change. One of them tried to scare me to and from absinthe :\ not cool.   Oh and for anyone who doesn't quite know how to say absinthe in the french tongue , it's pronounced "ab-sont"

9CWr1HukCWdjW-5zTCXVIA.review_text: There are times when it feels like I'm looking in on my current life with the lens of me as a kid and I think, "damn, I wanna be her when I grow up"   And then I realize.  I AM HER!  Yay!  Dinner at Absinthe with a Certain Someone followed by seeing his favorite opera made up one of those nights  Dinner was absolutely wonderful.  We shared french fries to start and they're AMAZING.  Then I had the scallops, which were large and positively heavenly.  The service was subtle and efficient.  And they even had a table for us even though we were 30 minutes late (bonus points for the host complimenting me on my fabulous red jacket).   I do want to go back for brunch....just to tease the little girl me and say look how cool my life is ;-)

plOtZruZJ-rxF7VCgeS40A.review_text: An excellent place for a weekday lunch, since it's quiet and uncrowded.   Fine, elegant food, and the cocktail menu seems amazing.  Had the Galapagos, which I can confirm is quite a treat.

41nlHIIkh19ENWF8X2_CRA.review_text: Oooh, I'm still dreaming of the French toast.  The butternut squash pnacakes were also excellent.

J485RScpVw3nN6KfJVIsOA.review_text: It was my first time eating at Absinthe Brasserie last weekend. I had heard from a few friends that the food was quite good and that I needed to check it out and I do not regret following their advice at all!   The food was very well prepared and SO flavorful. To be honest I hadn't had such a flavorful meal in a long time and it wasn't for not trying. We had the chicken liver mousse as an appetizer, then shared some gnocchi and the monkfish, and ended with a milk chocolate mousse dessert with salted caramel sauce that was to die for. I also ordered a pretty decent rhum cocktail that our waiter recommended.   The chicken liver mousse was really well made. It didn't have too strong of a liver flavor but still was plenty flavorful. The gnocchi could have been very boring as it seemed to be a pretty simple dish but it was amazing. The sauce had mushrooms and some herbs in it that just flavored the dish perfectly. The monkfish was equally good, although it had really different flavors. The fish was very fresh and served with a delicious potato mash. Although the portions didn't look plentiful, we had more than enough. I just wished I had kept some bread to dip in the sauces remaining from our dish.  I was hesitating in getting dessert as I felt pretty satisfied and from my experience sometimes dessert just ruins a good meal because they are not at the level of the savory dish. I took a chance with the milk chocolate mousse and I was pleasantly surprised. It was a perfect way to end the meal.   Service was also excellent. Our cute waiter was polite and smily and knew just when to come to the table.  I will spread my good word about Absinthe and hopefully get to come back soon!

lOMM7HTHhabi1qofd-w7zw.review_text: I love my little bit of French in San Francisco. Absinthe is open late, serving primarily locals and the symphony crowd, and has wonderful prompt service. They tend to be quite busy around 11pm, so just make sure you don't mind waiting for a minute, but in my mind, those few moments it takes for them to clear a table is worth it.  Even food to go there is worthwhile in my opinion. I wanted to eat light, considering the time I was wanting to consume food (way too late for me to eat just about anything) and so I ordered two of their delicious sides. Roasted beets and a wonderful bok choy with a little EVOO and garlic. Sounded perfect. Except that when I went to use their restroom, the server came and found me, explaining that because their evening had been so busy that the beets were no where to be found anymore. I opted for their thin crust mushroom pizza instead. Carbs. Yeah, I know. Not ideal as one of my best girls would say. Just not ideal. But I was hungry, and at some dirty dive down the street. I was interested in some sort of luxury to balance my bizarre evening out.   The pizza was wonderful, light, thin, flavorful. Lobster mushrooms and goat cheese, with the perfect amount of each, piled (literally) onto a petite eight inch pizza, just perfect for one person, me. Salted greens adorned the top. I thanked the staff, said my goodbyes to those working there who have mutual friends, and began my brisk two block walk back to the bar, pizza in hand. I consumed most of it while walking, making sure to carefully shove it into my mouth while darting inbetween relentlessly crazy cabs, so as not to drop any of the salty sweet goodness. Love the back kick of the mushrooms after you've gotten through the cheese. Just really fantastic.  Walking back into the bar, barely any pizza left in hand, I sat down and began to drift back into the scene I had been previously engulfed in. Thanking my lucky stars Absinthe was there to quench my need for foodie satisfaction. I looked around and realized that without my salvation break of the pizza, I would have been slightly annoyed by now with the hipsters. But it's amazing what sixteen bucks will buy you these days. It bought me peace of mind.

UNbRVJql-hopPSuvYmsDmQ.review_text: Oohhh la la! This place is super intimate and romantic. We went here for dinner on my birthday and I must say it's the perfect date night spot!  Totally made me feel like I was in Paris or what I imagine being in Paris would feel like, since I've never been.  We enjoyed a bottle of wine, the food was delicious and the service was great.  Definitely would go back!

tGkfSO_bRpXsSI1JYv1wQQ.review_text: I'm torn about dropping my review from 5 to 3 stars since I'm a regular at Absinthe and have been since I moved into the neighborhood 3 years ago. Since my first review, I have frequented Absinthe for cocktails and cheese and have probably tasted a good 80% of the cocktail menu by now, as well as stopped into too many times for dinner.  With the departure of two of their great bartenders and the (soon to be? already happened?) departure of head chef Jamie Lauren, a recent visit to Absinthe for dinner with friends this past weekend gave us a mediocre experience.  The cocktails were still very good, so I'm happy to say that the departure of two bartenders hasn't harmed Absinthe's reputation in that category! :)  We took ordered the marinated anchovy bruschetta as a starter since it was new on the menu - 2 orders since there were 4 of us and the waitress kindly warned us that one order was 2 slices. The beet puree smeared on the toast was far too sweet, almost like a jam and covered up any hint of the anchovy. The burrata that covered the top was even worse - bland, formless and tasteless - it neutralized the dish even more. We were all extremely underwhelmed and this was a huge disappointment since I have never had ANYTHING that underwhelmed at Absinthe.  We all ordered the french onion soup which is still good, but after my recent trip to Paris, I'm biased against American-made french onion soup ;)  Their were some new entrees on the dinner menu, but nothing that sounded tempting, so I got the pork confit, which I first reviewed 3 years ago and is one of my favorite dishes at Absinthe. Something went wrong. The pork wasn't tender and melt-in-your-mouth. The corn grits and shredded greens it sat on top were way too salty. Two of my friends got the perogies which were okay, but nothing to write home about. Other friend got the bass and he said that was okay.  I'm terribly disappointed that the food at Absinthe has taken such a dip in quality and inventiveness. I'm not sad to say I won't be recommending a dinner at Absinthe as a must for my visiting friends, nor will I be coming back here for dinner anymore.  Absinthe, you break my heart because you've simply become my cocktails and cheese stop in Hayes Valley :*( How will I replace you?

uOL2aGpVgUONh0Kvgy_DYg.review_text: This is simply one of the best deals in all of San Francisco. It is $$$ food for $$ prices. There are more "cutting edge" and "noveau" places in SF, but Absinthe is rock solid and consistent. It's always good. And it doesn't require a two month advanced reservation.  Also, went for brunch recently. OMG. This is my new go to brunch place in the city. I had no idea they had such rockin' dishes....and can you say MIMOSAS?  And if you don't know, their bar is the bar that set the standard in mixology. The reputation is well deserved.

i-6V2FjscqbcZh9VbsFwFQ.review_text: Great wine based cocktails, don't miss out on St. Martin ! Really liked the ambience.

EK9hrg3OVV9KS6qLbMFvsg.review_text: Service is great here, the food is fresh and good, very nice bar. I went with a group of 6 friends and we all agreed this is a special place. I'm going back.

xNHqdNOwosu6PRMYnEJP-g.review_text: I had just a few days with my girlfriend in the area and we came here twice. By contrast, we don't go to the same nice restaurant for cocktails twice in the same 6 months back in Boston.   Drink wise note to others: Absinthe tastes like minty, burn-y, concentrated hatred.   While having a mixed drink with it sounds compelling at a place by the same name, pass on it unless you enjoy drinking hatred. If you do, good on you. Otherwise, get an incredible drink with a proper brown liquid as the main attraction and you won't be disappointed.   Two notes: anyone showing up for a meal and having sticker shock didn't go in with the right expectations. This place is not cheap. The meals were incredible however - not a dish had was bad. Make the date worth it by prepping for the price.  Last thought -- I went back and forth on the 4 to 5 stars. The drinks and food make it a 5, the layout is definitely a 5, but the service when accompanied by the price keeps it back down at a 4 in my experience.

mLiGZsGKUZo5tGh_BdXtwQ.review_text: It is a "dine about town" review. This is a really nice and expensive place, but very reasonable for dine about town. They give u a big table and the service is great. From the dine about town menu I ordered the croque (delicious) and my date ordered the grilled cheese (it had fruit in it, and interesting taste). We also got some Spanish cheeses from the menu, which for $10 for 3 tiny slices is very expensive, but insanely delicious and rich in flavor. And last and surely the best part: the dessert. It was beyond what words can explain. It was rich, fluffy, and full of flavor, and we were given a large portion of it. Great place for dine about town. I do want to try it someday for its real menu.

uYFz9ITmzqome2xfq-kkhQ.review_text: Great drinks and fun atmosphere, friendly server and staff.  Great spot to get a drink and just hang out.

qzzc4HmrDOV--wK_TK-vLg.review_text: I really like this place! Heard about it from a coworker and passed by it all the time when taking the 21 Muni to work. I came here with my sister on a Thursday night and we just walked in (no wait at all). We ordered: Tome de Bordeaux - goat milk cheese that was pungent, but delicious! Seafood Ceviche - came with salty yucca chips, but the avocado/guacamole was fantastic. Bacon-Wrapped Whole Trout - I loved the mushrooms in this dish! And you can't go wrong with bacon-wrapped anything. I got the Wonderlust cocktail, which I also really liked! You can definitely tell that there's absinthe in it, but I thought the other ingredients in the drink blended well. For dessert, we got the Bergamot Tart, which was amazing! I love Earl Grey anything, and so I was very happy with it. Will definitely come back!

C69qzK8C7cxntmdSALgrAQ.review_text: French Onion Soup - it's a "must try" and did not disappoint.  Croque Madame - TOOOOOO heavy.  Buttered bread, then topped and grilled with cheese and egg on top.  It's a bit too heavy to consume.  Yelpers didn't alert me of how HUGE the portions were....I'm a big eater but had to take more than half my sandwich home!  The food's just okay, I had a croque madame in La Jolla and that blew my socks off...so here....ehhh probably wouldn't order it again.  Probably wouldn't even come here again.    Just okay...not WOW.

-QwKiVrUR7K8nmpdQUpvgw.review_text: With over 1000 reviews, there's not much more I can add about the food (which, btw, is DELICIOUS!).  But if you're thinking about hosting a dinner party, I cannot recommend Absinthe's Private Dining enough!    I had never been to Absinthe before, but I took a chance on hosting my party there after sifting through many restaurants on Yelp :)  Working with Absinthe was so easy - their private dining coordinator was able to figure out all the details with me (seating arrangement, menus, wine, valet, etc) through a few emails and phone calls.    The day of went very smoothly.  I loved that the private dining room felt like having my own restaurant - it has its own entrance, own bar, bathroom, coat check - it had everything! The menus were all customized and there's a sign right outside the door that tells guests what is being celebrated.  I won't say much about the food except that everyone finished their plates - and I mean everyone! (I was worried that some of the family friends who are older and only prefer Chinese food would not like the food, but clean plates everywhere!) The sea bass wasn't dry and came with amazing risotto, and as far as I could tell, everyone enjoyed the stuffed chicken and steak frites.  It was difficult to decide between the Chocolate pot de crème or the Crème brulee - but that's the beauty of sitting around friends: you get to order different things and share!  Umm, speaking as a chocoholic - the Chocolate pot de crème was like heaven in a bowl - YUMMY!  The night was really special for me because I was surrounded by family and the best of friends, but with the friendly staff and ease of the planning, I couldn't have imagined a better place to host the dinner than at Absinthe.    THANK YOU, Absinthe!!

rrgfL6g9R-Qzd-nYAUfa3A.review_text: My friend suggested this place, because she had been here before and she absolutely loved there brunch/lunch menu. I trust her judgment when it comes to food. She is a person of great taste. The place was packed and it was only 30 minute wait for our table. However, the table was very small and too close to each other.  I ordered the wild mushrooms omelet, my friend had the ricotta stuffed french toast and deviled eggs to share.  Everything was so good and mouth watering. I enjoyed every bit of it. We finished everything on our plates and washed it down with white peach bellini and mimosa.   Although we enjoyed our food very much but the service was horrible. Our waitress was nowhere to be found when we needed her. She was too busy chit chatting with other employees. Other staff were attentive and nice but they weren't our waiter...Lindsay was. She was unfriendly and rude when she took our orders. I will be back and hope I will not get her as my waitress.  4 stars for the food 1 star for service-Absinthe should thank Lindsay.

1UKab-nmvbBoyp6y6f052A.review_text: The menu is extensive, but for brunch there is just a petite selection (I think about 5 items?  ie. Pancakes for about $12- albeit really awesome pancakes that makes you think, "That hit my dessert craving too.").   My out-of-town friend and I enjoyed our Bellini and never empty mugs of coffee.  The service was quite friendly and there was no wait for Saturday brunch because of plentiful seating.   I had a flashback of Pastis a few years back in NY... Except here, folks are wearing Northface puffy jackets and hiking boots, which is typical SF fashion hehe.  We're all on our way to a hike anyway.

P4Lq9fJE7mFHekGj7hMuVQ.review_text: Maybe I'm just on a losing streak lately. Or maybe it's the time of year. Maybe it's the moon. Whatever. But it seems that there is a sudden rash of really awkward service wherever I lay my head (or actually, my butt in a chair or banquette). And I'm sorry to say that Absinthe, despite many wonderful years of food and drink, has been lately providing some itch to that rash.  A brunch reservation. A quick seating at an out-of-the-way corner table. A friendly welcoming server. But then....the dirty spoon with my coffee. The water glass with vivid lipstick marks. I sigh: it's a Saturday busy brunch, after all, I should cut some slack, right?  the cocktails come, and they are delightful. There is a little wait on one out of the three, but the waiter swings by to apologize. We toast. We sip coffees. We chat. We order.  And then we wait.  And wait.  And wait.  Now, I know there are always times when kitchen time and front of house time get out of sync. But when I wait a full forty minutes between placing an order from a three-top until our (very simple) orders come to table, I feel a bit miffed. Add to that the dirty spoon & water glass, and I start to think: "what is going on here?"  The food was, as always, delightful: onion soup, frites, duck confit hash, smoked sturgeon, a cheese plate, all as delicious as always. And I can't say that the service was poor: our server was affable and accessible, although the lack of comment or action or apology on the wait was unsatisfactory. And when the couple at the table beside us was seated -- and served -- during the waiting period we had, it didn't help me feel great about things.  Nevertheless, I still love Absinthe. But I would love to know that the next time I come with a reserved table, I can assume my food will arrive before the next mealtime rolls around on the clock.  Food? Four tasty stars! Ambiance? Four comfy stars! Service? Two cranky stars!  Overall? Three gentle, long-suffering stars for Absinthe!

CyQlabNTX0OnnosYgkPKnA.review_text: Wonderful original drinks, beautiful space, delicious food, good location, good service. I love this place. A little on the expensive side but you are paying for beauty, class, well trained staff, a wonderful bar and excellent food,  in this neighborhood.

uZ4aSRiIX8fjiXOcpUXrWg.review_text: The good:  -FOOD: The menu had the perfect amount of items; enough for a variety, and not too many that I sat there going O.O uhh what am I going to eat?? And as soon as I saw the Duck Confit Ragout arrive at a table next to ours, I KNEW that I just had to order it; and let me tell you, it tastes even better than it looks! Poached egg+duck+mushrooms+savory sauce+chive/potato cake = YUM CENTRAL! Five stars for food.  -SERVICE: This seemed like the PERFECT place for a nice Sunday brunch, and I'm so glad we arrived before the rush! We didn't have reservations, but we still got seated right away, and the service is SUPER nice! One of the girls in our little get together showed up an hour late, but we weren't rushed to order or give up our seats or anything, which I'm very thankful for ^^.  The not so good:  -DRINKS: I had the Absinthe lemonade, which was good, but nothing amazing... one of my friends had the Bellini, but she couldn't taste hints of peach at all, and neither could I when I tried it :/  Overall though, if I'm ever back in SF, this is definitely a top contender for brunch :) my tummy is very happy!

8bxzT_IAk3n4i94ZdJ4VBQ.review_text: Absinthe holds a special place for us.  We had lunch here following our city hall wedding 2 years ago.  They treated us like Kings that day and have ever since.   The food is VERY good, and the cocktails are BETTER!  Great mixologists and quality booze.   They do have some of the best pomme fritte in town.    Best thing about this place is for our wedding lunch and every anniversary visit since, they've bought us dessert all fussed up with "happy anniversary" wishes.

tSKGejZuR8E7OGLckX4-8Q.review_text: Kind of like a tacky French brasserie... Pseudo authentic interior decor, steep prices for average food buuuuuut:   Extra star for knock you dead cocktails!   But overall no Balthazzaar. Go to Soho! Now THERE is some cote du boef.

W8daOj5qhUhajT5GS8tR_w.review_text: It's not an everyday stop but we definitely enjoyed our time here and will probably come back soon enough.  Started with the famous pretzels and cheese and an amazing oyster that blew my mind, I really should have just gotten a tray of them. The pretzels were soft and worth trying with the cheese sauce delicate enough to not remind you of well...cheese sauce, it was great.  We had the potato crusted char and I think halibut. Very clean flavors and well cooked.  The only disappointment was the drinks, we came and expected to have some fun strong drinks based on their reputation and ended up with small and weak drinks that definitely did not stand out.  Probably won't come back for dinner as the appetizers/small plates impressed me much more than their entrees. I'll definitely be back for their bar food menu, probably brunch.

c8FOqDRhtL7q_YsQio6bog.review_text: I absolutely adore the classy look and feel of this Hayes Valley brasserie & bar. Their cocktails remain among the finest in the city. There's clearly a reason why Absinthe continues to survive and thrive in this ever-growing cocktail-centric city. Hell - their cocktail/wine list alone weighs about 10 pounds, and is a 30 page read!  And although I still appreciate their fine libations and food, I was less than thrilled by the snooty, apathetic bartenders working tonight. My friend and I saddled up at the bar around 5pm. After 10 minutes of being ignored by the bar staff, we finally asked for a cocktail/wine list. Even after our simple request, it took another 2 minutes or so for that to arrive. It's a bar with a famous cocktail menu, after all (don't you think they should have a few cocktail/wine lists on the bar?). After perusing their extensive beverage options, I finally ordered an Old Pal (sort of a variation of a Manhatten). The drink arrived a few minutes later and it was liquid perfection. These guys clearly know how to make great drinks.   But still... the service was so undeniably cold and detached. Not once did the bartender ask how we were doing or if he could get us anything else. Even when he delivered the drinks and we said thank you, he just sort of walked off. The too-cool-for-school attitude was really noticeable and really tarnished our whole experience. I'm paying $10 - $14 for a cocktail at your establishment. So don't make me feel like a jerk about it.  In any case, if you can stomach the cold service, I would still recommend coming here for a tasty adult beverage. And make sure you order some of their fried chickpeas. These tasty goodies are more addictive than crack.

w7CvXX2dtmPCm67TRJw7kQ.review_text: Absinthe is highly highly highly recommended for brunch. Book ahead, and try and get a table in the side room. It's much quieter and less crowded over there.   The service is spot-on. The cocktails are to-die-for (seriously, they have some pretty fly bartenders there). The brunch is fabulous, particularly the side of bacon. Seriously, I dreamt about it for many nights after.   I had the eggs benedict on corn cakes, and this hinted back to my mother's deliciously buttery corn cakes. The corn cakes actually stand up to the poached egg and hollandaise sauce better than english muffins, so I'm a new convert.  And don't forget the side of bacon. I certainly haven't.

kZnSGYEx0mLVGroGtZiXIA.review_text: * SERVICE:: very friendly and attentive  * AMBIANCE: Art Deco---classy  * FOOD: - French Onion Soup= soooo good - Chick Peas cooked in spices= interestingly delicious - Absinthe Burger= the meat was overcooked an dry (asked for medium) - Portebello Grilled Cheese: greasy, but yummmmy! - Fish(forgot which one? mahi or cod?!?---forgot to finish to review back in April)= whatever fish it was, that dish was DELICIOUS!!!!!! - French Dip: meat was a bit on the dry side, but the au ju(sp?) sauce made up for it - Garlic Pretzel appetizer: yummmmmy! freshly baked

98kge3NovzBHx61kPyIMSg.review_text: The bartender was AWESOME! He knew his stuff and was great at suggesting drinks. He makes them strong, but not overpowering, and he will gauge your alcohol preference before he makes your drink. It seemed to be the case for the other bartenders as well.  The place was very nice... good place for a first date. The wine list is AMAAAAZING. They brought out a BINDER for the wine list.   Drinks were a bit pricey, but on par for the location.

Qmx4WRromALhyN2Rhv6jWA.review_text: Honestly- the best dinner I've ever had. So delicious.

AwzHTqmQp-iU2wan6lyfzA.review_text: Great food.  Great whiskey selection.  Great service. Had the duck leg confit and did not reget a single bite!

5yJZkmlvuZUwDqCkCMtvnQ.review_text: Popped into Absinthe before the San Francisco Opera's Tosca matinee yesterday. Cute as a button corner brassiere was packed to the rafters for brunch, but two seats at the bar opened up before we could even make our way to the hostess.   I started out with a Sazerac (what else would one drink at a place called Absinthe I ask) and my companion had a Bloody Mary. Both drinks were good.    On the bartender's recommendation, I ordered the Duck-Confit Ragou and my friend opted for the Levain French Toast. Both were superbly executed and quite delicious. I especially liked the layered textures of the Ragou- crispy/crunchy cake, shredded duck, fluffy egg and creamy sauce. It was an excellent choice.  While my friend stuck with traditional cocktails, I explored the specialty menu. The Ginger Rogers was not nearly gingery-enough for me. It tasted like a gin mojito, but a good one at that. The 21 Hayes was a delicious, refreshing cucumber-gin concoction that I would order again in a heartbeat.  All in all Absinthe offered good food, drink and company on a busy Sunday. I'd definitely return!

omuL_vZ57i65EeLgLeG_4g.review_text: Brunch w/a girlfriend- Solid Drinks at any time- Stellar  Appetizers (and drinks) w/ a cute date on a Saturday night- Memorable ;)  I seriously heart you Absinthe!!!

FnerkhXZy1M0pgappwZ1TQ.review_text: This review is based on my experience having dessert and drinks. I came here since it was in close proximity to Dobb's Ferry restaurant. The other plus side was that they serve Absinthe, which is my favorite alcoholic beverage. Absinthe can be very busy and noisy. On a busy night sitting at the bar, you can be sitting shoulder to shoulder. (which I experienced) The only downside to this place is that they only have a few Absinthe specialty cocktails. I had the blackberry cheesecake which was fantastic. Absinthe Brasserie can be a great companion with dinner at Dobb's Ferry.  Great social scene, friendly bartenders and a great atmosphere.

gwiGnfRc88htvkyIRyCsIQ.review_text: A rainy day can make for a dreary indoor stay, but brunch at Absinthe in all its old world European charm makes it all better.   My fellow brunchers and I dined on a few savory plates including french soup (c'est magnifique), hearts of romaine, grilled cheese sandwiches with macadamia pesto, tomatoes, and mixed greens, and the Spanish chorizo fritata.  And we shared and shared and shared.  Coffee and the Absinthe lemonade made the rounds.  Yum!   For dessert, we split a St. Honore dessert with ice cream, chocolate, pistachios, and pistachio mouse on some kind of rice crisp bed of chocolate. Lightly sweet.  Perfect.  We lingered a little in the back of the restaurant until it was time to go home.  Thank you for feeding our hungry bellies with some of the tastiest food we've had in awhile.

GoN2IT-E20RHvCMuEH_hSw.review_text: order their duck. It's good!! pricey but good!!

vASaF47nWvCHEEDA8nfCVw.review_text: Came here to catch up with a couple of old friends for their oh-so-famous brunch only to get disappointed by the extremely low satisfaction : price ratio. Put another way, for the price that we paid, I really didn't have that great of an experience.    The food was mediocre at best - I had the $4.50 teenitiny soft boiled egg  which was for the most part hard-boiled, and a $7.00 "large" french onion soup which was served in a bowl no bigger than an 8-oz Philadelphia cream cheese container.  Regarding the soup, it's just as well the serving was on the smaller side - despite the beautiful presentation, the congealed cheese and strangely viscous broth made the soup inedible; I didn't even finish half of it.   The service, while courteous, was extremely slow.  We had to wait for 35 minutes before the food was served.  Good thing we weren't in the mood for a long, leisurely brunch (save for the need to feed the meter) or we would've been terribly upset.   And what kind of a French establishment does not have french press coffee? Thankfully Blue Bottle kiosk was only half a block away - we made an executive decision to pay a visit and get our post-brunch caffeine fix.

vpggRco6kp195nTP3FIDwQ.review_text: Wedding reception brunch was world class!  Easy walk from city hall ceremony.  Fun, custom menus featuring 'Skoda' greeted us at the door, super friendly wait staff and knowledgeable barkeep.  Fun Toulouse-lautrec genre wall painting, intimate room - perfect for our part of 15.   Food was three star Michelin quality.  Opened with a stunning fennel and leek soup, with a hint of lemon creme fraiche, some tiny tiny fried leeks on top with brioche crouton.  I had the arctic char, served with the smoothest butternut squash puree on earth, a bit of savoy cabbage and some white wine and mustard seed sauce and some rutabagas..  After the main event we enjoyed four artisan cheeses (including a nice pungent creme cheese, Humboldt fog, an English blue and some cheddar) and sublime french chocolate pot de creme (wow!)  The lemon cake (lemon curd filing and cheese frosting) was served with the lightest mint ice cream ever.  We will be back!!

gNzC6OJIdRlSkEQIZuP8QQ.review_text: three words: BLUEBERRY SOUFFLE PANCAKES  I don't usually like having only sweet stuff for breakfast/brunch but these were the best pancakes I've had: fluffy, and melt in your mouth goodness. it'll leave your tummy with the satisfaction of knowing that it has been able to enjoy something truly delicious that ain't so great for the body. oh well, you only live once.

hkHkvgNklP236_fs4d9iCQ.review_text: i love this place!! great drinks and great food.  i initially came here for a private party they had appetizers and drinks. the food and drinks were so good for this event that i bookmarked it to come back for a true meal experience. so if you're looking for a venue to host a little party, they do a great job here! they even have a separate room/area with its own entrance to make it more private and quite than the normal dining hall.  i came a second time just for a drink. the bartender was very unfriendly and every unenthusiastic or helpful. when we asked what he recommended from the classic cocktails he gave us such a vague bland generic answer i should had just closed by eyes and pointed randomly at the menu. he seemed so bothered by us coming to the bar and ordering a drink from him i'm glad we only had time for one drink. i wouldn't want to have to spend a moment longer around this guy or BOTHER him anymore than we needed to. the drinks were fine. i wasn't as impressed as when i cam for the private party. we had old fashion and sazerac.  i finally came around a 3rd time to have a sit down dinner with drinks. IT WAS AMAZING.   Drinks: for drink i had the uptown manhattan. LOVED IT. i will come back just for this. one of the best manhattans i've had. my BF got an old fashion which tasted much better than the bar visit. maybe a different bartender?  Food:  french onion soup- BEST FRENCH ONION SOUP EVER. i dont even like french onion soup. for two reasons 1) most are super salty 2) the cheese is usually one giant chunk and not that great. absinthe knows what their doing when it comes to french onion soup. ORDER IT. TASTE IT. LOVE IT. and do it all over again YUM  beef tar tar- very fresh with an egg on top. not super flavorful when it comes to herbs and spices etc. but just the right balance so you can enjoy the fresh ingredients.  garlic pretzel- this was good but not great. i wouldn't say its a must order. i could go to the mall courtyard and get a pretzel. but the sauce was yummy to dip with!  osso bucco- SUPER YUMMY and tender. they even give you a little special utensil so you can dig out the marrow from the bone and enjoy that as well. DELISHHHH highly recommend   coq au vin- had no idea what to expect when ordering this because i've never heard of it before. but when it came out it was like a chicken stew? came in a iron pan with lots of gravy/sauce surrounding it. it was great to eat with some bread. really flavorful and had unique flavors that i never excepted. if you're looking for something saucy. order this!  burger- the fries were really good. this tasted like a really yummy gourmet burger. i was so full from eating all the other food that i couldn't finish the burger. i took half of it home and ate it for lunch a couple days later and it was still good. the patty is really well seasoned and full of flavor and the bun was soft and yummy. i just got it plain with no added toppings and that was plenty burger enough for me.   overall i really enjoyed the dining experience i had here. highly recommend making a reservation as this place is very super busy. especially because its near all theatre, symphony, etc. definitely a MUST TRY and wanting a good meal with a good classic cocktail  i would give this place 5 stars if the bar experience was as good as the dining experience. i saw previous yelpers mention that they also had a not so awesome bartender. minus 1 star for the bartender  I WILL BE BACK! YUMMMMMM

d_OB-N712nDq0Yyv5hMO1A.review_text: Absinthe is your classic consistent mainstay. The drinks are powerful and staff is always on their game. Their croque monsieur is always on point. For a classic delicous cocktail or bloody this is the place to go after a late night. The clientele is super diverse with a locals sophisticated feel

XmBm3C-Y7TKHuMoEMO5AtQ.review_text: After trying to get in to Absinthe numerous times, only to be told they were booked solid, we finally got in on a mellow Sunday night......and it was fabulous. We were looking for a light dinner, and really wanted it to be delicious. They didn't let us down:  * Spicy Fried Chickpeas to start, yum. * Baby Romaine salad, extra yum with white anchovies. * Roasted Beets, red yum. * Liberty Farms Duck Confit......especially yum with Pinot Noir.  And dessert - Chocolate Banana Tart and Pear Sorbet.  It's been worth the wait, and definitely worth making that reservation early.

tXKTfiUh_3R1En0xYonXdw.review_text: Executive summary:  Okay cocktails, excellent appetizers, fantastic wine picked by the sommalier, very good cheese selections, and inventive entrees.  At a steep price, however.  Foodie details:  The braised beef cheeks were tasty, as was the lamb.  My pork confit, however, was the acknowledged winner on the table.  Wifey's mushroom pasta was a distant fourth---it felt like a halfhearted attempt to put something vegetarian on the menu.  The cheese selection is excellent, although the firmer cheeses were clear also-rans to the soft cheese selections.  The frisee and the country pate were amazing, and Wifey raved about the French onion soup, which is apparently a house specialty.  Unnecessary personal details:  Wifey and I went with another couple who we've known for some time, and who happen to be reverse negatives of Wifey and I.  To wit, with respect to the other couple: the wife is a lawyer and avid horsewoman, funny as hell, loud, and occasionally uncouth, while the husband is quiet, sharp as a whip, and sneakily funny in his own right.  In short, transgendered versions of Wifey and I.  Sorta.  This couple has such a long history with Absinthe that the sommalier knows their taste in wine.  In contrast, it was our first time.  I certainly understand the allure, and the food was excellent.  I continue to struggle with the classic SF conundrum: at this price point, there are literally dozens of excellent restaurants in this city, and I would be hard-pressed to explain what differentiates those restaurants, or why one would go to one such restaurant instead of another.  There are also scores of restaurants in the city that are far less expensive, but serve food that is only moderately less fantastic, and I often wonder if you're really getting your money's worth dining at pinnacle restaurants.  In typical lawyer fashion, I raise these issues not because I have a solution for you, but rather to ensure that you, too, are aware of these problems.  What you do to resolve them falls into the realm of "business strategy," and I wouldn't presume to tell you which resolution to take.  As your counselor, it's my job to ensure you have all the information you need to make a fully informed decision, not to make the decision for you.  You'll get my extremely reasonable bill at the end of the month.  As always, call me anytime if you have questions.

FwkNpN3KLp0WWKxuL_oEcQ.review_text: Went here after boxing room gator food because I heard they make good drinks and with a name like Absinthe I was expecting lots of drink options which included this. However, I was sadly disappointed.   Besides the lack of absinthe infused drinks the bartenders were absent minded about my eagerness to buy drinks preferring to chat with other customers instead.   So lack of absinthe type drinks and being ignored put a bad taste in my mouth leaving me with purchasing only two drinks when I came in to buy 6.

oZIu9tNLcfTmyMKxhKx6qg.review_text: Decided to take advantage of the DAT deal. My friend and I had pork with cooked apples on the side. The dessert was a yogurt with very unique ingredients, but none that fared well with my friend. Next time, I will order everyone's favorite pretzels. For now, I give my past experience 3 stars as I can hardly remember anything good from it. I don't recommend this place for DAT. Hopefully the next time I visit, I can update with a better rating.

DRli7vTj1dDtjRQi9uBtyg.review_text: This place is scrum-diddly-umptious! It's often hard to get a reservation but i've never had a problem when I just show up anyway and wait for a table. I'll sit at the bar and typically get a table within 20 minutes. The food is holy amazeballs! The drinks are innovative and the variety of them goes on and on and on! The bartenders have amazing charisma (Yuri I love you!) and the staff are generally knowledgable and quick. This is my go-to place in my neighborhood and it's never a let down.

fnIhaLLVaw5XMB_fyANCTQ.review_text: Walked in here with the intent of trying absinthe for the first time.  This place was extremely popular.  Diverse groups of people constantly flowed in and out.  At first I didnt see a single person drinking absinthe, so I wasn't sure if it was even on the menu.  Their smaller drink menu does not have it listed.  If you check out their full menu, it is there you will find a long list of varieties, as well as absinthe cocktails.   I did, end up trying the absinthe, which was an experience in itself.   But I think what I would definitely return for is to try the food.  It looked amazing!

p_v5Sh6Ji7wHChOu0eDJAw.review_text: Good service, Good Food, Great Wine.......  My only complaint?? most of the clientele were snooty old folks!!  A bit over priced for the portions, but hey that's the city!

bTIlLPbWNvAZRGKtrSCMAQ.review_text: Had the duck confit, very little duck for the ~$26 dish. The coq au vin was very good.   For the price ~$50, per person with just a main course and a glass of wine, there are better values out there.   We luckily sat in the back as it was incredibly loud throughout the restaurant.   This restaurant also had the highest  (4%) SF employee mandate I have seen.

JXGI1dQwGqfV8tM5qcZMbg.review_text: Was a great night.  Good service and food.  Had a nice table at the window so could see all going on in the rest. + outside.   Party of 6 and everyone's meal was just right. Would definately go back.

0laJN1kt-zz4AfkKB9RRYw.review_text: Coconut Corn Soup. Spicy Chick Peas. Soft Garlic Pretzels. So amazing!!!

aqWXHhcR_CdmKmxggFOlEA.review_text: My revised review...  I take it back!    I went to Absinthe for Easter Brunch and saw a brunch item that I had previously overlooked...  Corned beef!  I guess the magical word "hash" wasn't mentioned so I didn't think it was corned beef hash but IT IS.  And IT IS delicious.  The meal was hearty but not too heavy.  Everyone seemed to really enjoy their food too (my sister loved the croque monsieur).  And honestly, how many places take brunch reservations for 12??  French food for brunch is vindicated!  --------------------------------------------------­---------------------------  This review is for brunch only...  I LOVE brunch but I love a meaty, hearty brunch.  And after this experience at Absinthe, I realized that French brunch/breakfast just may not be right for me.  So, the cuisine probably drives my review more than anything.  I found no problems with the service and found it to be quite nice.  The brunch menu (items with a stronger egg orientation) was relatively limited, and there were no brunch items that seemed particularly compelling.  So I was then forced to move into the lunch category (sandwiches, salads and burgers); sandwiches (even a Croque Monsieur) can be on the small-ish/light-ish side for me, so I went with a burger.  I was quite disappointed with the burger which I found to be mostly bun (and a greasy, focaccia bun at that) and without much burger.  My friend who I brunched with was not very impressed with her runny eggs and sausage.  On the positive, places that take brunch reservations are always nice if you have a large group.  And the place is nice and open.  I probably made two tactical errors - I should've had a champagne beverage (seems as though there was a wide selection) and fries (I had them ages ago and they were delicious).    I'll definitely go back for dinner; French food for dinner is very different from French food for brunch.

cDAdfpWUkpP9BB_aW4qjbA.review_text: Yeah, I just had crazy good food. A few weeks ago I ended up back there and had their Coq Au Vin (red Burgundy-braised Mary's chicken, bacon, roasted crimini mushrooms, crostini, persillade). It was nothing short of amazing. Bursting with actual chicken flavor (not buried under the sauces), buttery/rich red wine sauce but not acidic, little chunks of bacon that were more like a candy reward than an in-every-bite overriding flavor. Oh, and the chicken was succulent.  Check my latest photo.  Times visited: many

zO9Z4y6JbyiMYDplbmUc8Q.review_text: I'm a Top Chef lover so we had to eventually make our way here and try the food.  I have had drinks here many times and love the huge and inventive menu.  For starters we got the country pate and persimmon salad.  The pate was very hard and didn't seem like it was just made, I also could not taste the apricot that was supposed to be in it and what prompted me to order it.  The salad was underflavored, not much more else to say here.  The beef cheeks were amazing, very tender and full of flavor, the sweet potatoes with them were smoky and very aromatic but undercooked.   The scallops were good, the sauce and mushrooms were amazing but they were a bit tough, I've had them more tender and that was what we expected.    We had coffee and no dessert, the coffee was good, and hot which I like, some places just give you something that's just warm and I hate that.    The service was good but a bit rushed, the bus boys were coming by all time to clear the table which was a bit annoying.    I still love this place and would come back, but the execution on some of the dishes needs to be better.  Came here for brunch twice and loved it, a great place to get some amazing drinks and creative food for brunch.  The menu definitely leans towards foodies with elegant and complex dishes that still are perfect for brunch.

hwe8ofQPXY9O9HTbiBrbXw.review_text: To celebrate our 5 year anniversary yesterday, we started with brunch here at Absinthe. We've been wanting to come here for a while now based on the reviews from Yelp. It came as a pleasant surprise seeing the executive chef Jamie Lauren on Top Chef (one of our favorite shows). Because of that, we've been rooting for her because if she does good, then you know the food here has to be good. Good thing she's been doing awesome in the competition so far. We were really hoping we'd be able to meet her because she's been our favorite competitor. Gotta represent the bay!   For starters, I would totally recommend the French onion soup. After reading the reviews here on Yelp and smelling the order of the table next to us, it was a definite must order for me. Hella good! It was really hearty and covered in cheese. How can you not love cheese? Every spoonful was like a cheezy scoop of ecstasy. We also had the pommes frites (fries for the layman's). Frites were aight, they're just expensive fries to me... For our main course, I had the croque monsieur (based on your Yelp recommendations) and Amy W. had the duck confit hash with poached eggs. The croque was the shit. Again, cheese = pure goodness. The Gruyere hit the spot. I don't care if a croque monsieur is just an overpriced grilled ham and cheese sandwich, the croque here was delicious. The duck confit has was good, but couldn't hold a candle next to the croque.   Towards the end of our brunch, to our surprise, Jamie Lauren came out and ended up sitting at the table next us and was chattin' it up with the people there. Soooooo cool. Not that we were trying to ease drop but we couldn't help it. She couldn't say much about the show because of a confidentiality clause, darn. I wanted spoilers. We ended up talking with her a little bit before we left and of course took a pic. She was totally cool.   So, awesome food and we got to meet Jamie. How can you top that?

WORlt-sXf24jb7w27tmi3g.review_text: Friday night in Paris...well the Paris of Hayes Valley.  Absinthe is quaint yet romantic, Europe meets America (our waitress has a southern drawl), French influenced food without any of the pretension but all of the butter.  French Onion soup? Yes, please!  Albacore Poke. Why not??  Bistro Filet?? Definitely!!! Wash it all down with a melt in your mouth not in your hand chocolate pot de creme that was AWESOME (yes in all CAPS and YES it was that good!)!  J'adore Absinthe

5Gg2ii0i1OUjty_s443nKg.review_text: This is the classier, more mature crowd in my neighborhood. I love it though. And they even have Génépy de Alpes! Even if you are on a diet, believe me when I say order. the. pretzels. They're handmade, soft pretzels that come with melted amazing cheese. There are only 6 so they'll be gone in 2 seconds. Still listening, now order the Mac and cheese. It has breadcrumbs baked on top--my mouth is watering just thinking about it! I die. Great salads. Wine list = Bible thick! I love gimlets and I like the 21 Hayes is better than the corpse...? The latter has a Brandied cherry I don't enjoy. Any kind of beef you get here will be amazing, but the burger is a lot more filling than others. Kinda $$$$ though, for the portions. Go for appetizers and cocktails or to eat with your parents!

GvRh9s4sUpSVJYy1U5czKA.review_text: I love any place that tells me the wait will be 30 to 40 minutes, and then seats me in 15.   We went here after seeing the Nutcracker, and this was the perfect spot -- except for the fact that at least a dozen other people also mozied in after the Nutcracker.   The food was great, and they let us order off the bar menu from the dining room. The French Onion soup isn't something to joke about, it's really, really good. The Brussel Sprouts were good too, and you could really taste the bacon.  I would give them five stars, save for:  - The waiter taking away our wine glasses after asking if we want water. Wine and water can be complementary! - The french fries being really hard to eat -- they're really small. Though note the dipping sauces for them were great.   All around good place though. I'd definitely go back.

coEX0WGa92jJZ0Wgn1WRMg.review_text: I used to come here way back in the day for oysters and cocktails.  A meal here and there but definitely only saw a return visit meant for the bar.  However, after drinking at Smuggler's Cove one day last year, I definitely needed some food in my stomach, so we walked down to Absinthe for some late night bites.  The waiter informs us that they just got a new chef less than two weeks ago and a recommended new item on the menu was the pretzel bites, so we give it a shot...OMFG!!  So yummy!!!  The mornay sauce was absolutely perfect for the soft doughy goodness.  Definitely a winner!!  Thank you Chef Adam Keough!  I got a quick kick out of the fact that when I reached for my butter knife to have some carb heaven before our meals got to the table, I realized it was magnetically (or whatever scientific reasoning you want to use) stuck to my fork. I still say, it's magic!! LOL  We kind of stuck w/ the bar food and ordered the Absinthe Hamburger w/ cheese, and the Croque Monsieur. Hamburger was good and, I was told, so was the Croque.  Definitely would love to return for brunch at some point, so hopefully I'll be back soon enough.

fES_Ws1CDBUw7vcTJzr8CA.review_text: Absinthe is great French-style brasserie in Hayes Valley.  I have been here a number of times over the year for lunch and drinks, but visited this past weekend for lunch with my wife, and we had an excellent meal.  I have never visited for dinner, so I can't evaluate them from that perspective.  We dined during Saturday early afternoon, and the 'breakfasty' brunch stuff was in full force on the menu, as well as the more 'lunchy' fare.  We shared two sandwiches- a delicious grilled heirloom tomato & mozarella sandwich with bacon and a mac-nut pesto, and a croque monsieur- one of my favorite sandwiches and perhaps the best that I can recall having in San Francisco.  The tomato sandwich was served with their superb house-made chips, and we also ordered their 'fries'- which are exceptional 'skinny' pomme frites- another item I can say is one of the 'best of class' amongst restaurants in this category.  There is enough variety on the lunch/brunch menu to satisfy a diverse array of tastes- including salads, soups, meat dishes, seafood and more.  In many ways this restaurant compares favorably to Bouchon in Yountville, although it's a tick below, and also a tick below in price.  Anyways, you will be happily satisfied and surely return after you give Absinthe a try.

DLJ1xM8DfFL6oqw_aPvGdA.review_text: Went to this restaurant for girl's night out, food was great, we had beef tartare, french orion soup to start with share. My friend order hamburger for her entrees, but when I try to order mines, the waiter suggest we share one entree too! we were wondering if its enough, cuz it's our first meal of day.  I have to say the waiter is really nice and helpful! share a entrees was good idea, so we had room for dessert and perfect.  Food, tasty! Drink, good! Service, good!

h_2NGTYvjOc38cjx90rM5Q.review_text: Needed a place to dine after the Vagina Monolgues. Absinthe never disappoints. I knew there would be some wait, but it wasn't too bad..   If you're looking for a romantic and quiet location, this isn't the place.. Sure it can be somewhat romantic due to the dim lighting, but it gets sooo loud, it's hard to hear much.   The food is delish.. I has the frisee salad, good to the last bite and Ant had the fries (which he soo graciously shared with us all) The fries were crispy and thin.. just like i love them.. Comes with a red pepper aoili, dijon mustard and vinegar.  Their wine selection is diverse and impressive.. I'll have to visit on a not so busy day..

CGRkejdGiNtvX-lhcOFUZQ.review_text: I came here for Dine About Town and my meal was just mediocre... Food and service were both average.  So first off, $18.95 for a two-course meal is such a steal, especially for a nice restaurant like Absinthe. I ordered the croque monsieur already knowing that probably wasn't worth my money but my friend ordered the pork tenderloin and the other choice, some pasta dish, did not seem appealing to me at all...  Sandwich tasted good, but I could have gotten that elsewhere for cheaper and just as good. Pork Tenderloin was a different story. It was like magic in my mouth... I totally regret not getting this but I didn't want to order the same thing as my friend. Apparently the pastry chef is top 10 in the nation... and the apple pie panna cotta was just "pretty good" for me. Again, I think it's just a preference type of thing. I'm not a huge fan of apple pie, and the dessert was like a deconstructed apple pie.  I mean, if it had chocolate, I'd probably go crazy.  Overall, pretty good experience, but wasn't blown away.

bONVIrUJfbO59R83ZQtoHQ.review_text: I was mostly impressed with this restaurant, with only one minor downfall. I brought my boyfriend here for dinner on his birthday and all of the food was absolutely delicious (and great for a vegetarian like myself.) and we loved the drinks (their Sazerac was amazing).  Although it is an up-scale restaurant, you can still manage to have a dinner for two with appetizers, drinks and dessert for under $100, which is quite less than I was expecting to spend. Unfortunately, the service was not as impressive as the food: I had made reservations and it still took them 45 minutes for them to seat us even though a handful of people walked in and were sat immediately. It wasn't until my boyfriend asked how much longer it would be that they finally sat us.  I'm not sure if it was because my boyfriend and I are in our 20's and he thought we weren't going to tip well, but our 'waiter' was completely inattentive and kind of short with us. It took him at least 10 minutes before he even got to our table and when he did he never even came to check up on us or see how we liked our food. Overall I guess I would say the food and drinks are well worth the price but don't expect to get adequate service if you are young and middle class. I'll probably still end up going back because the food was delicious.

HQkvlSJXBtpkRsVutPem5A.review_text: I've eaten and/or had drinks at Absinthe several times.  They make great drinks, and the food is good.  Every time I've gone, there hasn't been any particular food that has blown me away, but nothing has disappointed either.  Only quibble, the place is begging for a bit of a renovation.

ljmj1Bt6gxM5aEOAwqq9UA.review_text: update: the 'manager' I spoke with, who promised she'd call me on Monday to confirm that the extra charge was removed from my card did NOT call back.  Service goes beyond the table, Absinthe, and you oughta know.

9U30DANobkrn3Zlu6T9p6Q.review_text: Love this place. Came in Thursday night and instantly put this on my short list when I'm in SF. Incredible atmosphere - great scene & vibe. I was baffled by the ridiculously good Fried Chickpeas - how can chickpeas be that good?. The Ceviche & Tartare were both memorable.  I would absolutely come back here for dinner.

Rc6dYVAIrJP4cgF92TX89g.review_text: Delicious meal, fantastic cocktails, great vibe and impeccable service.

aOQzfh9UP31j0RIr1wwXZw.review_text: I have been to Absinthe now quite a few times, but only twice for full meals.  I have always enjoyed the ambiance and fun drink selections.  I recommend this place for tantalizing drinks and appetizers at the bar.  The bartenders are very amusing, well dressed and conversational.  As for the dinner menu, the food descriptions are amazing, but always seem to be a small slice short from how they deliciously they are described.

6-AA014-IT2FJjcEqJBZYg.review_text: The Casino is a very gin forward drink that is served in a martini glass with a salted brim.  Only now, can I surrender myself to the sense of bliss that comes with this kind of abandon.  Simple layers that progressively combine to form a completely tantalizing severity. Made with lemon, orange bitters, and then a splash of maraschino liqueur that sits in the bottom well of the glass.  I like to have at least 3 good sips before stirring my glass to release the deep enticing maraschino flavor.. it tastes much like a pendulum, when you lightly graze the bottom and are poised at the beginning of an upswing.  Every savory second is well worth the gamble of stirring my mood, and ultimately helping for me to decide if i'll be going home alone tonight because it is hard to refrain from having less than a single one.  Crisp, Assertive, and undeniably Refreshing.

tlY0QMQDyfjQAEwHnzvFnw.review_text: First time here for dinner...  Yam and Goat Cheese Ravioli - This sounds good, but actually tastes great...the sweet and sour flavors as well as the soft textures work perfectly together for this version of ravioli.  With a light topping of a butter/sage sauce and bits of brussle sprouts, walnuts and mushrooms on the plate, this was an incredible dish, especially for being vegetarian.  Cauliflower and Snap Peas - They managed to take a simple vegetable dish and make it something interesting.  With the help of capers, pine nuts and golden raisins, the dish pops with sour, earthy and sweet hints for an otherwise boring vegetable side.  Pot de Crème - I've always wanted to try this and it was fantastic - a decadent dessert of rich dark chocolate...who could seriously not like this?  This is a fantastic restaurant and it was great to enjoy my experience for dinner.

3jb4r2jc7iPvaslCveE3gA.review_text: A very charming restaurant in a very charming neighborhood. I came here for lunch and had a very enjoyable experience. The decor was simply lovely and the restaurant had a great French vibe to it. My waiter, Dave, was great and super attentive. The food was very good. I started off with the French Onion Soup and it was fantastic. As a French Onion Soup enthusiast, I was very impressed. I also ordered their Eggplant Sandwich, but was way too full from the soup to eat much of it. The sandwich was okay, I wasn't really into the pepperoncini jam they had spread on it. I ordered a pot of the Jasmine-Mint tea as well. It was really good. I had a great afternoon at Absinthe, and would come back for lunch or dinner the next time I find myself in San Francisco.

5zk5oqnyLH7dahN6fTNtMg.review_text: Stale and funky the place was a yuppy festival from yesteryear... packed and  and just a bit weird.   Got dicked around with tables 3 times. "There's a wait" " no there isn't" "yes there is" Asked for the bar they kept giving us tables until I finally said.. We want to sit at the BAR Bar, the place where they make the drinks BAR... "Oh! We thought you wanted to sit at the bar - (meaning the cocktail tables near the bar! WTF ! Weird.  We wanted to start with Mussels and fries. We got  6 mussels and 6 clams with some rubbery chorizo- $18! Fries another $6! Silly drinks.  Our server was amazing, remarkable in fact.  We dubbed him "he who shall not be seen". He kept coming at us from behind so I actually never saw his face the entire evening even after he brought the check. It was so peculiar we thought it was really funny but again.... weird!  The place had an unhappy corporate vibe to it but hey... it was packed so maybe it was us!  What a silly restaurant! We couldn't wait to get back to Oakland  and have a delicious hot bowl of mussels and fries for  a paltry $8 at Sidebar.

aK6jKRjd3MtwtAWIu5Fu9A.review_text: Had a fabulous and memorable brunch here.   Awesome service - Kristian was the best. Great food,  nice ambiance, tons of cocktails. Overall a fantastic experience, I will be back for sure. So many more things on the menu that I still want to try!

w8flMOM04LfF0175Stp3AA.review_text: Lordy, Lordy, Lordy....one of the BEST brunches I've ever had.      Went with the girls for brunch and it was definitely a place I'd go again and again.   I had a cup of the onion soup - piping hot, sweet onions with melted gruyere - need I say more?   We also had the Pommes frites served with Dijon thyme-infused malt vinegar and rouille.  Mmmm...shoestring potatoes fried perfectly with Dijon.  We had an assortment of the brunch menu:  Warm biscuits - Buttermilk-sausage gravy, sage, fried eggs, grits.  I am so getting this next time. I want to bathe in the gravy.  Wild mushroom omelet - caramelized onions, gruyère cheese, fresh herbs.  Total comfort food - gruyere complemented the mushrooms.  Griddled corn cakes - wilted chard, poached eggs, tasso ham hollandaise.  Corn cakes looked like mini pancakes with heart clogging ham hollandaise. Sigh.  Service was prompt, friendly and spot on - it was crowded and the servers handled all of our requests with a smile.

oK2h1GDvj0s5BJiGlQw2fA.review_text: I have enjoyed many fun evenings at the bar at Absinthe. However, our most recent experience with a fairly incompetent hostess has definitely dampened my desire to return anytime soon. We arrived late Saturday night, a party of 7, and were told that we would be seated shortly by the hostess just as soon as they cleared 2 tables and pushed them together. So we waited - and waited - until the hostess noticed that a couple had sat down at our table on their own! Instead of asking them to move, she just shrugged and apologized. So we left. Very disappointing. That said, they do have delicious cocktails - my favorite being the Wonderlust - so we'll probably be back someday. We've enjoyed their cheese platters as well, although I do find their food to be  a bit overpriced.

rb8Qbc0iCgDy3a5axRy8Cg.review_text: Great time here always- the caviar is the best price you will see in town and the wait staff is always really nice.

ixAzWY0pBHd-1P0gUPFcTw.review_text: Go for Brunch.  It is the best brunch in the City: price, taste, value and service.  It has the whole package.  Eat it up!

LCVzPHCq447ycmZ87fKHZw.review_text: Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me.    I went there for lunch a few years ago.  Pretty average food and there was a fly buzzing around my head the entire time.  Last night, I gave it another shot for dinner.  The lamb was overseasoned and undercooked.  Pardon me, the "Chermoula Rubbed Lamb Loin" was overseasoned and undercooked.  The seasoning itself was a pleasant blend of North African spices (nothing wrong with that).  But the flavor overwhelmed the lamb, plus it came out rare and still baaaaaa-ing.  You couldn't really tell it was lamb honestly.  Rubbing that spice on tri-tip from Trader Joe's and undercooking it would probably would taste the same.  The Israeli cous cous they served it with was a pleasant surprise.  Extra large grain that absorbed all the flavors really well.  The mussels and clams were also done very well as were their cocktails.  Lastly the servers were knowledgeable and swift, no complaints there.    None of this could make up for the lamb and the prices however.  The intimidatingly large and pretentious menu under-delivered.  It's a bloated restaurant designed to rip off the theatre crowd.

VzlXV2oye770BT6pr-wdwQ.review_text: Delicious drinks and yummy French cuisine.

wT3KT-3jvLLXynC8ss8Whg.review_text: I love the setting, I love the neighborhood, the love the decor! We sat at the bar since we didn't have reservations and tables were a 45 minute wait. Started off with some cocktails. They only had a few choices, nothing special but decent nonetheless. Bar staff was very nice :) Started off with the fries, thin and crispy with 3 different dipping sauces. Yum..  I ordered the lamb on a bed of greens and came with carrot puree. The puree added the slight sweetness needed to accompany the lamb. The meat was tender, not gamey and cooked just as I ordered - medium rare. The pork dish came with beans and seemed a little dry. For the most part, the food was OK. From what I've heard, I guess I expected more, wasn't impressed. Coming back again to try give their brunch menu a try.

WWP06D5BncW30kSOkOC6WA.review_text: I was totally ready to 5 star this place even before eating here. I LOVED Jamie Lauren when she was on Top Chef and was heartbroken when she got eliminated. So having said all that, I was very disappointed that I wasn't impressed by this restaurant, especially since I picked it for my birthday.  French Onion Gratinee - Everyone on yelp seems to love this soup. Jamie was known to make great soups on Top Chef so I had to try this one. I'm happy that it was well seasoned. So many times French Onion can be too salty. I loved that there were strings of cheese through the soup and the bread went well with it. I'd say it was good, but not amazing.  Slow Cooked Pork Confit - served with butter beans, bacon, wilted nettles, and roasted tomatoes. I really wanted the scallops but the patron sitting next to us ordered it and it looked pretty small. I decided on the pork and after one bite, I regretted my decision. The pork was dry even though it still had a good amount of fat on it. How did this happen? The beans and even the BACON couldn't help. I was so sad!   Grilled Hereford Ribeye - served with celery root puree, baby root vegetables, and bone-marrow butter. This was a generous piece of beef but for $32, it would be tragic if it was small. It was cooked well and still juicy and flavorful because of the amount of fat on it, unlike the pork. Jamie is also known to do purees well and this one was good. The celery root puree was exactly what I'd imagine her making on Top Chef and so it was the highlight of the night.   Buttermilk Panna Cotta - with a meyer lemon gelee, huckleberry compote on top, and lemon thyme tuile. The gelee was really sour especially for a dessert that I couldn't actually concentrate on any of the other flavors. The huckleberry compote looked and tasted just like mashed up berries. We scraped the gelee off and focused on the panna cotta. It was much better towards the bottom but still not memorable.
