We enjoyed the chocolate sauce that spelled out "Happy Birthday" a lot more than the actual dessert.  Maybe it would have been better if Jamie was actually there that night? I checked their website and it said she was in Miami for the South Beach Food and Wine Festival. =*(

yan0OV0G1jgv0TnQqj4TBA.review_text: Dear Chef Adam,   Thanks for the tasty burgers at 9:30pm on a Sunday night!  Your recommendation for the focaccia was spot on and Stephen loved the tartar.    Even if we didn't live three blocks away, we'd be back :)   -R   Ps the Levaine was awesome too.

8pONVRF4HDD9ynt5lCynTQ.review_text: Absinthe is where many of my relationships have begun and ended. One of my first real dates was here and as such, Absinthe has gained the reputation of being the place I go to get my heart ripped out. Yet...I keep coming back. Stupid or nostalgic? Your call.  I have fallen in love, fallen out of love, argued loudly, cried quietly, hid in the bathroom, serenaded my lover, and dumped wine on my date at this little gem. Every boy I've ever dated, loved, lost, slept with, regretted sleeping with, or considered falling for has had his moment (or moments) here. At least I'm consistent.   There's the cocky surgeon with bad table manners, boy who only eats caesar salads and french fries and says things because they sound good in the moment, there was the doctor that never took his eyes off my chest when he talked to me about how smart and funny I was, there was my first love who had the red sports car and leather pants, there was the guy who I adored but was married (talented liar, too), the winemaker, the lawyer(s), the dj...you name it, it's taken me to dinner here.  I love Absinthe so much that all the bad date juju in the world can't stop me from returning again and again. Sipping champagne at the  bustling bar is a great beginning or end to any night. Brunch is outstanding, small plates are to die for. The burger is one of my favorites. The upbeat atmosphere and pleasant waitstaff are huge pluses. There is always a fabulous prosecco or cava on the menu.  Absinthe is an institution. I think it's where I left my heart. If you'd like to make a reservation, I will gladly meet you there. Unless you're married. And if you see me here, feel free to interrupt. I'm probably on a bad date.

0lzDu-wpNr_4Q7BccjP4zA.review_text: Been here twice now, the first time since Jamie Lauren from Top Chef moved on. Obviously, the bar vibe, the essence of the place, is still there.   I did apps and drinks with my little sister this past Friday night and we had a fantastic time. Our server KICKED A$$ - great suggestions, had the right balance of letting us enjoy our evening vs. being attentive, and pleasant to chat with.  COCKTAILS I had the Wonderlust, she had the Covered Wagon. These aren't your grandma's drinks - be prepared for booze :) Flavors were great - mine had just a touch too much absinthe for my taste, but maybe my tastebuds were just overpowered to that flavor that night, because I could tell there wasn't much in there. These, if nothing else, are the reason you come here - tear this drink menu apart! These drinks will cost you $15+ at the closest thing to it in Chicago...  APPS Caesar salad w/ homemade dressing - fantastic Spicy pork meatballs - are the BOMB - I could eat these every day We hit up a cheese plate - Big Woods Blue (I've had better blues), the Flagship (tasty firm cheese) and the Hudson Valley Camembert, which is creamy like butter. Like the meatballs, I too could it this every day. In fact, I could eat this on top of those meatballs. (looking at you chef - make up a dish with those ingredients!!)  Whenever I visit SF again, you'll always be on my radar. Two visits, two great experiences.

YE6MfcqTdqrqPgubWfYJ4g.review_text: This place is conveniently located next to where I work.  One star for that.  Their cocktails are not poured, they are crafted.  The bartenders here take their mixology seriously.  The staff is unassuming and are all professionals at customer service - and having been in customer service for a while, I know my CS.    Unlike many restaurants that either bother you too much or forget you exist, these cats have mastered the 'subtle glance' at each and every table.  Is your cocktail getting dangerously low, a quick walk by just to let you know they are there is all it takes to order another.  If it is empty, you can expect to be posed the obvious question.  Have you craned your neck looking for a server?  You can bet that one of them will see you or somebody else will and send someone right over.  Empty plates?  Cleared.  Low water glass?  Filled.  Suggestions for plates or wine matching?  They know it.  They make dining here so easy that you can forget you are actually eating and drinking and focus on your gal, guy or group.  The food was awesome, but with nearly 1000 reviews behind mine, this may as well be about their excellent service.  Bravo!

PQmK3o8t5FtW_2Q_RR7hWA.review_text: I love Absinthe. I came here multiple times for food and once for just drinks. Their cocktails are fantastico. I brought my boyfriend for his birthday and not only did they listen to my request for a "private table," they basically moved us away from everyone else. Fantastic. Then they remembered from my reservation that it was his birthday and brought out cake with a candle. They went above and beyond. Thank you Absinthe! Their food is good too :)

B9UjKxB8fI_Y3K-ljp_Puw.review_text: Dinner here for my birthday was ah-maze-ing! Started with a Citron lemonade (yum!) that went down way to easy!  Apps were the garlic pretzel bites & the Hawaiian poke - to die for!  My entree had to be the Absinthe burger...couldn't pass it up!  Delicious!  My friend had the pork rib-eye that she can't stop raving about how perfect it was!  Wine selection is limited but really good, the cocktail menu is filled to the brim with delicious happiness!  Highly, highly recommend Absinthe for food, drink & atmosphere!

2Qfa3o72sq04_MCUxy3Shg.review_text: Brunch was delicious!  I had bacon, 2 eggs over easy, and some toast. It was really good quality and made me obsessed with eating drippy eggs on toast. I have tried to recreate this meal every morning for the past 2 weeks.   My friend got the duck confit and HOLY CRAP that was some delicious duck!  I highly recommend it for brunch, drinks, and if you make the money- dinner.

WZNf3WKBC18_E8qrvayj4w.review_text: 1. Charming neighborhood with lots to see. 2. Fancy cafe ambiance... like you're on holiday in Paris. 3. Garlic pretzels are worth the hype! Perfectly seasoned, not too salty, piping hot, crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. 4. Yummy and strong libations. 5. The only downside is the $$$.

NoHJb7x8IEakUJTx6_vGTA.review_text: This review comes from the pages of "When Good Restaurants Go Bad."   I decided to take my wife out on a dinner date to celebrate an important evening. We wanted a restaurant noted for food, ambiance, and service - this appeared to be the one. I relied solely on Yelp reviews - which is a safe bet for the most part; except this is that one big exception.  Before I tell you about anything, the food is spectacular here. The Butternut Winter Squash Bisque was impeccable and my french onion soup was beyond all my expectations (they actually make it themselves, they don't make it from some concentrate like most other places). The main dish that my wife was great - a bit rich and overwhelming. The burger I had, great... but I've also had burgers as great at dive bars (in fact, the dive bars have way better burgers). Desert... oooohhh, didn't even make it to that point.  While the food is good - that's all I can say. The service would be complemented at the mention or note of them being Aloof. Perhaps I'm being too polite, inconsiderate, maybe better. We were the first peopled to be seated in their dining area and showed up ahead of time. Other people quickly occupied the rest of the area. Our appetizer was provided relatively quickly. Afterwards, we waited for 35 minutes... and waited. All other tables filled, they had already been served their appetizers and given their main dishes... we waited. It was then we had to hail down another server (not our waiter/waitress) that we inquired if we will ever get out food for the night. Ah ha, within 2 minutes we had our food. Finishing up our food knowing the glaring lack of service. We went to finish up - there are a few other things we could have requested... oops, couldn't request them at all as the waitress never checked up on us at all. So much so, our empty plates lay in front of us until some unrelated individual came and picked them up. At this point our mood had soured to a point in which we wanted to get desert... maybe that'll cheer us up. Being given the desert menu, we had to wait for another 30 minutes until they returned to ask "what do you want."  Knowing the hostile situation, we gave our credit card and asked for the check promptly.   I'm sorry, this is the one time I will be the worlds most horrible tipper - I have have had impeccable service at IHOP... but this place leaves so much to be desired.  I will never ever set foot in this establishment. For food with nothing to make it stand out and service that is by far the worst service I have ever experienced in my years.... never.  I wish them well in ruining other people's nights.

hafcXRhwjSzEOpTxACqc9A.review_text: First that I have to mention is fantastic service. The place is a well run machine. Everyone was extremely pleasant. We spent time with their wine person before choosing the Freeman Pinot Noir. We sat in the bar area. We decided to each have the scallop and clam chowder, split the cured meat appetizer, and an order of fries... They timed ever dish perfectly... I usually do not get dessert, unless it is a special occasion but we share their plate of assorted cookies...  everything was amazing.. Looking forward to going back

qzu4UQbwcqdTQte0PccVvA.review_text: Only been here a few times during happy hour a while back.  I have a certain bias toward places in Hayes Valley only mainly because I love the area and if I could afford it I'd move here.    I guess the name itself deserves 3-stars no?  Drinks aren't super cheap, but it has the classy feel, vibe and furniture/layout.  I felt like I was in a black & white movie..sipping on some cool drinks like back in the Prohibition days.  Reminded me that I should wear my summer hat, tommy gun in hand...Johnny Depp Public Enemies style.  That's what I'm talking about.    I do remember the drinks being somewhat more stronger than usual.  If you're taking some friends in town and they're looking for a nice, safe, classy environment go here.  It's fairly quiet even when it's full and no one is out obnoxious or looking to get destroyed!  If you want something more hoppin' I'd say pass on this place.  Actually, pass out of Hayes Valley in my opinion.

355W7iKObLwu3greKAJcqQ.review_text: I have been meaning to try this place since I moved back to SF (and watched top chef with jamie!)!  I never really make it to hayes valley, and hate leaving the marina/russian hill for parking reasons alone.  Since it was bay to breakers, for which i had flown specifically back for the night before, we walked all through hayes valley!  After we hit the park we ended up backtracking, and as i had busted my toe open at the beginning of the event, i was eager to sit down when my friends wanted lunch.  We ended up backtracking even further when we sat down elsewhere, there was no liquor, we called absinthe and they were surprisingly open (had been closed when we passed by earlier)!  We reserved a table and walked over (hobbled in my case), and they tried to hide us in the back as we were of couse in costume.  As we had more people join us they were forced to move us to a less hidden booth, and our waiter wasn't especially friendly from the very get go.  My friends absolutely LOVED their food (and had been here before and like the place), however my friend and i that ordered bloodies pretty much hated them (she literally didnt drink hers, at all)...after that i switched to champagne, which sadly is pretty much all the same to me.  The decor was cute but relatively simple, and i think my expectations were so high that mediocre service and a bad bloody made for a somewhat disappointing experience =(  That said, if i were in the area, i would still give it another try!

lvydy9YebJr_qz3_helliw.review_text: Thanks to my friends, Julian and Jessica, Top Chef became a staple in my life this past season and I couldn't help but to cheer on the hometown girl, Jamie Lauren. I vowed to try her restaurant as soon as the show ended, and I finally made it out there for brunch this past Sunday. Both B2B and the Giant's game were going on and yet somehow, I found a parking space within a block of the restaurant, so it was meant to be that I try this place out.   In my mind, Absinthe is the definition of a classy French bistro. The walls were adorned with hand paintings and the tables were dressed perfectly in long white linens. The service even matched the ambiance as I had a pretty handsome, European server (with an amazing accent) waiting on me. The menu had a great variety and featured a lot of items that I recalled from the show. I was impressed by the cheese pairings and the varieties of oysters that were also offered. A Spanish cheese selection named Mont Enebro was an absolute dream!! I would never think to pair goat cheese with anchovies, and raisin toasts, but MAN O MAN, it blew me away! I also ordered the Duck Confit hash, which was decent and the Panna Cotta with a Meyer Lemon gelee and huckleberries which was a great, refreshing end to the meal.   Overall, I was truly pleased with the experience at Absinthe. The waitstaff was great and the food was upscale, yet still very comforting and hearty. If I ever need to be whisked away to a European bistro, I know Absinthe is right around the corner to fulfill that need.

s1ZCMA57MwXi_xAe0GcZQA.review_text: Review based on a visit for brunch a couple of Saturday's ago.  Arrived right on time for our 11:45 am Yelp reservation and a great little booth waiting for us . It has been 10 years since we had last dined here.  Well, apart from being so NOISY from raised voices of a crowded room (you cant relax and enjoy here), the quality of food has seemed to have slipped badly.  We started with a couple of choices from the many cheeses they have to offer, but the brie and the cows milk we selected were nothing excitable. I then had the half dunenous crab in shell, and although cooked perfectly, it was simply bland which was extrememly disappointing. They need to learn how to flavor this when boiling. Partner had the french toast and gave a 7/10. Any cocktail they make with their own house-made sweet-and-sour etc has a strange, almost cheap, taste to them. Also their Lemmonade is dreadful.    Ended with the french onion soup and that saved the entire meal - delicious!  I'm giving 5 stars for our servers and the water boy, then taking off 3 for the mostly 'blah' food - what happened Absinthe?

vn0G593HwCmSztJf2wGoOg.review_text: Yes, they live up to their name and have the drink and are friendly with instructions on properly making it.  We like to share and were not disappointed.. the oysters, fresh  ... the cheese, stinky and delicious, the fish was delightful and the chocolate mousse with a beet creme fraise was amazing...

Td-4iSeOrz72KnX1Xa4tRw.review_text: I went to Absinthe last week for a drink and was slightly disappointed. Both my drink and dessert were good but the waitress really wanted me and my friend out as soon as we were done with our food.  The atmosphere was also too pretentious. Overall not a bad place but not as good as people make it seem.

xz4IbQzaubDuhc-aLK3i2g.review_text: Yum and Yum! Scallop entree and hamachi crudo appetizer was fantastic. and my Tcho chocolate pot de creme dessert was pretty much heavenly. also awesome cocktail menu!!! good job, absinthe.  it's a little pricey for the everyday meal, but i'll definitely go back here for a special occasion. or if someone else is paying :)

TZatgTt9RyYGlBa7uZTgBg.review_text: Nice place to have a friend's birthday dinner.  We had the wagyu beef steak with mashed potatoes, Absinthe burger, and the 21 Hayes, which is like a Pimm's cup.  The wagyu we asked to be cooked medium, but it came well done and was tender and could be cut with a fork the way braised short ribs are prepared.  It was a little confusing, but it was delicious so we couldn't complain.  They could've called it "braised wagyu" instead of a steak.  We also had the mussels appetizer, excellent dish for three people.  The ambiance is dim, classy.  LIKE!

lZRW6fvPTe1q8G7fJYvMZA.review_text: We spent the Vday weekend in the city and discovered Absinthe was right next to our Inn. Being avid Top Chef fans we had to go. We could only get reservations for Sunday afternoon but according to my fellow yelpers brunch is a great time to go.   And it was! We had two other couples with us and we all immensely enjoyed our meals and each others. Some of our favorites ...Biscuits and Gravy, Grilled Corn Cakes, Wild Mushroom Omelet, and the Hamburger. The fennel sausage they make is bursting with savory flavor, the coffee gives you that warm fuzzy feeling inside, and the french fries are crunchy, salty, and soft in the middle.   Next Dessert! We ordered and shared the Chocolate Banana Tart, Scharffen Berger Pot de' Creme, and the Grapefruit Sorbet. The Chocolate Banana Tart was a trio of Chocolate tart absolutely to die for, the salted carmel banana delicious, and the banana ice cream creamy and tasty. My Pot de' Creme smooth chocolaty heaven, intensely delicious but not heavy. The sorbet was good, just not my thing (no chocolate, not interested)   The Service was great. A little slow at times but this place is ALWAYS packed. We could see it from our Inn across the street and there was a long line waiting for it to open. Our waitress was attentive and very accommodating. My friends burger was rarer then he expected (when you order a medium rare burger from a real chef it actually comes out medium rare). He took the blame when talking to the waitress but she was very nice and even said she thought it was a little rare too. The ended up bringing him a whole new plate. The prices were actually surprising reasonable. $160 for brunch for 6, plus 3 desserts, and drinks..not bad.   If I were to have one complaint it would be that I thought my bloody mary could have been more flavorful. All in all a wonderful experience that I will definitely have to have again!

bQOouBetqy31RaEY1v5nqg.review_text: Went here for Valentine's Day dinner. Great place! The atmosphere is romantic and very classy. The food is finger-licking-delicious. We had a bottle of champagne, quail and steak. Everything was absolutely delicious. Their desserts are to die for as well. Very much recommend.

RsQVVr71wsiSD1i2APot7g.review_text: Despite the supposed accolades, skip the burger. One of the more expensive and overrated burgers in town. I've had it twice and been disappointed twice.

IVS_EDQ44UAN2zcQ5Rm46g.review_text: Wonderful food. The duck confit was perfect. Love the hint of green on every plate of food as a nod to its namesake. Had a taste of Pernod....very strong, difficult to finish, but I'm glad that I tried it.

W-WA-dZh768K1nWbJedmKQ.review_text: Outstanding Brunch.  Stellar service.  Beautiful restaurant.   I can only comment on the food that I tasted, so:   french onion soup: excellent duck confit ragout with poached eggs: delicious bloody mary: ok to good sommelier: when I asked him about an obscure bottle of wine, he went next door to the wine shop and found it.  returned, and told me that if I walked over there myself to buy it, brought it back, and paid corkage (half corkage fee for bottles from this shop) I would save approx $25.  That's a quick way to earn my repeat business.    5 stars.

K9pJVvUH8eURB2CBLdo37g.review_text: Absinthe is wonderful. It's great for both groups or date night, and the ambiance is lovely. The soups are always delicious, as is the beef tartare and baked mac and cheese. The cocktails are also great. Such a great spot in Hayes Valley. My only complaint is that the portions can be quite small.

Suw8tiW7EHWpt7HhuB7SDw.review_text: There is no PG-13 way to put this: Chilled corn puree (soup) is orgasmic. It's not of the naughty variety, but might cause your eyes to roll back in your head from pure pleasure.  Party in your mouth. Field day for your taste buds.  It doesn't stop at the corn either... Scallop & Clam chowder is balancing act, perfected. Delicate scallops nestled between petite clam shells in a creamy & rich, but not the least bit heavy, base. Unexpected halibut kept me taking mini bites so as to savor every last tender flake, morsel, drop, drip, lick. The server returns to the table, ready to clear my plate, asks (to my seemingly empty plate) if I am finished to which I respond, hesitantly, "yes, otherwise I am tempted to lick the plate and it just doesn't seem appropriate" *flashes a smile* He reminds me there is some bread left on the table I could use to soak up the last bits (but what fun is that!?!).  Complements to the chef. (Way to go Jamie!) It's pure bliss.  Ambiance caters to any occasion and is way more PG-13 than my tango with the soups, but you still might want to leave the young'ns at home and enjoy this for yourself (and your lucky hot date).  Strawberry gazpacho, I'll be back for you! *****  Treated myself to strawberry gazpacho before diving in to some ginger-infused cocktails, nibbling melt-in-your-mouth olives (why don't other places serve olives warm? Oh, the difference!), and a duck confit salad...   what can I say? It didn't blow my mind like the corn puree but did not disappoint. The silky texture throws you a curve, I just missed the ball.

bKfeFC2Z4c9obKbB_ZKN8w.review_text: Absinthe was so great! The service was amazing. Our waiter was so awesome at explaining the whole menu. One of our friends has ciliac, so she can't have gluten, and he was very helpful.  We had the oysters to start, which were great. Drinks were awesome too. For dinner, I had the absinthe burger and added a fried egg and cheese. It was delicious, and the meat was cooked perfectly. I also had a side of french onion soup. It had great flavor.  For dessert we did the 3 different cheeses, and those were so good!  Can't wait to come back!

0H6xBMOXRlfnFaPorYCm3g.review_text: Absinthe had long been on my radar as a place to try ever since I saw Top Chef and Jamie Lauren (Top Scallop lol).  She has since left and as such any chance of meeting her and trying her food lest I drive down to her new place in LA.  Overall, the food was good, just neither great nor memorable enough (even when taking the overpriced menu into account) to really warrant a return visit in the future.  In fact, the lack of memorable food is what will impact the length of this review.  Started with coffee, pretty good but too pricey for regular coffee in my opinion.  However, props for the real sugar cubes.  Fruit Plate:  My friend and I debated between this and cinnamon roll, we chose poorly.  For close to $10 we got a couple of slices of fruit neatly arranged on a LARGE plate with a little bit of vanilla crème fraiche.  While the fruit was fresh I could have used a lot MORE (1 slice of kiwi = booo!)  Banana-Pecan Pancakes:  Another swing & miss; 3 pancakes the size of my palm with 3 slices of banana on top, 2 pecans on top, and a smidge of chopped pecans in the actual pancakes themselves.  I was so depressed when I saw such an anemic plate that I ordered a side of bacon!  Plus though on the real maple syrup for this and the French toast.  French Toast with Pear and Mascarpone:  The friend dish, 4 slices of overly-cooked (read dry) French Toast and a large half-poached pear with a dollop of mascarpone in the hollowed out pit area.  Meh!  Sides:  Scrambled eggs and bacon.  The eggs were good, really good, and probably the highlight of an otherwise unmemorable meal.  The bacon was cooked right but too skinny, I likes me some hearty bacon!  In conclusion, there are soooooooo many other places I will try before I return to Absinthe.  In fact, I ate at Ella's a week later and their pancakes...NO comparison!

qzDsm_hKogII5g3qM9XilA.review_text: Great food!  Came with a group and they were very accommodating!

IHp8NjRO2oYqP8-I4VRoAA.review_text: Had reservations on a Friday at 8:45 PM. My friend and I were running late and I called to let them know. Hostess said she'd be able to hold our table for 15 minutes. But, couldn't promise after that. We got there  a little after 9:00 PM and were seated right away.   Place was packed and roaring with people.  It took us a while to order. The service was not as attentive as I like or am used to. However, our waiter was efficient when he was around. We each got a drink (Extra Dirty Grey Goose Martini and something called a Ginger Rogers). Both drinks were strong and delicious!  We started with the french fries with dijon mustard, thyme-infused malt vinegar, and rouille. They were nicely salted and crispy. My friend ordered the large french onion soup and I got the Grilled scallops with sunchoke purée, slow-cooked artichokes, baby fennel, and wilted chard. Soup was superb and my scallops were the BEST SCALLOPS I HAVE EVER EATEN IN MY LIFE! Perfectly cooked and spendy ($30 for 4 scallops!). But, well worth it.   An additional star for the Jamie sighting! :)

BwTPj8XS_iqdSTLPBVMs1w.review_text: Date night this past Saturday night. I chose Absinthe after hearing good reviews. We were promptly seated at a very romantic table. Circular booth so that the boy can put his arm around you.   We both ordered the pork rib eye and passed on the appetizer for fear that we could not accommodate dessert. The pork came out perfectly cooked on a bed of mashed potatoes and a side of sauteed veggies. Mine was HUGE but as a woman in a tight fitting dress, I tried as much as I could to finish. I got up until the bone before I was about to pass out. For dessert, we shared the pumpkin custard. It was like a deconstructed pumpkin pie with graham crust shavings on top and pumpkin custard on the bottom. Yummy.   Highly recommend this place for dinner and or date. Very romantic setting w/ ample amounts of booze.

jYAPeHfAfh9IdvFg7gzpGA.review_text: Great drinks and friendly staff =). I'm admittedly not an absinthe fan but my husband is and he really enjoyed what he ordered. I had a french 75 which was wonderful. Next time we go I intend to try the desserts. I hear they are spectacular!

CMdFQ0y0zvzBS2x6tjZcWA.review_text: I had the pleasure of dining here on a Saturday evening for a friend's birthday.  Although this corner gem isn't that spacious, they set our party of nine at a nice long table in the second room in a more quiet part of the restaurant.  My night here was exceptional from start to finish.  The service is impeccable, and everyone working here has enthusiasm including the guy who scrapes your crumbs off the table and the girl who refills your water glasses.    We chose from a three course menu selection.  They added a personal touch by printing my friend's name for her birthday on all the menus.  I started my dinner off with mixed local greens, Asian pears, pecans, brioche crisp, goat cheese mousse, with medjool date vinaigrette.  The goat cheese was so creamy and smooth and the vinaigrette was light in flavor- just perfect.  The potato-mushroom-leek soup, with green garlic and brioche croutons was pretty tasty too and teaming with fresh flavors.  For the main course, I had potato-crusted arctic char with Little Gem lettuce, yellow wax beans, red radish and niçoise olives which were minced in a line down the center of the plate (an interesting touch of presentation and addition to flavors with each morsel of fish).  It was my first time indulging in char which is closely related to salmon and lake trout.  It was tasty but nothing that "wowed".  For dessert I had the cara cara orange parfait with yogurt panna cotta, cara cara orange sorbet and pistachio crumble.  This was an interesting concoction of dessert flavors and by far the most delectable orange confection I'd ever enjoyed!  The wine and spirits selection here is one of the larger selections I've ever seen.  The menu is contained in a small binder.  It's likely there is a wine here to suit anyone's palette.  The martinis are quite smooth too.  Unfortunately, it never occurred to me to try any of their absinthe cocktails.  There was an exorbitant amount of wine, prosecco and champagne being poured around our table.  This is definitely a splurge but worth the experience in a dramatic ambiance with dark wood paneling and rustic style interiors with some slight modern touches.

oIxgvmN7FLJUqd015CKSXw.review_text: What a wonderful place! San Fran priced but delicious and lovely service. We stopped in with some friends after getting hitched at City Hall and the servers were so kind, and we got a complementary dessert with "Congratulations" written in chocolate syrup. So sweet! Oh, and the fries, grilled cheese, and flat bread were ahhh-mazing! :) Cheers!

c24niAEMJmgne4UflTS_mA.review_text: Cocktails are amazing,  Wine selection is a dream come true,  not to mention the staff is really nice and helpful.  The food is equally amazing.  I have heard so many good reviews from friends that I finally went to see what exactly there were raving about, and It did not disappoint,  I am just disappointed i waited so long to go.

4eR6hYFJcBHoAqhuOS07ww.review_text: ------------BRUNCH ONLY--------- Very easy to make reservations online and make sure you do, this place gets packed pretty quick!  -French Onion Soup - OH MY GAH. I'm usually not a fan of french onion soup but this one pretty much hits the spot, esp when you're craving something cheesy & soupy -Seafood ceviche - Pretty standard but what made it great was the taro chips. Those addictive suckers make the dish worth getting and we had to ask for more taro chips because we finished those before we could finish the ceviche itself. -Omelette - Had lobster bits inside with green garlic. Pretty solid omelette but nothing wow factor   Service is whatever. The busboys were way more attentive than our actual waiter but it was probably because it was super busy. Either that or she just didn't think we'd be big tippers so she didn't bother.   Overall, a really good brunch. There's plenty more on the menu I wish I tried but I liked it enough that I'd come back just so I could try the rest of the menu.

aIWXZ3MCfehI-LbxCN4arg.review_text: Wow, I love Absinthe. I mean the place, not the licorice flavored drink (licorice, ewwww). I got a nice gift cert to come here. After carefully perusing their menu online, I decided the best bang for this buck would be to hit brunch and lunchtime.   The husb and I left our fog bank into sunny Hayes Valley. We were pleasantly surprised at the warmth and sun, convinced that our Absinthe experience would be fabulous.   Upon arrival we noted plenty of seating, which made us happy. We were shown to a table by the windows, to further enjoy the sun. I had the fried green tomatoes, an eggs benedict type dish but with tomatoes under the eggs. It came with the most perfectly done potatoes one could ask for. The mans got the ricotta french toast, which was also heavenly. I also got the lemonade which I think has ginger in it? But it was pretty good. I will for sure be back soon to use up the rest of my gift cert...so looking forward to it!

LQFYriKlA6HPahTx8SWdJQ.review_text: Mel G. said below she saw an "unwanted guest." There was a cockroach incident involving a flurry of ladies scrambling when I was there about a month ago too. Why am I not surprised?   I erased my prior (detailed) bad review, including accounts of consistently horrific service and mediocre food. 3 times is a charm. I'll never go back to this place. They're awful.   I might be able to forgive the roach problem if the restaurant treated their guests in a more appropriate way for an establishment with the lie "Private Dining" plastered on the window.   Don't be fooled. Spend your money somewhere where you get treated with more kindness and respect.  It's called the "service industry" not the "turn your nose up and ignore people industry."  Sorry Absinthe, I go back and forth about sharing any negativity here, but eating at your establishment has felt like a slap in the face every time, so there you have it.

ie_bGu6v9pksMsYKn8srLA.review_text: We happened to be walking by and thought the place looked interesting.  Because we only wanted appetizers and not a full dinner, we were told to wait while they seated everyone else who wanted a table for dinner.  Then we were seated at a table in the corner.  Service was slow and both the server and busboy had attititudes, like we were wasting their time.  The silver was dirty and we had to ask for a second set.  I did ask the server about their brunch.  She stated it was "really terrific" but did not even offer to get me a menu so I could see for myself.  She told me I should look at their website.  Another hint that they didn't care if we came back or not.  Just a hint- dirty silverware and poor service do not translate to repeat customers.

e0yJoOJ6xiqZGo8LM9cVsQ.review_text: Yummy drinks, yummy desserts, didn't eat the food. A great date type place. Expect to spend some money though.

_BHTC7nyCBoZcfiiD5cOXg.review_text: Absinthe did not make my heart grow fonder. Was it just an off night? The bistro steak, closer to well done than the medium rare I requested, was tough, and the highly-touted fries were nearly burnt and overly greasy. When I nicely suggested to the waiter that they might be a tad too cooked, he snarled, 'That's the way we make them.' Either I was expecting far too much from all the raves I'd heard, or I'm the only one who sees the Emperor's not wearing any clothes. At prices like these, I'm loathe to give them a second chance.

qahEbl4cbKX3tz_smwOf4w.review_text: This was one instance where it proves how the flow really affects the enjoyment of a meal.  We ordered our drinks as soon as we sat down.  The waitress came by shortly after we ordered our drinks to take our order but we needed more time so instead of giving us just 5 or 10 extra minutes, she decided to leave us there for 20 minutes before she finally returned to take our order.  We had hoped she would be returning with our drinks but alas, she was empty handed.  With our food orders in, we waited another 10 minutes or so before the waitstaff brought us some bread.  This was quickly followed by our appetizers and shared dishes, however, our drinks STILL hadn't arrived!  Finally, nearly 40 minutes after we had ordered our cocktails, they made it to our table.  We were planning on starting with cocktails and then splitting a bottle of wine with the entrees but our entrees ended up coming out only a few minutes after the drinks.  The entrees were on par with most French-inspired restaurants in this price point.  Good but nothing spectacular.  In the middle of our meal, our waitress came by to let us know that she was going on break and that someone else would be taking over for her.  We found this confusing since she hadn't been very attentive up until this point - I doubt we would've noticed that she had gone on break in the first place!  After we finished the entrees, we decided to order some drinks and dessert, hoping this would salvage the meal.  It took another 20 minutes for them to arrive.  By this time, we were just ready to leave.  2.5 hours later, I left Absinthe confused and tired.  Absinthe is known for their drinks and I think next time, I'll skip the food and just stick with the cocktails...at the bar.

IcDn5f-a5mt7v3WnFBvOdg.review_text: The food was amazing and the service is top notch. Unfortunately my girlfriend and I both got food poisoning from the muscles.

Dgx185t0xrXT8nboVCNBqA.review_text: Great late night dinner. We had the French onion soup, a cheese plate, and an Absinthe Burger.  The burger was a little average , but still very good especially for the late night 10pm dinner we were eating. They had some fantastic looking cocktails and the Spanish Coffee that the bartender lit on fire like the  " fire eater in a traveling circus! " Everything was very good and I hope to go there again! I want to try the other cocktails.....especially the fire cocktail!

-0SqALqeWmInVftG_iHcHg.review_text: Very active bar and restuarant in Hayes Valley. I was able to get outdoor seating on a warm evening in November. Does that really happen?  Five different labels of Absinthe, with the Hangar One label at $18.50 the flagship. Ordered a of couple two olive martinis with ketel one, very nice. They have a nice selection of beers on tap plus many of the feature labels of premium hard liquor. Very accomodating service.

e6OwRdPgmjx3R-HCgAN1-w.review_text: I have ben here several times and have never had a bad meal. I did have a bad waitress once, not sure if her boyfriend dumped her or her dog died, but she was terrible. After serving at a restaurant for five years during college, I can rarely find it in my heart to tip less than 20%. I reserve 15% for those really bad occasions. We left 10% which I reserve for occasions when I feel a tip isn't even warranted. I like to give people the benefit of the doubt, this woman was absolutely terrible though. Possibly the worst service ever. "So do you know what you want to eat yet?" "Oh, you want cocktails first?" Who the hell talks to a table like that. Anyway...  The food is excellent though. The first time I ate here I got the beef cheek. It was fantastic. The last three times I have eaten here I went with the burger, add some gorgonzola and a fried egg. I'm a sucker for a good burger. The garlic pretzel appetizer is always a good choice too. And the wine list is to die for.

QBXAIu1Vm-nKXUwBqZ5H7Q.review_text: Oh, Absinthe. I oftentimes wander by or ride by on the bus past the establishment only hoping that the green fairy actually delivered more actual green into my pockets so I can dine here.  I had the epiphany one day to enjoy brunch here, since that's a more reasonably priced menu I can afford, right? Right!  Our host was gracious, our server was attentive and hey, throw some linens on the table and a cocktail in my hand and I'm all growns up by 11 am. Most of the time I'm in Hayes Valley it's for a cheap shopping thrill or some pizza ;-), so this was a plus.  I started out with a "Death in the Afternoon" cocktail even though it wasn't even noon yet, but hey, I'm a professional. And I did not die.   The food arrived at the perfect time and the array of plates was impressive and presented well. I had split several yummies with Jen I. and enjoyed each one.  Sometimes brunch is meant to be meat and grease, sometimes it's meant to be sea salt and chanterelle mushrooms.  I sampled the fried green tomatoes which was a bit salty for me, but very rich and filling. The pommes-frites beat out Frijtz any day in my book, and the mushroom flat bread was the perfect level of crisp. The buttered lettuce salad was just a salad, which they so kindly split up into two plates for us without asking--I like that. It was tasty nonetheless. I have to have some veggies!  Wonderful upgrade from the usual cacaphony of downtown or the Castro in the places we visit for brunch.   Oh, and just because we eat and drink like ladies doesn't mean we can't get a little sassy and crass over lunch--kudos to our server for keeping up and humoring us.

HorQ90eiUPfnesQlIraaJA.review_text: Went for brunch the day after my birthday to soak up the libations from the party the night before. Perfect choice.  I ordered the Duck ragout - what the photos don't show you are the 2 crispy potato cakes that the duck and mushrooms sit atop.  My bf got the $26 short rib dish which was also excellent.  We ordered a croque Madam for the table too (yes we are pigs, but there were 4 of us) that was a damn fine croque! the thin bread and the pungent gruyere were in perfect balance. Really one of the best croque's I've ever had. my only quibble my be I would prefer a side of french fries rather than salad, but  I'm a pig.

pUfi0asEwUZZsSM7W_sGiA.review_text: Visited this place just for desserts. We ended up ordering 4 different desserts for a group of 4. I have to say every dessert was delicious. They have very good wine list and lot of cocktail options. Spirits is bit expensive.

Ldy03uMFaEEEnh3KIsPP_w.review_text: The cocktails were lovely, the bartender was making a lot of fancy drinks for both the bar and service bar, and she was pretty fast for how involved the drinks are (unlike some OTHER places in SF where it takes nine years for one stupid drink!)  My friend and I sat outside later and a lovely gentleman who might be the manager or owner was very friendly and personable and checked on us to make sure we didn't need anything.  The people working there are the reason we will definitely be back.  (And the very interesting drink menu)

BbrL55gPmTlOAPQkt4y5Rg.review_text: Very nice restaurant with Amazing creations. We loved their tartar and caviar dishes the best!

aU6uxCZ6jMZ7mw6ptu5Ecw.review_text: We had a great time at Absinthe. We ordered the oysters and 3 different cheeses and the fries to start with. The cheese with the blackberry purée was everyone's favorite and the fries came with an outstanding smoked ketchup that none of us tasted before.  The lamb and coq au vin were both the winning orders for the table. The pork cheeks and the salmon were the other entrees and they were just ok which is why I'm rating it 4 stars overall. The pork had an overall good flavor but was pretty dry tasting.  The salmon was pretty boring and nothing special.  The German chocolate cake was fantastic. We also had the buttermilk panna cotta. I normally love all panna cotta but this one tasted very tart like a yogurt because of the buttermilk and I did not care for it. The cocktails we tried were great, the Ginger Rogers was like a ginger mojito, the have  was delicious as was the French 75. We also tried a French absinthe at the end of our meal which was really good and we loved the service we received.

muPKUHFQnK5_G55k48Avkw.review_text: It took me almost six years to finally get to Absinthe, and I preface my review by saying I came in after 11 and ate only off the bar bites menu. I wasn't super hungry, so I just got the French Onion soup and a side of French Fries.  Absinthe Hot Tip #36: Use the French Onion Soup as a dip for the fries.   I'd heard a lot about the place being a cocktail destination, and me being distinctly a beer and whiskey guy, figured I'd give the gold standard - an Old-Fashioned - a shot. It was flawless. The best cocktail I've ever had. The bourbon wasn't overpowered and it perfectly balanced. Yes, I think I'll have another. And another...  So yeah, to the question of desserts, now being prepared by Luis Villavelasquez, formerly of Citizen Cake. I have to admit that he and I know each other through a mutual friend, so I'm a little biased, but we had the panna cotta with strawberries and sweet basil, and it literally blew mind out the back of my head onto the fancily decorated wall behind me.   Yes, I think I'll have another. But next time, I'll come in for dinner service.   PS - I know that given my male status my chances are nil, but Steffan was right, Jamie Lauren is uber-cute.

FysDiqCS1fxxwC9PLHNqNg.review_text: Was here recently before a show. Had a nice time. The wait staff was quite charming and the wine was delicious. What I liked it about it was that the wait staff asked when we needed to leave. My friend said that we had a lecture to attend. So they rushed our order. The neighbors next to us were friendly. I had not been here before so it was nice to eat here finally. I was not impressed with their house pate. It was blend. I loved their French soup. I would not come back unless I've eaten all of the other French restaurants in the city. Having been to France a half a dozen or so times, it's hard to impress me with French food. I will come back, if I'm in the area and run out of restaurant to go to.

H5avBytFZxJQ44-IB0h6VA.review_text: It's undeniably true, the Coq Au Vin is the best I've ever had, but you're also safe with almost ANYTHING on the menu, here!!

aKsdAkwuIlYARLNPYSFIkA.user_location: Tahoe Park South/Tallac Village, Sacramento, CA
aKsdAkwuIlYARLNPYSFIkA.review_text: Great service.  Great food.  Cheese burger was amazing.  The French onion soup was awesome

U28XN1IGtjsQL2DUxr7FKg.review_text: Great spot for a special date night. Few veg options but what there is is very good. Great cocktails and ambiance.

d2ruV4DWHGHsORkMcZJTnw.review_text: I'm updating my review to 4 stars after a phenomenal brunch that would've earned 5 stars on its own. Food was incredible and quite reasonable, and all of our cocktails were great.

GIWfonZr53ChlBTpmLmUsA.review_text: I've been to Absinthe a number of times; for dinner, lunch, brunch and drinks (I even finally had some absinthe the last time). The ambiance, food, drinks and service are always great. It gets little crowded for good reason.

WjOgr5CIxFqIrEYIk9DsOw.review_text: Yumtown. The drinks were awesome. We tried a variety including some with Absinthe, some without and a bottle of wine. Our waitress had the best suggestions, so we stuck to those.  We did a cheese platter with Mt Tam, Humboldt and Keen's Cheddar which were all delicious and paired excellently. There were four of us and all three were someones favorites.  Grub included Filet, Chicken, Osso Buco and Pappardelle with Duck Sugo - all were excellent. I think the filet was my favorite. The mac n cheese side was a top notch addition and so worth the calorie splurge!  Overall an excellent experience here. It's a great spot for a drink, food, whatever you need!

L2uIVVgoODNLj16V2U1eCg.review_text: I've dined at Absinthe probably 10 times in the past few years. Historically, the service was excellent, the food pretty good, and the bar program excellent and well celebrated for it.  However, as of late, I've noticed a slip in the service that has reached a tipping point today where I simply won't return.  My girlfriend an I walked in and told the hostess that we wanted to sit at the bar for a quick snack and a drink or two. We were told to "belly up," to what was obvious upon looking at it, a completely full bar. The hostess didn't care to observe this, or more pointedly, didn't care to bother herself with a solution or even an eta.  We sat by the door.  We then proceeded to watch as two more couples walked in and stared at the bar as well. At no point did the woman at the desk feel that maybe managing her dining room was important, so we stood up and walked to hover around some guests to protect the seats we felt should be ours, and others followed suit. An excellent outcome; make patrons feel like vultures are circling.  We then waited 20 god damned minutes for the bartender to notice us. He didn't. We finally got one seat thanks to a patron, who noticing our plight made sure we got her seat.  The bartender finally took notice when he attempted to seat two of the later arrivals in some clearing chairs ahead of us and Jenn spoke up. He replied to this by saying "Hey, I don't know you or them, but they had a drink." Maybe we would have had one had he ever noticed us waiting for 20 minutes to order one.  Top it off? As I attempted to complain to the host when we decided to leave and go elsewhere, another employee got pissed that I interrupted him.  Won't be back.

h5qf9owtv9q8HjaNcrz3OQ.review_text: Came here for late night drinks.  The availability of absinthe is a obviously a plus if you like absinthe and the kitchen is open late.  I had some of a grilled cheese sandwich which was very delicious.  They also carry Sailor Jerry's spiced rum which is great.  It tends to be lively but not too busy here late night, so a decent option if you're in the area (and say, want to avoid a 1 hour wait for Smuggler's Cove).

LRHs4D9teQatVJ4-m0djcg.review_text: I really wanted to give this place 2 1/2 stars.  Let me start by saying I used to LOVE this place. But the last three times Ive been... it was very different. Not horrible... but for the price vs quality... not worth it.  The fried chickpeas are good... and other dishes are good as well.... but not outstanding... There are so many other amazing dinner spots in SF...

C9Ll5T1fcs55r8B69-I8JQ.review_text: The atmosphere is perfect for a date.  The food though... it was OK.  I had the arctic char and wasn't too impressed with the over-cooked meat.  What is arctic char you ask?  It's a fish related to salmon.  Basically looks and takes like salmon.  I have to admit though, it has a bit of a milder taste than salmon.  The description of crispy potato slices on top sounded great (who doesn't like fried carbs?), but it ended up not really adding to the overly-cooked meat.    The slices were also way too salted for salmon. I mean arctic char.      The chocolate cake for dessert was really great.  Not too sweet and the crust had a great crispy texture, almost like a wafer.

Z8I_C55SRATUKIlfZzgQuA.review_text: Stopped in for lunch the other day. The food was amazing. So much so that it made up for the bad service that we received. The server was friendly when she came around. Unfortunately, she didn't come around that often.   Another issue, was the flat bread on the menu said it had artichokes but when it came out there was asparagus on it instead. My companion flagged down the waitress to figure out what was going on and the waitress kept looking at her like she had three heads. She didn't understand why we were questioning the asparagus. Finally another server walked by and overheard the exchange, he advised that they had changed the flat bread but hadn't updated the menu. I think that's kind of important to mention when someone orders an item off of the menu. After all asparagus and artichokes are two very different vegetables. Better yet, you should update your menu.  Aside from the flat bread issue, everything else was fantastic. Three of us ordered the special pork tenderloin that they had that day. It was one of the best dishes I've ever had. So yummy. We also got the mac & cheese and potatoes off of the sides menu to share. I could do without the potatoes, they weren't anything special but the mac & cheese was pretty good.   This place is a definite must try...just hope that you get a better server.

CPdkpOswYgtdxMPUbZ0T9Q.review_text: So...I have heard all sorts of things about how Absinthe has "fallen from grace", how they have "bad service", that the food is "not that great", etc.   Good thing I like to make my own decisions, because everything negative I had heard about Absinthe was 100% *wrong*.   let's start with the fact that my date and I were almost a half hour late for our reservation - we did call to warn them it was going to happen, but when we got to the door, we were immediately ushered to a waiting table, and the hostess and server were amazingly nice and polite about it - not seeming the slightest bit put out (although I felt bad regardless).   We started off with a couple of classic cocktails from their amazing cocktail list. I had the Blood & Sand, my date had the French 75 - both of which were mixed to perfection, and were absolutely delicious.   Then we got into a small oyster tasting...everything was fresh, tasty, and presented quite nicely.  We were both in a "must eat steak" mood, so I knew that we were going to get a nice vintage bottle of wine off of their list, and our server had the sommelier come out to assist me with picking out something to pair with our meal. The sommelier was extremely friendly, and knowledgeable, and he worked with my palette choices/leanings, and I decided on a beautiful '98 Castello di Verduno Barolo (a Tuscan/Piemonte Nebbiolo based Italian red). For the price point, it drank like a much higher end wine, and both my date and I were extremely pleased with the selection.   For a mid course, we shared the artichoke and chantarelle/crimini tart, which was baked to perfection. I could have eaten about twelve of those things myself!   Then, as the wine opened up, our main courses came. she got the 7oz Filet, I got the 10oz rib eye - both came with beautiful reductions, more 'shroomy goodness, beautifully sauteed spinach, and an amazing slightly curried potato gratinee. To say our steaks were cooked to utter perfection would be an understatement. We were both blown away by the quality and amazing taste of our meals.   To finish we split a berry sorbet, and I paired it with a tasty little Moscato di Asti.   That was the meal - everything was perfect in terms of taste, portion size, etc. Beyond that - our service was IMPECCABLE. We never had to lift a finger to pour our wine, to ask for water, or even when my date got up to use the restroom, the server was ALWAYS there to refold her napkin for her. And on top of all of that - both my date and I noted that the staff that night was exceptionally gorgeous. We wanted to take our cute, pigtailed server home with us ;)  All in all, our Absinthe experience was amazing, and I'll surely return to explore some of their other offerings. I'd been in once before with some other friends that had reservations, and I sampled some of their cheese plates and their lamb - but that was a much more casual and impromptu visit, so I didn't want to review them at that point. This last meal was worthy, and Absinthe is worthy of high praise. Do yourself a favor...ignore the naysayers and give it a shot yourself...I think you'll have a great experience!

fSzJO3tSVQ6DNx6jNf_fzA.review_text: Wowoweewow!  Everything (food and drinks) were DELISH. Truly lived up to the hype. My lamb confit over couscous was so moist, I thought I was eating lamb mashed potatoes (not really, but it was moist like you know what!)  Mistep: The panna cotta included a basil meringue on top, which I didn't love due to the mixture of savory and sweet. If you like curry flavored chocolate, you might like this.

tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ.review_text: 12.07.10  Who waltzes into Absinthe for a second dinner after Sebo?  We do...  Immediate bar seating, water, bread, + cocktail, dessert and regular menu.  Rabbit meatballs, pretzels, french fries, french onion soup, and a sorbet.  Plus a cocktail.  (Side bar: did they take the housemade hot dogs off the menu now that Jaime has left?)  Come hungry, leave happy.  Total damage: $59

mROok9JZx19AwvOJlI8FHQ.review_text: Excellent food and ambiance! We had 3 small plates consisting of sausage and potatoes, tuna poke, and seafood...All of them were excellent and our favorite was the seafood. I normally don't eat too much carbs but I couldn't help but dipping a ton of bread into that sauce.  The Uptown Manhattan I had was excellent and the lady's drink, the Gold Miner, was very good too.  Service was friendly and professional and we were stoked to get a table at the front window.  The only negative thing to not was the price. Everything was really good but it just seemed a bit overpriced. I've had similar meals in the East Bay for much cheaper.  Still, I would not hesitate to return in Absinthe!

wm1YzpmZPIPYhDu5t2QVsw.review_text: Sunday Afternoon. I need a drink with a friend. this place is empty - just 10 old couples at the bar. We go straight to the reception desk and we are all smiley and excited to be here. Old fart in a suit with glasses looking in an empty paper sheet at the desk. So it turns out that they are busy and we have to wait 30 minutes although the place is empty. No "Welcome", No "I'm sorry", No "Sir". This place is so shiny and expensive and this attitude is so fucking wrong. Not going back there. Ever again and I'm gonna tell all my friends!

K5as-hBg2K4oAP-J54iX3w.review_text: Went here for a really nice, work dinner to celebrate something and had an amazing meal!   We had oyster-tomato shooters that were AMAZING! The french onion soup was unreal! The rest of the meal is a blur, as the drinks were strong, and the wait staff attentive. We had a great time and left very satisfied.   PS- the absinthe was indeed flaming.

s_pPOKOScfqU_uea-qztew.review_text: We were greeted cordially and seated promptly in an intimate and rather plush dining room.  The noise level was low, the food was delicious, and the service outstanding.  We will definitely be back.

4DF-Y8ev3af6qZeF4KrL6g.review_text: I walked into Absinthe feeling like I was going to see Earnest Hemingway or some 1920's novelist. It is a beautiful place with a romantic ambiance. I enjoyed being transported to a different time while eating my delicious burger, cocktail, and small plates. Everything was delicious and made with fine ingredients.   What I had: 1. the Hotel Internacional cocktail. I've gotten accustomed to drinking strong drinks, so if you like a drink with a kick and a good fruity flavor, try this one.  2. the burger, stuffed pasta shells, and the curry tasting chickpeas. I mean, how could a well rated place like Absinthe get a bad review for their food? I was completely satisfied.

kVse5lPbrFuJD-BTKDUitA.review_text: If you live in SF and you haven't been, I'm not sure what you're waiting for.  If you want an actual bartender that cares about how drinks are prepared, you've found your place.  Servers are also extremely knowledgeable about drinks and food.  The food is always excellent.  I suggest starting with a cheese pairing, they do an excellent job pairing correctly.  Their bread is also wonderfully prepared.  French onion soup is very good, but you probably only need the half-order so that you can sample some other things.  My sister ordered the stuffed french toast...AWESOME.  This plate is probably enough for 2 to share.  Actually, go with some friends and share a few things!  Drinks are about $10-$12 and well worth it.  Our table of 3 had 6 mixed drinks, fried chick peas, 2 french soups, 6 cheese sampler, french toast and a salad.  Total bill was around $160...cheese sampler alone was $65ish, but well worth it.

A_bb24ikt27QpMuwGEWsqw.review_text: Food was delicious.  The service was mediocre.  For a French restaurant, you would expect water and bread/butter without having to ask.  And, I had to ask for a mug of hot water twice.  When I finally asked another waiter, it was brought out to me in about 30 seconds.  We ordered the halibut.  Super tender and well worth it.  The pretzel nuggets were warm and tasty, especially with the dipping sauce.  We also ordered the pork belly.  Absolutely delicious!  My brother and his girlfriend ordered the cassoulet, which was also delicious and full of meat.  We had a late lunch so we split two appetizers and two main entrees between four people.

A2GArf1Nc-Kb1EK3TubKYA.review_text: I learned about Absinthe by watching Top Chef Season 5 where Jamie showed off her amazing culinary skills. I've wanted to eat there ever since, so I chose it for my birthday dinner. My S.O. and I made a reservation several days in advance, and we were seated promptly in the back private dining area. We were originally seated at a table that was in the most highly trafficked area. It felt like we weren't fully in the room, so we asked to move. They kindly offered us the next table over that was a bit more in the room. That was a comfortable solution. The service left a little to be desired, as we waited what seemed to be too long for bread and water and for our server to take our order. Overall, it seemed like our server was either too busy with other customers or that she would have rather not been working that night. She wasn't as attentive as I would have wanted her to be. Here's what we ordered: We couldn't resist indulging in some cocktails. My S.O. got a gin-based drink with orange and angostura bitters from their cocktail list. He also got a glass of Cabernet Sauvignon to go with his dinner. I got a couple mint juleps and am really grateful that they were able to make this drink that isn't available at most places, as it's one of my favorites. 5 stars for the drinks. - Escargots in shell -- I felt as if I were Julia Roberts in Pretty Woman, as I got to use snail tongs to hold the shells in place so that I could get to the meat. I was so nervous that the shell would go flying across the room, but I succeeded in eating them without incident. They were perfectly cooked in a butter/garlic sauce. And the sauce was perfect for dipping the crusty garlic bread and other table bread. - Saffron & cinnamon braised lamb shank -- This was my entrée. Wow. I've never had lamb shank that was quite this succulent. The meat jumped off the bone just with a glance. The flavors complemented the meat well. I do think I would have preferred a crunchier side than the Israeli cous cous because it was also really soft. I think the plate would have been slightly better balanced with something like rice or al dente cous cous. - Grilled Hereford ribeye - This was my S.O.'s entrée. I tasted the ribeye, and it was perfectly cooked and flavored. For dessert, we shared the Scharffen Berger chocolate pot de crème, crème chantilly. Perfect amount of chocolate -- smooth texture. Since we had made a note in the reservation that it was my birthday, they brought it out with a candle and "Happy Birthday" message. I appreciate that touch. Overall, dining at Absinthe was a great experience, and I would return again for a special occasion or just to get a signature cocktail from the bar. Be sure to check out my pictures. yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…

xcyDP9KumziCqcMOaMXNBQ.review_text: I visit Absinthe from time to time. I enjoy their Pretzel bites and cocktails. However, their main dish are quite over-priced and salty for me. I recommend here if you want to go for drinks and bar bites, but I think there are better French restaurants if you are looking for authentic French entrees and desserts.

Nuk54dt8Osk8ghUhpuNxqQ.review_text: I celebrated my birthday here and dinner was amazing! It was classy and romantic, the food was delicious and well-prepared, and the service was excellent. I couldn't have been happier with my night out. Upon entrance, the bar is the first thing you see; loud, crowded, people blocking the walkway, but smiles and laughs all around. Beyond the chaos and fun though, lies a quieter and demure dining room. A white table cloth, dim lighting, and a rounded velvet booth set the mood for a great evening.  THE ORDER:   - Mixed Local Green Salad ($13). The mildly sweet poached apples and whipped-fromage blanc really made this simple salad over-the-top special. I also appreciated how they automatically brought the salad out on two plates since they knew we were sharing.  - Beef Tartare ($16): SO GOOD. Flavorful, fresh, and just perfection on the delightfully crisp crostini bread.   - Coffee-Crusted Liberty Duck Breast ($32): The duck was tender, flavorful, and the whole dish worked together very well. I don't know if I tasted the coffee, but I liked the concept nevertheless. Great variety of textures with the wild rice hash, spinach, and almonds.   - Braised American Wagyu Zabuton Beef ($35): Gosh, doesn't the name just sound amazing? I think I prefer my Wagyu beef without the braise, but it was still pull-apart tender and money next to the garlic mashed potato puree.   After many silverware and plate changes later, and a delicious Ginger Rogers cocktail and dessert, easily one of the best meals I've had in SF. Each dish got better and better and I became more and more impressed. Our server was extremely knowledgable about everything on the menu, was very accommodating to our allergy concerns, and remained professional and friendly throughout the evening. Of course the restaurant is a little pricey and the portions can be small for certain dishes, but for what you get, I think it's completely worth it! I had a wonderful time and highly recommend for a special occasion!

NCzHQR580RU3A9JjlgHbNA.review_text: I wanted to try this place for a very long time but my husband always refuses to go here because he had a very bad experience in the past, so I decided to go with some girlfriends. The food was really good, great ambience and delicious drinks! And our server was great!!!

PZ90fTgOCEbRNiZ48F8rQA.review_text: I haven't read the reviews (there are quite a few here), but this place was a perfect match during our date night.  The Wife and I were going to see a show at the Davies hall on a Saturday night, and we hadn't made any real plans to eat beforehand.  I did a quick Yelp! search and found Absinthe and called to see if they had an opening for two in 10 minutes.  That we returned from our trip to Paris the week before also made us pine for the French menu (for the souvenir, of course).  The hostess was remarkably efficient, she pointed out that there would be some cocktail tables open soon, and she could squeak us in if we were there in 10 minutes exactly.  We were seated promptly, and we ordered drinks from the  pretty good wine list.  Our water glasses were always full, and while it is a bit noisy from the crowd, it wasn't too distracting (except for That Lady in the corner announcing how she's okay that her 'friend' married a stripper, and he's happy, and she's happy for him that he, after all, chose to marry a stripper...).  They bill themselves as French/California, and that's a good description.  For appetizers, we had a selection of fresh (non-pasteurized) cheeses (which I love) and had an alternate toast that didn't have walnuts.    I had the pork and The Wife ordered the coq au vin.  Both were excellent, and served hot.  One really cool bonus, after we ordered, the waitress asked if we had a showtime to make.  We told her we did, and they put a rush on it without spoiling our experience.  We didn't have time for dessert, but maybe next time.  It's moderately pricey, but only because we had a bottle of wine, and it was definitely worth the experience.

PMPOxuDcSTyOLzFf-Vnv3w.review_text: Must try the sinfully delicious French Onion Soup. The service is really friendly and prompt. We tried everything on the menu with the word "French" in it :) Totally worth it!  Loved the location though finding parking was almost painful.

qrWcpUBmahYT73-qQojRkQ.review_text: I really love Absinthe. It's become a very special spot for me and my boyfriend after having a perfect track record of special occasions and romantic dinners here.  French food, wine, and dining culture are near and dear to my heart. I was fortunate enough to travel there a lot as I spent a large portion of my childhood on the south east coast of England -- just a short ferry trip from Normandy -- and my dad is a not-so-secret francophile. I grew up eating pates, stinky cheeses, all kinds of  fresh breads and pastries, and even getting a taste for wine. My dad told me that it would serve me well to learn about the finer things in life... and he was right!  Sadly it's not always easy to get a taste of France in San Francisco. New York, yes, but it doesn't really exist in the same way here. Sometimes I get homesick and feel like nothing here scratches that itch. Absinthe is an exception! It's a brilliant casual yet sophisticated setting in the classic bistro style. The menu is flexible so you can have a modest meal or have a grand experience, as you wish.  To start the meal, it's hard not to order the chicken liver pate. It's just so good! It is quite filling though so I wouldn't order it expecting it to be eaten by just one person. Again, It comes in the traditional bistro style -- served with toast and fruits softened in a glaze. I love having some with the crusty bread they serve as well, as it's nice to vary the texture from the pillowy toast to the chewy crust of the other bread. The steak tartar is my boyfriend's favorite after he got over the initial shock of eating a raw egg yolk (even though the raw steak didn't make him bat an eye).  For mains, the ribeye steak is hard to beat. I also love the potato crusted salmon. It's hard to pull me away from these two, but I've had and enjoyed chicken and pork dishes as well. The WINE, can't believe I almost forgot. I generally order a bottle of a dry Burgundy or Cote du Rhones. The recommended Burgundy is delicious, but there is so much variety it would be hard not to find something to your taste. Sometimes I'll start with a glass of white as it's a nice accompaniment to the richness of the liver pate.  The desserts are generally lovely. The last time I was in I enjoyed a goat cheese tart, that was sort of similar to a cheesecake made with tangy goat's cheese, but it was just fantastic so I feel that comparison doesn't do it justice. Complemented beautifully by a glass of Sauternes. Can't go wrong with that combo! And of course there are so many cheeses to choose from. I could go on and on, so let's just say I always leave here full and happy!  It's not all perfect however: we've had the cocktails not work out so well on occasion, so now we generally give them a miss and head straight for wine. The overflow seating area on the far side of the bar leaves A LOT to be desired in terms of ambiance. I'm willing to wait longer to avoid sitting in what feels like a lobby or a restaurant at an airport. (OK, that's pretty mean, but I really do not like sitting there.) So much of the experience for me is the look and feel of the main dining room. The full experience.  For anyone familiar with and fond of bistro style dining, found of course in France, but also quite popular in New York -- Absinthe is hard to beat for San Francisco. It doesn't have to be super fancy, the prices are reasonable and the menu is flexible enough that you don't HAVE to break the bank to have a nice time. It is a lovely spot for a special occasion dinner however, when you want to mark the event and really treat yourself. The food is lovely and classic, and the service is warm and polite.   Absinthe is a real gem and I plan to have many more romantic dinners here for years to come!

IjoMFDpWKoj2lMO65xN9YA.review_text: After finally trying this place, I have to say that it was pretty darn good.  The atmosphere is very cozy - a perfect place for a rainy San Francisco evening.  The service was quite attentive, the cocktails were outstanding, and the food was decadent.   Stuff I tried: - ceviche - dungeness crab - beet salad - coq au vin  Although everything was tasty, nothing stood out enough to make come back again too soon for dinner, but I will definitely think about coming to the bar for some cocktails!

5Y5KbsI5buMcNh2hTFaRpA.review_text: Fried chickpeas?  Hell. Yes.  Located in the heart of Hayes, this charming dining experience was a highlight of my trip to San Francisco.  Although there was a bit of a wait for a table at Absinthe, the hostesses were a delight and helped us score some seats at the bar instead for our impromptu dinner. Not a bad seat in the house!  We gulped down delicious glasses of Grenache while noshing on the new love of my life, fried chickpeas, tasty salads, mini-pretzels, and comfy french fries. This broad was stuffed! Wait service was efficient and professional yet not overly friendly.  Prices were fair as our bill came out to around $75 for two!

HmVwoENIOxzISPdpkaEbaQ.review_text: I was really hoping for great bistro fare, but was underwhelmed with the exception of the excellent steak tartare and wonderful soup.  Very little in the way of what you would typically expect to see on a French bistro styled menu.  I had the trout for an entree which was very nice, but nothing spectacular.    Service was okay; sommelier was great, but our server seemed distracted.  Our drinks and food were all brought by different staff and our main server seemed incredibly disinterested us.  Absinthe is known for their cocktails so we each started with one,and ordered wine to come with our dinner.  The cocktails were very good but then sat with empty glasses on our table for 15+ minutes when our server finally came by and said she had completely forgotten about the wine.  It was definitely a busy weekend (Memorial Day Weekend) but we certainly a lackluster experience.  There are better bistro moments to be had.

ub4E5HicD-67LNsPmKRInw.review_text: Went her just to drink some Absinthe while we waited for a table at another restaurant that had a 2 hour wait.  It was pretty busy and with a groupe of people there were no tables except a table for 2 in a corner.  We almost left when a waitress stopped me and said she will put something together.  In about 2 mins she used that table, grabbed some chairs and made it work.  We sat down and got down to drinking.    This was not the 1st time I had actually had Absinthe but it was the fist time I had it with the whole sugar cube thing.  It was kinda cool.  I would deffinately go back when I am in the area.  I didn't get a chance to taste anything here as we were just there to drink.  Service was great and I love how they went out of their way to make our group comfortable.

DGx3nBZsv6SOKed_L-DFaw.review_text: I've only eaten at Absinthe a few times and found the food just "OK," but their specialty cocktails and wine selection are extraordinary.  When I lived in Hayes Valley, it was my home bar. I'd take all my dates there. The early 20th century French design, gourmet cocktails and instrumental music always conspired to create a night of enchantment.   I remember this one Saturday night in particular, when I took a date there, after dancing the night away at a Downtown club.  Electricity was in the air because we were going to see Madonna in San Jose the following night. As we passed by a pawn shop on Market, on our way to Absinthe, we noticed that they were playing "Desperately Seeking Susan" on an old TV/VCR combo in the window. Somehow the night seemed like it was orchestrated just for us.    Arriving at Absinthe, we took an outside table (because it was a warm summer night) and ordered oyster shooters and a bottle of champagne. After swigging the creamy oysters and peppery Bloody Mary shooters, there was something so refreshing about that champagne.   We just sat there, drinking, talking and laughing, as people do when they've only known each other briefly.  Somehow the time just escaped us.   But at some point a limousine pulled up right in front of us.  A woman finally emerged with short hair, pulled back in a chignon and wearing a ball gown.  She reminded me of the singer in "Diva."  Unable to find a table (it was particularly crowded that night), she asked if she could join us.  We obliged and she ended up ordering another bottle of champ and telling us about her night -- she had just come from the Opera.  She also entertained us with stories about her friendships with local celebrities and politicians.    At some point she asked us when we were getting married.  That was a little awkward, since we had just met, but she just kept trying to convince us that we're perfect for each other and that we must tie the knot at City Hall asap.  But before that, she thought that we should join her on her yacht for a cruise the following morning. Somehow we didn't think we'd be up till late afternoon, but she gave us her card anyway and told us to call the next morning.   When the bill came, she tore it from our hands and insisted on paying for everything.   We refused, but she wouldn't have it any other way. Finally, she gave us a ride home in her limo.    It was truly a fairytale evening and I don't think that it could have happened anywhere other than Absinthe.

HIoLZjbbstCXkvlwkULO9A.review_text: All the credit for this exquisite meal goes 100% to my genius boyfriend.  In all honesty I was hesitant about eating here, I'm not really a French cuisine enthusiast but hey you give and you get right?  Well thank sweet baby Jesus for my compromise skills because our meal at Absinthe was fantastic.  First things first, drinks: When in Rome, right. Absinthe is my newly monthly cocktail obsession!  Not only is it hella strong but creatively served.  5 stars for creativity & affect.  Food: Everything was delicious, we ordered: fried chick peas spicy pork balls  french onion soup and the pork loin  The service was great, the atmosphere is sophisticated but light.   I absolutely would recommend! :)

oJUh9tCVHoNEwLdAiTD-9w.review_text: Loved the ambiance in Absinthe.  I went for the traditional Coq au vin...& it was delish.  The waitstaff were attentive and the sommelier was very helpful.  Also, the burrata salad and oyster platter to begin were heavenly.  A great vibe, crowd and place to enjoy dinner with a friend.  Fab food!

hDs8NCFpXWeYVnT5hie41g.review_text: This place is so solid I do not even know why I am writing a review other than I just wrote two bad reviews of other restaurants and didn't want to sound too bitter. THE BEST ONION SOUP I HAVE EVER HAD. I have eaten here at least every other month since I moved here 12 years ago and it is consistently fantastic. The waitstaff are courteous, professional, and friendly. The food is outstanding. Keep up the amazing work!!!

f1Kun-va7jSgcCqj08aOZg.review_text: I have never eaten here, and will never.  Called to make a large party reservation a month in advance.  Was originally told they could accomodate us (which THRILLED me) with managers approval.  The reservationist seemed very nice but then came back with an "I'm sorry we are actually booked."  When I asked what happened to the original 8pm reservation she said was open she responded was someone didn't enter another reservation.  I'm sorry but that sounds like a lie.  They were very rude in how the declined my reservation and I will never eat here for that.

lWP8MzKDY95PzNjk479wvw.review_text: Went there for an afternoon snack - fabulous french onion soup! The staff is a little pretentious and the seatings were a bit tight - but I guess that's what you would expect in most SF restaurants ha! Overall - great place.  Would likely go back again.

0hlsFkkaHdoXd9fW197EvA.review_text: The absinthe wasn't terribly good.  And though half of us were eating they forced us to wait in the bar area for 25 minutes on a Wed. night when there was plenty of tables in the "eating" area where we could have been seated.  The food was good, but a bit overpriced and the hostess really needs to work on her people skills.  Kind of a major part of the job description.  Probably won't go back here even though I'll need a place to go for a bite and drink after many a symphony and opera performances.  I so wish Jade a few blocks away hadn't closed.  That was an awesome place.  Where to go in the future?

TZVxTKa5E4R3XvYyCIxQFw.review_text: Amazing variety of cocktails and upscale booze. Love to sit at the bar have a fancy cocktail and some oysters. Food is very good here.

agwHHRcxUjMplPVtvQFoag.review_text: I've been watching Top Chef obsessively, along with my brother and we've been rooting for Jaime, the executive chef here. We've been wondering if her food in real life is as good as it looks on tv, so I treated him to dinner here for his birthday to try it out.   Chickpeas: best thing to eat while drinking, if only these can replace peanuts at all bars.
