Frites: crisped to perfection, big fan of the rouille and mustard sauce, not so into the vinegar sauce Onion soup: good - but not worth raving about, should've gone with the celery root puree Celery root puree soup: delicious with an interesting kick and texture Lamb loin: huge portion, medium rare just the way i like it, combined well with the carrot puree, almonds, and greens. Leftovers still taste almost the same the next day.   Definitely coming back. It's nice to know we can justify rooting for Jaime now.

4eMf_36O9SaIzaEJdJXl9g.review_text: Wow.  We had such a wonderful experience at Absinthe. The atmosphere, service, food, & cocktails were all fantastic.  Our server, Stephanie, was amazing.  The restaurant is a bit loud in the bar area, but not so loud that you can't have a conversation.  We ate: French Onion Soup Leek Soup Fried Chickpeas Pretzels w/ cheese sauce Coq Au Vin Squash ravioli Ice Creams Beet & Tangerine cheesecake (?)  Yum. Yum. Yum.

vI58xZpbh4cM8d8yO8avmA.review_text: I love this place but their burger is pretty lackluster. The meat was awesome but the bun is very dense. Even though the patty was well seasoned, there is nothing special about it at all. Go for the meatballs or the garlic soft pretzels instead.

8ro9EoJQEmuQFRvMk36RUQ.review_text: I hate to be meh about this place given my initial level of expectation about it.  After my third trip last night, I think my opinion on this place's slightly above par-ness is solidified.  Cocktails - I've had a bunch of their specialty cocktails here and overall they tend to be too sugary and lacking balance.  At $9-$12, they should be perfect.  Food - I love the French Onion soup here and I've had good luck with entrees.  I think the bar food tends to be sort of bad.  The homemade buns have been too dry every time I've had them.  Usually the bar food (hamburgers, hot dogs, croque madames) leaves me with a stomachache.  Service - It's not good enough.  I love the maitre d but the servers don't check in enough.  Last night we received our food and needed an extra condiment but the waitress didn't come by for another 20 minutes to see if our meals had arrived properly.  It wasn't the first time I've had disappointing service there.  Frankly, I think the restaurant is too big.  Details slip through the cracks every time I'm there and they seem to be related to the scale at which they're trying to deliver high quality food.  The location is a bonus and likely to lure me back in at some point.

Z88N6qly3Dp5C06XbZ9IMQ.review_text: Absinthe gets it right EVERY time.   When I think of a top notch restaurant in SF to celebrate an occasion: birthday, anniversary, retirement parties, fifth date dinner before the symphony, random Tuesday happy hour .. well, you get the picture.   Hang out at the bar and check out their cocktails, there are currently 19 choices on the list, so take your time. I personally love the Galapagos Cocktail (that kaffir lime taste with a peppery kick in the end is really something!) or go for a well made Corpse Reviver #2. Pair your tipple with truffled popcorn, soft pretzel or french fries.   The dining room is evocative: sultry reds, Parisian art and snug booths to keep the romance going. But wait til you get your hands on that Absinthe Hamburger: seasoned well, with aioli, red onion and house made pickles. Or you can go MMMeat-y way by ordering a rib eye, prepared medium rare of course, in a lovely chimichurri sauce.  Absinthe, I'm crazy about you. I only see you couple of times a year, but you get it right.  Every. Single. Time.

_lWYCU6u1rE-YAqRALUCdw.review_text: Food and drinks: five stars! Try the pretzel appetizer and pretty much any cocktail on the specialty menu. T  Service: 3 stars. Our french and entirely unattentive waiter, (let's call him Pierre), took our drink order and subsequently disappeared for the next hour. Pierre resurfaced in all his French glory about an hour later, chatted up the table next to us in his native tongue, the disappeared for another half an hour without so much as an au voir. He showed up just in time to bid us adieu. The majority of the evening was spent flagging down random servers and hostesses to take our food order, bring us our check, etc.   I've heard really good things about this place so maybe our bad service was an outlier. I probably can't live without those pretzels, so I'll be giving it another go. The meat ball appetizer is a close runner up. Be sure to make a reservation if you want to eat on the earlier side. We showed up at about 6pm on a Saturday and it was packed, (mostly the ballet crowd). If you arrive after 8pm things clear out significantly and getting a table right away looked like it would have been no problem at all.

GkGRnqa9NUZK-913K3WIvw.review_text: We only stopped in for drinks and some appetizers after a long day of walking around after Bay to Breakers. Luckily my husband and I got a lovely seat for two right by the window and watched the last hours of the sun disappear over quiet hayes valley. Is hayes valley always sooo quiet? Anyways our server was great he got a whiskey recommendation from the bartender for me and I loved it! Exactly what I was looking for. and he let me take a picture of the bottle so I don't forget the name.  We got the duck confit which was excellent. Perfectly crispy

gV7zdM8n0pEVErNwdFcgAA.review_text: I ended up at Absinthe the first day that I was in the city the last time, and I was really impressed with it.   The bar was well appointed, with polite and patient bartenders that were really nice about helping me pick out some excellent drink options. I really appreciated that after a long day of air travel. The drinks were on the expensive side, but not excessively so.   The spicy chickpeas that are on the bar snack menu are so addicting that I ended up eating multiple orders of them for my dinner that evening with a small salad. The berbere spice blend and the texture of the chickpeas was absolutely perfect.   I still dream of them.

YG5EroFMYByZODecz3U_kQ.review_text: I've had my eye on this bar/restaurant for awhile now. When expectations are this high, it's easy to be disappointed. But disappointed I was not.  The beef tartare was THE BEST. My friend, a self-proclaimed beef tartare connoisseur, says that it's definitely in her top 5 in SF (though apparently can't beat Marlowe's -- gotta try that spot next).  The burger is one of the cheapest entrees on the menu at $15 (+$1.25 to add gruyere cheese), and freaking fantastic. We got it medium and it was cooked on the medium-rare side, which was A-OK with me. It did come with some of the skinniest fries I've ever had, if that's your thing.   The French onion soup is also supposedly famous here. My friends and I shared a bowl. It looked just as a French onion soup is supposed to look, topped with copious amounts of melted cheese and chock full of tender caramelized onions. My only complaint was that I woke up the next morning PARCHED. Make sure you stay hydrated if you eat this, as it's super salty!  But the real reason for my high rating was the chicken liver mousse spread. I thought Range prepared this well, but Absinthe blows their rendition out of the water. It was so so so so creamy, I was literally scraping the mason jar for the remains when it was finished. Addicting. I would come back just to eat this again and again.  On top of all that, the dry martinis here are out of control. Who knew gin martinis paired so well with French onion soup?

BIdFgt_4owlS1VUcTuZ4fA.review_text: Cute cozy corner restaurant, cramped seating and reservations are a must.  We started off with wine and the complimentary french bread which I liked very much.  For appetizers bf had the Frisee, it had a good amount of little bacon chunks with some type of coating on it, tasty but not sure what it was, baby leeks (hard to chew), and tasty caviar on top of a rich fried duck egg.  I had the french onion soup - served in a cute mini soup tureen and it was intensely good. A rich broth, not too many onions and lots of crusty cheese melted on top with a nice piece of french bread at the bottom.  Before our meal came, a horrible stench overcame the restaurant - smelled like dead fish and everyone was looking around.  I can't repeat the comment that my bf made but I sure hope that whoever ordered that horrid fish sent it back because isn't good fish not supposed to smell fishy?  Anyway, we endured the foul odor for about 5 minutes before it dissipated. For dinner bf had the stuffed chicken, good but not great.  I had the hamburger.  Asked for it to be medium well and got it rare, too rare!  I like rare but ordered it mw so bf could have some but he thought it looked to raw and didn't want any.  The ground beef was almost tasteless, lots of grease on the bottom of the bun but the bun itself was good.  I had the french fries too, a BIG metal cup with a paper cone inside to hold a good amount over the top.  They were good but very small, short & skinny and served with a few different condiments, even some infused malt vinegar.  Not our server, but one of the employees came over and took our plates away, okay, fine but I was still eating my fries and he took them too, I'd hardly touched them!  I could have asked to take them to go but it was obvious that they wanted us out of there to get ready for the next reservation.  The bill was high, I think they overcharged us for the drinks because the prices didn't match what we saw on the menu.  Too bad we came on and "Off" night because we went to see "Wicked" afterwards.  Perhaps I'm just spoiled but I love to have an over the top meal before seeing and over the top show, especially in the city.

kie7nzDJYisVYHGWBS373Q.review_text: The last place I had Absinthe was in Australia.  As much as I could remember the licorice taste, I can't remember what happened afterwards.  I kind of like to remember what happens when I get trashed.  Fortunately, I was slick and saved the receipt so I didn't have to trust my shit-for-brains memory.  We went straight to the bar, through a swanky packed crowd and ordered the bartender's recommended Absinthe (The Prenod and the St. George).  For something listed as highly flammable, they were great sippers and I think I realized that I really do quite like drinking liquid licorice.  A lot.

vX25YeTtrmjT1-dXj1VmWg.review_text: The ambience of this restaurant is welcoming.  I started at the bar and enjoyed the Galapagos at the bartender's suggestion.  I thought I had swore off pisco from my trip to Peru but I couldn't resist.    My friend and I were very pleased with the menu!  We started with Tsar Nicoulai (farm raised) caviar and shared the country rabbit stew and Niman pork rib eye.  I highly recommend the rabbit stew, it's delicious!  The service was excellent, friendly and attentive.  I wish I had room for dessert!    I'll be back as I want to try other items from the menu.

m5cBT7OYfn0HM0d-RCsdZQ.review_text: M a g n i f i q u e  Tres tres enchante, Absinthe.  For a first timer to hit the 10th anniversary party, it was the perfect soft opening to their environment, their service and level of culinary performance.  I was invited along with a friend of mine to attend the party and although we arrived right on time, the place was packed.  I fell in love with the interior of this charming invocation of Southern France replete with deep crimson velvet couches and dark wood touches throughout.  The white linens on the tables were but a quiet indicator that food was indeed the showcase of the establishment.  I wandered over to the bar where the bartender asked if I wanted some absinthe.    "Isn't that illegal?" I queried, remembering an episode on food network how people drinking absinthe abroad had horrible reactions to the wormwood concoction labeled distinctly as the la Fe Verte.  I was hesitant, but since the opportunity offered itself, I accepted.  The drink itself was presented with flourish, a bit reflective of the green tea ceremony in Japan.  After he finished, I tried my first sip tentatively.  It was strong.  And refreshingly cold.  And hinted of licorice.  "This is it?" I found it good, "Almost like licorice!"  "This is Swiss Absinthe," he replied.  In addition to the good drinks, we were fed beautiful little hors d'oeuvres, my favorite being the little scallop with caviar on top.  I had to take a picture of it........absolutely exquisite.  In addition, little lamb hamburgers made their rounds, but I was in no mood to open my mouth wide to take a bite. These apparently came from the sister take-out cafe, Arlequin, located next door.  After spending time in the dining room, we filtered out to the main bar, where my friend knew the bartender, who turned out to be an extremely charming man; quite social and communicative.  He then in turn introduced a friend of his, a sharp handsome Brit, who then fell into conversation with my friend.  I was feeling rather cloudy (such was my absinthe drink) but in a good dreamy way, so I was quite content in leaning against the counter and smiling dizzily at everyone.    Funny, then I ran into someone I knew.  Small world.  I'll be back for their brunch as well as their famed Neiman hamburgers next.  Excellent service, the waiters were extremely attentive-cordial-communicative and knew exactly what was on their menu.  Bartenders top notch and the host/hostess were accommodating and nice.  This is a classy establishment and it resounded quite so throughout, which would indicate my favorable review.

qcqjzBi2pzWzCnc5crDiyQ.review_text: Came here late on a Saturday night. Wasn't hard to get a table at all. Food was great, the absinthe was delicious, and service was prompt and courteous.  The steak tartare is good, but nothing compared to the ones in Paris. The blue cheese was great, and I thought it was interesting how each cheese had a pairing to come with it. I never thought of drizzling my blue cheese with honey!

FdJliLMmxccEswA_ULO06w.review_text: Overall we had a great experience at Absinthe.  As all the other reviewers say, the drinks were fantastic.  Loved the Ginger Rogers.  My boyfriend and I split the french onion soup to start and it was delicious.  The waiter nicely split the soup into two cup-sized portions for us.  Cheese and bread were tasty and I love whenever a restaurant serves salted butter.  The entrees were fabulous.  Beautiful presentation as well.  I had the bistro filet and my boyfriend had the lamb dish.  We were very pleased with both.  The only negatives: 1) I didn't like how the restaurant was set-up.  We had dinner reservations, but the dinner dining is divided into two areas.  There is the main dining room, but there is this small section behind the bar area (separated by a low wall) that also is for dinner.  We were placed behind the bar area and it feels like you are in the bar with all the noise that comes over.  Also, the music didn't jive with the setting.  That could be because we were hearing all the music for the 'bar area' and not the main dining room.  Make sure you request to sit in the main dining room. 2) Our waiter forgot our glasses of wine that were supposed to come with our entrees.  He seemed to disappear for awhile, so we had to ask someone else to bring our wines.  Unfortunately, we were too stuffed to try dessert.  Delicious food though and we'll be back!

FiNQWY0RDGXoYCQ_IswrLQ.review_text: We recently went for dinner before the symphony. Our waiter was very nice and asked us when the concert started, just to make sure we would get out on time. He also suggested my husband just get a club soda when he asked for a mineral water, so he wouldn't have to pay for a big bottle.  We thought the food was great. We shared the garlic pretzels with cheese dipping sauce. This was yummy. The hubs had the onion soup and a steak. He said both were good. I had the sole and thought it was well seasoned and cooked just right.  The restaurant was busy and crowded, but it was not too noisy and we got out in plenty of time for our concert. Our waiter did forget to bring my glass of wine, but when I asked again, he brought it right away.  Would definitely go back.

p-mXpuj_T8jb0h8zutkvbw.review_text: The brunch/lunch menu is fairly limited. The food did not seem special to me. If you are looking for Hayes Valley brunch/lunch I would stick to Bar Jules down the block--a much smaller scale operation with food that is of much higher quality.

pQN0zYVU9pv9Xr_DwwcTQw.review_text: Even though this place has over 1250+ reviews...I continue to echo my fellow Yelpers in the deliciousness of each dishes served and superb services surrounded by plush and classic decors.  Even though I've only consistently only tried their brunch here, I vowed that I *will* one day try their dinner menu.  :)    Now onto brunch!  My favorites of all times: - Banana Blueberry Soufflé Pancakes served w/ maple syrup & whipped creme: amazingly fluffy, seriously they taste as light as air... :)  - Wild Mushroom Omelet served w/ caramelized onions, pecorino, and fresh herbs: this is perfection in an omelet form, unlike all the other omelets that are generally heavy and cheesy filled - Croque Monsieur: my ultimate brunch sammi ever!!!  Black forest ham, gruyére, Dijon mustard, all sandwiched between toasted levain topped w/ a fried egg.  This is the place where their Croque Monsieur is done RIGHT!!!  Try it!  You won't be disappointed.  :)  No brunch is ever complete without drinks...so here's what I'd get: - When Figs Fly: house made fig cordial w/ champagne - simple yet elegantly appropriate!  perfect drink for brunch!   - Galápagos: kaffir-lime leaf muddled in pepper syrup, Alto del Carmen Pisco, lemon-lime juice plus a splash of grapefruit juice.  All shaken and served w/ brandied cherries.  Sinfully sweet & delicious but watch out...this drink is definitely *much* stronger than it tastes...don't let it fool you... ;)  Happy Brunching and as always cheers everyone!  :D

yGcRDtBOpCYnEFooKOPUOA.review_text: I had not been to Absinthe since 2006!  But now I have a client in the hood there and decided to give it another try. Wow, I'd forgotten how beautiful it was and the food is divine. The neighborhood has improved greatly and overall it was a very fun evening celebrating a large deal closing with the perfect meal and wine. I'll be back!

px2AZNJaNKOoh8mj5q39Tw.review_text: What a great spot! Perfect location for a meal before or after the symphony, ballet, etc. in the area. It has a wonderful French atmosphere. We went on a Wednesday for lunch and it was not over crowded or very noisy. Has a cozy feel. Service is very refined and responsive. They can actually make a real French Croque Madame, which is rare in SF. High marks to the pate, the lamb meatballs and wonderful salads.

Nwm7pKZNBnOKH-GDEiyipg.review_text: Why, with so many other (better) choices nearby?

kMiDDOecnXNNShl2i3Z54Q.review_text: I was fortunate enough today to attend a work luncheon at Absinthe. I was really looking forward to eating here and it didn't disappoint. Everything we had was really good...from the Starters to the Dessert! The Marinated Olives and Soft Pretzel were good and so was the Little Gem Lettuce salad. I got the Fulton Valley Chicken with Artichoke Spatzle Gratin for my entree, although a bit salty for my taste, it was still yummy. The best part was dessert--the Chocolate Pot de Creme was divine! It took care of the chocolate craving I've been having for the past week...so yummy! And their coffee wasn't too shabby either.   I would definitely come back here again to try other stuff on their menu. And I saw that they also have a Pavlova on their dessert menu--I can't wait to try that for sure!

srk3OTdk6omfcmSVUto4IQ.review_text: For a fun environment, excellent service and fantastic food - go to Absinthe!  As a vegan, I'm often nervous to eat out, but the server here was happy to explain each item on the menu in detail and even went to double-check a few things with the kitchen.  The corn soup was one of the best things I've ever eaten! As far as the drink menu goes, Absinthe is definitely the star, but they have a whole other list of cocktails if Absinthe isn't your thing. The ambiance was great - not too loud, but not silent - the bathrooms were very clean and the decor is warm and inviting. I can't wait to go back!

6Mi5woaSUh6gGcLnzLYNfg.review_text: Not too much to say about this place.  Everything was ok. APPETIZERS ARE BETTER THAN THE ENTREES. And for the entrees, the side garnishes are all A-ok.  I guess at least the showcased proteins are good.  Thats all.

_UiFOW3BLrCi_g6UP3P6aQ.review_text: Going more downhill.   Terrible cocktails- 'Sidecar', 'Corpse Reviver #2', 'the one with the longest name'  ($9)   Salad serving getting smaller ($13).  French onion soup was ok and better than the one at The Grove, acoording to my companions  (it was my first time trying it).  KURI SQUASH CAKE: tiny portion  Really loud obnoxious crowds.

WzTapC3mZGEcX7Umvy7KtQ.review_text: Gotta love Opentable to make reservations because the wait can be awhile at this place. We ordered the oyster shooters with the bloody mary mix, which was very good, who would have known that that combination would taste so good. Our entrees we ordered the burger and the lamb. The portions were good and we both left full and had no room for desert. The service was excellent, very attentive and always checked on us.

_DmZf8CUPgsuPdSnQcP4Ug.review_text: A completely unexpected decadent evening of perfection. Very sexy/swanky decor...I wasn't expecting any of this and was more than pleasantly surprised.  Also, the aromas hitting me through the bar and brasserie had me salivating before I even got to our table.  This chef knows how to make sauce...I know it sounds weird, but it's a big deal in my book. A really good sauce can make even the most boring plates amazing. Not that the food on the plates we ordered had any issues...if I was home, I would have licked my plate.  Started with oyster shooters. Do it. I skipped the vodka but was informed it was excessive and necessary. Really yummy bloody mary mix accompanied by a massive local oyster. Need I say more?  Entree: Osso Bucco- WOW. seriously juicy, fall off the bone pork (smothered in awesome sauce as I mentioned above) - VERY HAPPY I ordered this (I almost went with the burger). SO SO SO SO SO DELICIOUS.  Hubby Entree: Coq Au Vin. NOT your regular braised chicken. Seriously smooth, rich, creamy jus sauce smothered all over tender/juicy chicken. Homestyle cooking taken to another level, indeed.  Desserts: Holy crap! The most amazing, German chocolate mousse cake EVER. I will not give away too much about the dessert-just please trust me, you need to have this. Honorable mention goes to the Butternut Squash Cake-yum!!!  We made reservations and ended up at a cool table in the private dining room-which was a little stuffy but allowed us to have a really cool dinner and take our time...service was great, we were left alone but didn't feel ignored.  Oh yeah-the drinks are made with absinthe and I was told they were unique, delicious, and 1 will do you in!  PS. 4 oyster shooters (3 w/vodka), 4 entrees, 4 desserts, and 3 cocktails and 1 espresso came to $230 before tip.

gf4tyQgQOtVMkOdvveRHVA.review_text: A great place to get drinks in a great neighborhood!  I always forget how nice Hayes Valley is.  It has a nice selection of cafes, restaurants and shops and its close enough to the theater district where you can have dinner before your show.  I came to Absinthe for drinks this past Friday evening and we really enjoyed ourselves.  My wife and I had four drinks between the both of us, I had a 21 Hayes and a Galapagos and she had a Sidecar and another drink that I cant remember.  I was informed by our waiter that the bartender who invented 21 Hayes and the Galapagos  was the actual bar tender that made our drinks that evening.  The ambiance was chill yet sophisticated and the service was impeccable.   Although we didn't dine here I read on their website that their head chef is competing on Bravo's Top Chef show!  Absinthe is definitely worth coming to if you are in the neighborhood.

QPhKwoNEGYzIeidIOh-5gQ.review_text: We had a long wait and the hostess was a little snobby but it was all worth it last Sunday when we got our brunch. First of all, everything single thing on the menu sounds amazing. How do you even choose?  We ended up all ordering different things so I was able to try about half of the menu. We got the: Deviled eggs with smoked salmon and black tobiko caviar (awesome!), Griddled Corn Cakes with wilted chard, poached eggs and tasso ham hollandaise (yum), Ricotta-Stuffed French Toast (the winner of brunch. AMAZING), Duck Confit Hash with red peppers, onions, potatoes, arugula salad and poached eggs, Dungeness Crab-Salad sandwich, and the Absinth Hamburger with sauteed mushrooms (so good!).   We loved everything. The drinks were also amazing. I definitely want to come back here for some intense drinking.  There's a wait on the weekends and it's not cheap but I would highly recommend it if you are looking for a great brunch spot.

Xjfc1owyGoFcM94kRxOCJg.review_text: Absinthe is my go to date-night spot.  I love the atmosphere - it's often busy, so make a reservation if you can!  The servers are top notch and very attentive so you never feel like you have to wave someone down to get a refill on your water.  From experience, I can HIGHLY recommend the chickpea and pretzel appetizers.  For dessert, the chocolate pot de creme is beyond amazing, and probably the main reason I keep coming back!

DWZuxdAD1K1RtLlWCuTDsQ.review_text: I have a pretty good feeling that my 1203rd review on the place will truly make the difference.    We sat at the bar and knocked out their burger w/ Gruyere.  Pretty damn good.  The highlight was definitely the cocktails.  Whoa!  I had a French 75 and a Pimms Cup.  Super tasty.    I'd definitely go back.    Don't half step.  Make a reservation

1zkQK41CPXT4fcCpOshYDA.review_text: I love the ambiance here, and the bar!    In the past I would have given it 4 stars, but during our most recent visit, the service was pretty bad.  No one did anything wrong, everything just took forever - for the waiter to arrive, then to come back to take our dinner order, then for the food to come, then for our 2nd drink order, then for our dessert order, etc.  And there were only two of us!  This never happened when the previous chef was in residence.....   Regardless of the service, however, the food is always quite good.

6S6IabAw5CfN4EY6p3jIlA.review_text: Wonderful little restaurant in San Francisco.  Even though we had confused our reservation time and arrived late, the host & hostess were very gracious and accommodating.  Our party of 2 was seated within minutes at a cozy table (side note: the tables are close, as in most urban restaurants).  The wait staff also offered fantastic service.  I found the cocktail list quite amazing ... I tried the Sacred Heart which combines tequila, absinthe, and limoncello into lemony goodness.  I highly recommend the Spicy Fried Chickpeas and the Sweet Yellow Brentwood Corn Soup (on the menu Fall 2010).  The Kurobota Pork Rib Eye also had delicious combination of flavors with the cheddar grits and braised red cabbage.  I tried the sauteed Dungeness crab; this was my first time with Dungeness and I doubt I'd try it again.  The presentation and flavor was amazing, I just think that the restaurant has so many other dishes that have more personality (and of course less work/mess to enjoy!). The Olive Oil & Chocolate dessert combined elements of comfort food (an ice cream sundae!) with new flavors and textures.

oGiqow-Dt9IMepgkswdM4A.review_text: Came here for my birthday brunch with some friends last weekend. Luckily we made a reservations because the place was packed! Service is absolutely fantastic here, because we were seated half an hour after our reservation, the hostess apologized and took care of our desserts!   I started off with a cup of the french onion soup and that was delicious. We decided to all share everything because none of us could decide what we really wanted. We got the banana-blueberry souffle pancakes, ricotta stuffed french toast, and the wild mushroom omelet. The omelet was nothing spectacular, the french toast was actually good and very interesting. My favorite was the pancakes - so fluffy, soft and full of flavor! I also had the Absinthe Lemonade -which I didn't care for..because it was on the bitter side.  For desserts we shared the chocolate pot de creme, thai coconut sorbet, and a strawberry dessert. The desserts were not spectacular in fact we all thought it was all too sweet. Overall, the food and service combined made it a great experience. Will def. want to come back here to try their lunch/dinner menu!

Qd1KGikCmSWlEafDJkLLVQ.review_text: The best crusted salmon that Ive ever eaten. Unfortunately there is not much choice for  me other than fish or vegetarians, so I always end up ordering the fish. Pretzels are definitely unique and tasty.

o60yRcNLuy-oIjHfNlAEdA.review_text: This place was pretty good.  Packed on a Friday night but we had reservations... hostess was great, service was great, food was great.  We weren't that hungry so we got some beef tartar, the roasted beet salad, and the winter vegetable ragout.  The beef tartar was really good... good amount, not stringy at all, nice crostinis... the roasted beets were fantastic but I always love beets... the winter vegetable ragout was just ok... probably should have gotten something else but I had been eating fatty and fried all week and didn't feel like something heavy.  cocktails were tasty and evidently very strong as i found out later in the night... bathroom was clean and easy to use.  It was an enjoyable experience but doubt I'd go back... fancy-french-bistro that's super-crowded is not really my style... maybe I should have grubbed more... but trying to cut back.

UVxY0iyPaqY7s4BSFtt-xA.review_text: Absinthe has an old school feel in the up and coming Hayes Valley.  (actually, Hayes Valley isn't up and coming anymore, it has arrived about 10 years ago.)  I believe it is owned by the same group that owns its neighbors, Arlequin Cafe, and Arlequin Wine. I had been to the Cafe many times, a casual number at your table type of place with a great rear patio, but never here.   The great thing about Absinthe that is perfect for its location near the performing arts centers of Louis Davies Hall, the Opera House, etc., is that they are open late. So you can come here before a performance, or after.   The Bar is always lively and full, the tables are brass topped, and the dark wood decor gives it that old school feel. The service was good, with an old school waitress who was professional, and the rest of the staff attentive and on top of our needs.   We came here for a late night snack about 9:30pm, after another event nearby. We tried the 1/2 sized French Onion Soup ($5.50) and the 1/2 sized Butternut Squash soup ($7). These were followed by dishes in the appetizer group, like Beef Tartare ($16) and a Fuyu Persimmon Salad ($14). We supplemented these with a couple of cocktails.  Food was very good, service great, and a nice casual, but city vibe ambiance.

bDLN3J8NOI2cSY2tScFEig.user_location: Lower Pacific Heights, San Francisco, CA
bDLN3J8NOI2cSY2tScFEig.review_text: One of my absolute favorite brunch spots in the city. Be sure to check out yelp reviews and pictures because they'll often serve food that doesn't show up on the menu. The cocktails are so well executed, the deviled eggs are some of the best I've had, and the french toast is delightful. Hands down, though, my favorite is the duck confit and I'm not even a huge fan of duck or mushrooms. The flavors blend together so well it is purely spectacular.

Qcrn8nFhxURsgwguAjRGUA.review_text: Went in for a catch-up dinner with my best friend from out of town. Juan was a fantastic server - funny, charming and perfect recommendations. The pretzels to start with and the recommended cocktails were amazing. Absolutely can't wait to go back.

C5VdqjjQ7cXKCG1x0UJ19g.review_text: I've coming here for quite a while,I love their dishes as well their Brunch.  Master Chef Jamie Lauren,takes pride and perfection on her dishes. As well the selection of the ingredients are Fresh and in perfect season.  I love the sample of Cheeses as well the oysters are superb..this is a perfect place to bring your first date. It has a flair of Romance and flavor of a Parisian Restaurant.  Which is worth checking out! Bon Apetite!

LwTfiTN6C29195R43xboew.review_text: Updated: 3.5 stars  Far better consistency and service now than years ago when I wrote my review. The seasonal dishes are delicious, the service is thoughtful and attentive and the Absinthe burger is awesome. My family and I eat here about twice per month before the opera and they take great care to get us on our way before 6:30pm.   The menu changes with the seasons and rather than breaking it down by dish I'll just say I'm always happy with the onion soup (which is available year-round) and the wine list is is balanced nicely with French and new world selections. The Sancerre is a good value.   The table bread is a whole wheat or multigrain sourdough from Acme bread and it's dangerous delicious, you may over-indulge if you're a bread 'n' butter fiend.   The swordfish is my favorite entree I hope they have it again come spring. Absinthe is a great choice for an early supper before symphony, opera or ballet. They also host a great bar for a cocktail or a glass of wine and you can order from the bar menu if you don't have a reservation.

54SKBrYbotdvQ8xA0swfdQ.review_text: Hello French Onion Soup and cheese platter! AMAZING! Had a fabulous dinner at Absinthe on Friday night! I had the chicken dish- nothing speical but my friend had the burger! The burger was excellent. The best part though- French Onion Soup and the cheese plate- I will be ordering those two again for sure.   Place is crowded- we had a 9:30pm reservation and got there a bit early- the hostess was pretty accomodating and after we ordered our first drink from the bar she was able to seat us about 20 mins early. I thought the staff was very friendly and the atmosphere was very energitic!

CO3V-Hv7xoyBvjriZ_q_Wg.review_text: I've always driven past this place everytime I am on my way home and seen it on the Dine About Town lists, but I've never had a chance to actually stop and eat here.  First time I've heard of Absinthe was in Europe... not the restaurant...but the actual liquor.  I've always wondered if they served it here... Not like I would try it if they did... I've seen people's reactions after taking that shot.. haha.  Given it was my friend's birthday, we decided to come here for her birthday brunch since she's a fan of breakfast foods.  Parking can be difficult around Hayes Valley, but luckily for us, we were able to find metered parking about 1.5 blocks away!    Upon entering, the restaurant has an old parlor feel to it.  There wasn't much of a wait when we arrived, but we had reservations anyway.  We were seated right away and within a few minutes, our waiter came by.  We ordered the Duck Confit Hash and the Absinthe Hamburger with Guyere cheese and fries.  Since we were sharing our dishes, our waiter had the awesome suggestion of splitting our burgers in half for us, and putting the duck hash in the middle.  Brilliant idea!  Service was a little slow...It took a while for our food to come out to us.  As soon as the food came out, I essentially devoured the duck confit hash... It had sooo much flavor and was absolutely delicious!  I would recommend this dish to everyone who goes here. I almost wish I had it all to myself instead of just half =P  Our burger, cooked medium rare, had the bare minimum on it (everything extra was $1.50 EACH... so we skipped on it), but was still delicious.  It had a really good flavor to it or I was just really hamburger deprived lately...  The fries were okay... I've had better.  If only the fries weren't broken up into small pieces... It was as if we got the bottom of the batch of fries =(  The fries came with 3 dipping sauces - an aioli, dijon mustard, and malt vinegar.   Overall, for our 2 dishes and a side of fries, it came out to be pretty pricey for being brunch ($38 before tip)... but I enjoyed my meals, which is the most important factor.  I would love to try their dinner menu... but maybe when I get more money =P  I can see it being a very cute romantic spot for a date, so guys definitely keep this place in mind! ;)    Because the tiny details count for something, I think it's awesome that they have coat/purse hooks on the walls near the tables.  Why don't all restaurants have that?!

Zlel20PN_ghaa1h5U_fxLQ.review_text: My sister and I celebrated her 24th birthday here, among other places, and we had one of the best brunches of our lives.  The service was excellent.  We also found two charming girls that were neighboring diners to take our photos, and considering how keen I am to capture moments with my kid sister, I was thrilled at how sweet the pictures came out.  One of the girls has a sister in fashion in New York who just broke up with a boyfriend in Queens..of course I volunteered my navigating Brooklyn services-after all, we Brooklynites know more than one way to mend a broken heart and access to discount couture is more than adequate consideration.  We had originally wanted to share the crab omelette, but we changed our minds after sharing several smaller plates.  I had an absinthe and champagne drink, which was strong but awesome.  The licorice started to permeate my brain a bit too fast, but then the firm imported Mahon cheese arrived with homemade walnut bread and apricot jam (with actual rinds).  What an amazing cure for a hangover after our silly fun night hopping around the Marina!  Then the Russian caviar came out with all the trimmings-we spread crème over blinis and added luxurious sprinkles of sieved egg and scallions and then layered on the tiny black pearls...absolutely melt in your mouth, and an intensely sensual pairing with the absinthe and champagne.  Then we had 3 kinds of raw oysters with red wine vinegar, which were outstanding.  Then came the deviled eggs that were the best I've ever had-even better than my friend Carl's mom's.  And then the side of bacon-4 perfect strips of maple glazed, perfectly crispy, and long and warm pieces of meat.  I closed my eyes and those strips reminded me of a well cut custom suit on a well built gentleman caller.  I said aloud, "Please kill me, life can't get any better than this."    We were surprised by a complimentary birthday dessert-a truly inspired grapefruit sorbet with blood oranges and a perfectly crumbling little cookie that my sister loved.  I finished my meal with an excellent espresso-the absolutely perfect finish to a perfect meal.  And quite frankly, although the price of the meal was relatively high, I would have spent twice as much for the food, drink, and experience.  Brava!

XgXeGLT_MXYVt9PoPtxr4g.review_text: I was really excited to try Absinthe despite some of the mediocre reviews it had gotten here (there are always going to be yelp haters), but after experiencing it for myself, I have to agree. It was just okay.  The ambiance was great. Great area, cool bar area, really cozy seating area that was perfect for a date. Aside from not meeting my food expectations, I would give the place 4 stars.  However food really is the important part, and it just wasn't that great. I really wanted it to be great too. We started with the house made hot dog, which really wasn't that great. I could make a sausage sandwich just as good on my own. The homemade sauerkraut was great. We got a good cheese plate as well, but I've had better cheese plates honestly. My boyfriend got the pork shoulder and it was actually pretty stellar, but to his point, that's a pretty hard dish to mess up. I got the pierogies which just weren't that good. The veggies with them were cooked perfectly, though, I will admit.   All in all, just not close to the best food I've had in San Francisco. Also, our waitress was just a total phony. She was all chatty and pretentiously suggesting cheeses and wines in the beginning, and then completely ignored us at the end of the night when we wanted the check. She was too busy speaking french with a table of men who looked like better tippers. Cheesy.

estC5tTFmCr-Yylemlfkrw.review_text: I am only reviewing for the bar as I did not sit down to a full meal. Though I did have the fries which were quite good.  This place has great street presence and that ultimate drew me in. The interior is excellently appointed. The decor, the staff, and the service is just brimming with class and style without an ounce of snootiness or pretentiousness.   The bar is AMAZING. The selection of classic liquors is in all price ranges and taste profiles would keep me coming back on a far too regular basis if I lived nearby. Additionally, their knowledge of classic cocktails and proper preparation of such, dating back to the birth of the industry is refreshing. It creates an atmosphere that can spirit the mind away to passion and emotion of a long lost time.   Not only is the liquor top notch, the execution flawless, but the quality of garnish itself is so impressive as to warrant frequent patronage. Unlike many places, they actually provide a full menu of their alcohol selections. The staff is also well versed and can provide the information necessary to guide you in the direction of a selection that you will be pleased with. The wine menu is extensive as well.  Whether you are looking for a romantic dinner for two, to treat yourself to an upscale lunch, an upscale night out for cocktails and appetizers, or just stopping in for a quality drink after work, this is your place.

qd8qaNXa43kGcHpyHvWIrQ.review_text: Certainly one of the top-tier San Francisco restaurants. A good point of comparison is Zuni Cafe, which is about 5 blocks away. Zuni is a better restaurant, but Absinthe is no slouch. The drinks are better at Absinthe, if you are into the artisan mixed drinks thing.   The food is excellent. Full stop. No qualifiers.   If you eat in the bar area it can be very loud. Also, the faucet in the men's bathroom sink is so close to the edge of the basin as to make it annoying. Those are my only two complaints, if you can even count those as legitimate complaints.   It's not cheap, but it's worth it. It's also not pretentious, which is a relief. Highly recommended.

WH3OVosYE5IZq0zjDsMjzA.review_text: Finally made it here for Sunday brunch with my mom and it was delightful. We had an 11:15 reservation and were seated promptly.   We started with Bellinis and a morning bun. The morning bun had some orange zest in it, which we weren't really feeling, but it was a nice little pastry appetizer. My mom got two eggs with bacon and raved about how the bacon had some kind of delicious maple flavor. I got the Croque Madam and it was sinful. It was basically a ham/bechamel grilled cheese with a fried egg on top with the perfect tangy mixed green salad on the side. It was enormous and I almost finished the whole thing because I just.couldnt.stop.   I probably wont add this to my brunch rotation because it's not in my hood and I think it can be quite busy, but I will definitely add it to my fancy/cute brunch for impressing in town guests list.

8iGlM6TTUeth03PL8gSwVg.review_text: Ok, so there are a ton of reviews on this place.  I think the yelp community got it right... average 4 stars.  ----- The Food ----- The food is very good, but I'm upset that they took off the vegetarian risotto dish.  Beyond that, this place is great.  Asparagus (without the speck) is awesome.  The roasted chickpeas make me wonder why it hasn't replaced popcorn.    ----- The Location ----- Good location near the opera house.  Don't expect to find parking so easily, but it's no worse than any other place in downtown.  I've always found a spot with a little bit of searching.  ----- The Service ----- The service was not really up to snuff.  We had a table full of  vegetarians.  We asked specifically for non-meat recommendations.  We ordered the asparagus, and he brought it out to us... wrapped in bacon.  He said the description included speck, which we now know to mean a type of pork.  I'm not a stickler on this type of stuff, but when a table asks you for vegetarian options and they order a dish with PORK, maaaaybe mention it?  ----- The Booze ----- The sommelier did a great job asking questions and describing wine options.  We first chose a bottle described to be "earthy."  By "we" I mean not me.  I didn't choose it.  By "earthy", I mean literally that it tasted like the earth.  The ground.  Dirt.  Grow-a-plant-in-my-mouth earth.  The second bottle was a denis mortet.  I'm not sure what kind it was, but it was AMAZING.  I felt a separation anxiety come on when I had my last sip.  You'll spend a pretty penny on this wine, but it's well worth it for any special occasion.  (I assume you're coming to Absinthe on some sort of occasion.  If you're not, then you're too wealthy to care about the price -___-).    ----- The ABSINTHE ----- Ok, I didn't have any.  Not because I'm a chicken, but because I don't like the flavor of black licorice.  It was interesting to watch people take down the drink (in forms with water, ice, sugar, and all kinds of weird contraptions on top).  Seriously, it's not because I'm a chicken (chaaachi chaaachi chaaachi).

4rscUhRnHPie0Uv3VEcoOQ.review_text: Ten years and going strong. Still one of the best places to get sloshed and stuffed *real good* in one evening. Oh Absinthe, keep doing what you're doing.

UXbCcmkYGl3DH_Py5UOtbQ.review_text: I'm going to have to revisit Absinthe to write a review worthy of the food.  We met friends for dinner here Thursday night before a performance at the new SFJazz Center, which is right around the corner.  We had 6:30 reservations.  They took BART and arrived on time, even early.  We drove and were caught in indescribably awful traffic.  It took us an hour and a half to drive in from El Cerrito.  We arrive shortly after 7:00.  There are two reasons I am writing this review now.  We pulled up in front of the restaurant and discovered they had valet parking.  Not only that, but they would keep our car until after the concert.  Alan turned the car over to the valet and we joined our friends.  The restaurant has that classic old San Francisco restaurant look w/ dark woods and a sense of history.  The bar area is in front.  We walked through it to the back where our friends were seated and had already ordered.  They reassured us that the waiter was wonderful and he was.  His name was Brennan or Brendan and he had a faint brogue.  He was masterful.  He encouraged us to order from the top of the mesu, the appetizer section, as it would be faster.  Alan asked about the hamburger and was told it would be out in 8 minutes.  We both ordered hamburgers and they were out in less than that.  They came well prepared, w/ thinly sliced red onion, a large piece of lettuce and pickle spears affixed to the top.  There was a pile of crispy fries and some catsup.  The hamburger was good, but I think Absinthe deserves to be lingered at and inhaling a burger and fries doesn't do it justice.  Next time--and there will be a next time-we will arrive earlier to savor the experience.  But for now, we felt wonderfully cared for by Brendan and the valet.  Our car was parked right in front of the restaurant when we returned to pick it up after the concert.

Sk0FrFPoaC3QU5bvBcexGQ.review_text: So so good. The drinks are well made and delicious, had this great pear vodka drink and also the oyster shooters with vodka. It's a french place but I did the burger bc I heard it was CRAZY GOOD. Medium rare and the burger meat was heavenly. Fancy vegetables, bun, and toppings to perfectly compliment this beautifully textured patty. I went for the cheddar and had no regrets. I also enjoyed the French onion soup, great thick texture and very very savory. The beef tartar was amazing, little almost translucent morsels of raw beef each coated in the seasoning and oils as to not clump together when you put it on the crostini. I was full of good food and drink, and the atmosphere made me feel fancy af. Will come again and try some of the more traditional french fare.

Vg95DIeQoYgAQPr1td1Tjg.review_text: Excellent all the way around. To drink, i had the Cliff Diver and a Blood & Sand, both of which were pretty good. For eats, we shared the garlic pretzels with white cheese sauce and fried garbanzo beans--all delicious. The only complaint was my boyfriend's: he said the oysters could have benefited from a greater range of sauces.

fCpniKsfDPBjKagpCGHMZg.review_text: I adore this place. I've been here for brunch and dinner. While I slightly prefer the brunch here more, the dinner menu is also delicious. The Dungeness Crab Omelette is amazing. They don't skimp on the crab and everything is very fresh.   But the one dish that blows my mind here, is the French onion soup. I'm going to be bold and say it's the best French Onion soup I've ever had. The cheese is slightly burnt to perfection, just how French onion soup should be!

xR8PP0Zy3NbvOeL3SV3b6g.review_text: Honestly - just fake french BS pretention. Not raffined at all. (talking about the food) The drink menu is ok. You can do better than this.

uhOmmaB3qFi-QsPfQKg3ww.review_text: Waaaaayyyy overpriced.  And their method of serving absinthe when you are at a table is silly.  If I'm paying $25 for a single glass of absinthe I want a ice water decanter with the spigots that drip slowly:  I don't want to pour it myself.  Apparently, if you sit at the bar you get that, but not at a table? But we pay the same price, right, so how come not the same experience????  That being said, the service was excellent and the eggplant panini was out of this world.

deY8YTZCcbZkSQ8PFdUs-A.review_text: Stopped here for an early dinner to avoid trying to get out of the city at traffic time.  Really liked the vibe of the restaurant, feels like a throwback time.  I also thought the area that it is in is rather cool.  I ordered the fried chickpeas, and while I enjoyed them, my table mates were underwhelmed by the flavor (which is very mild).  They all ordered the hamburger with an egg on it and I had the beet salad and the steak tartare.  They all really enjoyed the burgers (although they were very messy) and I thought the tartare was perfect.  The service was good and all in all it was an enjoyable experience.

SteFlMAxi2uhN38oW_V_sw.review_text: We were married last year at City Hall and then held a small, elegant reception in the private dining area at Absinthe.    Our contact, Vanessa, was very helpful and she made the process painless.  They were very flexible and allowed us to create the event that we wanted. We brought in a cake from a neighborhood cake maker and our guests were served hors d'oeuvres and champagne.    The space was perfect for us- initimate and classic.  Our guests were comfortable mingling at tablets and sitting on the settees.    It goes without saying that the food was wonderful.  We had food that ranged from seafood trays, to sliders, to chick peas. I think our sliders were a little undercooked but when we complained they were immediately replaced with fresh, adequately cooked sliders.   I will keep Absinthe private dining in mind for future events as our experience was a positive one.

Taeo8Wk79_diXR3jlH17tA.review_text: Came here for dinner before a night drinking to celebrate my friends 21st birthday. Depsite how attractive everything on the menu was, i decided to order the burger...actually, everyone at our table decided to order the burger.  The drinks are pricey, but they do their job...so, less is more in this case (and that's the last time you'll hear me say that in reference to drinks)  I ordered my ($15) burger medium rare with gruyere and spicy caramelized onions (for $1.50 each) and we shared an order of fries.  The burger was delicious. So, so juicy. The meat was incredible and literally (well, not literally) melted in your mouth.  The meat was served on fresh baked brioche, a perfect choice given how juicy the burger was and how well brioche stands up to a little liquid. The killer here was the side of house made pickles. As i've mentioned in other reviews, I love vinegar and anything that is submerged in it for some period of time.  These pickles were amazing. So crispy, so vinegar-y, so full of flavor and and spice. A perfect way to cut through the richness of the burger.  The fries were pretty good, especially when dipped in the smokey tomato ketchup.  The entire menu is impressive, and i'd love to give this place another whirl when i'm in the city. The food is expensive, and i've had equally delicious burgers for less...however, this one is worth a try at least once.

-ulvjJmtH7qHV3IBBkExLg.review_text: My wife and I arranged to have someone watch our kids on a recent holiday weekday night. During this particular week in December, "Colors of Christmas" is being performed at the Davies Symphony Hall, and "The Nutcracker" is at the War Memorial Opera House. With these shows within an hour of each other, many ticket holders make an evening of it with dinner before their scheduled performances. Needless to say, many of the nearby restaurants are pretty full. My wife and I also decided to make it an evening of it, so I planned ahead and made reservations before "Colors of Christmas" started. Not sure I have much more to add from the other 1200 Yelp reviews, but I will say I'm glad I made reservations as the bar and restaurant was full, and walk-ins were being turned away. Our Order (sorry for the poor quality of the photos, low light limitations of the iPhone camera): -Hamachi Crudo (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…): slices of buttery hamachi was topped with thin slices of peppers, drizzled with a citrus oil, then sprinkled with sea salt. Peppers added a very subtle kick, added with the tartness of the citrus. -Pan-Seared Scallops (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…): prepared with bacon, wild mushrooms, greens, black-truffle butter, on top of a caramelized-onion purée. Nicely-sized scallops, tender and soft. My wife thoroughly enjoyed this dish. -Braised Beef Cheeks(yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…): This was served with maple-syrup-glazed smoked yams, sautéed kale, and horseradish crème fraiche. Although a steak knife was placed on the table for this dish, it really wasn't needed because the beef was fork-tender. The smokiness of the yams mixed well with the glaze of the beef cheeks. I really liked this dish! Dessert? Of course! -TCHO Chocolate Pot de Creme (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…): Topped with a Crème chantilly. Firm, but smooth and rich without being too overly sweet. Chocolate taste comes through very well in this dessert. You'd want to roll each spoonful between your tongue and the roof of your mouth. Kabosu Lime Mousse (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…): The mousse was in the shape of a fat tube, on top of a green tea biscuit, surrounded by little meringue balls (4 inches long, 2 inch diameter, thanks Mona C.!).  The mousse was dense, but refreshing after the beef cheeks. Our server was very friendly and attentive, always cheerful without being over the top.  Very attentive bus staff as well, clearing the empty plates in a timely manner. My wife is a big fan of Top Chef, and she asked our server if Chef Jamie Lauren would be available to drop by our table.  Being a very busy night, with a large party in the back, we didn't expect her to come out.  But to our surprise, she came out and stopped by our table.(static3.px.yelp.com/phot…).  Very friendly, very personable.  My wife was thrilled to have her drop by and had a nice chat with her. Very pleased with the start of our evening here in Absinthe, and set a nice tone for our evening at the Davies Symphony Hall.

zIeWHm_nGnomfNm_-Ta1Uw.review_text: Overall, a great dining experience but with a couple of missteps that prevent me from giving Absinthe the full 5 stars:  (1) Ribeye steak was cooked to a true medium rare as ordered but came out lukewarm, which was unfortunate. Otherwise, it would've been close to perfection. The vegetables on the side added nothing to the plate but the fries (we substituted fries instead of the fingerling potatoes) were kick-ass.  (2) Service was inconsistent, alternating between attentive (at one point, we had 2 servers) and invisible (there was a long stretch between courses when we were ready for more cocktails but ended up having to put the order in with a busgirl).  (3) We had brought a nice bottle of Cakebread cab and when the bill came, I asked my husband how much was charged for corkage. He skimmed the bill and didn't see it on there, and we thought, "Wow, what a nice gesture!" We figured that since our table of 4 had each ordered a pre-dinner cocktail and an after-dinner drink (at least $80 worth), they had extended us courtesy corkage. But alas, the server apparently overheard our chatter and informed us, "Oh, I forgot to add the corkage, I need to make sure to add it in, because the sommelier audits us all the time, and I would get in trouble."   Ummmm, okay. Can you say "awkward"? I understood where he was coming from but it should have been handled a little more gracefully for a restaurant of Absinthe's caliber (and prices).  Now for the good (and hence the 4 stars): As eveyone has stated, French onion soup was amazing, as was the scallop and clam chowder with bacon (although the bacon flavor was almost overpowering). Kampachi (yellowtail) crudo was extremely fresh and tender. Duck confit was above average, but I've had better (at Fringale). Pork confit was good, mushroom risotto was delicious but very umami so stay away if you can't handle too much savory.   Loved the brasserie atmosphere and the cocktails (complex but subtle flavors, in particular the infamous Galapagos), although I've heard the main dining room near the bar can get crowded. We were fortunate to get a table in the quieter, side dining room, which I will request on future visits (yes, I do plan to go back!).  And like everyone else, what drew me here in the first place was seeing Jamie on Top Chef. Loved her personality and cooking on the show -- down-to-earth and elegant, respectively, and it was reflected at the restaurant.

jrYscIy7U89UAUGFM87MTg.review_text: How else do you start a review on a place like this but ESCARGOT! everything POSH and formal can happen here. it can be just a cute dinner for two or a birthday with friends. with a full bar complete with PUB menu, and a fine dining room complete with white linen and Sommelier. My suggestion is to take friends that can appreciate fine dining. If your saddled with someone that can't don't worry, they have a basic burger and fries just for them! Treat yourself, treat someone you love, find any excuse you can, just go here. It's one of my favorite dining experiences in the city and im certain it will be one of yours as well!

h_ewbDmZ3M3Z2QfyAqm24w.review_text: DO TAKE IN THE:   -- Vibrant and bustling (at times quite loud) atmosphere, dimly lit w/sultry yet low-key elegance that takes you back to 1920's Paris   DO MUNCH ON:  -- French Onion Soup: not the absolute best I've ever had, but certainly deletable w/a rich complex broth luxuriantly topped w/Gruyere cheese  -- Soft Garlic Pretzels: garlicky goodness served w/creamy Vermont Mornay cheddar cheese  -- Oysters: clearly fresh w/great options  -- Absinthe Hamburger: brioche bun and grass-fed beef w/the option to add gruyere cheese yum  DO SIP ON:   -- Galápagos Cocktail: balanced blend of pisco, kaffir lime, pepper, lemon-lime, grapefruit, brandied cherries  -- Sazerac:  rye whiskey, absinthe, bitters, and sugar   -- French '75- gin, lemon juice, and syrup on the rocks with a touch of champagne, brandied cherries, and lemon  GUILTY PLEASURE  -- Chocolate Pot de Creme: dark and seductive like Absinthe's decor, mmm

mWovMFEZgWE40UVchWHlWA.review_text: Beautiful beet salad w a quixotic sauce of some kind. The Coq au vin reduction sauce was of another realm ! Parking worked out right on Gough and arrived at SF Symphony spot-on time w the wait-staff's help. Not too many awesome options for the vegetarian, though ....

YCz8cwM8TFQ3Qq6hW6Tghg.review_text: I never write reviews maybe because I never go to restaurants alone. Here I am in SF on the way to the Civic Center BART station to go to SFO. This place is worth going a few blocks and bucks out of your way. Great food, great service, good bar but a bit pricey.

9psTN1k5dUuV6B97pxjpRQ.review_text: Great food. As you enter this establisment you are greeted with the beautiful atmosphere. The croque monseur and the hamburger are both delightful. Fresh food at the highest standard. Well worth return visits.

37HswRimgBEf7_US-c3CDA.review_text: Came here before XANADU & were completely impressed!  Drinkys included the Fame for me - anything w/ Elderflower & I'm automatically a fan & this was no exception!  Incredibly delish!  Buddy got something like a Mood Adjuster - it was w/ Rye & she said it was too strong for her....but hello - you just ordered Rye!  There was another Pisco drinky I wanted to try but they forgot to bring it out - but it also wasn't on the tab so no harm, no foul, I guess  Starters included French Onion Soup for Sis & buddy - they loved the stringy cheese & intense onion flavor  I had the Butternut Squash Soup - it had pumpkin seeds & mint oil & at first I was kicking myself for not asking they hold the mint oil but it actually added quite a nice contrast & I didn't taste any mint at all - big score!  It was creamy, dreamy & pumpkinny!  Entrees included Cog Au Vin for buddy - she said it was among the best she's tasted & she even took her leftovers ( which she never does ) so BIG props on this dish  Sis & I shared the Baby Beets w/ Stilton - could have used a bit more cheese but the beets were tender & there was a good variety of colors  We also shared the Market Veggie Platter which had the most scrumptious egg roll thingy.....it was a crispy potato crust surrounding a tender, creamy, parsnip interior - like a a huge twice-baked potato & it was so delish!  There were also some wilty greens (which was all Sis as they make me gag but she totally dug them)  Came with Brussels Sprouts, little dollops of Butternut Squash puree ( more dollops needed here! ) & some frisee  Arrived there too late for dessert but given we can't wait to come back, I have a feeling this error will be soon rectified!  Kuri Squash Cake.....you are MINE!

EJPBXvEdaodsPQuYBT6low.review_text: Does anything in San Fran suck? Cause I haven't found it...  This place was nothing short of amazing. I came here to meet some friends who were having a later dinner and ended up having a 4th dinner of my own.  First of all it's a absinthe lounge -- and within minutes I had original old school Van Gogh juice in front of me, with a sugar cube over a metal frame to dissolve to taste. It was good. Tasted like black liquorice but got me in that absinthe mood. I like mine with a lot of water-- like some people drink scotch.  Someone at the table was getting fresh oysters so I felt inclined as well. 3 Marin Miyagi's at 3.25 tasted divine.   I then proceeded to get a single cheese order of the Bayley Hazen Bleu. Served with some sort of fresh honey or sweet spread with gourmet multi grain bread-- it too was to die for. A real upscale bleu.  I had to get an encore round of oysters, and tried the Kumamoto which are a smaller but sweeter sea creature. Also great but I like the Marin Myagi's because they are saltier... An oyster should taste like the sea right?  A little pricey at $40 for just a cocktease of their menu but well worth it! Loving this place.  Tried someone's risotto -- pretty god. But there chicken pasta dumpling dish may have been the best thing that entered my mouth...wow.

UgNhsXHrqUbYhHJOq_O9sA.review_text: Its worth making a visit here, the drinks are good, the steaks are always cooked perfectly. Its got great ambiance. I've had dinner here 3x and I'm never disappointed with the consistency.

NP-675YVy9URhNmdQdnWsQ.review_text: Easily and solidly "good but not great." Somehow I thought it would be a bit nicer inside, and the service was also a bit lacking (we were brought another table's food and the waiter was a bit curt). Also... I don't really get the big deal about the french onion soup or the fries (both of which I'll still file under the "GBNG" above). So, clearly, either my expectations were too high or I wasn't hungry enough. But the brunch menu was nicely diverse in terms of price and sweet/savory, which I really appreciate. My French '75 was really nice; I'd probably mostly come back to explore the cocktails.

0IYQrdPM9NPJsRThHfpdEQ.review_text: Came here as my first stop for "Dine About Town".  I went to high school down the street and actually came here once with a friend few years ago to meet with his editor (my friend wrote a memoir of his experiences as a child growing up with ADHD)-- can't really remember how the restaurant was back then. Anyway, today was great!  Service was fabulous and food was delicious. I had the Croque Monsieur and Roasted White Chocolate Panna Cotta. Both dishes were out of this world delicious!   I was also pleased that the waiter was honest about portions and discouraged me to get a "Snack" on the side as the main course was expected to be very filling. He was right: I had to hold off in order to even fit dessert.   Thank you Absinthe for the lovely lunch-- I will be back!

UC9i2YIaD9qwVXJ1obAmZw.review_text: I really liked this place. They have a great collection of cocktails and wine to go with an equally great choice for dinner. Went there with friends, were seated at a really nice window table a little before the reservation, and before we were all there. It was moderately crowded in the bar area and had a nice vibe.  Food and dessert were delish, and drinks were great. Our service was really good. Definitely recommend.

wwh1D-yDvJDrcdM_9-FhYg.review_text: I have eaten here twice. Once for dinner. Once from brunch. Learn from me.  1 = Dinner:  * I dressed very nicely as it was dinner in a French style spot.  *  I had the coq au vin. Exquisite.  * I had an Absinthe Sazerac cocktail. I was the waking dead the next day, of course the half bottle of red wine with the meal had nothing to do with it. Of course.  * I had an obnoxious self important waiter. He irked me so much with his hoity toity carry on, who's the guest chump? He deserved a kick up the arse with my nice shoes, but I was too scared I might damage his head.  2 = Brunch:  * I dressed in my sweats because I had a long haul flight straight after and I believe in dressing like an incognito bloated Hollywood star that is falling from grace.  * Upon entrance the Maître d greeted EVERYONE except me. He simply looked me up and down and rolled his eyes. Feck off. Seriously feck off. It's feckin 10am. Also you have UGLY SHOES, but did you see me roll my eyes?  * The waitress and the hostess were so sweet, so attentive and did not baulk at me.  * I had the crab omelet and she had the granola I think. Mine was delicious. You simply cannot fault the food in this place.  4 stars overall as the self important idiots get balanced nicely against the very good natured waitress and hostess, and of course the food.  I dare you to dress in a shell suit with slippers on your feet.

bJ6aZno8R6AtxnfhOumMrA.review_text: Went with my girlfriend for our anniversary. We had the duck confit and the swordfish, which were both good. However, the service there was average at best. Food took 40+ minutes with no explanation. Only saw our waiter three times over the course of the entire meal. The busboy checked on us more than the waiter did! Would have been 4 stars if the service matched the food.

3jitIdvMADOpNPVRTcsyqA.review_text: Great for post-civic center events (i.e., opera, symphony) because the kitchen is open late as opposed to many other restaurants in the area which tend to stop serving food by 10pm.   Been here twice post-opera in the past month. Bar area both times was absolutely cramped on a Fri and Sat night so if you were willing to buy an entree you could be seated at a dinner table... Some are in the periphery of the bar room which is lively and noisy but the main dining room next door is much more dark and mellow, prolly good for dates.   Wine list is ample. Single malt whiskey list is great. Try the Lagavulin Distiller's edition before it's sold out.  Food... french fries and aoli are a must. Skinny goodness. Had the burger the first time. Requested medium. Was cooked right, but it had an overly raw meat smell to it which was off-putting. Also, it wasn't all that flavorful (2.0 stars). Second time had the hanger steak which was good, but not fantastic (3 stars) and sent to me med rare rather than med.   Bottom line... pretty happnin place... great for drinks and atmosphere... okay for food... would come again, but probably not primarily for entrees.

ehdrFZwh1XRxzqR-6Kbg9A.review_text: I went here recently with a friend, who had been before and told me that the scallop appetizer was phenomenal, and sort of "craved" it- so we went, and it was good- I have always hated scallops since I was a kid and was forced to eat the fishy white pieces..This scallop appetizer was raw scallops, a pea puree that it sat on, lemon rind, caviar,and some sea salt..mmmm- it was so good, and not fishy at all!  It changed my mind about scallops completely.  I had the ribeye steak, and my friend had the pork confit- Mine was great, but his was even greater- melty in your mouth falling apart tender pork...  This place can be a dressy-ish sort of place, but I was in jeans and flip flops, and it was fine.  People were actually eating outside and had their dogs with them..if I would have known I would have brought mine- they are always up for a good piece of meat.  my dogs are sort of spoiled.  The service was great, and the place was nice- food was good and worth every penny.  I will definitely go back here for sure!

9QITXadhXwFd08ZO1sNnJg.review_text: We stopped here for lunch after a visit to the Asian Art Museum, which is about 4 blocks away. The pasta dish was awesome.  Also, the apple pie panna cotta!  I was a bit surprised that the menu was so small, but everything my friend and I ordered was cooked to perfection.

GHZdMggvuYk1fsVWcyy0JQ.review_text: I love the food here. It is really, really good. The drinks are also really good. Unfortunately the entire staff needs a refresher course on customer service.   The first time I ate brunch here was probably about a year ago. Dishes were slow to come out of the kitchen but service was friendly and efficient. I went here again last Sunday for brunch. I stood at the host/hostess stand for 10 minutes behind a couple waiting for the host to return to seat us. When he finally came back, he casually walked chatting with a waitress, paused at the bar to continue his random chit chat (the conversation they were having was in no way work related and I suspect was some story about a recent night on the town) slowly walked over to his stand and finally decided to do his job. When I was finally seated, it took forever for a waiter to come over to take my drink order (the person I was meeting there was already seated) then it took forever for the drink to come or for him to take our food orders. My drink finally arrived just before our entrees. After the food arrived the server was attentive but by that point I was a little irked. In his defense, I do think he was covering a disproportionate number of tables. I will forgive a lot of great food but this was just ridiculous. I've also eaten at the Boxing Room and Comstock Saloon recently and Absinthe definitely has the worst service in the restaurant group.   Can you start serving the duck confit, the stuff my brunch dreams are made of, at one of your other restaurants... please?

cvsTVPriw7uXMNRgOQo3Sg.review_text: Surprise!  After I posted, we were contacted immediately and sent compensation for my jacket.  I just wish it didn't take this post and almost a year to reconcile a promise.

kKGilrqyIylpMsRLs-l86Q.review_text: The brunch was ok, nothing too spectacular. We had French Onion Soup (which is really amazing though), Croque Mousieur and the Eggplant Sandwich. The sandwich is a bit over grilled and overall the meal was on the saltier side for French food you would normally expect. Service really good though, but for the price, I would suggest you go to Stelline just opposite the street.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: Since I was on lunch, The Wonderlust and Sacred Heart and the effects of the "green fairy" will have to wait another time...*SIGH*  My friend and I came to Absinthe for an early lunch last Friday, 5.28 at 11:30 AM. We had reservations and were promptly seated.  FOOD: We each got the French Onion Soup and shared the other items:  *French Onion Soup Gratinee ($4.50/cup): YUMMY! The beef broth was rich, savory, and very comforting. The onions were perfectly caramelized to bring out the natural sweetness of them. It was topped w/ a cube of toasted bread and gruyere cheese which remained crispy in the broth and gave it a good texture contrast. The melted gruyere had a distinctive savory taste w/o overpowering the broth and the sweet onions. Overall, a perfect start to a meal.   *Frites ($6): It was only good for the first 5 minutes when it was still warm and crispy. B/c it was packed into a paper cone in a metal cup, all the pent up heat caused the fries to become very soggy and mushy. My friend and I weren't very fond of the three sauces provided. The Dijon mustard was more like Chinese spicy mustard and was too overpowering for the skinny fries. Same goes for the malt vinegar which only seems to work better with steak cut fries or a cut that has more substance to it. The rouille was more like red pepper aioli; it was too heavy b/c there was no citrus to balance the richness.   *Croque Monsieur ($11.50): YUMMY--Buttery, Crispy, Salty and Savory! The bread was perfectly grilled; buttery and crispy on the outside. The ham was salty but balanced out with the savory and creamy melted gruyere.     *Absinthe Burger ($12.50 +$1.50 each for gouda, caramelized onions, and fried egg): OMFG--I think it quite possibly one of the BEST burgers I've ever eaten! The thick patty was perfectly grilled to a medium and was AMAZINGLY juicy, moist, and melted in my mouth. The gouda added just the right amount of bitterness to offset the richness of the beef. The egg didn't do much since the yolk was thoroughly cooked and the onions were too vinegary as opposed to being sweet. The bun was toasted on both sides which allowed it to stay crisp. If you are burger connoisseur OR a carnivore, Absinthe's burger is A MUST TRY!  SERVICE: It was ok. Our server was very robotic in nature and once noon hit, he became very S-L-O-W. He would come to "look" at our table to see how we were doing as opposed to just asking. When it came time to pay the bill, it took nearly 15 minutes to do so. This is not a place to have a one-hour lunch at, so plan accordingly and expect to spend about 1.5-2 hours here.   AMBIANCE/DÉCOR: Reminiscent of the rolling 1940s; classically retro. There's 2 dining areas. The dining area near the bar is more casual and more suited for brunch/lunch. The dining area in the back is more sophisticated and gloomy w/ dark burgundy drapes at the window, dark tan carpets, white linen tables, and red velvet-like chairs.   CROWD:  Stuffy, much older crowd.   PARKING: Street parking.  Can't wait to come back here for dinner, so I can get my "green fairy" fix!

TBrakUJb0hMyp242KiD41g.review_text: Delicious foods, long list of specialty cocktails, and serious attention given to aesthetics and the overall experience.  ...All for hefty prices.  The first (and, likely, last) time in my life that I spent $50 on breakfast.  Go here to impress out-of-town relatives, or to celebrate special dates, but otherwise it's just a comically bad deal.  They replace traditional, cheap ingredients (like chicken eggs) with atypical, more expensive ingredients (like duck eggs) and then charge accordingly... plus some.  Is the food really that much better?  Or are we just buying into the idea that expensive things are automatically preferable?  ...People have different feelings on those issues.  But me -- I guess I learned that standard chicken eggs are already really good.  Aside from my pricing rant, I'll also offer this:  We didn't have to wait at all for our reserved table (as others have, apparently.)  But after we were seated, service was slow throughout the meal and a few orders were delayed or forgotten.

lNJEs5XjjD7iFDneFUfPUw.review_text: This place is fantastic atmosphere-wise but I didn't care for the limited food menu. I really wanted more to choose from, and some lighter options would have been nice.   The variety of cocktails, on the other hand, was stupendous. And I liked how late this place was open--it's a great place to dine after taking in a ballet (walking distance to the SF Opera House). But make a reservation and expect it to be pretty busy and noisy, too!

Q8TGsARjdIfWsnXqgQYHhw.review_text: Came here for some late night eats with a group of friends.  The service was pretty on point even with it being later in the evening!  I do have to say though....their burger is absolutely fantastic.  It definitely ranks pretty decently on any burger list.  Their pretzel appetizer is also delicious.  Space is a tad on the smallish side but really where isn't in the City?  Bar selection (I mean Whiskey selection) also looked pretty good from what I saw  as well.  All in all I thoroughly enjoyed Absinthe and I really hope I come back to try their steak frites with that bone marrow butter.  Oh yeah and oysters.

3eTizQ3IU-PihPGJpx6BuA.review_text: They gave us a great table. and I enjoyed the ambiance but this place is good but waaaay over price. This is why I gave it 3 vs 4 stars. I wanted to try this place because my friend raved about the french onion soup. It was good but I prefer the cheese melted across the top of the bowl. (I prefer Butler & the Chef on South Park shhhhh~).  We had oysters, beet salad, seafood stew, pot pie, and the skirt steak, and 1 more item.. I can't remember what it was. but everything was all pretty good. I came here with a few girls and they all ordered a cocktail. The bill came to $280! For 2 entrees, 1 soup, 18 oysters and a couple of appetizers and 4 cocktails/beers. I don't mind paying paying good money for good food but this was ridiculous. I tried the soup that my friend was raving about and I think that's all I wanted to do... so I prob won't be coming back. I don't want to pay 3.50 per oyster with mignonette sauce again, hahaha.

tlTHlEOTOUNRjFuAdBwtsA.review_text: It is France in San Francisco! Divine! Recommend to choose the outside tables or table close to the window... If not, too crowded.  Food: delicious... If you go for appetizer, pretzels is the way to go!

uIDJBzBhnF5r5rxN8VXwWA.review_text: Food was by-the-book.  Not worth the price asked, but I'm generally willing to pay a bit for atmosphere & service, even if the meal is decidedly unenthusiastic..
