Atmosphere and Service:   This is the root of my dissatisfaction with Absinthe.    My wife and I spent our anniversary dinner staring at the armpit hair of the man at the next table.   He rolled in wearing a *sleeveless* plaid shirt and a baseball cap.  (In his defense,  he did remove his cap after the second cocktail).   Naturally,  the sort of fellow who wears a sleeveless shirt to a grown-up restaurant is also the fellow who makes bold arm gestures while amusing his date with tales of derring-do.  I'm a fool. I showered, shaved, and dug a jacket and tie out of my closet,  when clearly sandals and a  paint-spattered, sweaty t-shirt would have been fine.     Make a note everyone - You needn't hose the barnyard muck off your wellies before heading down to Absinthe..    Hell,  they'll probably even valet park your urine-soaked shopping cart if you tip them a nickel or two.  Atmosphere:  Fail.  Service:  Fail,  but much more subtly..    It's cold and foggy, and I'm headed to a fancy dinner,  so I'm wearing my expensive overcoat.   No coat check, no surprise.    I'll  just fold it up and put it  on the bench next to me, and hope Thumbs the Busser doesn't spill anything on it.   Oh,  I see there are coat hooks here?  Why didn't you say so?   No,  that's okay,  miss server lady,  you just stand there like a stunned deer while I get up and push past you to hang up our coats.   Do you get a basket of bread with the table?  I don't know.  We never got any,  while other tables did.    Our first server seemed a bit unclear on the composition of a menu cocktail..     and then was even more confused when my wife had a question about "the chicken" entree..   LOOONG pause..  "Oh, you mean the Coq Au Vin ?"     Yes,  sweetheart,  coq au vin is made with chicken. and wine.  Coq. Au. Vin.   It's the only one.  Took the orders,  and then she disappeared.     The next guy came over to let us know he was taking over,   and then similarly disappeared.  Our entrees hit the table alongside empty cocktail glasses.   I had to flag the chap down to order wine.    Poor form,  particularly if all you care about is inflating the final bill.  Alcohol sales are your best margin, you dolts..  Clearly,  Absinthe is just not trying anymore.   I can only recommend them if you are in a similar state of mind.    Naturally, shirtsleeves are entirely optional.

BiRLsPNxF7Do5H6j9NYPdg.review_text: Went back here after a couple of years. Dined in the bar area on a table. Atmosphere was loud, but not so that you had to shout at your date. The loudness comes from the other dinners and their big mouths. The music playing in the BG was actually stylish electro, which is what I'd rather hear than obnoxious diners with money to burn and boring stories to tell. Our waiter was so-so, kinda left us hanging for a while and not very knowledgeable about the menu.  Prices still high, but food still great. Tip: buy a bottle from Arlequin and get a smaller corkage - makes the experience more affordable. Will come again.

vcOtDqQ2Cc731kFjklFeBg.review_text: Absinthe may just be my new favorite restaurant. My loverman took me here for our 6 month anniversary after not being able to get reservations in time for Gary Danko. All I've heard were good things about their food but it was mostly for their brunch menu so I wasn't sure how good the food would be. I always judge a restaurant by their dessert menu and I was not feeling theirs at all.  We had reservations at 7:30 and we arrived a bit early. My loverman gave the hostess his number so they could call him while we took a walk outside. Less than 2 minutes later, they called us. We ordered two appetizers, two entrees, three glasses of Prosecco, and Absinthe.   Escargots In Shell: I never knew what the big deal with Escargots were about since I ate it all the time as a child at home. My loverman never had it before though so we ordered a dish. It came with all these fancy utensils (much different from the fingers+toothpick method I used at home). I had a blast watching him trying to eat them. While they were good, he also remarked that they didn't taste like anything special.   Porcini & Potato Flatbread: AMAZING. I wasn't expecting much and I hate potato but this was probably my favorite dish out of the whole night. I could barely tell there was any potatoes because they were thinly sliced and blended in with the cheese. It was kind of oily if you care about that sort of thing.  Wild Mushroom Farro "Risotto": I love that they used Farro to make this dish since I hate rice. It seems like the only options I ever have at restaurants are fish or risotto. I usually always order fish so I thought I'd try something new. I could barely finish my plate and I got the rest packed up to go but they left it on a counter for me to pick up after I was ready to leave and I forgot it!    My loverman ordered some steak type dish that he loved. He tried to get me to try a sliver of it but that was not about to go down. I did try a fried green tomato off his plate since I've never had one. He thought they were deep fried pickles at first. Haha.   We didn't even end up ordering dessert since we were bursting at the seams. It ended up being the longest dinner we've ever had, 3 hours! Our waitress Kimberly was super knowledgeable and I felt like we were in a culinary class when she was speaking. Haha. If you're on a date, request a booth seat. I wish we had gotten one but then again, I hate sitting next to people while eating. Haha.   Warning: Apparently if your bill comes out to be over $100, they charge you like 15% extra on your credit card just to make sure you have enough funds to cover the bill.

oeSP4tyY8VKMW-ndSMVv1g.review_text: My boyfriend and I came here for dinner right before he left for home in New York for Christmas.  I've been meaning to come here for a while since I'm a huge top chef fan and know Jamie works at this Absinthe (although I'm not sure if she works here anymore).  Being a previous vegetarian for 6 years, I recently moved back to eating meat for health reasons, but still being environmentally-conscious of what I'm eating (yes yes, I know such a San Francisco thing to do as Anthony Bordain would say)  I appreciated that Absinthe is very specific of where their meat comes from and fully discloses on the menu, which made it easier because I will only eat meat that is locally sourced.  My boyfriend said they were known for the cocktails.  Although almost all the cocktails are made with gin.  I HATE GIN.  I got the one cocktail that looked like it didn't have a trace of gin.  Citron Lemonade which was made with Hanger One Buddha's hand vodka which was really good.  We started off with some Point Reyes oysters, which I had to admit, at $3 a pop, weren't that great.  Maybe I was eating them wrong, but I hate getting shell in my mouth when I eat raw oysters.  We then got the rabbit meatballs which were great.  They weren't too "game-y" and they came in a great marinara sauce.  I ordered the coffee crusted Liberty duck which was AWESOME.  It was cooked medium rare which looked almost like beef.  The taste was ORGASMIC, at least in my opinion.  Very juicy and delectable, the coffee crust gave the duck a very nice bold flavor.  My boyfriend had the chicken which was also really good.  We finished off with a Quince Tart with olive oil ice cream. I was actually really looking forward to tasting olive oil ice cream.  The taste was more like a light vanilla flavor which was very refreshing.  The tart was also good but the crust was a little too hard.  I'm definitely a fan.  Absinthe met my expectations as they were high for someone who was on top chef.  As a previous vegetarian, I noticed there was a very SMALL amount of vegetarian options.  I don't recommend if you don't eat meat.  The place is pretty popular, I also recommend making reservations.

W3fjr4Y_Etqt03ebhLy5Ig.review_text: We were treated to lunch here by our best man and maid of honor after being married at city hall on Wednesday, 9/11/13. A great walk from city hall and we were not disappointed in any way. Our waitress was genuine happy for us and made sure everything was to our satisfaction. All the dishes that were  ordered were fantastic but what I remember most was the coconut-corn soup - a delight to the palate. Trevor, the manager was so kind to help with the delivery of our small wedding cake from a nearby bakery - he called them, then went over to get the cake himself! What great service from not only him but the entire staff.   We sat at a table near the windows - the lighting was great and everything about the place oozed French with sophistication without being uptight. We could not have picked a better place to celebrate!

POYuBOxR_SQd1WVd-_RoiA.review_text: We had brunch here on Sunday with a friend of ours.  The waitress was pretty good, so detailed in describing the menu items, you could almost taste them.   I had the burger, after much hype by the waitress as the "best burger in the city"  I added a fried egg to the burger. It was an above average burger, but would not say "best in the city"  The food that Lana and our friend had were better. Lana had this meal with fried eggs over black beans, pork confit and tortilla. It was spectacular from what I could taste with my one bite.   Our friend had eggs benedict over duck confit and THAT WAS GOOD.   So I gave them 4 stars only because the waitress hyped the burger too much. Otherwise, great place to eat.

k_mBMxzXm8F6VeeJoTBYnA.review_text: The great folks at the Boxing Room (see that review to verify that indeed I can gush about good food and service) described this restaurant as their "upscale sister restaurant," in the same Hayes Valley neighborhood and ostenisbly run by the same restaurateurs. Because of this and good reviews on Yelp, we were excited to make this meal the 'special' final meal in San Francisco and our splurge for the trip.  Maybe if we hadn't set the bar so high in advance we wouldn't have been as disappointed. I contend we would have been soundly disappointed nonetheless.  The highlight of the meal was the cheese plate we ordered to start the evening off-- the place was dark and hip and everyone in the place was 'beautiful,' as my (equally beautiful) companion remarked. The cheeses were great and the portions were very generous. Best of all, they were each paired some sort of sweet condiment to compliment the cheese-- the accacia honey and quince paste were especially delightful.  The cocktails were also good and their presentations and whimsical names and descriptions (think the Peterman Catalog) added to the fun.  Our entrees ranged from bad to only above average. We ordered halibut which came with a sweet-but-spicy corn-and-chili sauce, and the fish was cooked well- moist but flaky with some sexy brown searing. It was tasty and prepared competently, but if it seems like I am damning it with faint praise, perhaps that tells you something. We also ordered a risotto featuring macadamia nuts and fresh vegetables, ingredients that the chef should have trusted more to carry the dish. Instead, butter and salt overwhelmed the dish and made it a chore to finish despite a healthy appetite.  The wine recommended to us was good. The pana cotta was smooth buy watery, and overwhelmed by sickly-sweet strawberry syrup-- we couldn't finish it between the two of us. pana cotta should be creamy and firm and subtle. This was only creamy.  The absinthe, enjoyed as an aperitif, was fun. The accouterments and the fanfare made it memorable. I discovered that I enjoy a visit from the green fairy, and my dining companion discovered that she did not.  A note about service: I cannot fault the service in the least-- we felt attended to without feeling overwhelmed and we got good advice on wine and expert tutelage on how to consume absinthe. If the Chef and the Dessert Chef were on a summer vacation together or it was an off day, that would account for the ambivalent experience we had, but I would sooner explore other fine restaurants in San Francisco before going back to Absinthe.

TFyYs0F17UXQr_x2V8ZvcA.review_text: This jaunt was a great late night stop off after the local indy-theatre.  Late meaning access to a full menu was not there but the options you had are great.  Had the burger and a salad.  Yummm.  Bar concoctions are awesome.  Soda not so for the other half but it's a damn soda!  Definitely a keeper:)

R5i-8R4vBov0wfNBGg2MwA.review_text: We went to the bar area for a quick meal before the opera.  It was packed, but luckily my sis and brother-in-law came early and were able to get us a table.    We started off with the fried chickpeas and the french fries...both were really good, I definitely want to try to make that chickpea dish someday.  My brother-in-law got the half-crab...I'm not much of a crab person but I'll take his word for it that it's good.  My hubby also enjoyed their caesar salad...the portion was a bit small, but it was good.  We also shared their hamburger, with gruyere and sauteed mushrooms...it was definitely good, though I wouldn't say it blew me away.  Since we were craving some cheese, we got their 5-cheese selection.  The Robiola was probably my favorite, I've seen it at Whole Foods lots of times but I could never buy it 'cause they only sell it by the wheel.  The Clisson and Ossau Iraty were good as well.  While their foreign cheeses were excellent, I was a bit underwhelmed by the domestic selection. We  skipped the Beecher's and Humboldt Fog since we wanted to try something new.  The Hudson Valley camembert was just ok...it was a little bit bland, especially next to the Robiola.  I do like all the condiments that came with the cheeses and the walnut bread.  We ordered wines by the glass, so I got to try quite a few of them.  My favorite one was the syrah, but the temperanillo and the zin were pretty good as well.  I wasn't expecting much service since we were in the bar area, but the service was surprisingly good.  They were very timely with the dishes and the pacing was good, we had plenty of time to make it to the opera but we never felt hurried.  Highly recommended to all opera-goers for both its proximity and excellent food and drinks.

doPKEIuKDBz1n4idofWECA.review_text: Absolutely happy with our dinner!  We got:  french onion soup - it lives up to all the hype you read in the reviews so just go get it coq au vin- hubby ordered this and couldn't stop saying wow.  He said he didn't remember my coq au vin tasting like this haha.   yam and goat cheese ravioli - delicious, light but filling at the same time milk chocolate napoleon - a deconstructed napoleon which was ok, nothing great  Hubby got wine and I got their spring cocktail with kumquats on it and it was just the perfect combination of fruity, tartness and alcohol.  Service was great and definitely make reservations.

KW38OXpDlH3Xd1LutwjaQA.review_text: Stopped in for a long intimate dinner with some old friends and we were overwhelmed by one of the best meals of the year.  The restaurant itself is nicely decorated but not over the top fancy. The business casual vibe creates a nice comfortable not too stuffy atmosphere. The service was stellar with a very attentive waiter and several runners that kept our water and wine glasses full.  The wine list is ridiculously fancy with everything from a $40 Paso Robles Cab to an old world $2,000 Grand cru. Let's just say I was happy with my Paso cab.  The Tome de Bordeaux goat cheese starter was light, creamy yet firm served with some rustic "healthy" bread. Along side was some fennel jam that was presumably dabbed with crack and honey.  The show stopper for me though was the Liberty Farms duck breast crusted in coffee topped with huckleberries and surrounded by wild rice and greens. This dish was nothing short of out of this world good. The portions were perfect, the jus sauce was just the right amount of sweet and the duck was oh so tender.  My wife went with the filet mignon and it was perfectly cooked well presented and simply yummy.  For dessert some moscato and a glass of panna cotta that was decent but pretty basic in comparison to such an awesome entree.  So yea we'll definitely be back when we feel like dropping some dough on a lively dinner.

GXr-GTPFGX9PG6Z8Jd7VXw.review_text: Very disappointed. Four of us for dinner and none of us was happy. I ordered a medium hamburger. It was very rare, almost inedible.  Someone else ordered the filet medium rare. It was over cooked and "stringy", not a lot of flavor. It wasn't a great cut of beef. The green garlic potatoes tasted like powered mashed potatoes. They were really kinda gross in both texture and flavor.  The color reminded me of the green food coloring frosting used on store bought sugar cookies around St. Patty's day.   The salmon was tasteless and had a consistency of sawdust. The French onion soup was very sweet, cloyingly so.    Maybe the kitchen was having a bad night.  The service was excellent. The cocktails were great. But the food was just not good. And when there's so much just not right with your meal, it's difficult to send it all back to the kitchen to fix it. So we're disappointed and I have to really wonder about all these 4-5 star reviews. As someone said, it's not that it cost so much (it did, this place is expensive), it just took so long to park that it's just not worth it.

kuCPbPY5gzmwb-7tUSVSsw.review_text: Was in the Bay Area a couple weekends ago, and my fiance had the foresight to make reservations at Absinthe, the Hayes Valley brasserie best known for it's Executive Chef, Top Chef Season 5 contestant, Jamie Lauren. Throughout that season, my man and I longed to try her scallops. She was always making them!! So often that an exasperated Fabio was caught on camera exclaiming, "This is Top Chef! Not Top Scallop!"   Anyhoo, our Absinthe experience was a good one. The French Onion soup (the best I've ever had) was well-seasoned and perfect, considering the chilly evening weather. The oyster shooters were also lovely. Go Bloody Mary! And the main course... the scallops. They were so delicious that my picky fiance declared them the best he'd EVER had.   Service left much to be desired, and the dessert menu was lame. We didn't order any. Rare, as I'm such a dessert junkie. But boy, were the savory items yummy!  I look forward to returning.

7c8joC_i9wM9eamWjXj4rw.review_text: I trudged into Absinthe on a cold, rainy Thu night (every night in SF is starting to seem this way).  Amazingly, the place was completely packed which seemed mildly irritating to me. Room at the bar for me, I felt, should have been provided for my efforts. And after a short wait, it was.     Knocked off #45 on The Big Eat SF List - The Galapagos.  This was accompanied with 3 oysters each for me and my companion and an order of the Spicy Fried Chick Peas. All in all quite satisfying even though at $3 an oyster - there was some sticker shock at the end there.

Tm9mBbxE5ZLiCXMhRxY9ug.review_text: The pretzels are seriously amazing, but the cocktails were mediocre and pretty weak. Probably won't come here again even though the service was quite good.

NEcZ8xGjIwAWXXdKKu7Xfw.review_text: Absinthe is ok. I don't think they deserve 4 stars because they just aren't very standout and their food is average to good. I came with some friends for sort of a midday snack and we ordered fried chickpeas, baked mac and cheese, parmesan popcorn, and the oh-so-famous soft pretzels. I personally thought the parmesan popcorn was way too mild in flavor, I could barely taste the parmesan at all. The baked mac and cheese was awesome, but of course, how can you really mess up mac and cheese?? The fried chickpeas were ok, but I think I could also make the same dish and it wouldn't cost $4 for a teeny tiny little cup. And the pretzels - very good, but when you think about how they cost more than $1 for each little pretzel stick it really makes you cringe. It comes with a cheesy dip as well but... not 7x7-worthy, necessarily.   In summary: too pricey and not exciting enough. Pass!

A5tqOLbpek26Zu84timWVA.review_text: For a place that has a reputation for cocktails, they really don't live up to it anymore.  I've gone in here and looked at the cocktail menu, only to decide to leave because nothing looked like my style.  Their drinks are all SWEET.  Once I asked for something dry, and what I got was Coca-Cola sweet.  Not what I'm looking for.  Maybe it'd help to sit at the bar, but I've never been so lucky as to snag a bar seat, and at this point, I don't know if it's worth it to go back again and try.  Vegans, don't even think about getting food here, other than the fried chickpeas.  This place is less vegan-friendly than the Ferry Building's great hall of meat and cheese.  I could just be spoiled because of other cocktail places in Chicago and New York, but I'm pretty disappointed.

T4rXSHtNUOA47GXS63S6mg.review_text: Cute place.  I came here for brunch and ordered the 2egg dish w/ bacon and sausage. I liked the sausage and the potatoes. The eggs (scrambled) were a bit too cheesy for my taste. The pancakes were really fluffy and good. The Bellini is good too.

M19NwFwAXKRZzt8koF11hQ.review_text: (See pics) Updated Review. Finally after all the years gone by I actually came here for dinner! And while the drinks were consistently good, the dinner dish was definitely better than brunch, and way way better than post opera bites.  If I come back I will order the Atkins ranch lamb sugo again- a perfect delight for its perfectly broiled top lamb and perfectly cooked papardelle pasta, my absolute favorite. The taste was rich and complex.

aIUyQ1nePT0WE4hAbSukfg.review_text: Loved their ceviche plus the duck confit. Affordable price and nice environment.

HHtsSEWylv5yAPhk5r1DLg.review_text: Excellent Coq au Vin and French onion soup we shared everything since we had been eating Shulzies bread pudding and the absurd handmade liquid nitrogen ice cream all day.  I've had good French onion soup before and this was definitely up there. One of the better Coq au vin's I've had (that is French for rooster with wine but I'm sure you already knew that).  It is bigger inside than it looks outside and the wait for a table wasn't too bad for a Thursday night. I could see how the weekend would get really busy.  It was packed with a nice crowd of folks.  Can't pick fault with much of anything, other than it being in San Francisco, Nancy Pelosi, Leland Yee and Tom Ammiano's home turf.  I didn't try any cocktails so review is food only.

GiC_S3Hhfh02Yy6c9prDvg.review_text: Absinthe is a very darling place and i had a nice experience when I came. Only a handful of restaurants have valet in SF, so I was elated to find out that this place had it. The atmosphere is very intimate and elegant. My friend and I weren't really in the mood to drink so we didn't order any cocktails. They have an extensive list of amazing cocktails, so next time, I'd love to try one or two ;). We started our meal with the mixed local greens with asian pears, pecans, brioche crisp, goat cheese mousse and medjool date vinaigrette. This salad was just delightful. I really wish my bf was there that night because this salad had his name on it! Everything about it was perfect; more specifically because of the goat cheese mousse. I was really looking forward to trying the medjool date vinaigrette but the flavor wasn't pungent enough to really identify the date flavor. It was still yummy though.  For our entrees, we had the coq au vin and the sole. My coq au vin was great, but nothing out of this world. The Burgundy and jus together made a lovely sauce and the crostini that accompanied it was great for dipping. My friend's sole was perfectly cooked and the citrus fennel brown butter went beautifully with it. The wine list was very nice, so I had a phenomenal grenache and my friend had a nice chardonnay. For dessert, we had the german chocolate cake with milk chocolate mousse, pressed coconut, and candied pecans. I had very high hopes for this but it didn't really live up to my expectations of any german chocolate related dessert. The candied pecans were amazing though.   Overall, it's a very cute little place with amazing service (and valet!!). I'd love to come back here to try the cocktails and more things from the menu.

1bG9ndpgpD9hE9tG5HcKtg.review_text: Cheese selection is impressive, house made walnut bread makes you salivate, raw bar worth note but soup, salad and appetizer is about as light as it gets.  This place rules on drinks - wines, cocktails, and libations of great creativity!  Within minutes you're transported to the roaring 20s or the French Rivera as you're chased by The Green Fairy...

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: I've been here plenty of times over the years for cocks n apps, but I finally got in here for a proper lunch this past week. French Dip, French onion soup, bloody Mary oyster shooters, a Manhattan. A little vanilla ice cream for dessert. Everything is amazing. A great bar, mixed with a great kitchen, a great location and great atmosphere.

AqdRcNkyh3b-GMsQqcPI5A.review_text: I came to Absinthe with the expectation that someone who could make it onto season 5 of Top Chef could produce fantastic food. Jamie was one of my favorites from the show (perhaps a close second behind Fabio) and so I was eager to see if she was worth her salt.   I started with the butternut squash puree soup. It was fantastic. It reminded me of Jeanty At Jack's tomato soup, in that it was perfectly seasoned, appropriately light for a pre meal whetter of the appetite, and preparing for a delightful experience. It was lovely, and the best part of the meal. It all went down hill from there.   My date and I shared the fries with dijon mustard, vinegar and rouille dips as our appetizer. Nothing overly exciting or original there. The fries were nice and crispy, but the sauces themselves lacked anything special. I've had better fries at Fog City Diner, but that's setting the bar pretty high.   Next came our mains. I had the ribeye and she had the scallops. How disappointing they both were. My steak was cooked perfectly at the requested medium rare, but it lacked flavor. How amazing it could have been with a touch of salt and pepper. There was a marrow butter on top, but the flavor there was too subtle and got lost in the taste of the meat, which is to say there wasn't any flavor to begin with. The veg under the meat was quite good, however, as it soaked up the sauces better than the steak itself. The celery puree on the side of the plate was a random addition, not adding anything to the dish in terms of taste, but perhaps simply being a beige attempt at unique presentation.   My date's scallops were also perfectly cooked, but unfortunately just as tasteless as my steak. Again, however, the veg that garnished the dish was really quite good. The artichokes in particular were the best thing on the dish, but only so because they offered much needed flavor to the bland composition before her.   For dessert, I had the chocolate banana tart, and she had the panna cotta. The panna cotta was good, and an excellent finisher to any meal. The lemon and thyme gelee topping added just the right amount of acid to the tartness of the custard, and the blackberry gracing the top helped to round out the flavor. My tart was also good, but a little too heavy for an after dinner pallet cleanser. That was of course my fault in choosing that. However, I was surprised to find that the tart itself was actually a small cake with a somewhat creamy center, with no attribute resembling what I know a tart to be. The banana ice cream on the dish was pleasant, but could be bought at any super marker. The slices of banana on the plate, encircled by dashes of butterscotch and caramel, were as bananas tend to be, and there was nothing interesting going on there.   For $113, I could have gone to Boulevard instead and spent the same amount but had a much better meal. It was not worth it, and I do not plan on going for dinner at Absinthe any time in the near to distant future. I do, however, want to attempt a trip there during lunch at one point. Considering the rather tasty veg on each of our plates, my date and I decided to come back during lunch, when the price isn't stupid-high, and try the vegetarian items on the menu, like the farro risotto. Perhaps Jamie should think about ditching the proteins for a vegetarian restaurant, because it seems she doesn't know how to actually prepare meat properly.   In conclusion, the soup was amazing (a la Jeanty At Jacks), the fries were mediocre at best (certainly no Fog City Diner), for the price of the meal the mains were sub par (just go to Boulevard if you're going to spend that much), and the dessert was certainly nothing spectacular, but not horrible (think a cross between Chez Panisse and McDonalds).

iLjMdZi0Tm7DQxX1C1_2dg.review_text: I've yet to enjoy the bites at Absinthe, but I'll tell you what - they know how to make a mean cocktail.  I don't know what it is about Absinthe, but they seem to capture an amazing energy inside the doors of their Hayes Valley eatery and drinkery. It's warm, it's cozy, the bartenders are super nice, and the crew enjoying drinks, bellied up at the copper bar, are always in a swell mood. If life has you down, it's hard not to get sucked in by the great vibes bouncing off every wall of this place.  I forget the name of their newest bartender, but it's a local mixology staple around San Francisco. He's been all over, and he definitely has a legion of fans following him around the city. Not sure if he's planning on bringing his own creations to the menu, but I don't think Absinthe needs it. With over 30 pages of specialty cocktails, beers and wines to choose from, it almost seems silly to add anything else at this point. Whatever you're in the mood for, they have it. Aperitifs, hand-shaken and stirred cocktails, IPAs, digestifs and wines from around the world are some of the things you can expect from their overstocked library of adult libations.   Speaking of drinks, this one's for the fellas: if you're on a date and want to wow your guy or gal, order the Spanish Coffee. It's like Cirque du Soleil behind the bar with firey wine glasses and cinnamon embers flowing like fireflies. Good stuff.  The drinks can be a little pricey, but nothing we haven't seen at other bars of this caliber around the city. The affordability is neck and neck with Rye, Rickhouse, Alembic and any of those other fancy schmancy saloons that have muddled their way to alcoholic infamy.

GmLpBIfp2_lug_UPkCAFNA.review_text: Nice, fancy, classy ambiance.  I came here for brunch on a really nice sunny day. The restaurant has that old "cheers" bar decor.  I wanted to order the Pretzel bites because that was the dish that made the 7x7 list and they don't serve it til 3pm! DARN IT! Oh well.  My friend and I still had an awesome brunch and ordered a delicious DUNGENESS CRAB OMELETTE  which has hen of the woods mushrooms, spinach, garlic, Meyer lemon. Great portions.   The service was flawless.  My coffee and water was always full.  Can't wait to come back there to try the 7x7 dish for dinner or late snack.

M8_SCgSFAS8MYNtIzy5aZg.review_text: Extraordinary. Bread kept coming by reqeuest, drinks were delicious, meatballs were sharp and flavorful, duck was magnificent, chicken stew was savory and divine. Shared stew sauce with entire table afterward. Looking forward to returning

ITyi4bckrJlR7A0ge-8yfg.review_text: I went here for brunch.   I had the croque madame with an arugula salad. It was delicious. It is on the heavy side for brunch though. The dijon mustard gave it a nice punch.   We ordered dessert because...it was too hard to resist. We ordered the brown butter pear panna cotta with moscato foam. the foam is GENIUS. AMAZING. We ordered the dessert to share but I pretty much ate the entire thing. I wish the dessert was not a seasonal menu...

cyJmYIvS_aN9XPyTIz4kOQ.review_text: If you want to try this restaurant, you should definitely make a reservation in advance! The food is excellent! However, I did not like the drinks. Here is our menu for the night:   Starter: Duck Confit Salad - EXCELLENT. I would highly recommend this dish. Each item had it's own flavor and contribution to the dish. I have never had such good duck in my life!   Entree: Stuffed Chicken and Braised Beef Cheek - Both excellent dishes. I wouldn't get the chicken again...but it was still delicious. Braised beef cheek was extremely tender with super yummy yams!   Drinks:  Galapagos: I ordered this because I saw other yelpers rave about it. Umm yeah, I didn't think it was good. The brandied cherries were excellent, but the drink itself wasn't very good.   ____ Havana (can't remember name): This was definitely a strong drink and I probably wouldn't be able to handle it if it wasn't for the sugar rim. Again, not so great....in my opinion.   Absinthe: My bf had one of the Absinthe drinks. It was definitely interesting...I think it's worth trying if you are intrigued by this stuff. The presentation was definitely nice...but it was really expensive ($16.50!!!).  All in all...very cool restaurant. Decor wasn't that impressive and didn't quite reflect the price of the menu. We got shafted with our table (we got some dinky one against the wall), but our server was extremely kind and professional. I hate it when servers are pretentious because it is an uppity restaurant...they were definitely down to earth and nice at Absinthe.   Enjoy!

KQO_5-MguqX0iTtuuHSs_w.review_text: One of my favorite places in the city. Really enjoyed the steak here. Nice atmosphere.

HAv257_IVJnQT0ZIL8Nn-Q.review_text: Pretty much a standard in the neighborhood. I think when I first moved to the area, I was intrigued by the decor of this place. The doors, the shiny brass fixtures. Just the old looking style and the beautiful bar. I guess I wasn't the only one who thought this place looked cool as it also attracts a lot of people. Not just for the looks, the food and drinks are also quite good.  They make one of the best burgers in the city and definitely the best in the neighborhood. I recommend getting it with cheese or an egg. Not both as it's really messy. The bun holds up though. The bartenders are great. They are attentive and make some pretty good mixtures. Sadly that have to put up with a few foo-foo idiots from time to time. Overall a good spot

zhbuv98kaozSOU4N_gPMXg.review_text: We went here for my Girlfriends birthday. The ambiance is great and the wait staff was friendly, but the cocktails were pretty bad. My cocktail tasted like a flintstones chewable. I was really amazed how that was even possible. The food was good, but not sure it was worth the price. My steak was unevenly cooked. Overall it was just okay. The city is so competitive with food.

wq_Twp10CYCk_kfewrJtSA.review_text: I've been five times in two months and I'll just share the positives:  1. French Onion soup 2. Croque Monsieur 3. German chocolate cake  Lunch has been a better experience ....

uEBYjEEGORtagp9bafj9mg.review_text: They make an excellent expresso and the Spanish coffee with 151 in it is really good.  The service is great and the wine list they have is insane.  There's this one wine that costs $7600 which is the equivalent of about 10 years of 2 buck chuck.  My homeboy and I started looking for our area codes in the wine prices.

suuIf6JWTZFjSu55k7zTBA.review_text: I've been to Absinthe a few times and have enjoyed each visit. The ambiance is 'French Brasserie' with a lot of wood paneling, a casual dining area on one side with a full bar and a more formal dining area on the other. There are also some tables along the front of the restaurant if you don't mind the busy street. Brunch menu has a good selection of egg dishes, pastries, soup, salad, pancakes, cheese, etc. They also have a raw bar and what seems like a bazillion cocktails. I enjoyed their house made granola with milk and yogurt. absinthe.com/pdf/menu/br… Dinner menu includes a good selection of hearty entrees, along with some salads and soups. I had their Potato-Crusted Arctic Char and thoroughly loved it, esp. the potato crust on top of the fish. absinthe.com/pdf/menu/di… The service was wonderful. Parking can be difficult, but they have Valet service if you get tired of circling the blocks.

_GQBtphPlhSNc7Sk1Mqm0w.review_text: I suppose you could say it was inevitable that a distinguished British detective like myself would end up at Absinthe. The place practically beckons for quiet mysteries whispered through dimly lit booths and I happen to be all ears, professionally so. I didn't expect to be there nursing a bloody shiner, though, drowning out the throbbing pain in my skull with a well-received Riesling.  I have been booted from the force (see the Seasons and Moffitt Café case files) and am officially no longer on the Case of the Missing Papaya Diamond, but a chap like myself will still follow the clues when they present themselves. It just happened to be that the clues presented themselves in a street brawl with an organ grinder and his pet monkey. The organ grinder didn't appreciate it when I refused to drop a shilling or two in the monkey's little fez and how I went on to claim that their rendition of Moonlight Sonata was an uncivilized assault on the senses. One thing led to another and I found myself with a screeching monkey clawing at my head and a portly organ grinder attempting to jab me in the face, all accompanied to an organ's death cry as I was trying to smash it on the pavement. But the clue was there.  During the scuffle my peripheral caught sight of the blonde bird (as reported in the Trace case file), disappearing into Absinthe. No mere man can forget a woman, nay, a lady, that stunning. The lead in my case. The dame in distress. A shapely embodiment of great genetics and a gentle motivator for myself to attempt a treadmill again. In that brief moment of distraction I received the bloody shiner. A lucky strike I suppose, but we'll just tell the mates at the Yard that it was something more chivalrous than a barbaric slaughter of Beethoven that brought this on.  So there I was, hid away in a booth at Absinthe, scouting the room for the lady who know haunted my thoughts. It was at this point that the server gave me the menu, I saw the word "steak", and promptly forgot why I was here in the first place. It was a splendid meal, indeed. To start, I received what can only be called the best gourmet pretzels ever graced on a plate, accompanied by a melted cheese that the chef must have loved making as much as I loved eating. The steak was accompanied by perfectly prepared asparagus and creamy mashed potatoes, a statement of side dishes done right for future generations of self-entitled youngsters trained by reality cooking shows. At some point during the meal, the server handed me a note, saying it was from a Southern, blond lady with important information. The note must have served as a napkin, as I found it stained with gravy at the end of the meal. She was since long gone, but on the note, or what was left of it, was what I needed to see.   Bangers!

wwKKW3uInlLLkDzrwbuIkQ.review_text: I'm really pissed off. I made a reservation through Dine About Town's website for dinner at Absinthe for tonight. I was so looking forward to trying Absinthe during Dine About Town. Three course meal for $35 at a fancy restaurant- what a good deal! Unfortunately, I've been had. I went to Absinthe's website today to look up their address for tonight and see if they posted their Dine About Town dinner menu. I noticed they mentioned their Dine About Town lunch menu but not their dinner menu. I called and sure enough, they are only doing Dine About Town for lunch. Not only did  Dine About Town and Absinthe fail to inform diners beforehand but the woman I spoke to have me so explanation at all. At this point, I don't really care if it was Dine About Town or Absinthe that dropped the ball. An apology and explanation is Customer Service 101.

7fSdeNTN-yXJ_e-QEgONXg.review_text: I came here on a Sunday around 2pm with some friends, and we were luckily seated right away. As we were being seated, I was basically drooling over everyone's food as we passed by their tables. Everything looked delicious.   We were given a brunch menu, and I ordered the Absinthe Burger and Buck's Fizz. Service was a little slow, but our waiter was very nice and professional. My burger was very juicey and tastey. I ordered it well done but I came out more medium done. I do with that they put a little more Aioli sauce on the burger - I could barely taste it. By contrast they gave you a ton of red onions, but those were easy to pick off. The description of the burger said it came with house made pickles, but it was actually a slice of a pickle skewered on top of the burger. It was a good pickle - sweet and a little gingery. It just wasn't between the buns like I expected. The french fries were thin and perfect, and served with a little dish of ketchup which was nice to not have to request.  Buck's Fizz was a pretty average, not very sweet despite the grenadine.  This place wasn't cheap but I feel like it was worth it for a special treat. The food was delicious and there were plenty of other things on the menu that look like they are worth trying if you have some spare cash. Their drink menu also looked fabulous but I stuck to the champagne due to a nasty hang over the day before. I would definitely stop in if you're in the area.

fK0LmQ7O-iiiCDAbtMyKuw.review_text: I've been here twice.  I love this place.  It is my favorite place to go with my beautiful companion when in the bay area.  Both times, my companion and I had our meals in the bar .  The first time, we sat at a small table.  The second time, we actually sat at the bar.  It seems that you can get a seat in the bar with only a bit of a wait even on a busy night (either that or we were extremely lucky twice).     For me, sitting directly at the bar in this restaurant is the way to go.  For one, the bartender, Carlos Yturria, is simply amazing.  Throughout our meal, he made great wine and food suggestions, mixed us very cool cocktails (one with an elaborate story and preparation), and was genuinely entertaining.  To be clear, he was not invasive (or, like, cheesy in a Tom Cruise-Cocktail manner) in any way.  Instead, he had the perfect balance of being attentive and engaging, while leaving us to an enchanting dinner. Sitting in the busy, well tended bar provides a level of buzz that is almost intoxicating (this could have been the wine combined with my amazingly beautiful dining companion).    As a treat, my companion surprised me with the scallop appetizer, which was served with pea puree and sea salt.  It was so yummy.  So subtle yet complex.  Sigh.  The food is very solid, higher-end brasserie food (oxymoron, right?).  I loved the snails (prepared in the traditional burdundy style, they serve with a lemon, which is a nice touch) and the french onion soup.  My companion had the burger, which was really good.    Jamie Lauren was the executive chef when I was last there.  She has now left, so I do not know what the impact has been on the menu.  Based upon what I have seen of her on top chef all stars (Does she hate to cook??), it seems any impact she would have had on the kitchen would have been minimal.  And Carlos is still there.

p-0-WnPB8mTV5b3E0saTGw.review_text: Great!!!  Great place, great scallops, great stuffed chicken, great french-onion soup, great drinks, great bathroom!!!!  "Great!!! Now I can't hear either!!!" -Stevie Wonder, 2010

R-i4F_rOYAMipGlvlP7A-Q.review_text: Years ago, as a broke college student, I was inexplicably getting my haircuts in Hayes Valley, my only indulgence at the time other than textbooks and gas. I would walk by this place often, check out the menu, and daydream about how much I would like to eat here someday.   Six years later, for my 30th birthday dinner, some of my best friends made it happen. (OK, granted I chose the menu and put down a $250 deposit to reserve our spot three months in advance... but all told, this dinner was meaningful because of the presence of my friends. Also, full disclosure, they paid for everything)  We had a prix-fixe menu (personalized for the occasion!) with several delicious selections, shared many a bottle of wine, our own table, and overall, had a great time.  Vanessa Harris and team were definitely accommodating and endlessly patient with me, what with my propensity for emailing via my phone (sometimes after a few drinks, I'm not gonna lie), the multiple last minute changes to the number in my final headcount and such, and they deserve a lot of credit for why this night ran as smoothly as it did.  This is probably the last time I'll ever do something so extravagant for a birthday dinner (well, until I turn 40), but this was a great way to close out the most eventful decade of my life!

3G9Jkn7hKc8fmbdK8_lC8g.review_text: i had a verrrryy good experience this time around at Absinthe.  i wanted to set up a private party of 14 girls for dinner. Joanna was really efficient about getting things set up and in order. the reservations and whatnot were a cinch and all i had to do was make a deposit of $250 (which would be deducted from the bill the night of the dinner).  we all arrived pretty much on time and didn't have to wait for our table. sometimes large parties like that get pushed back if the restaurant tries to fit a smaller party in earlier in the night (i used to work at a restaurant, so i know). the server was really nice and did a good job at timing the food so that we didn't feel rushed nor starving at any point. glasses of water were refilled often and he was super attentive. sometimes with large parties in which the gratuity is already added to the bill, the servers slack off a bit, knowing that they have a guaranteed tip coming their way.  the food was prepared nicely and everything seemed to be to everybody's liking. due to the large group we had a three course pre-fixe, in which i chose one of three differing menus (varying by price and entree options). i found this to be convenient for the restaurant as well as for myself so that i wouldn't have to narrow down options from their regular menu.   this is a great place for large parties.

YdQpmBRUvxjzNxdqlQgGFw.review_text: Great food, ambiance and service! My dad and step-mom took me and my boyfriend here to celebrate my birthday and we had a great meal.  Strawberry Gazpacho: surprisingly delicious! I wasn't sure about the flavor combination (crab and cucumber salad with strawberry) but it was light, frothy, cool, slightly sweet and a fun pink color. The crab added some nice texture and the flavors worked well together. It was heavenly. I would go back and just have a bowl of it for lunch.  Steak Tartare: We were lucky enough to be there on a rare night they had a special - steak tartare with meat from Marin Sun Farms. It was very good.  Escargot: they were cooked perfectly with just the right amount of garlic and butter, served in the shell. Great introduction for my bf who had never tried them before.  Pork Confit: This was the highlight of the meal (besides the strawberry gazpacho). The meat literally melted in my mouth and the corn was a nice sweet touch that complimented the rest of the plate. I highly recommend this entree.  Dessert: we had 2 cheeses (blue d'auvergne and l'ami du chambertin), which were both good. I have a huge sweet tooth, so I ordered a white watermelon parfait, which was a bit bland and disappointing. Luckily, I mentioned on the Open Table reservation that it was my birthday so they brought out a complimentary blueberry tequila sorbet, which was amazing and had a very strong flavor.  We had a nice bottle of cab with dinner, but the cocktail menu looks amazing and I would return just to try some drinks, along with a bowl of the strawberry gazpacho and some cheese.  In short: try the strawberry gazpacho and pork confit.

w7RP1MZad3YO7Vjgp3s3Dg.review_text: I came here for drinks and the pretzel ( to die for!!!!)only so I would have to come back and try their entrees'.This place gets packed even if its early during the week so make reservations. The bar have some tables but those are also for people with reservations.

JpwnCiInMQdqPz9XnTZsEA.review_text: As soon as we walked in, we were seated - Hubby made reservations early on and mentioned it was our anniversary. Before we were even seated, the front of the house wished us a "congrats" at least three different times. Overall, the experience was amazing. We arrived hungry and ready to order everything.   I ordered one of their popular drinks that I was curious about, since I read about it in Yelp - The Galapagos. There were two "mysterious round objects" on the bottom of my glass which I thought were either olives or blueberries...wrong! They were brandied cherries. Obviously, I didn't feel the need to bite into these round objects! Ha!  We started with their pan roasted mussels and clams which were in a chorizo, white bean broth - and we had to order their frites that came with a side of dijon mustard (didn't care for it), thyme infused malt vinegar (yum) and roasted bell pepper aioli (SO GOOD).   What to order, what to order. We wanted to try their soups since Chef was a self-proclaimed soup genius,  so we went for it. We ordered the celery root soup and french onion soup. So fantastic! I'm not a big onion lover (or liker), but the french onion soup at Absinthe was delicious. The celery root soup was good as well, very mild but comforting.   For dinner, I stayed true to my pledge to try grits for the first time so I ordered slow-cooked pork confit over house made bacon, collard greens, and cheese grits. It was very good but sadly our entrees took way too long to come out and after the starters, I was inching towards "full status". Hubby ordered their braised beef cheeks with smoked yams and sauteed kale. Damn, those yams! I couldn't stop eating them off his plate! And the beef cheeks were good too!   As full as I was, I had room in my belly...more like a desire...for dessert. We shared their cookie plate which included blood orange meltaways, double-chocolate-chipmalt cookie, chocolate hazelnut sticky bun, and Oreo cheesecake bites...HEAVEN! The double-chocolate-chipmalt cookie were mini versions of my fave cookie - the chocolate duet from Panera of all places. So I was especially happy. And they wrote Happy Anniversary in chocolate on the plate - nice touch! Thanks Absinthe!

dqhj8d-XmdF6-TNj2R_DmA.review_text: Honestly one of my favorite places to get drinks and/or dine. I have only had two poor experiences here. The good definitely outweighs the bad! The food and drinks are simply phenomenal here, and if you really dislike something, they will try and fix it for you. I have only really done their mixed drinks - I try to stay away from the wine list because it's extensive - but my favorites are usually the ones on the chalkboard. Also, I really love the Wonderlust, which is a mixed absinthe drink.  A place like this would be more for a night on the town. The bar is really loud and fun, but you can always make reservations to sit in the dining room which tends to be more quiet. I would say that this is a dressy place, but my boyfriend and I love to just walk in. :) They are always really nice.  Also, I thought this place could not be anymore amazing than it already is, but it can. They serve brunch here on Saturdays and Sundays that is to die for. The Duck Confit and French-toast Brioche are both exquisite.  By the way, they have the BEST french onion soup. I almost never go here and not order it. :9

cBywWCmCDAxQcCZcEsoJhA.review_text: Seasonal menu. Intimate restaurant.  Mt Tam Cheese with fuji apple slices and almonds. = Awesome flavor and texture combo. Duck comfit and fettuccine. = Surprisingly light yet savory. Coq au vin. = C'est parfait. Chocolate pine nut mousse. = Gorgeous presentation, though I was too full to appreciate.  Overall probably one of the best meals I've had in SF. Money well spent.

rWTMjx1lUDRIrSnL2s7tVw.review_text: Expertly cooked steak, solid absinthe selection, reasonable and nice general manager, classy atmosphere.  My friend got water spilled on him, so the manager gave us a discount on the meal.

8zpsKgYaCN7kO-lRCJ-B1A.review_text: I am a fan of Absinthe. This review is only on their bar and bar food, as both times that I've been here have I only ventured to the bar. While I would love to have a formal meal here, I have enjoyed my time at the bar.  The cocktail menu is fantastic. I love the names, and I love the drinks. They are definitely designer, with a designer price tag, but they don't shy away from the liquor in these drinks. The first time I went I had the Perfect Pear, which was a lovely drink. Last night, I ordered the Galapagos: pisco, pepper syrup and some other liquors mixed together and served a la Manhattan style - complete with cherry at the bottom. It was a stiff drink, but very good.  Last night we ordered the house made hot dog, and the first three starters: fries, marinated olives and chickpeas. I expected the chickpeas to be more crispy throughout, but only on the outside. The house made hot dog was specifically ordered to cross it off "the List". It was good - unique in that they make a "house made" hot dog, but I would never want to order it again. And, any other sausage place would serve a better dog. The sauerkraut was good; loved the caraway seeds.   This place just has an elegant feel, but is casual enough for you to sit and enjoy some appetizers and drinks in the bar. The crowd is mixed, and lots of ballet-goers hit it up before the show. Overall, a great time with good people!

1Swf4nYNSpCj46xrqHOqbg.review_text: I came here for brunch and was very satisfied. The decor is nice- somehow simultaneously dark and light, new and old, but no doubt about it- inviting. The service is great- friendly, prompt, efficient. And the food is mmm. So good. I got some grapefruit juice and wild mushroom omelette that was so good, even though the mushrooms got tiring after awhile. Most of the table got the breakfast sandwich which I would recommend as after having a bite or two of theirs I wanted more! And I love that my water was always filled. A sign of good service to me.   The service is great. One of the girls thought that she found a piece of a fingernail in her dish (it really did look like it), and we told our waiter who promptly got the manager to look into it. After doing some investigating, the manager realized it was bits of dried pasta that fell into her dish, but still took her meal off of the bill for the scare. He was courteous, professional, and warm about the entire affair and that was greatly appreciated.   And because we were there for my sister's bachelorette, they came out with this very sweet dessert plate for her at the very end (see picture). I started with 4 stars for this place, but thinking back on my pleasant experience, I'm bumping it up to 5.

q3A2T4SjVtWiTyWCzCWGXA.review_text: I went ages ago for cocktails but tried their Sunday brunch for the first time last weekend with a group of 6 girlfriends. It was packed but since we had 12:30pm reservations were seated right away. We had a corner window table and Absinthe was the perfect place to catch up with good friends over a great meal. Between the cocktails, food and dessert for the table our brunch ended up lasting almost 2 hours.  Our waitress had a great line to give us the heads we were borderline outstaying our welcome... "did you want some more water?"  Yeah, we should probably bounce.

OktfRbV9zJb4WoJafRMthQ.review_text: Fun and busy location in Hayes Valley. The staff was extremely attentive. We enjoyed the fried chickpeas, french onion soup and the hamachi sashimi. Coq au vin is one of the best we've ever had. I had the burger - nothing spectacular.  Although staff was attentive, there was a minor mistake when they brought out the wrong entrees to us. Then we had to wait another 10-15 minutes for the right ones. The waiter apologized but no offer of a free dessert or something to make up for this hiccup. Most restaurants which pride themselves on service and quality. Even an additional apology from a manager (never saw one) would have made the difference given how much we are paying.  Overall, good food, good service, but won't go out of my way to get here.

rpxd6VEP_AipWLN8CYjWzA.review_text: There are only two things I need to survive in this world....tasty cocktails and pork.    This place does both extremely well.

sXtYdtCP3Ew1gHfxJxk51w.review_text: Upon a friends recommendation and the fact that Jaime Lauren is the Executive chef here, we decided to give it a try despite not being a huge fan of French cuisine.  I checked the dress code on opentable and it states "Business casual," but most people were in jeans so we were a little over dressed.  The bar was the spot to be, it was a bit hard to get through and follow the hostess to our table in the back section.  With the noise at the bar, we could barely hear each other.  As I walked to the restroom, I saw a larger room.  I wish we were seated there, maybe the noise level would be toned down a bit.  I remember Jamie on the season of Top Chef...she was known as Top Scallops.  So of course I had scallops with mustard sauce.  It was good and perfectly cooked, but it wasn't life changing or the best thing I've ever eaten.  Actually my favorite dishes were the apps; spiced fried chickpeas and our bowl of French onion soup.  The soup was excellent, not too salty but the opposite with a nice sweetness to it.  My BF was content with his pork confit, though a tad salty.   I just don't see what the hype is about this place.  A bit loud and not romantic at all.  I can see the bar being the place to hang out after work, but I wouldn't come here to talk or catch up with friends.  It's very loud and dark.

7_SjX_GOcRROCh80KfycSw.review_text: Why review when there are over 1000 reviews? Just to say thank you Absinthe, for your fried chickpeas.

LVfY9jsjvwvOtjuZu-BOig.review_text: A friend's cousin treated us here, much appreciation for that. This place was great his cousin definitely knew what was good. Because of the drinking I can't really go into details about this place. Let me break this down  Atmosphere: Great place to be at good vibes everywhere. Mostly everybody seemed to be with somebody or in a group. I would suggest coming with a significant other or group (just a suggestion...). Staff was friendly, and they worked very well. The place was running smoothly. Good management, and well trained employees.  Drinks: Good, I didn't hear any complaints. I enjoyed mine, and everybody else enjoyed theirs.   Food: The visual appearance of their food was elegant. They didn't just throw it on there, an drizzle what not on it. There was definitely a pleasure in actually looking at your plate. I ordered a filet mignon steak cooked rare. Most restaurants tend to make rare extra rare, but they did a good job. Their pretzels were very good, because they weren't your average pretzels. Menu was variated, but I still wanted steak.   Bathrooms: They were clean, and pleasant (To some people this matters).  Left the place with good vibes, good alcohol, and a good experience.

70aCUk-YIZSasoHfoe-LVw.review_text: Absinthe (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) was the second stop on our two restaurant feast last Sunday. I was extremely excited and expecting a grand experience after skimming through the 1,300 reviews and solid 4 star average. I was also eager to check out Jaime's culinary skills from Top Chef. Sadly, my experience didn't match the expectations. Maybe the bar was set too high, perhaps Absinthe is overly hyped, or maybe I'm just not big on French cuisine? At any rate I just don't get what all the hype is about. That night we ordered: -French Onion Soup (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) -Escargots in Shell (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) -Rabbit Rillettes (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) -Sausage & Cornbread Stuffed Mary's Chicken (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) -Galapagos Cocktail (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) -Old Havana Cocktail (static1.px.yelpcdn.com/b…) **The Good** My favorite dish of the night by far was the Sausage & Cornbread Stuffed Mary's Chicken. This fantastic dish included apple parsnip puree, brussel sprouts, and cranberry gastrique. The chicken was extremely tender and juicy, and the cranberry gastrique was mind blowingly delicious! What was surprisingly amazing was the brussel sprouts. Normally I am not a big fan of veggies, but they were so crunchy and extremely luscious that they kept me eagerly eating more and more! My most highly anticipated dish for the night, the French onion soup. While it didn't blow me away like the chicken dish, I did find it quite enjoyable. The taste was quite rich and simply delicious. The soup base is full of onion and was very flavorful. The cheese is gooey yet firm on the top and heavenly divine. **The Forgettable** After getting a good buzz from our first stop and feeling quite adventurous, I was game to try some new dishes I've never experienced.  That's where the escargots and rabbit rillette came into place. The escargot was in a garlic herb butter sauce that offered an interesting texture and flavor. They were a bit chewy and rubbery for my preference and nothing spectacular. The rabbit rillette was a lot saltier then I was expecting, and reminded me of sweeter version of tuna fish. I ordered the Galapagos cocktail mainly because it was #45 on 7x7's 2009 Big Eat SF List. I was very hesitant to order it after reading the ingredients, and after taking a sip I instantly knew I should have followed my gut instincts. Service - I remember telling our waiter when we ordered the French onion soup that we wanted to share a large bowl. When the soup came I asked if we can each get 2 small bowls to split the soup. Then he apologized and said we couldn't split up the soup because of the makeup of it. Rather we should just take turns with the soup. Had we known this we would have just ordered two smalls bowls, thanks for nothing! Also, the service here is EXTREMELY slow. Summary (2 stars): Don't believe the hype. Most of the dishes are ridiculously overpriced. Service is slower than the snails they serve!

G1EQySgLTrqgtywHmyI1mQ.review_text: Came back from a quick brunch this Sat - note, they don't open their doors until 11am. It's good to line up before it hits 11am if you want a quick seat and their service was pretty darn quick. 3 of us ladies, 3 French 75's, 2 AMAZING sticky buns, 1 coffee, 1 order of biscuits'n'2 over-medium eggs, and a soft boiled egg with sea salt and croutons. YUMMMINESS.   We sat at the bar where the bartender was very pleasant and prompt. The food was lovely - you MUST try their sticky buns. Anyways, all was delicious with nothing to complain about. Only that we couldn't stay longer as we had a lunch banquet to go to. Stuffed, we were. Anyways, this place remains one of my top Bay Area brunch spots. Always a good idea to make reservations!!!

IdnbvI-jYalwwSdLldiw0w.review_text: Delicious! Everything we ordered last night for my sister's birthday dinner was amazing. The drinks were all so tasty - sacred heart, citron lemonade, galapagos (on last year's 7x7 list). The beef tartare and the country pate were great to start with, and the pork rib eye was HUGE! I'd read some reviews saying that portions here are on the smaller side, so when that dish came out I was like O_O. Barely ate half of it, but SO GOOD. There was this one bite of pure skin and it was heaven - crispy, salty, and paired with the red cabbage and jalapeno-cheddar grits = MMMMMMMM.  Definitely a great choice for a special dinner or when you've got some extra cash to blow. Great for groups or dates!

LdmQm8Y9B_9NBEaDiAHnwA.review_text: I adore Absinthe.  Get the Blood and Sand. Get something a little offbeat off the menu (easy to do, the menu is highly offbeat).  Repeat.  Interesting location, good browsing street, perfect Sunday afternoon.  Dinner is nice too I'm sure, but to me this is an afternoon kind of place.  Just don't plan on doing especially ambitious afterwards, as I guarantee you, you will be slightly tipsy if you did things right.

uqsFEsjL_0QlZO2U__F6XA.review_text: Impeccable service, ambience is suitable for an intimate date albeit a bit noisy on a Friday evening. They were out of the sole, which may just be an indicator that they order fresh on a daily basis as should be expected for an establishment in this range. The cod was perfectly acceptable. No absinthe fountains, but pours were traditionally prepped with slotted spoon and ice water dripped over a sugar cube. Respectable selection of Scotch. Quite a few beef dishes on the menu.

_tYdp-NhWaKnwYveFE2JnA.review_text: Meh. I like the atmosphere but the service and the crammed bar is a little much.  We came here after seeing the Nutcracker at the Ballet a few blocks away. I would have given this place two stars but my friend had "the best scotch on the rocks ever" here, and we didn't try the food.

eUmVXP9UnoWtz9NSBwY4jA.review_text: Pretty solid fancy pants brunch. Prices are in line with some of the other nice restaurants in town (think $12-$15 brunch entrees on average) but the food and overall brunch experience pales in comparison to my favorite brunch spot, Foreign Cinema.  Don't get me wrong, we all cleaned our plates and were quite happy with the food...it just wasn't five star "Oh my God, foodgasm!!!" great. Plus the bloody mary was pretty lackluster - considering the pedigree behind the Absinthe bar I was definitely expecting more.  Anyhow...good place to take the parents (especially if they are paying!) or to catch up with old friends. Just make sure and make a reservation or get there right when they open.

xa74dGTzDqbrOxz4AWa5gw.review_text: The OJ here is just delicious! refreshing brunch on weekends. Wild mushroom omlette is made really well . I am usually not a french toast fan, but the the ricotta french toast is awesome.. Dont forget to try the walnut bread

D5uMny1pAVWhNGDvFDPp8g.review_text: You know how you hear about how good a place is but just assume it's hype or you have a great business event at a place but assume the regular menu food isn't as good? That's totally what I did with Absinthe.  Really can't think of anything I haven't liked when dining here. Finally made it to dinner here recently after having only been during lunch and for business events.  We were celebrating the some good news and wanted to try lots of dishes so we avoided the larger plates and focused on the soups, salads and smaller courses. We ordered far more than we need to for two people and really indulged.  We started with the French Onion Soup and the Strawberry gazpacho, which turned out to be two of the best things we would have. While not vegans we were amazed and happy to learn that the gazpacho was vegan and made with no cream. It was so wonderful, I'm already planning on going back to have a big bowl of it for lunch.  I think the name french onion soup is funny since it's just onion soup outside of the US but this was one of the best onion soups we've had the US. It was a rich broth without being too salty which is a huge problem with most onion soups, the crouton was nice deep bread and the cheese was perfect in it.  Then we had the frisee salad with a duck egg, lardons on the side since the spouse doesn't eat meat. It was a HUGE salad, really a meal in itself.  Then we had the Escargot in shell. The meat of the snail was tender and soft with a nice earthy flavour.   For our entrees we had the blue nose bass and the beef cheeks.  Beef cheeks seem to be the new hot meat replacing pork belly as the must have high fat tasty flesh choice. That said, the beef cheeks were amazing. They were maple-syrup-glazed and served with smoked yams, sautéed kale, horseradish crème fraiche. Horseradish creme fraiche is one of the best things ever and a perfect compliment to the beef cheeks.  The bass was tender while still being firm and the Winter squash puree, wilted chard and pecan brown butter vinaigrette all just brought out the flavour of the fish.   I really like that the vegetables that accompanied the dishes were all as well cooked and flavourful as the proteins.  We then had a cheese course which the cheese snob French spouse loved and declared to be very good.  The true test of the place came in dessert with the very simple pot creme which seems to be something American French restaurants have a hard time making. Usually they come out to liquid and too sweet but the chocolate pot de creme was just the right texture and flavour.  Having now eaten here a couple more times I think Absinthe is a great go to place for a first date, a special night or just as an occasional treat.

fbU5hr0TG0qb6oVcEc9JDw.review_text: Stopped in for Saturday brunch and was not impressed. Service was really good, but the food was beyond lackluster. I ordered the smoked salmon omelet and it was under seasoned and accompanied by thick slices of hard potatoes covered in a sweet, over-reduced onion/wine mixture. My husband decided to send back his steak and fries because the meat was overcooked and the cut tasted cheap. They offered him an extra drink as an apology, but it was a disappointing experience overall. We hadn't been here for a long while and definitely will not be going back. I'd go to Chez Maman if you are looking for French food in the area.

biDXUgnUXN_yJmjAAe8hIw.review_text: Always love it here but have only been to the bar, never a sit down table dinner.  They have great drinks here!  We ordered a sidecar and wine.  We also had the panna cotta which was served in a glass cup with muddled huckleberries on top.  It was fab!  Great, fun environment!

uDYNXKTd_cixNNfsyWg57Q.review_text: 4.5 Stars  For something as simple as pretzels, Absinthe sure knows how to make them special.  They are small, soft, pillowy bites of dough full of garlic and butter (but not too much) with a hint of salt.  The Vermont Cheddar Mornay makes the pretzels just a bit more special.  Delicious!  The Absinthe Hamburger comes simply dressed with lettuce, red onions and aioli on a fresh bun, which is skewered with a couple pickle spears.  The ground beef was super moist and flavorful.  The crispy shoe-string french fries were just as tasty.  My husband had the Roasted Mary's Chicken Breast,which was also incredibly moist.  But the best part was the red onion rings that garnished the dish.  I wish I had a side of the red onion rings instead of the french fries.  The Chocolate Pot de Creme was so rich, thicker than most I've had, yet still so silky.  The perfect way to end a great meal.  Our server Carlos was friendly and offered great suggestions.  Our busser Jose was even friendlier.  But the reason why Absinthe does not get 5 Stars is because our main entrees took FOREVER to be served.  After our appetizer dishes were cleared, a couple was seated at the table next to us.  Their meal was served, and they were almost done, before ours even came.

2XX0A2hNEzM_q5wlrPlv5w.review_text: Most recently we came here right after seeing Pink Martini at the symphony on a Friday night a few weeks ago. I was expecting a little bit of a wait, but we got seated right away. Service was friendly but not overly attentive.  The two of us shared a few appetizers and sides (French fries, duck confit, flatbread, and French onion soup), and it was perfect for a late-night meal. For dessert we had the panna cotta and the chocolate cherry baked Alaska. All very good.  Oh, and at the next table was Cloris Leachman, who was in town to be a grand marshall in the Pride parade the next day. And on our way out, we saw Thomas Lauderdale of Pink Martini on his way in.

Njr-4deTIXPvXfKHaXn_0A.review_text: Absinthe came recommended by a bartender we met while on vacation in New Orleans. He couldn't stop singing praises about Absinthe's libations and noted that he frequented the place quite often since he had dated one of the bartenders. We knew his suggestion could be trusted after seeing him pull out a special pack of imported beer for a German family that were regulars at his New Orleans bar. Obviously he cared about his customers enough to go the extra mile, let alone not to steer them in the wrong direction!  So, since my wedding date and I were dressed to the 9's on Saturday, we decided to stop in for a few drinks & a snack while waiting for the reception room to open up. And... the bartender couldn't have been more right! The cocktails ARE top of the line.  After having a crappy sidecar in NYC that left a bad taste a-lingering, I was ready to put Absinthe to the test and see if they could wash away the bad experience. Absinthe ended up rising to the occasion and had me on Cloud 9 once I sipped that well-crafted drink to the last drop. Yum! With a perfect 10 cocktail like that, how could I not order up another drink?? So, I pointed to one that I saw a server delivering to a table, which was like a cross b/w a caiparanha & a mojito (its name starts w/ a "C"), but better!   We also shared an order of fries that came not w/ ketchup, but thyme-infused vinegar, Dijon mustard & rouille for dipping. What a lovely alternative to the norm and the fries were long gone once it was time to head out.  Hats off to that bartender in New Orleans. He sure has excellent taste!!

F9r9fv9Zf0mt3D8QaX3_nQ.review_text: Met some of my friends here for lunch one weekend.  I wasn't too impressed with the food selection for brunch, I ordered two eggs with sausage, potatoes, and toast.   I had the absinthe lemonade which was pretty good. Our waitress was great.  She was super sweet and very efficient.  I've been here for dinner before and I remember enjoying the dinner menu so much more.  The neighborhood is great and parking may be difficult.  Would recommend this place for dinner over lunch.

5ZXT4BQB-C1XjUpKmh7kaQ.review_text: I have yet to dine here, but at the bar I've never had a drink I didn't absolutely love.  My current obsession is the Dark and Stormy, and Absinthe makes my favorite in the city.    These people know how to mix a mean spirit.

46rNdBIvXaHXAj9uMggoVw.review_text: This really is as good as it gets.  From the moment we arrived until the moment we left, everything was perfect.  If I was eating out every day, this is the place I would choose.  Our server, Erin was the best restaurant server I have ever encountered in all my years - seriously.  She knew the menu, was able to make suggestions, was there whenever we needed her, had a marvelous personality, and made us feel right at home.  My friend had the baby beet and kale salad to start and I had French onion soup.  We tasted each other's food because it looked so good, and it was!  I had Coq au vin which was mouth-watering with just the right amount of bacon, root vegetables of perfect doneness, and the sauce that seemed to make the chicken and chanterelle mushrooms sing.  My friend's potato crusted salmon was also excellent.  I could go on and on about our drinks and desert and how I want to tell the whole world about this marvelous place, but you get the idea.  If you like excellent food and service when you dine out, this is the place to come.  They have weekend brunch too!

Q_yIbRXuE4AHxRr4Fnd_Vw.review_text: OH MY GOODNESS. Upscale, suave, enjoyable spot I must say.  The first thing that caught my eye was the bar and the rows and rows of unknown alcohol bottles on display right before me! I've never seen half of them before!  The whole point of going here was to try the absinthe and although they have different choices ranging in price. My friends and I went for the cheapest one just since we were en route of a whole days worth of alcohol consumption. I must say it didn't do anything for me but my friends swore they were floating.   Their raw oysters were probably one of thee best I've ever had. Even though they're $3+ each, they're so worth it!   Verdict: Didn't have time to try any of the dishes since we were on our way to the next food joint but I must say I'd love to come back and dine on their oh so delicious looking menu.

6TMrfAI26FK3JKULW6K5oA.review_text: I've only been here for wine and appetizers, but I looooovvvveeee it! Pretzel bites are good but you can taste the high cholesterol being digested into your body. The flatbread is fantastic, nice and crispy. The fries are good as well! The grilled cheese was a little intimidating but very nicely portioned.   AND THE WINE IS RIDICULOUSLY DELICIOUS. I'm a sucker for Rose and they have the best still Rose I've tasted in a while. Also two blocks from my house so I'm a frequent visitor.

fSR_UX9kSeU4oOkrP4zacg.review_text: Absinthe Brasserie & Bar is a fantastic place for drinks and excellent food, both for dinner and brunch. Being located near Van Ness and the San Francisco Ballet makes parking a little difficult at night but with a little patience and a few circles around the block, you can snag free residential parking.   The first time I came to Absinthe was for the girlfriend's 21st birthday brunch. We were seated in a nice cushy, round booth that had enough space to fit a party of four. Ordered the duck-confit ragout and eggs benedict. Both were absolutely delicious and surprisingly not to heavy for brunch. Midway through I asked the waitress if there was any special for the birthday girl and they were nice enough to provide a scoop of vanilla ice cream with Happy Birthday written in chocolate on the plate. It even came with a candle place right in the middle of the ice cream.   The second time was with a larger party, without reservations for dinner. The wait was approximately 40 minutes and we were seat at a very small round table in the bar area of Absinthe. Ordered the Sacred Heart to eat with my Spicy Pork Meatball snack, Duo of California Lamb, and Absinthe Hamburger with sautéed mushrooms and Vermont cheddar cheese. Don't judge me I was so hungry after the wait I needed to sample their pork, lamb, and beef. And I am thankful I did because Absinthe did a fantastic job cooking the protein and flavoring it. Even the Sacred Heart was a surprisingly sweet, yet tart absinthe cocktail.  I will definitely be back again and again for the food and drinks.   What I recommend:  -- Absinthe burger

Q2OqdQVwtQvTAidzheKk7g.review_text: Had dinner here last night with friends, and the food was pretty good.  -2 stars for a few things: 1) The table was small so it was a hassle trying to fit all our plates and glasses and food. 2) The servers kept taking away our small plates and not giving us new ones. We ended up using our bread plates, which they promptly took away after another round of appetizers. Finally, we all held on to our plates for dear life and fiercely protected them against the invasion of the dish snatchers. 3) The bar was backed up so much it took 40 minutes for my friend J to get her second drink. 4) Overall I think the food was really good, but the price tag was a little stiff for my poor little wallet.  Here's what we pigged out on last night: 1) Soft Garlic Pretzels with Vermont cheddar Mornay - hot, soft and chewy. It was yummy but not outstanding. 2) French Fries - I have always loved Absinthe fries, especially with the smoky tomato ketchup. 3) Spicy Pork Meatballs - don't know how they tasted, since my boyfriend ate his, then stole mine while I was distracted with a dish-snatching situation. I am told they were divine. I will probably go back just for these. 4) Maine Scallops - these were pretty good, but 3 for $15?
