That's just a little too expensive for me. 5) Beef Tartare - my second favorite dish of the evening. The cornichons were diced and mixed with the meat, providing a nice tangy taste and crunchy texture. 6) Absinthe Hamburger - also ordered a fried egg on top. It was a good burger, but nothing really stood out. 7) Masami Farms Pork Loin - now this, this was AMAZING. Juicy pork loin, crispy pork belly. The sauce was divine, and we sopped up every little bit with bread.  Will probably head back once in a while, but not a go-to place for me.

5XECxkkMoRw14YFNh5n2LA.review_text: The food here is incredible. Everything is done perfectly.   Pretzels: They are covered in garlic butter. (They also happen to come with a way too mild (cheddar?) cheese dip, which itself is unnecessary.)  Mussels: Awesome broth. This + bread is way good.  Oysters: I don't even like, normally, but the Pt Reyes were friggin tasty.  Lamb: This was my entree and it couldn't have been done better. The meat was perfectly cooked and the vegetables were..perfectly cooked. I need to find another word. Lamb is from California, too. I don't mind the gamey, lambey taste, at all, in fact I like it, but they said this wouldn't have it, and they are right. So, non-lamb-lovers would eat this too. I loved.  Coq Au Vin: Too smokey for my taste.   Panna Cotta: Buttermilk with strawberries and basil creme. The best panna cotta I've EVER eaten.   We also got one of their cheese plates but it was too mild -- our bad.  For a butt-ton of food and a little wine it was around $150, after tip, etc. (Special occasion and a zillion courses for two people, so that felt like a deal.)

LdWIjNvjdaAoAfpQhT6F9w.review_text: Rather spendy of a restaurant. The main courses are solid, and the desserts creative - I'd mostly return for their French Onion Soup. It's one of the best I've had!

EiwxlbR8fb68lMgEXhcWKA.review_text: Along with many others, I think I was expecting something grand considering the number of reviews this place got and the average number of stars. Maybe they all came during brunch, or ... I don't know, happy hour. I'm not sure, but the dinner experience was far from good and far more expensive than I would ever pay for a place like this and food of this caliber.   We arrived as a group of 6 and were seated after 30 minutes of waiting despite having made a reservation and not going during "peak" dinner hour. We were seated in the back room and the hostess came to hand us our menu's. After that I think we didn't see anyone for at least 15 minutes while we were waiting to order some drinks.  After the drink orders were in, we ordered an appetizer and some food. The appetizers came quickly, but it took almost 30 minutes for our food orders to come. Two orders were wrong, one order had cheese for someone who was lactose intolerant even though it was specified for that dish to have no cheese and one pasta dish was cold.   It took another 20 minutes to resolve the issues and by this time our dinner party had been at Absinthe for almost 2 hours before we even really started our meals. There was just so much waiting.  I think this place is overhyped, unfortunately and the bar needs to be set a bit lower. Our total bill came out to be $90 per couple and all we ordered were two drinks, two entrees and split an appetizer. That's pretty outrageous.

NnL6HUNY9ckb9mSbTGkjOg.review_text: Their most memorable dish was their French onion soup. Broth was a bit too salty, but delicious cheese. We ordered their coq au vin and lamb shank for our mains. Portions were generous. Liked their side of mac and cheese. Overall food was A-OK. Minus one star, however, because service was incredibly slow (and this was on a Tuesday night) and they forgot to bring us our leftovers!

xh_dBseJU8gwIeRtjmBGCg.review_text: Onion Soup is Yummy!  Everything else is solid, decent.  Would come back if in the area.

fgsPrYEeqvdCAQl8mROqgg.review_text: I would give it 4 stars if not for the lackluster, soul-less service we received. Visiting SF the man had been here before and wanted to return. I'm not a fan of the French food - my fav meal when actually in France was Italian - BUT I wanted to try since he liked the place. So, I ordered the burger and it was seriously one of the best burgers I've ever had. Everything we had was delish, but our server was so weird and with the worst energy. It really ruined the meal. I've never experienced anything like it. We spent a lot of money on good food, but all we will ever remember is the serious lack of good service.

Atkr8oX92lSlfa7ucNwD1g.review_text: Delicious food- not the best. The cocktail list is extensive and interesting! The waiters are very knowledgable about the whole menu and go out of their way to make your dining experience a good one. The bar can become a "scene" especially with 30 somethings. This isn't the place to go to "party".

aAtCVEptN28n1v67v1xrUg.review_text: Went here for the 1st time on a Sunday for brunch. Cute place inside and they have outside seating which I liked. We sat at the bar which was a nice feel. I ordered this drink that was in a champagne glass and had grapefruit, champagne, lime and some other ingredients and it was amazing!!!!!!!!! I ordered the Duck Confit Ragout which sits on poached eggs, a chive potato cake and toast on the side, I truly fell in love!!!!!!!! My friend ordered the fruit dish which comes with cream and she really liked it!  It was very busy and there was only one bartender who handled all of the bar and all the drinks for the restaurant and that is why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. I'm not saying it was the bartenders fault because he was doing the best he could. But it would have been nice if he was able to be attentive, especially for the price your paying. Overall great experience and I would go back!

0s_c3pTsuoc-T-tiHG9d7A.review_text: The host is always so kind to us here, and I know every time I go, even if it's packed, I'll be treated with warmth. That's a great thing for a place that gets super busy, especially after shows.   The cocktails of course, are gorgeous--the French '75, the Wonderlust--really any of their gin cocktails are just ooh, so well crafted and good. They also have a solid selection of cheeses, and fresh oysters. For some reason it's always here that oysters taste incredibly dynamic.   Consistently just makes me love SF. Mm.

f0R-Mjfwm2-xA47r36A_wA.review_text: Not that this place needs another raving review, but a friend and I dropped by for their Dine About Town brunch and OMG it was delicious! That was a week ago and I'm still craving another serving.   Try the portabella mushroom grilled cheese. Or even the coconut rice with chicken dish. Haha this was a friend I haven't seen in months, so we had a lot to catch up on. Needless to say, we stopped talking for a bit to enjoy our food and comment on how good was.   Lol...can't wait to go back!

QHfD9kNQjcVnD1vrLVj0zw.review_text: It was that time of night when "just restaurants" were about to close, yet not really ready for late night, 24-hour "diner eatin'" either. So the suggestion of Absinthe was made for a quick snack. And I must say, Absinthe fit the bill.  Although the dining room was bustling and there was a 20 min wait for a table, we found 2 stools at the bar within 5 min.  Everyone's reviewed the joint, so I'll get to the point:  Artisanal Cheese platter: yes Croque Madame: no

RgotWt-6_53vAkQfIc81Dw.review_text: I had been looking forward to trying Absinthe for a really long time, and I was so disappointed that the entree I had my heart set on was sold out! If anyone had the pan-seared local halibut earlier in the evening, I sure hope you enjoyed it.   Unfortunately I couldn't decide on another entree, so instead I had the strawberry gazpacho and the shrimp salad, and shared and order of french fries with friends. The gazpacho was amazing! It was definitely the highlight of my meal, along with the Ginger Rogers cocktail.   I would definitely come back to Absinthe, but next time maybe for drinks and appetizers at the bar.

q3x249UGWYz0x6FsYg9Zmw.review_text: I am going to give this a 4 of 5, although this particular experience could have been much lower.  The only reason for this high level review is because I do believe this place could be much better on any other visit... And because the visit did get better due to the wonderful bartenders conversation and level of service that started when things started to go wrong.  The food we ordered was good, not spectacular but high quality.  I think it would have been better if we had received when we were still hungry but the food took about an hour to receive and many others were seated after us but go their food before us, so at that point we weren't so much hungry but past the point of being hungry... And not in the best of spirits.  The brunch and drink menu are both quite comprehensive and good selections are available.  The choices are also various in ingredients and unique in flavors.  I liked the variety and style of the food.  The service when we were first arrived was a bit low, as the host was a little rude when we put our names on the list to be seated...we did get a seat at the bar but the bartender took about 10 minutes to even take our order...  Service improved as they calmed down... Other than not getting our food forever!   Def a little pricey, but worth it as far as food and restaurant quality.  As long as service improves next time, I would go back.

96us9i9zB7QIxBtyRlhvDQ.review_text: (This review is for dessert & drinks only.)  I'm not a hard girl to please. Even after I've had dinner & dessert, you can still take me out for more dessert. I won't say no. I won't even try to be girly, (or uninterested) cock my head shyly and say noooo.....  Please.   More chocolate? Sure!  But u just had a slice at fill in the blank restaurant. Am I having cake here? No...it says "pot de creme..." Sounds perfect!   Life's too short to pretend to be cute, tiny, and blasé about desserts.   And so here I am at Absinthe, (after coming from dinner & dessert from somewhere else) about to have a chocolate pot de creme, and a buttermilk panna cotta w/roasted strawberries, basil meringue, and pistachio crumble. And a glass of an ever so smooth tasting Riesling.   5 stars for being mMmmMmmmmmMM. Service was awesome, ambiance was sweet, dessert was fantasticals, (I will be back to try the rest of their dessert menu)  and my nite couldn't have ended any better.

xQm19fuRHxQZt1ORqE0ppA.review_text: I love Absinthe, it's my favorite spot and has been for years! The cocktails, the food, and the service is always, always just what I want!

FoPy5PSHEqALnXGPoYFWuw.review_text: The best French bistro in the city -- the bar, the ambiance, the always-changing menu that offers new plays on classic French.  Brunch is awesome, as is any other meal.  And the cocktails....mmmm.  I go habitually 1x per month, and I can't say that about most any restaurant.

IPy3uJllYJmFcZwYJ0kujA.review_text: Been here twice now and this place gets a solid 5 stars from me.  They are a well oiled machine with staff that is at the top echelon of what they do - cook, serve, bartend, bus, etc.  Each time I've gone was on a Saturday or Sunday for brunch when they open with my family which was either a 5 or 6 top.  We sat in the same location which is some of the first seating near the bar.  The decor is of class without being snobbish.  The service is of the same regard.  I started my morning out with a shot of espresso.  Strong, black and tasty, just the way I like it.    Their creative cocktail list gets me going at 11AM each time.  Many of the cocktails point to their origin or accolades which I found to be a nice touch.  My last trip I ordered the Sazerac which features rye whiskey, absinthe, and bitters among other components which I now have forgotten.  It was boozy and delicious.    We have ordered and split the whole crab each time and were never disappointed.  Served with drawn butter, this is fun, family style, get your hands dirty kind of fun.    I ordered the croque monsieur both time for brunch as I rarely have an opportunity to have this great sandwich.  This place does it right; oh so tasty.  Two others in my party had the prime rib.  I thought it was very tender, flavorful and exceptional.  Easily my mother's favorite cut of meat, I heard her go all the way to 'best I've ever had.'  I tried a bit of the heirloom tomato BLT.  For a BLT, I found it in a category of its own.  Just a combination of great ingredients, fresh heirlooms, thick cut bacon and top notch bread.  Really, really good.  The Spanish chorizo frittata was not bad at all, but to me it was the least impressive entree on the table.  All in all, a wonderful dining experience each time I've been there and I certainly will be back!

NVei24-9k5GIZNRR1xGcRQ.review_text: Pre-opera dinner. Arrived @ 5:30. Spent 2 lovely hours here.   The food is exceptionally good, but it does not taste truly French. Nothing of the 5 courses we enjoyed at Absinthe evoked fond memories of meals in Paris. Let's call the cuisine here French inspired Californian.   Our young waiter gave sound food recommendations.  In comparison to pre-symphony early dinners I've had at the Hayes Street Grill, Jardinierre,  and Indigo, Absinthe is the clear winner for food / ambience / service expertise. We got splash samples of wines before we committed to $12 - $15 per glass.   I think my favorite aspect of the evening here was sitting in the romantic dining room full of chatty people who were all well dressed for the opera & symphony. I didn't feel out of place wearing my tuxedo.  Bambie was dressed to the "nines".  She probably was the best looking woman in the place, but that happens often where  ever we go...   Food & wine bill before tip = $175.

eSlOI3GhroEtcbaD_nFXJQ.review_text: Very good brunch, nice area to walk around and enjoy the city.  Food ratings were deviled egg (4), French onion soup (3), grilled cheese (5), butternut squash pancakes(4), and French toast (4).

sGYrxVCEJGGBArWI1LUgxQ.review_text: I've been here a handful of times for drinks, light dinner, appetizers and wine and brunch. Sincerely, I don't get the appeal of Absinthe. I think the service is lax, the food is just ok (good fries do not a restaurant make, no matter if they're served in a cute metal cone/waxed paper).  And the drinks are so watered down that I seriously thought they were pulling our leg. Hey people, it might be Sunday evening but don't ruin my week before it even starts!  I miss the old Ivy's that used to be there. Yeah, it was old-time Hayes Valley circa 1998 or earlier.. but it was a better restaurant and not snotty like Absinthe is, a poseur whose reputation is better than it deserves.

pI7T-4BW9YM_R8E5ojxR9w.review_text: Awesome food, service, drinks and atmosphere! My husband and I held our Wedding Dinner reception at Absinthe and it was amazing! Vanessa was wonderful helping us make all the arrangements and made the process easier since it was all done via email.  We are still getting compliments from our guests about the food! The staff was attentive and made our guests feel welcome. We had an amazing time at our dinner reception and would recommend Absinthe for any small intimate parties.

T8J027sFoRJn7506ctdIrQ.review_text: Absinthe is all about indulgence with luxurious food and rich flavors. Their menu offers both classic dishes and more unique restaurant specialties that are definitely worth a try!  We started with the potato and duck croquettes and the garlic soft pretzels. I'm not usually big on croquettes or duck, but these were done perfectly with a crispy exterior and a creamy potato inside. The duck filling wasn't too gamey, and the sauce on top really brought it all together. The garlic soft pretzels were almost like garlic bread bites and the texture of the pretzel was perfect. Both were on the heavier side, but they were elevated at the same time.  I had the grilled octopus entree, which came with a great puree to complement the octopus. The octopus itself was the most well-cooked octopus I've ever had. The texture was not at all rubbery, and it ended up being almost tender like fish or chicken. The char flavor was perfect and the greens on the side brightened up the whole dish. We also shared the mac and cheese side, which kind of made our meal over-the-top rich, but I loved the cheeses they used in it. Absinthe is definitely a place to come to treat yourself, so pick your poison and indulge!

pcpu6-riyISr95INc9KgCg.review_text: Friday night dinner.  DRINKS:  My favorite cocktail of the night was BRAZIL 66 - highly recommend. Manhattan cocktail - meh, bitter-y, manly, will not order again Santa Cruz mtns Chardonnay was mediocre.  Freeman Russian River Pinot Noir by the glass -fantastic.  FOOD: Hood canal oysters were great, very fresh  Black caviar - could not be better, an A+ Hamachi - fantastic French onion soup -solid   Will come back plenty =)

9w-xZg6DgZkX6ucYZbN4KQ.review_text: Knowing that Absinthe would probably be uber crowded due to it's rising Top Chef's popularity, we made reservations (same day, mind you) for Sunday brunch.   It was a smart move. Parking was difficult to find and despite having a reservation, we still had to wait 5-7 minutes or so to be seated. So let's get down to business...  Ambiance -makes you want to whip out a cigar. large windows, lots of dark wood, full bar, dim lighting, tiled ceilings, and french posters a la its' namesake -not a 'girly/cute' place - but that doesn't mean it's not for the ladies -they played random Top 40's music during brunch. totally random and out of place for the restaurant and it's patrons (a classy, mature crowd). makes me wonder if this is their usual music set  Food -the french onion soup was tasty (not too salty!) i'd recommend it for a rainy/cold day -the banana-blueberry pancakes were good, but not memorable. i'd prefer something fluffier. you could barely taste/see the banana - it was moreso a 'hint of banana' if anything -very satisfied with the wild mushroom omelet! the gruyère makes it flavorful enough that there's no need to add pepper, ketchup, etc. jump on it! -absinthe lemonades were refreshing, but you could save $3.50 for something else  Service -honestly, service lowered my rating for absinthe. you're not getting what you pay for -the restaurant is understaffed, thus making waiters/waitresses stressed, inattentive, and fake friendly -we waited a very long time between our soup and our main courses. after finishing, it took even longer to pay the bill  Have fun!

i6YzuulerZN3SxEUorINVg.review_text: Great brunch here last Sunday.  Great service.  Fantastic food.  Nice mix of lunch and breakfast items.  Be warned, you will be tempted by the sweets.  They are worth the calories, in my opinion.  Make a reservation.  They get very busy.

LA2AVpWayjlmlaeyLmQ5kQ.review_text: Reliable service, good drinks, and voluminous food (although I'm not sure the last is an asset), it's an institution that's aging well. The clientele often let the setting down a bit, but it's tough to be both a neighborhood haunt and a special-occasion place (distance from symphony, etc. stretch its menu). Will happily return.

xaK7JRbicw8m6bn8ZjY2LQ.review_text: We made reservations here for a quick meal before we went to the symphony. They seemed very accustomed handling customers short on time since they are so conveniently located but did a great job at keeping service quick but not making you feel like you were rushing through dinner.  My husband ordered the Grilled Skirt Steak Frites and I ordered the Grilled Bluenose Bass. Both dishes were delicious though I was naturally more partial to what I ordered. To me what made the dish was the pancetta, chick peas and pine nuts that accompanied the perfectly grilled fish. The earthiness of the sides brought out the delicious grilled flavor.  The steak was good in it's own right. Simple but well seasoned and perfectly cooked. We cleaned both plates.  To finish things off we ordered the cookie plate. The cookie plate like my entree had a unique combination of flavors that I never had but were great surprises. We will definitely come back the next time we are in the areas.

urUaAKYkdQ9ncEQ5HWpEzg.review_text: We held an event in the Absinthe private room, and it was absolutely perfect. We had 30 people, and the management at Absinthe was wonderfully helpful via email in the weeks leading up to the event. Our guests loved the evening, the food was delicious, and the service could not have been better. The private room at Absinthe is really a nice setup - you have your own separate Hayes Street entrance, your own private bar (and dedicated bartender), and a really beautiful, relaxed ambiance. Combine this with great food (and creative cocktails), and it's really a great place for a private dinner event.

jGUdsAMkurKYZCh6l84n7w.review_text: My friend kept raving about this place and on my last night in SF I decided to appease him. We went in and I was immediately turned off by the swanky sort of atmosphere and the suits everywhere. The drinks list is a BOOK. If the bible didn't always come in pocket sized editions, it would be as big as this drink list. I opted for the cheapest cocktails ($9) and got the High Cotton. It tasted sorta like a smoky alcohol (the Pimm's) but there was also a hint of spice. What I was most surprised by was my state by the end of the drink. I was pretty loosey goosey after just that drink, enough to not have another. And let me tell you, that drink was SMALL. I can't imagine that people come here and have more than two, but there you have it. If you want to get the job done quickly and actually appreciate what you're drinking instead of shoot it down your throat, give Absinthe a try.

PHNZitGb-jgWgEzoxvSntg.review_text: Absinthe at the bar for drinks was divine! I had the French 75 & the bartender was able to talk whiskey with my date. Everyone that worked there was dressed well, the decor is red, and darkly lit, with big booths....Definitely worth stopping in.

dJtrZhOFp7TAF685qc8JjA.review_text: I hate to sound really American and uncultured--but I like big portions and cheap bills.  I think I had heard such great things about this place, that I was really disappointed when it wasn't all that.  That's not to say the food wasn't good, but as a college student I like to eat without feeling guilty about what I just paid for it. Not only that, but after eating it, I was still hungry so we headed to Mission Pie for more.

Ik8PLdmfOR7j3WaQzP1PJQ.review_text: This is a 4.5 star review.  I've been here a few times, and though it can be over-packed with people, Absinthe is a great place to grab a beverage and grab a bite.  If you don't know them for their bar, shame on you. This is the main reason I like coming here.  Get a proper freakin' cocktail and food that does not suck.  My husband is obsessed with the Holy Smokes drink. He loves smoky flavors, and the mezcal is fantastic in this drink.  Pretty much all of their cocktails are solid.  I have never had a bad cocktail here.  They have fantastic bar bites, and classic, straight forward bistro food. It can get a bit loud here, and it can get packed, but the experience hasn't disappointed yet.

1BuH5Es8d161YjfBmt6cDg.review_text: Came again, but this time for the drinks. The bartenders are a bit haughty... But, once you strike up some sort of convo with them, they melt a little bit (less cold). Their cocktails are delicious and freshly made! Get the Palermo, one of the house specialties. It's delicious! Like a Moscow Mule but more fruity. Oh, and the fries were pretty yummy, too.

u6PqJa4QFjPQzKgL-r6JEg.review_text: ***Brunch*** Have been coming here for brunch at least once a month for almost a year now - my favorite for poached eggs (with the duck.. mmm!).They have potato at the bottom instead of the english muffin - such a great idea!!  Also recommend the deviled eggs - the salmon and the caviar on top - just a great addition.  Tried their peach brown sugar pancakes today - Was not disappointed:)    ***Dinner**** Fancy place. Good ambiance. Awesome appetizers!  ***Drinks*** Very hip place to come for drinks. Nice people watching too

pDfL8xt8F8ls0-kQIG_ADg.review_text: Five years ago this week, Absinthe once again became legal to sell stateside. The herb-infused liquor was banned in countries worldwide due to the supposedly hallucinogenic effects of the wormwood, one of it's main ingredients. Celebrated the occasion by starting at this landmark Hayes Valley bar for a guys night out pub crawl. The crowd for a Thursday night was Marina-like without the attitude. Pretty loud at the bar but you could still hear. Even though it's classy looking while being a little dressy, the atmosphere was unpretentious. The dining area did look a little more "business". I liked how the hand-shaken and stirred absinthe cocktails weren't too herbal-y or menthol-ish. Who wants the taste of a ricola and coke or mouthwash and tonic? Their sacred heart ($11) made with tequila, limoncello, lime was refreshing. The sazerac ($9), a classic and essential New Orleans cocktail, was good too. Here, expertly crafted precision trumps a heavy pour. None of us had any hallucinogenic effects but I'm sure anyone after drinking several of these would suffer from a case of beer goggles. (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…)

vLqbQkcSkvbWJRB96UTAsA.review_text: Delicious food (I ordered the pork and my friend had the French Onion soup). Great wine. Fantastic service. Great ambiance. LOVE IT. Highly recommended.

4bi4fdprC-dmTqPOUnceWQ.review_text: i make a point to have dinner here whenever i'm heading to the opera or symphony. i've had dinner here both before and after the events, and the ambiance, service, food, and drinks (FRENCH 75s!) are always a delight.

SqFMB4kvBCRZtyySDsG1eg.review_text: Really delicious... but there were definitely standouts and wallflowers.  Standouts - French onion soup (you can order small or large size), roasted beet salad (with hazelnuts, arugula, fresh mozzarella, and citrus gelee), pork confit (meat cooked in its own fat? thank you very much)  Wallflowers - artic char (tasty, but nothing to write home about)  Okay so one wallflower.

LiTdGYd3g9-5TmjXXgWWug.review_text: Have been here twice. The food is O.K. but not great. I had the Marin Sun Farms Beef Short Ribs. It was good, tender and tasty but I did not find it to be exceptional. Parking in the neighborhood is tough at best. Valet parking is available for $10.

GFkOkEpTGcXxHd0-mnNVdw.review_text: Review for EXCELLENT customer service by Fiona!    I had received a gift card for my birthday about 4 months ago and when i finally remembered that i had it, it was nowhere to be found...*sigh* I'm usually not a careless person...I searched my office, junk drawer and basically tearing up my house for 2 days! Yes, OCD kicked in!  I was on the verge of desperation and planning to go thru my recycle bin like Charlie from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory frantically buying/opening chocolate bars in hopes of finding the golden ticket!  As i was about to put on the plastic gloves, I decided to send an email to Absinthe, cross my fingers and hope for the best...of course, with very low expectations as most places are not responsible for lost/stolen cards.  Well, they pulled thru and i'm overly excited and thrilled they could help me. I am now able to enjoy my Saturday with this wonderful weather and not sift thru the recycle bin after all. Whew!    Thanks Fiona...I'll see you guys soon!

A7x60kNtgbXpCjMn_BUXIQ.review_text: Really... Really?! That was it?!! That's what the hype was all about?  That's how I felt after having a lite dinner and some drinks last night.  I am thoroughly confused about why this place is so recommended, packed, and on 7x7's top 100 list.   We tried their "infamous" hotdog featured on 7x7's The Big Eat SF, one of the things you have to try before you die. And honestly... I could definitely die without trying it. Priced at $12, I thought it would be mammoth-sized or at least spilling out of its bun due to all the deliciously complementary fillings... ENK! Wrong on both levels. It was a normal sized hotdog that came with mustard, ketchup, and onions on the side. Okay... well the sausage had to at least been good right?... It was bland. Let's just say I'd choose the $1 hotdogs at Costco over Absinthe's hotdog anyday.   The fries where pretty good. They're shoe-string fries that come with 3 dipping sauces: mustard, vinegar, and this delicious orange radish sauce. (I doused my hotdog in that sauce which in my opinion barely saved the hotdog.)  On to cocktails ... contrary to popular belief, I did not enjoy the Galapagos. Maybe I'm not a huge pisco fan.. I don't know but it just smelled and tasted like tequila with 3 tapioca balls on the bottom of the cocktail class (can anyone tell me what the hell the balls were for?). So if your a tequila fan, this is the drink for you. The Ginger Roger's was yummy but yummy in a i'm-on-vacation-tanning-by-the-pool kind of way. It tasted like a mojito made with a splash of ginger ale. Not really what I had expected.   So how was my overall experience? Just like the drinks, not really what I had expected after reading all the good reviews.

i60dDRk_xPWmv6I3aXvBPQ.review_text: Excellent drinks, food, service, attention.  5 stars says it all!

Wh2Y4k8MPPvBAGoRu4WCNw.review_text: We came for the Dine About a Town Lunch menu on a weekday. I tried to make the reservation for the weekend originally via OpenTable. However, when I called in the day of (Saturday), they said they tried to call me and tell me that they don't do DAT on weekends. I never got that call or any message so it was lucky I was running late that day.   Anyways, I came the following week on a Tuesday with 2 friends for DAT, an $18.95 two course lunch. I got the GRILLED PORK TENDERLOIN which was a small portion (cut into four small pieces), which was delicious. It was nice and juicy. I didn't like the panna cotta dessert although I think my friends did. It just tasted too cheesy for me and reminded me more of cheesecake than panna cotta. But maybe that's how it's supposed to be here...  My other friend got the DAT menu with the CROQUE MONSIEUR, which was a Black Forest ham sandwich. This was more like a lunch! The portion was definitely bigger than my pork so she shared some with me. It was good! The ham and the cheese sandwich (although simple) definitely hit the spot.   My last friend ordered from the menu and got the burger, which she enjoyed. I didn't get to try any of that, unfortunately.   My overall impression of the DAT lunch menu is that the selections were not great. I mean, there were 3 entrees to choose from but the pork was so small that I would have been better off just ordering straight from the regular menu. And skip the dessert if it's the panna cotta. This lunch wasn't that worth it but I think I'll have to come in for a real meal so I can possibly re-review this place. I felt like I got a preview of what they may have to offer but I need to try some of the other things!   One last note though... Our server was a bit too persistent with our orders. For example, she asked if we wanted anything from the bar and suggested some drinks. We said no thank you. She went on to suggest (it felt like) 10 other drinks. No thank you. We were having lunch in between class and really didn't want a drink! We already said we wanted water only. That should be enough.

hEjhuWxQwDvP_B8yeCjDYg.review_text: Brunch @ Absinthe .... just typing that makes me hungry. A great variety of dishes prepared in a quality manner. Where else can you get a duck egg breakfast sandwich? Fantastic. The traditional 2 eggs/sausage/potatoes/toast type dishes are great & creative as well. They bring the mimosa to a whole new level with super creative combination's ... a must have with brunch. ITSA wow brunch joint, with great service.

0Fx75JBkz6XpcPOU8lfY4A.review_text: Expensive but well-laid out and quiet. Definitely a grown & sexy place with full bar service that's neatly away from the business of San Fran.  Only had appetizers and they we're good but nothing spectacular beyond other SF eateries.  Also, Im not sure if they have music other nights but there wasn't anything playing when I was there, not even jazz :-/

r01zHizMGnxS00AqXyJb8Q.review_text: Brilliantly executed brunch complimented by their renowned list of creative cocktails leaving nothing left to be desired.  Food-  Absolutely superb.  We started with deviled eggs and a plate of fresh fruit.  The deviled eggs were as good as I have ever had it.  Rich, creamy perfectly flavored with the caviar on top.   The fruit plate had fresh strawberries, asian pear, passion fruit, kiwi and a cup of creme fraiche. I went for their pretzel breakfast sandwich with bacon and soft duck egg with a side of salad.  Sandwich was great and the side salad had the freshest, crunchiest, tastiest butter lettuce I have had in a long while. For desert I went for the vanilla creme brulee that was also as good as I ever had.  Went 'traditional' with the cocktail: spicy bloody mary.  This is probably the only food item that I can say "i've had better elsewhere".  Too thin and definitely inferior to that of Foreign Cinema.  Service- As expected from a fancy restaurant.  Nothing to complain about and did not have to ask for our glasses to be refilled.  Ambiance- Located at the heart of Hayes Valley it was amusing to see a mixed crowd.  The majority are obviously well dressed wealthy people but there are a couple tables with t-shirt wearing funky young folks.  It's fancy without being stuck up.  Price- Not a cheap price for sure; but for $35 per person we felt like it was a good price considering we ate really well.  That covers the cocktail, 2 starters to share by 4 people, entrees and 2 desert.

viwKpVVaOhWur77Sh4L4cw.review_text: Sunday Brunch Review  I really want to give this place 5 stars, but the service sucked! We were able to get seated right away for a table of 4, but it took over 30 minutes for our food to show up at the table. The food took so long to come that my friend missed her BART train. They were running low on teacup apparently so we got soup bowls for our drinks.   The omelet was delicious and fluffy! There was a ton of mushrooms and just the right amount of cheese that it didn't over power the other components. The plate comes with these amazing potatoes. I'm not sure what the potatoes are called, but they were similar to chunky homestyle fries. They were crisp on the outside and very flavorful. I love their generous use of herbs here.   Great decor with big cushy chairs. The only thing that freaked me out was the absinthe green monster that was painted into all of their murals. It was so lifelike that every time i turned to the left to speak/listen to my friend, he would catch my eye, and I would get startled.

2TN-jjYg98_cPNft8OJHCw.review_text: The girls and I were here last night to celebrate my friend Michele K.'s birthday! We also had tickets to see Wicked at the Orpheum so we wanted to be close by.  They sat us in the super cute booth close to the back of the restaurant.    We ordered the flatbread, french onion soup to start.  The soup was delicious!  I was in the mood for a hamburger so I ordered just that and so did two of my other girlfriends. The bday girl ordered the halibut and Julie K. ordered the lamb shanks.    My burger was delicious and cooked to perfection!  They also added mushrooms and onions as I requested.  For dessert we had the chocolate pot de creme and some cheese.  They brought out one of the desserts with Happy Birthday spelled out on the plate and a single candle.  It was a great way to top off our dinner.  I will definitely dine here again!  The service was great!  Parking is difficult but you can valet your car.  I forgot how much valet was but I think we paid no more than $10.

CO82sC1pmHrRs_JXW96FAg.review_text: I called for a post-opera dinner reservation here on Saturday, and amazingly got in! Open table is a bit of a bitch and wouldn't give me a slot.  Since we were late night, we only got the bar menu, but this was not a bad thing! We ordered the soft pretzels with cheese dipping sauce...and fought over the last bite. Get them, you won't regret it. And we split the burger. THE burger! We fancied it up with caramelized onions (in red wine), Gruyere cheese, and mushrooms. Cooked medium rare, it is to die for. No need for ketchup here!  Absinthe is known for their cocktails, and has a very extensive and detailed menu. Classic, revitalized, signature, whatever, get one! G. had the Galapagos, delish...I'm a idiot and had a glass of red wine, but next time..Cocktails!

qx1-YaJ5bNTg6CV6X3rmGg.review_text: Local. Organic. Super tasty. Highly recommended. Great service too.

juCytqKd0zBCneE8I_yK2w.review_text: Great Moroccan Meatballs. Dinner was wonderful, BUT THEN dessert... tried the apricot crumble with potato Ice Cream! In the heat of summer potato ice cream? It was inedible. Avoid this item - eat everything else

6nP89hUq3NM0VVYEdjyX3A.review_text: Our favorite place in Hayes Valley!  my partner and I have been here a couple of times and they are always consistent with their great service and amazing food.  Even when we just stop by without making a reservation.  Their wine selection is great, every bottle of wine we have had has been delicious.   The Masami Farms Pork Osso Buco and the Market Selection of Black Angus Beef are our favorites.  I'm a cheese lover and they have a very tasty selection of domestic and imported ones.  We are going back and back again!....oh, and they also own Arlequin, next door, the best cobb salad in San Francisco!

q5-6Y521ZkrLNfWUoPzUuw.review_text: We stopped in for 2 rounds of drinks after dinner at a French restaurant in Castro.  I had the Ginger Rodgers and a dark beer on tap.  My wife had a French 75.  Drinks were all excellent.  Side note - we orders the Beecher's Flagship cheese - a cheese from Seattle.  My wife and I lived in Seattle and this was our favorite cheese.  They brought a different cheese and argued with us that it was indeed Flagship (which we know for a fact is not).  They did take it off the bill, but waitress was a little too sassy about it. :)

G-BqlQjScP-WHAY2QtNBZQ.review_text: A truly authentic high class French cafe brasserie, with drink and food flavors you can't often find outside of Paris. Their salads and small plates and oysters and Croque Monsier or French Onion soup are amazing. But really, my heart always beats for one thing when I go there. They also have the BEST BURGER EVER. Grass fed beef (yes, in this instance you can definitely taste the difference), perfect buttered roll, and options of Gruyere or muenster cheese, fried egg, etc.  I enjoy the fact that not only do they offer fantastic whisky, rye and bourbon, they also offer Absinthe, and even Pastisse and Ricard in the traditional Parisian fashion. I drank Pastisse every night that I was in Paris and tend to miss it here in the States unless I just serve it at home. Service is impeccable, however prices are a bit high and it is incredibly trendy so it can get pretentious and overly packed in the evenings and weekends.  Luckily I have the opportunity to take occasional lunch breaks with the office folk every now and then, and the clientele and elbow room can be much more palatable during the day!

pSfeno8ExPHvn8NXca5sfA.review_text: Tasty Tasty Tasty!  We came for a birthday dinner and I could not have been more delighted. I had been wanting to try this place and I was not let down. I nibbled and tried a bit of everyone's food but I really loved the potato crusted fish!! The presentation was unique and the fish was super moist and ..did I say tasty?  Parking can be troublesome but just keep circling!  SPICY FRIED CHICKPEAS berbere spice, parsley SPICY PORK MEATBALLS San Marzano tomatoes, grana padano POTATO-CRUSTED ARCTIC CHAR Little Gem lettuce salad,   blue lake beans, red radish, Niçoise olives LIBERTY FARMS DUCK BREAST ginger-soy marinated, peanuts,   fried black rice, Napa cabbage salad, citrus-soy duck jus

SyranwUdmsEdNT_orKP0Zw.review_text: A lounge with a very glitzy and distinct look, not for your average saturday night crowd. Huge selection of drinks, the bar menu could easily double for a small book. Keep a close eye for the number of drinks you have or pay by the drink, the drinks are not cheap and getting out of hand could run up a tab well over 100 dollars.   We didn't eat, as we saw no one else doing so (...not a good sign). Sat at the bar drinking next to older professionals and watched the very experienced bar tenders. All in all just a very glitzy bar with an incredible selection, who's hefty prices will drive you away from trying anything unknown.

VgtlJNoaXZNDJ_NhmnFyRQ.review_text: I recently enjoyed a great (but super expensive) meal at Absinthe on a Friday night. The food and cocktails were great, but the service was not up to snuff. We waited a long time between courses, our drinks were brought out at odd times (I finished my coffee long before our dessert made it to the table) and the wait staff was constantly changing throughout the meal. The service needs to improve to match the stellar food and the steep prices, but still a solid and pleasant place to enjoy a nice meal in the hood.

RCKdmKDZRd-RovZVtNSCLA.review_text: Spanish Coffee: it gets lit on fire!

45DhrSxqQRUDdnxlECPDYQ.review_text: This place is phenomenal.  Impeccable service, tremendous food, and a great ambiance.  It does not get any better.  We recently had a private party there and even though some people showed up late, the waiters were on the ball with every detail.  They customized a prix-fixe menu for us and even printed them up with my girlfriend's name on them.    The strawberry gazpacho was off the hook, a perfect appetizer mixing sweet, sour and crisp all in one bowl of delicious chilled soup.  This place is known for their drinks and they didn't disappoint.  They have an amazing selection of absinthe (no surprise there) and their bartenders are really knowledgeable.  After having a straight absinthe we tried the Sacred Heart cocktail, the perfect mix of tangy and strong.    The pork was amazing.  It was cured perfectly, and it was so tender it just fell apart on the plate.  It almost tasted like it was cured like pastrami or corned beef.  And finally the chocolate mousse!  This rich and creamy dessert was amazing, but so rich that I couldn't finish it.    As if it wasn't obvious enough, I think this place is great, and I would recommend it for any occasion, even just a night out at the bar.

D96pOQ39yzgoJWObBZ9Wzg.review_text: How you have taunted me with your green sign and promises of licorice flavored liquid. Hehe, my boyfriend and I didn't try any absinthe today (seeing as how some of the stuff they offer we already have at home!) but we did enjoy the cuisine!  A recap of the wonderful meal (and yes, just two of us ate all this...I think we'll pay for this with bigger butts and thighs)  1) Spicy fried chickpeas: Think of this as a fresh version of your favorite wasabi pea snacks. Except with the wasabi or peas, and instead you have crispy, spicy chickpeas that leave flavor lingering on your tongue and lips. Mm.  2) Oyster shots: Large oysters in the half shell with shots of Bloody Mary mix. Mmm. You couldn't really taste the oysters and lemon anymore, but these shots were zesty!   3) French fries: Comes in a large silver cone/cup, with three different dipping sauces (malt vinegar, dijon mustard, and rouille). The fries were both crispy, stringy, and thin - good! And salted just right. I couldn't stop eating them.   4) Escargots - Served hot and buttery, with lemon, and with toasted bread triangles. The tongs and skewers are cute and make eating them less messy!  5) Country pate - The pate is made of pork, not goose (sadness!) and has a rather sweet flavor to it. If you like lighter, sweeter pate, this is ideal for you, but my boyfriend and I like the heavier, fattier goose or savory pork pates, so we didn't enjoy this dish as much. Came with toasted bread triangles as well, mini pickles, and mustard.  6) Beef cheeks - The meat was SO tender and fell apart. Potatoes were creamy!  7) Grilled scallops - A little heavy on the herb crust, but the scallops were tender, and the winter squash puree was SO GOOD! I kept scooping it up with my spoon and licking it. Mmm.  8) Mushroom flatbread - I wasn't a fan of this, the whole thing tasted a bit..gamey?? I think it was the goat cheese..and I normally do not like goat cheese..  The service was okay, our waiter was fairly quiet and didn't interact with us as much as we're used to other waiters, but overall, a very very pleasant and fun meal!

Lu8y2ayxVlAzuJEVfVcH4w.review_text: I could have sworn I reviewed the Absinthe Brasserie and Bar. It was near and dear to my heart at many of Happy Hour Celebrations and Lunches over the years of working in the Hayes Valley area.  While I am not a fan of Gin, Absinthe inroduced me to cocktails I couldn't say no to. The 21 Hayes is Gin, cucumber, Pimm's, lemon, sugar, cucumber slice, onion and splendid. The Corpse Reviver #2 is Gin, Cointreau, Lillet Blanc, absinthe, lemon, lemon twist and introduced me to Absinthe cocktails.   While enjoying cocktails at the bar, I highly recommend trying the cheese plates - you can mix and match your picks in 3 or 5 selections. They also have oysters, which I am a huge fan of - but have yet to try here.   The french fries are good as a snack, but the Absinthe Burger is the real deal. Start with the Angus Burger and add on some smoked gouda, sautéed mushrooms, gruyère or even a fried egg. The burger is not your average patty, so be prepared or split for a great mini meal.   I'll have to come bring my guy here one day, he loves the word Brasserie, Gin cocktails, Oysters, Cheese Plates, French Fries and Really Tasty Burgers too.

7ziWZULyiZv2TesYNMFf4g.review_text: Nice bar. Nice ambiance. Got the burger w caramelized onions, mushrooms and fried egg.  Egg was perfect with runny yolk that popped as I held onto my burger for a big bite. Burger was perfectly med, juicy and red! Fries were okay, they were skinny fries.  Huge drink menu. Tried "sacred heart" which tasted like licorice...hmm not to my liking.. Also had some lemony cocktails. Strong cocktails, indeed. I was wobbling walking out of the restaurant.  Meatballs were yum and garlic pretzels were okay.  Parking can be tough around this neighborhood. Fun place!

UNesCmi0Za_Ce1xR_FcYXg.review_text: Ordered the Absinthe burger which was an average burger.. I give it a solid 3. My bf however, ordered the coq au vin which was PHENOMENAL. Everything from the tender chicken, perfectly seasoned gravy, to the toast was perfect! Solid 5! The food came out really quickly too which was a plus since we were super hungry! I was however annoyed with the dish guy who picked up my fork and spoon from my plate rather than taking the whole plate itself. The sauce spilled all over my pants and shoe.. He noticed but decided to walk away instead.. At least our waitress was extremely friendly.

P2fXcmsU_vrs4zB2IfsHnQ.review_text: My sister brought me here for my birthday dinner. As she said, this place is a "Grown people restaurant." LOL. The atmosphere is cool but chill. Nothing to fancy or too trendy. Just a cool spot to dine with good people and food. Our waiter (I forgot here name--sorry)...was very nice and very attentive. She recommended wines that would go with our meals and made sure we had everything we needed. My sister chose the local sole. I tried a piece and it was flavorful and moist. I chose one of their popular dishes, the Pork Osso Buco. Delicous. The meat just fell off the bone. It came with root vegetables. A hearty meal. I ate almost all of it. For dessert, we had the strawberry tarragon pavlova. Don't know what that is? Neither did we. We ate. We loved it. Very flavorful and not too sweet. What a wonderful place. A great place to get full. LOVE.

Bzbna6x9SSYXd3RZem7Lbg.review_text: When I used to live in Hayes Valley this was always a safe go to spot.  Why you may ask?  The drinks and food always deliver.  So when a friend of mine and I decided it was time to grab a drink and some appetizers I suggested Absinthe.    We walked in and the place was crowded, but we were seated right away and the decor was just as I remembered it - very cute, french and nice lighting!!  We ordered drinks - I had my signature drink - a dirty martini (the dirtier the better is how I like em) and the drink was perfectly shaken!  My friend had the house Cab which was so smooth and also a perfect choice when chatting the night away.  When it came to dinner I chose a salad with white anchovies which was outstanding and some shoestring fries to share with the most delicious dipping sauces (a mustard, spicy mayo and vinegar).  My friend had the french onion soup which she couldn't stop raving about - she said it was the best she had ever had!  I loved my salad and the fries - what is not to love!!    Absinthe still has it in my book - this is a great spot to start or end a night and it was the perfect place to have a light meal and some great beverages!  I miss great cocktails and this place reminded me how special a well made cocktail truly is!

-zuV9Du1HFHaQ6GnVyGWsQ.review_text: Every time I go here I have a good meal.  The food is always consistently good.  Extra points given to them for the superb meal that they always make off the menu for my vegan friend.

2CQ89eKJF7zxgCH1T0nupg.review_text: It's one of those places that if you aren't stuffy or hoity-toity yourself it could be intimidating. Good thing I am none of those things and just don't give a fuck. Upper-middle class crowd, but I come in jeans and tee to meet my dad for dinner any way.   Great service, waiters working for their tips, and managers picking up any slack. They got us in and out fairly quickly; even though there's an annoyingly huge line of onlookers without reservations watching you eat, waiting to dine themselves.  Absinthe seems like one of those places that is so into being 'of the moment' that their food sucks or lacks love... not the case. I ordered stuffed chicken breast with vegetables. I honestly expected it to be just so-so; something I pick at and probably don't finish. But I cleaned the plate!   I have this problem with these pseudo fancy restaurants in San Francisco that they either over or under season their food. Sometimes I bite into my asparagus and think, "did they taste this when they made it? Or go straight from recipe?"  Moist chicken, tasty brussels sprouts, and enough on my plate that I can finish all of it and then take off walking quickly without getting sick.  Full bar + Easy walk-to location + Good food + good service = one of the better restaurants to impress your hot new date.

dJnqnQ4MgQX0NmjHEysvoQ.review_text: Probably one of my most favorite dining experiences to date. It's been months and I still have vivid memories of the meal at Absinthe. Amazeballs!!!   A colleague and I decided to be adventurous after a long day at a conference/training Fortunately, we share an appreciation for classy ambiance and delicious food. Absinthe provided both. We made rezzies via OpenTable the night before and scored a rezzie at 7:30pm. Great, diverse crowd upon arrival - the ambiance, food, service created the perfect experience.   Let's talk food...  Cauliflower Soup. SO good. I could've eaten two bowls of just this and I would have been happy. Velvety, piping hot, and topped with brioche croutons. I'll need another bowl of this when I return.   Beef Tartare. Perfection. The "accroutements" of green apple, red onion, cornichons, and quail egg yolk created a festival of flavors when paired with the crostini.  Deliciously indulgent.   Local Sole. The fish was cooked perfectly - moist and juicy - and accompanied by sun dried tomatoes, beans, brussel sprouts, and braised artichokes with a light lemon-based sauce. So freshing and hearty at the same time.   Ice Cream. We opted for a trio of cinnamon, browned butter, and vanilla. Together, the flavors blended well although my colleague and I agreed that the browned butter was the standout.   If I had to choose a last meal, this would be it. I can't wait to go back.

A7FNqfL30IjpcQ6fQffoOQ.review_text: F%$& this place!!! If you want to go somewhere that ignores you if you are not wearing a suit, go here! If you want to be given lackluster service, drinks and food be cause they think you don't have money, go here. The crime perpetrated by my 2 friends and I? We were wearing jeans and casual wear, not evening attire reserved for a night at the opera. There are too many great restaurants in SF for that snobby bull. Go elsewhere kids if you want great drinks and food. The bartenders did not come back to ask if we wanted food. The tall guy sans hair in a suit barely greeted us or looked at us because he did not want to serve us. What kind of restaurant is that? If you want a higher caliber of service without being judged for not wearing your power suit go to Alembic.

NK5nADZUYGor1Bknp1CrLw.review_text: I feel like an asshole for giving this place a 3 star rating... this is a yelp favorite!! Well, hear me out. I waited until I've tried both dinner and brunch menus to write the review and I wish I had half star options because the brunch was 3 stars and dinner was 4 stars. Maybe my expectation was too high from the anticipation, but I was so underwhelmed for the brunch menu.   French onion soup: good, but the french onion soup at chez maman is better  Croque Monsieur: not sure what I missed, but it was very ordinary, even when soaked in my favorite thing in the world...runny egg yolk!  Shrimp salad roll: The description sounded amazing. Tobasco aioli, avocados and malt vinegar chips. I tasted no tobasco, came with no avocados and it was just shrimp with mayo in stale bread. The chips were not vinegary at all. What a waste of money (sad face)  Fries: skinny fries with winning aiolis.   Spicy pork meatballs: moist and flavorful  Coq au vin: this chicken is out of control. I'm pretty sure if I can cook chicken like this, I would be married by now.   Oh I can't forget about the booze. They are fancy pants when it comes to cocktails and it comes with a very extensive wine list. Service was great. My coffee cup was refilled about 5 times. Will come back for dinner again!

Et83fPQu3jbYeEG_t8wHig.review_text: Review is for brunch only.  It was good, but it wasn't OMG GREAT.  I judge a lot of brunch places on their lattes.  What's a brunch without a good, hot savory latte?  My soy latte came out in a huge bowl cup and it was steamy hot, but it just wasn't that satisfying.  Not enough espresso punch to it. I'd much rather head over to Blue Bottle around the corner.  I had the ricotta stuffed french toast.  It sounded awesome.  The portion was huge with 4 very thick slices of toast and berries on the side.  The first slice was good, but not melt in your mouth good.  Anything after was just OK and it became real repetitive.  It was also quite heavy.  Great concept and presentation though, so I give them props there.  My bf had the wild mushroom something omelet.  There was a TON of cheese which masked the mushroom flavor and the eggs weren't amazing fluffy or anything.  He did order a side of the Benton's bacon which was lightly covered in maple syrup which I found very delicious.  Our friend had the fried green tomatoes.  I didn't try any of it but she seemed pretty pleased and her plate was clean afterwards.  Good ambiance, a lot of space, good food, but not mouth watering excellence.  Sure I'd go back again.  Hayes Valley is pretty fun.

Ccp2WIoquFyn3kMNqN93JQ.review_text: This place was sooo good! I had the wild Mushroom omlette and it was very tasty! I also had the peach champagne which was good as well.  The ambiance was amazing. It has a bar as well. Next time I will go and try the French Onion soup that everyone seems to rave about here on yelp!

dbhVJUFLbVD2JoUo2L7dOw.review_text: Hands down the best meal I have had in San Francisco. My boyfriend and I ordered two different types of steak and it was to die for. The service was excellent and our waiter even gave us a free espresso at the end. Our favorite spot for special occasions.

gdTAebkameev_DQq_NCZzw.review_text: Came here last night before catching Aziz An Sari over at the Davies Symphony Hall. Seems like this is the spot everyone goes to grab dinner and drinks before a show at the ballet, the symphony hall, or the sf jazz center soooo beware of crowds!  The bar area seemed to fill up real quickly but luckily I made a reservation and we were seated immediately.  I would highly recommend the snacks, appetizers and drinks!  Definitely go for the garlic pretzels! Sooo garlicky and the cheese dip is a perfect complement to not overpowering at all. I would highly recommend the beef tartare as well. At some other places, the beef tartare is too mustardy for me but this was just right!  Any of the drinks are strong and taste delicious so you can't go wrong here. Again the drinks are pretty strong, just the way I like it :)  As for the entrees, I had the monkfish and it was done perfectly but my bf and I felt that the menu for entrees was too simple? I mean it was good but again I think its worth it more for the snacks and drinks here.  Definitely coming back for those pretzels!

fou9pya19z4NWWAGZslxXA.review_text: Great place for brunch in Hayes Valley. Nice up-scale French brassiere style decor. We went with a large group and were well taken care of by the friendly staff.   I suggest ordering the souffle pancakes. While more pancake than souffle, they're super tasty with tons of blueberries and bananas. Paired with a champagne cocktail...now that's a decadent way to start your Sunday.  Highly recommended!

Eql29rFLwZqvXbWMOuLloA.review_text: Absinthe is all that.  The staff is friendly, the cocktail menu is a thing of wonder and delight, and the food is tremendous.  Beautiful ingredients, prepared imaginatively and skillfully.  Richly flavorful.  I'd never had beef cheeks before, but having watched too much Travel Channel lately, I wanted to take the plunge.  Verdict: I'm still swooning.  Everything that came to the table was delicious.  Unlike many other SF restaurants where culture seems to demand that all the diners shout at each other all night, the noise level in Absinthe was appropriate for adults who are out to enjoy a tremendous meal.  Go, you will not be disappointed.

FtGEpYCF6DYwiBL4zFMfRA.review_text: Came here a couple of months ago on a date. I remember them having an EXCELLENT craft cocktail list. It was a shame that I am both a lightweight and had to drive back to the East Bay that night, otherwise I would have partaken.  The food was well-executed as well, if a bit on the salty side. The portions were much bigger than I expected though, so that made up for it.  I think I may have to revisit Absinthe soon to refresh my flavor memory and stay with a friend in the area. :)

J1-B5TtWM5CCKlTL_NG7vw.review_text: Setting:  Dinner with two coworkers,  Wednesday night at 930, had a reservation.  Seated immediately.  The GOOD: 1.  Soft Garlic Pretzels - 10/10, melted in our mouths!  We talked about them the entire meal. 2.  Cheese Plate (3) - The waiter recommended Humboldt Fog, MT Tam, and Fromage Demeaux.  All three were amazing! 3.  Potato mushroom leek soup - filling, perfect amount of mushroom flavor without overpowering.   4.  Coq Au Vin - perfectly cooked, we were dipping bread in the sauce after the chicken was finished. 5.  Potato-crusted Arctic Char - I was skittish about this, but once we started eating it, we couldn't stop.  The potato top had the perfect level of crispness while the fish was perfectly flaky. 6.  Winter Squash Cake - The waitier recommended this, and I was apprehensive about a dessert with "Squash " in the title.  I was proven wrong, it was excellent.  The OK: 1.  Spicy fried Chickpeas - Honestly, these were actually good, but when we had to compare them to the rest of the meal, they couldn't hold up. 2.  Meyer Lemon Tart - Again, a decent dish but it just didn't wow us like the others.  The BAD: 1.  One of only two meals I ate in SF (over a 5 month period) where I had nothing to put here.    Overall, absolutely great meal, and a breath of fresh air after underwhelming meals (at least for the money spent) at Fleur de Lys and Gary Danko.

lLfcbYGTeVxQN5Ig0ompJg.review_text: Been wanting to come here for a while, but never got the chance.  Finally I dragged a friend to the ballet and decided it was a great opportunity to have dinner here before the show.  I grew up in a French restaurant so I love French food.  To my surprise, the roasted bratwurst was really good.  We randomly ordered it cuz we wanted to try something different.  It was nice and rich and tasted great with the bread.  My filet was also very good.  Cooked nicely and came with asparagus and whipped potatoes.  All very tasty.  The other dishes we ordered were the oysters, ceasar salad and beef tartare.  I remember the salad and tartare needing more seasoning, but other than that I had a good meal.  Overall, half of what we ordered was delicious and half of it was okay.  I'd come again to try some other dishes.

aSkpHhKpY-NZVjlY-7uGTA.review_text: Can here on a whim for a late night dinner. I must say it wasnt what I expected. I was expecting more of a bar by the name of the place but the food was amazing. We started with 2 types of oysters that were super fresh(beau soleil and kumomoto) and Popcorn. Not just any popcorn, but parmesan and garlic popcorn! Who could turn that down? I wasnt that hungry so I had a grilled cheese with roasted peppers that didnt disappoint. Needless to say everytime I come to the city I will be stopping by this spot.

hvjhcPOG8zuqqLOohDKBmA.review_text: We came here for brunch on a Sunday and the wait was about 20 minutes. Not bad for a brunch in SF!    Our orders were promptly taken after shortly getting seated. I ordered the butternut squash pancake and my boyfriend ordered the burger. My pancake was good, sweet cinnamon taste with fluffy texture. I could not taste much of the squash.    That burger, that Absinthe burger was amazing. I had a bite of that burger and I wanted to switch plates. Unfortunately, my boyfriend devoured every morsel within five minutes.     Service was great and the price of plates were about 15 dollars on average.  Next time, I am getting a burger all to myself!

B856VSGCvHAB-mil7JVprA.review_text: I strongly recommend making reservations if you want to sit in the quieter part of the restuarant. It is super interesting, how the place is almost divided into three sections. The super loud and hustling bar section filled with beer fragances, the medium noised bistro sounding resturant seating section, and the quiet, more romantic dim lighting section.   We ordered:  *Snacks Soft Garlic Pretzels $8 (2 od 5) - was ok. I read other reviewers and they were disappointed. I guess I was pretty disappointed too. Garlic wasn't in baked in the pretzel. Just came out as finger sized pretzels. Nothing special other than it came with small tub of rich melted butter mashed with some garlic. And the garlic wasn't even that strong. I wouldn't recommend it. Try something else. *Masami Farms Pork Osso Buco $27 (4 of 5) served with white bean stew, baby root vegetables, citrus gremolata, pork jus - was good. The pork meat fell off bone. I liked the tiny texture and taste details on the plate. There was a crunchy sprinkle of something that blended very well with the soft pork pieces. The white bean stew was soft, and also complimented the pork very well. I thought this dish was well-executed. Green garlic mash *10oz Rib Eye Steak $35 (3 of 5) served with green garlic-whipped potatoes, grilled asparagus, green peppercorn jus - Steak good but not a wow. The cut was thin, would have been nicer if it was thicker. Mash potato was made from green garlic and gave it a wonderful color. Again, plating was very pretty.  *Opera Cake $10 (4 of 5) espresso custard, chocolate ganache, almond jocande cake, orange - was superb. Layers of delicate flavors. Every layer had a different flavor and texture.  *Cinnamon ice cream (free because it was birthday celebration) (2.5 of 5) -  was fresh and strong. Like eating a Big Red Stick of Gum. Creative but cinnamon is not my favorite.  Overall, I give a thumbs up to the main entrees and dessert. The pretzel listed on the 7X7 2012 Big Eat should be removed from the list. And make sure you have time to look for parking. It took me 20 minutes to find parking.

FN9GBf0qq5Bd2kDnIBh90w.review_text: Not my favorite by any means. the ambiance is cool and dark, making you feel like you're in some old saloon or something.  what really doesn't shine for me here is the crowd (on random Thurs nights it's impossible to even stand in the bar area) and the food wasn't that good (especially not for the price)  we ordered the asparagus, ceviche, and a few other dishes. they all tasted OK. and that's just it... only OK.

xfbSQGUaUAlkQ_v-ZCR09A.review_text: One of my favorite spots when my boyfriend was living in Hayes Valley.  Super friendly service, great ambiance (nice for dates), and awesome drinks.  I've been here for brunch, dinner & drinks/appetizers, and here are my favorites:  Brunch:  - Deviled Eggs - best deviled eggs I've ever had in my life. - Duck Confit Ragout - what other people WISHED they had ordered. Get it. You won't regret.  Drinks/Appetizers:  - Soft Garlic Pretzels - warm (REALLY WARM), chewy, pretzels w/cheese dipping - Parmesan-Garlic Popcorn - warm, greasy & addicting - Spicy fried chickpeas - there's a bit of heat in these  I like the bloody Mary (virgin), but I tasted my friend's Ginger Rogers, and I could barely taste the alcohol (that's a sign of a good drink, to me).  Dinner:   I've had the lamb & steak here & would highly recommend both. Consider yourself warned, however, that the portions are ginormous & very heavy, so make sure you are starving before you get dinner here.  Desert:  Chocolate pot de creme is the only way to go :0)

tj2GPWuaJsTbR2YwP6Yd7Q.review_text: This is usually my preferred spot for dining prior to a performance at Davies or War Memorial.  I've been coming here for quite a number of years and was looking forward to sampling the menu from the new chef.  On this most recent visit, I ordered the gazpacho to start while my friend ordered the duck leg.  The starters were well portioned.  The soup, which seemed to be rather popular that night, was not what I was used to.  It is basically tomato soup with some diced avocado, a fried squash squash blossom and drops of balsamic vinegar.  I was worried that the soup would be too acidic but when eaten with the avocado and sweet vinegar, the combination was delicious and balanced.  A situation where the sum was greater than its parts.  My friend really enjoyed the confit of duck.  For the main course, I ordered the halibut while my dining companion ordered the cannelloni.  Okay, so this is the reason for the less than five star rating.  The portions were TINY, as in appetizer-sized portions.  The halibut could not have been more an 3 ounces and came with 3 or 4 small shrimp and 4 tiny mussels.   Seriously, where's the rest of the fish?  For being one of the most expensive items on the menu for and for being the reason why our entrees were taking so long to be served, I expected so much more.  The only time I've seen portions of this size is when it is part of a 5+ course meal.  Aside from being slightly salty, I did enjoy this dish and just wished there had been more of it.  The cannelloni were on the small size as well and my friend did not enjoy them at all - taste, texture or  flavor.    To end our meal we decided to order a selection of three cheeses - Humboldt Fog, Flagship and the Ossau Iraty.  The servings of each cheese was sizable and the cheeses were delicious!  It came with a basket of walnut bread.  The waiter was kind enough to wrap up what we could not finish as he knew we really enjoyed these cheeses.  A snack at intermission, perhaps?  The staff here are very accustomed to the performance crowd and getting people seated and served in plenty of time to make curtain time.  Service is very efficient and professional.  The restaurant is dark and feels cozy even though seating is spread out amongst several rooms.  A solid choice with good food and service.

OcFOBEDwGMdeTrJseGpcWA.review_text: Cocktails and Lamb were great.  Service could have been better as our waitress rarely came by out table.  I believe the only thing she did was take our order and drop off our check.  The rest of the staff spent more time delivering our food, re-filling our drinks, etc.  Food was great though

39eSgXJRZwdWHs0IDAtzhQ.review_text: Absolutely wonderful restaurant!  Sumptuous french food, with attentive but invisible staff.  A perfect quiet, dark place to talk.

7sBZaqo57glRsFlWwuXnaA.review_text: The whole, "I'm on Hayes Street having brunch", is such a cool message.  Love Hayes street!  The shopping, the restaurants, the people.....very very hip.  This french brasserie probably had the BEST latte I've ever had in my life!  It was served in a soup bowl.  Goodness!  I was "bowled over".... LOL  The scene, the food, the service....everything was delightful.  The next time I'm in San Francisco..... I'm definately going there.

YwlywryPFBD-ZAJFqwXkdA.review_text: Cocktails are the best in the world and the cuisine lives up to the cocktails. Very accommodating to theater patrons.

becChstN1Nelt61S8j8exQ.review_text: Didn't like it the first time I went years ago. Glad I gave it a second chance. Quite honestly the best French onion soup on the planet!  Of all the crazy things to get here...the burger...was a religious experience. Let me tell you about the home made pickle the stabbed on top of the burger. I can't describe it other than it's the best pickle I have ever eaten... ever. What an amazing dining experience.

UqkrP5O2ToeXRcYbp7okIA.review_text: Didn't know what I was getting into when I walked into Absinthe. Looked around and felt chic, sexy, sultry decor all around. The walls are a dark red color, which makes this place feel very bold and sexy. It reminded me of being in a bar in Boston or New York... I already knew I was going to love this place before I looked at the menu.   We arrived a little early, so the three of us ordered cocktails at the bar, I tried the Chuauca, which tasted just like a shot of Apricot Liqueur chilled over ice up.. and my friends ordered one of the drink specials of the night with Absinthe. I tried Absinthe for the first time and -- I'm not sure if I'm a fan..it tastes similar to black licorice, but not as good.. ;-)   Once we were seated, the service was incredible! We each ordered something different--the Market Vegetable Plate, the Arctic Char, and the Sole. The Someliar came over and helped a couple of us figure out the perfect wine specifically to match each of our dishes. It was very nice. We finished off our meal with the Butternut Squash Cake-- which was similar to carrot cake but even better and not as sweet! I loved it. Absinthe is a classy joint. I really love this place.. one of my favorite places in SF for sure!

sbfyu-6A37yS2mb2QcnZcA.review_text: Our party of six was seated immediately, and a very attentive but not intrusive waiter asked if we had concert reservations (we did). He assured us that there would be plenty of time to make the 8 PM curtain.  Absinthe has very extensive cocktail and wine menus from which we ordered pre-dinner drinks. Excellent. Three of our party had the coq au vin, one bistro steak, and two pork loin orders followed a round of salads. The coq au vin amazed all three diners, and the other dishes were also excellent.  A bit noisy but convenient location near Civic Center is a definite plus. We shall return.

KVv0koe_WKZSVJoVthobMA.review_text: Let me just start off by saying that of the 1200+ reviews, I'll try to make mine as detailed with tips as possible. I'm only going to be raving about how awesome and tasty and amazingly great service this place was, so let's just get to the facts.  #1 - MAKE A RESERVATION (use opentable, it's so easy). We made a reservation for 5pm, and as soon as we arrived, we were seated promptly at 5pm. Those with reservations also get seated in the better areas (less noise, more cozy and intimate). Usually (as many will note) that the wait here is pretty long. So don't forget to make a reservation!  #2 - Go with a half glass of wine. There's so many to choose from... this is an AWESOME way to get to try a ton of their wines. And it keeps the bill low, too.  #3 - Start with the spicy fried chickpeas and flatbread. OMG melt in your mouthe gooey ooey amazing sensations.  The flatbread for sure is a MUST HAVE.  #4 - ORDER the French Onion Soup. I guarantee you this is the best french onion soup you'll ever have. The broth was perfect, the cheese amount was just right... I didn't feel like I was going to get a heart attack after, either, like I normally do with other french onions.  #5 - The burger is OK - tempting because of the price, but I wouldn't recommend it as the best dish ever. And if you do order it, skip the caramelized onions. I would DEFINITELY add sauteed mushrooms if you like mushrooms, those were delish.  Those are my 5 quick tips. I'm sure you'll enjoy as much as I did! I plan to come back for sure to try the Duck Confit, Escargot, and Pan seared scallops.... :-)

nokGt37dRsJHnux52UtwYg.review_text: Great for brunch, lunch, dinner, or just a drink.  I really can't give them enough stars.   Hours will drift by as you sit outside at their sidewalk bistro tables on a sunny day enjoying wine and cheese  About the food... the following are winners: Brioche French Toast Duck-confit Ragout Croque Monsieur Burger French onion soup Duck-confit & chicory salad Fries Scallops Burrata Spring onion risotto etc...  Highly recommended.  If you haven't been yet, it's time.

L1IRIY-hqXHkQOki_mQm1Q.review_text: Spent my birthday dinner here!  Lovely ambiance and European feeling.   For starters we had lamb critters (only 3 per dish)  the ceviche, the pretzel bites and the persimmon salad.   All the appetizers were delicious.   I would probably get the fritters and pretzel bites again and again and again though.   For my main course I decided to go with the mussels.   Yum yum.   The dish came with clams and great garlic, tomato and onion flavors.   I was so full, no room for desserts but I would definitely go back and would love to try brunch!

SLKK-fP3Qctl8BeUDNJ5oA.review_text: Came here with my boyfriend on a Saturday night. I'm glad I made reservations in advanced since there was hour+ wait. We were seated immediately. At first I wasn't wowed by the menu, but found I was too quick to judge. My boyfriend and I split the large french onion soup which they brought out in two bowls. It was delicious. I wish I had ordered the large for myself. I'm used to french onion soup having a foul smell (even though it tastes good), but I didn't seem to have that problem here. There was just the right amount of gooey cheese on the top, and the bread in the soup was soaked just enough to still be chewy. For our entrees, I had the pork Osso Buco and my boyfriend had the duck. I've had Osso Buco once before at another place. It was fantastic and I was hoping the one here would be just as good. They did not disappoint. The pork was tender and perfectly seasoned. My only complaint was the portion size! I could have wolfed down 3 portions, it was so good. The duck was a little too sweet for my taste, but my boyfriend loved it. We finished up with the squash cake and German chocolate cake. We had to wait a while for dessert, but the waiter made it up to us by taking the squash cake off our bill. My only (actual) complaint was the waiter refilling my boyfriend's $15 drink without asking first if he wanted another. Of course, I was the only one complaining. We loved the food and would definitely come back.

fxOM0K1czdmGhtAoP1UBUQ.review_text: One of the best drink selections in town.  Solid brunch choice if you live close by.  4/5 stars and "if you are close by" only b/c I cannot help but compare with equally high-priced eateries like Foreign Cinema. Ambiance and food are good, but for $15 I need my brunch choice to create warm tingling sensations in my socks before slowly, but surely blowing the same off.

JKIkdVqAJLEXTq92gF98bA.review_text: Absinthe has been sitting on my "to try" list for the longest time, yet I've never really felt the motivation to find a time to go though.  Well, until last week at least.  With a couple of my childhood friends back in town, I ended up choosing Absinthe for our dinner...partly because they were able to fit us for a last minute reservation.  Since we had to squeeze into a small-ish booth, leg room was in high demand amongst the five guys.  However, all was forgiven once the food started to arrive:  - Oyster Shooter - the least impressive part of the meal.  I was hoping for something like what I had at Pesce (best oyster shooter I've had to date), but this fell short.  Nice presentation, but the oyster seemed small and the taste was overpowered by the Bloody Mary sauce.  - Spicy Pork Meatballs served with toasted cheese baguette - we got a couple of orders for the table to share and though they weren't the best meatballs I've had, it was certainly one of the better ones.  Tomato sauce wasn't too much in taste or amount, and the meat was really well seasoned.  - Masami Farms Pork Loin - awesome dish.  The loin was ridiculously tender and moist, and the strip of pork belly was terrific.  Nice, crispy skin with a sort of glaze to it, while adding just the right amount of fatty flavor.  I wasn't a fan of the yellow carrot puree though.  Maybe it was intended to be subtle and sweet to balance the pork belly, but I thought it could have brought a little more.  It didn't hurt the dish, but it didn't add anything either; I wonder what if they had used squash.  Our waiter for the evening was a nice enough guy, but I actually liked his substitute better.  When he went off on a break, a waitress came by to take our orders and tend to our table initially.  She was really friendly and a little more sociable with us (not to mention pretty cute too).  For the winos out there, their selection of bottles on hand is very impressive.  The choices are plentiful with a huge price range, and their cocktail menu certainly holds its own as well.  We didn't order the Soft Garlic Pretzel appetizer since unfortunately, we didn't realize it was the hot item on their menu.  Sadly, I begged off on the French Onion soup as well since I didn't have the space for it, but I see that other Yelpers have liked it quite a bit.  No matter though, since I'm sure I'll be coming back sooner rather than later to knock both of my to-eat list.  Now I just regret that I took a while to finally trying Absinthe (the restaurant, not the alcohol...definitely tried that before...haha).

QZ3jkFQ74X-Z2SyfqMl7Fw.review_text: Warning!
