Super quick review will follow: - went here for a dinner before a show @ the Orpheum - they were very accommodating making sure our food comes out in time and we can leave to catch the show - the wine we drank was really bold, so they offered a decanter to let it breath ;-) - the food was good - not the best or something i will remember forever, but good - the ambiance and the staff was great All in all, it's a good place to try, especially if you are in teh neighborhood

O9zQONxkWxJlqvoQY89VgA.review_text: Sort of basic slightly run down french style restaurant.   Great bar scene and bar menu and good for before Symphony dinner.   Nice service not quite exceptional food.

mrsaXhSPfPVAXgR6MG9-qw.review_text: We came for lunch and the food was slightly underwhelming. We had the caesar salad, Moroccan steak, and the crab omelette. Though everything was good, it was all quite pricey.  They serve freshly squeezed orange juice ($5) and delicious, huge lattes served in a bowl.  The service was very good.

9JMmZEW1rQlO8EYNGNvAnQ.review_text: Absinthe (among others) was recommended to me by my favorite bartender in Seattle as having some of the best hooch in town.  They did not disappoint.  In fact, I knew I was in the right place when the waiter rattled off 4 different cocktail specials for the night that were not on the *extensive* drink menu.  Unfortunately, I can't recall the exact ingredients of my choice from the specials but it was innovative and complex. (reposado, chartreuse, orange and um...some other stuff)  The also win the prize for the best sazerac I had while in town.  The menu was chock-full of savory dishes, though all were exceptionally rich.  Don't go here if you're looking for light fare.  I settled on the chermola-rubbed lamb loin served with chick peas and cucumber relish.  The lamb was cooked perfectly and the flavors were at the same time unexpected and familiar.  The staff was attentive but not intrusive and clearly professional in their work.  In fact, after our before-dinner drinks our server had to hand us off to another, which normally doesn't end well.  In this case, they gave us fair warning and the name of our new server with a brief explanation as to why.  When she arrived she was familiar with what we had ordered so far and immediately picked up where we left off.  Aside from the change of face, we barely noticed.    The ONLY reason I don't give Absinthe 5 stars is that we didn't get to sit at the bar, which was at the top of my agenda for the evening.  Not surprisingly the bar is VERY popular on a Friday night and was 3-4 people deep when we arrived.  All in all a delightful experience.

GqzoKYXv6F1O85bhywyoSA.review_text: Absinthe is a very cute and intimate restaurant perfectly located at the corner of Hayes and Gough.  It may seem like it is small as you first enter into the bar area, but the dining room is located in the back.  The atmosphere is warming and it just makes you feel like you can relax and spend however many hours you want there.  We were able to get a booth in the back, which was perfect seating for the view of the venue.  Service was excellent at the time with no complaints.  Ordered:  -Soft Garlic Pretzels: On the top 100 things to eat before you die in SF.  Great little nibble to tease your stomach with the meal that it is about to have.  -Beef Tartare: the quail egg yolk and crostini completely topped off this dish to share.  One of the better steak tartares that I have tasted yet.  So flavorful and so raw.. I just loved it.  -Liberty Duck Breast: tender and juicy.  I enjoyed every bit of this dish.  I paired this meal with a cocktail called the perfect pear.  The cocktails here are delicious.  You get to see the bartenders hard at work at the bar, where flames go off for who knows which drinks are in the makings!  Pretty awesome!    Parking in this area may be a hard one though. Just a heads up!  Too bad I haven't really been in Hayes Valley as much!  I recommend!!

JLZs2s5Z6AtvE6Ry2AovTg.review_text: For brunch: Three stars doesn't mean it's bad. It just means I think there's better in the city.  To be fair, I'd have no trouble coming back because it was good. Just not out of this world.  Had the large fresh squeezed orange juice--kind of expensive at like 6 bucks a glass, but it was tasty orange juice, to be fair.  Also had a soy cafe latte and IT WAS HUGE.  Came in a cup without a handle, totally traditional feeling.  Tasted good, but needed sugar since it was a little bitter and frothy.  The menu is pretty interesting looking with neat sounding breakfast food and lunch food too (like burgers).  The deviled eggs sounded good but it had smoked salmon and I don't care for that so I opted not to get it. But I did see a lot of people around with it.  I started with the french onion soup since the reviews said it was good: it was.  very tasty and yummy.  Not too strong a flavor and not too much overpowering cheese or bread. 4.5 STARS  Then I had the duck confit ragout over a potato cake with poached eggs.  It looks neat like a eggs benedict and it was good.  The duck was good, the everything was good.  I got the bernaise sauce on the side and I'm glad because I didn't love the combination since the bernaise is just so heavy and thick.  I don't know if I have to have this again but it was ok. I ate half of it and that was more because I didn't think the calories were worth the effort it'd take to burn it off later. 3 STARS  The french toast was ok.  Had really sweet stuff on top and the bread was super bready and eggy too.  1.5 STARS.  So it was a mixed experience.  I hear the burgers are really good and the overall feel of the place is cool.  I'd try it again, but to be honest, I'm more of a Curbside Cafe girl. But that might be because I love their french onion soup and corned beef hash and french toast dishes like no other!  It's on opentable: make a reservation, it's worth it.  Parking on Sunday in the area is usually pretty good. I mean, don't come on the Bay to Breakers day and expect good parking but on a normal day I think it's pretty easy.

pXeGiGgexdzYoVz-uhObAw.review_text: Love sitting in the bar by the window. The BEST FRENCH FRIES with 3 sauces. I rarely eat fried food but can't resist the fries at Absinthe - they call my name!   The menu has a nice assortment of oysters.   The Croque Monsieur with an egg (technically Croque Madam) is rich & delicious - not soggy like some places.   The assortment of cheeses are intriguing with well paired accompaniments. Try 3 on each visit.   The Scharffen Berger Chocolate Pot De Crème with crème chantilly is rich & creamy - would be heaven if the chocolate was darker. I miss the Creme Brulee & Chocolate Tarte with salted caramel.   Chocolate Cherry Baked Alaska with beet cake & cocoa nib paper sounded more intriguing than it tasted.   Master mixologists create the cocktails.

O96xqRJ8NghRgWOjDoPNXw.review_text: Still me favorite!!!  Took the Mr M there for his birthday last night and we had a great time - romantic booth for two - a french wine that knocked my socks off, bone marrow appetizer with a parsley salad that I could have had a giant bowl of to myself, scallops for me, lamb for him, absinthe for the mister and of course the decadent warm chocolate banana tart for dessert.   What I think I like the best is that fact that I am not bombarded with a huge plate of food for dinner - it is enough that I can enjoy but not feel stuffed - even the lamb shank was on the smaller side but delicious and so slow cooked my husband pulled the bone out and the meat fell all over the plate.   Another great meal!!! Im so moving into the back room

9mSQt20-HY5bycsWPFeLZQ.review_text: If it's a cold rainy evening in San Francisco... there is nothing like martini's, oysters, onion soup, and a cheese plate at Absinthe.  Great lively atmosphere, good bar tenders, fresh oyster offerings, excellent cheeses and wonderful onion soup.

l26TgP9ox03XRLDuG-9wvA.review_text: If 3.5 stars were available to give, I'd give them to Absinthe.  After much thought, and the narrowing down of a long, long, long list of places- I finally decided Absinthe was the perfect spot to celebrate my boyfriend's 25th birthday with him (my treat)! I'm still quite happy with my choice, though it doesn't go down as one of my favorites.  I made us a 6:00 p.m. reservation for Tuesday evening, which was hardly necessary; the place wasn't all that busy. We were immediately seated in a corner table, which was cute and romantic. The ambiance in the main dining room is quite nice, and perfect for a romantic meal.  Our server, though not overly friendly, was attentive and like-able enough. He was kind enough to go over the drink menu with us, suggest some favorites, and give us the time we needed to make our decision. I ordered the 21 Hayes. Although refreshing, something about an onion as a garnish turned me off. Additionally, I'm not a big fan of the parts of cucumber (at least, I think it was cucumber) that eventually settled at the bottom of the glass. Those last few sips were less than delightful. The boyfriend ordered the Sacred Heart- and absolutely loved it. I liked it as well, though I'm not a huge fan of the anise taste.  To start, we ordered the meatballs. These were melt in your mouth delicious! I wish I would have just ordered these for dinner! The cheese crostini that comes with them are delicious as well.  Although aiming for a fancy meal, he ordered the burger and added Gruyere and the spicy caramelized onions. This $18 burger did not disappoint! He states it's the best burger he's ever had in his entire life (and he would know- he eats enough of them)!  I ordered the Mahi-Mahi with Prawn. Although flavorful and delicious, I can't believe I spent $31 on this dish. I wouldn't order it again on the value principle alone.  We had a lovely meal, but I'm not sure Absinthe won me over. If you're in the Hayes Valley area, it may be worth checking out, but if you're willing to expand your geographical area, I can think of other places that have won me over.

cciEFmYlnR-Uff7xe-JoHQ.review_text: I chose Absinthe for our first meal in SF based on a huge burger craving, and I remembered seeing said burger in a list I'd read about the best burgers in the city.  Absinthe was the perfect introduction for us to California cuisine.    We went for lunch, starving, immediately after landing at SFO.  We chose a corn/zucchini flatbread pizza for an appetizer, which came loaded with fresh veggies, cheese, and onions, with a chili-ed up lime on the side that we were instructed to squeeze upon the whole shebang.  This could be a meal on its own... I ate the leftovers (cold) for breakfast the next morning.  Standing up.  In front of the bathroom sink.  The burger TOTALLY satisfied my craving, and was made from grass-fed beef, which seems much more usual in SF than in NY.  (I can't figure out why NY restaurants are so ass-backwards with the grass-fed beef thing.)  It's rather pricey and doesn't include fries (mercifully, really), but with a hunk of gruyere on top, lettuce, tomatoes, and onions, that burger hit the spot and was worth every penny.  My sister had a gorgeous roasted veggie sandwich along with homemade chips. Not as gloriously satisfying as my burger, but delicious nonetheless.  For dessert, we went light with blueberry tequila sorbet, which was served with agave katafi (new to me, reminded me of shredded wheat and provided a nice foil to the smoothness of the sorbet) and lime "jello."  This was such a perfect summer dessert, not at all heavy, and we loved the combination of textures.  Service was not great-- slow-- but it was an off time and we were extra impatient because of our hunger.  I love the neighborhood it's in!  I just regret not going back to get one of their cocktails!

oIylWWfGfSjHaBkquL7MjA.review_text: We came here on a whim and a recommendation from my uncle. We left with a dent in our wallets and not a great experience. Bummed I bumped other restaurant ideas for this...live and learn right?   We walked in and the hostess wasn't the nicest, almost as if we were bothering her. We got seated right next to the bar and the entire restaurant was LOUD. It took a while to get service and when we did it was mediocre which was the total opposite of what we'd experienced all over SF.   We both got drinks which were definitely yummy! I can't remember but I know mine had prosecco and his had gin.   Food:  country pate earned a good review from my husband but not a great one.  big eye tuna crudo had delicious flavors but was 4 tiny bites.  chocolate pot de creme was ok.  we shared a salad and something else, neither of which I can remember so they clearly didn't leave an impression.   I'm not sure what exactly it was that made the experience less than I was hoping but I was unimpressed. Total bummer but live and learn!

eedG7XItxbGcSUCjoy60Jg.review_text: Well, what can I say.  It was a gorgeous Sunday, just about Noon, and one of my gal pals and I decided to go out for some brunch.  She lives in Hayes Valley, and suggested we check this place out, as her many passing by's had built up a curiosity.    So we dined, and it was delicious!  We started off with a couple of Bellini's which quenched our pallets very nicely.  I ordered the cheddar grits, which were served in a well portioned sized bowl, caked with Cheddar of course.  Perfectly gritty in texture, serviced nice and hot.  I also had a side of Panini Toast, which were served with creamy butter, and house made perserves, sooo good!    As for my gal pal, she ordered the Wild Mushroom and Guyere Omelet.  Let me tell you I should have ordered this.  This was one of the best Omelets i've ever tasted. The mushrooms were cooked to perfection, and the fresh melted Guyere cheese gave it a nice light and smoky flavor.   Service was good, we were seated immedietly, despite the fact we arrived at the height of Brunch/Lunch hour.  The price range was what I considered to be a median price range, especially for a semi-upscale place like this.  Affordable, and word to the wise, portions are suitable for sharing!

4QFaWuGXPZXBkqjkl9ruOg.review_text: We actually didnt head out to eat or drink at the Absinthe...but the place we had originally planned on was full and no longer even accepting names for the rest of the evening...so we headed down the street to Absinthe. It is a little more well known, popular, and trendy than what we usually choose...but they only had a 25 minute wait list and we got a seat at the bar within about five minutes. The bartender was really helpful and personable once we got his attention. In fact, we ended up just staying at the bar even after our table was ready.  First off, the prices really threw me...appetizers, soups, and salads ranged from about 5 to 15+...with main dishes in the high 20s...and drinks in the 10-15 range...not what we had planned for the evening.  We started out with drinks...my daughter got a strawberry/gin/absinthe cocktail, which she loved. I got a ginger drink that actually had zero taste of ginger at all...it pretty much tasted like a weak mojito.  The drinks were expensive and a little on the small side...lots and lots of ice in mine and a tiny glass for hers.    We passed on the expensive main dishes and opted for several side dishes. We got the pretzel bites with mornay sauce, a cup of the French onion soup, and the baby field greens with strawberry and rhubarb and candied walnuts.    The pretzels were good and the mornay sauce was delicious, but you only got four small pretzel bites.    The salad was delicious but, again, small. Although $13, you could not have had it for a meal...it just wasnt big enough. The candied walnuts were actually candied pistachios. The salad was fresh and tasty, but disappointing for the price.  What bumped this up to four stars from my original three was the French onion soup...hands-down, the best French onion soup I have eaten in decades.  I dont know what they do to it, but it is onion soup nirvana! We had only ordered the cup...and we did everthing but lick the bowl clean...trying to scrape out every bit.  However, if you like tons of actual strings of onions in your soup, you will be disappointed...I dont know if they strain it or, more likely, puree it, but it is smooth...no chunks or strings of onions.  A pleasant evening...but our three appetizers and two drinks, with tip, ran us $70...a definite hit to my vacation budget!

521_QKerZNYI0ylftfbj4g.review_text: GNO!! Whoohooo! I picked this place because 1.) I didn't want to go clubbing  2.) I wanted to go somewhere nice and fancy for both food and cocktails  3.) I've always wanted to try this place. I am a French cuisine virgin, and I thought this place would be the perfect place to start.  Anyway, the place looked fancy and elegant, as expected.  I initially wanted to be in the bar area, where the atmosphere was more lively. But since there were 8 of us, and they don't do reservations for the bar area, I just opted for the quiet, more intimate dining area.  First order of things: Cocktails. I ordered the "Wanderlust", and ended up not really liking it. I forgot that Absinthe has that licorice, medicine-y taste that I'm not fond of. Wanderlust has Absinthe. I kinda thought it started growing on me after a few sips. But maybe it was because the drink was pretty strong and I was starting to get buzzed, or because I was thinking that for $12, I better freaking enjoy it. One of my friends got a Mojito- like drink which was pretty yummy, and another friend got the "Perfect Pear", which I wish I ordered instead.  We got the pretzels to start. NOM!! Soft, fluffy, flavorful, cheesy and garlicky little tidbits of NOM-ness. Plus, you dip it in this velvety, cheesy, buttery sauce that I wanted to take shots of.  Coq Au Vin.  I've decided that I will order this, pretty much 4 days before our dinner reservation. Of course, I made sure I figured out the proper pronunciation so I can order it confidently. Yes, I was that excited. I did not feel a bit remorseful for the $27 I paid for it. Chicken was fall off the bone tender. The sauce was rich with flavor. It comes with chunks of potatoes and carrots, for it is a stew. The dish also comes with some kind of cheesy garlic toasted bread to dip in the sauce. All in all, I've never had stew that good in my life!  Everyone else raved about their dishes. There was Tuna Tartare, Mac n cheese, meatballs and the Absinthe burger. I heard the meatballs were melt-in-your-mouth good and the Mac n cheese was the best she's ever had. I may have heard my friend groan after her first bite.  We really liked our server. It's a shame I forgot his name, but he was an older gentleman who has a hunched back posture. He was very polite, sincere, sweet and funny. If I was filthy rich, I'd hire him as my butler.  I will definitely make another trip to Absinthe with my bf for a fancy date night!  And uhhhh, guess what? We ended up at a freaking club at the end of the night after all! Damnit!

e3qZZ9n6l_1c68li8SLCMA.review_text: My cousin and her boyfriend took me here for dinner when I was in SF for the weekend. We came at 6pm and were seated immediately. The waiters were very attentive, and the atmosphere was alive and fully of energy. Most important though, the food tasted incredible! I got the yam & goat cheese ravioli, which was to-die-for. I love eating out in San Francisco!

-EQ1Emcof6LetySGmUJ2PA.review_text: I hadn't seen a friend of mine for a while and we decided to meet up for brunch at Absinthe.  I'm a total sucker for Top Chef, but couldn't really afford dinner there, so I thought brunch would be a wonderful substitution.  This was during DAT and I thought we'd be able to take part with the lunch menu.  Little did I know that the lunch menu offering was only available M-F and when we got there, we were presented with brunch menus.  I love brunch!  What other meal can you have an alcoholic drink disguised as a V8?  It's great!  So we settled in their lovely banquettes and proceeded to order a bloody mary and a martini.  Then we dived into the menu.  The first thing that popped out at me was the duck confit hash with poached eggs.  That's what I got.  When it came to the table, I thought the portion size was a little on the small side, but that's my messed up Americanized-TGIF-Chili's vastly skewed portion size mind.  It was actually, quite perfect.  The eggs were poached nicely, albeit a little too medium for my taste, but the arugula salad was a really nice complement to the duck hash.  As was the bloody mary (let's not forget about that).    My friend had the griddle corn cakes, which when described, doesn't really bring up thoughts of an eggs benny, but that's what showed up at the table.  Their hollandaise was to die for!  That tasso ham was perfect.  Now, I didn't have the oppty to have the scallops, which Jamie seems to be quite famous for, but I would venture to guess that it would be pretty damn good, based upon the duck confit hash and griddle cakes.    And last but not least, the lovely bartender who makes a mean bloody mary!

96SWIePpb2QmY-wrr4A5_A.review_text: April 20, 2011.  6:45 PM reservation.  It was a concert night, so place was packed in both the bar and the dining area.  Pluses are the outstanding service.  You will be well cared for if you are dining before a performance and out in time.  The food was well prepared.  I always worry about ordering pork because its often overcooked.  Not here.  The Masami Pork loin was perfectly prepared.  The caesar salad was a generous portion and tasty.  The negative was the pricey wine selections.  Specifically, there were some 50+ cabernets on the menu but only 4 were priced less than $100!  If you want a cab with dinner here, bring your own bottle and pay the corkage.  You are better off.

5gbkhlWANGVzQYi_0m3vOQ.review_text: I think Absinthe is movin' on up to my numero uno spot for brunch in SF.  I would stray away from the breakfast burrito, and warn you that the burger can get expensive when you add the fixins. The french onion soup was almost too cheesy.  Everything else was delicious. I can't wait to come back and try the rest of their dishes and grab a bloody mary!

Y_UX6HwQs7xoJPNNYJRraA.review_text: Late dinner anyone?  We had  just gone to check out the San Francisco Ballet which was amazing and we needed to find a nice place to eat that was open past 11pm.  You see my wife takes about 20 hours to get ready and we missed the change to grab food before the show that started at 8.   While at the Ballet I got out my trusty iPhone equipped with the Yelp app and went to work.  Once I saw the name "Absinthe"... I was in.  It made me think of days spent with my old roommate who ordered wormwood and attempted to make absinthe in our basement.   Absinthe Barasserie had a nice vibe. The people were all dressed to the nines, but I feel like the 7 or 8's would have fit it also.  We ordered a glass of wine and french fries... Talk about class... The wine was good and the fries where also.  They did not pile on cilantro which is what most places in CA seem to do with fries.  I also ordered the olive plate which was great.  As it was late in the night I think we were ordering off the bar menu so I went for the burger.  I like my burgers med/med-well and they cooked it to perfection.  The wife also had a burger and she ordered it WELL (pregnant) and it seem to be more med.  I was in the mood to fall off of my diet wagon in style so I did so... I ordered the cookie platter and what seem to be a chocolate pudding type of dish.  Both were very good.  I only wish I was sophisticated enough to remember their official names.     I am not sure if they had Absinthe... But tonight was more about food than drink... If we are needing a good late night place again you can be sure we will stop in again...

qPGhjScyxtuHrWXN4A8VXg.review_text: I had snacked a bit before we arrived so I didn't think I'd be that hungry. I got some lamb skewers and  a large onion soup while everyone else got their regular sized mains.  The skewered lamb was alright. I'm glad that it came with hummus and pita bread because I ended up being a little hungrier than I thought and I needed something to nibble on while I waited for my soup to cool.  My beloved and I switched plates for a little. He ordered the coq au vin, which was quite delicious. I tried not to eat too much of his sauce but it was so good!  The other folks at the table were quite happy with their food and we were very well attended. You certainly can't go thirsty here.  The one thing I wasn't keen on was sitting so close the back door. Every time anyone left we were hit with the cold breeze. Overall, though, it was very nice.

_UYWp3oYG0jxgwENp1JirA.review_text: Absinthe is in my top 10 for brunch places in the city for a couple of key reasons - the prime location in cute, sunny Hayes Valley & the superb start-of-the-day offerings!  We started off with the coffee cake, which came to us in a paper muffin wrapper, served with a side of berry jelly (cranberry, we both thought, but we weren't entirely sure).  The coffee cake wasn't quite to our liking, as it was a bit dry and dense, not quite as moist as we'd both imagined it would be, and instead of having an even layer of streusel topping, there were just some drops of streusel topping baked into the top of the muffin.  Next time, I'll pass on it.  We shared the griddled corn cakes with chard, poached eggs & tasso ham hollandaise & the wild mushroom omelette with carmelized onions, truffled pecorino & fresh herbs.  Though we liked both, we agreed the wild mushroom omelette edged out just a bit.  I was expecting more of a masa, corn studded corn cake, but the base of my brunch selection was more corn bread-like, but with a heftier and sweeter consistency.  The chard was nicely seasoned and wilted, and the tasso ham hollandaise was slightly spicy.  The twist they put on the standard eggs benedict was really tasty, and surprisingly light!  We both really liked the wild mushroom omelette.  Nestled within the layer of soft, fluffy, buttery egg was a deliciously plump medley of wild mushrooms, with slightly sweet carmelized onions, fresh herbs and truffled pecorino.  Truffled anything is way tasty, but this combination was wonderful!  I secretly wished I had gone with my gut and ordered this dish instead, but had been swayed to order the corn cakes so we could sample both.  At least I now know what to get the next time I go =)  Great service, nicely appointed dining space in a cute neighborhood, and a delicious brunch!  The ambience was ruined a bit because of a large, raucous dining party seated to our left, but we just ignored the rabble-rousers!

tEgHGR1Mmo5SXmG8bsHhZw.review_text: This was my first time at Absinthe, and it won't be my last.  Absolutely KILLER cocktails - I tried at least a half dozen of them and they were all delicious.  We waited about 45 minutes for our table (not bad for Friday night without reservations) but this gave us the perfect opportunity to watch the bar action.   Have you ever seen a wine glass set on fire, then sprinkled with cinnamon (?) while it's still burning, setting glowing embers afloat along with a delicious aroma?  Kudos to the bartenders - they sure know how to dazzle a girl!  If you find yourself here, order one (or two or three) of their gorgeous libations, and don't miss the garlic pretzels.  Hot, chewy, buttery goodness dipped in a cheddar mornay sauce...mmm mmm good!

_XvuuSBHNvXC4eziLEpbkA.review_text: My boyfriend and I came here for dinner, with a reservation on a Saturday night.  Our table was in the same room as the bar, towards the back of the restaurant.  The table space was extremely cramped and awkwardly in an aisle with wait staff and customers squeezing by.  Most of the tables in our area also seemed awkwardly situated.   Appetizers, dinner, and drinks lived up to their reputation at this restaurant, and the waitress was friendly and helpful in drink selections, although she forgot about a drink order towards the end of the meal, so I ended up not ordering it.    Overall, I would definitely come here again for the great food and cocktails, however I would try to ask for a table in the other room, not where the bar is.

htiVdsiY_rBmJc65aZ3YAA.review_text: I can only comment on the drinks but they were inventive and chic!  I had the 21 Hayes (as named for a public bus route that cruises by the place!)  Such a cool place I cant wait to come back and eat!  There are tables outside also with heaters!!!

w1tI3Oh7GB-fUYzECYrnlQ.review_text: A veritable SF/Hayes-Valley institution, Absinthe has been on my "must-try" forever. I finally made reservations for a mini-celebration lunch.   I started with the French Onion Soup Gratinee. If you like French onion soup, you must try it at Absinthe. The melted gruyere cheese on the top was a thick, gooey barrier to the goodness lying within. After breaking through the gruyere cheese, you reach sweet caramelized onions in a rich, savory broth. What was even more surprising about the soup was the large toasted crouton that remained crisp till the very last spoon of soup!   My boyfriend had the Absinthe Hamburger (Marin Sun Farms ground beef, aïoli, red onion, lettuce, house-made pickles, french fries) while I tried the Masami Farms Pork "Prime Dip" (horseradish aioli, provolone, buttermilk-fried onions, pork jus, french fries). We both agreed that although the burger was good, it wasn't particularly memorable or outstanding. The burger was served with a very generous portion of tasty frites.   The Prime Dip really stole the show. Thin, tender slices of pork loin were complimented by the sharp bite of horseradish aioli and the crunch of buttermilk-fried onions. Dipped in savory, rich pork jus, this made for a really delicious and memorable sandwich for which I would return.

EEy2KCX4z-Ea25gR-P3zsA.review_text: Half Dozen Beau Soleil Oysters.  Check. Frisee salad with fried duck egg.  Check. Steak Frites cooked rare.  Check. Pan-seared scallops.  Check. Two Belvedere vodka martinis with a lemon twist.  Check. One "Uptown" Manhattan served in a low ball glass on the rocks.  Check. One Sazerac.  Check.  $180 later and it's still the best place ever.   Order the steak frites rare.  The steak was like butter.  Pan-seared scallops were amazing as well.  If you order with drinks, stick with the classics like the sazerac, manhattan, or a martini.  Seriously, trying to find the words to describe this place is pretty difficult.  If you want a quiet dinner then ask to be seated in the more "romantic" area towards the back.  If you want to see and be seen then ask to be up front, near the action.  Oh and good luck finding street parking.

EDyAbL7u6eLDm4sU7pBadA.review_text: This place is pretty legit. I usually go here before the opera or the symphony because its so close by. I've probably been here 6-10 times and it is consistently good. The onion soup is always really good as a starter. Last time I ordered the Coq au Vin and I love it! I can definitely recommend it. My friend had the mahi mahi and the corn soup special, and both of those were also good. They always get you out on time for your show.. so there are no worries about that!

Bf7idvknr6Y-NOyOEBOUUA.review_text: Beau and I eloped at City Hall and decided to have our first post-wedding drink here with our two guests. We had some wonderful drinks -- I highly recommend the Ginger Rogers -- and the snacks were delicious. The cheese plate was good and the fried chickpeas were phenomenal.    Everything about the experience was practically perfect -- except our server. He was a grouchier, blonder Lou Reed. I'm not sure what the issue was but he gave curt answers to our questions and yanked out a menu that was under a plate and silverware which caused it all to clatter and slide across the table as he ran off. He was the most pleasant as he was turning our table over to another server.  We saw another couple who had also just wed at City Hall so my guess is Absinthe might be one of the go to places right after couples tie the knot. It's a great place to celebrate and feels very SF.

KI7gPbRvdngGcgq3-RD7Gw.review_text: 5 stars if you order the fantastic cocktails, the French Onion Soup and/or the Duck!!  Otherwise, still a solid 3.    Seating is a pretty tight and the wait can be long (we waited 1 hour at 6pm on a Sunday), but it was perfect for our double date last night.  I can see myself being back, especially with any out-of-town visitors.  We ordered: --French Onion Soup ($5 for cup) -- Tasty tasty, but oh so rich and heavy! more cheese than liquid.  all four of us ordered one.  Looking back, i'd best if we had shared. --Liberty Farms Duck ($30) -- A MUST GET!!! We nicknamed it "endless duck."  Two huge duck breasts, super moist.  Perfectly seared in a delicious coffee crust.  The sides of spinach, the bed of hash and parsnips, and huckleberry all made for unique pairings with each bite of duck. --Mahi Mahi and Blue Prawn ($31) -- Pretty dissappointing, mediocre at best.  Very small piece of Mahi.  Cleary overcooked.  One prawn. Not much flame and flavor was pretty underwhelming. Nothing really redeeming about this dish, unfortunately. --Peach Float ($9) -- The cookies it comes with are divine.  Nice way to polish off the meal.  Cocktail recommendation: Sacred Heart ($11) -- Absolutely delish!  I'm not big on the black licorice taste of anise, but figured "when in rome!" -- so I asked for a absinthe cocktail that would quiet those aspects of the spirit.  Sacred Heart did just: pomegranate tequila, Absinthe, Limoncello, and lime juice. Super refreshing and very unique.

5qgJTus1l35A6bqW2fFk0w.review_text: Great place to stop in for cocktails or wine before grabbing dinner at the restaurant or another place on Hayes.  The drinks are always delicious and service is excellent!  Last time I came in I got a drink off of the chalkboard menu and to echo the latest obsession in SF the Holy Smokes mezcal drink was complex and absolutely wonderful!  I've eaten here for dinner in the past and have always been satisfied with everything ordered. Beef tartare is very very good and the fish entrees are always perfectly cooked.

hOwNzTU0g0UzNLNQhhuHEQ.review_text: I know I am in the minority but I didn't love this place, I just thought it was OK. Maybe because it's been hyped to me for so long, I was expecting more or something different but it just seemed to be another expensive restaurant with nothing special to it.   We came here for dinner on Thursday night around 9:30pm and there was a decent crowd at the bar but we were able to sit for dinner right away. Our waiter was nice enough. We ordered the cheese plate, oysters, fries and cauliflower soup and all were decent just not spectacular for the price.   I might give it a try again some day but for now, there are so many other restaurants in SF that I will give those a try before I come back here.

S0elD2i4_QjuPQ85aue12Q.review_text: Check it.  Food, good. Service, slow. Woman next to me, loud. If I wasn't drunk as Davy's sow on a frosty night I probably would have been annoyed most of the time. As it were, I was drunk and it was an enjoyable experience.   Walked in without reservations at 7:30pm on a Friday and got seated promptly. And that's about as far as their service went. Took us 30 mins for our drinks, another 30 for our food, then 30 more to get the check. So all in all about a 2 hour experience give or take. Not really worth the bill, but I'd probably go back and give it another shot. Maybe take a few shots BEFORE I go so I don't have to numb myself at their expensive bar to tolerate the place and people.

6RJBeJlbDGrZO91Qc2NG9A.review_text: I reserved judgment on this restaurant, until I had been there for a full dinner.  I've gotta say the service was excellent each time I've been and that alone, is worth the price of admission.   I was also excited to see if I could get a glimpse of local celebrity Jamie from Top Chef, but sadly she probably wasn't there on a Sunday early evening for dinner.  Me and Mom had 5pm resers to get to Wicked, so we were one of the first people seated in the dining room, save the bar.  The bar was hopping as usual, and I guess they now have Sunday brunch, so that explains it.  My first disappointment was that the entree list was either shorter or about the same as the hor's d'oeuvres and appetizer lists (which are separate).  My Mom and I weren't sure what we wanted since we are not great on raw food, which I would imagine, if you like oysters would be good.  The wine and drink selection is great, and I have had and can attest to their amazing appetizers.  Sadly, many of the things we had were tasty but didn't really live up to the description.  Never have I had a gazapacho loaded with cream, and albeit tasty, not what I wanted to eat.  Same with the halibut -- seriously, halibut in cream?  Not what was described and didn't set well with me even though it was perfectly cooked.  I thought the prices were reasonable, and again, I'll mention the amazing service, so I'll probably be back for the bar more often.  ~ Ms. Ali

Udq7d8q7faRfTwrVeQiZtA.review_text: Interesting crowd of foreigners with black frame rimmed glasses and tightly wrapped scarves, perfect example of San Francisco smugness in my opinion. (Feel free to disagree with me as I'm open to discussions about SF and have a love-hate relationship with the city.) After we sat at the bar and got a little settled (were waiting for a friend), the patrons seemed a little more approachable and some offered us a taste of their absinthe cocktails...which we didn't accept, but was a kind gesture nonetheless.   They were so stingy with the chocolate fondue. Two marshmallows? Seriously?? I can get a huge bag of them for less than a dollar! When we were out of dipping materials, we ended up eating spoonfuls of the chocolate fondue. So classy, I know...was delicious though! p.s. Please watch South Park SF smug episode, so hilarious even if extreme! Also, I agree with most points in these articles:   stuffwhitepeoplelike.com… al3x.net/2009/10/04/so-y…

XzBx0QLXsycIZc_nkuupiQ.review_text: I have been here twice, once for dinner and once for a weekday lunch.  I loved it.  The atmosphere makes me feel like I am at a bistro in Paris, and the food and drinks are great.  The service is nice, I like how they do not rush you at all, but you do not feel neglected either.  I love to start with the oyster shooters.  The onion soup was great, and so were the steak frites.  Lightest fries I have ever had.  And the desserts are superb, so save room.    I will be back for my birthday.

ftqKNw6BbcEqT6eQCDzupg.review_text: Seriously, whats the big hype about this place? I came here for the first (and last) time for brunch, and the service was ok, if not a bit slow. They served bread when seated and the bread was cold, and hard. The bread at Cheesecake Factory is better than this place.   We ordered a steak, french onion soup, and a hamburger. The French onion soup was mediocre. It wasn't the best I'd ever had. And the steak and the hamburger was so plain! Yes, it was better quality meat, but there was nothing special about it and the flavors even were on the bland side.   For $80, I could have gotten a MUCH more tasty and satisfying meal somewhere for half the price. Everything about this place is just so overrated, including the price.

2LHC6nZR3ZRujHJH4BSxAg.review_text: Only had drinks here but the drink list was extensive and delightful

920SZSvECa2tmGW8W5byyg.review_text: My experience at Absinthe was superb!  We started out with the Antipasti and Escargot. The Escargot came out piping hot and in garlic and  butter, the only way to go! The Antipasti had 6 to 7 different types of meats. We all agreed the Antipasti was our favorite between the two.  Between three people we shared two entrees: The Roasted Chicken, which was not spectacular, I think next we'll go for the Pork Confit. But the Grilled Scallops are a MUST! Perfectly cooked with the most tastiest baby leeks ever! and the secret clincher was the Artichoke puree! we LOVED the Artichoke puree. We also had the Chicory Salad: the bleu cheese was very strong in this dish, but none the less very satisfying.  The restaurant Wine Connoisseur came to our table to help us pair a bottle of wine to our dinner. Boy was he spot on! We had a bottle of the Sauvignon Blanc by Toraine. The wine was so aromatic and it rolled off the palate so well. Top notch.  We didn't have time for dessert, unfortunately. We went to the Adele and James Morrison Concert.  - - - - - - - -   We came back for drinks three hours later! The bar was open late! I love their drink menu, Ginger Rogers and Daedalus! The General Mgr was hanging out too, super nice guy! We were hungry so we ordered the Absinthe burger made with Escancia meat. Awesome burger. Fries had great dipping sauces as well.  Overall, I enjoyed eating here and I think you will too!  notes: Valet $10, Crowd~ San Francisco  Matured Socialite scene, Chanel tweed if you know what I mean.

NeXRy1C7PxS7bvIcQ3SymA.review_text: You can tell that the people who live in this area and eat here are rich by their kids.  Dressed in riding boots, blazers, and pinstripe... they remind me of NY's Upper East Side spawn.  We sat near the front of the restaurant where the tables are really close together.  I know it's a Cal-French restaurant but they need to know that we are much fatter than the typical Frenchman.  I like that there are hooks on the wall for coats and purses though.  Absinthe Lemonade - Fresh squeezed lemon juice, ginger syrup, cranberry juice, and ginger ale.  Lots of ice.  Very gingery and tart.  The cranberry is very minimal and provides just a hint of taste and color.  French onion soup - People are right about this.  The broth has such a deep beef and onion flavor.  The bread was pretty soaked so there was only a slight crispiness to the edges.  The gruyere was plentiful and baked to a perfect brown.  Croque Monsieur - I really like how every restaurant makes this differently.  They still follow the standard bread, ham, and gruyere but to be able to have different interpretations of such a simple thing is so wonderful!  The thing that stood out most about this one was the bread and how it was toasted.  They use Acme Bread's levain bread which is great because it's more porous which allows the melted cheese to seep in.  Duck confit hash - Although this wasn't bursting with flavor, the eggs were perfectly poached (runny yolk, slightly crusting, and cooked whites).  Unfortunately this was the least favorite dish.  Banana-blueberry souffle pancakes - Very fluffy.  For some reason I kept tasting a hint of lemon.  The whipped cream really made the dish because it's not too airy.  I definitely want to come back for the $92 cheese tasting!!

TzD4IkLN2MWb3hA7gO2GOQ.review_text: Really 3.5 but I rounded up.   Drinks Negroni Spagliato Special house Manhattan (can't recall name of drink) Awesome. Refreshing, tasty and no skimping on the alcohol. Kind of hard to do with a Manhattan.   Brunch Fried deviled eggs with salmon Soft boiled egg with crouton Ricotta stuffed French toast with bananas and walnuts.  1/2 Dungeness crab  Where to start? Everything was exceptionally good. Favorite was the fried deviled eggs with salmon. So freaking yummy. I did not taste the French toast but my BF said it was very good but got a little to sweet towards the end.   Not cheap but worth it.

Vkf4e4SLFm3gApONFnWk7Q.review_text: Okay so per food item I would vary between a 3.5 and a 4.  We get to the restaurant for lunch on a Friday and I can see that at night this would be a very cool place with the paintings on the wall, and they have curtains to make it dark.  Food: (you get free bread!) Appetizers: Pretzels and meatballs - these were pretty good. the pretzels come in 5 pieces and the meatballs were very flavorful French onion soup - THIS IS A MUST ORDER. it was so savory and the cheese. yummmm.  Food: Pasta of the day, with the same lamb meatballs - this was good I wouldn't say anything especially stood out but delicious just the same. Croque madame - THIS LOOKED BOMB DOT COM. so much cheeeese with the egg on top? omg I wish i ordered this, but I just ate it off my coworkers plate. buahahaha. chicken breast - I didn't try this but my coworker said it was good and not dry.   Overall pretty delicious, I wish I ordered the croque madame, but everything was good and the service was also great. But I will still give it a 3.5 for nothing SUPER standing out.

kFV28P1bj1Uo-g_hrT1W8w.review_text: The seating and the general ambience is not really worth the 5 stars, but the food is totally worth it! So I am giving it 5-stars! We found it on eater.com - it's listed as one of the 38 best fine dining restaurants in SF. The food and the wine recommendations were just too good!

Ml2i2mGdUyrRswXZZlbKNw.review_text: 2.5 STARS. Food was just OK and service was EH..   Crispy Skin Pork Belly: A very small portion. Tasted delicious. Pork belly was crispy. Tasted like roast pork.  Grilled Black Angus Rib-Eye Steak: At first glance, the rib-eye looked very delicious, but looks can be deceiving. The rib-eye was supposed to be cooked medium rare, but only certain parts were. A portion of it was undercooked. It was purple and squishy... Told/showed our server and he told me not to order medium rare since medium rare is like that and next time to order medium. The server acted like I didn't know how meat was cooked.. Like WTF... I know how well/rare meat is cooked. Otherwise, the other parts of the rib-eye were not really that tender nor moist. Worst rib-eye I've ever had... I think I'll stick to steakhouses now for any types of steaks in the future..  Absinthe Hamburger: EH.. Pass. Wasn't amazing.. Burger wasn't that juicy nor tasty. It just tasted like any other burgers.. Not sure why they're known for it. If you want an amazing burger, go to Marlowe's!   Maybe we just came on an off day, but Absinthe did not wow me. Our server was way too sassy and our water cups were not refilled. We had to ask a few times. I'm pretty sure our server looked down on us just because we looked so young compared to all the other customers in the restaurant. We didn't get the service that the server gave to others. With other restaurants in this area, I doubt I'll be back.

4MJ7go3WJwIcak_17vWw9w.review_text: Came here for Dine About Town but ended up just ordering off the regular menu. I was pretty glad we did so because I peeked at other diners' plates who did the DAT and it didn't look appealing.   Our waitress was pretty sweet and very good at her job. I wanted something warm to drink and asked for a mocha. She made this face like it wasn't on the menu and quickly made up for it with a "I'll make one for you." It was good and later when my friend was chatting it up at La Boulange a block away I noticed the it was the same cup! Sweet! I am glad we gave her a good tip.  Appetizer  SOFT GARLIC PRETZELS Vermont cheddar Mornay ......................7 - Five pieces. Very garlicly and sooo delicious! I want more than just five pieces!  Entrees  GRILLED STEAK FRITES wild mushroom jus, Star Route Farms mixed baby lettuce........................................ 26 - My friend ordered this. Comes with about 5-6 pieces of circular steak with mushrooms on top. Juicy. Comes with string fries. My friend asked the sweet waitress about sauces for the fries and she brought over three dips! =] I like choices. Not sure about the salad since my friend has an aversion to salads.  DAILY MARKET PASTA ..................................................­.............MP - I was going to do the DAT menu but when the sweet waitress mentioned the daily market pasta it sounded so good I decided to forgo the DAT menu. It was a shrimp and tomato with croutons pasta with a cream sauce. I love shrimp and cream sauce. I believe it was 19 dollars. The taste felt light and this is good because it is just lunch. The portion is just right. It's not Cheesecake factory here! With the appetizer I felt like it was the perfect amount of food.   Nice bathrooms.   I wouldn't mind coming back but probably just for dinner. Nothing really appeal to me from the lunch menu that I haven't tried. I don't really care for ordering a sandwich at a nice restaurant.  to the 7x7 2010- they changed their chef so the homemade hot dog isn't offered here anymore.

rWLI-KeG6u1Y7zLIEGWJlA.review_text: Have been back a few times since my original 5-star experience.  And while this place is still great, it is occasionally inconsistent with some dishes.  Last time out, one of the groups member ordered a preparation of duck, with grits, baked figs, and a honey sauce that was not only outstanding, it was borderline orgasmic.  My beef cheeks on other hand, were just OK.    I'm still a big fan, for sure, but after multiple trips, the experiences have been more in-line with 4, rather than 5 stars.    Curse you Yelp for not allowing a half star!

TH_9hdtJX67bGgOcGrJ1Fw.review_text: I've been wanting to try out this place ever since I saw Jamie compete in Top Chef. I finally got the chance to last Friday with my girlfriend for our four month! WOOT! =)  We started out the night with some drinks and the spicy chickpeas. I got the French 75 - a sort of modified gin and tonic. It had gin, lime, a lemon twist, some drunken maraschino cherries and topped off with champagne. Fancy! I loved it. The spicy chickpeas came out in a little ramekin and smelled delightful. They had a slightly spicy note with a hint of curry. I loved how they were crisp on the outside, yet tender inside. MmmMmmm! In between, we were served a bit of bread - I thought it was sorta weird that it came out cold, but my girlfriend liked it.  For our first plates, my girlfriend got the French Onion Soup and I went for the duck confit. The soup was delicious - she said it was about a thousand times better than what we were served at Bijou in Hayward. I thought the duck was absolutely amazing! The first time I had duck confit was in Paris at this little cafe that didn't have an English menu. I pointed at the "Confit de Canard", not remembering enough French from high school to even begin fathoming what it would be - and was treated to an excellent preserved leg of duck. This one brought me right back to that little cafe, but it was so much better! The salad that was served with the duck was equally amazing - sweet and bitter perfectly balanced. The only part of the dish I was confused about were the fingerling potatoes. Their presence didn't really add much to the dish and the texture kinda made the rest of the plate a little awkward.  I've had an obsession for Jamie's scallops since Top Chef, too. Unfortunately, like the judges, I wasn't so impressed with hers. But then again, I think it might be some sort of scallop superiority complex - nothing I've had really meets up to it. This one wasn't bad - I just think I'm not much of a medium-rare scallop sorta guy. That being said, the scallops were served with some thick cut bacon (sweet, smoky flavor), mushrooms (nice and earthy), some greens and a mustard-type sauce. And with this dish, I'm officially off my scallop kick - I really want to try to Braised Beef Cheeks if they're on the menu next time =P My girlfriend's stuffed chicken was excellent, by the way. Tender and juicy with really good flavors.  We ordered two desserts - the pot de creme and the cashew-chocolate bar. Awesomely, when I made my reservation through OpenTable, I made a note that it was our anniversary. The pastry/dessert chefs were nice enough to pipe "Happy Anniversary" on both our dessert plates - yay! The pot de creme was delicious - rich, but not heavy or overly sweet. The cashew-chocolate bar was pretty good, but I didn't detect much cashew in it. The persimmon ice cream was a nice touch considering I don't like persimmon. =P  Service was good - there was no rush even near end of dinner service. I LOVED the ambiance - good lighting (read not too dark) and an excellent selection of jazz.  Overall I have to say that this was a pleasurable dining experience from start to finish. I'd definitely come back to try out a new menu and would recommend this place to anyone. If you have a date, the private dining room is a definitely plus since the rest of the restaurant seemed a bit noisy. Woot! =)

wNsSz6R73I3tcskuTv6yQw.review_text: Absinthe was rated in the top 100 restaurants in the Bay Area for 2012 so I figured I'd check it out when I went through Hayes Valley. It's a very elegant restaurant for sure, with a nice dining area and a decked out bar with drinks for any hour of the day. But it's definitely aimed for people with more refined taste buds in their mouths and more dollars in their wallets than me. I went for brunch and sat at the bar with a friend since the dining area had a long wait. The man next to me was ordering Oysters, Bloody Marys, and a whole host of other dishes and drinks that I probably wouldn't normally see, and definitely afford, for a brunch. I stuck with a simple Stuffed French Toast while my friend got Dungeness Crab Omelet, with the latter definitely being more delicious than the former. If the prices for everything weren't so high, I might have gotten a mimosa as well.   All in all, the food was pretty good but the price and elegance of the place makes it a restaurant that I can't see myself frequenting too much or introducing to other friends my age (early 20's). But wait half a decade and this could become my favorite place in Hayes Valley.

g5oKp1Xed3cT1YJ_87TEpQ.review_text: I went there for the bar so I can't speak for the food.The place seemed a bit pretentious in general, but that wasn't surprising. The cocktails were good, although a tad pricey.  I definitely recommend the Ginger Rogers. Excellent drink!    Unfortunately the bartender was extremely rude to us. I asked him if he had a favorite cocktail. His response "Bacon." Confused, thinking he misheard me, I said "No, do you have a cocktail that you'd recommend?" He then proceeded to go into a long rant about how he can't recommend drinks without knowing a person and if someone asked him what to drink he'd tell them to have a shot. He also somehow managed to mention his ex wife in his long rant. He was either drunk, just a jerk, or both.   Honestly, I'm not too needy as far as customer service goes. However there is no reason to go off on a customer for asking a perfectly reasonable, friendly question. We even tipped well! That whole experience really soured the mood for us. I don't know if I'd go back there. If you go, do yourself a favor and don't talk to the bartender.

YsnVq-tnmUoCjO5d47jFFw.review_text: Hello, happiness.  Yes, I'm talking to you, you deliciously tender beef cheeks nestled on my plate near amazing braised carrots. You are amazing. And yes, yes I did fall in love with you the other night. You are worthy for battledish.com.  And you shall receive the mindfulness you deserve. Dear Chef, you have completed my heart.

mIo2cFs_89a7i0DWHT9F-w.review_text: Great food (of course, all food in SF Is magically wonderful) and superb service.  I went here on Saturday night with the bf for dinner before heading to the symphony. The only time they let us make a reservation was for 6:15pm but we got there early and they were able to accommodate us, as there were several open tables.  The dimly lit brasseries was charming and it had a combination of sophisticated dishes and comfort food.  I appreciated that the waitress asked if we were headed to a show (since there are two nearby theaters) and made sure service accommodated our 7:30pm show.  BF had the pork shoulder with roasted vegetable and ate every bite.  For me, I had been craving a cheeseburger for months so this was my chance and it was oohh so good.  It was nice to check out a different neighborhood and I would return for sure.

SJwqSB5CF35mIRaYZEgwEQ.review_text: We sat at the bar for about an hour and chatted with the bartender.  The hostess was so attentive, and asked us if we would like a table prior to our reservation time. We declined because we were having such a nice time at the bar.   The people next to us ordered the soft pretzels.  They looked so good that we ordered some too.  They we the perfect fluffiness inside hard outside and the pared dipping cheese was divine. Once we were seated we ordered the fried chickpeas which we had smelled from the bar as the plate walked by.  This was the best dish we had.  My husband had the burger which was above average, and I had the shared plate of squid with gnocchi which I throughly enjoyed.  We both agreed that we would come back to Absinthe.

EjVRsZhNyG7vkCxVci7xHQ.review_text: Many failed walk-in attempts and longings to go to Absinthe resulted in myself and a few friends finally celebrating a birthday at Absinthe (not mine).   Woo me please, with all the hype, buzz, and top chef mania. No question that the food is going to be good, but let's see how good. The menu is not terribly vegetarian friendly but you will have options. In addition to the main menu, there is a bar menu where you can order the likes of oysters, sweet potato fries, and burgers.   I found the salad menu very pleasing and went with a chicory salad with cinnamon pecans, Gorgonzola and spiced pears. Sharing a plate of the roasted beets with arugula and goat cheese was also very good. Entrees range from stuffed chicken with pancetta & herbs to farro risotto with caramelized onions & mushrooms.   Nice cocktail list.  Be brave and try a little absinthe. If you don't know what you feel like the $8.5 glass of Prosecco is a great choice and goes with most of the menu. Another plus for Absinthe is their cheese menu (slightly over priced, but amazing selection). Order single, double, triple or grab a taste of all cheeses ($95).  Rounding up dinner with a complimentary sweet touch of ice cream and chocolate for me friend's Birthday celebration. Thanks! Good food. A little pricey (but a nice treat). Spotty service (changing or servers, and a bit slow).    ** How to drink your absinthe**: when drinking your absinthe: use the ice to chill the absinthe if you would like. Pour the ice water over the sugar cube and spoon to dilute and add sweetness. Stir and sip. (still pretty potent).

L_hQYvp2mLgs4NQbdgruww.review_text: I've been here a number of times in the past and had a few appetizers, all of which were good.  I came here on Saturday night, ordered the burger and was disappointed-  it was salty and the bun didn't seem that fresh. It was 10pm at night, so maybe that had something to do with it? My girlfriend ordered the potato-crusted salmon and didn't rave about it or didn't complain. I had a cup of the french onion soup which was great but very rich and after about half of the cup, i was over it. I'd be willing to go back and stick w/ a few apps at the bar but i dont think i'll be coming back for dinner.

4QIyUE6oV5yBoIAm73ehug.review_text: Went for a couple nice Sunday brunches. Probably one of the best brunches in the city. Their cocktails and champagne go great with their ever-changing menu.   The souffle blueberry pancakes are simple, soft and to die for.   We got an order of fries for the table. They are excellent and come with four sauces: ketchup, mustard, vinegar and aioli. mmm....  The burger was good. The house-made pickles are really good and sour.   Jamie Lauren (top chef masters) is the executive chef.

tCj3wFbLtnMcs3etQ9mW0A.review_text: Top Chef caliber! Loved the food and thought the cocktails were amazing.   The restaurant is warm, loud, friendly, and full of life. I recommend reservations for this place gets packed. Because I was a first timer my friends and I ended up just sitting outside on one of these nice summer evenings we've been having recently to avoid the 45 minute wait time. The outside was pleasant and completely dog friendly and despite being on the outskirts of the restaurant we were very well taken care of by our waiter and the other staff. I thought it was a great environment to enjoy some catch up time with friends.   Right away we ordered cocktails off their menu, most were ~$9. I thought the Ginger Rogers was great and the pleasant pear was refreshing. My friend ordered one of the Absinthes and I was pleasantly surprised at how Not harsh it was to drink. Licoricy and minty at the same time with a kick at the end of your sip.   We decided to just enjoy the cocktails over an assortment of snacks to share as oppose to entrees. The plating of the food was enjoyable in itself, cute sized portions presented artistically on their dishes. We enjoyed a wonderful cheese platter which had 3 types of cheese paired with fruit, jam, or some other garnish to enhance its flavor. The fries were some of the best, perfect crispy and came with 3 dipping sauces to make a frie fiesta. The chickpeas were surprisingly tasty, a spin of wasabi peas sort of. Tis the season for tomatoes so we had an assortment of heirloom tomatoes tossed beautifully and tasting like summer. Yum! Aside from the appetizers, we munched on their bread and butter which was just as tasty in itself.  This little sneak peak of Absinthe makes me craving for more, I can't wait to drag someone here for dinner with me!

EXKkKWAxWQAEmAWo-nL3Yg.review_text: This establishment is nothing to write home about or special apart from the name that is a little hip so i will give them that although I would cut out the "Brasserie & Bar" part which is really a waste of ink.  The only thing I do liked is the bartenders with the accent that understood my accent and had the ability to read my mind, providing a hangover worthy cocktail as well as making me a new one when I spilled it the first time.  The place otherwise is in need of a renovation. It looks desperately sad and tired. Sad cheap tiles too but the most urgent issue is the need for sound control especially in the bar area which gets extremely and annoyingly loud.  Compared to another old establishment, take Zuni, the fairly high level of noise is more charming and less annoying maybe due to the people or the cool, less desperate vibe.   The fries and food in general is also lightyears better at Zuni.

MLffhJw5cQ_eeyI1i8NUcQ.review_text: Drank the best Manhattan that I've ever had (made w/ small-batch bourbon. not usually big on cocktails but this was well-balanced and unique; not too sweet w/ just the right amount of bitterness). Still thinking about it 10 days later. yum.   Great, high-energy atmosphere. It's a retro/French-inspired restaurant-bar with art deco design. Very crowded; you have to move quickly or even fight for space at the bar. The bartender flipped drinks @ a very fast pace to keep up and ended up splashing some vodka on my poor dining companion. But all was forgiven once we took our first sips.

BJSt17AMbTi5boWT3NaMlg.review_text: Wow! Delicious food, great cocktails, and excellent service!

OjzwEyl7DSgjLxUcJeex6w.review_text: Get the octopus stew!! It's the most delicious seafood seafood stew I have ever had with an impressive depth of flavor and great textures in a rich tomato broth. I know I will be craving this dish again soon on a chilly winter night.   The baked mac and cheese side dish is amazing as well and is served in a cute little skillet. We also shared the foie gras torchon (yayyyy foie is BACK!!!) and I had a decent French 75.  The ambience is classy but not too stuffy, dimly lit and with a constant buzz reminiscent of West Village in New York. Great spot for a dinner date! Can't wait to come back to try the duck and other dishes on the menu.

VVtaIyZH1Mpq7swC5lwWnQ.review_text: Absolutely love this place. Whether you go for brunch or dinner, you cannot go wrong.  Great drinks, good food.

3uJootQ876cXOb4Q2H39IQ.review_text: Within walking distance from an evening of opera or classical music, Absinthe is a wonderful place to have cocktails and dessert.  The bar room is where I sit.  The decor is Art Deco chic, classy, and sexy.  I love how the hushed lighting, geometric patterns, and deep yet vibrant colors work together to create an ambience of muted romance.  It is a gorgeous room and when you have to powder your nose, you will be equally charmed by the ladies' room.  The drinks are simply superb.  To begin, the bartenders are just a dream to work with--knowledgable, solicitous, and immaculately mannered.  I never fail to tip them generously.  And the choices could rule the world--you have everything from the perkiest Champagne cocktails, velvety Ports and Madeira, age-old brandies, and an encyclopedic wine list.  The list of cheeses will make your mind reel and your palate as greedy as Enron.  They have everything from creamy chevre to intense blue to Swiss rarities.  As a cheese lover, I could probably try the entire selection in lieu of a real supper (which they do offer).  Wait, in France, I do believe a simple meal can comprise of cheese and fruit...  As I have always thought, nothing beats French avant-garde ideas (Enlightenment, French Revolution) and America should not snub their nose at them.  The desserts are marvelous.  Some, like the Scharffen Berger chocolate pot de creme, are tailor-made for my perennial sweet tooth.  The lavender creme brulee is intriguing with its waft of linen-clean lavender married to silky cream and sweetness.  Or try the chocolate-banana tart which comes with warm caramel sauce.  The service is impeccable.  I have come here dressed to the nines and more casual and, like most San Francisco establishments, they treat me with class and courteousness either way.  A fantastic place for a date.  Alas, the reason I can only give Absinthe 4 stars is because their main course entrees are just okay and do not match the rest of the menu in temptation powers.  It is a curious, but unfortunate thing.

e0uq-809XRqHIecAxdlgBw.review_text: Loved it! I had one of the best meals of my life here. We made reservations but arrived early to have cocktails, and were told upon arriving that they could seat us right then if we wanted. We chose to sit at the bar for a few minutes just for drinks. I had a cocktail with absinthe in it, of course, and it was pretty good, although I don't really love the flavor of actual absinthe. Oh, and I do NOT recommend having more than one of those. Especially if you are wearing heels.  For an appetizer we had the pretzel bites. It was like someone read my mind and engineered a food out of my dreams. They were so freaking delicious, seriously. If you have a secret guilty love for refined carbs and a maybe slightly less guilty love for cheese, especially cheese sauce, then you might just love these too.  For the main dish, I had chicken with some kind of filled pasta and tomato sauce. I was drawn to this dish mainly for the pasta (secret guilty love for refined carbs, remember?), but it was actually the chicken that was the best part. I can't even put into words how great it was. I don't even know what I was tasting, I just know that it was incredible.   I really really want to go back.

BBel1uYoIcRXhxgzPeg2BA.review_text: We came here around 4:15 p.m. hoping to have an early dinner. The dinner menu usually isn't open until 5 p.m. The waiter was kind enough to put in our order of drinks, ceviche, and onion soup first. The onion soup was full of flavor with lots of gooey cheese and the ceviche had a lot of creamy avocado chunks. It was almost 5 p.m. and we decided to order the prosciutto flat bread and the wagyu beef to share. The flat bread was delicious and the wagyu beef was extremely tender. The service was good and the food was good. I would come back to try a different menu.

EbtEBo_nccHifQHCABWTXQ.review_text: I love the food here, but this is what happened when I called recently and tried my best to make a dinner reservation, three months out, for a Wednesday night.  Absinthe: Thank you for calling Absinthe, how may I help you?  Me: I would like to make a reservation for [date of anticipated dinner].  A: We don't take reservations that far out.  Me: How far out do you take reservations?  A: Three months.  Me: That date is three months from today.  A: I'll take your word for it.  [You are the reservationist and you don't have a calendar?  You don't know the months of the year?  You can't count?  What do you mean, "I'll take your word for it?"]  Me: OK, I would like to have dinner that evening for 14 people.  A: We can't seat that many in our dining room.  You will have to reserve our private  room, if it is available that night.    Me: What is the maximum you can seat in your dining room?  A: 12 people.  Me: OK, I would like to make a reservation for 12 people in your regular dining room.  A: We serve a lot of people who are going to the symphony and the ballet, so we would have to work around that when selecting your seating time.  Me: Yes, I'm aware of your location.  But the symphony and ballet seasons are over by then. [And if this is a major concern of Absinthe, why don't they have the schedule for the symphony and the ballet?]  A: You will have to give us a deposit of $250.  Me: OK.  A: You will have to sign a contract.  Me: OK.   A: And you can't order from the menu.  We will give you two choices for the appetizer and entree, and you have to tell us in advance what you will be ordering.  Me: I don't think this is going to work, but thank you for talking to me.  I could not believe how many barriers the reservationist (Vanessa) threw at me, as if she didn't want me dropping $1000+ on a Wednesday night in her restaurant.  I can understand the deposit, but signing a contract?    And I hardly want to invite my closest friends to a special dinner and then tell them they only have two choices for food, and then collect orders from all of them, communicate that to the restaurant, etc.  Sorry, that's not my idea of hospitality.  So I will have my dinner for a large group on a Wednesday night at a restaurant that actually wants the business.  BTW, Absinthe was just dropped from the Chronicle's list of the top 100 restaurants.

fFC1ZgtGIQiwQsVgwaPCaA.review_text: This is a pretty cute spot with a very French ambiance, but after eating there a couple times I always walk out feeling like I paid way too much for a mediocre brunch. Today I got the granola with fruit (weird choice for me but I wasn't super hungry) and I got a bowl with 85% granola, 10% yogurt, and 3 berries total. Pretty disappointing. I probably will opt for one of the other brunch spots next time.

DNcUxYpQokysMlrcI_0mYg.review_text: Fabulous experience! One of the best meal's I've ever had! My boyfriend surprised me with dinner here for our anniversary and it's romantic atmosphere and exquisite cocktails and food were to die for! Highly recommend their Ginger Rogers cocktail, warm homemade garlic pretzels with warm creamy cheese for dipping, and the COQ AU VIN is a must try! Sooooooo good! We also ordered the Petrale Sole which was wonderful. Everything we ordered was soooo good we wished we could eat more! Can't wait to come here again!

Fr_rLfBcfvVVXkLTanrkvA.review_text: Great place for a pre-theater dinner.  Highly recommended.  SERVICE: Fantastic.  We got reservations through OpenTable, and AC indicated that it was for our anniversary.  The maitre d' wished us a happy anniversary and we were quickly seated at a corner booth just off the bar.  Both the maitre d' and our waiter confirmed that we were going to an 8pm show, and our waiter provided us with complimentary glasses of champagne for our special occasion.  The service ran smoothly, and we were able to enjoy our 2+ hour meal without the need to feel rushed to make our show.  FOOD: Everything we had was wonderful. -- Gazpacho: A simple preparation executed perfectly.  The soup really brought out the flavor of the tomatoes, and I found it much better than the more complex versions that have cucumber, celery, peppers, etc.  The fried squash blossom was done in a tempura style and was a nice addition. -- French onion soup: Just right for a cool evening. -- Steak frites: AC enjoyed hers very much.  Cooked perfectly with a hint of rosemary (?) on the crust. -- Goat cheese and leek pierogies: I was a little wary of ordering pierogies, which I think of as a simple Polish/Pittsburgh type of dish, but these were fantastic.  Nice and crusted on the outside, warm and fluffy inside, and on an excellent bed of mushrooms, spinach, and butter. -- Cheese plate: I would highly recommend the Stilton and the Perail de Brebis. -- Chocolat pot de creme: Rich, velvety chocolate.  What else can you ask for?  Ours came with Happy Anniversary written in chocolate on the plate.  A great way to end a meal.  DRINKS:  -- Domaine Allimant Laugner, Brut Rose of Pinot Noir: A nice, refreshing way to start off a meal. -- Sazerac: The glass is rinsed in Pernod Absinthe, something I've never tried before.  The drink had a little bit of a licorice flavor.  It was not overwhelming like ouzo, but just enough to make you want another sip. -- Citron lemonade: AC enjoyed this.  One of those drinks where you barely notice the alcohol.  ATMOSPHERE: Sort of a modern, French-American brasserie scene.  The crowd was everything from Young Republican (guy in khakis, a blue shirt, and a yellow and blue striped tie) to Pre-Theater Dressy (lots of suits and even a tuxedo) to Early Evening Bar Hopper (guy in a slim but not overly tight black v-neck).  Being fairly close to the bar it was a bit noisy, but not distracting.

g2hQYumU1nGsneneavMA1g.review_text: We had reservations for brunch on a Saturday at 1 pm.  It wasn't really necessary, but it was nice that we had that option.    We started brunch, with oyster shooters (sadly without the vodka).  I'm cutting down on my alcohol intake, not that I drink a lot.  I'm not sure why I ate the oyster separate from the cocktail sauce, but I did.  I'm sure if would've been better had I placed the oyster into the shot glass.  The cocktail sauce had a nice little kick to it and it wasn't tart.  The deviled eggs were delicious with the smoked salmon, roe, and capers!  I usually don't order deviled eggs, but my friend wanted to try it.  It was very flavorful, rich, and creamy.    My main dish was the smoked trout BLT which came on a buttered, toasted slice of brioche.  Two strips of perfectly cooked, crispy bacon with a cornmeal battered green slice of tomato.  It was also served with a light side salad. I tried a bite of my friend's kurobuta enchilada.  It was good and the sauce a bit of a kick.  At the end of the meal, I felt quite satisfied.    Come have brunch at Absinthe for a low key, leisurely meal.  Afterward, take a walk around the neighborhood.  It's a nice area.

OFNFtTc48LmXNk_NeZe9dw.review_text: Had never been for dinner before until a few days back, so I can now give it a proper review.   We ordered the following:  HEIRLOOM-TOMATO & MELON SALAD hearts of palm, Persian fetta, wild arugula, aged balsamic - Delish... interesting combination of flavors, but it somehow worked.   NIMAN RANCH SKIRT STEAK black garlic potatoes, braised artichokes, green peppercorn jus - Friend got this and I got a bite. It was very flavorful and tender as can be.   ALASKAN HALIBUT sweet shrimp & mussels, saffron-chorizo broth, crostini, rouille - Didn't get to try this, but I have tried food with the chorizo broth before and it is fab fab fab!  CLISSON peach jam goat's milk, sticky, creamy, fruity Union Laitière de la Venise Verte, Bordeaux, France - Creamy yummy delishciousness!  BUTTERMILK SPICE CAKE Lillet sherbet, Capricious goat cheese, pickled blueberries - Pass on this one... it just doesn't work. The spices are good... the sherbet is great and perhaps if there was more of it to melt onto the cake... it might help... it was just too dry.   PETIT ENTREMET 6. malt-milk chocolate & Guinness, smoked vanilla & lemon, carrot cake & fromage blanc - Tiny yummy morsels...   Papaya Sorbet - This was the one I thought I would not like at all and turned out to be the best one of all. It is not super papaya tasting at all. I would go back just for this!  Overall the food was great... service was good. I had a cocktail, but can't remember what it was called... I just know that it was DELISH!   This is a great place to go on a fun date (kinda loud... not for first dates... unless you really aren't into him. LOL), or to hang out with friends.

TXzjss35nJP9Q5EJ9VkYBg.review_text: Nice things first: the food was pretty tasty.  The rest: well, we were seated quickly for our not-overly-crowded Tuesday night reservation.  When our server returned for drink orders we were informed that the bar was unable to make one of their three signature ("chalkboard") cocktails. First sign of trouble.  I ordered one of the remaining two, but the server quickly returned to advise I couldn't have that one either.  (How can the Owner allow the Manager to allow the bar to to not stock the ingredients for the signature items customers encounter first during their visit?!) After that I didn't order a drink right away.  In time we ordered our dinners. After waiting ten minutes for my smallish water to be refilled, we received our tasty appetizer.  After waiting ten or fifteen minutes, at least twice more, for my water glass to be refilled, with no server visits to see how we were doing during the 40 minute wait for our food, I finally went to the bar to order a drink.  The bartender seemed nice, and I thought maybe I should have sat in the bar.  The drink, a rye manhattan with a twist, was fine, and I brought it back to the table.  I don't think my server ever noticed.  Someone did offer to bring more bread, which never came.  When the main courses finally arrived, one of my companions who had ordered Coq au Vin received a Croque Madame, which wasn't even on the menu (though it looked and smelled very good).  To the staff's credit, a Coq au Vin appeared in a mere minute or two.  I guess what I'm saying is that while the Chef is putting out pretty good food (though short of extraordinary), the manager does not seem to demand the bar stock what they put on the menu, does not demand the bus keep water glasses full, and permits an inattentive and inaccurate staff.  In a city like San Francisco, it generally means you probably won't bother visiting again.

x4gmaAEEExn2LIjTXd4Jtg.review_text: Was hesitant at first since I'm not a huge fan of French food but I was pleasantly surprised.  Martini's were top notch and the food was great.  There's something weird about eating green mashed potatoes but they were wonderful.

U9yWtQO_0LPjtaU9jN0JsA.review_text: This is just for the soft garlic pretzels with Vermont cheddar mornay ($8). Fantastic!   I know everyone talks about them and they're perpetually on the 7x7 Big Eat list but I always felt like, meh, it's just pretzels and wouldn't order them. Finally yesterday I bit the bullet and tried them for the first time.   You get 5 small chunks of pretzel bread brushed in garlic butter and sprinkled with chunky salt along with a dip of melted cheese. Seriously good. So good that it's inspired me to try to make them at home. Like this week if possible. I could kick myself that I waited this long to try them.

4m1PPtF587WIZTBlT6xh6A.review_text: Dinner at Absinthe recently. We came in without a reservation on a busy Thursday night but were able to be seated in the bar right away. You lose a bit of the ambiance sitting in the bar but the menu is the same as the dining room. We started out with Absinthe to drink which I guess is part of the experience.
