It was nothing special except a little buzz before dinner. The service is slow, but I guess that's part of the experience. The food was fantastic. I had lamb loin and my date had beef cheeks, which were fantastic. The portions are not huge but with the entree and the bread it'll fill you up. We tried the Olive Oil ice cream for dessert with was bizarre and tasted oily. I wouldn't order it again but would say it's worth a try just for the novelty. This is definitely a splurge place, but great food, great wine/drink. Overall it's a great place to impress a lady-friend or celebrate.

P_r64y7TgPbd5-KhnSctLw.review_text: Atmosphere: Very demure, great spot for a 1:1 dinner or a meal for a small group.  F&B: The food was delicious and the cocktail menu didn't cease to amaze. All of the fish dishes were prepared perfectly, and the steak looked really good (with a positive verdict from one of our dining guests). Also, I'd highly recommend the spicy chickpeas (we tried these on a whim, and boy did they pay off!).  Service: Our server was amazing. She understood the ins/outs of the menu & food allergies (specifically, gluten), and was incredibly proactive in checking with the chef if we had any questions. Absolutely stellar.  Location: Fantastic location in Hayes Valley. We ventured over to a quaint bar (Two Sisters Bar & Books) immediately following, which proved to be the perfect end to a great evening.

m1-thxlHKvy7Dg1Mwob-CQ.review_text: The food was delicious. I ordered the wild mushroom pot pie and the ginger rogers cocktail. The service was a bit slow, our waitress was kind of ignoring our table. Want to come back here and check out the rest of the drink menu.

AhQrL-2wh5aCsWdsmE27kw.review_text: While visiting San Francisco I was lucky enough to make it to Absinthe. We were seated with in a few minutes of checking in....we  also had reservations though.    The ambiance was great, low lights and knowledgeable staff. The drink menu was handed to us and was a book....it was ginormous. I had the perfect pear, blood and sand, fame and a muscat wine with dessert. The drinks were amazing!!   To start we had the warm marinated mixed olives, roasted beat salad and then Jamie Lauren's pan-sear scallops. Everything was perfect. The best scallops I've ever had.   Dessert we shared the cookie plate, the Sarah Bernhardt cookies were fabulous.  Love this place...I would love to return and try some meat off the menu.

OhFEevRThMfm1MHzi7TfFg.review_text: I've only been there for lunch on Saturdays, but I really enjoy the steak with Pommes Frites and Hamburger there.  They're both very tasty.  The dining room is nice, upscale casual and lively.  This is one of my favorite spots for a bistro steak and fries.  They are busy during lunch on Saturdays and Sundays, so arrive before 11.30 for quick seating.

U13tLFucJNz1fNv_Xgdj0g.review_text: Dude.  Oh man.  3 stars is pretty generous because the food was pretty good, but upon coming here for lunch, and being sat in the back, we were promptly greeted by... a moving "unwanted guest", as the manager put it, crawling along the side of the booth.  Totally gross.    We pointed it out to the hostess who reseated us, but didn't seem very apologetic about the whole thing (maybe she was as shocked to see it as we were, who knows).  We deliberated for a couple minutes about what to do: stay or leave?  The manager came over not too shortly after, and graciously comped our meal, which was much appreciated.  We both ordered the hamburger with fries, which was quite tasty.  Without that whole encounter, I'd give this place 4 stars.  Hoping that this was just a random incident, it's been docked to 3 (barely 3).  Ew.  Recommendation: sit in the front area, at one of those round tables, far, far away from those booths in the back.

tIs8AnbTyvmS_S7mgYRs-A.review_text: Had a late lunch here on a glorious Friday afternoon in the city; it was a nice meal.    Started with a couple glasses of Rose, followed by the charcuterie plate for me and the mussels for the wife.  Wife had the chocolate pot de creme and I opted for a dessert cocktail.   Excellent drinks and wine list; pricey but worth the indulgence. Will come back to try more menu items, but could be very happy coming back to hang out for drinks, oysters, and more drinks.

Ew5Lma8WMJpyjI-ypsmNrw.review_text: A must try when you're in San Francisco! Loved the entire night here. Check out my full restaurant review on DWAtheBlog.com. :) Absinthe Brasserie & Bar: dwatheblog.com/2014/01/2…

WYoy-T0VGq9g2UILqrLc-A.review_text: Best burger I've ever had, bar none.  Add gruyere and mushrooms.  You'll die.    Did it cost almost $20? Yes. Is it worth it though? Hell yes.  It's that good.  It was so fresh, if you close your eyes, it's like taking a bite right out of a cow.

B32R0S8kFFQ7ughP8zivJw.review_text: My wife had food and drinks here last night before a show at City Arts. We decided to sit at the bar which was crowded but service was good through our stay. Bartenders bust their butt here making all kinds of specialty drink ($10-14). Draft beers are $6 a pint and they have 4 good ones on tap. I started with an Anchor Liberty ale.    Later, we both had the Uptown Manhattan. Very good with 4 Roses bourbon, Carpano and Orange peel with those delicious little cherries! ($12). For food, started with a country pate. Good but a smallish portion for $15. It had pickled veggies on the side and some toast. We split the Absinthe burger ($15). Not a huge patty but cooked perfectly and tender and juicy. We added cheddar cheese for $1.50 more. Pricey no doubt but you are in SF, right?     Wines by the glass range from $9 to $18 and a few "library" picks at the $30 level. They focus on French and Euro wines here with just a couple CA. products on the list. Service was top notch here. We will definitely be back!

qZKiJCW-iD27LD-nq1xd7A.review_text: We were a group of 6 and had dinner here prior to a show at the Orpheum (Bourdain & Ripert!) and we were given a great table by the window. It was Friday and I arrived early (5:20pm)oand got a seat at the bar, surprisingly, bartender made great cocktails. I haven't been here in a long time but this time I ordered the Oyster Shooter (with vodka, natch), kale and radicchio salad, spicy pork meatballs.  I recall loving their Onion Soup. Coq Au Vin but wanted something different this time. Again, I was satisfied, the food was delicious and the service, terrific.

JSPE5bMOg6rAKvKVEdfIXw.review_text: Been meaning to come here, especially when my friend Jessica still worked at Arlequin, but I failed to and have no idea why it took so long! Solid ambiance, an amazing selection of gin and wine....and absinthe! Started the night off with wine, ended with Old Raj up + olives. We were the odd number of 5 that all restaurants struggle to seat quickly, after the 20 minutes we were told to wait we decided to hold out for the larger table and wait longer. Drink are easily said a good reason to delay.   Seated, with immediate acknowledgement from our waitress, we had additional drinks come. We ordered oysters (YES! The anti-seafood/shellfood protestor did slurp one!), french onion soup that was hands down the best I've had, garlic pretzels (close to trumping The Monk's Kettle...gasp!), and their short ribs, braised in pinot noir. All well presented, delicious, tender, moist. Our waitress was a split shift with another waiter, who was perfectly nice, but we missed the feminine touch. 2 hours later, 11am, we're all yawning with food comas and happy as clams. Wait, that's oysters.

_IRX4WKhIuxuC7NNHdL1xw.review_text: I came in for brunch with a friend of mine. We were seated right away and luckily we had reservations because the place got packed pretty fast. The restaurant decor is swanky. Very nice inside and bigger than I expected.   The food was alright. We both got the savory places. The bacon was SUPER CRISPY but way way salty where i could only eat one and half of the four. My friend got the omelet which was yummy. We also shared the French Toast with ricotta  and a side of berries. Very yummy. The potatoes were a little tough though. BOO!   I wasn't too impressed but it was good. I really want to come back for dinner since i've heard that's way better.

HSC_IX7an8PKdLhtDx23XA.review_text: The fiance and I went here for Brunch on Valentine's Day and had a really great experience.   To start the drinks were amazing. We both had the mimosa with fresh squeezed orange juice and grenadine which was really good!   2 highlights of the meal were the French Onion soup and the banana blueberry souffle pancakes. Both of those things were really out of this world.   We definitely will be coming back here for brunch again and hopefully to try dinner sometime.

EXLFF7M-DprDtE9PIwX_wQ.review_text: Unlike the service, my review will be short and sweet.  Our Sunday brunch reservations for 2 were made 4 days in advanced.  We arrived on time for our reservation and got our table. Then we waited.  The 3 empty tables around us filled up 15 - 30 minutes after we ordered.  When they all tables around us all received their entrees, including one that basically ordered the same thing we did...we got up, informed the staff, and left.  55 minutes should be enough time to make pancakes and French toast.  ***** Okay, over a year has past.  I have not had the urge to go back, but moving my stars up to 2.  I cannot hold a grudge forever.

-W9HDXVtCk1IlO96nzOOYQ.review_text: So many restaurants, so little time.  This is another example of a solid four star restaurant.  The portions were very large, the food was very good, and the service was excellent.  This is a very good choice for a night out in Hayes Valley.

Cs6IIZgShzOgzjDLRApmDQ.review_text: Update on 11/15/14: Fantastic meal. The duck ragout was one of the best conceived and executed dishes I have ever had. (Outside service could be better.)

saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q.review_text: Sigh!  It pains me to write review like this as, though I enjoyed the food and the company, the service just didn't cut it.  Last summer, my dinner experience made it seem that I was dining in an entirely different restaurant when our group came for Sunday brunch.  When I called on Friday, the reservationist found me a 1:30 pm slot which, given the parking situation, seemed just fine; I specifically told her that there were two birthdays and one child in our party.  Arriving a bit early, our group patiently waited by the outside tables as brunchers left the restaurant.  The host was kind in apologizing for the wait and I was happily anticipating a nice birthday brunch for some friends.  Our waitress took our drink orders as two couples were seated just behind our table.  It was strange that our coffee, lemonade, and hot tea orders came staggered over a fifteen to twenty minute period.  Adding to the strangeness was our waitress did not take our order until another fifteen to twenty minutes.  Here's what I tried: Appetizer a) French onion soup, small (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…) - Excellent and regretted not ordering a large one.  Not too salty (in fact, sweet from the onions) and cheesy good. Entree b) Absinthe Burger with sauteed mushroom and a fried egg (yelp.com/biz_photos/353b…) - Ordered medium rare, the beefy taste was strong and loved the runny fried egg oozing on the soft bread.  The bread/meat ratio leaned towards the bread side a bit. c) Duck Confit Ragout - Looking like a benedict-like breakfast meal, the flavors were good and, again, there's nothing bad to say about runny eggs. Dessert (shared) d) Strawberry Pavlova - Most tempting dessert with fresh strawberries fully in season now.  The licorice flavor was a bit overwhelming. Four stars for the food, but two stars for the experience and service.  Our brunch lasted a marathon 135 minutes, almost as long as a foreign movie, with 20 to 30 minute gaps between dishes and ordering times.  The diners from the two nearby tables arrived later than us, yet ordered and left waaay before we were done.  For me, the topper was that there was no birthday candle(s) despite my above mentioned conversation with the reservationist; we sheepishly sang "Happy Birthday" to the two guests of honor, again with no acknowledgement from the staff.  My friends didn't have anything bad to say other than one questioning about the timing of things.  Wanting to share my previous four-star experience with them, I was sadly disappointed and left with a slightly bitter taste in my mouth.

UyhnjAlyMXtbR-qB5kkhlQ.review_text: Absinthe is a cute French bistro in a trendy and fun neighborhood. Service is great. However, after brunching here three times, I've decided that the brunch food and cocktails are a bit lacking. I may come back here to give dinner a chance.  * Croque madame - $15.75 I've given this two chances, and both times it was a bit too greasy. I've had better.  * White prawn omelette - $16 The eggs were cooked nicely, but prawns were so salty that I felt like I was eating mouthfuls of salt that interrupted an otherwise okay egg dish.   * French onion soup - $5/cup, $8.50 per bowl Delicious!   * Cheese plates. Good selection of cheeses, including Humboldt Fog and Mt Tam - $9 per cheese I know I could just buy the same blocks of cheese and eat them at home for less or wait to visit a cheese shop like Mission Cheese, but sometimes instant gratification trumps frugality.   * Sangria - $10 The sangria did not taste good. I could barely taste any fruit.   * Red snapper (Bloody Mary with gin) - $10  Watery.   Note: Absinthe has no tables for parties of greater than 6.

XDQCUG6dB_NntrZNsn5Frw.review_text: Romantic. Classy. Amazing food and beverage. Impeccable service. Expensive. Try the cocktail called "casino". Take a sip and let the magic happen. A new sensational taste reveals itself as the liquid travels down your throat. By the time you're ready for another sip, you will have experienced a multitude of flavors that only a truly well mixed drink can provide. The halibut melted in my mouth like whipped butter! Fries are some of the best I've had in my life. (I can't believe that I'm saying this.) Oysters, however, were a huge disappointment. They were so teeny and bland. For $3 per oysters, I'd like something more plump. Well, maybe it's not the restaurant's fault. After all, it's not the oyster season. :( My fault for ordering oysters in May.   It's a beautiful restaurant where you feel sexy and are treated like royalty (with a tab that only a royal can afford.). We, mere mortals, should probably visit this restaurant once or twice a year. . .

MGxuBuCMXUvHR2u39TNRdQ.review_text: Great place to go to before or after the opera or symphony as it's right around the corner. Food selection is limited, but the food is good.   I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE their chocolate pot du creme!!! :)))

EguCbVaxCE8ZqyUTy93Y7w.review_text: I want to start by saying the food at Absinthe is top notch. We have been here many times and love the food. However, there is one bartender in particular who is very rude. He ruined our meal at Absinthe the other week which is hard to do when the food is so good.  The food is a 4.5 but this particular bartender is a 0.

ZHkWI9-dlnwNhBek5Ks4og.review_text: "Love this place. Never a dull moment but it is all class:-) It is one of my favorite restaurants in the city! Everything about this place is wonderful, the crowds are amazing and have met great people over there:-) Erik the weekend night bar tender is absolutely ..."

dpG3fPAiKPrQ14xnWE2rHg.review_text: I've been here twice and gotten the exact same order each time: French onion soup and a starter. I recommend making reservations because it's almost always busy. If you don't make a rezzie, expect a 20-30 minute wait.  Also, I've had the Absinthe burger too (off a friend's order). It's divine!

4CFRtiIde5WDXGWcgw2-Kg.review_text: one word - LOVE!   This is was by far one of the best dining experiences I've had all year.    From the moment we entered the restaurant, the service was impeccable.  The maitre'd was super friendly, and showed us to our table right away.  Our server was the BEST!!  He was extremely knowledgeable of everything on the menu, from the speciality drinks right down to how the meals were prepared.  Very impressive! The meal was awesome.  I had the seared scallops, which melted like butter in my mouth...fresh and light...The onion puree sauce that came with it was so decadent....  Only one drawback for us this experience was that we didn't get to meet Chef Jamie Lauren from Top Chef, which was the main reason we wanted to eat here....but as we enjoyed the experience so much, I'm sure we'll have to return again.

GABWrw5Et9jubriKwMUDbw.review_text: I finally found an excuse to come here for brunch! Shoutout to Katy I. for joining me. I've heard brunch on weekends is busy so I made a reservation on opentable but it was unnecessary since it was after 1. Parking can be tricky in this hood but I scored a sweet (free!) spot on Hayes a few blocks down.  I loved the selection of mimosa type drinks. I had a Monk's Fizz since I love grenadine. It was tasty and not too sweet. I wanted to order a death in the afternoon but since I drove I decided against it. Most of their brunch options include eggs which I can't eat so I ordered the grilled cheese with mushrooms & bacon. The sandwich was very greasy. Disappointing. The house made potato chips were good but combined with the sandwich it was too much grease/fat for me to handle. I would love to come back for dinner but I'll be extra careful what I order.

f6AIy9FfE-8wzSTKu-Brig.review_text: After months of planning, my friend and I finally got ourselves up to San Francisco to dine at Absinthe. Die-hard fans of "Top Chef," we HAD to eat here to support our season four favorite, Jamie. After several other friends had made it up to Absinthe, with rave reviews, we finally caved and made the trip north.  With reservations at 8:00, we were starving by the time we actually got to the restaurant. We ordered some appetizers and small plates to start off. I was impressed with the spicy fried chickpeas--they were something unexpected and a nice start to the meal. The escargots were pretty good, but not great. (Of course, I'm spoiled by Bistro Moulin here in Monterey and Chef Didier's amazing escargot.) The apricot sage country pate was amazing--by all accounts the best thing we ate all evening. Our entrees were quite good--she had braised beef cheeks, I had the Manchego and chorizo stuffed chicken (a great combination!). While we were tempted, neither of us had the scallops, Jamie's signature on "Top Chef"--maybe next time.   Had we ended our dinner here, this would have easily been five-star dining. Unfortunately, we stayed for dessert . . . and I hate to admit that I was a little disappointed. We ordered two desserts--the figs and the soft chocolate--and both were pretty lackluster. The figs were poached in Fernet Branca which seriously overpowered the figs, and the whiskey mousse on the soft chocolate was a bit odd.  Our service was great and with a great dinner menu--and equally enticing lunch menu--we'll probably be back. But next time we'll skip dessert.

CCuB98X_LjCts0Fno3xTJA.review_text: The drinks were superb and strong. The appetizers (especially the garlic pretzels) were delicious. I had the monkfish and would recommend it to anyone (they call it the poor man's lobster.)  A great, fun vibe, with excellent servers. I will definitely be coming back.

zFjHD-GCcf1Hat_a5iXnbA.review_text: Everything about Absinthe is perfect- the cocktails, the menu, the atmosphere and the service.  I was lucky enough to eat with three very generous people and ended up sampling a large variety of dishes.  The night started with four memorable drinks- the 21 Hayes (a smooth variation on the Pimm's Cup), a Ginger Rogers (a bitter Mojito with the perfect amount of ginger), the signature Manhattan, and the Galapagos (a Pisco based martini with grapefruit and brandied cherries) - all very much worth their $8 price tags.  We then moved on to oyster shooters (with, hands down, the best, boldest, bloody mary mix I've every tasted) and fried chick peas (imagine spicy, crunchy, mini falafel).  After that came the second round of appetizers, Garlic Escargot,  Clam and Scallop chowder, and Bleu Cheese with aged balsamic and walnut toast.  I want to take a second to recognize this chowder - as someone native to the east coast, I'd like to think I've got a discerning tongue for New England clam.  This was the best soup I've had in my life.  Ever.  Rich, tender clams (still in the shell) paired with crisp bacon, delicate, buttery scallops and firm potatoes all served in an elegant dish with a tiny fork and ample spoon.  GET THIS SOUP.  The meal just kept getting better - with main courses like Pork Confit over red cabbage, Scallops (yes more scallops) with wild mushroom and bacon, and perfectly cooked lamb with chickpeas and cucumber relish.   Desert was on par as well, every selection offering creative blends of flavors sweet and savory - olive oil ice cream with chocolate ganache and pop-rocks was interesting, but the chocolate pot was the winner.  I can still taste the coca an hour later.  We didn't make it around to the actual Absinthe, though I am promising myself a quick return.  Bottom line, you won't be disappointed.

L5rw1x2M5I3SOrZq_WAi3g.review_text: Great food, wonderful service, and beautiful presentation.   I am very satisfied with the brunch I just had at Absinthe. I ordered the Grittled Corn Cakes which were phenomenal! The hollandaise sauce was scrumptous and the poached eggs cooked to perfection. My friend ordered the biscuits and gobbled them down.  Our waiter was very attentive but not overly so. My water glass was always full :)  I am looking forward to coming back for dinner and testing out their large drink menu!

AgzHzIzC6ZHTKgker0egAg.review_text: Nothing gets me out of bed and into a restaurant quicker than two magic words....  Breakfast.  Burrito.  So it's a Sunday and I'd just gotten back from a two week road trip.    Not sure what to do so I get on the 7x7 things to eat list.  Check.  Check.  Not interested.  Check.  Ohhhhhh....soft pretzels at Absinthe.  Hmmmm....  Check the menu.  Breakfast burrito with PORK BELLY AND FRITES INSIDE!?!?!?!  Done.  Two hours later and I am eating a pretty damned delicious burrito and a drink that looks prettier than a well dressed metro dude.  It was, however, a double edged sword since after we were done, we were stuffed walking around Hayes Valley and only then saw the new food truck area by the Octavia st. park.    Figures.

TjH9gxY2jYIVrY-zlplIcA.review_text: My two friends and I went here last Friday night. We didnt have to wait long for a table, but in the meantime enjoyed some drinks at the bar. When we did get a table, we ordered the French Onion Soup, and the small bowl of warm marinated olives. The French Onion Soup was divine! The cheese was not too heavy, but soft and gooey. The bread still withheld its crispiness long after being immersed in the broth. The soup is a must for French Onion Soup fans :)  For dinner two of us got the scallops and the other had the steak tartare. The scallops were delicious and well-balanced with everything else on the plate. The Steak Tartare was quite filling, even though it looked small.   Between the three of us the total bill came out to around $100. I was definitely expecting it to be a lot more.   Overall the service was great, and the atmosphere was enjoyable and cozy. It was a little crowded around the bar, but do you expect any less on a Friday night?

_50Laiz1Z8rVLVOzCFCFjA.review_text: OMG I love this place. It just hits the spot every time.  Brunch, Lunch or Dinner - it works for all 3 occasions, which I think is rare in a restaurant.  It's a little pricey - but I feel like it's worth it and I am satisfied every time.  Their french onion soup rocks, as do the salads and the croque monsieur of course. I never get tired of Absinthe. The one thing that's not so great is their desserts, but I don't care - I shouldn't be eating them anyway.

FpOste6Fh4ppO7jol-JlQw.review_text: I came here for brunch with the BF. Wow it gets crowded at brunch time! After a twenty minute wait or so we sat down near the bar. Now I get it. Absinthe is a restaurant & BAR, but damn! These people were already three sheets to the wind, rowdy as hell, and it wasn't even noon yet. Not to mention, one of the drunk guy's gorilla ass-crack was sticking out of his falling-down-pants.  Once we adverted our eyes from the hairy butt, I ordered the grilled vegetable sandwich (not sure the specific name, but it came with chips!) and the BF got the sausage & egg dish on brioche toast. We also got a side of the rosemary potatoes. I loved my food and his toast and the potatoes! We are planning to come back to try the stuffed french toast. and I cant wait!!  In short,  Love Absinthe, Annoyed by drunk people.

u3kC1ktQox0G2wvptVBurw.review_text: Perhaps I just went in with my expectations too high. I'd been told that Absinthe had delicious brunch. The food was fine, and the service was fine, but nothing that great.  I ordered an americano and the omelet. The omelet had nice flavor, but the eggs weren't very tender and the onions weren't sliced fine enough. The accompanying potatoes were delicious.  The waitress was good, but one particular aspect of the service seemed pretty unsophisticated. I'd ordered an americano, and the assistant server kept trying to refill my cup with coffee. I dodged him a couple of times, but he got me when I wasn't paying attention a third time. It was nice that he was so attentive, but he should've known what I had or at least remembered that I'd said no thank you.  So what do I like more? Well, I love brunch at Foreign Cinema (could take or leave their dinner) - they have one of the best omelets I've ever had (consistently).

8dbcwwaw-gvJ2TWqJPtlMw.review_text: Not much to say that hasn't been said.   Brunch service was exceptional, the staff was as attentive as possible without being pushy or distracting.   We Ordered: Duck Confit hash, 2 of the wild mushroom Omelets and the Warm Biscuits and Gravy.   'Just Right' portions of amazing food.

-bT32tHNq7ngqZNA4Tr8jA.review_text: I've wanted to try Absinthe for years-literally years. They've been around since the 80s. I was a bit disappointed when I finally got a chance to check them out the other night.  Ambiance: Mr Q and I were crammed into a small table close to the bar. It was very noisy and waiters were rushing back and forth chaotically. Not romantic.  Prices: Um. Not what I would call reasonable for a "bistro" type restaurant. $14 for a small salad ? $14 for a plate of brussel sprouts cut into quarters? I don't mind paying for great food but at those prices it should be spectacular if you are paying entree prices for the appetizers.  Food:  I had the Quince salad ($14). There was something horribly salty in either the dressing or salt had been applied liberally to the finished product because it was extremely bitter/salty. I asked Mr Q to try it and he couldn't taste the salt so when the waiter came by I didn't mention anything. Mr Q took another bite and said "WOW..I just got a mouthful of the salt you were talking about". Sigh.  I also ordered the Sea Scallops ($30). I joked with Mr Q that I'd probably end up with 2 scallops on my plate. WRONG..I got THREE. Woo hoo! They were cooked well but they were supposed to come with braising greens. There were no braising greens present, just mushrooms and pancetta.  Mr Q had the Beef Cheeks ($26) and a side order of Brussel Sprouts ($14) that we shared. If I ever came back here, I would probably order the beef cheeks since it actually seemed to be a substantial amount of food. The brussel sprouts were OK to me but Mr Q expressed disappointment.   We shared a chocolate Pot De Creme for dessert ($9). It was good. I also ordered one cocktail called Velvet Hive that was delicious.   Service:  I hate it when waiters ask if you are ready and when you're not ready they don't come back for another 20 minutes. We saw amuse-bouches being brought to other tables but did not receive any ourselves. We got our appetizers in a decent amount of time but it took *forever* for our entrees to be served. Then there was a delay clearing our plates, and yet another delay after we ordered dessert. I had finished my drink midway through dinner and the waiter waited until after our plates had been cleared to ask if I wanted another one. At that point it was too late.  Since Jeanty at Jacks is closed, I'm still on the hunt for a cozy French bistro type of restaurant. Absinthe did not fit the bill.

dr_mce0J8Q-BLLOA23KuAQ.review_text: Popping location in civic center area. Feels old school but not stale like your dad's favorite old restaurant might. Dim lights. Definitely a young crowd.   We started the night with the pork meatballs. These had a decent amount of flavor, stewed in my favorite San Marzano tomatoes and topped with grated grana padano. So italian and so savory!  Then we had the french fries with the sweet onion aioli. These were well cooked and crispy, without being too crunchy. The aioli was delicious.  The cheese plate was nice, and our waitress did a great job picking the right stuff to fit our requests.   For my main, I had the coq au vin - red burgundy wine-stewed chicken. Mixed with bacon, chanterelle mushrooms. Served on perfectly-toasted crostini. The flavor wasn't the richest coq au vin I've ever had, but it was very tasty.  I also tried the local petrale sole, in the meyer lemon sauce with brussels sprouts. This was light and fresh, but not overly-memorable.  Finally, I had a piece of the steak with criminis, creme fraische whipped potatoes and black garlic jus. This was also nice, but not overly-memorable.  Where the food lacked a little punch, the service more than made up for it. Our waitress was very attentive, kind, and accommodating.

5wRCMyU9dEdkja_mO0qfeQ.review_text: Came to Absinthe a few weeks ago as part of a group of six.   We had reservations on a Saturday night and they were able to seat us right away which was good because the bar was pretty packed.   But they were up for the challenge.     Since there are over 2500 reviews as of my writing, dear reader, I'll be brief.    Service - top notch.   Everything was well paced, we never wanted anything and when we were getting close to needing anything, someone would stop by the table to help.   Awesome job.   Bar - Order something, anything, and it will come out nicely.   We all ordered drinks and were very happy with what we had.  In fact, the birthday gal, my wifey, asked our waiter for the bartender's favorite gin based drink.   Moments later he came back with a drink that tasted like slightly spiked lemonade, it was strong and fantastic.   Great job.   Food - Awesome!   We all ordered different things, pork, chicken, beef and fish.   Wow.  We all loved it.   It was great to share and taste the flavors of each dish.   What a great job.   Appetizers and desserts were great too.     Atmosphere - it's a little crowded and a little noisy.   But when a place is this good, it's no surprise everyone wants to come here.     If you are anywhere nearby, try it out.  Stop by, you'll be glad you did.    Will I be back?  Heck yeah, can't wait to my next visit.   Great job folks!

DKmUukETiMVidu548TE-zw.review_text: Okay, so I am the kind of person who'd sit next to Obama, elbow to elbow, in Waikiki, and watch all kinds of fans coming by asking for autographs while I only worked up enough courage to take a picture of his calves and a small part of his back. For years I had to persuade people that it was really him, and not just some random guy relaxing in a hotel bar that may or may not have been the President.   So needless to say, however much I watch Top Chef and rooted for Jamie Lauren to win, I wouldn't dare in a million years to come to Absinthe just so I can talk to her in person.   No, I came here because I hear the food is good and my friend wanted to take me out for my birthday at a nice brunch place. And you know what? Most of popular brunch restaurants in SF don't take reservations and I have never felt it justified to wait for an hour for some fluffy French toast, no matter how fluffy they are.   Absinthe was crowded when we arrived! Not sure what symphony/ballet/opera plays on early Saturday afternoons, but almost everyone there was above 60, dressed nicely. The place looked very old-school and I felt classy.   I thought I'd skip the boring usual breakfast stuff and ordered the deviled eggs instead. something different. it had smoked trout or something on top, with a pinch of caviar. For $16, I get 6 halves of eggs. All were too salty, and not quite filling.   My friend had the smoked sturgeon (apparently both of us were in the smoked-fish-for-breakfast spirit) and crostini. Smoked sturgeon came in thin little strips, and didn't have the bright red color of smoked salmon that I am used to. I didn't ask her how she liked her dish, but for about $15, she didn't looked stuffed either.   So we got a side of scone with home made preserves to share. The scone was alright. It was kinda crumby and the cranberry jam was fine, but nothing spectacular.   Overall, it was quite expensive for brunch, about $50 for two. And I didn't feel wowed. Maybe I should have stuck with the boring usual french toast.

2dPE2x2ILv9-IkndQwo1vA.review_text: This place is still one of my favorites - started going there the year they opened and just went last week and had a stellar dinner - not to mention delicious champagne cocktails by the ever fabulous Raoul! The menu has been updated since my last visit, I was afraid I'd miss something, but was instead faced with too many choices I wanted and not enough of us to sample everything we wanted. I did not expect anything earth shattering from the Gazpacho - I expected good - but DAMN!! it took Gazpacho to a new level of fresh and beautiful for me. Caesar salad and Coq au Vin delicious, as expected. Trout canape also delish - corn salad (can't remember the right name) was  just superb - and Brown Butter Ice Cream, shut the front door!!!  I can't say how much we ALL enjoyed ourselves - great service too from 2 servers, a back waiter and a food runner...and a very lovely woman at the front door. (long blond hair, pretty accent) Lush velvet booth in the dining room - convivial vibe in the bar - How does Raoul (and a helper) handle that many people with grace and panache when at other places the bar-keep keeps you waiting with far less action at the bar? Give that man a raise :)

D2setZ2_pKZ9CWEb0IgrOQ.review_text: Have completely fallen in love with the Absinthe brunch -- nice, if slightly slim, selection of Frenchified brunch fare, including the adorable French coffee-in-a-bowl thing that never seems nearly as delectably hang-over curing when I attempt it at home.  Most of us had omelettes -- nice, if a bit bland -- in addition, an amazing fruit plate w/ figs, berries, and a vanilla creme fraiche that I seriously considered slathering on everything edible on the table -- and as mentioned, pretty banging coffee.  Our waitress was super friendly, gave decent suggestions and was 100% hitting on the man friend with which I was dining.  An adorable place to lounge away your Sunday, and am looking forward to returning for din!

bHllTE4zEeRihvx5vUZl0Q.review_text: One of the best decorated restaurants I have ever seen with great atmosphere and great service. Our server (Ting) was really attentive and friendly at all times and made a difference to our experience. The food I ate was more of a 3 star experience but with Tings service I am more than happy to round up.  The Onion soup was very tasty and was better than the Onion soup we had in Bouchon the day before. I had the Scallops with butternut squash which were good, I thought the Scallops needed another 10 seconds in the pan and the butternut squash was ok but the texture was too similar to the Scallops.  The Hamachi crudo was very tasty and a very good option as an appetizer. The skirt steak was ok, I've had much better steaks but the green peppercorn jus was tasty. My friend had the Rabbit stew and they said if was very enjoyable. Judging by the bones being licked clean, I reckon thats an understatement.  Desserts were very strong and very rich. The chocolate pot was very rich and decadent and the creme brulee was very good too.  For the food and service we received the total was $140 with no wine and this is very well priced for the level of food and service we received.

dOsIIVVfgiDevGZLWaPnTg.review_text: I am a huge Top Chef fan, and Jamie fan...so the bf and I had a little pilgrimage to the city for our anniversary.    We had a wonderful dinner - but I am looking at the brunch menu thinking I should have come back in the morning!  Next time....  I think that the menu is put together oh-so-perfectly.  I loved that there was a dish that included braised celery....hmmm, confronting her enemies perhaps?   Scallops were the shit, and it was nice to actually get to reach through the TV screen and taste the food I had been droooling on for weeks and weeks prior.    Cocktails!  Wow what a unique list!   Oysters - simple enough, and a great set up.  We also grabbed a small portion of the sauteed crab - a little rich but wow was that some sweet goodness.   That squash puree soup - I think she may have done that one on the show (or something similar) was a party in my mouth.    The booth we got was ever so romantic...perfect ambiance and lighting. Thanks for an amazing date Absinthe!

kZJWAY828P8QZTqVYzhTCg.review_text: Absinthe pays homage to Ernest Hemingway's novel & the cocktail he invented of the same name, "Death in the Afternoon." I've spent many afternoons completely knocked out after particularly libatious Sunday brunches, but I've been more nice than naughty this month, forgoing (some) sugar & (many) cocktails; My rendezvous with "The Green Fairy" will have to wait, but I anxiously look forward to it.   This past Sunday, I had a reservation for a late brunch with the BFF at Absinthe. We were led to a corner table with tons of privacy & a great view of our tres chic surroundings.   Foods: - "two eggs any style" for me: a quartet of perfectly buttery eats--soft scrambled eggs, roasted potatoes w/ a dash of onion marmalade, toast & thinly sliced grilled ham. Simple & flavorful. - egg whites over fried pork on tortillas for the BFF (can't remember the exact name.) He was very happy with his meal. - we shared brioche french toast with a spiced mascarpone & apple maple syrup. So fluffy & not too sweet. Highly recommended for the table. Total: $42  It's very cool that Absinthe has not let it's popularity get to it's head (have you seen the crowds? the wait? the nearly 1500 reviews?!) Not a hint of snottiness or impatience (from the host or our waitress) that I've seen/experienced at equally bustling restaurants. Five stars for their service.   Sidenote: the brunch online menu differs a little from the actual menu (i.e. no fried green tomatoes, which I had my heart set on.)

TWAoZh2LMrL7wEadofab0w.review_text: Excellent food, staff, cocktails and ambiance. Great burger, too. What more  does one need?

zieFgZfbaA_6-5v06nOQZg.review_text: Went here after the SF St. Patrick's Day parade.  We were marching with the Irish Wolfhound Club.  Host came out and rearranged the outside tables to accommodate our group of 5 plus one giant wolfhound. Staff then appeared with a dog bowl of water, score double points!    We started with cocktails and oyster shooters. I split a hamburger, meat from Marin Sun Farms, yum.  My husband had the shrimp sandwich loaded with flavor. Croque Monsieur was ooye gooey cheesy goodness.    Service was impeccable.  Sometimes the outdoor diners suffer but not here.    Bring your pooch and sit outside you won't be disappointed.

XcWmZ6BTXyiEGL6lofBAbA.review_text: Man, this place was the haps.  No keep reading, I don't actually say "the haps" i mean, who says that? Lame  Anyway, I took the girlfriend here on a date, because she'd been nagging that we haven't gone out in a while. After spending time searching for the right place that was Michelin starred, she threw a wrench in my plan and chose this place. So... we went.   The food was very tasty, I got the duck and the portion was ok. The tartar is a must and won't give you the runs. The drinks were nice and strong, and the service was great. It gets incredibly crowded so if you're ok with random dudes standing in the middle of walkways with zero regard for surrounding space, this place is for you.   I'd come back, this place was the haps.

OaRk-RwFEzfOtc45ff0fGA.review_text: I always feel like it's a waste when dining with a friend to both order the same thing (because you don't get to try as many things!).  A lot of orderer's remorse has resulted from this, and a little bit of that occurred here.  There wasn't anything special about my omelet, and the toast was perhaps a bit too toasty.  My friend's duck dish was taste-tastic though.  I wish I could tell you what it was, but it's been over a month since we went there and they have since updated their menu (sorry!  that'll show me to delay the writing of my reviews!). It felt overindulgent to be offered dessert for brunch, but it was the best part!  The creme brulee with berry reduction and shortbread cookie was quite...perfect.

af3BXGK9-cqBK6vyRPDFrg.review_text: Still 5 stars but they changed the menu and remved 2 of my favorite dishes.  It is still a must visit every few days.

YlJNqoHqIssCHP25h2sUFA.review_text: There's so much can be said about Absinthe but I'm going to keep it short and sweet.  Great location for drinks and dinner, especially prior to the opera or symphony as it's so close.  They're used to that rush so they'll make sure you're in and out on time.  Great food...always consistent in their service.  I recently came here for brunch for the first time on the recommendation of Rachel F and I was not disappointed.  Some of the best bacon I've ever had!!  This is a place where I can come again and again.  It's consistent and always an enjoyable experience.  Check it out if you've never been!

Vy5TLaSTsFvdXb6QZdGn2Q.review_text: My wife and I took a nice, kid free weekend in SF and tried Absinthe on a Friday night.  We were trying to decide between going here or Jardiniere, which is around the corner.  We chose Absinthe. We were going to make reservations, but were told that the earliest available time was 10pm.  So, we took a chance and went down there anyway at around 7:30.  Hoping to get seated sooner as a walk in. We lucked out.  We put our name in and waited for about 20 minutes before being seated.  Nice.  Dress code is casual.  I saw everything from cocktail dresses and suits to jeans and baseball caps.  Take a taxi.  Parking, like everywhere in SF is a challenge.  I don't live or work in SF,  but if I did - I'd toss my car off the Golden Gate Bridge and never drive again.  Again, we lucked out and got a nice table that was somewhat private.    Absinthe gets a lot of the "Opera" crowd, so the best times to go, I assume, would be during a show time.  This is probably why we were seated so quickly.  Looks like it gets real busy before and after the shows.  Anyway, the bar area was packed and lively.  We chose one of the cheese plates for an app.  It was great.  The French may be ready to wave the white flag and ridicule people who do not speak their language - but, they do know cheese.  Sorry to any French people out there, but it is true.  You know it.    My wife ordered the french onion soup, which I tasted.  The soup was insanely good.  For dinner, I got the Absinthe hamburger.  Okay, now before you start yelling, "You idiot, you ordered a freaking hamburger at a high end place like Absinthe!?"  Let me tell you, it was one tasty morsel of a freaking hamburger....and, believe me - I know hamburgers.  Trust me.    Further, I had a dirty Martini that was very good.  My wife ordered a fancy mixed cocktail that the waitress recommended, that was equally great.  Also, there are plenty of nearby stores, etc. to walk around after dinner.  We want to go back again.  Soon.  Great place.  Great food.  Just avoid the "Opera" hours."  Enjoy.

b_OZlXCsj5t-wx2pgpaRjw.review_text: I took my wife here for dinner last night, following a daytime performance of Wicked - sufficed to say, it was a special occasion - and Absinthe lived up to our expectations.   We decided since it was early (5:30 pm), we'd take our time and really savor each course. We started with a half dozen oysters (2 of each of the west coast variety). They came with an Asian inspired mignonette that was very good - the oysters were of the highest quality as well.   Next, we had the French onion gratinée. One of the best onion soups I've had. Ever.   We followed that with the Green garlic flatbread with fava leaves, house-made ricotta, ricotta salata, lemon oil. This was a great combo. I especially loved the house-made ricotta. Overall, savory and delicious.   Moving on to the mains... I had the Slow cooked pork confit with butter beans, bacon, wilted nettles, roasted tomatoes. I can't say enough how great this dish was. The pork was done just right, and what fat was left on the meat was amazingly flavorful, and just melted in your mouth. The butter bean, bacon and nettles that accompanied were also very tasty. i enjoyed this dish so much, that I just finished eating the leftovers for lunch... just as good the second time around.   My wife had the Pancetta-&-herb stuffed Mary's chicken with Brussels sprouts, fingerling potatoes, lacinato kale, roasted shallot sauce. This dish was also great. The stuffing was actually between the breast meat and the crispy skin. Not what we expected, but still really great. it seperated the flavors quite nicely. Roasted shallot sauce and the spouts really added a lovely finish to the dish. I will be having these leftovers for dinner.   The sommelier had suggested a great red wine to accompany both our dishes, and met our price point - Domaine Gallety 2005 Ricolte.  We noticed it's distributed by Kermit Lynch, so we will definitely see if we can get some from his shop.  We finished the night with the Scharffen Berger chocolate Pot de crème  with crème chantilly . This was delicious - the perfect ending to a perfect meal.  Although Jamie did not win Top Chef, her skills are definitely amazing, as was proven to us last night.  I will definitely be returning for more!

WDsr8RnPqbceR3s2yZYr3Q.review_text: Came in a group of 5 and ordered a ton:   Cocktails! - French 75: "mike's hard champagne?" A fruitier harder champagne than I'm used to.  Recommended if this description pleases you.   - Mujer Verde: roughly translating to "dirty lady" this one's taste was, um, true to its name.  Liked it but felt like I needed a cigarette and a shower afterward. - Ginger Rogers: the most popular drink, it's basically a ginger mojito.  A really good ginger mojito.  My fav for sure.  Apps! - Oysters (the Japanese name ones): super tasty, but pricey too at $3.50 each. - Those spicy chick pea thingies people on Yelp liked.  Good but not great, especially when compared to: - Garlic Pretzel rolls or something: these were the WINNER.  Turns out that soaking hot soft pretzel dough in oil butter garlic and salt makes for a really tasty appetizer.  Reminiscent of the (in)famous garlic knots at C&O Cucinca in Marina Del Rey in Los Angeles.  Oh yeah, they also served these with some cream sauce that we kept around and dipped the regular bread in... so yeah, that was pretty bomb.  DO IT. - French Onion soup: like the other Yelpers said, it's money.  We got the larger portion, which they split for us.  But EACH of the "'halves" they gave us were large enough (and of course rich enough) to split between two people.  Full frontal dishes: - Pork Osso Bucco: this was so tender the person who ordered this proclaimed "never has a knife been more superfluous."   She was right.  We ate this with spoons.  Just fatty and rich enough and a generous portion too. - Absinthe burger: the meat was just good, but when served with cheese and egg, it became downright magical.  (Two of us independently proclaimed the cheese and egg to be most virtuous.)  - Sole something: this was super mega tasty excellent according to the person that ordered it.  Desserts: HFS save some MFing room in your prissy little Francophile stomach, because it's TFing worth it.  Why did I just attack France?  Anyway: - Chocolate pot de Creme: as you'd expect a creamy thick chocolate pudding is really tasty.  But this one gets the slightly-darker-than-usual balance just right for a winning combo. - Black forest cake: this was the SURPRISE WINNER.  Now, going by the name you'd expect this to look like well, a slice of well, cake.  It didn't.  It looked like a supremely perfect choco wafer cookie.  I don't know exactly what they did, but somehow they combined frosting type stuff, cake type stuff and crust type stuff in such a perfect ratio that any cross section of this thing you ate came out perfect with just a hint of satisfying crunch.  They also served it with pitted cherries that looked fascinatingly like pitted olives, some toasted almonds, and a pleasant surprise - moderately tart cream that was a perfect balance of the perfect chocolatiness that was the "cake"' / stick thingy.  See photo, it'll make more sense.  Service was excellent, and it was fairly pricey overall, but pretty awesome when you consider we had a full dinner at 11pm.

_79am2d41qLN90WXgUefSQ.review_text: If I could give 3.5 stars, I would give that to Absinthe. I went back here for a second visit about 1 week ago and the entree disappointed me. I came here with 2 friends and we got 3 cheeses to share, 1 beef tartar, the mushroom pot pie and the absinthe burger to share.  The cheeses were excellent. Great appetizers and you really cant mess up on cheese. The restaurants don't even make the cheeses, so Absinthe really cant take credit for this dish but I'll give them credit for having a good cheese buyer.  The beef tartar was decent. It wasn't the best I've had, but it also wasn't the worst I've had. The beef was cut a bit thicker than I would have liked, but the flavoring was decent.  Mushroom pot pie was a huge disappointment. It looked really good and my friends and I were excited to try it. However, in the end it was just a glorified mediocre cream of mushroom soup inside of a pie. My friends and I weren't fans.  The famous Absinthe burger was another disappointment. I always hear people talking about this burger so of course, I had to try it when I was here. We got the burger and added the smoked guyere cheese to it. The burger was bland and nothing special to rave about.   Excellent service. We had a fantastic waiter with a wonderful personality.    All in all, the food was ok, but Absinthe does have excellent service and ambiance.

Hw2SRN8V8Py3CbIubdkxjg.review_text: Great vibe, good atmosphere, cute interiors. We started with the Cheese plate, which was delicious. Service was a bit slow but our waitress was extremely nice and sweet.  The oyster shooters (we got it virgin, without the vodka) but the spices in  the Bloody Mary mix was perfect!   Then we moved on to some scallops, which was also good, I liked the green garbanzo beans, balanced the flavors of the plate, and gave it an aesthetic touch.  My dinner plate was the trout, it was deboned and pink inside. Perfectly grilled and crisp on the outside, but the inside flavor wasn't too memorable.  I think i recall it tasting a bit like salmon.  I was drinking the Cava all throughout. I think it was very pleasant, we sat right outside, and I liked watching all the patrons coming in and out of the place.   I think it wasn't too memorable in the sense that I feel like I've had these plates everywhere else. It's a nice neighborhood joint, but not anything too outrageous or intriguing.   Worth going if you are on a date, or just grabbing a pleasant dinner before your movie.

RbZ_yOCZjYE675izT3Oymg.review_text: Brought a friend from out of town here for dinner.  We each got something different to sample.  (refer to Stephen H's review) Everything was good, but nothing was memorable.  So, i'll give it 4 stars.

O3epMWdW0mzuLk4aGQ18nA.review_text: Consistent quality in food and service.  burgers always good.

V5dipYFRtJYThwHnSUEPHQ.review_text: I have been looking forward to visting Absinthe, and finally made it for a late brunch on 8-18-12. I was not disappointed. Our waitress was fabulous, very attentive, even though the bar was packed .  The wine was great, pricey, but expected. As an appetizer we tried the garbanzo beans, fabuloous, I would come back for that alone! I ordered the smoked trout open face sandwich.I am not eating bread or chips, so mentioned it to the waitress, she was phenomenal, she offered suggestion in place of the bread and chips, and then spoke to the chef who refined it even more.  In place of the bread I had a delicious giant heirloom tomato slice and a lovely salad instead of the chips. The meal was great. My friend had the  black bean pork mexican dish. He enjoyed it, but  said there wasn't enought pork for his taste, nevertheless he  liked it very much.  My friend had the strawberry sorbet and capucciino to top off his lovely lunch.  We left very satisfied and eager to return to this GEM.

C54Hm4nC9ZphqXj5XDGtTQ.review_text: Menu has improved drastically since I first tried Absinthe. Now one of my favorite restaurants in SF.

-2mdZhSzWmFdujk6zYLwFA.review_text: Yum. Thought I was coming for brunch, but it was lunch haha. But, it's cool.  Lunch was good. I got the daily special pasta. Very fresh and tasty.  I also had a bite of the passion fruit panna cotta from my friend who got the dine about town prix fixe special.  It was BOMB. They also took off the macadamia nuts for me because they didn't want me to die, which was really nice.   I must come here not hung over for brunch so I can eat some good grub and drink some absinthe cocktails.

Fe_9lLtiKrGSIBEky36kWA.review_text: The food is good sometimes, but the service is crap always.  The last 3 times I have been there, service has been horrific.  No matter how good the food is sometimes, it cannot make up for the poor service.  There are many great restaurants in SF and I'd rather spend my money where the wait staff is polite and attentive.

ot3m-jIwFMFFCMG1bkLZgQ.review_text: My friends and I came here back when Jamie Lauren was the executive chef hoping for a taste of her scallops. har har har.  It was after a day of wine tasting in Napa, which I regret as our taste buds were basically burned out.    I had the trout with vegetables, while my friends had lamb and the other a halibut with a sauce and vegetables.  The trout came in whole fish form which I noted as unusual, though not bad.  The vegetables were excellent.  We all enjoyed our food as a whole, but I wasn't as wow-ed as I hoped to be.  In a city of culinary goodness like SF, I probably will try some of the other restaurants on my next trip.

XtviyjItNG5QzrSE_sE6cA.review_text: I recently went back after not having been to Absinthe in several years. Both of the dishes we ordered, the Coq au Vin and the Pork Tenderloin, were amazing. We skipped dessert but I did enjoy a truly outstanding latte before running off to the theater.

42-eIb7z-ZLr2oNrDomWiw.review_text: When I came to Absinthe on me vacation to SF I was very excited to be eating at Top Chef contestant Jamie's restaurant. However by the end of the meal, I wasn't as happy as I was hoping I'd be. Don't get me wrong, there was nothing wrong with the food or the service but it just wasn't anything more than "A-OK". I had the french onion soup which was actually the best thing of the night. For my entree I had the lamb shank. It was good but nothing out of this world. Overall it was pretty pricy for just and OK meal.  I think i'll have to go back sometime just to make sure it wasn't a bad night.

puYmrcccLvW3EnKDFNqSmw.review_text: We went to lunch at Absinthe before the show at the SF Symphony Hall. The restaurant has a wonderful atmosphere and ambiance. They were very gracious to merge two reservations into one.   The waiter was very attentive and made great recommendations. We had a crab sandwich, the "pork" special, steaks, and burgers. Everyone was happy with their dish. I had the crab sandwich and it was delicious, the pork was tender and the hamburger was juicy. We brought the wine and they charge $20 corkage fee, the max is two bottles per table. We find the food a bit overpriced, more likely we are paying for the location - so close to the Symphony Hall.

uZdFsE_aHbFBChgN6Xa8tw.review_text: I came here for BF's firm cocktail and appetizer hour before Wicked (which is a couple of long blocks down the street).  They rented out the room on the right side and the restaurant is at the corner on the left.  They have tables outside too.    The ambiance and service was pretty good.  The lamb sliders were good.  The tuna tar tar was good.  The fromage and cuts were ok.  The mushroom risotto tasted like barley.  Creme brulee was pretty good.  The chocolate cake was not that good.  The bruschetta with goat cheese and fig was pretty good.  Probably my favorite.  Their signature absinthe drink was not so good (maybe b/c I don't like licorice tasting drinks).    Would come again for a real dinner.  However, only one hour and half max for cocktail hour since I started to get dizzy since there was no circulation in that room!  No air, no circulation so I had to sit outside for several minutes.  They crammed like 40+ people in there with no place to sit and no ventilation whatsoever!  Other than that, this would be a good place to go to dinner before the theatre.  It's even closer to the symphony, which is just around the corner.

msx_dW71evibaOzjLoEyrA.review_text: Can't say enough wonderful things about this place. Fun ambiance with craft cocktails, some of the best oysters in SF, and a consistent amazing menu.

GE64PcKGFWo_W49PWPb1JQ.review_text: My wonderful partner brought me here fro dinner before treating me to a fantastic SF Symphony performance.  The food was good & the drinks were mostly pretty awesome...so why 3 stars?  Star deduction 1 - price.  To be perfectly honest, Absinthe is pricey but not TOO unreasonably so.  However, when you are 2 graduate students, these prices can at time approach ridiculousness.  The 2 of us ordered 4 drinks, fries, 2 entrées & 1 dessert for a total (after tax + tip) of about $140.  You be the judge.  Star deduction 2 - service.  When we got to the restaurant, the head host/manager sat us immediately but he didn't look at us & all he said was "follow me."  I wouldn't think twice about this if I hadn't seen him treat other patrons totally differently - smiling & chatty!  What about us makes us different?  Our waitress treated us well but she definitely paid less attention to our table than to some of her other customers.  I had a great time & a good meal (hope the boyfriend felt the same way) but the experience could have been better.  We would consider Absinthe again for special...really special...occasions & for their hot dog (it's featured on the 7x7 list).

lqDaxpZQBXZDEkJ890GYOw.review_text: didn't expect it to be anything special - but everything was actually really good! we got the soft pretzels, beef tartare, a salad, the swordfish, and a side of brussel sprouts. i think the beef tartare was the highlight for me, and it's something i would actually go back for

1tObli6sTFk4iyAN9A84rA.review_text: We went here on Sunday at about noon and I was immediately thrown off by the service. Upon entering we were rudely shunned since we didn't have a reservation (on a Sunday morning? Do people do that?) I was told that it would be AT LEAST a 30 minute wait and that we would still have to sit in the cafe. Not like there is anything too abnormal about all of this but it was just the attitude.  We decided to go to Stacks down the street. I was looking forward to throwing down around $20 for breakfast when our friend arrived, very disappointed. She said she had heard so much about Absinthe and would be broken hearted if she didn't go. So we went. And got a table. In the cafe. 45 minutes later.  After all that we were seated and waited about 10-15 for a waiter to come and take our drink orders. BS at a restaurant like this. I didn't even want to drink but the menu was so tempting I ordered a champagne and white peach puree mimosa. Pretty unexciting for $10. Though I do want to come back and try some of their other enticing drinks.  We started with the deviled eggs - they were OK but could have used a lot more smoked salmon and caviar and a lot less egg. They were $16 for 5 halves... come on, don't skimp!  Next my sister and I split the burger with mushrooms and the duck confit hash thing. Both were pretty good to OK. The burger wasn't spectacular. Duck thing was interesting although I never tasted any duck.  My friend got the French toast with spiced apples and this was by far the best thing on the table. Seriously amazing. Although soo sweet it was more dessert than breakfast. Yum.  So all in all.... I expected more. Definitely expected more from the service. When we left the hostesses just looked at me and I had to say Thank You to them! Oh and I love Top Chef and Jamie seems cool so I wish it had been better though, and I really wish she would have come out to great us.   Oh and $45 for breakfast is just wrong.

n7h4oo9rSMpIf-yoQvkROA.review_text: First time here for Saturday brunch.  Surprisingly unimpressed.  The meal started out hopeful with a tasty french onion soup.  But it kinda plateaued after that.  I had the croque madame.  The first few bites were good but it was too rich and greasy.  My date had the duck confit ragout which sounded more amazing on the menu than it tasted.  Again, it was very rich.  Overall, I don't think the food was bad but I was expecting more since there are so many rave reviews for it.

Yi_zEiDF0Xdj8VsosumjPA.review_text: I only ordered desserts. Chocolate Creme was monotonous and boring. Apple pie with creme fraiche ice cream was underwhelming and flavors didn't work. I was very disappointed.  Also, all the drinks tasted like cough syrup to me.

zUGNL2kbzomjtB9YMzpY6g.review_text: I wasn't prepared to like the joint as much as I eventually did when we first arrived. Something about the restaurant looks mysterious and chique from the outside but when you get inside it falls of, slumps, and reminds me of a cheesecake factory.   But lets not get lost on the details of ambiance. There are real gems on the menu(s) and we should first start with the cocktails... Ginger Rogers WE LOVE YOU... reminds me of a Gin Gin Mule, probably the same thing from that famous bar in Burma, the Galapagos was terrific and had a wonderful character. Nice selection of Absinthes on the menu of course... The Wonderlust was delightful and made me want to sing I'm a wonderlust king by Gogole Bordello, briefly that is.   Oysters, we stuck to the local fare, Tomales Bay and Point Reyes and they didn't disappoint, neither did the charcuteries plate that was piled high with various cold cuts, pickled goodness and other sundries. All in all I kept thinking to myself, this is good, a 3 star affair, but when the entree arrived we went up a notch as I began to scarf down my own duck leg confit and my girlfriend's braised beef cheeks. The waitress was right, it's not beef cheeks, its bloody beef butter! Soft, fork tender, rich and wonderfully topped with vidalia onion strings this was the right hook I was hoping for.  I've heard good things about their breakfasts, I'll have to try that one day, but for now I'm quite satisfied with their dinner.

VlVx6clfF7iZfO_idvuMfA.review_text: One of my good friends is a huge Top Chef  fan, (as am I) and after having a great dinner here awhile back, she decided to have her bachelorette dinner here last week.   Since she raved about this place, I was eager to try it.   We started with some fantastic cocktails, which they have a huge variety of.   We shared escargot, beet salad, and french fries. All were fresh and delicious. The bread was fan-freaking-tastic too.  Of the eight of us more than one of got the scallops, and lamb, one person had the duck, and one had the burger.   Everyone raved about their food.   I am not normally a huge fan of scallops, but after remembering that Jamie Lauren was known for them, I had to order them.  So glad I did!!! They were cooked perfectly, the sunchoke puree and spinach was wonderful. The flavors all worked so well together. It was also the perfect size, I am a big fan of restaurants that actually serve real portions and not mammoth plates of food.  The dish was absolute perfection. I savored every mouthful.  It was so good, I was kind of sad when I finished it.   For dessert we shared: TCHO pot de creme, the cookie plate, and a cheese plate.   The pot de creme was luscious, and being the fan of cookies that I am, I adored the variety of mini cookies. All were fantastic.   Even though this place has a hip vibe, and they were busy, it wasn't too loud to talk, which I think we all appreciated.   It is a little pricey, but they serve local, organic, and sustainable food, (not to mention high quality) and you have to expect to pay a little more for that.   Service was good, waters were kept refilled, plates were cleared efficiently, and drinks were replenished when wanted.   All in all ,a great dining experience. I will definitely return at some point.

O4UcQIKyjeg6KcbAiM37Zg.review_text: Love Absinthe for both brunch and dinner. Can't go wrong with any food choices here and the bartenders really know their stuff.

VfAfrBGohcjD_CRCwuKz6Q.review_text: We went to Absinthe for a business dinner, though it's really more of a neighborhood corner bistro type place.  Regardless, I had an excellent meal.  I started with the Lyonnaise salad, which featured a perfectly poached egg at its center and was perfectly dressed.  I only mention this because cooking an egg and dressing a salad correctly are basics that so many restaurants screw up.  Despite many other appealing options on the menu, I felt like a burger.  It was very good.  I really liked the abundance of grilled onions.  The German chocolate cake for dessert was kind of a deconstruction (of course) of the original, but still very good.  If I lived in or near Hayes Valley, I'd be a regular at Absinthe.

VfZ62dxri2CxsSBXgrzqsg.review_text: I've eaten dinner here twice since moving to San Francisco and both meals were exceptional. In fact, the first one was the best dinner I had since October 2010 in Chicago (yelp.com/biz/sprout-chic…). It's not cheap, it's not fast, the service is prompt yet cold. But the food is phenomenal. Coq au vin on a chilly SF evening? Heaven.

SGuh6KBUNF34sdTFaJntBg.review_text: I've only been here once for dinner and grab drinks a bunch of times. Not bad. Cool when it's sunny and you can sit outside.   I have affectionately referred to Absinthe as the "home of the high dollar steak dinner." It was good. And it was high dollar.

8kgQupO4TS2bpCGSPhTTIg.review_text: Came here for my little sister's birthday brunch and we had an amazing time. Everything was good, and the service was impeccable:  My family started with the local mixed greens to share. Let me start off by saying that my parents are lettuce and mixed green snobs. They go to the farmers market weekly to ensure that their mixed greens are the best of the best. My dad eats the mixed greens plain (no dressing) to fully experience the mixed green taste. Anyways, we were blown away by this salad. Granted it's only a simple salad, but everything was so fresh and so delicious. Definitely get this.  Between the 5 of us we tried the portabello grilled cheese, duck ragout, and a few other dishes. All were good, but the duck ragout is the one that stands out to me the most. Delicious chive/potato cake, poached egg, and (lots of) duck. So good.  Anyways, all in all, this was the perfect place for brunch. I will definitely be back!  Be sure to make reservations. This place gets packed.

1Oa4dj8Bcmtf5178NO7U8Q.review_text: My Bf & I came here for our anniversary dinner. Made a reservation and got seated right away. The ambiance was romantic and dimly lit. I love the interior. Our waitress greeted us with a smile throughout our dinner. She was very nice and attentive. I enjoyed myself with a glass of champagne. We each ordered the french onion soup (got the cup size and it was enough). It was very delicious and one of the best we had. Very authentic. I had the potato crusted artic char and my bf had the duck confit. The fish was moist & delicious. The salad that came with it was very yummy. I like the vinagrette on the salad. My Bf love his dish a lot. It was very tasty. Looks just like the photos posted on yelp here. For dessert, we ordered the strawberry panna cotta and when it came out, it was written "happy anniversary" on the plate. That was nice. The panna cotta was delicious and light. My Bf had coffee and it was good strong coffee. Altogether, the bill come to about $85. We had a $50 gift certificate from a friend and used that. Overall, we had an awesome anniversary dinner. The service was great and so was the food. Will be back again to try other dishes. Or better yet, stick to the same dish since we love it so much :) GO LOOK at my photo I post up for the artic char (4th page). No one else posted a pic of it and looks like I was the only one. Very delicious!

cP-UyxlDAJuOTUdrerySGQ.review_text: I don't really know why everyone likes this place so much. I mean it's ok, but nothing special and it's always packed and hard to get into. I've eaten in the bar and restaurant now and both times is sorta eh...I say don't bother.

w1lHu6I_xLDKHMXc4Cv5ig.review_text: If you're stuck in the fog of San Francisco and would much rather be in Paris, come to Absinthe. From the French posters, to the small tables outside with the classic French woven chairs, this restaurant is great.  The sommelier patiently helped us pick out a nice bottle of Chardonnay, Keenan.  I hadn't heard of it before, but now seem to see it everywhere.  It was a solid suggestion, especially since we debated which bottle we'd get.  We started with the flatbread, and escargot.  Both were succulent and delicious.  The flatbread was equivalent of an Indian naan, and the escargot was drenched in butter - and honestly, what is better than that? The best entree that we got was the beef cheeks, which I ordered.  Oh my sweet little baby Jesus! I've never had beef cheeks until now, but they were SO tender and tasty.  The chicken and the lamb were also great; however, everyone unanimously agreed that the beef cheeks were the best!  The food is great, but the decor makes the entire experience even better.  The cocktails are great too, and they have a fantastic selection of liquors.  I'm definitely looking forward to trying brunch here - I've heard it's awesome too!

2nE0zU6y_F7gkwHi3yL6cQ.review_text: Would I come here again? Only if the check wasn't on me. A friend drove here and since parking is difficult in SF we grabbed valet.   I came here with a friend and the check totaled $150+  Cocktails:  Galapagos Cocktail. Rating: 3.5/5 Old Havana Cocktail: Rating: 3.5/5  Food:  Selections of Cheeses Liberty Duck Breast Colorado Lamb T-Bone Niman Ranch Skirt Steak Grapefruit Sorbet  Overall, the food was decent. I came for the drink Galapagos since it was featured on 7x7 100 Things to Eat before you die, and yes, I was disappointed. I do not think I will be coming back to eat here.

_ziHXR2ue19G4DpDYTHtwA.review_text: I've wanted to try Absinthe for a while and finally made it in today!  We showed up around 4, killing time in SF. We thought we'd just have a drink or two, but wound up snacking a little.  I ordered the French Onion soup - something I always order at *brasserie* type places. Oh my - it was really, really nice. The broth was complex - meaning, both of us kept taking little sips wondering what we were tasting. Was there a teeny hint of tomato? Vermouth? It had a slight sweetness, but it was meaty also... It was good. My drink was a special called a Halo. Honeyed vodka and candied jasmine. The sugar rim was jasmine-y. I'm a rim licker, whenever I get a drink with a sugared rim, I try to lick all the sugar off as inconspicuously as possible. Jasmine sugar?! Shut the front door!  My friend is a cheese making fool and ordered the imported French raw sheep milk cheese and swooned over it for an hour - she's a slow eater, and the longer she takes the better it is. She also ordered the Halo, but found it too sweet so ordered for her next drink some cucumber concoction. I did not like this - cucumbers, meh.   I'm so happy to have made it to Absinthe in Hayes Valley!  Oh, and our waiter whose name I didn't catch, was a low key sweetie.

TLiv7pKzS1ruZ4rD1ZzhJw.review_text: Walked by Absinthe one weekend and we noted to ourselves that we would come back to try this place. Mike made a reservation for 4 on a sunday and the earliest reservation they had was 2pm but we decided to go with the flow (afterall, that's what rainy sunday afternoons are all about!).   When we arrived, the place was still packed (it remained that way throughout the whole time we were there). The atmosphere is charming. With it's art deco floor, it reminds me of a speak easy french bistro (if there is such a thing). We weren't seated until about 2:30 but the bar was a nice place to chat while we waited for our table.   Their brunch selection isn't huge but we all enjoyed what we had. I had the ricotta french toast and mike had the standard american breakfast (eggs, sausage, toast). Our friends had the absinthe burger and the mushroom omelet. The ricotta french toast was fluffy and the ricotta filling was perfect with the fruit compote,whipped cream, and syrup. Yum, it was like dessert for breakfast. Mike's brunch was also pretty good-the sausage is house made and was really tasty.   The dessert, the chocolate tort looked amazing and it was huge! My only complaint was their tea was a bit bland. I should have gone for the coffee!   Great place to have brunch with your friends or even on a date. I can see why this place is a local favorite!

ABlSOquUAEYSUvySN0AeXw.review_text: Great place for after work drinks and great food. We had reservations and we were seated immediately upon arrival.  Ordered the scallops, 3 large scallops in a potato puree with fava and chick peas was the perfect appetizer. Perfectly cooked and nicely seared even Gordon Ramsey would be happy!  Next was the Artic Char which arrived hot and perfectly prepared with a slight golden brown crispy edge just the way I like any pan seared fish.  Server always had a smile and was very attentive but not overbearing, always making sure our drinks were topped off.    Presentation was great, portions were perfect and the menu has something for all. This definitely will be a place I return.

L-Yn8yfik3DvNdiJKUZWMQ.review_text: Best fancy burger in city.  Pretzel bites and martinis are good pairing.  Delivers always.

rVHSNa7tzfz4L0J4YqyjvQ.review_text: 4.5 stars  Absinthe happened totally by accident and fortuitously. We were headed to a wine bar several blocks away and then someone spotted Absinthe and said we should go there. The deal was sealed when we realized we were right in front of an open parking spot!  We shimmied up to the bar and started contemplating drinks, then were approached if we'd like to get a table in the dining room instead. I have to say everyone was as nice as you'd expect in a 5-star establishment. We were dressed in jeans and jackets, while everyone else in the restaurant at the time was 20 years older than us and wearing formal jackets and ties. Oh well, the staff didn't treat us differently. In fact, our waiter was excellent. He was deferential yet casual, and even made a few jokes as the night progressed.  The drinks are quite tasty (and of course you have several options with absinthe). I had the Peju, which was smooth and tasty. The brut champagne is also one of the best that I've had, and I'm not particularly a fan of sparkling.  And the dinner? The food is very good. I'd say the weakest part was the cheese plate (I can't remember which cheeses we got, but one of the goat cheeses is extremely pungent and difficult to palate). The fried chick peas were quite good, though kind of simple with Indian spices. I had the pappardelle, which was well-rounded and very filling. The lamb and chicken were also well flavored; everyone was happy.

_2XCMm2_FsEW5lqHULuAaA.review_text: This place is awesome. The atmosphere is amazing, the food is great, and the service is even better. We were greeted at the door, and given a table right away. We ordered the pretzel bites to start off, and they were the best pretzel bites I've ever had! My main course was the osso bucco. The meat just fell off the bone, and the seasoning was spot on. All in all, the bill came out at around $140 for two people. We got drinks as well, and they were as good as the food. We will definitely be back!

xT7RQksnkdGnDiu9EiPsWw.review_text: This place came highly recommended from a friend so for the fancy dinner the BF and I planned for SF, we chose Absinthe.  We were a little weary because it was SO loud in the front and the bar was PACKED but we were seated in a quiet area in the back in this round booth.  I ordered the Duck breast and he had the filet.  I loved my dish and he loved his.  We both thought we ordered the better meal - agree to disagree.  Mine was better.  The duck was perfectly cooked and I loved the citrus touch.  For dessert I ordered a brown butter panna cotta with a moscato d'asti.  LOVED IT.  Even he loved it and he doesn't like desserts.  I'd definitely recommend this place. Good food and a cute setting

JnGjZVSlfCkKHErvO5ts4g.review_text: I had hoped my 2nd visit here would've been better, but unfortunately not quite so.  Came here for a Dine-About-Town lunch, but decided against that meal since the first course (butter lettuce or french onion soup) and dessert (sorbet) lacked appeal. Instead I had the Pork Confit sandwich and was quite pleased with the portion size. The homemade potato chips that came with the sandwich were slightly salty, but were crispy and delicious.   The pork in the sandwich was tender with good flavors. And the wilted greens accompanied well with the confit. As a stand-alone dish, awesome. As a sandwich, bad idea. Even though the bread was grilled, the grease from the pork and greens turned the sandwich into a soggy mess. Picked up the sandwich, grease ran down my fingers and hands. Took a bite, grease gushed into my mouth and down my chin. After that, ate the sandwich with fork and knife and avoided the soggy bread. Overall, the sandwich was not a very enjoyable experience. And my stomach agreed.  Service was slow. Friends who ordered the DAT meal waited long for their courses. We saw the server with desserts. But just as he approached our table, he turned away. Few minutes later, a busboy came over to clear our dishes. Then we waited. *Tick tock* The server returned with the desserts only to turn away once again. He came back with spoons but without the desserts. Errr. Took off again, and minutes later, finally desserts on the table.  If I do ever come back, I'd like to try their brunch. Hopefully 3rd time's a charm.
