wr1_WjqJ_IvY9KuAVAe7Cw.review_text: Went here before the symphony at 7:30p on Friday - waiter was good about asking if we were going to a show and getting us out in time. We had made reservations awhile ago.   I'm pretty sure their menu changes...that being said...  We had 4 different types of raw oysters and they were all very fresh, varied from each other, and clean (no shell pieces, thank goodness...)   Their pumpkin bisque was yum, lemongrass flavor came out as well as a bit of spice. I'd say this was a 4/5. BTW, complementary bread was so good, the carb avoiders I was with ate more than 1 slice and loved on the butter, as well. Marinated Mixed Olives were great! Fennel slices with the olives. Had many different types and they varied in texture and flavor. Yum. I had the coffee crusted liberty duck breast which was very flavorful (little too flavorful for me) and a bit chewier than I liked but still very good. My friends had: osso bucco (had a taste and by far the best of the 3 entrees) and steelhead (healthy choice tasting...)  We had this squash cake for dessert that was very good. The cake didn't taste like squash and had an interesting outer crusting. It came with bourbon ice cream (which one of my friends insists on being really good -- thought it was sweeter than I liked) and some other cool looking things that tasted good. Coffee was good, as well.   Hung our jackets close by to our table. It got busy and someone that worked there took our jackets and began walking away before my friend caught her to let her know those were ours. She must have been confused. You may consider just keeping your jacket with you.

Rgpxl8b2F1W5JaMfEPw5uA.review_text: Great wine and cocktail list..... Wine list really caters to people that dont want to blow their cash on expensive vino...prices were pretty reasonable. I have not eaten here in years...and it appears that the new changes are really good. They have a wonderful new chief who has great skills. The ambiance as always is great: Busy hustle bustle fun.

whxFLzaFkvLTIhWzI5FcRA.review_text: Company party last night in the private lounge.  Love their food.  The mini burger is very yummy, and tuna tart (if I remember correct).

2uBbhf4dHL54V9sDNkyWRw.review_text: We had a perfect late night meal at Absinthe which started with some very smooth martinis at the bar while we waited for our table.   We shared the mac and cheese which was delicious. It had a nice crust but the mac and cheese was perfectly cooked with a creamy cheesy balance.   I had the coq au vin which was definitely not the coq au vin your French grandmother would make. The ingredients of the dish were combined after cooking each individually which allowed each component to be perfectly cooked.  The chicken was perfectly cooked, the bacon pieces were crunchy. The pieces of veg were still slightly al dente. The sauce had an amazing velvety richness albeit a bit on the salty side.   My partner had steak which was perfectly cooked and very tender.   The sommelier also recommended a perfect bottle of red.  When the waitress said she was sending the sommelier over to help with our wine selection, my heart sank a bit - am I going to have to pretend I actually know what I'm talking about when it comes to wine!? But she was awesome. She was super friendly and just asked some basic questions: red/white? Full bodied/fruity? How much do you want to pay? She brought over the perfect bottle of red and explained the history behind the vineyard. We loved her! And well done to Absinthe for having a female sommelier!!!  The service was top notch. Very friendly and laid back.  Our waitress was awesome. It was my friend's birthday and she brought out ice cream with a candle on top.   Super fab restaurant!

V1ra0vxOSalQADQKi1TCLg.review_text: This place is always good... I'm a regular here for their duck confit hash and the french toast is ridic...  Try the bellini & the deviled eggs if you get the chance!

J23PQGUK4f9BlVVI502VfA.review_text: Let me start by saying I LOVED this place and will definitely go back.  As I sit here to review, I can't think of one thing that would reduce it from 5 stars to 4.  Seriously, I do not have a single complaint.  We walked in on a Sunday afternoon (in November) right at lunchtime and figured we'd have to wait - it's not very big and has tiny tables - but were pleasantly surprised when a couple of seats opened at the bar right after we walked in.  I ordered a Bloody Mary and the Levain French Toast.  The Bloody Mary was good, though not the best I've ever had.  Bonus - I could definitely taste the alcohol.  The french toast was wonderful.  It is made on an artisan bread and then covered in currants and slivered almonds.  The honey maple syrup was pretty light given what it is, and was the perfect compliment to the tartness of the currants.  It comes with butter but I didn't even use it because it was not necessary.  I didn't think I was hungry but it was so good I finished all three slices.  I switched my drink to my very favorite - a sidecar.  It's an old fashioned cocktail and sometimes bartenders do not know how to make it, but this guy did not disappoint.  My companion explored a few of the specialty drinks and overall was pleased with the flavors of the drinks she chose.  The one thing I wish we had ordered - and will definitely order next time - is the Spanish Coffee.  It's a specialty of the house and we watched the bartender make several of them ... it looked divine.  Go.

gSZ_PvKBmdsnW0EOuaq3IA.review_text: I'm conflicted about Absinthe. On the one hand, the bar, on a recent Saturday evening, was vibrant and full and good fun. The drinks were interesting (especially the absinthe-infused concoctions, like the "Sacred Heart") and the bartender was attentive and witty. It's a good spot for observing the activities outside on Hayes Street, and it has a really cozy, intimate brasserie feel.  On the other hand, the restaurant proper feels a bit stuffy, the crowd is older, and the room is slightly peculiar in its layout. (I found myself making weird eye-contact with other diners near our table, because of the configuration of the tables.) The food is good, if a little bit pricey. (I had the Steak Frites - good, though not the mouth-watering meal I had been anticipating.) And our server was inconsistent, quick to take our drinks order, but then she disappeared without telling us anything about the food menu - and I had to hail her over later to order our main courses. Surprising, in a place that clearly aspires to be a high-end eatery.  Summary -- I'll be back for drinks and people-watching in the bar. For dinner, there are better choices. (Indeed, there are even better French Bistro choices in San Francisco.)

fqfROIXNBnIOvMkp2We-Fg.review_text: Overrated. Still reeling from a disappointing dinner last Friday. Absinthe has been on my to-eat list as some friends had mentioned that it is always "consistent"- a characteristic that's not an easy feat for any restaurant, so I was intrigued. Too bad it was such a letdown.  Was excited to check it out with a girlfriend for dinner after work. She was at the bar for 1/2 an hour before I showed up. Wanting to pick up her tab as she had been waiting for so long, I was surprised that it took what seemed like forever for the bartender to even walk over and acknowledge me (what if I had wanted a drink?) and even more surprised when she told me she had waited at least 15 just for him to lay out a cocktail napkin and greet her. Here's a beautiful single girl sitting at the bar, ignored when it wasn't even that busy! He's an older bartender who may just be numb to everything. Didn't seem friendly, no smiles, a barely-heard 'thank you' as he dropped off the check. I gritted my teeth as we headed to our table. What a start.  Highlight of the evening was the warm hostess...and the runners/bussers. Once we got to our table, service was spotty at best. Our first server was just...blah. Took forever to take our order, busy handling the adjacent table of men who were seated after us, as I jokingly asked if it was because she liked them more than us. A few cordial exchanges, order-taking...then just like that, poof- another server took over out of nowhere for the 2nd half of our night who was just as unmemorable. I don't know if the staff there is just complacent given it's always steady and busy there.  Just goes to show again how much service contributes to an experience. I eat out all the time and let's just say it's rare for me to cringe this much thinking about how much we spent on a so-so meal (though the garlic pretzels were the highlight) and so-so service. Also I lost street cred with a friend who had trusted me up to that point to always pick great spots..up to this point.

4uhpiOBNzIUZLqh7bskj_Q.review_text: Came here for a dine about town lunch and wasnt so impressed over the selection. but......  what few items on the menu they had...nailed it. My gf and I started out with the french fries; crispy and sweet with the onion aioli accompanying. And by far, order the Croque Monsieur. The mix between salty ham, rich gruyere cheese and toasted bread is to die for. Yes, this 'lunch' plate is pretty damn heavy and  leaves you in much need of an afternoon nap afterwards. But it something that will keep you coming back for more.

O9iVmgS_hPtNd887LDBctw.review_text: I've loved this place since first trying it almost a decade ago when I moved here.  I still remember that first French Onion soup, it was amazing. And even after my expectations for the restaurant scene have risen over the years, Absinthe continues to maintain its status as one of my favorites, as evidenced by me still loving that soup years later!  The restaurant service here is solid and the food is always good to very good, there's rarely a disappointment on either end.  I recommend their filet mignon, it's solid.  Their cocktails are famous and there's a reason, I even have one of their cocktail books at home.  The bartenders are phenomenally skilled and professional, and its a labor of love for them to create every cocktail as a little work of art.  You just have to be a little patient for them to not rush their craft.

5JSCIxhAJKjp8KXgtM2fUA.review_text: Amazing !!!. The food is getting better. I came here a few times. The food was just so so for the last 2 or 3 times. But last night I ordered the same food, Black Angus Bistro Filet, it was just tasted totally different. They must changed the recipes, or they changed the chef. Anyway, I love it. Good service too.

0vO0jNvxJ-AwRiqY6jvWCA.review_text: Overall this place was ok. There's was nothing tooo spectacular about the food. From the reviews I read, I thought I would expect a little more regarding the food. But the service was good though. Our wait staff was very attentive.   Would I go back? Probably not especially since I don't live in SF. I prefer to keep my car mileage low.. =)

Dbq1m-h1FMEdqN0UjFS_DA.review_text: Kuma Moto Oysters, Ricotta Stuffed French Toast, and Absinthe's Bloody Mary's are amazin'ballz --As what Perez Hilton would say! I love this delicious restaurant! I would eat here all the time if I had the $$$ and if I want to start wearing a moo-moo. Before I get carried away in my obsession with this place, I should comment on the star ratings for food, service, and ambiance. (jackin' the style of the last reviewers comment)  Four Stars -Food :Scallops- were tender and scrumptious, but the pairing of the greens made the plate a little mushy & didn't have much depth. The other dishes that I have eaten here: Ricotta Stuffed French Toast (5 stars)..super fluffy and thinking about it makes me turn into Homer Simpson (mouthwatering style). If you decide to get the oysters...you must get the Kuma Mottos! They are creamiest oystas that I have ever had...super DELISH!   Service- Bar staff, Waitstaff, Hostesses, and kitchen staff are extremely efficient. E.g. -Quick, Knowledgeable, and they bring me simple syrup for my sweet tooth for cocktails (needed for the Pear Cocktail)  Ambiance- 3 Stars...I feel bad giving 3 stars, I just wish it wasn't so damn noisy and that's someone complaining with a deaf ear! haha Other than that, the decor is French bistro feel and cozy! PERFECTO!  Fin

7MV6BOi3tXSMTodHTMc_cg.review_text: We were surprised! This restaurant is always very busy every time w try to get some food before symphony.. We finally decide to make a reservation. The food is really good. A lot of flavor in one dish. We will be back again to try other food.

-2BL_elUiIHEtldlHgwvbQ.review_text: It has come to my attention that my "review voice" is  not representative of my actual speech.  Thus I will try to make this review "less clever".   Friend and I went to Absinthe for brunch at 10ish, we saw that the place wasn't as packed as expected, so we went to Le Boulange also on Hayes St and waited a while for Absinthe to fill up so that it would be less awkward for us.  We got croissants and coffee there and then headed back over to Absinthe at 11ish.    Things we ordered: - Mimosa with grenadine (the grenadine was a nice touch but it didn't taste too much better than ones I have made at home) - French onion soup (super cheesey, soggy "croutons", but good with the bread they put on the table) - Croque Monseur (crunchy ham and cheese sandwich, ate like 2 bites of it because I was too full by that time) - Mushroom omelet with herbs (nice and fresh tasting, friend was impressed)  But probably the breakfast item I liked most was the croissant I got from Le Boulange before we went to Absinthe.  Absinthe would be better for a nice dinner, rather than brunch.

xFsX2ySUNCOIGfNTNYiPMw.review_text: Came here on a saturday night around 7pm. There was actually no wait, so sat down immediately in the corner, which is fine with me. More privacy. Decor is really nice and there are a lot of mirrors around my sitting area. I guess that is a good thing?  Anyways, my boyfriend and I decided to split the food since we both weren't that hungry. So, we had the scallop and clam chowder (highly recommend this). Even though the serving was really really small, it was good enough for both of us to try just enough without getting full.   For appetizer, I fought hard with the bf to get the escargots. Since he is defintely not a fan of that, but still manage to stuff one into his mouth.   Lastly, for the entree, we decided on the pork confit, which was very favorful.   We were actually both really full, especially for me since I ate a whole order of escargots!!

oHgFEYuxCs9KDmYZ55qHOA.review_text: First time I came to Absinthe was for drinks thirteen years ago and I recall the charm of the decor and the French brasserie vibe.  Last weekend, I came back for brunch and the charm is still there.  And the food was great.  The morning bun was light and flaky (although a bit pricey at $3.50).  Bloody marys were delicioso and paired perfectly with the eggplant panini (w/ bacon added - a must!).  Their famous burger with shoestring fries also did not disappoint - esp with add-ons of gruyere, grilled onions and mushrooms - although the accompanying pickles looked old and unappetizing.

a0G4ZMN2jScFevRzzLafCw.review_text: Over the years, Absinthe continues to please me. My most recent dinner included the winter pumpkin soup (tasty), the escargot (eight hot, fat snails with buttered toasts on the side), a few bites of my father's scallop and clam chowder (with bits of bacon), and the lamb loin entree. My mother's pan-seared scallops were great, too.  We tried the vanilla tomato dessert for shits and giggles: one of those unconventional desserts in which you have to keep tasting it to decide if you like it or not. Vanilla ice cream, white cream, and slightly salty, soft cut tomatoes. We finished it all, but I'm not sure we had reached a decision on if we enjoyed it or not. Exceptionally odd and quite interesting.   Absinthe is a perpetual favorite in Hayes Valley.

58Z5WJQc7LHLj0tgVt0UVQ.review_text: Great food. Great atmosphere.  We had such a nice time here and will definitely come back next time we're in SF. Highlights: -the french onion soup -the curry soup -coq de vin

1IEjfmsxU05v-NBOs0NFkg.review_text: Nice place to sit outside and have a glass of wine and meal on a sunny day. Food is always decent and service is great. Place has a nice old school vibe to it. Its very high class yet no one freaked out when my drunk date started knocking over chairs and eating food off of someone's plate. Everyone laughed it off. The manager said good night with a huge smile on his face. Amazing.

M-6CNwptNAOb8Uvck59ZSw.review_text: Our party of 2 ordered:  Beet salad garlic pretzels  2 ginger rogers (cocktail) 1 absinthe  Osso buco Lamb with pasta  pot de creme winter squash cake 2 coffees  Total with taxes and tip $175  We were greeted abruptly and seated promptly (had a reservation). Service was wonderful throughout the evening.   Beet salad was DELICIOUS. Garlic pretzels were tasty but left us wondering how an $8 order of pretzels can be lacking in presentation. They were merely "nuggets"- same look as the ones at the mall. The osso buco was a bit dry. The lamb surprised us as we were expecting a piece of meat, not what was basically pasta with lamb bolognese. The chocolate pot de creme was smooth and rich (although we swear it used to be made with a darker chocolate which we liked better). The winter squash cake was boring. The saving grace on that cake was the filling that tasted like cheesecake. Coffee was decent.   All in all it was another good experience at Absinthe. Our impression of the current menu was "boring". Everything seemed to be very similar and we missed the excitement of a creative menu.

8nZ3Ku4yC5HJxY_m0WFsGQ.review_text: Absinthe has become my new go to spot for drinks or a quick bite to eat. I absolutely love their Perfect Pear drink! Considering the quality of their cocktails I think many are reasonably priced at $11. The crispy garbanzo beans are also a must for anyone who remotely likes beans. I've also been here for brunch - options are bit limited for a vegan but you can get: (1) garbanzo beans, (2) side of potatoes with onions, (3) fries, and (4) one time I was there they were able to make me a full salad also with garbanzo beans.

YrAvAU68l_A0X6n6XHhH-w.review_text: Delicious Delicious Delicious cocktails.  These people know how to use their pisco, rye, and the like.  Great neighborhood spot and I was disappointed that I only got to try a cocktail, but the food also looked great.  Hard to get a seat at the bar on a Saturday night.  Oh Sanny Franny, you're so crowed on weekend nights!

wo352zBi6mhqU6hCwNOg-w.review_text: Had a great time here with some friends for dinner.  The place has a very "clubby" (social club not Vegas club!) feel with dark wood accents. Very atmospheric and classic.   This sense of "classic" certainly extends over to the food as well. It's a very steak frites + martini type of place, done exceptionally well with solid service.  Would be great for taking the parents out!

yWJdCruWP2Z1V8hsiT5JQA.review_text: The restaurant was REALLY loud on a friday night, so I would recommend it for a quiet date night spot.  The food was good, but not 4 stars. I say this because the steak I got (ribeye) was over cooked, grisly, and more like something I'd get a diner. It tasted well marinated and the rest of the meal was good, just not anything to rave about. The corn soup was great, but I expected more a of kick from the jalapeño creme swirled on the sides. The tuna tartar was very salmony and have little additional flavors. My dates potato crusted salmon was much better and very moist, this was the best of the meal.  Overall, probably better for friends drinking than fine dining.

C0fNn8my4xNPqFJ5MzboBw.review_text: I love this restaurant.  The food is really delicious.  We loved it so much and decided to rent the private dining room to host our wedding dinner celebration and we absolutely loved it.  The room decor is adorable and unique.  The event went great, all of the staff were really friendly. Definitely had a positive experience from the booking and all e-mail communication to the end of the event. I will be coming back to this place for a very long time.

dlsa-RdLTm3pGkpu_tKU2w.review_text: I dined here on the first night of my vacation and had a nice experience. I love the exterior's charm and the rich color and decor inside too. The absinthe menu was impressive (for obvious reasons).  I had the summer squash and corn flatbread, which was VERY good and light. It was well cooked and not overdone and I devoured it within 2 seconds because it was so good. I also got the frise salad and enjoyed it too. The house cured bacon was amazing and it was well seasoned without being overwhelming.  The restaurant has a lot of regular customers, which I think says a lot about it. Overall, a good experience!

zIDUDgoHsfvsi8oS8QlgIA.review_text: I love Absinthe. I'm happy to go here anytime, for any reason.   They have great food, amazing drinks, the staff is nice- its a reasonable price, and I just love the place.   My husband says they have the best hamburger ever, and I'm a big fan of their brunch. While I enjoy their "dinner" menu, I much prefer their bar menu.   its especially fun late at night, too ;-)

Wlb-k9jXifJHotEhiAcRRg.review_text: Came here for dinner on a Thursday night.  I had the petit filet with asparagus and ordered the charred cauliflower to share.  The food and service were great.  Maybe if the tables weren't so close to each other we could have enjoyed everything without constant interruption from fellow diners.

LNU_DfbZKT6WkRKYnrV7iQ.review_text: I would actually give the bar and maître d a ZERO star that's what they deserve. She was the rudest person I have ever come across. She was not at her post when my mother & I enter the bar. There was no one waiting so when a table opened in the bar, we sat down. They made use leave because we did not check in and sat a group who entered the bar 15 minutes after us at the table. We came here because we had a great dinner a few months ago. This will probably my last visit to this establishment and I am a ballet ticket holder so I frequent these establishments regularly.

3xhIAIzNPhFAp24U3oCB1Q.review_text: Duck confit for breakfast? Yes, please!  Add poached eggs with bernaise? Now we're talking!  The duck confit ragout was yum-o, but portions were a little skimpy.   BFF Princess Ryan opted for the pork confit with black beans, tomatillo salsa, and tortillas. It was also tasty, but he agreed that the duck confit was better.   Go before 11 am to avoid any lines.

nvtFXpBauOcS-i0fMxRdIg.review_text: Finally came here after seeing this restaurant pop up so many times in my Yelp searches. Boyfriend and I came here for brunch and we ordered the 2 most popular items on the menu - the ricotta stuffed french toast and duck-confit ragout. We were a little underwhelmed by the food, given the hype of the restaurant, as well as the expectation of ordering the most popular items. It was just... ok.  Service was great though! We made a reservation because it was for 11am on a Saturday, but it wasn't crowded at all inside when we walked in. As for ambiance, the decor is nice... just wish it wasn't so dark, for a meal like brunch.

uSCYNal_CJDPGBYUAenyoA.review_text: The food here is fantastic. But I think this is a $$$$ dollar sign place and not a $$$ when you're being honest. Even paying corkage fees instead of buying bottles of wine we didn't escape for less than $80 a piece on the bill...all said and done.    But the food is amazing. This weekend I had the Coq Au Vin and my date had the duck. Amazing, especially the duck which involved BIG hunks of duck breast. I didn't think there were ducks big enough for what was on the plate. So...yeah I want more. And it was so savory, like the beef of poultry.   Our server--Kimberly--was awesome! And I told her I'd call her out by name. She was helpful, knowledgeable, conversational, and cool. I like it when servers are cool.  Some of the tables here are really spacious and put in a lovely and quite back space while others are jammed up by the front door--so that may make eating here a bit of a crap shoot. If the chefs found a way (other than ordering a burger) to bring the price point down to a real $$$ instead of $$$$ I could call it a go-to spot for once or twice monthly nice meals, but as it stands it's a little pricier than some of my existing favorites.   This is all personal preference though...you should absolutely go to Absinthe for yourself.  P.S. Get dessert. I'll be in for drinks and dessert again soon, even if I space dinners farther apart. The yogurt panna cotta & orange sherbet parfait with pistachio crust is hella good.

XT25er2V1pbE2mUh4PoaDg.review_text: I usually enjoy this place for drinks and tasty food, but my experience this past Saturday will keep me from going back for a very long time. Service was horrible. Maybe because I brought my kid in and needed a high chair- but the waiter had zero qualms letting me feel like my baby and my business was not appreciated.  It was 3pm in the afternoon on a Saturday and there was plenty of tables. I didnt think it would be an inconvenience to have my kid there on a casual Saturday afternoon.. but I was wrong. Our food order was forgotten and took a long time.. once it came out the steak frites entree was cold and my hamburger was rare and the meat crumbled apart when I cut the burger in half- turning it into just a bunch of raw meat on my plate.  However, the french fries were good and the bussers were helpful and friendly. Disappointed and a little miffed, because I truly used to love my experiences here. I really used to love coming here and sitting in the lounge, but the hostess placed my friend and I in the lounge this time and I felt unwanted. I expect better service for an hour half casual Saturday with a bill of $120. Perhaps the hostess should have put us in the main dining room, if kids are an issue? Not sure, but Im pretty sure that I am the customer and that shouldn't be a problem. Just dont bring your kids and maybe your service will be better. Definitely NOT KID Friendly.

-C7U618MdXeVqUVqGyH98A.review_text: We came with friends before the symphony on a Saturday night - reservations are a must!  We were seated immediately in the dining area (happily because the bar is a really popular lively, noisy bar).  The waitress/service was impeccable.  We were asked if we were attending a performance and what time we needed to leave, which I thought was very thoughtful.  The food was wonderful - I took a shot in the dark and ordered the Kale and radicchio salad--I don't think I've ever had a better salad!  Tasty and beautifully presented . I followed that with the grilled Black Angus bistro filet with creminis, sour cream & leek whipped potatoes, Worcestershire jus and it was indeed wonderful and an absolute bargain for $28.  Others in our party got the Coq au Vin (also a winner!), the hamburger and the grilled country pork chop served with a really wonderful jicama-cabbage slaw and an avocado salad.  The flavors were amazing!  We followed dinner with a cheese course, picking 3 cheeses from their varied selection of about 6 cheeses.  The portions are small (as they should be) and all were lovely especially the fromage de meaux.  We will definitely be back.  I rated it 5 stars because the value for the money is really excellent - I would have expected to pay more for the quality of this dining experience.

9aZJMOox-6E0W_pBnaVZlA.review_text: Dropped by here for brunch and thought it was really overrated. Maybe I ordered the wrong dishes but everything was overly rich and a smidge too fussy for me. Even the service and the ambiance were kinda ehhh. Am I missing something? Everyone seems to love this place...  I really wanted it to be good too because I'm a huge Top Chef geek and I think Jamie is lovely (I've met her before and think she's painfully adorable and cool). With that said, I would be willing to give it another shot, maybe for dinner? Then again, with so many wonderful restaurants in the city, it's hard to go back somewhere that you were kind of disappointed with...

O77iwtKRJ5tgwAPrhhwyUg.review_text: Top Chef: Jamie Lauren, Season 5, 5th place  We went to Absinthe before a Seinfeld show.  I was impressed with the space and the drink menu.  Made a mental note that it would be a good place to come back to and just visit the bar, although the bar was standing room only when I was there.  Its one of those places where the foyer, bar, hostess station and pathway to the rest of the restaurant share the same space, so when the restaurant is even somewhat crowded, its insane at the front.  I had one of the Absinthe drinks, just because I've heard about Absinthe for decades and have never tried real Absinthe before.  I wasn't that impressed.  I'm sure its good...the presentation seems to be accurate, with the slotted "spoon" and the pitcher of water to pour over the sugar cube, but licorice drinks have never really been big to me.  Bars in France have little appeal to me as well, as all of them seem to be wanting to serve me some licorice-tasting liquor which they claim is the best around :)  For starters we had the fries, which were very good...done and seasoned to perfection, and the warm marinated olives...okay, but nothing to write home about.    I had the frisee salad, with the sunny-side up duck egg and bacon cubes similar to something Jamie did on Top Chef.  I have to say that the dish was well intentioned, but the presentation was poor...it was a HUGE mound of frisee, with no other lettuce texture to break up the "fuzziness" of the frisee.  The duck egg was good, and the warm yolk coated the frisee, but there was just too much lettuce!  Buried at the very bottom of the dish were very large, good tasting chunks of bacon, but the chunks were so large that they could not be supported by the frisee and always sunk to the bottom.  The flavors were good, if they were only able to be eaten in closer "proximity" to each other, but that was really not possible.  It was a bite of egg, a big mouthfull of frisee and then a chunk o bacon.  My main course was the beef cheeks, which were stupendous.  They were melt-in-the-mouth delicious and everything on the plate really went well together.  I'd definitely go back, but not for the salad.

ibSIRYjrJG2oaLHDL2fhog.review_text: Came back for soup and cocktails just like I said and yay! I'm a fan.    The French Onion Soup is just wonderful and with the bread equals an excellent meal to soak up the signature cocktails.  Will probably end up sharing an entree next time (the duck confit is calling me), but I almost don't want to leave my soup comfort zone, haha. Ooh, or maybe brunch?  Until next time, Absinthe.

yAerUZJKW7bNcYVH-Z3YXQ.review_text: 3.5 stars  A pricey restaurant and 2000+ reviews sounds like a promising meal but nope, Yelp has failed me.  Made reservations for 4 people at 12:00, got there and was seated right away.  It's DAT time and everyone decided to order from that menu.  I decided to go a differemnt route.  Started off the meal with the infamous garlic pretzels.  I should've tried the cheese sauce but it was good on it's own.  Perfect snack food.  Then came the mac and cheese.  It was HOT so make sure you wait about 5-7 minutes for it to cool down; unless you want to burn your tongue, dig in!  Finally, the burger.  There must've been a new chef or maybe I was supposed to add all the extra toppings but it taste like what everyone was saying on Yelp.  I was quite disappointed.  Definitely not the best burger in the city, not even top 5.  Service was great.

EhIolH5byA5_IO7VVZyAPQ.review_text: This place has been on my list for a long time and maybe I let my expectations get too high. Nothing was bad - in fact, the service was excellent - but the food was pretty average. I might be back for a drink, as they have an interesting cocktail menu, but the somewhat bland food doesn't seem to justify the high price and usually long wait.

INSTaEHJc09kzAgYJ9PoJA.review_text: Mainly because it had been neat external, many seats had been indoors. Essentially a long tavern build using smaller kitchen tables to at least one aspect. Almost all appeared to take a seat side-by-side. This particular spot features a 'fine foodstuff diner' style (it's a stretch out, although virtually sums that upwards. )  When i started out having an Eastern side Coast Oyster Player with the dice. Wonderful, although I have acquired superior (see my report on Tokkuri-Teii within Hawaii).  The actual waitress steered myself clear of this Linguine using Seafood as well as towards Outdoors Prawn as well as Scallop Sauté Appliance. Fantastic guidance! Wonderful major waste fresh new bass inside a cut garlic wealthy hot sauce recipe. Some sort of cup a Sauvignon Blanc using the dinner. Fundamental although would the secret to success.

TSs6cGV6N1EAWb5ovnKLPg.review_text: Although I know my non-profit salary won't allow me to eat here on the daily, I'm glad my tongue got to experience the magic that is their brunch. I can't begin to describe how amazing the food at Absinthe is.  I'll start with drinks. Correction: DRINK; as in singular. Why? Because as much as you may think you can out-drink any frat boy, get their Absinthe Mimosa, and you are DUNZO. I sure was after mine.  Appetizer included their oysters... which were just oysters served all dolled up and fancified. Nothing extraordinary in taste, but they were fresh and delicious. Always a plus.  My entree melted in my mouth. Like M&Ms status. I got the Duck Confeit. It was the most delectable thing I have ever put in my mouth. And I don't even use the word delectable! The poched egg on top just made it even more magical.   Dessert was non-existent because my full, drunk ass needed to get home and nap.  Overall, great place to dine. If you make the big bucks, EVEN BETTER because you get to dine here more often then I get to, and I admit it, I am jealous.

fqBtSumkO-PQStdIo1YH7g.review_text: This is my all-time favorite spot in the city for cocktails and a light meal and/or snacks. The bartenders are true artists and constantly have new creations on the board. A perfect brunch for me at Absinthe is a cheese plate pairing and cocktails shared with a friend, maybe a croque monsieur. Good service, friendly staff, great location. Love it!

cAvcYTQDGHDO9SH8HbWQHQ.review_text: I wasn't expecting a lot, since we just dined at M.Benjamin a couple of weeks back. But I was pleasantly surprised.  Highlights: Steak tartare Chicken liver mousse Coq au vin Chocolate pot de creme   Meh: Musells and clams  Our waitress was very attentive, I also love the small couches/booths they have for couples. Will def come back and try more cocktails.

0GHsxjCk-Ynzx4Ihj8tjPQ.review_text: When I went to Germany last year I searched all of Bavaria for German chocolate cake but to no success. When I finally did locate a bakery in Munich they had some sort of chocolate torte thing that tasted like chalk. It was terrible. I guess it's like going to France and asking for French Fries.  Lesson learned...no German Chocolate Cake in Germany...but when I went to Absinthe last week I think I had the BEST GERMAN CHOCOLATE CAKE I have ever had.   It was a milk chocolate mousse with coconut and candied pecans. OMGGG!  The chocolate cake is just one of the reasons why I love Absinthe. Their top notch liquor cabinet and delicously crafted cocktails is another reason as well as their simple but high quality and yummy food.

EzCLDNVlT7ztlcD8lGF-nA.review_text: Great ambiance and great drinks. I love the Galapagos cocktail!  For the first course we had:  Spicy Fried Chickpeas - Small appetizer like peanuts in a bar, but a million times better! The spice was just right and kept me wanting to eat more and more. Sometimes a little mushy though, so those who aren't a fan of chickpeas should stay way.  French Onion Soup - This was traditional and decent. It was missing my favorite part though: the bread on top.  Scallop & Corn Chowder - Rich, but really good. It had smoked bacon, potatoes, pieces of fish and clams. The soup tasted great with the clams, but it was a little too rich for one person.  Strawberry Gazpacho - Very unique with the sweet based strawberry. When I saw this on the menu, I thought this would be weird but I was pleasantly surprised. Also has crab & cucumber salad and basil and is pink!  Dried Apricot & Sage Country Pate - The pate was made well, but it wasn't outstanding to me. I love spreadable soft pate, but this was more like a roll. Also had house-made mustard, watercress, cornichons, and crostini.  Liberty Farms Duck Confit - Nicely cooked duck with a delicious salad. All around a great dish with cherry vinagrette, shaved fennel, and mixed cresses. Warning: a slightly bitter salad.  Manchego & Chorizo Stuffed Mary's Chicken - Chicken was cooked well, but the stuffing was interesting. The highlight was the shelling beans and the grilled shisito peppers with aioli underneath.  Slow Cooked Pork Confit - Best dish of the evening. Came with yellow corn, house-made bacon, fava beans, tarragon, sweet-corn sauce. The pork was perfectly cooked and fell off the bone. YUM.  Overall a great meal. I'd love to go back and try more of the cocktails, but the Galapagos was great!

-8ZM-jzJEGkKCxYEJnFrqQ.review_text: I have eaten at Absinthe approximately 460 times, and always love it, but this review is for the private dining room, which is between the main restaurant and Arlequin.  We had our office holiday party here tonight, and to say it went well would be the biggest understatement ever. Vanessa, Natalie and crew went above and beyond to make everything great and everyone comfortable and happy. The food was incredible, service flawless, and the room was absolutely perfect for our group of about 30. LOVED it, and will undoubtedly be holding as many events here as possible- THANKS Absinthe! Our best party yet thanks to you! :)

a5Y_gk7fFugj_FJl1g3pxw.review_text: Fun. Great cocktail menu.  For those who want to eat but have limits on purse strings, fo to the bar and eat off the bar menu which is cheaper than the dinner menu, and sip on cocktails beer or wine. Bartenders are friendly and interesting to talk to as well.  Recommendation from the bar menu: croque monseiur with an egg on top.  Also, brunch there is one of the best brunches I've had in the city.

nUms0RzJFJsqlR_VkjrSuw.review_text: The cutie hostess seated us immediately - the table was ready 5 minutes before our reservation time.  The nerve of that hostess: seating us early before we can get drinks at the bar!  The server was attentive without being overbearing throughout the meal, although she wasn't that friendly.  The oyster shooters come as a DIY - fresh oysters on ice with the tomato juice and vodka in separate shooters on the side.  The pate was just alright - I grew up on chicken and pork liver, so I've had it all before including high-end pate in France.  The garlic pretzels were exactly that - garlic pretzels, which obviously led the dinner conversation towards how Wetzel's and Auntie Anne's are a better value.  We are classy like that.  The entrees ($25-30) were hit-or-miss.   (We shared food because we're also classy like that.)   My Coq Au Vin was just ok - the chicken was moist, but the sauce reminded me of dark brown Thanksgiving gravy rather than lighter red wine sauce.  Mike L'.s Pork Osso Buco was too citrus-y - uh oh, he's going to write a scathing Yelp update!   The lady friends had the 7-oz Bistro Filet and the Duck, which was "stringy."   The wild rice hash and spinach, which came with the duck, were the highlights of the meal.  With an extensive wine list and drink menu, the cocktails were good all around.  Of course, I had to try the absinthe (Lucid Absinthe), but it just wasn't my thing.  Classless, I am indeed.

qrpjsp5G7_KNhZ7I6wt9uQ.review_text: Not open Monday :-(. Oh well. Will be back. Great bar tender (raoul) and the best hot pretzels in town.

VJhr9n-ecPtRVhJ993LSMg.review_text: Came here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon.  Made reservations the day of and was placed at our table fairly quickly once we arrived.  This place was a lot smaller than I thought, but it was really nice and clean.  This place has one of the best french onion soups I've ever had!  So delicious, full of flavor, and comes hot.  $5 for the cup.   Also, ordered oysters (fanny bays and the kumamotos).  Quite fresh and it was around $3.50 per oyster, a little bit on the expensive side, but we ended up getting 7 of them cause they were so good!   Two eggs any style w/ potatoes, toast, and a choice of meat ($12)= pretty simple dish, the sausage was on the sweeter side which I liked, and potatoes presently came out different than I expected, but was good too.  DUCK-CONFIT RAGOUT chive-potato cake, poached eggs, béarnaise ($15.50) = Got this one cause the waitress said this was one of her favorite dishes.  It was surprising pretty good, but it seemed like it was missing something though...  I will definitely come here again and try the other dishes...  It's a nice place to gather a few people for brunch and have some mimosas or a bloody mary.

JsVB8eE-FOhJjf5hL0nNwQ.review_text: It doesn't get any better than Absinthe. Great ambience. Amazing food. Yummy drinks.

uLA0rPnBf9Zl0AjlSnpJRA.review_text: Best burger in S.F.???  Quite possibly...  It is the best one I have had so far...and I am no foreigner to bacon cheese burgers  Overall: 8 Service: 9  Ambiance: 8  Food: 8 Food (for the price): 10  Bacon Cheese Burger (package) : 10  Burger Meat: 10 As leftovers: are you kidding?  There weren't any Zert: N/A Charity: N/A   Summary: The burger was GREAT as was the service.  They have a good selection of wine and it is reasonably priced.  The fries were good but were too short to do much with; if they were twice as long (the same length as most shoestring fries) they would have been perfect since they brought four dips for them (mustard, vinegar, ketchup and a spicy sauce of some sort.)  Memorable items: The burger.  The burger.  The burger.  The meat was good enough to eat on its own, they cooked it the way I wanted, and the smoke gouda cheese was a great touch.  They use Marin Sun Farms meat, which is incredibly tasty.  They could do something a bit more creative with the bun (I know everyone is doing ciabatta but that is because it compliments burgers...or why not try a sour dough bun - your burger would be awesome with sour dough).  The service was also very good.  Even though they were packed (it is a big place so there is never that much of a wait) we found a high-top at the bar and ate there.  I always love it when a server doesn't blink twice or tell me "that is going to cost extra" when I order something that isn't on the menu.  Seriously, if I am going to order a bacon cheese burger when there is no bacon mentioned anywhere I am well aware it will cost me extra.  Our server was great and only asked me how I wanted it cooked.  THAT is great service!  This might be one of the first times I have had a burger that cost $15 ($12.5 plus cheese and bacon) where I didn't feel like I got taken.   I don't know when the standard burger price went up over $10 but in most places it isn't worth it..  So far, this is the best bacon cheese burger I have had in S.F...and I have had many.  I actually started at Zuni, since I heard their burgers were great but was informed that they don't serve them for dinner until after 10pm otherwise the grill would be overwhelmed with orders.  Well Zuni, let me learn on you a bit of economics...it would be better to offer it, even if you have to charge more at dinner time (so that the grill doesn't get overwhelmed with too many orders), then to tell me I can't get one at all.  So, instead of having us stay and spend over $200 for food and drinks you allowed us to leave and go somewhere else...which we did...and ended up finding my favorite burger in town.  I would like to say that I would come back to try yours but with Absinthe being so close, theirs being $12.50 compared to your $15, and them serving it whenever I want it I am going to have a hard time not visiting them again when we are in the neighborhood looking for lunch.  Check out my other burger reviews....I know my burgers and let me tell you - this one is INCREDIBLE!!!  If you are passing through the city and want a great burger, this is the place to go.  I am not happy that all burger places seem to think that $10-$15 is now the accepted price for burgers but at $12.5 (extra for cheese and bacon) this one of the few that I find to be well worth it.  @Mikey S... I am having a hard time with your review, which was from only one day ago. First of all, this is an incredible burger.  Maybe you don't know anything about burgers and that is why you didn't like it but I know burgers and I know meat and this one rocks the house.  Maybe you were looking for a diner style burger, which this one is not, but there is no way to say this burger wasn't at least in the "good" category, no matter what else disappointed you with your experience...of which I also find suspicious.  When the meat has enough flavour to eat on its own (which this one does) than you know they are using quality meat which usually leads to an excellent burger.  You state that you had a burger, scallops and a glass of wine for $80 and that wasn't worth it to you.  Well, the burger is $12.50, which is well worth it.  The scallops are $30 which seems high to me but that is why I only eat seafood up the coast where it is not only more reasonably priced but usually more fresh.  That makes your meal roughly $45 at this point (if you got cheese)...which means you had a $35 glass of wine?  I was surprised to find that they had a great selection for under $10 a glass so I am not sure what you were doing ordering in the $35 range...especially if you didn't know specifically what you wanted.  That being said, maybe $65 would be a bit much for your scallops and wine but to lump the burger in there as not being worth it or not being good is criminal.

gELwQeYees4tVxCOQyRclQ.review_text: Came here for a late lunch and ordered the duck confit with poached eggs, hash browns, and toast. The duck meat and hash browns were incredibly over-salted to the point where I couldn't finish my meal. Very disappointing since that was my first time here. Tried my sister's ricotta french toast as well and it was just decent, nothing worth noting. I'm hoping the food is better during dinner hours.

Q8lwG6Lc9w04LyGkfMQ_Lw.review_text: I love coming here after a show. The service is fantastic, and they do everything they can to accommodate dietary needs....and people who don't like mushrooms. *cough* *looks guilty*. The food I have had here has always been good to good+. I recently had the monkfish, and it was a tad dry. I love the oysters...but I love most oysters. It can be a bit crowded, but that just speaks to it's popularity and the quality of the food.

q5BgRIPSzxQnFBIM2QLrrQ.review_text: 2 Horrible experiences in 1 Month.    The servers, Michael and Keith were total assholes from the get-go.  On our most recent visit last Sunday, my husband and I ordered the Mussels to start and specified that the fries come along with it, not with our entree.  That never happened and we had to ask twice for the fries. When the fries finally came the waiter, Keith, did not even apologize and blamed someone else. Not to mention he had  a major attitude.  Then we ordered the burger with egg on top, and for the second time in 1 month, the egg came on the side.  This is the most ridiculous thing. If 2 people are sharing the burger with an egg, the server should ask if we want the burger cut in the kitchen or if we want to cut it ourselves. But why the hell would the egg come on the side?   This isnt breakfast! When we ordered it on the second visit, we specified to the waiter that we want the burger NOT cut and with egg and cheese on top.  The dish did not show up this way and when we called him over, he again had a major attitude and made us feel like it was our fault.    He just took the plate and didnt even tell us what he was going to do: new burger with a new egg? Or same plate and they put egg on the burger? Didnt even say he would be right back with corrected dish. We were left guessing.  Then, the manager showed up and asked us what was wrong. She was super nice and apologetic about it and said we would get our dish immediately.  This is the only reason I am giving this place 1 star.   It's a shame this has happend because we go to the ballet a lot and always come to dinner beforehand. Now I am going to give my business to another restaurant in Hayes valley that deserves it and appreciates its patrons....

9AkVFSJm_lWZ7OUXwEHjXw.review_text: Great spot with lots of fun things to try.  We opted to dine tapas style, since there were so many appetizers and snacks we wanted to try. We let our server help recommend our courses.  The soft garlic pretzels are a must and the french onion soup is delish. The roasted beet and burrata was well balanced but sadly skimpy on the burrata.   We shared the coq au vin as a main (apparently this restaurant is famous for it), which I had never tried previously. It was rich and flavorful... but ultimately chicken is chicken. I wouldn't get it again.  For dessert we shared the german chocolate cake and the pot de creme. Both were rich... too rich to finish... but delectable.   Seems like a nice spot to come before the ballet or opera.

M7yNfpLXro9QBUkmmlGrcA.review_text: I went for the brunch and got a breakfast burrito. It was pretty good, but way overpriced. The plate looked rather disappointing since the burrito wasn't even that big and that was the only thing that was on the plate. Where's the greenery decor?! Just kidding. Cute place, but I don't think I'll be coming back for brunch.

VjUuaL2A0QwrRZ8hDdFf7Q.review_text: went here for brunch and wasn't impressed.  went here for dinner and was blown away!  oysters were super fresh - beau soleil is where it's at! country pate was perfect - not too salty and pretty mild roasted beet & green apple salad - solid  the atkins ranch lamb sugo was what did it for me.  one bite and i was already doing my little happy dance.  noodles perfectly al dente combo'd nicely with the refreshing flavors of the fava beans and mint. i'd come back for that again and again.  opera cake with citrus notes was pretty yummy too.   service was excellent.  can't give it five full stars cause well, it aint' cheap!   but certainly a fine fine meal!  4.5 stars!

NQ0REATs1_MehrNtnCaV2Q.review_text: Does it get much better? No. Does Absinthe need yet another glowing review? Again, no. But I feel like I kind of owe it to them, so here goes.  * Cocktails - Fantastic. Well-balanced & restrained without sacrificing interesting & unique combinations. Over the course of the night the three of us tried five cocktails and they were all excellent. * Wine - A ridiculous list, obviously, but with plenty of options at a variety of price points. I always look for a bottle whose price I know to gauge what the markup is, & from what we could tell, it looked to be a very reasonable 2x. The sommelier was knowledgeable both about the wines as well as how they would pair with what we were eating & made spot-on recommendations both times based on what we told him. * Salads - So good. Generally I like a good salad during a fancy meal, but in this case, I might recommend skipping it so that you have room for... * French onion soup - The best I've ever had. I wanted to die, it was so good. The only drawback, really, is that it's big & rich enough to almost be a meal in itself, which was kind of a problem once I got to... * Coq au Vin - Oh. My. Sweet. Jesus. Christ. Just get it. It's absurd. JUST. Absurd.  I would've loved to try dessert, but there was just no way anything else was going in my stomach.  An absolutely fantastic meal with excellent service. I'll be back.

S-eb2s_2Ec_1rcmvec-H2A.review_text: I ordered the burger and it was delicious and a pleasure to eat. I originally was going to do brunch at NoPa with two friends, but that fell through so one friend and I went to Absinthe instead as a back-up, but it ended up being the highlight of my day.   The burger as I said was delectable. Good quality meat, ordered it medium rare (it was really rare! but that's ok) but the toppings (fried egg, cheese, and tomato) were all an additional $1.50 add-ons. I am sorry but I come from a place where tomato and onion are standard and should be included with every burger. Charging extra for a tomato is just plain greedy people.   Second qualm, the service was not that great. Waiter seemed disinterested, only seemed like he was there to collect tips and was not really interested in helping us, or providing excellent service. He didn't check us on the entire meal expect when he brought the check.   I will revisit this place, and I will order the burger again, but I'll be damned if I pay $1.50 for tomato again. That's just dumb, as I already said above :)   I also hope I get a different waiter. That's it.

397N9-g-uc56q97VnaSBCw.review_text: Nice and friendly wait staff ++ Great presentation ++ Tasty crab mmmm ++ nice ambiance  ++ Decent burger ++  The two of us shared a salad and crab.  We ended up splitting part of our meals as well.  I had the burger, he had the chicken.  Both were cooked well and were full of flavor.    Overall, it's a great place.  I don't know how often I would frequent the place since I'm usually more of a low key kind of person but it was definitely a good spot.    Next time I will have to try one of their desserts.

TmhFYYTHodJnrubq9IeFNA.review_text: My partner and I had an excellent and enjoyable evening here! We loved it. Very nice atmosphere esp the lighting.. created a lush romantic setting. It did remind us of our time in Paris.   We had reservations via OpenTable so no waiting. The bar area was very busy, dining room less so but it was 7pm so still early. We had perfect table in the corner. Loved their wine menu.. amazing variety, lots of French wines and others from around the world. Priced from $40 I think to well over $500. We had a Bordeaux, Chateaux Dutruch Grand Poujeaux.. one of the better red wines I've had. I must have been lucky picking this one since there are many many many to choose from and I'm not familiar with most of the wine on their menu. But you can't go wrong with Bordeaux (plus it reminds us of Paris again). Loved that a sommelier came over and poured the wine for us. Fancy! :)  We started out with the pretzels based on Yelpers. They were Ok, not sure they were worth the $8. Loved the sauce though.. we asked for more bread so we could dip them in it haha. For main course I had the pork shoulder and he had the coq au vin. Both were presented well, pretty dishes. And tasty as well! One quibble.. we both thought they were a little salty. A minor complaint though. Since we were not too full yet, we ordered the brown butter panna cotta with pears... I had not been previous fan of panna cotta but this made me change my mind, so delectable!  We had a great time! Service was top notch, impeccable. Everyone from the hostess to the wait staff to the person who filled our water to the sommelier.. they were all very nice, very capable, very professional.. and most importantly, esp in a French restaurant.. very nice and not snooty. Oh, and we really like the Hayes Valley neighborhood. Lots of nice things to see on our walk from Nob Hill (actually our first time in the neighborhood). My partner has bias against French places.. but Absinthe may just have redeem the French for him haha. Vive la France!

M-wlPtaR3P0ujRqkDgpxbw.review_text: An unexpectedly beautiful interior, considering the neighborhood. Then again, this may be the second or third time I've walked around this area since I moved here, so....  Anyway, the service is chipper and efficient. A variety of absinthes are available, as are several cocktails that include it. I had no idea which absinthes were more treasured than others, so I ordered one of the mixed drinks (the Wonderlust, I believe). Delicious! Not overly sweet, which kills most cocktails for me.  The duck rillette had a marvelous texture, served over their unique French-style bread. Greens with a tad of vinagrette topped it, and added a bite necessary to cut the fattiness.  Their French Onion Soup was one of the best I've had in the City. Tons of caramelized onions, and the gruyere on top was stringy and gorgeously browned.  Finally, the Croque Monsieur was arranged very nicely, with the sandwich cut in two and stacked, with a side of mixed greens. Lovely!  Spendy, but I would try it again, as their menu appears to change rather frequently.

_jooCMbtNISAbAQ7oZAfug.review_text: Crab and Spinach Omelet was really good.  The bacon was glazed with maple syrup!  Really good place for brunch!

4RUXeyp_Af2C5t9JFyJlBQ.review_text: [October 2014 Self Date]  So if you know me, I tend to go on these self dates. It tends to be a nice place that I've wanted to try in the City, and just haven't been around to yet. This way, I don't have to wait for some guy to bring me there - I can just bring myself there!   Made a reservation (I will admit dining by myself is lonely, but definitely great for accidental eavesdropping)  Ordered the following: Sacred heart - which was tequila, citrus, and absinthe. I could taste the absinthe - that anise flavor was a strong aftertaste, but I did enjoy it! Doubt it was the hallucinogenic kind.  Soft garlic pretzels - Absinthe is known for this dish. I definitely ordered it because I want to try it. It wasn't amazing, because of the cheese sauce. I just didn't love it as much I really hoped that I would have.  French onion soup - someone had said it was an amazing dish...and it was! I enjoy a good french onion soup.  Duck with wild rice hash - duck was amazingly cooked. Very little fat on it because it was all rendered out. The wild rice hash was great as well because it had some pieces of duck in it so it tied well together. There was some sauted spinach, but there was also some raw spinach. That was weird to me.  German Chocolate cake - YUM! It came with this coconut lime sorbet that was different, but it wasn't the best either. I REALLY had wished for some chocolate ice cream or vanilla.   Overall, loved the place. Drinks and food was great. Ambiance - mostly romantic, but good for dates and dinners.

xMNS7Ryl1ptKLE9Ki5Zw1Q.review_text: This place is decent but not worth all the hype.  Like a lot of restaurants in San Francisco it is a nice place but overpriced for what you get.    I started with the French onion soup, which some claimed was the best they ever had.  It was good, but not amazing.  Then I had the lamb meatballs, which were undercooked, over-seasoned and lacking in flavor and juiciness.   All in all, its a pretty place.  I like the bar and they make some good fancy-pantsy drinks, which will set you back about $12 a pop.    In sum, its a decent place, but not a good value.

SeJ9bfovLJpPgUkbtqwp5w.review_text: Worst bartenders EVER!! Sooo rude and the opposite of attentive!!! Don't ever go there!!! Too bad, cuz the food is really good.

4c2RYnS2mdDSMwyY9xWBaQ.review_text: San Francisco is well known for restaurants that have one good dish and that's what you go for. Absinthe has great garlic soft pretzels. The rest you can get anywhere else, at least in terms of dinner.   I didn't come for cocktails so I can't comment.   I wasn't as impressed as I was hoping to be.

aiGHNhyHcFo0TVHyL7C4sA.review_text: I believe I have eaten here one other time, but this recent visit was a remarkable experience. I made my reservation through OpenTable.com and made a note to the maitre'd that the dinner was in celebration of a two year anniversary and that we'd be attending the opera for the first time as well (which is right near the restaurant). To be honest, when you put something in that little comment box in OpenTable you think, "yeah right, like they'll actually get this or read it." When we arrived a little early for our reservation we were not quite hungry yet as it was an early reservation to accommodate the matinee performance. The host pleasantly understood and pushed our reservation out a bit so that we can grab a drink at the bar. The drink menu here is fantastic. If you're not an expert mixologist, then you'll enjoy trying something from their large cocktail menu. And if you have your favorites, they'll have the right liqueur. We had some unique martini's and enjoyed each of them. When we did get seated for dinner we passed many of the less appealing tables and got seated in a very personal two seater booth where you get to sit next to each other. Having already smelled many of the wonderful dishes we were very excited to begin ordering. We started with some cheese and another round of drinks and ultimately ate our way through multiple courses into dessert! It was some of the best food I have had (pork confit, risotto, pate). As we awaited for our dessert, I was pleasantly surprised by the attention we received all evening and specifically when the plate arrived with "Happy Anniversary" written in chocolate. I really can't believe they did so much having only read the comment from OpenTable. I will be back and if you have not yet visited, make it a priority!

sCCxBa2-koaCLOkMyx9LlA.review_text: PORTABELLA MUSHROOM GRILLED CHEESE  with cheddar, provolone, arugula-almond pesto, sundried tomatoes, chips  is probably the best thing I've ever tasted. Came here for lunch on a weekday with some friends. Everyone seemed to love their dish as well. The PATA CABRA cheese was great with the grape jam. Great atmosphere and location. Will definitely be back to try other offerings.

-6-ULOBhVn0mDV26qILqAA.review_text: Amazing cocktails and bar staff, but there isn't much reason to go any farther into the establishment.   We had a party of four on a Sunday and the service was atrocious.  While we waited for a table to be cleared we took a seat at the bar. We listed off four separate cocktails and the bartender delivered post-haste. She was friendly and efficient with the cocktails matching the service. Tragically, it was all down hill from there.  When we were seated the waitress didn't give us the impression that she wanted to be serving us. She couldn't manage a smile and was short on words. If they had specials that night we certainly weren't informed. It was a long time between our water being brought to the table and our orders being taken.   As the food was delivered we were notified that there had been a shift change and a new waitress would be taking over. We would only be graced with her presence twice during the rest of the evening. She never checked to see if we were enjoying our food. Perhaps most unfortunate is our cocktail glasses from the bar sat empty on the table for the entirety of our meal. Considering we were at Absinthe on the recommendation of their cocktail list the establishment lost out on at the least four more cocktail purchases.   After sitting at the table with empty glasses and plates, the waitress failing to return to our little section of the restaurant, the busser asked if he could clear our table. He saw my companion had his credit card out and it must have alerted him to the fact that we hadn't been offered our check yet, because he groaned, walked away, and came back with dessert menus. It was a commendable acknowledgement of our situation and we discussed pulling him aside and giving him the tip.   We declined dessert and I watched him head off to the cashier and say something. Roughly five minutes later our waitress returned and also asked if we wanted desserts. We repeated our "no" and she turned away. We assumed she left to bring us the check, but it was at least five more minutes before she came back.   Our dinner took nearly two hours with roughly 30 minutes of that being actual food consumption.  I had the lamb shank, and it was fine, but not memorable enough to make up for the lousy service.

uKkNmBfkMjFQKKpDSe4vLw.review_text: The boy and I popped over to this quaint restaurant after catching Wicked (which btw is 4 stars). The dark, cozy but not too quiet atmosphere was nice for some nibbles.  We ordered from the bar menu (it was close to 11:30pm) and got the smoked salmon, french fries, hot dog and chaource cheese - of course they all had fancier names than that but it is what it is!  The thinly sliced toast that came with the smoked salmon was scrumptiously crunchy and went well with the sour cream concoction paired with the salmon. I enjoyed that. The shoestring fries were a little on the salty side and not that impressive. The hotdog was aiight but like most "homemade" sausages, the texture was a lot more rewarding than processed meat franks! It kind of crumbled in your mouth. Sounds weird, but it was like: ooh real meat.  Last but not least, the Chaource cheese - this came with some walnut/raisin bread and some grapes. We had just watched Pan's Labyrinth the night before so something about those grapes felt sinfully forbidden. And I ate them. Every last one of them. And they brought out the sweetness of the cheese. (I never thought I'd say that). Creamy cheese with a strong flavor that came in a burst and gently faded away on your palate.   Yeah. I dig cheese.  The service was good, the company was wonderful, the cheese quite delightful. Not sure I'm quite sold as a fan yet, but I guess I'll have to go back to decide!

_q7zxpob2aSEjbeFribBPw.review_text: Absinthe, I give you a 4!  Ordered a drink, something citron lemonade. It was a yummy drink, but I had to ask myself, did I order a non alcoholic drink? But i was sure, it was from the bar and was alcoholic. Just a little disappointed that I couldn't enjoy the burning sensation that comes with most alcoholic drinks. =P  There were 3 in my party, and we shared the mussels and clams dish as an appetizer. Delicious! The sauce was so good I kept sticking my spoon in there and enjoyed it like it  was soup. I tried my best to not be seen by the other diners who were enjoying their sophisticated dinner. I was a little embarrassed, but what do you do when it's that good?  I had the chicken with cornbread stuffing, and it was amazing! There was also the bass and the pork confit, and the bass was very lightly flavored and pretty yummy. The pork was on the more intense side, almost too sweet for me. I thought Mary's chicken (I think that's what it was called) was just perfect. The skin was lightly crispy, very well flavored, and the chicken was juicy and flavorful. The brussel sprouts were sweet and cooked to just the right amount of.... crunchy ? mush? Whatever it is, it was GOOD  We did order a dessert, and we really wished we picked something else. We ordered the sorbet, citrus sorbet or something like that. WOW was it bitter or WHAT. It was a couple of scoops of this sorbet stuff and some agar cubes or something. The sorbet was VERY very bitter. It had a lot of grapefruit, but I think they put more of the skin than the fruit itself. We took a few bites trying to decide what we should do with it, and we could not get ourselves to eat it any more. The waiter saw that we put our spoons down after few bites and offered to take it out of the bill. The service was great, I think they may have had someone new, training. She snuck in behind one of us to clear the pepper and salt and it was kind of funny to watch her squeeze between the wall and the person sitting, and trying to be sneaky.   Yummy food, good service, the food was a little slow but the waiter said they were backed up a little. It was a busy night, so it's not a big deal.

sUkvo96O3uKHW9zzg-NOBQ.review_text: I went in with high hopes for the food and they met my expectations. The food is excellently prepared; however, nothing amazed me. It is probably because I was expecting a lot. I recommend a visit here. Order what ever you want. You won't be disappointed.   Also, they have Chimay on tap.

_HmVfjZizikfli0zzBd2vg.review_text: Best American or shall I say French spin on German Chocolate cake.  The flavors glided together and finessed my tongue with the perfect amount of sweet filling. Make that reservation before or after the ballet or symphony as it is standing room only if you don't, although they will always do the best that they can.  This place is another SF institution.

QxicE6c4zNxYYJh_aeywlA.review_text: Classic... Old School. Glug-F'in-Glug boys & girls. Came here for an after work date time. Wasn't disappointed.  Good cocktails, great wine, divine food. Baby was not put into a corner.... Baby jumped into a fat booth in the corner and swayed the night away. Play it again Sam....    I SAID PLAY IT AGAIN!   Oh yeah.... That's it. Like the magical green essence that provides the name.

HCtEYgABFgwGhHB3rPQeQQ.review_text: I am completely obsessed with this place.  Absinthe's makes some of the best cocktails in the city and I love stopping in since they are in my favorite part of the city. Food's great too and they have a very nice wine list!

RsJsu2Nd6NZQfYkxya_EOQ.review_text: Absinthe is a beautiful sf chic restaurant ,, however disappointing in flavor. This is a perfect place for wine, cheese and maybe a couple apps.   We had Cesar salad- average Meatballs- ok,, nothing to remember... Also we're Luke warm French onion soup-sweet in flavor,, had much better at Perry's  Lamb shank- ok Wagyu- more like a pot roast, tender, tasty but I didn't realize I was ordering stew  The food here is more like comfort food that was pre-made. Wishing it at least came out hot.  Sadly nothing was on the mark

hRD1uMCRXkpDSbr5xC3R8g.review_text: I like this place.  The drinks were good and so was the food.  I also really enjoyed sitting at the bar with the male, Hispanic bartender.  It's rare that people are as personable as him.  He was so easy to talk to and made me laugh a great deal!  I came here for happy hour, so didn't sample much of the menu.  What I did enjoy was: - fresh oysters (very good!) - french onion soup  The atmosphere is a little too pretentious for my taste, and seems a little overrated.  However, I would return if I was with someone who wanted to go.

ogMHL0yOLYyWNtIcbga9AA.review_text: Anna C. described this burger to perfection, particularly the bun. I could steal her words but I'll just let her description do the work, because it's spot on. We too had heard the Absinthe burger is Right Up There for a perfect gourmet burger in our fine City so in the name of duty we hightailed it over there to road test it for ourselves.   It was a great burger, but there were things about it that were off, and we all know when a burger is described as perfection, EVERYTHING about it must follow and work in harmony together. With Absinthe, the bun did not cooperate with the fabulous Niman Ranch meat, blue cheese, spicy onions, lettuce etc, which created something of a challenge to eat. With that said, I still thought it rated pretty high up there, though not nearly as perfect as I'd heard.  I dig the atmosphere of this place however. It feels  so cozy and old school San Francisco. I'll be back but maybe on a hunt for a different experience than what the burger offered.

9IF2ZMnkrZlvxCHcO0h1EQ.review_text: It's hard to add anything more to the 1000+ reviews.   The cocktails are amazing.   The pork confit was a little piece of piggy heaven with the meat melting in my mouth.   The chorizo and manchego stuffed chicken was an out of this world combination.   The service? Not so hot. Our poor waiter was way overworked and had tables strewn throughout the restaurant rather than a section.   Almost perfect if it weren't for the slow, unresponsive service.

yXtStKz2c9LVLPd1_LgjsA.review_text: I came here for brunch on Sunday when my cousin was visiting town after getting some Blue Bottle (mega bonus point for fantastic location).  I wasn't really up for going here at first because I expected over an hour wait and when my stomach and brains felt like it was eating each other, I just wanted to stuff myself silly with anything.  To our surprise, even during peak brunch time, the wait was only 20 mins.  Success!!!  I was able to keep my growling body parts calm and I'm sure glad I waited.   I ordered the duck confit which sat on top of a chive-potato cake, with a poached eggs running over it and some bearnaise sauce.  Essentially it was a fancied benedict.  Given that eggs benedict is my go to brunch dish, this stepped it up a couple notch.  Thinking about it now makes my stomach screams.    Was able to try other dishes from our party and everything tasted delicious.  I am looking forward to going back here.  Good food, great service and not a crazy raging wait?  Jackpot!

7rfBi8WiNHliL-cAqMGNew.review_text: This place is pretty cool for an older crowd. I came here with some friends and I ordered a Bellini and had some fries.   Thank god I came late because my friends were wait for half an hour for some seats.   The drinks were good and the food was good.   Thumbs up~

DLw5PaUpgyNHYYVuSxlACg.review_text: I use to go the old establishments in NYC, and this brings me back to those days.  It has that old school charm of the better restaurants in NY.    Great place for a date.  Your date will be impressed with the service and the food.  And yes, must try one of the signature cocktails.  I also sat at the bar with an old college friend on a Saturday afternoon.  Very enjoyable and classy atmosphere.

OxU8X46h4tVQq7sib8JASg.review_text: Coq Au Vin - delicious burgundy braised chicken. So tender and delicious. Can't wait to return and order this again. Cleaned the entire plate, this comfort dish won my taste buds at first bite and had me on cloud 9.  Their cocktails pack a punch. Their manhattans are great.  Mac n cheese - very good, there are probably places that do it better but I had no complaints.  Service - amazing service! Friendly, professional, helpful, and prompt. Can't wait to return.

sht0n7Up25_gkrIYbD36jQ.review_text: This review is for the eggs benedict only:   Absinthe's take on the traditional eggs benedict is such a clever twist, that it's delightful & refreshing to the palate.  Think: Eggs benedict...but instead of English muffin, it's on a crispy hash brown with béarnaise sauce.  Oh, it's also topped with duck-confit & wild mushrooms.  No big D.  The chive-potato cake has a hashbrown kind of crunch to it, which went perfectly with the poached egg that drizzled down & into the duck confit. I especially loved the variations of textures with the crispiness of the potato cake, the softness of the egg, and the tenderness of the meat.  if you ever come here for breakfast, this is a MUST get!

OXYtOFX9xXukagW5Ku5dfg.review_text: I have been very curious about this place for the longest time so when the opportunity presented itself, I chose to guide some friends over here and grabbed lunch.  We may have been a tad underdressed and we were definitely the youngest ones there. I think this is the reason why we were seated in the back hah.  Despite this, we were still treated well. Our server was really nice and attentive in an appropriate way. Very accommodating.   The prices here are pretty steep but quality is wonderful. I chose to get the grilled cheese/portobello sandwich, soft garlic pretzels, and a Cintron Lemonade to sip on. My friends got the Masumi Farms Pork "French Dip" and a Guadalajara cocktail while the other got the grilled chicken/prosciutto sandwich. Later on, we shared a German chocolate cake based on our waitress' recommendation.   It didn't take too long for our food to get to us although my appetizer came after my meal. It wasn't a big deal.   Soft Garlic Pretzels - expensive little things, but the best pretzels I've had in my life. Buttery and delicious. It's like, high quality finger food. Even the cheese sauce was amazing!  Grilled Cheese/Portobello Sandwich: Delicious. Expensive at $14, but it's a huge sandwich and it comes with a huge pile of house made chips. I was only able to eat half of it because it was really heavy (it's a very buttery sandwich).  Grilled Chicken/Prosciutto Sandwich: My friend had the same issue I did, but he seemed to enjoy it very much.  Pork "French Dip" : This sandwich was different in the way it was prepared, but my friend liked it a lot. The fries overwhelmed him, but they're good quality fries (remained crispy after sitting for a while).  Cintron Lemonade: Hangar One Buddha's Hand, ginger syrup, fresh lemon-lime juice, ginger beer & a topping of cranberry juice. Looks as girly as it sounds and tastes just as nice.  Guadalajara: I forgot what was in it because it wasn't my drink, but it was pretty good. Looks even girlier than the drink I got, but it tasted much stronger.  German Chocolate Cake: We chose to get this based on the recommendation of our waitress. We're glad we trusted her because it was the best German chocolate dessert I have ever had in my life. The mousse is very light yet strong enough in flavor. The coconut inside was delicious and complimented the dish well. The caramel sauce was amazing and the toasted pecans really added texture and a subtle nutty sweetness. Amazing.  GREAT PLACE but madly expensive so expect to spend a pretty penny on some great food.

WW8jaGsBh9_rYcVSbEjLiQ.review_text: My beau surprised me with birthday lunch here just yesterday. He works late so din-din wasn't an option.   This did it! For a sexy sophisticated lunch, you want to come here.   The menu was just enough, with offerings of soft baked garlic pretzles, dreamy cheese plates, oysters and oystee shooters! They also had caviar and an exteeeeeensive wine list. They have a fantastic somm, lots of variety, vintages and vinters! Triple V's for the win:D   We opted for the bottle of Cava for $39. It was brut and did the trick. The Cava is the most reasonable bottle on the menu, but there are so many other options to explore. They had like 15-20 different Chablis! Like, if you looooove wine, come here! However point is, it was lunch and we ordered a ton of random items to share. So in short, we ordered a reasonably priced bottle of Cava to compliment everything. It did NOT disappoint.  The service was good. Nothing stand out. Ok, our server kind of seemed like he may have been having a bad day, but when I asked my boyfriemd what he had thought, he said he thought the service was fine. So, yeah.  I am excited to come back here for dinner and I've already recommended this place a ton, so clearly, 5 *'s

fYmxh9XPEsj_VctHDlU61w.review_text: Yum! We liked everything here. We each got an absinthe cocktail and both were really good! We tried the persimmon salad which was excellent, and the delicious pumpkin bisque. For entrees, I had the pork osso buco and my husband had the potato-crusted fish. Both were good, but the pork was a richer and more interesting dish. For dessert, we had a parsnip cake that we enjoyed. Service and atmosphere were great, but it was SO loud in there. The bar area was unbearably loud; the dining room was a little bit better. But the whole place was cozy, so we had fun and would go back if we were in the area again.

CI9cxb-iDl1xlxFF0jEquQ.review_text: I came here this past weekend with a party of 7 for my friend's birthday.  None of us had been here before yet but have definitely been wanting to come for some time now.
