The following dishes were ordered:  French onion soup Carrot soup Scallop-clam chowder Antipasti plate French fries  Liberty Farms Duck breast - pretty tasty, but felt it was lacking something......just can't pinpoint what?! Braised Beef cheeks - very tender and juicy.  hands down the best of the night.   Pork confit - really tasty and tender as well.  I really enjoyed this one.  the portion was huge. Bluenose Bass - least favorite of the night.  It was too fishy for my liking.  Some absinthe (I don't remember which exact one we ordered now) - I can't stand the licorice taste, so ehh this just isn't for me.  The food was pretty solid and tasty overall.  The apps and soups were just pretty average.    The service was superb.  Our waiter was so friendly and patient with us.  He even brought out a complimentary dessert for our friend at the end of the night, even after knowing that we were in a rush to head to another engagement.  Overall, a pretty great experience.  The decor is so modern and chic.  It's definitely a fun and cozy vibe inside.  Surprisingly, the food disappointed just a little, but the service and overall experience and vibe definitely made up for it.

FRSoGLPQI16pus03avyaSA.review_text: Je t'aime Absinthe..   I've been to Absinthe numerous times, for brunch, drinks, dinner  (pre-show and post-show), and they never disappoint. Ambiance is fun and inviting; service is typically friendly and efficient, and servers may ask if you are attending a show (so they can put a rush on your food/drinks).  If you were to only order 3 items from this delectable and numerous options menu, the following would be my suggestions:  1) The burger and pomme frites are top notch. Can't ever go wrong with that pairing, as the burger is juicy and cooked to perfection (Medium).  2) Mac and Cheese - This simple dish has such a bold and sinfully good taste, and comes in a very hot dish. The cheese is literally sizzling upon arrival. Oui Oui!  3) Garlic pretzels - At minimum, you need to order 2 of these. One for me and one for me! Just Kidding.. Ok,ok... one for him, I guess :-) I don't know what they do to these pretzels to make them so darn delicious and tasty, as the pretzels are served warm and are soft and the outside is crisp, and the butter, oil, garlic sauce makes you want to lick the plate clean. Ridiculous, I know, and I fully admit to doing that, and proud of it)!! The cheese dipping sauce is also served warm and just as divine!  Go ahead and sit at the bar area and enjoy the following above items if you can't get ressies or don't feel like waiting for a table. You can also ask for the sourdough bread and butter (and sea salt), as it's highly addictive as well. Special cocktails (my fav is  Ginger Rogers- Gin, fresh mint, ginger syrup, & lemon juice, 9  topped with ginger beer) are available, as well as a wide variety of wines and select beers (on draft) if that tickles your fancy.  Dessert menu includes creme brulee, chocolate pot de creme, and banana sticky toffee pudding. Makes me want to go back now and get my sugar and savory fix!  Bravo Absinthe! Bravo! You are worthy of my 5 star rating!

aATCOyzKuF37EGAE7Lp4uA.review_text: Haven't dined here awhile since my office moved from civic center to embarcadero.  Spontaneously, my sister and brother in law were in Hayes Valley and asked for a restaurant recommendation, and I suggested Absinthe.  We decided to join them.  I was pleasantly surprised that they still have it!  We ordered several items to try including meatballs, pork osso buco, coq au vin, Mac and cheese, and all were delightful.  bar scene was happening, and it was great to observe.

4Po_4vgdBFk2GPeKfJqVww.review_text: Absinthe was 2010's first act of rebellion for me.   I hate feeling pressured to do something when it comes to food/drink.  Like, going to a restaurant called "Absinthe"...of COURSE you should order absinthe to drink, right?  Or knowing that Jamie, the chef, is obsessed with scallops...of COURSE you should order scallops to eat, right?  And remember how you were supposed to watch your pennies this year...so of COURSE you should cook at home instead of eating out, right?  Forget that!  It's 2010 b*%ches!  I want to rebel!    I had the Citron Lemonade (decent...lightweight...needs more umph), the stuffed chicken (ridiculously good...the brussel sprouts were to die for), and spent a crapload of money.    But it was all worth it.  This rebel felt like treating herself.  Snap, snap.  PS - I've been here for brunch a few times and it is PHENOMENAL...in fact, I think I prefer it...

9ktvHxI2ofhWxnIvAa1JYg.review_text: I've been here now at least 5 times, and I usually sit at the bar, and to be honest I've never really had a super friendly bar tenter. There is a brown haired lesbian that you have to win her over it seems, never very friendly. Last night there was a tall skinny guy with a mustache. I waited for 10 minutes to get a glass of wine, then he hounds me to pay the bill the second I get it. I was like F-you, I ended up sitting at the bar and he barely paid any attention, the mexican busboy was 10 times more attentive and would have deserved the tip EXCEPT, and here is why Im writing this:  I was joined by my friend who happens to be Latin and speaks Spanish. the mexican barback and his other worker were both speaking spanish very loudly (it was crowded and loud and they were right in front of us) They were saying something about the "fucking faggot" (repeatedly) in the dining room. (in spanish in sevaral different ways) Well I am gay and my friend was translating as they were talking, I couldnt believe it - do they not think anybody speaks spanish? I am done with the staff at Absinthe, the food and atmosphere is always good, but its pricey for the recession and I must say, its consistently the WORST staff in San Francisco. And as to the 2 mexican guys who hate "fags" - I hope you get fired for your offensive comments to those that  pay your wage. I will never go to this resaurant again. Shame on Management.

NUz84kGfvNmRb8zk1pDYXw.review_text: I was torn on how many stars to give- my experience is based on holding my wedding lunch reception in the private dining room. The food was perfect- 5 stars all the way for everything that was brought out. The servers were courteous, couldn't ask for anything more from them. The 3 stars are for my dealings with the private dining manager, Vanessa Harris. She seemed very cold and unhelpful for most of the process which is extremely stressful for a bride who is trying to plan. About a month before the wedding, suddenly she was very eager to iron out all the details. I realize this may be due to her being overly busy and not being able to dedicate time until the very last possible moment- but that isn't very comforting to a bride who is pretty overwhelmed herself.

Hr5rzkiljte0oHrPw5P6Ow.review_text: Foursome dined well for $ 306.00. Pricey, but well done. My pork skirt steak was great with breaks and a delicious sauce.  Monkfish was really great, with unusual side ingredients. Coq a vin was great!

Jn-vpQvjNbpLUaG8fsqcaQ.review_text: A great restaurant to go to before the opera!  The service and food was good.

Yit4HBiAW9lyNWVTIYi1Yg.review_text: Ambiance was dim and romantic. Waitress was decent. The beau and I started with 6 oysters-- each of us had 3 different types of oysters. Oysters were alright. I've definitely had better. I had some sort of peach cocktail that the waitress suggested tasted like biting into the sweetest pear ever-- I don't know what kind of "sweetest pear" she's had, but it wasn't sweet whatsoever. The beau had a mojito and he nor I were not pleased. I've had better mojitos at elephant bar.  We ordered a cheese plate and it was excellent. We also had the French onion soup which the waitress said was the best she's ever had, but I would have to say it wasn't all that great. It was yummy but not the best. Maybe I'm not so much a French onion soup kind of lady.  I ordered the sole, which was kind of disgusting. Salty on some parts and bland on other parts. It was too mushy and unappetizing.  Definitely would skip this place.

ReDoGveUTyzlfC0bZOQ3bA.review_text: I've been here a few times for brunch and one time for lunch.  BRUNCH: Each time for brunch I ordered the seasonal fruit and poached eggs over duck confit - except one time I ordered some poached eggs over black beans and (I think pork?), which was a mistake, not because it was bad (though it was salty), but because given the choice you should ALWAYS choose duck confit! The duck is moist and sooo perfect.. I don't even really care about the little potato pancakes underneath, which have been too salty at times. The seasonal fruit is always awesome and never just an assortment of boring grapes and unripe melon but blood oranges, mangos, and all kinds of wonderful things.   LUNCH: I went with friends during dine about town, but I ended up ordering off the regular menu since I dislike panna cotta. I ordered the grilled cheese and portabella sandwich, which also includes fennel, little bits of broccoli, and pesto. I added bacon (duh, Absinthe has some of the best bacon ever). It was very delicious and the buttery grilled bread is reminiscent of a sandwich at Tartine. The server we had was the sweetest and checked up on us a lot. My only complaint is that a coke should never be $3.25.. ever.   Anyways, I wish I could afford to drop $30 on breakfast or brunch more often!

LBiXAs8W3HkJyT7JsPMC_Q.review_text: Chef Adam Keogh's snacks are breathtaking, innovative and an absolute delight to the senses!!!!

Bo9Atw5Ee5zXhzuoudzIQg.review_text: My husband and I stopped by for a light dinner before catching our plane at SFO.  We had the:  Heirloom tomato & melon gazpacho (cool and delicious) Monterey squid & pei mussels (fantastic taste, only not perfect because mussels were a little small, and there could've been more squid) Stonefruit salad (nicely composed, tasted as good as it looked) Mixed mushrooms (just very tasty) (and I had a Perfect Pear cocktail - so refreshing and just what I needed)  The place was packed on a Tuesday evening - kind of a yuppie crowd, and the service was a little perfunctory, but we enjoyed it immensely and our only regret was not being hungrier so we could've tried some of the entrees.  Next time we're in SF we'll be sure to return!

GkW9ZGxa5MnusaaDVZ6_RQ.review_text: Amazing drinks.  Perfect place to get hammered on a Sunday monrining.  (Just kidding.  Or not.)  My friend liked the perfect pear cocktail.  We also tried the bellini, sazerac, and wonderlust.  For food, the french onion soup and the absinthe burger.  Everything was good including the service, I will be back.

kpwvGQXD0dgZ8P9rHrkmNw.review_text: Came here with a girlfriend to indulge in some SF French cuisine. We had the caviar and filet mignon. The meat was tender, thick and very rich. The service and drinks were great. Overall a great dinner experience.

Q0qo1Gi99LihNjitnpfCAw.review_text: Absinthe has been on my list of restaurants to go to for a while, and I finally made it for brunch with some girl friends.  I chose Absinthe for brunch for a few reasons 1) it's on my list, and 2) they take reservations.  Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed with our brunch.  It was a nice restaurant, not crowded or too loud, good service and good food, but there was nothing extraordinary about it, as I had anticipated.  The brunch menu was a bit sparing, and none of the items really caught my eye.  There were items that I would settle on, which I did order, but I was hoping to not just settle.  I ended up ordering the Stuffed French Toast, which was delicious, but it was more like eating dessert for breakfast, than having breakfast.    Oh well... I guess I'll just have to go back for dinner and re-assess...

bSaC5jqVot6YxiySIA8kUw.review_text: French onion soup was really good, croque monsieur solid but a little salty, burger was damn solid.  Have been here for drinks before and remember them being good.

CMMUUtzS-skWRhxHE3xn4w.review_text: I went witj my coworkers and we all enjoyed our meals, delicious. Monk fish, mac n cheese, the onion soup is full of flavor, the steak was great (acording to friend). To top it off, the service was friendly, fun, attentive. The bar tender knows his stuff! And the Spanish coffee was very popular hat night,.., just ask for it when you are there and see the show :)

vn8nPLA7J_GkHEiW5vEmbA.review_text: This was the 2 hour vacation away from my life.  I roll up casually after getting of the glamorous 21-Hayes bus, my splendid coach with so many horsepowers.  I'd taken it at the most appropriate time, right after people are getting out of work, around 6pm, on a thursday night.  Most are just rushing to get away from the insanity, some are on their way to find insanity.   In my fabulous couture attire (jeans and a little black dress with running shoes), I glided in a smooth as a ballerina.  I could see everyone turning emerald green with envy when they saw that I was carrying and owning the very latest and most practical school wear:  the backpack crammed full of every girl's beauty essentials.  The 17 inch macbook pro, practically unwieldy in the possession of such a small Asian as I, and yet I flaunted it, I worked that runway known as Hayes Street.  I made them look at my fab-u-lo-si-ty.    When I entered, the hostesses immediately knew what I wanted:  a seat at the bar.  Next to me was an LV wielding Opera fanatic that ate the tiniest oysters, on the other side was a jet-set record producer who had flown to 3 continents in the past 4 days.  Oh.  Darling.  Let me tell you.  Being fabulous is never easy.  A glass of the savignon blanc.  The bartender was very good at listening and soliciting the story from every weary patron.  An order of fries.  And escargot.  I was in heaven.    Now the fries are unlike any other fries I've had.  They are nearly chips because they are so crispy.  I would have liked them a bit more limp.  A bit more mealy.  And the batch given to me were the end scraps, the crispy, super-fried bits.  They tasted good, but the texture was a bit too crisp for me.  I like the middle bits of the fries.  Tender, slightly soft in the center, that kind.  The escargot came out in a little skillet, covered with toast and a few lemon wedges.  I've never had them with lemon wedges.  It was still not salty enough though the flavors of parsley was fresh and fragrant.  The garlic was nice, though I like it really garlic-y.  And the shells.  Without tongs.  So I had to use my fingers to hold the little suckers in place while I dug out my bounty.  I am giving this 3 stars because it was an A-ok experience.  I think it could have been better.  But I didn't have time for it to be better.  And I don't think they had the space.  The place was hopping!  I will come back and actually try dinner.  I've heard it's quite good.  Oh yeah.  I wanted more bread with my escargot but I was too shy to ask because the place was really packed and I obviously wasn't spending as much on booze as the 2 groups next to me.  No sf health on the bill.  that made me smile.

7hLF7wIEID7AdZZqs0x1fw.review_text: Our friends have a picture hanging on their wall of THIS VERY BAR.  When we spotted it while walking around, we knew we had to go here.    I had a French 75.  It's my favorite cocktail, and it was beautifully executed.  I didn't have any absinthe..I wasn't in the mood.  I was giddy with joy when I saw Flagship on the menu.  I'm from Seattle.  I have gone to Beecher's shop in Pikes Place Market.  I bought pounds and pounds of the stuff at Costco.  The crap they brought us...it had a rind.  Flagship does not.  In addition, it didn't taste a thing like Flagship.  And when this was brought to our waitress' attention, she argued with us.  Whatever.  I'm right (as usual as my husband would say).

3mbHUTAkQBE5rgMaT7kVhw.review_text: The All Day Breakfast Burrito was awesome!!  Service left much to be desired...

mJHWZK3zl_FhdoYPVjBPcw.review_text: Had a Ginger Rogers, soft pretzels and a flatbread.   Ginger Rogers... Made me never want to drink anything but gin, lime, and ginger for as long as I live!!  So delightful! Soft pretzels were 100% savory and absolutely delicious....   Mmmmmm!  Hungry just thinking about them! The flatbread wasn't super memorable buuuuuut I'm not really a huge fan of pizzas and the like unless the circumstances are ideal so don't hold that against them! Our server was nice.  For sure food over priced.  I'd go back again.

rS4OEY7fWDZG_JuJjR9HWg.review_text: Had a delicious Croque Monsieur sandwich the other night while dining with a girlfriend. While my waistline wasn't too happy about the extra calories, my tummy was content and fat-happy after that meal. I also had some Oysters that were delish. The service is impeccable and the ambiance is top-notch.

-2sNTzGyci98Mp9PmPRg8w.review_text: You know what we are missing in Austin? We have everything from 7-course prix-fixe dinners, to some of the best Mexican food ever, to Polynesian food carts that serve intestines. But do you know what we are truly missing? A place like Absinthe.   Absinthe was Jen's choice for our Saturday brunch. We had reservations for 12:30, and even though we had to walk farther than we had planned because we bolted off the L bus when we suspected the guy next to us was preparing to shoot up heroin, as soon as I walked through Hayes Valley and its rich collection of home decor shops and arrived at Absinthe, I knew I was at home.   We arrived exactly on time, and were informed a booth was almost ready for us. We replied that was fine, and spent the next five minutes milling about a PACKED house. Jen told me this was normal, as not only was Absinthe just known as a fabulous restaurant all around, it also was a popular pre-show venue. Normally we'd sit at the bar, but I'm not lying when I said it was packed. Even the bench up front was occupied by a girl with a boyfriend who was clearly out of her league. I was just thinking he must've been on a whole lot of absinthe to be with her, when the hostess found us and informed us it was taking a lot longer than expected, and the people weren't leaving. I told her to tell them I was there, and kick their lolly-gagging behinds out. She laughed, not knowing I was only half-joking.   I decided to take in the decor while awkwardly standing around. It has a very warm, sumptuous look about it. I recall a lot of jewel tones (such as the maroon walls) and I loved the hardwoods and brass accents. It immediately reminded me of my favorite brunch spot in Boston, Stephanie's. Any place that has champagne on ice as a decoration is OK by me.   Finally, our corner booth was ready. The mural behind us on the wall was a nice touch. We settled in and ordered two bellinis (White peach purée and champagne). Great starter cocktail. I know it wasn't the most imaginative drink on their menu, but Mama was a little tired from all the gay bars the night before, and a bellini was the perfect ease-in drink of the moment.   Our appetizers included a flaky, buttery croissant with butter and jam, but the real stars were the deviled eggs. The presentation of the smoked salmon, salmon roe, and capers was just delightful. The flavors were perfect to get the appetite going. I could probably have eaten a dozen more, but we had oysters on the way.   At least I thought we did. Our orders of the Duck-Confit Ragout (Wild mushrooms, chive-potato cake, poached eggs, béarnaise sauce) and the Absinthe Hamburger (Storm hill angus beef, aïoli, red onion, lettuce, house-made pickles, and French fries) arrived next. My duck confit was cooked perfectly, and I appreciated the variation of textures with the crispy potato pancake and the soft, poached eggs. The meat portion could have been a little more generous, but overall it was excellent. Jen has become quite a connoisseur of hamburgers as of late, and remarked this ranked as one of her faves. I could tell by the thick, juicy patty she was right. (Sidenote: Can I make "Juicy Patty" work as a drag name?)   Our oysters arrived sometime in the middle of our entrees, which was odd. There were three different varieties, but we both agreed the smaller, sweeter versions were our favorite. However, consuming the raw oysters alongside our more savory meals did create an odd juxtaposition. We would have liked to have cleansed our pallets between the two.   Dessert--I opted for the Chocolate Pot De Creme (Valrhona Nyangbo chocolate, crème chantilly) and their suggested wine pairing of the Lustau, Dulce, Moscatel Sherry from Spain. The chocolate was divine, and not too sweet, allowing the sherry to add that layer in. Jen could not resist ordering the Persimmon Sticky Toffee Pudding with buttermilk vanilla ice cream and poached apples, mostly because 1.) She has rarely seen it on a menu, and 2.) It's one of her mother's holiday specialties, and she wanted to see how it stacked up. Final verdict? While it was indeed enjoyable, it wasn't quite up to the homemade version. But if you're looking for a particularly British-style dessert, this one is perfect.   5 Stars. 5 Stars all the way, except...service. A few points: 1.) A complimentary drink as an apology for our longer than anticipated wait would have been appropriate, but was not offered; 2.) The timing of the oysters was unacceptable; 3.) We were charged for an extra cocktail we did not order; and 4.) Empty plates languished far longer than they should have. It's all relatively minor stuff--and our brunch wasn't torpedoed or anything--but it explains why I had to deduct a star for an otherwise fantastic brunch.   I'll admit it. We don't have a truly upscale brunch spot like this in Austin. So... Dear Austin,         We need a place like Absinthe. NOW.    Thanks in advance,  Nathan.   4 Stars.

XrTrDvffM58Soes5NN9ayA.review_text: If you are ever dating someone who you have great sexual chemistry with but convo that doesn't flow, take them to dinner at Absinthe. You can sit side-by-side in the dim lighting on a plush banquette in the bar area so as to avoid the full-on face-to-face. You can order a cracked crab which is a hands-on project so it takes the focus off of the convo and onto what you do best together - being sensual- ripping apart the crab, pealing off the shells, pulling out the meat, dripping it in butter, feeding it to each other.. You can drink wine, nibble on caviar, drink more wine, touch each other on the thighs, get the coq a vin and say the word 'coq' over and over again, and drink more wine. If you are lucky and there's not to many people around when the scharffen berger chocolate pot de crème arrives you can put a big spoonful on your tongue and then give him a long deep kiss..   Absinthe is everything a french bistro should be sexy, dark and sensual with decadent food.

F8V2HTFnN67ydhr11iZhbg.review_text: We had a lunch here after our City hall wedding. It couldn't have been better. Our waiter was fantastic and the food was absolutely wonderful. We really enjoyed the decor and atmosphere. I had the Duck confit and it did not disappoint. Wonderful crisp skin and very moist and flavorful. My wife had the potato crusted salmon. it was equally good. Our waiter even came outside and flagged us down a cab. What a guy! We can't wait to come back for another visit.

J0ZKp7ASTxtfWfRJYBmrig.review_text: The Absinthe Brasserie and Bar in San Francisco is a wonderful French restaurant worth the price of admission, or, more precisely, of exit.   Of  late, I have started to enjoy cheese platters before dinner.  They have an excellent selection and will help you if you know as little about cheese as I do.  I had duck. I almost always have duck if it is on the menu and their duck confit with  chaterelles and toasted walnuts and garlic with their citrus-chardonney sause is  simply wonderful.  Everything we had there was.  The deserts were worth the calories.  Of course, with me, one of the main attratcions was the selection of Absinthes they had.  They know this spirit well and assisted me in making a wonderful choice.  They didn't even charge me for a second drink when I knocked the first one with my elbow and spilled it all over me after one sip (and at $28 a pop, this was very much appreciated).  Their wine list is, in my view, expansive, and like the Absinthe, they can help make the right choice.  The server was wonderful.  I advised her we were in no hurry and she was more than happy to assist us with the menu and to make the dinner one I will remember.  Everything was perfect

XmEywucVDyUP9VJ4SXGjzw.review_text: Absinthe is still quite the spot.  Pulse pounding crowds of people entering and leaving.  All very up tempo.  And with a new chef, good service and an interesting menu.  A small serving of almond cauliflower soup was refined comfort food.  More about texture and accents than the taste of cauliflower itself.  But very nice and well-portioned for the price.  Heirloom beet salad with goat cheese and some bread crisps was also very nice.   The beets were sweet and tasty, the cheese added a somewhat bitter accent; but the bread crisps were bland and added texture and nothing more.  A main of potato crusted arctic char with little gems looked institutional when placed on the table.  The fish on one side of the plate the greens on the other.  Fortunately, the fish was fresh and perfectly seared.  The little gems likewise were pristine and fresh.

81DfAXtigQtrorj4ClA3KQ.review_text: Before heading off to the SF Ballet to see the Nutcracker, our group met here for drinks.  I've never had the drinks here either, but I did get a nice cup of tap water.  Even on a Sunday night, it was super busy.    I never got a chance to try any food, because cheese and bread cost a fortune.  I decided to wait until after the Ballet to get a decent meal for that price.  Overall, I think it's a good place to mingle, but I can't tell you anything about the food.

CxWcGXtQSRJn6_C241xC9A.review_text: My friend and I didn't have this place in mind, but when plans fell through for dinner at another restaurant, we decided to eat here because he had heard good things (I think the previous chef Jamie Lauren was on Top Chef, season 5).  The place is huge, but we were seated in one of the darker corners of the restaurant near the bar. The other sections of the restaurant seemed brighter and more suited for families, I guess?  Server was meh, and our table was only about an inch away from the ones beside us, but we really enjoyed the food, despite it being on the pricey side. In the end we paid about $90 between the two of us for one cocktail each, two small dishes, one large dish and the fried garbanzo beans. We had the flatbread (soooooooo delicious, all the flavors really came across and went well together), the duck (tender on the inside, crispy on the outside, with sweet peaches, cream and greens), plus the burger. Sooooo good. Definitely a place to try at least once.

b72PPT6ObUckUCUjdzeUtQ.review_text: I think Absinthe is my favorite SF restaurant.  It's really good french cuisine.  The first time I went there was for a drug-company hosted talk and we sat in the private room.  I remember having french onion soup and coq au vin.  I truly thought I had died and gone to heaven.  To this day I cannot find a place with better french onion soup, dripping with yummy gruyere.  They have a good wine list and great cocktails.  I'm a gin drinker and there's always something good to try.  I have also gone here for brunch.  We took my mom and godmother once when they were visiting.  Mimosas, bloody marys, eggs benedict and the like were all fabulous.    How a place feels is important to me.  Absinthe is dim, with comfy booths and tables.  Nice crisp white linens.  Bonus - they have valet.  Just make sure to save a little room for a cupcake next door at Citizen Cake.

bmiAy-CdzxWPi3Yr_fljHw.review_text: Hungover and wishing I was back in bed, I was slightly annoyed that we had to trek to Hayes Valley from Union Sq. for our brunch reservations. Thankfully the trip was quick enough to get the much needed food in my belly.   We started with the butter lettuce salad and knowing we were sharing it the waitress brought it out split on two plates. Smooth butter lettuce and crisp slices of watermelon radishes were paired with a cider vinaigrette that was only slightly acidic - very easy on the stomach for a Sunday morning.   My friend's ricotta pancakes were perfectly done with a toasted outside but soft cheesy inside. The caramel apples lent a nice sweetness to the dish without overpowering it with sugar.   I couldn't decide between a bunch of other delicious sounding dishes but finally settled on the"breakfast sandwich'. Fried duck egg, raclette and andouille sausage on grilled brioche was a nice twist to a classic favorite, although I felt  the sausage was a bit too salty for a dehydrated weak stomach. After seeing every other table order a burger I was wondering if I missed the "big hit".   An order of brunch potatoes were the much needed carbs our stomachs needed. Thick cut, roasted just enough to keep the outside crisp and the insides tender, starchy and yummy.   After stuffing our faces and 3 cups of coffee later, we were recharged and ready for some Hayes St. shopping. Absinthe offers a bustling atmosphere that reminded me of the energy found in similar NYC brasseries - Les Halles, Balthazar, Pastis - it's stimulating for a Sunday afternoon meal. It gets crowded so make reservations or be prepared to wait.

HSFXuYnNMGCJuRu_DvzLRg.review_text: Had our first annual holiday dinner with one of my group of girlfriends here and I have to say it was a good choice.  Nice ambiance for a girl's night out or a romantic date. Food was delicious, I had the duck that was cooked to a perfect medium rare and had a great sauce. The rice hash was very different and I thought I wouldn't like but was a great accompany to the duck. I usually eat only a portion of my meals when going out to eat but had to devour this one to the very last bit of sauce on the plate. Definitely a place I would like to take the bf to on a special night or when we want to splurge a little.

e9UPHIeBJ54Z4kaaGSW7yQ.review_text: Highly recommend the cocktails. Make reservations, and even then, expect to spend a little time at the bar waiting for your table

dqwk2Zv5aKKZFmirn8kkZQ.review_text: Absinthe has become somewhat of a regular spot for me... great drinks, bar menu, ambiance, and service. Last time I went in, I got the Fame to drink (super refreshing!) and we ordered the garlic pretzels, fried chickpeas,  and flatbread pizza. All were delicious! I highly recommend getting the garlic pretzels... they're doughy little balls of deliciousness.

NnSczz_889Ejm3hXrquy-Q.review_text: Had a fantastic dining experience at Absinthe and I only wish there was something like this in San Diego. The ambiance is small, but comfortable. We had an excellent little table next to a wall that felt intimate, even in the lively restaurant. Our server was nice and very knowledgeable, especially about different kinds of Abinsthe and when it came to recommending them.  We started with the Chickpeas and the Pretzels. Chickpeas were fried perfectly crispy and nicely spiced. These are delicious and a PERFECT bar food. I could snack on these all day and night! Pretzels are bite-sized, soft little salty, yeasty morsels, accompanied with an excellent cheese double-dip-me-please sauce.  I had an unforgettable dinner here, which unfortunately is no longer on the menu. It was Sea Bass, sunchoke puree, roasted brussel sprouts, and a vadouvan-caper beurre noisette, which is fancy-talk for a friggin-delicious butter sauce. I loved everything about this dish: how excellent the fish was cooked, how perfectly everything was seasoned, the creamy sunchoke puree, and most of all, the friggin-delicious butter sauce.  Hubby devoured his Filet that came with fried garlic chips, melt-in-your-mouth mashed potatoes and asparagus. It was delicious, and cooked just right. For dessert, we had a Butternut Squash Cake, which I wouldn't recommend, although it is also off the menu now. Cocktails were all very good, especially my St-Germain infused one, but do try the Absinthe. Our waiter gave us excellent recommendations and we highly enjoyed it.

7j_syb_HopcSgw5CEVoDKw.review_text: I've had brunch here a bunch of times and it's super yummy!! Cocktails are awesome and they have an extensive list, I mean, binder of choices :-) I have yet to have dinner here, but if it's as good as brunch then I'm sure it'll be great.    For brunch if you're feeling savory try the burger with all the fixings, its delicious, but you'll need a digestive nap afterwards. If you're feeling sweet try the ricotta stuffed french toast. Also, I took my mom here (yes, I'm a shameless Italian mama's boy) the other day and she had the crab sandwich with bacon and thoroughly enjoyed it.   If you sit at the bar the bartenders are usually pretty cool and fun to talk to if they aren't running around like crazy.  If you're in need of some coffee to help you burn through all the yummy food you just ate, try closing out your culinary delight with a Spanish Coffee.  They really good and a lot of fun to watch the bartender make (think fire, melting sugar, and burning cinnamon, YUM!!).

jGoKQxSU_bh-aBPlr-9jEQ.review_text: Big fan of Absinthe. Great selection of cocktails and every time I've ordered food I've been extremely satisfied. Love the intimate setting and atmosphere.

RUAb4yMazoRbbCNAxlbsFQ.review_text: Much ado about NOTHING!  I am a hands-down Top Chef fan.  I, being the devoted follower of all things "TC," decided it was time to check out Jaime's culinary skills at Absinthe.    One of my galpals and I wanted to make a night of it.  We ordered champagne, apps, entrees, and dessert.  We wanted to really check Absinthe out.    Apps: 1.  The smallest oysters I have ever seen in my entire life.  It was about the size of my thumb (just the tip).  I was shocked that they charged $3 per each oyster.  Had we known, we would have never ordered 6 of them.  Rip off! 2.  French fries with aioli, was absolutely delish!  I could have eaten handfuls of those fries.  They were seasoned perfectly, potato-y, and altogether lovely.   Entree: 1.  I ordered the halibut with sunchokes.  It was BLAND.  No salt, no pepper.  I had to cover my entire plate with S & P and finally I could taste the fish.  The fish was cooked perfectly, crispy on the outside, silky on the inside, but without flavor, who cares?  2.  She ordered the lamb shank.  I am not a huge fan of lamb, it's way to gamey for me, but even so, I still tried a bite (because I'm a daredevil), and it was alright.  She said it was "falling off the bone" good, I believed her.   Dessert: 1.  After stuffing our face with mediocre food and apps, we wanted to end our meal on a high-note.  Glanced through the dessert menu, saw the lychee sorbet, thought brilliant!  It came on a bowl with these tricky crunchy bits, that I still have no idea what they were used for or why it was on the sorbet in the first place.  The dessert was NASTY!  It was bitter and left the most funkiest aftertaste.  The waiter saw our disposition and asked if everything was alright.  We told him that our sorbet was not good and he suggested ordering another dessert (on him).  He recommended the panna cotta, so we obliged.  At that point, whatever.   The panna cotta was again, weird.  It came with strawberries and graham cracker (so far, so good), and PESTO!  Come again?!?!?  What the sam hill...  It was like eating cheese pesto with strawberries.    I sighed.  She sighed.  We laughed and shook our heads.  It was time for the check.   It was about $77/person.  A bit pricey given how "not good" the food was.   I will say this much, the service was outstanding, too bad the food doesn't compare.    Will I ever go back there again?  Maybe for the pappas fritas, otherwise, NEXT!

ZvC5l-_x5c6bUK2TZNtRfw.review_text: My girlfriend and I went there we had fun the service was excellent and the drink were strong and the dinner was great with good service. I will begoing back soon.  Part of the fun was the company.

PC1QjVXVy1iVPbP-zLgpQw.review_text: The really nice thing about Absinthe, for which you need reservations to eat in the restaurant proper, is that you can also eat dinner at a table in the bar section. My friend and I were lucky enough to be able to walk right up and grab a small copper table by the front window and enjoy the ambiance with less than 15 minutes wait (on a Saturday night at 6pm, no less. I suspect that is rather unusual, but so it went).  My friend had the French Onion Soup which smelled delicious, but was probably not vegetarian.  There are very few vegetarian dishes offered, but I had the mixed local greens salad which was really good.  Likewise my friend had the Dungeness crab which he seemed to enjoy while I really liked the the Roasted Baby Beets and Quinces, quite good!  I don't really recommend this place for hardcore vegetarians or vegans, but for a mellow, dairy-vegivore like me it was great!

8BWHn8BNHtRW4rbzFc3u5w.review_text: I came in here last weekend to meet a friend from culinary school for a good drink. She had a negroni and I had a glass of sancerre. Both were delicious. The bar is lovely and busy.. it was early around 7pm but still the place got more and more crowded. By 7:30 i was starved so we decided to grab a table while we still could and have a bite to eat.   We shared the pretzels with cheddar mornay, she had the burrata and I had the beef tartare. Everything was just OK. The burrata was pretty delicious because well it's burrata and there's little you have to do to make this more " melt in your mouth". My beef tartare was very "herby" too much taragon and parsley and there's a better version over at Wayfare Tavern for the same price.   Overall. this place in Hayes Valley is great for drinks but you're better off diving elsewhere in the area.

FsE3Ol4yUfJZZX8pGV0Rvw.review_text: Absinthe is a must when it come to fine dining in town. Definitely my favourite French restaurant in SF. Me and my friend came for the lunch during dine about town week and was very satisfied. Amazing service and very welcoming atmosphere. Some highlights recommended from our order: Coconut-corn soup, Potato Crusted Salmon, German Chocolate cake. I didn't get the hype from the French Onion Soup. Was good but not the best I've had. Still would definitely like to come back.

mmaE7ZZxYiite10QSvWEOA.review_text: Came here with some friends. Always wanted to try it since I watched the seaon with Jamie in  Top Chef.   I had the brioche with pear. It was slightly brown on the outside, crisped from rich flavorful butter, and soft inside from the cream. Oh it was delicious with the maple syrup and soft pear.  I wanted to try the Earl Grey Pavlova but damn, I felt too obese from that buttery french toast!  And what a boisterous place! I recommend you make reservations before coming here.

Ic8KhzNeAUVcTLK__iOHlw.review_text: Food was really good! Had their steak. Portions are good for me. Plate was clean. Their desserts were pretty tasty as well. We tried three different desserts.   The 4 stars are purely based on food.   Service was pretty bad. The guy forgot about one order and mixed up a drink order. He hardly checked up on us. I would only suggest going here on a weekday evening when it isn't so packed.   We left to go to another bar, but it was too packed. We ended up going back to Absinthe. The bartender was not very kind. They have an extensive drink list though.   Service was 1 star for me.

sYtO-WgBz9oShCaezw2UwQ.review_text: I came to absinthe with two of my girlfriends. We showed up about 20 minutes early for our reservation on a thursday night, but they were very accommodating and seated us right away, so 1 point for them!  The restaurant vibe was great-- a little loud overall but where we were seated was quiet enough. Our service also was really great, 5 star service.  We ordered to start the fried chickpeas, french onion soup, caesar salad, and the garlic pretzels. All of them were really really good, but honestly... those garlic pretzels were out of this world. Like, in the running for best thing I've ever eaten. Just thinking about them right now is making me want to go back!  Two of us ordered burgers and then our other friend got the coq au vin. The chicken and the sauce was really good-- I only had a bite. The burger was good, but honestly it was nothing special.   I think when I go back I will probably either sit and the bar and just eat those garlic pretzels like there is no tomorrow, or I will order a different entree.  Overall: 5 stars for service, 5 stars for the appetizers, and 4 stars for the absinthe burger. (I'd love to give this a 4.5, but overall it was a great experience so I'll bump it up to 5)

zyLIp7DRFqeIE1Grrh3Zng.review_text: Had the burger here, really delicious with our servers recommendations to add caramelized onions, fried egg, and avocado.  The 7 oz patty was very juicy and nicely seasoned.  Good dirty martini.  Nice place in Hayes Valley to have a drink at the bar. Have yet to partake in their pickles/drink happy hour.

uEE9O8nn1PT5dCbqFN11pA.review_text: Great cocktails and the food is terrific! Loved every bite of my omelet with crab. Can't wait to go back for dinner. Brunch was definitely a success.

1DP8r48ONQsDZOMgr0ZY-w.review_text: Why I give 3 stars:  1. food was decent but over priced. 2. Seating is very close to others  3. Nice place for drinks 4. Very nice decor inside.  5. service is okay. Could have been better  I probably would recommend this place for lunch or for drinking at the bar but not really for a nice enjoyable dinner though. I've only been here once so it maybe better the next time.

0P99_VOWLdUNlYlSCuzwpg.review_text: The reviews say it all, this place is both amazing in ambiance and food. We were a party of 10 our server was all about it. Our huge group didn't phase her at all. It was absolutely a great experience. Great brunch cocktails "buck's" Bellini. YUM Breakfast burrito- YUMO Shrimp salad on a roll- Fabulous! Will certainly be back.

QMvKdCyjwCzqQey1Y32nKQ.review_text: Delightful place with really spectacular cocktails--years before the trend took over the majority of bars in the city.  Food can be a trifle over the top rich, but always delicious.  There is a feel of luxury about this place, the setting and service reflect this--and of course the prices too.

aGYvA2vEwv34rzuJJfVXhw.review_text: Just Eh.  good fun drinks, but the food is average and not memorable at all. Sure the service is good, but I come for the FOOD!

AGguH04Fs6s-0fqUAw8hXw.review_text: Just a stop this time at the bar on a late Sunday afternoon for a drink on our way to dinner. Very nice service, great wine and beer. And enough turnover that we 4 did get seats at the bar for the bit of time we were there. Great ambiance. We'll be back for drinks and dinner again for sure.

mUWCHtlYW_nAJlT1EnBMQQ.review_text: Finally had a late dinner here after hearing from so many about their fabulous burger. The place was slammed but the service was decent. Cocktails were interesting. Loved the fried chickpeas and expected them to set the pace for the rest of the meal. Ordered a burger and fries. The burger was so salty my mouth was burning (and I drank a gallon of water later on). The bun was uninspired. The fries were good, but definitely not great. The burger was so awful I just wanted to pay the tab and get out as quickly as possible. I so wanted to love this place.

I-0Be1dHEacp293TeRUDpw.review_text: Wow- amazing lunch! I wish I worked/lived in the area so I could come more often. City workers, lucky you!  I had a croque monsieur and it was fabulous! Also had a virgin absinthe lemonade before heading back to work... def dying to go back for the real deal! My partner had the most amazing sandwich ever, which was just on San Francisco mag.   Look forward to coming back, this time for dinner, with DRINKS!

WkBSBfRRloP6QFH7O8I5dg.review_text: Been to Absinthe several times for lunch & dinner...Has consistently come through and delivered strong performances every time (the Coq Au Vin is great by the way).  One meal that I had never tried there was brunch.  Finally had the pleasure this weekend.  The host set us up with a wonderful table right by the window.  Since it was a perfect sunny day, this was awesome...felt like I could grasp each ray of sunshine coming through the glass...but I digress...back to the review...So we ordered the Croque Monsieur & the Banana-Blueberry-Souffle Pancakes.  They were perfectly prepared.  Both dishes were very tasty and not too greasy.  Overall, I'm really glad I finally checked brunch out at Absinthe.  I would go as far as saying that it's their best meal offering of the day...Being kind of a brunch snob, that's pretty impressive in my book.

HGXZCJuWzdP9aAiAkLJe1Q.review_text: Went here for my 21st birthday dinner with girlfriends. Left a message to make a reservation and my call was returned the next day. Very cute neighborhood, and a nice dark, romantic interior. Definitely would be an ideal place to go on a date.   Our waitress was knowledgeable and patient and explained what exactly absinthe is more thoroughly than I think any of us cared to know, but still very nice of her. She recommended cocktails and checked on the gluten content of the liqueurs for my gluten-sensitive friends. I got the Galapagos cocktail and it was perfectly strong and sweet.  We ordered the soft pretzels as recommended by 7x7 and they were truly to die for. Might be the best bread product I've ever eaten.   Entrees were good, although one of us ordered a Caesar salad which turned out to be 4 leaves of romaine hearts with a slice of Parmesan on top...not nearly enough for dinner. I wish our waitress had given some kind of warning about the size of the salad.   Coq au Vin, stone fruit salad, and the swordfish were all really delicious, but my friend who ordered the hamburger didn't seem as thrilled about her dish as the rest of us were. Other than our poor friend with the 4-leaf salad, portions were big and it took a little effort to clear our plates.   Complimentary strawberry sorbet served as dessert for my birthday, which was very nice of our waiter. All in all a good experience and we all left full and happy!

tLaJ2WAQhiLpCMI5ugSwHA.review_text: I came here for brunch this past Sunday with my mom and we loved it! The place we originally tried to go to had an enormous un-organized line out front so we drove a little ways and parked.     We stopped at one other French place before coming upon Absinthe. The name alone sold us (recently we've tried and loved absinthe for the first time) and the menu looked scrumptious and also accommodating (she's a vegetarian and I'm vegan).     It has a very quaint Parisian feel yet has plenty of room for busy brunches and packed dinners. I got the French Toast with strawberries. Yum yum yum yum!!! The bread was thick sourdough... It came with three pieces but the were so filling I only ate one and a half. The strawberries and nuts on top were divine. My mom got the blueberry buttermilk pancakes which came with I think a lemon flavored kind of cream. She was in heaven.     Overall this place is a fantastic brunch spot with that warm Parisian feel and delicious food.

lvGlIBv4xkHiQBnNOuRYZQ.review_text: awesome brunch. had their version of eggs benedict as well as the french onion soup.   everything that everyone ordered was awesome. just a great meal.

CRQxUA153gfihCM7eR8psA.review_text: Wow, wow, wow...how have I not been here before? The food is pricey, but it is AMAZING. I had the Coq de Vin (spelling?) chicken and it melted in my mouth. Pure decadence on a plate. My friends had the Halibut and something else. We all thought it was amazing. A nice dark lounge like vibe, but not a lounge at all. Fun for friends, business dinner, or a romantic date.

rp9my_uNCGKYgAh4FN29Pg.review_text: I don't like veggies but I did eat 2 dishes of veggies at Absinthe: spicy fried chickpeas and a frisee salad (with a fried duck egg, caviar and bacon).  Granted, both items were fried or contained something fried but I happily ate all the veggies off both plates!!  I also quickly polished off the cheeseburger.  DE-licious.   Service was a little slow but at least they were attentive when they came by.

K7-zOceF1slgqJTZSKe7YQ.review_text: Hello green ferry!    This is a great place to come for drinks.  We had a couple of absinthe drinks, which was a really fun experience.  It comes with the absinthe, sugar, and water that you're supposed to pour over the sugar cube.  I found the drink to be a nice sipping drink on a night when you just want to take it easy.  I think we also had the 'sacred heart' drink, which also had absinthe, pomegranate and a twist of lemon.  I also had the scallops and raw oysters.  All were delicious.   I would definitely come back here.

jNsPTMmg9EcqY7q2Q-Rm6A.review_text: came by in the afternoon with my cousin and sat at the bar - grabbed some cocktails and bar snacks. LOVED everything we ordered, and bartenders were very friendly.  as for drinks, we ordered the Citron Lemonade and Sacred Heart, and for snacks, we ordered the Spicy Fried Chickpeas and Marinated Olives. I had the Sacred Heart, which I really enjoyed. As for the snacks, the olives were your usual olives, but we both LOVED the spicy friend chickpeas. such a simple snack, yet unique, and when you eat it, you're just kind of like "OMG".  overall, great afternoon snack experience. definitely want to come back, do it all again, and possibly dine here.

RdxQYJC6Bs6ItbPr2IAvtg.review_text: Great-Original cocktails, but be prepared for them to be STRONG. I'm so used to bars that are very light on the alcohol when they pour, this place will not let you down if you're looking for something with a bit of a bite!   We ordered some cheese to start, a little pricey but definitely good. Be sure to use all of the ingredients that they put on the plate, they are paired with the cheese for a reason!   We then split a filet, which was served with potatoes, some spinach, and a beautiful sauce. SO delicious. By far my favorite part of my meal. If it was socially acceptable to lick the plate, I would have.  We finished our night at Absinthe with their "napoleon". Don't order this if you're looking for a traditional style napoleon. This was unfortunately the only part of my meal that I didn't think was absolutely outstanding. We knew it was a unique variation of the treat, but I didn't quite care for it.  Service was lovely, lighting is both edgy and romantic. A little loud towards the front where the bar is, much quieter in the back where the seating is. Be sure to make a reservation as the place is pretty busy. We made ours on OpenTable and ate here after going to the symphony. Check this place out if you're around the area!

A1mJ0kf_4UhFriEu0KkwNw.review_text: I've always been curious about Absinthe during seven years of living in the city and I finally quelled my interest over dinner on a Saturday night.  We had a dinner reservation as the place is extremely popular at night and sat at a two-top in the dining area behind the bar.  We passed the owner of the Boxing Room on our way to the back - he must give Absinthe a thumbs up as well because it looked like he was loving his soup.  The list of cocktails is extensive but our waiter helped me decide on an absinthe drink called the Sazecar (I think that's the name).  It was good and strong.  The Citron Lemonade is also good, light and fresh.  Our appetizer was the delicious soft garlic pretzels (also on the 7x7 Big Eat SF list).  For $8 and five little bite-sized pretzels, they are probably the most expensive pretzels around but with the melted Vermont cheddar on the side they are nearly to-die-for.  We then shared Roasted Beet and Green Apple Salad.  Well done and I recommend.  As for entrees, the Coq Au Vin (chicken) and the Pork Osso Buco are musts.  Both were devine and I would eat again.  Absinthe won me over and except for the loudness of the bar feeding into our meal, I will go again.

qN5TasA_y2tS5s-LxoTaqw.review_text: During Dine About Town 2012 I made a reservation at Absinthe Brasserie & Bar. The list of restaurants during Dine About Town is longer than I will have opportunities to try, but just the name alone drew me in. I've always wanted to try absinthe (the drink), so I figured this place would have some options.  First, let me give you a suggestion: arrive early. The Hayes Valley neighborhood is a very nice area to walk around in. There are some restaurants, bars, and stores to look in (I saw other places I want to try), and a nice little parklet on Octavia a block away. A second suggestion: take MUNI! Absinthe isn't far from the Van Ness MUNI rail station, and then you don't have to worry about parking, feeding meters - or drinking & then needing to drive.  Walking around the exterior of the restaurant, the first things you notice are the golden logo on the glass, and the Private Dining room to the right. This looks like a great venue for a private event, with entrance, restroom, and bar separate from the main restaurant.  Walking into the restaurant, I was immediately drawn in by the color scheme, very warm & inviting. This seems like a great place for a date or a business brunch, and I saw both types of diners the afternoon I went.  I've never had absinthe before, and the menu listed many options. I asked my waiter for help. He explained that different absinthes have different strenghts of flavor. The main flavors in absinthe are anise (like black licorice), with a background floral note. He suggested a mid range absinthe from France. A glass is served to you, ~1/3 filled with absinthe; this particular one looked clear like vodka. A slotted spoon with a sugar cube in it are placed on top of the absinthe glass. A separate container of chilled water, and a glass of ice cubes are also supplied. You very slowly drip chilled water over the ice cube, dropping sugared water into the glass. The absinthe clouds to a milky white color, called the louche. The waiter explained that normally you'll end up with double the amount of liquid in the glass. He said the best thing is, taste at various points to figure out how you like it (you can always add more water, but you can't take any away). My taste was approximately doubling the amount of liquid, using up virtually all the sugar, and 2 ice cubes. Everyone's different. I don't love black licorice, so I didn't love this drink, but I can check that off my bucket list. I'd like to try some of the absinthe cocktails on the menu as well.  For lunch, I had pan roasted Mary's chicken breast. You could say it's hard to mess up chicken, and it's also hard to distinguish your dish from another. But this chicken was excellently prepared, moist inside, with just the right thin crunchy exterior. Very tasty. It was served on a bed of mash potatoes which were rich, creamy & delicious, and rainbow chard with mushrooms that were flavored with the chicken jus. I ate everything on my plate. This is one of those dishes that sounds deceptively simple, but getting it to taste just right is difficult. This was excellent.  For dessert, they served a roasted white chocolate panna cotta with raspberries & a cocoa nib crumble. It had the consistency of a vanilla pudding, covered with some crunchy chocolate bits & raspberries. Not heavy, just a nice finish to an excellent meal.  A very tasty meal at a fine restaurant. Service was excellent. I had a nice chat with the couple next to me about other Dine About Town experiences. Their dinner menu looks a tad expensive, but their brunch & lunch menus look reasonable, and of course the Dine About Town menu was a great deal.  - Adam

habA0R6JXSY-mxnawlg8lA.review_text: Really poor lunch... mostly because the service was really bad, long, with a non polite waitress, wearing a dirty shirt :(((

IAPYgh6vQNlL8R2Bs3iQGQ.review_text: The restaurant was a nice space.  The service was great. we felt well taken care of...  The food did not blow me away. If you are walking away from a restaurant and the salad is the best item that you had, there is something wrong. For what was spent on dinner, i've had better.

rZLqAZbRfiyUDLVmDqhdbg.review_text: The food is always spectacular, but the service left something to be desired on Saturday night. We had to wait a long time for our drink order, despite the server knowing that we had a show to catch, and had to ask multiple times where are drinks were. There was no waitress to be found when we needed to flag someone down. Twice, items were delivered to only a couple members of our party while the rest waited. Very disappointing as the meal itself was expensive (tasty, but expensive) and the service certainly affected our enjoyment of the meal.

ygn1QWGOyJPbfDo5Nekk9Q.review_text: The food at Absinthe is very mediocre. I give it three stars for the nice ambiance.  The onion soup was the highlight of my lunch. It's very cheesy (expect big chunks of melted cheese) and pretty rich so I got tired of it halfway.  The croque monsieur and the burger were just regular dishes you can expect to get anywhere else.   I can't comment on Absinthe's dinner because I haven't had it, but is it so much better than its lunch that it gets 1500 reviews and four stars? That's hard to believe.

7fltnO-v3-Btdonpi99cjA.review_text: Out of town review - my sister took me to dine here while I was visiting and I thank my lucky stars that she picked up the tab!  Overpriced?  Yup!  Ambiance is great, service and food was okay, and there was a bit of a wait even with a reservation.    I did enjoy the fried chickpeas but probably will not come back here even if it's on someone else's dime.

uNIyxmljF0IVuVEifJNQ6g.review_text: After a great dinner with friends in Hayes Valley, it seemed only appropriate to drop into one of the more famous, albeit crowded, bars in the area for a smart cocktail.  Absinthe features Jaime Lauren, one of my favorite contestants from the Bravo show Top Chef, and has become a local hero for her energy and creativity in the kitchen.  While we only really came for the absinthe loaded drinks, I was excited at the potential of being able to meet her.  Absinthe is known for serving up some excellent absinthe cocktails and it was my first change to try some.  I ultimately ordered a drink without the green stuff but did get a chance to try it via friends' cocktails.  I haven't quite warmed up to the unique flavor and effects but can see myself enjoying it after a few tries.  I ordered the "Scarlett O'Hara" which consisted of Willett Single Barrel Bourbon, Nardini Amaro, and Leopard Brothers blackberry liqueur, with a lemon twist.  It was extremely tasty and the twist was peeled on the spot, which added an additional layer of quality and freshness to the cocktail.  Since we were occupying a table, we decided to order some fries to nibble on.  The fries were delicious with their bell pepper aioli, Dijon mustard, and vinegar dipping sauces and I really enjoyed the small cut with perfect crispness.  However, the fries were cut a little too small for my tastes and were a little difficult to eat.  While we didn't get a chance to meet Jaime, we did get to enjoy some really great cocktails.  The service and ambiance were extraordinary and it as a great venue to hangout and catch up with friends.  I'm not sure whether absinthe has quite grown on me yet, but it was definitely an interesting new drink.  Absinthe is every bit the awesome, classic bar that many have raved about, and despite the inflated cost of the cocktails, worth every penny for the unique experience.  Come for dinner and you just might be able to have your picture taken with San Francisco's own Chef Jaime!  Food: 8/10  Service: 9/10  Price: $$$  Atmosphere: 9/10

oEvsA_IvL0yRyI7d4lT-IA.review_text: We walked in right at 10:55 a.m for brunch, and the two best things about it were 1. no wait, and 2. no $ for street parking. We had the deviled eggs (super good, loved the smoked salmon with capers), the duck-confit ragout, and the ricotta-stuffed french toast. Both dishes were good, but if I had to pick again, I would pick the ragout. The potato-chive cake was executed perfectly and was a well-planned dish. The duck could have been little more moist. The French toast was great but I wasn't a big fan of the cherries, but that might just be me.   The restaurant was packed by the time we left, so come early or be prepared for a longgg wait.

v4OqcE77gEAelwYU8lbP7w.review_text: This review is of my dinner during Halloween weekend. Better late than never, right? we were a party of three without a reservation and were sat in a reasonable amount of time. The table was in the bar area, which had the smell of vanilla candles. Looking around, I couldn't spot the candles, so it may have been a guest with heavy perfume. i't was somewhat heavy handed and distracting when we first got it. Once our drinks and food came, we were able to forget the candle smell.  The service was ok. They sat us and the server wasn't able to get to our table to take care of us right away. The service was otherwise fine. It was kind of full in the bar area (Halloween weekend people, so there were a few people in costumes too) so it was difficult to tell how busy the rest of the restaurant was. The only misgiving I have was for the server who told us, after the fact, how we are supposed to taste the wine when the wine is corked. It was well intentioned, but we just felt awkward afterward.  My kudos go mostly to the food. We started with the chickpeas, oyster shooters, and pretzels. The oyster shooters were some great call backs to bloody marys that used the brininess of the oysters. The pretzels had a smooth, creamy mornay that made be miss those big pretzels in malls and movie theaters. The potato crusted arctic char was well seasoned, had a crispy golden potato crust, but overcooked for my taste. Pork rib eye was great. The red cabbage was just the acidic touch that helped cut through the cheesy grits and juicy pork. What I liked about the vegetarian plate was that it was even artfully plated. Just doing a Veg Plate is one thing, but to take the time to conceptualize the plating shows that the kitchen really cares about making the food a part of the experience.

WtZyXabdl1bP1XJ7vQRG-A.review_text: "What's a brasserie?" my partner asked. "I don't know, isn't it French?"  I leave the French, Spanish and Russian words to him.  Brasserie: an unpretentious tavern that serves drinks and food  I can see this place being "unpretentious" in the SF sense because the furnishings are classic, not unusual or unique.  But the restaurant is beautiful, the decor alone making it perfect for an elegant date night.  What took it over the top was the outstanding meal.  --- FOOD: Summer Menu 14 ----  Crispy Skin Pork Belly: 5 stars. The crispy outer layer had a perfect heft to it, like crunching down on a chunk of honeycomb, then having the fleshy fat fill in your mouth around the perfectly tender pork belly meat. Every element on that dish contributed to the complexity:  from the tangy pickled root (fennel?) to sweet cherry, perfumed arugula, and whipped fennel cream like a soup I would slurp up if I had a whole bowl of it.  California Swordfish: 5 stars I asked the server to help me decide between this and the Potato-crusted Salmon. She said "Oh, the swordfish. All day." The smell of the dish preceded it as it approached: a sweet adolescent char, telling you that a grill was used but not excessively. A perfect browned seared crust makes a knocking sound when tapped with a fork, flat and evenly brown and caramelized hard, not soggy. When I took a bite I was shocked, "Is this sashimi?" from the way it burst in my mouth. But it was perfectly cooked, juicy, just heaven.  The plate was swirled with umami-filled sauces - a golden corn purée, orange pepper cream, and the juicy red peppers were amazing.  Roasted Leg of Lamb: 4.5 stars Mascarpone polenta, porcinis, zucchini gratin, charred tomatoes, pine nuts, black garlic jus.  German Chocolate Cake: 3.5 stars Good, but tasted much better when I jettisoned the coconut layer under the cake. Also, the candied roasted pecans stole the show.  Buttermilk Panna Cotta: 4.5 stars A lovely light refreshing dessert, not too sweet except too much Basil cream on top.  Perfect with the Moscato slightly fizzy dessert wine  ---- FOOD: Fall Menu 14 ----  Wonderlust: 5 stars Delightful cocktail in a martini glass, containing creme de violette, absinthe, and lemon juice.  Sazerac: 4 stars  Heirloom Tomato Salad: 4.5 stars The melons were sweet, countering the piquancy of arugula, and cradled by the glob of soft crescenza cheese.  Beef Grilled Black Angus shoulder: 3.5 stars Good quality beef, standard, would've been better if the mashed potatoes and mushrooms had been dressed in a more intriguing sauce.  Caramel Panna Cotta: 4 stars Bruleed marshmallows with a delicious burnt caramel cream and spiced apples in the bottom.  Goat Cheesecake: 4 stars Light and not too sweet, not as creamy as crumbly.

1GvVA0POzfoQpvq4ziTfDA.review_text: This place never fails to deliver the best french union soup I have ever had! However last time we got there we had the worst server ever. She was all over the guy who was sitting next to us. She even sat on his lap. Not professional.   Otherwise this place has good food and good drinks.

B8h0JIKorcV8LbDouurNIw.review_text: A strong 4.5 stars rounded up to 5.   My boyfriend and I booked a table here last Saturday night at 9pm. I didn't expect the bar area to be so crowded, but we managed to get a drink pretty quickly anyway while they readied our table. (We were a bit early).   My boyfriend was a bit worried as the valet parked his car right out front and what seemed to be a little too close to the curb, but from what I could tell after dinner the rims weren't scratched (big deal on a new GTI.)  My boyfriend ordered this insane Chipotle-infused vodka which I accidentally sipped and regretted it (yuck!) But he liked it so I'm not marking off any points for that.   We sat and ordered the fried spiced garbonzo beans which my boyfriend was crazy about but I was impartial to them. He then got the French onion soup which he said was delicious. Entrees: the bf got beef cheek (WEIRD) but very delicious and I got the cornbread- stuffed chicken which was tender and yummirific. The plate could have used a bit more of that squash or whatever sweet puree was on the side of the plate, but overall it was delicious.  Now here is where Absinthe really earned their 5 stars: the dessert.  I had this mind-blowing coffee ice cream with some kind of pastries and candied brazil nuts and OMG I thought I had died and gone to heaven.  Alas, I didn't see the bill, so I can't say price-wise how it was. (VERY expensive I'm sure!)   I would have hated to sat in the front room with the bar because it looked cramped and was kinda noisy. Not sure if that area is for walk-ins or what (we booked ahead on OpenTable). But I really enjoyed the service, the fun painted walls, and the overall ambiance.  Not sure if I'll be back for dinner because it's kind of a "do it once and check it off your list" thing (and the $$$ factor) but I'd definitely love to try a brunch here.  Merci bcp!!

q0HDybhT0V9dXrs63_WqWQ.review_text: I've wanted to try this place for the longest time. Yes, it is because Jamie was on Top Chef (I'll admit it). My friend Mike and I came here for dinner not too long ago; I was a little upset because he'd been here once before and neglected to tell me. Anyway, we started off with a couple oyster shooters (with bloody mary, of course). The vodka was strong! But that didn't keep us from having another haha. As an appetizer, we started off with a cheese plate, which was delicious. I believe it was the Pierre Robert cow's milk with grapes, and toasted bread. Mmmm...  As for the entrees, definitely the wild mushroom risotto stood out for me. I love mushrooms, and the risotto was super creamy and was the perfect portion. Not too big, not too small. The stuffed chicken was also fantastic, a little crispy on the outside and definitely moist on the inside. Unfortunately, I just looked at the menu, and it looks like they change it every month depending on what's in season. Look's like I'm coming to try the August menu soon!

59Zmdh7FJ3xTn68D6uc-HQ.review_text: Wow.  We were in San Francisco last weekend and decided to go to Absinthe for brunch.  Okay, disclaimer: my boyfriend and I are big Top Chef fans and have been rooting for Jamie all season.  So we call, ask for a reservation 1/2 an hour away, and BART it over to the Civic Center station.   We were seated towards the back.  The clientele ranged from yuppies to locals sitting at the bar, drinking, to moms sipping wine with their little kids coloring.  I got the Absinthe lemonade (highly recommended) and the breakfast sandwich (minus the meat).  The sandwich had duck egg, raclette, and sage on brioche and was accompanied by a mixed green salad.  Everything was so well-balanced and delicious.  My boyfriend got a take on eggs benedict with corn cakes, ham, egg and hollandaise and some potatoes.  We also tried the pommes frites which were crispy and came with some tasty sauces.  Everything was so clean, fresh, and delicious.    We decided to splurge and order desert.  I got the chocolate/banana dessert trio which included a dense chocolate-banana tart, caramelized bananas in salted caramel, and a scoop of banana sorbet.  The plating was beautiful and everything was so flavorful.  By boyfriend got the buttermilk panna cotta and enjoyed that as well.  The best food that we've had in quite some time, easily.  Additionally, perhaps the highlight of the day, was that Jamie wound up coming out of the kitchen to talk to the diner behind us...

tcXbDFbFKrEA3Bks_zAm0Q.review_text: Mmmm! Get the cheese plate. Love the little fruit/nut/honey/jam pairings. The walnut bread that comes with the cheese is ...different. Relatively large drink menu. The burger is rich and moist- just like it should be from a French restaurant. Try it with an egg on top.

LA6fq9dhiV_5pIzfPV31jw.review_text: The duck is PERFECT!! I had the burger with the Gouda and fried egg and it was delicious. My boyfriend opted for the duck and I don't eat duck.. ever, but I swear I was jealous that his dish was more appetizing than my own. Definitely a must!!

xEc6S6ZTbFeNekKgWTZP9A.review_text: Lovely French style brasserie that is deceptively larger than it looks from the outside.  The oysters are fresh and fantastic, the cocktails creative and expensive, and the food is quite good.  Service is a little slow, this place is quite busy! My favorite cocktail here is the Admiral's Daughter - it's light and refreshing but packs a good punch!

lPXKpwMBKqkhiJ1DBnhYwA.review_text: Absinthe is one of my favorite places in the valley. I have been coming here for many years and every time I come in for either a weekend brunch or weeknight dinner/drinks the food and service is always great.  I also need to add that the Private Dining with Absinthe was another great experience. They made it so easy for me to plan a going-away party for 20 people!  It was a work-related event that I was in-charge of putting together and they were just great at helping me out with the menu and wine pairings. It turned out really well and everyone was happy.   Thanks Absinthe staff. Now my boss trusts my decisions with all the dining/event at work.

pzC8jGN4xvfR-dZRz9V9xw.review_text: Came here for a Saturday brunch and it was nice to see that while the restaurant was crowded, it didn't seem overly noisy. And hey, I always love a place that doesn't get upset when I dump a glass of water on the table (accidentally, I swear!) :o) I ordered two eggs scrambled that with awesome rosemary potatoes, two pieces of toast (slightly overdone and no butter, odd) and homemade fennel sausage. My friend had steak frites, which (on my one bite) tasted awesome, and when I go back there, I'd most likely order that and the french onion soup which looks super yummy.  Long story short, had a great time, will definitely go back.

TS2j_gt5qugbmQ1R_fq6TA.review_text: This place is just incredible!   The chickpeas and pretzels were awesome!  And the watzu (sp.) steak was so ridiculously awesome...  It did not feel like a SF restaurant, no pretentousness, no gimmicks, no BS. Seemed like every SF demographic was represented in this place on a early Saturday evening...

zDltf7SGyDANcA6ndZkF7A.review_text: The good:  The second you walk in to this place you feel as if you've been taken to a cozy dinner party at one of your friends house. It's warm, intimate and beautifully decorated; I felt so relaxed and at home. We had a reservation at 8:30pm and when we walked in they took us right back to out table.   The really good:  I have never in all my life had a better french onion style soup. I was having a very hard time looking civilized as I attacked it with my spoon at an extremely rapid pace. I may have gotten some soup bits on the couple next to me the way I was flailing about.   The average:  It's not that the service was bad because it wasn't; however, the timing of the meal was not done properly. We waited for what felt like an eternity for our main entree which was frustrating because we needed to be somewhere.   The bad:  How do I put this without sounding crass; the chair I sat in felt more like a torture mechanism than something somebody on a Friday night should be enjoying dinner on. Afterwards, my ass felt as if it had been used as a punching bag.  3.5 stars

YHgx0uQau9ZPdKBuxBiWSA.review_text: This place is awesome. So glad I took my mom here when she came to visit me. The atmosphere is perfect. The food is amazing! The service was on point and it gets busy!! Make sure that you make a reservation because it fills up fast at dinner time. We both ordered steaks and they melt in your mouth!! My mom took some of hers home and the waiter was so classy he didn't want to clutter the table up with the to go bag so he kept it around the corner. I think our waiters name was JP he was excellent with perfect timing.   Huge drink menu. I tried some things I had never had before and I wasn't disappointed. I will definitely be back soon.

pWuflmEV88KcJov0hAT-Ow.review_text: This isn't Top Scallop!  Or is it?  Being a Top Chef fan, when we heard that Absinthe was going to have a Scallop tasting menu from Chef Jamie, we had to jump on it.  The dishes were all very flavorful and enjoyable.  The only downside to the evening was the service.  It took forever for our fourth course to come out that I even ended up flagging the waiter to check on it.  He tried to compensate by getting me another glass of wine, and my friend a coffee, and even asked if we had a chance to meet with the Chef yet.  Supposedly he was to have her come by, but alas, that didn't happen.  I wasn't terribly disappointed for long when I dove into my warm chocolate-banana tart.  Delicious!  In summary, food 4 stars... but service was average.... that was one long 3 hr meal.

h3KpLypa9SZEw2ydFNC19Q.review_text: 2.4/5 meh/embarrassing experience  the food is what it is; i'm guessing by how underwhelmed i was that the lunch service is very different from the dinner service.  what i want to yelp about though, was the particularly rude service we got at our company luncheon. i was really embarrassed, because it was my recommendation to come here, and i don't think it's one i'll ever make again.  we ordered our drinks, some items to start, then each ordered some sandwiches. two of my coworkers got the one with chicken. when our food finally came, only one chicken sandwich came out. the other one placed on our table was the grilled cheese-esque one, which no one ordered. when we pointed this to the server, he gave us a stiff attitude, citing in a snobby attitude (read: jackass) that he had in fact dropped off the chicken sandwich, that it was sliced (implying that we were stupid not to realize that), and that it was OUR mistake. we opened it up, pointed clearly that the sliced items he was making his argument on were in fact the mushrooms that came in the cheese sandwich. he lifted the plate back to the kitchen, and later brought out the correct sandwich. never apologized. the waiter later came by and apologized for his error, but i was really surprised that the server who dropped off the food did not.   i'm going to file this away in my head as that server not knowing their own menu, but admittedly it's going to be a long while before i even consider returning here.

RbmKlWEsatQyPdtldZNafQ.review_text: Went here for our anniversary dinner.  Had a fantastic dinner, with a great cheese selection.  I was surprised by the crowd, being that our reservation was for 9:45 PM.  The food took a little long to be served but my husband and I both enjoyed dinner.  Because the restaurant was named after the famed drink, he had to also try absinthe. It was nicely served with sugar water and ice to strain the alchohol, interesting drink.     Beet salad was awesome, I loved the pan roasted mussells  and the Pot de Creme is to die for!  Will definitely go back!

9mekV4vtN96H9_wNgVSZ0A.review_text: I haven't written a review for Absinthe yet because I wanted to make sure I got it just right.  My now fiance took me here on our first date and it was the perfect atmosphere for it. It has such interesting menu choices and gorgeous, unique drinks (absinthe is in several cocktails, hence the name) that getting a great conversation started is easy.   I've also taken friends & family here when they've come to visit us and they always say "oh I feel like I'm in a big city here" (I know, sounds silly but when you're raised in a farming town...)   Anyways specifics; the Sacred Heart drink is my fave with absinthe but my fiance would argue that their Manhattan's are the best drink offered. The french onion soup is something you'll crave and come back for and OH the mini pretzel bites well...you just have to try them yourself to understand!   The ONLY con, and it's just a fact of life really is that it's crowded ...all the time! So if you're just stopping in for a drink it can be hard to find a place to sit. However they'll take your cell# and call you when they have something (awesome!) while you walk around the very cute shops surrounding the restaurant.

WF1o6AyXm6-NovD5dFnMOg.review_text: Sunday brunches should be a tradition I embrace much more, especially when Absinthe doles out gut melting cures for Saturday Night drink aftermaths.  We were unable to make the secured reservation, but the host was very accommodating and we were still able to be seated fairly quickly.  The Brunch menu hits all the regular stops, and I ended up diving into the Banana-blueberry soufflé pancakes. It had been some time since I had these griddle coins, but it brought me back to childhood memories of Sunday mornings and cartoons. ( Why do we stop watching these?)  Soft, fluffy, and the bursts of fruit within were fantastic. Not being one to indulge too much in the sweeter things in life, I was supremely delighted with my choice.  Another great dish that I was able to sample from a friend were the biscuits and gravy. I'm a sucker for this dish, and while I was trying to avoid it, I was really glad she ordered it.
