It's a dish that will stick to your bones, and keep you smiling through the day, and this dish did just that. The gravy is a creamy blend, and it soaks the biscuits thoroughly. Take the plunge, and get this.   The freshly squeezed orange juice is a morning pick me up, and overall I can see multiple brunch visits in the future. Plus, it was nice hearing the other day that one of the Top Chef contestants is the executive chef here. Not bad.

hPeSX63a_iABNawBRl3-mA.review_text: Based on food alone I would give it five stars, because the food is truly exceptional.   The elements that need work are it can be crowded and cramped, and the service we had was "just OK", particularly since the SF-mandated work break seemed to come up right in the middle of our service, causing our server to introduce us to somebody new, who then handed us back a half hour later.  For the price you are paying, that is rinky-dink and they should manage it better.  Also, parking is difficult, the valet is slow because nowhere to park nearby really that is easy, although that is just a fact of the location.  Now, back to the incredible food -- wow!  The soft garlic pretzels with Vermont Mornay melted cheese to dip in are a must-have starter that are to die for (and you might if you eat more than one, they are small so its OK....)   Other high end cheeses are on the menu including Hudson Valley Camembert and Bog Woods Blue Honeycomb.  Two in our party ordered the Brentwood Corn Soup which was excellent.   For entrees, I have tried the Mahi Mahi with citrus-brown chili butter, apricots, endive, as well as the Za'Atar Spiced Lamb Shoulder with cous cous, Zucchin gratin, and charred tomatoes, each was a bespoke delight.  Another great starter (which is almost large enough to order as main) is the Hawwain Albacore Poke Tune with Habanero Chili, Fried Garlic, and Sesame Oil.    Incredible.  In summary, the food is worth the service, crowd, and parking hassles.

drI9J9xeWephVGlfMC487w.review_text: A visit to Absinthe is always a pleasure. They have some of my favorite bar snacks (a lovely selection of cheese and spicy fried chickpeas!) and interesting desserts. I love kicking back at one of the bistro tables in the bar with a good friend and a zingy cocktail. It;s definitely one of the best places in Hayes Valley.

k0sh_jRpA-gpdbvu4iXnGw.review_text: cocktails are good, but food is overrated.  pretzels are delicious but everything else we had was just somewhat of bland at best.

L_j9sE8ZL14KZNH-SNx9YA.review_text: A fan due to their late night dining :D  When you just don't make it out to get together with friends until late and want good drinks and food - perfect place.  Oysters, pot de creme, flatbread sans meat were all yummy.

igM1UcP99upbVcgwaLTGZA.review_text: Great spot in a cool area only minutes from downtown ... Really diverse menu for brunch and dinner and great drink options.

aN3bpfDLsMjQloJ_4-P13Q.review_text: Honestly, I found the flavors on the two dishes I sampled (the dandelion greens flatbread & the escargot) to be very poor. The onions on the flatbread completely overpowered all the other flavors & the escargot were tough. I was quite disappointed especially considering the price point. Others at our table enjoyed their selections more. One of those selections was the pork confit - come here if you love your bacon, it littered half of the otherwise veggie friendly dishes (ahem, salads).   Service was also a bit off; for dessert, one member of our party ordered dessert, one coffee, and two of us cocktails. The cocktails arrived long after the dessert & the coffee had been finished.   A hopeful three stars that I just picked the wrong dishes, I doubt I'll be back to try more though.

4LMErvQTSEx6pXVAXAJaQw.review_text: My experience at Absinthe has a curious genesis.  Weeks ago, I bought a pair of tickets for Donizetti's L'Elisir d'Amore (The Elixir of Love) at the San Francisco Opera.  Elixir is my most favorite opera of all time.  Period.  The Girlfriend said that she would take care of dinner reservations.  First she got reservations at Farmer Brown, Tenderloin-ish, but not too far from the Opera House (15 minutets by foot)  Two weeks before the opera, I had an audition at the Opera House, not for SF Opera (I wish) but for Berkeley Opera.  As I was boarding the BART train in Rockridge I noticed that my photocopy of my audition piece was missing one page.  I had to make a detour to copy shop on Market.  As I was walking to Opera House in my audition attire (a suit) I walked past Farmer Brown's.  It's Tenderloin sure enough.  Then I started having reservations about our reservation.  I have no issues with the Tenderloin but to walk in that area on an off-night for most theaters while wearing a suit (and the Girlfriend in a dress) in the dark doesn't sound like a good idea.  So I promptly shot out a text message to my female half that read:  "Farmer Brown's, you sure know how to pick 'em."  She quickly canceled her reservation and placed a new one at Absinthe, she found the restaurant from a listing on the SF Opera website.  On the night of the opera, we were running late.  According to the Girlfriend I was being "snappish" (I swear I wasn't...Dammit).  We got here just a little bit late for our reservation.  Once seated, the tenor of the night changed.  It became awesome.  Over an appetizer of french fries we discussing if it was sacrilegious of us Oaklanders to proclaim these fries to be better than the ones at Luka's.  But those fries, while awesome in their own right, were quickly eclipsed by the main course.  The pork confit was, scrumptrilescent, as in "there is no word good enough to describe it... so I am going to make one up right now..."  The pork was tender and the sauce was perfect.  But there was one little element of taste I couldn't figure out until a server explained it.  Server: "You know, we use duck fat in the confit." Me: "Aahhhhhrrhhrhrhhrh."  *drools*  Yes, the duck fat totally made the dish and my arteries are probably still clogged.  Gotta do some cardio.  We made it to the Opera with plenty of time to spare.  That performance was easily  metaphor for our evening; it started out just a little bit rocky, but it ended great.

eQ5WbPWC-8km9PFYCGt8Xw.review_text: Good food but horrible service. My friend and I visited this place on Wednesday night and the waiter kept disappearing. It was just ridiculous. For the kind of prices they charge the service needs to be more attentive. Will never come here again.

jjuxiwKoiz8voegbWEJVMg.review_text: I had been to Absinthe before for brunch a while back with its cute decor and sexy red booths, and remembered having a great experience, but when I returned for dinner last night, the service and food fell flat.    When we were seated, our waiter took a few minutes to come by and take our drink order.  A full thirty minutes after that, he finally came back to check on us and take our meal order.  That's pretty unacceptable, but I wanted to give him the benefit of the doubt.  Even further, it wasn't until after our meal order that three measly slices of bread were given to us...Mind you, it wasn't a busy night.  So, waiting forty minutes for our first bite of sustenance was a major minus.  My boyfriend ordered the Estancia burger with smoked Gouda (which was an extra $1.50 for a slice), and housemade pickles.  It was pretty good, and, the meat being from Estancia, put us back around $12.  I didn't mind that.  What I did mind was the local Halibut with asparagus and cauliflower.  This was truly a disappointing $29 entree that the waiter recommended.  The fish was dry and lacked flavor.  The saving grace of this dish was, sadly, the vegetables.  I'd recommend skipping the fish here and maybe trying the risotto or one of the small plates.  Those sound more appetizing.  We also ordered a cheese plate with Grevenbroecker (blue cheese with balsamic), Tome du Haut Languedoc (goat's milk cheese with hibiscus jam), and Pecorino Pepato (sheep's milk cheese - sharp and probably my favorite of the cheeses).  All three were really tasty, and we finished every last crumb of the cheese and accompanying bread.  It's never good, however, when the highlight of the meal is a cheese plate!  I wanted to give Absinthe a higher rating, but I just can't justify being happy paying over $100, including tip, for a meal and service that was just blah.

xkD0dzAHIcqMVxIWMxeKRQ.review_text: Came in on a Tuesday night, around 7PM. Not very crowded, you could definitely get a table. Apparently no matter how busy it is or on what days, there will always be space for you. Nice!  Great ambiance, completely screams bougie. $$$ is the correct rating for this restaurant! Here's what we ordered:  Coq au vin: burgundy-braised Mary's chicken with vegetables, bacon, mushrooms, crostini, and more. A $28 delicious pot of yumminess and of course, price-yness! The chicken slid off the bone and the sauce was perfect - not too salty. Would I come and order this again? Probably not. Was one of those try it one time and brag to your friends you ate a pot of saucey chicken.  French Onion Soup Gratinee: AMAZING. This is an absolute MUST. Rich textured onion soup with a layer of creamy cheese. Actually craving this as I write this review...  A bunch of wine & cocktails: Yes, that's what we ordered. Each were delicious and topnotch. Their wine menu is endless so you're guaranteed to find something you like.  Fabulous service. Perfect place for a date night. But warning, this place will burn a hole in your wallet!

-J4c9-XLzJshOohHFuGNmg.review_text: This is my new favorite SF restaurant. I went with a girlfriend, and we split a few appetizers- everything was done just right, not too fancy - perfectly prepared Cesar Salad, Mac and Cheese- and the tempura crab was to die for! I am sure that the main courses are just as delish. The restaurant is very dark, which I love. Its a fun crowd at the bar, and more intimate in the dining area. I will definitely be coming back!

QSR9eKMtAbOotNDqNjwTJg.review_text: Really enjoyed this place, my boyfriend and I got in to SF late one night, went over, the waitress was soo nice, really took care of us and made us feel special. Everything we ordered was delicious. Felt like I was in NYC. Would def go back every time we're in town!!  Five stars for FOOD, SERVICE and AMBIANCE!!! and DRINKS.

qlB5UhcN4sx_LIwJJvLYCw.review_text: Solid food, fun environment, and room has great buzz. I love oyster shooters, big hunks of braised pork shoulder, and fun cocktails.  Well done!

Cx2E56zbHsxa6NE1Gdn_dQ.review_text: So this is where I always end up if I'm gonna go out for a drink in the neighborhood. It is not awesome, but I like the friendly staff and I like their big wine glasses.  Make sure you'll get the know the staff and they'll give you the table in the very center. That's my favorite spot. Good bar menu, perfect for a late night hamburger when you forgot to eat and the clock is 10 pm.

F9ZIRNpFWiNAJUT-hwsNVQ.review_text: I have and always will love this place.

VwWYIBvVgx9PVoOoD_Vb_w.review_text: I've only been here twice for brunch. No wait both times and everyone's dish was very tasty. Their coffee stood out - very fresh and delicious. Great option if the line at Stack's is too long :)

hK3Rihrn915lKLNOueEuRQ.review_text: I went there for a dinner with some family and friends, as we were there we had a reservation and kept us waiting for over 30 minutes because they were full. As we were seated they kept us still waiting for over another 20 minutes, in all we waited for almost an hour to be approached. At the beginning they were rude, as we told the manager how long we waited he apologized and things started too move faster. I had to say that the drinks were good, the food very good, but the attitude should change, I may give then a second chance and then let you people know.

-vh3rQnqhurZwe_r49wRqg.review_text: Hit and miss.  The mushroom pot pie deserves rave reviews, and is reasonably priced compared to the other options. Portion is also generous enough to merit the lack of sides.  The duck is well prepared, but the 2-3oz servings are overrated for the cost and lack of sides.  AVOID at all costs the "surf and turf" - their American Kobe beef and 3 overcooked shrimp do not merit the ink used to print the description on the menu.  The wait staff is attentive about food allergy requests and happy to substitute upon request. However, they took too long to bring the bill (we had to request it) and we were never offered or asked about refills other than water.

oSN3M4_WKdlTsnpgqPDiBg.review_text: This is where my fellow SF half marathoners and I came for dinner after the run. Talk about a nice treat! It's very swank inside, but no attitude whatsoever from anyone. That's something I found nice about SF in general: lack of 'tude. Anyway, this is a nice restaurant, very nicely decorated, appointed, etc etc. As you walk in you see the bar with a big jar of what I presume to be absinthe dripping its contents into a glass with the sugar cube and stuff, and it looks really cool (see my photo) but alas, I did not imbibe. Felt it might be too hardcore for my post-run sensitive stomach. I indulged in another cocktail, however, as they have quite the extensive cocktail menu.   That's kind of my one regret when I came to this place--I wasn't THAT hungry, because I'd had my big late lunch at Polker's earlier. So I just ended up getting the Perfect Pear cocktail (very delish) and some smaller nosher plates I shared with a friend. We got the country pate appetizer, escargots, prawn salad. and an order of their shoestring fries (these are sucky photos, sorry). Everything was very very good, especially those little escargots, which came to the table all hot and sizzling in a cast-iron pan. They give you these funky escargot holder thingies to facilitate their extraction, and I must say they were quite delectable! The shoestring fries, with their various accompanying dipping sauces were excellent also, but I wish they'd been a little longer--I felt like a pig reaching in there every second. Prawn salad and pate were very good, also--everything tasted very fresh and well-prepared. Other people had the trout, chicken, and a bunch of other stuff, which I forget, but I think we all uniformly enjoyed our food. I must say the service was top-notch; even when we screwed up on our math with the bill and was kind of arguing with our waiter about it he was perfectly pleasant and retained his equanimity til it was all sorted out. This is not a cheap place, but I do believe I got my money's worth. It ended up being a great evening out with friends.  UPDATE: Forgot to mention that they were out the halibut that night, and it was something that two people from the party had wanted, so that was kind of a bummer.

1ArdBetF-pM3Y4eP1pgNPA.review_text: Best oatmeal I've ever had! Their breakfast items and cheese plates are killer. Their Galapagos Cocktail is on the BIG EAT SF 2009, so be sure to try it!

3syzIf7C5LjCmk522qB1UA.review_text: Had a blast... great food... great service. A bit tight as far as the space goes... thats the only real negative.   #Solid

I2RPXXuZzn3WaXk2dxfalA.review_text: The scallops were life changing. At Absinthe, mixology truly is a science, a delicious wonderful science. Absolutely go for brunch, though their dinner and drinks are still their best feature.   Make a reservation! One night my husband and I went in without a reservation, 30 minutes later they sat us at a table right in everyone's way, we were run into so much we had to get up and leave. Make a reservation!

qc2NbphhxhWcwn_J-x-Pqw.review_text: We came here for brunch at the weekend as I've heard always great things about Absinthe. I was not wrong. The drinks are excellent. I had a bloody mary and it was nice to see it was (as it should be) made from scratch and not a mix.   I took the crispy Berkshire pork belly and it was everything I had imagined and more. In fact after the theatre we tried to come back for dinner but unfortunately the wait was longer than we wanted.  I cant wait to come back.

Valva2MGzBW8ux3641YINA.review_text: I ordered a Ceaser Salad and it was good, nothing amazing. Then this cocktail with Basil, cucumbers, and fruit, I wasn't a fan of the basil. Then the shrimp roll with chips came out and I was in heaven! it tasted like a lobster roll and the bread was so good! The chips were good but it needed to be seasoned better, I had to add salt and pepper. Overall good time but not pretty when the bill came ha.

G0-1gXLQBYuCkFcl322mlw.review_text: I love this place. It is my perfect take-the-parents-and-boyfriend spot and the food is consistently delicious.   I recently had a brunch, and I may have tasted the most perfect mushroom omelette ever created. Awesome!  I will be back for a duck egg salad soon...

tRz8Js1WU9GqyAxDdFrqJQ.review_text: Have been here twice in the last month. One of my all-time favorite restaurants. Amazing food, great service, chic and fun ambiance (feels authentically French) and best of all delicious drinks. Cannot go wrong with this spot... Great for large gathering of friends and equally as special for a romantic night out with your honey.

nVgHgyvvhVaTzvevfrFCpQ.review_text: Holy. Hell.  Soft. Garlic. Pretzels.  I should be able to end the review right there. These things will literally knock your socks off (maybe not literally, but come on-they rock). Came here on a busy Saturday night. We were quickly seated at the bar; enjoyed pretzels, cheese (amazing selection; we went with Humboldt Fog) and some great wine.   Service is great. Bartenders work their tails off to make what look like amazing drinks. And the pretzels. Did I mention the pretzels? It's like there's an Auntie Anne's in the kitchen that's being ran by Jesus or Gordon Ramsey....or a Jesus Gordon Ramsey. Just be prepared for all other food to forever be terrible by comparison. Seriously, I had these things a week ago and I'm still talking about them...and they are f&*#@n pretzels.

ki2i0kGBowKsT9ZmuJ9Djg.review_text: great burger, very reasonably priced & fantastic service as a added bonus. Cool ambiance, I felt like I was in Paris looking out the window watching all the crazy Giants parade fans walking by.......

GrVIegI1gjVevOMgXyoxiw.review_text: This place is really good!!  I really enjoyed their corn soup which was cream and flavorful. I really wish I would have gotten the large size.  We also ordered the fried softshell crab which came with this little salad and creme fraiche guac. It was a pretty good dish although I do wish it was a big bigger. I was def left wanting much more.  I had their burger which was very good although not as good as Farmer Brown's or Nopas. It was def high up there on my burger list though.  My bf got the grilled fish which he said was really really good.  I definitely want to come back and try out more things!!  The menu has so many interesting options!!

dNGUYhx9yCTlBRnCcd-7Eg.review_text: My boyfriend and I decided to stop in for a drink after catching a show tonight, but we were beyond disappointed with our experience. I have nothing but praise for the bar food -- we ordered chickpeas, popcorn and pretzels and were very satisfied -- the ONLY reason I even gave two stars!  The service, on the other hand, is subpar, to put it nicely.   According to the bill, Xan is the bartender who served us, but we wouldn't have known because she didn't even talk to us! She was very monotone and unfriendly. Not only was she unpleasant to start off with, she didn't even bother to ask if my BF wanted a second drink (his glass was empty the entire time we were munching on our snack bites). She did however, manage to eat a meal and take a shot in front of us. The final straw was when she presented our check with a mouth full of food... Thanks a lot! Extremely unprofessional!!!!! This experience has definitely deterred me from returning, unfortunately. My boyfriend and I are both in the industry as well and we honestly expected more from such a highly reviewed restaurant.

WG2GqF3teG_YNI3ZNS4Syg.review_text: Everything was amazing..... Probably the best deviled eggs I have ever tasted in my life. Just make sure to have a reservation or you will be waiting for ever.

wWNb-LKSNVykqMrpBC-5IA.review_text: This is ALWAYS a solid dining experience.  Oh, the brunch (duck confit-ragout on chive potato cakes, HELLO!), the super crispy, consistently delicious pomme frites, the tasty and imaginative cocktails, the silky smooth pate, the BURGER, oh, the burger.  The skirt steak that melts in your mouth.  The scallops, lying there in that delicious cauliflower puree.  Oh Absinthe, you never disappoint.  That must be why I always manage to find an excuse to come back.  This place should be on your go-to list.  It's definitely on mine.

qEglvl7uKyS1aRn-vX4MkA.review_text: Located on hip Hayes Street, Absinthe is a great little neighborhood brasserie.  All dark wood, and red velvet, its a great spot for intimate conversation.    Had mostly small plates.  Must definitely get the fried chickpeas which are crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside and flavored with a hint of curry.    The garlic pretzel bites are baked to order.  Little salty, doughy pieces of heaven dipped in the creamy cheese sauce.  With tomatoes in season, had to get the heirloom tomato gazpacho which highlighted the sweetness of tomatoes.    Ended the meal with a cheese plate of the Mt. Tame cheese which comes with fiji apples slices and macarona almonds, the Great Hill Blue with honey straight from the honey comb, and El Trigal Manchego paired with wine-poached apricots.  I loved that the cheese actually came with cool little tasting flourishes, whereas some places just stick a slab of cheese on a plate.   And of course, one cannot go to Absinthe, without getting a libation made of the infamous elixir that inspired a whole generation of artists and writers.

VopIGiWC6A1QN8FfoeMn-Q.review_text: This was one of the best meals I've had in a long time.  I just wish we could get a reservation to include some more friends since it created a very awkward situation and made me enjoy the evening less.  But now back to the review.  We had a table by the window so we can people watch.  The cocktail list is fantastic and it takes some time to make a decision.  There is so much  variety and the wine list is also extensive and amazing.  My friends gobbled up the oysters (I'm allergic) but saw the joy on their faces.   They have an award winning French onion soup, which got 10 thumbs up from my friend.  I ordered the persimmon  salad, which was good but should have had more fruit in it.    I loved the lamb dish.  It was absolutely amazing with so many great flavors.  It had chickpeas and a cucumber relish, which made it absolutely delicious.  It was also a huge portion so the guys were happy to sample.  I sampled the Halibut, which was delicious.  We enjoyed a fabulous bottle of Barbera and the waiter was great.  I think this is a new find for me.  And the best part is they have a valet :-)

Z6c6U4YedPfjATLGAgZJbw.review_text: Without a doubt, the tastiest duck meatballs out there....   The cheese plate was delicious and the food was very, very solid. Drinks were inconsistent- my first one was delicious and the other two were pretty decent.   Overall, a really delicious experience... the tartare, the cheese plate, the duck meatballs, the fish, and coq au vin... everything was amazing!!

GY-cXF5pYlpLisuHpUexHg.review_text: Came here for a Saturday date-night dinner, and was able to make same-day reservations.  Excellent food, intimate atmosphere in the dining area but a fun energy near the bar.   As first-time absinthe drinkers our waitress was very helpful in showing us how to drink. Their cocktail menu is worth coming back for!  The food and slow, un-hurried reminded me of France. I'd love to come back to try brunch.

rUCAjW8bhyoFj-uwPQlfgA.review_text: how does this place continue to be so reliable after all these years?  it is just the best ever in every way.    the food, cocktails, wines, desserts, and service are always outstanding.    it doesn't matter what you order, it will be divine.

MVcjg_H94whc8NZqs23SFg.review_text: I go to Absinthe when I feel like being indulgent ^_^  The front bar area is usually crowded and the front room tables are great for people watching. The second room feels dimmer and has all these small curved velvet booths. Really nice for a date or an intimate catch up.   The food is always unique and intense, hits your palate and takes you away to the warm happy place. Drinks are excellent. Most of all, I appreciate that I can always depend on the oysters to be good and in good variety.

gm0V0GmBBlUlTqoZHsjWqw.review_text: Date/Time: Sunday - 7:45pm Occasion: Date night with the bear Party of: Two Location:  Romantic ambiance. Trendy. Cozy and dark. Ordered:  Beef tartare, French onion soup (bowl), Skirt steak, Absinthe burger, mango sorbet dessert, and an Absinthe lemonade Total incl gratuity: ~$100.00  My boss dined here a few years back and raved about it.  I was eager to check it off my list of 'places to eat' in SF.  Unfortunately, it didn't quite hit the mark for me.  Most of the food we ordered was just...ok.  To start, the beef tartare was a bit hyped up for me. It was definitely lacking in seasoning.  Good but not great.  They started to redeem themselves when I sipped the french onion soup. O.M.GEE! What drug did they put in this thing.  I'm straight hankering for more of it as we speak.  The swiss cheese, perfectly melted atop a pot of soft stewed onions in a sweet flavorful beef broth. Seriously, if nothing else. come here just to try their delectable french onion soup.  I didn't have a substantial appetite that night so I only ate about 1/3 of my skirt steak.  It was, again, ok.  Meat was tender however a little under-seasoned.  The creme fraiche potato puree was very good. It's hard to go wrong with that.  I had a nibble of the burger.  It was tasty but my goodness, twenty dollars for a burger....not worth it, in my opinion.  Service was friendly.  They keep your water glasses and bread plate filled. The drink menu looks delectable and it appears a lot of people come here for the brunch. Might want to come back and check that out.

q25gV3Ranp5DEF1Ivh2O1w.review_text: Great place for a date :) I highly recommend that you get a little of everything and share with someone..that way you both get to taste all the yummy food!   p.s. the pretzel appetizers are a must

oneuz-Puse9Ky9-QFuErWg.review_text: Again, I must stress the importance for an Yelp improvement -- add half stars! I would give this place a solid 3 1/2 star but since there's no half, I am rounding it down.  It's a very nice place, good ambiance, but the truth is, if we're just speaking of food, there are so many more awesome places in LA where you would get the same, if not better tasting, foods for less than the price.    Food was decent. The meatballs, pork belly, pumpkin bisque and beef tartare were all very tastfully done. I personally think the appetizers and snacks were all better than their entrees. For entrees, coq au vin was highly recommended (and we ordered it, which I thought was good but I wouldn't say it's to die for). The sole was just so-so.   Desserts were good also. Our server gave us the wrong item, and we ended up with the genoise. We decided to keep it and try and actually was a pleasant surprise.

qfwjJY9XwbZbABSI7PyKdw.review_text: went to check out this place after a matinee performance of the nutcracker.    love hayes valley and the energy here--went with my admin assistant/friend and we really enjoyed the meal--and the masculine cocktails--however, it seemed our server (not sure if he still works here since this was last christmastime) had a stick up his butt--not sure what the other tables were experiencing, but this dude was taking forever, was short with us, and when we witnessed him with the other tables, he was laughing--and so were they--  but we weren't laughing when he would come to us.  regardless, being the kosher gal i am, i still tipped him 20%.

rjE_SpqTmW-mrQOSAmGhdQ.review_text: The last time I visited Absinthe was probably 10 years ago when I first moved to San Francisco.  I'm not sure how many chefs ago that was, but I remember having a great time and eating a wonderful meal. I was particularly impressed by their cheese plate accompanied by slices of fruity, nutty bread.  I mentioned my dinner to everyone afterward and promised to return.  10 years later I finally made it back, this time for a quick after-work meal instead of a longer dinner.  I sat at the bar and had one of their premium cocktails, the joy ride, and it was pretty tasty.  Their bar menu has a nice variety of items to choose from so I ordered the Absinthe burger.  The patty was very juicy and tender and I loved the homemade pickle, but I was expecting more from this eponymous burger.  It didn't stand out from other burgers I've had at comparable restaurants.  The french fries were good, but a little thin and unsubstantial compared to the hefty burger.  I was expecting them to be served with the sweet onion aioli as advertised with the a la carte fries, but I guess you only get the ketchup.  Perhaps it was the time of day. Perhaps it was the bar setting. Perhaps I've enjoyed better food in the 10 years since I lasted visited, but I wasn't too impressed by Absinthe this time around. The food was good, the bar service was friendly but erratic, but I wanted more or something just as good as last time. And I didn't get it.   :-(

kwiyfnGA7JEcl5qp2Bzqsg.review_text: Absinthe is definitely a go-to place for me.  I've been coming for years.   They have plenty on the menu to make this gluten free & paleo girl very happy, and they adjust things if they can.    Killer wine list, great cocktails.    The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that there have been times when a meal missed the boat (badly, in fact their legendary coq au vin and cesar salad both blew one time)  And they don't really do much for my vegan friends.  Stand outs for me: Burger, rare, no bun Fries, about the only time I eat fries is here.  They fry them in rice oil and they are gluten free as breaded things don't come in contact with the oil Oysters The Cesar salad (or romaine salad as they call it, is 2nd to Zuni's) Coq Au Vin  Sorbet for dessert And wine . . .a great list always, and the wait staff know their wines.

B78KOUmVHDef6LfYGEgQIQ.review_text: Loved it!  I went here for my birthday and was impressed from the outside in.  First, green twinkly lights outside gave it a nice curb appeal. I am a sucker for monochromatic twinkly lights.   Once lured inside, you see a lovely, quaint set up. There is a nice bar area with cute little tables by the front window, where couples and friends sit enjoying the vast array of special cocktails, wines, and cheeses. We decided we will definitely return some day for drinks and cheese.   If you are there for dinner, as we were, and if you have a reservation, they seat you right away in the dining area, which is farther back or on the side of the restaurant. We were seated at a cozy  booth in the back. My husband would have preferred to be up front in the bar area by the window, but he hates booths, so this wasn't a surprise.   The excellent service continues throughout the night. The wait staff is always there when you need them, but not overbearing. Our waiter was also quite knowledgeable about the menu and every single ingredient in every single dish.   The food: I actually loved the scallops. The dish was less about the scallops than about what they sat upon, which was a scrumptious and savory blend of wild mushroom, caramelized onions, and some sort of heavenly onion puree. MMMMM, mmmmm MM. So good.   My husband had the lamb, ordered medium. It was also delicious. This dish is very influenced by East Indian and Mediterranean flavors and spices. The base of the dish is a bed of perfectly prepared and flavorful chickpeas, upon which sits the lamb, on top of which sits a bed of salty and pungently flavored cucumbers.  Together, this makes for a perfectly balanced bite.   The drink menu is large and impressive. I ordered a half glass of champagne for my birthday, and my husband had two cocktails (he enjoyed the degalis  but not the second one, whose name he can't remember right now).   The dessert did not disappoint. We ordered the pot de creme, which was creamy, cold and sweet. The coffee was also quite good. Next time, we will try to be a little more adventurous and order the mince meat dessert.   I also forgot to mention, the frisee salad was warm savory and comforting. The hamachi was fresh, and topped with just the right amount of Indian - influenced spices. Yum Yum .   Overall, we were very impressed by Absinthe. The ambiance, the service, and the food were all outstanding. I plan on returning again with a friend for drinks and to try their substantial selection of fine cheeses.

Ey2029k-xGm9blqP4LW6Yg.review_text: A "must eat" restaurant near the symphony.  We took our family, from New York, here and they looooved it!  The staff was very professional, catering to our needs which included review/advice of cheese selection, wine selection, and post-dinner cab procurement. An excellent french bistro with panache and culture. At the same time, cozy and inviting.  I will be back!

Vf2xUpoWXBkBd2wf8vXCbw.review_text: Don't believe the hype.  I think this place benefits from being in a super location and having a good interior layout that draws a certain crowd.  Food.  Meh.  You can get much better food at Chez Papa and at much more reasonable prices.  Service.  Ok.  A bit slow considering we started our dinner early when the dining room was less than half full.  This might be a great place to stop for a drink and a quick bite at the bar, but not a spot I would make an effort to return to.

7sUiu0cnDc1iStAH0XC3DQ.review_text: It was our final night in SF and my BF has always wanted to try real absinthe, so we came to this place with high hopes!  First off, The list of absinthe that they offer here is almost endless! So many choices! Since, we were totally new to this experience, the waitress was glad to give us a recommendation.  WOW...after a glass, my BF felt cross-faded hahahaha! I had a tiny sip, and it was HANDS DOWN the strongest thing i've ever tasted. All for the experience this one. It was awesome!  The food was also very very very good. No complaints except for the AC; the restaurant was hot and humid, kind of uncomfortable, especially after drinking.  All in all, SF has done us no wrong, We were so impressed, and cannot wait to plan another trip up there in the summer.

yJT7Q4NWkBFCvBy_860TtQ.review_text: I came to Absinthe on a recommendation from my mother after she had a wonderful experience. I made reservations for two for 5:45 p.m. on a Friday night. We arrived about 15 minutes early but were seated immediately. We actually ended up waiting about 15-20 more minutes for a server to even come to our table to greet us, which was a little nerve racking for me. I totally let this slide, though, since we were early. However, there weren't many tables seated at the time and I don't really know what the hold-up was all about.   Our server eventually came over after another table was seated near us (thankfully?) and we ordered a glass of Sauvignon Blanc and a cheese tray with three cheeses: Blythedale Camembert (the first cheese I've ever tasted in my life that I actually thought was disgusting), Beemster (my favorite), and Pecorino Ginepro (delicious). Each cheese was served with a different jam or spread and delicious house-made walnut bread.  We both ordered the hearts of romaine caesar salad, which was absolutely delicious and probably one of the best caesars I have had. The garlic croutons paired with the wonderful dressing were top-notch and I really enjoyed it.  For my entree I had the potato gnocchi, which to me seemed to be the only vegetarian entree even though a yelpy insight exclaimed that "vegetarians go nuts for this spot." It doesn't really matter because the gnocchi was delicious and I ate every bite of it without complaint. I loved all the different kinds of mushrooms in the dish. An option was also to add Italian black black winter truffles to any dish for $10. I would have loved to do it, but it just seemed even more excessive than all the food we were already ordering!  After ALL OF THAT FOOD, we ordered the chocolate Pot de Creme and a shot of espresso. This was a delightful way to finish everything off because even though I don't normally eat dessert, I was glad we did because it was wonderful and the espresso was just the right touch with the chocolate.   Even though the service might have fallen short in the beginning, we ended up having a wonderful waiter that was checking on us constantly and he did a fantastic job. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a special meal at an upscale restaurant.I would definitely go back if there weren't so many other restaurants to try in San Francisco!

56VC5zAQQnB-oHEqE8LHNw.review_text: Yummm!!! Absinthe is one of my fave SF restaurants and it never disappoints. Do yourself a favor and start with a cocktail (I like the 21 Hayes and one with whiskey). The French onion soup tastes just like the ones I have had in France and the poke is so un-French but totally delicious! The char entree is like a deconstructed nicoise salad and is phenomenal. Tried the duck and coq au vin as well and they are both good choices too. Brunch is pricey but definitely worth a try as well!

RaSq7WPbxH7Dm5yfVBAgYw.review_text: It's great when you find a parking spot right outside the restaurant, so that's already a good start. The restaurant was empty because it was 2:30pm. All of the waiter attention was on us practically... obviously a plus. We started with the cauliflower soup and shared the french dip. A pork sandwich that was sooo tender and still pretty juicy is impressive. They put the au jus sauce on the side for us to dip and that was damn flavorful. The fries were a little over fried, but no worries, I still ate them. I must come back for dinner one of these nights!

1igck2-p9UECA9DuyV_Cqg.review_text: We had a wonderful meal. Request to be seated in one of the rooms away from the bar if you wish to carry on a conversation during your meal. Our server was efficient but not much in personality. I would highly recommend their clams for an appetizer and french onion soup as a starter. Their Coq au Vin is the best I've ever had. Their weakest course is dessert. We ordered two and neither was exceptional: one was the Chocolate Pot de Creme and I can't remember the other one. I would definitely go back but I would skip dessert.

2pcZLlgeqIIoIXmUxaDPYg.review_text: I liked it. Not the best french restaurant but their food was at par and one of the better ones in San Francisco. It was not overly pricey. The service was great.  The pretzels for appetizer is a must. So soft and savory. Yum! I also had a coconut corn soup. It was on the sweeter side. A hint of Thai. I didn't like it as much.For the main course, I had the Breaded Chicken Paillard. The side salad that came along with it was delicious. I wish there was more of it. Two big pieces of chicken. Well, big for me. I couldn't finish it. It was juicy but I felt that it was a little on the heavy side. Then finally the Chocolate Pot de Creme. It was not too sweet or heavy. Just perfect. I want to come back for dinner to try out the rest of the menu!   The restaurant seems to go on and on with space. I'd think it would be good to have a little gathering there in their private dining area.

vqiqvShDGoT7kaFSs2r9iw.review_text: As an addict to French Onion Soup, I am convinced there needs to be a FOSA. If anyone knows of a FOSA chapter in the Southbay area please let me know, I'm like a crack addict waiting for my next FOS high. Though I can't really walk around Sunnyvale downtown going ...."Pssst man, ehhm you got some Onion Soup?" I tell you, Cannabis devotee has it easier than F.O.S. lovers. Absinthe seves high grade quality French Onion Soup with plenty of fond. The Fond is the highly flavorful soup base from caramelization of the natural sugars present in the onions. The onions are allowed to cook slowly for a long time. FOS addicts are know to be too fond of the fond. -Duck Confit Hash was flavorful, -the Grilled Corn Cake had a plunky Hollandaise sauce, -the Warm Biscuit is so yummy to the tummy, - the Potatoes were wowww. Thanks to our opentable.com reservation we got a nice big table by the window though there was a crowd of at least 20 people waiting even before the doors were open.  I will be back for more of the ono French Onion Soup. Unless there's some FOSA intervention for me...

MOeT1h_tYabtcU3i1-NL8g.review_text: Stopped in for a small lunch.  Had to try the ceviche with the spiced taro chips.  Yummy.  Literally it was placed in from of me less than 5 minutes after ordering.  Loved the citrus that was included, along with lots of guac.  Winner.

Te18TxvzfLomGE56N7s3Dw.review_text: Came here to celebrate Valentine's day with my gf.  We've been passing by Absinthe's for many years and always look into the window and see a crowd of people filling the place.  We've decided to celebrate Valentine's day one day earlier so we didn't try the special four course menu they offered.  For dinner we had caviar service, hamachi crudo, mushroom pot pie, lamb t-bone, and finished it off with earl grey pavlova and grapefruit sorbet.  The caviar service was Tsar Nicoulai Osetra and for $75 it was a pretty good deal seeing as how most places charge $90.  Even though I doubt I was short changed on caviar, I wish it would have come in the standard jar/packaging instead of dumping it all into another bowl/jar.  They did use an ivory spoon so kudos to knowing that as too many places just uses silver.    The hamachi crudo was excellent.  Slices of hamachi with blood orange, radish, fennel, and vinaigrette.  This dish had an excellent sweet and sour taste to it and somehow finished it off with a bit of saltiness.  Even though it's a bit pricey 5 pieces of $17, I highly recommend it.  The mushroom pot pie was flavorful and filling.  The crust of the pie goes really well with the sauce and the truffled essence.  The gf had this dish but if it was me I'm not sure I would be able to finish it because it tasted very heavy.  Nonetheless it's not every place that serves a mushroom pot pie.  The lamb t-bone was excellent.  Perfectly cooked and seasoned, it was soft and juicy.  The bit of yogurt on top of it complemented it very well.  Additionally the farro was extremely delicious.  I'm not sure I've had it before but the way they made it, I enjoyed it very much.  To finish it off the beets were also excellent.  We also ordered fries and I think we could have skipped this since it was too crunchy and pieces were too small.  The ketchup and the aioli weren't great either.  For dessert the earl grey pavlova took a major point away as it was extremely disappointing.  It was blah.  There was no earl grey flavor whatsoever.    The grapefruit sorbet was okay but the tarragon syrup messed it up.  Ambiance at Absinthe is great.  It has a vibe of a bistro in France with music playing softly in the background.  We asked to be switched one from table to a booth and they gladly did so for us.  Service was not bad but not great, just okay.  The waitress took our orders but I was disappointed as she seemed to be friendlier and personable with others and I heard other waiters and even heard her introduce the menu a bit to others while we didn't get any of that.    Anyway it was a great way to celebrate Valentine's day and perhaps we'll come back another time.

95QlG_jTRsFnhFO19xH7qg.review_text: It was great, I wish there was a 4.5 rating, because it's really in between.  The food was really good and the wine list was crazy long.  We didn't even know where to start.    It was pricey, but worth it.  I don't think you can eat for two in San Francisco with a bottle under $150.  The service was perfect, not too much and pleasant when she was there.  I loved sitting outside during a perfect day and enjoying Hayes Valley on a symphony night.  We'd go here again, no question.

BOSkl3S-MUI2ad1p2BUWeg.review_text: Beef cheeks.  Yum.  So we had reservations but still had to wait in a loud, over crowded, oddly shaped-bar area.  Whatever, I'm not put off by that, but for those of you who are, I figure it is worth a mention. Food was still good. :o)

rBRuie_HNzxCkMDF-ooRog.review_text: I have been here a number of times, but my most memorable was last wkend.  Absinthe is the perfect hotspot for pre- or post- symphony events.  I love the bar and overall romantic ambiance of this place.  We were running late since we took my Bichon to the dog park, so we didn't get a chance to eat prior to going to see Johnny Mathis at Davies Symphony Hall.  So immediately after the show we were starving, so my date suggested Absinthe.  I was afraid we wouldn't be able to get a table, but fortunately we did.  Even though, I was hungry, I was feeling guilty that we were eating so late.  I didn't want to eat a heavy main entree, so I was happy that he agreed to my idea of just ordering small plates of apps.  He ordered this French cheese, I don't recall the name of it... OMG it was sooooo good and was amazing with the wine. The tuna tartar was also delicious.  But the meatballs and french fries?!?! who would have thought... but that was off the chart yummy!  Will definitely be back:)

PI8-E5cXr-boIzYY5QacpQ.review_text: 3very small scallops to "share" as an appetizer: $14. Chicken casoulet: 2 insignificant pieces of chicken: $28.  Why do people go to this stingy restaurant?  Wine glass pour: tiny and expensive.  Why are you rating this ripoff place highly?

KUusL15g7gVmPO7_XRp8cQ.review_text: What a magical 1st Saturday night of the year at Absinthe!  Outstanding service by Carlos. If I had a restaurant I would definitely want him to work for me. Warm and attentive service. 5stars all the way!!  We had:  Two glasses of their brut bubbly 1 glass of Chardonnay .& a vodka pear cocktail Kusshi oysters  1/2 Dungeness crab 1once caviar with fixings Mac n cheese Brussels sprouts & butternut squash Burger with Gruyere grilled onions & mushrooms (which came with our individual fried eggs and cut in half)  ALL STELLAR DISHES!!! Everything hit the spot.  Could not left the dinner table any happier . Thank you absinthe team for an incredible evening. What a happy new year indeed!!!

4BJaPqhuazDidAn8fNpY6A.review_text: Earlier this year, tomato gazpacho was incredible! Service is wonderful and ambiance is interesting. A destination spot in Hayes Valley!

yYTIrIhEZPNToqf364N2qw.review_text: I wish rating this location zero stars was a possibility because if it were, this review would be zero stars. First and foremost my party and I arrived and asked to be seated for a table of 5 and the hostess rudely asked "are you just here for drinks?" I replied and told her my party and I were at this bar for dinner and drinks. She seated a party of 4 right away prior to us and then shortly informed me that it would be at least a 40 minute wait. Can I also add that it was not a crowded house. Not to mention my party and I were all of Asian descent and everyone was obviously white. It was quite apparent there was discrimination taking place. In addition, my boyfriend and his friends were at the bar browsing the menu for alcoholic beverages as I was attempting to reserve a table and the staff was also very unpleasant. Needless to say I will be informing all my fellow non white community that if you are looking for a diverse, friendly, nondiscriminatory location in San Francisco, this is NOT the place to go, I repeat this is NOT the place to go.

OA23ntWl8sRnKCf0tWE_MQ.review_text: Went to Absinthe tonight.  It was rather tasty!  I wanted to order the handmade hot dog because i was on 7x7's list of 100 things to eat/drink in SF before you die.  The waitress told me that the new head chef was taking that off the menu and the previous night was the last time they officially served it.  She was very nice and said she'd see if there was one left, but she said she was pretty sure the bartenders ate the last one.  Turns out they were out of their infamous hot dogs.  Luckily this wasn't an issue since everything we ate was excellent.  I had the beef cheeks and wifey had the hamburger.  I ordered some Pastis, which came with an Erlenmeyer flask of ice water and a cup of ice.  Overall, we had a great time.  The service was great...everyone from the host to the waitress to the bus boys was very attentive.  I would strongly recommend this place and look forward to going back.

SjAxcc6MrBvA-9QWngmV4g.review_text: I attended a wedding reception dinner over the weekend.  It's located in the Hayes Valley Neighborhood among many other restaurants and bars.  Since we were from out of town and part of the wedding, we conveniently had the courtesy of SF trolley drop us off.  The restaurant has valet and there is street parking.  I'd recommend the valet because otherwise you are going to spend the majority of the evening finding a spot in the street.  The dinner was located in the restaurants private dinning room (probably could 50 or less).  The room has it's own private unisex bathroom and a full bar.  For dinner we had a house salad with almonds and strawberries, entree was a choice of fish, chicken, or steak, and desert was of course the wedding cake.  We chose the steak with broccoli and a potato puree.  It was had a nice sear on it and was grilled to a delicious medium.  The service was top notch as my glass of wine was filled on regularity and the courses came out in a timely fashion.    When we go back to SF, it will definitely be on the list to try the regular menu.

BVDRbz4XB-oAWfVOVEXewQ.review_text: Really enjoyed our experience here for dinner on a Friday night! We had a reservation and getting seated was a breeze.  Service: Our server was incredibly helpful and friendly! She recommended a wonderful wine to pair with my dish and was very attentive overall.  Food: Really liked the food here - I had the filet which was tasty and the boyfriend had the Coq au Vin and loved it. We didn't have appetizers or dessert so can't comment there.  Overall we really enjoyed our experience at Absinthe! Only downside is the noise level - it's quite loud in there which made it kinda tough to hear each other - but I would definitely recommend you try it out for a nice dinner.

B35Nwmd15-0WNdI-8jISOA.review_text: The cocktail onions alone make this place a five star establishment.  Throw in the 21 Hayes and it's cloud nine for this yelper.  The 21 Hayes is probably the best cocktail I've had in my life.  It's Gin, muddled cucumber, Pimm's, lemon, simple syrup/sugar and accented with the delicious cocktail onions and a cucumber slice.    I usually hate paying $10 for cocktails, but in this case it's well worth it.  You're really paying for the quality of alcohol, plus the TLC needed to pickle those onions.    Besides the cocktail, I've had a few very pleasant experiences.  I've been for Sunday brunch and Friday HH, and seated right away.  The service has been great, and the food delicious.  From what I've eaten, the soups are probably my favorite.  Both the French Onion Soup and Clam and Scallop Clam Chowder were delicious.  Please note, I HAVEN'T tried Jamie's scallops yet but I hear they are to die for.  I'll definitely be back soon!

8ExCZVowOo3LK2QG6G8Xmg.review_text: Came here with my sister and friend for dinner. Our waiter was friendly and wasn't pushy (we took forever to decide on drinks and food).  Complimentary bread was just okay. I tried the Sacred Heart absinthe cocktail, which was OK. We tried 2 oysters each, and they were yummy. I tried the chicken pate which was served with pickled veggies and toast -- it was pretty average. The coq au vin was very rich, served with only a few pieces of bread, and lots of tender chicken.   Overall, everything was pretty good. I wasn't blown away, but I understand the appeal of a restaurant with a variety of absinthe cocktails.

jp1jV6Ym0ZcTHEDpxhB6lA.review_text: Try the seafood ceviche. Absolutely the freshest avocado and seafood served up with crispy chips. Perfect with a cocktail which of course this place sets the standard.

RlpHzq3cHW6M_Y6VB4S0GQ.review_text: All hail the best restaurant in the city.   I've been here countless times; every one of my friends knows this is my obsession. I come here for brunch and dinner frequently because I just can't get enough.   I love the french onion soup for an appetizer and have tried a wide array of the snacks, like the popcorn, fries, olives, cheese plates, lamb kebabs, etc. All divine!   I've had quite a few of the entrees- the lamb sugo, lamb shank, coq au vin, arctic char, and even the hamburger. I've had an assortment of brunch items, as well. I love all of them! They are all truly perfect in my eyes (and mouth).   My drink is always the Ginger Rogers.   This place is perfect for a date or to just feel special. J'adore.

i5o9heILJtx3Yrwm-BdviQ.review_text: THANK the higher powers that may be for dine-about-town.  2 people, $18/person - throw in a glass of rose and a delightful 'Galapagos' cocktail & voila ~ $59.70 bill (added $10 for attentive service) & docked a star cos they forgot to give me my doggy bag. *sadness.  Roasted Mary's Chicken Breast - although I have issues with the name of this (I don't wanna be picturing Mary or her roasted (chicken) breasts(!)) - it was AMAZING.  Perfectly cooked, moist, and just oh-so-freeeakin flavourful.  Grilled Chese & Portabello Mushroom Sandwich - it was good. nothing super memorable & divine for me though.  Dessert: Pear Parfait - OMG OMG OMFG.  Just, amazing. crunchy oats, smoooooooth yogurt-y thingamabopper, perfectly poached pears. *salivate.  Thank you Absinthe + Kristian for making our otherwise average Tuesday something special by adding a certain...je ne sais quoi~*  A la prochaine!

IGkZa0eanufzVv9FR7kSUg.review_text: Great heart of Hayes Valley location. I've only been here for the bar food, but that in itself is great! Love the pretzels & cheese sauce, they're really cute and stubby :)   We've also gotten oysters and cocktails, both of which are yummy.  And a cheese selection: beware when you select your cheeses! Can't remember what it was but there was one that was SUPER SMELLY--probably should have asked the waiter :) so that's your warning! They have a great selection, just know what you're getting into!

yZM8bO0dbhffVp6RCTFN5w.review_text: Great brasserie-style food serving dinner at hours which make NYC ex-pats feel at home.  If you don't grab an early bird special with octogenarians before the Opera, then you are famished by the end of a Verdi and ravenous if having seen a Wagner.  This place gets the French classics spot on and deserves 4 stars for that.  The huge list of artisan cocktails and, more importantly,  the rare (for San Francisco) sophisticated late night dining experience bring it up to a 5th.  French Onion Soup Gratinée: Possibly the best French Onion soup I've had in town!  The broth is savory, the onions melt away, the bread has a toasted presence but is not overwhelming and the cheese is just the right mix of gooey and crispy.  The cheese isn't baked on top and oozing over the sides, but I can forgive that minor detail.  Steak Tartare: The meat was pretty darn good, but I've had better quality around town (Harris' and BIX).  However, I do appreciate the innovation.  A lightly poached egg is used instead of raw to give a bit of egg white texture and flavor.  The habañero adds much stronger kick than traditional onions or capers.  I barely noticed the mint though.  Overall, a nice revamp of a traditional favorite without traveling too far into the avant garde.  Duck Confit: This leg rests in duck fat for over three days to produce an extremely rich and crispy treat.  A tad small to make a meal out of, but great snacking material.  They were right on the mark for this classic.  Hamburger: Not sure how they did this, but the outside was extremely rich and seared while the inside was perfectly medium rare as requested.  The veggies were fresh, but nothing memorable.  The aioli was by far a better topping than ketchup or mustard.  The bun was a tad too dense for my liking.  Oyster Shooter: Had to get this since it looked cool.  You are presented with a single oyster on ice, a wedge of lemon, a shot glass of Bloody Mary mix and a shot glass of vodka.  How you take it is totally up to you.  I added the oyster and lemon to the Bloody Mary mix and topped it off with vodka.  Pretty strong!  Way too much liquid compared to oyster meat.  I think it would have been nice if a trained professional arranged the proper ratios... or maybe I just need more practice.

1MB1w6BfjnMjivtF9hw9lw.review_text: I only had appetizers there. But they were soooo good! Innovative, elegant, very fine cooking!

3ofrjsn5jQM9lAU7LE47jg.review_text: Had the filet and onion soup, both awesome!

GPofl5-KBzdz5tt_jM152w.review_text: The food was incredible and the service was great. One of my best meals ever. Yes, it's expensive but not outrageously so and the prices are not out of line for what one would expect for a restaurant of this caliber.

JxzkJndx3mxz7mA2iKrGcw.review_text: Celebrated my girlfriends birthday here.  1) Original waiter that sat us down apparently didn't want us so she gave us to another waiter whose only customer was us (?)  2) I came an hour early to drop off the cake and asked the rude old lady in the front to bring it out after the dinner and she agreed. The waiter was so unaware of the situation and didn't realize I had a cake and preceded to bring out the check at the end of the dinner so I had to run and stop him. I then had to tell him that I had a cake in the back waiting so what this guy does is bring the cake out and light the candles IN FRONT OF US and then brings the cake over like we're totally surprised. WAY TO RUIN A BIRTHDAY YOU ASS HOLE.

7y5B-JdnCrUwSINsVxoMeQ.review_text: Very good service, super "Old San Francisco" ambiance, I had the famous french onion soup, which held to its reputation, and the "Coq au vin" rich, and tasty!!

Zoq4sk2ob0t6WDv0fUIl6Q.review_text: 3.5 stars.   I finally managed to get my butt into Absinthe last night, and I'm slightly disappointed by how 'American' the food is. I was kind of looking forward to food with more French flair. Here's what we had:   Two Kumamoto oysters. At $3.25 each, the oysters aren't cheap, but they make a succulent and refreshing appetizer, perfect for whetting the appetite.   Pan-seared scallops. A poorly presented dish, in my opinion. Also, even though the scallops themselves were perfectly done, and the roasted vegetables were tender and delicious, I don't think all the components came together particularly well.   Liberty farms duck breast. This dish was very flavorful (emphasis on very). I liked it better than the scallops, mainly because the creamy farro risotto it comes with was sooooo so good.   TCHO chocolate pot de creme. The classic lives up to it's hype. Rich, creamy, and ultra-chocolatey, it's everything a chocoholic like me dreams about.   Overall, I think Absinthe may be overhyped. I do not enjoy being at a table that is a mere foot away from two other tables. Also, the restaurant is incredibly noisy, which is not ideal for a serious date. The food is good, but the main courses could use more subtlety and refinement. Finally, the service here is friendly enough, but a little on the slow side.   Would I come here again?   I'd like to try the cocktails at the bar. I'm not sure I would return for dinner.

50m0ejwjWU8QOCZgNJ17sA.review_text: My boyfriend and I spontaneously walked in for brunch on a Sunday at noon. I was surprised to be seated immediately despite the crowd.   We had:   - Great Hill Blue cheese with honeycomb This came with their house-made walnut bread slices. This was SO GOOOOOOOD. I am totally in love with the honey walnut bread.. I think I can eat it all day every day. Great appetizer!  - Scrambled eggs with potatoes, toast and sausage Standard breakfast plate with an extraordinary quality. The eggs was perfectly fluffy and perfectly seasoned. Potatoes were lightly crisp on the outside and wonderfully warm and soft on the inside. I recommend you dip the sausage in their almond-maple syrup.. soo tasty! *drool*  - Brioche French Toast Not only is it pretty to the eye, it is so extremely kind to your tastebuds.. AHHH!  Absinthe has become my brunch spot of choice. I can't wait to try their dinner menu!

Q_-6GtYQvPyIDJafbnNa4g.review_text: I have dined at Absinthe a few times since I moved to San Francisco, and each of the times has been a solid, worthwhile experience.  The last time I was there was on Wednesday for dinner.  It was before a show at one of the performing arts locations nearby, so it was pretty busy.  I arrived with my friend; we did not have a reservation, but were told it would be 40 minutes or so.  We had a drink at the bar, and after what felt like less than 40 minutes we were seated in the dining room.  Having dined here a few times, I prefer the dining room over the louder bar-seating area, so I was thankful that we were being placed in the dining room.  My dining partner and I started with spicy fried chick peas.  These were good, but not really necessary for the meal.  It was something to eat before my French onion soup arrived.  Mmmmm, I love this and try to get it every time I dine here.  Large crouton, lots of cheese, and a delicious broth.  For dinner, I had one of the "share plates," the seafood stew, as an entrée.  This had one very large scallop, manila clams, and PEI mussels in a bacon-bell pepper nage with crostini spread with herb rouille.  Uhhh, the herb rouille blew my mind.  Like a heroin addict on mid-Market, I wanted more, more, more.  The seafood was cooked perfectly.  The size of the dish was so-so; I don't know that I'd want to share the plate with anyone if I ordered it as a "share plate." In the past, I have had the hanger steak here, and thoroughly enjoyed it.  My friend had the acorn squash soup for a starter; it looked delicious.  He followed it with the burger, which came medium; personally I would have bumped that up to medium well.  I know I will be back to Absinthe.  I still need to try to the Sunday brunch at some point.  This restaurant is a solid choice for the Hayes Valley area.  As for the price, you don't have to spend a ton here, but it is always tempting to do so.  For me, it's worth the price.

tL0RL-FgATE2xvcrv7uxCQ.review_text: Wow. We ate here tonight and everything was excellent.  The duck was spectacular, the pretzels, steak, lamb, all wonderful. Highly recommended.

FAXBvjCR0mM92RAWbEKlRQ.review_text: Such a classy little spot!  I came here with two good friends late one night and we got a few appetizers. Everything was so tasty and delicious!!  They have a fabulous drinks menu and so we got a few rounds of martinis AND oyster shooters. You MUST try the oyster shooters!!  Great place to come with a couple friends for an intimate dinner or just to hang out, chat and have some drinks.  Charming, low key and delicious food and beverages.

wRcYyeWLcUVJErhuojY16g.review_text: I've been here for brunch twice and both times was absolutely blown away.   The first time I went, I was seated within ten minutes at a cozy table near the window. I ordered the french onion soup and the wild mushroom omelet and had citron pressé to drink (how refreshing to get some real French lemonade!), and my boyfriend got a scone and something else. We appreciated how the waiter brought an extra scone for free (they were 'smaller than usual'), and of course all the food was fabulous. The omelet was a liiiiittle on the salty side but still some of the tastiest mushrooms I've ever had!  The second time we went, we got a table in the second room. It was a little bit more crowded so the service wasn't quite as prompt, but it was worth it when my ricotta-stuffed french toast showed up. The portion was HUGE but I ate every bite (despite my protesting stomach) because it was so delicious! The ginger lemonade was fantastic, as well... I think I had about three of them.  I'd really love to come here for dinner sometime, but it's always packed!

LTWUnGE5dCVGFsKuwuWV9A.review_text: I'd been wanting to try Absinthe for awhile, but haven't had the opportunity. Well, I needed a mid-week nice dinner spot, and Absinthe had an open reservation. Overall, I was really pleased with the place. Absinthe excels at being exactly what it's trying to be: a nice french-style brasserie with excellent cocktails and a romantic atmosphere. I don't think the restaurant is trying to be the next sensation. It's trying to be really good at the basics, and I think it does pretty well.   We arrived early and had cocktails. My date ordered a dark and stormy (which was good), and I ordered a cocktail which I cannot find on their online menu. I do remember that it was rye-based, had some sort of liqueur, bitters, and a flamed orange twist. It was served in a coupe, and was excellent. I thought I was getting some variation on a normal old fashioned, but it was interesting and new.   We sat down, and Kimberly was our waitress. She was great throughout -- talkative (discussing Downton Abbey) and professional. We told her we wanted to have a "fat kids" night, and asked her not to judge. She told us she'd only judge if we didn't order enough food. Again, she was great.   We ordered three "snacks" -- spicy fried chickpeas, garlic pretzels, and spicy pork meatballs. The first two were awesome. The chickpeas were really interesting bar-type pop 'em food. They had some sort of moroccan spice. The garlic pretzels were divine and came with a great white cheddar sauce. The meatballs were fine, but nothing special.   For entrees, my date had the 8 oz filet mignon, and I had the 10 oz rib eye. Both were excellent. His was tender and marbled, and mine was very flavorful. The jus they covered the steaks with was really flavorful and yummy, and we both replaced the mashed potatoes with frites (which were standard, but good).   With the entrees, I had the Sandler Zin and my date had the Lang & Reed Cab Franc. Both were good, though I slightly preferred his cab franc. But since he was driving, I got a third of his glass anyway -- score for me.   For dessert, which was COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY, we split the awesome german chocolate cake. It wasn't what I thought at all. It had milk chocolate mousse on the outside, with coconut and pecans on the inside. It was lovely! And left us super stuffed.   The atmosphere only added to the experience. Dark, very French, with a nice dining room din that almost adds to the sense of privacy and intimacy in the place.   The total bill was like $140 (exclusive of the cocktails, which I paid for at the bar). The prices are at the high end of what I think is fair. Still fair, but only barely. Kimberly earned every dollar of a 20% tip, which is no small amount at a nice restaurant.   In all, a really great place. You'll definitely enjoy it.

QTsAZpgR1kKVDjOLJYa2MQ.review_text: We came here for brunch, so this review is for that only.  We had reservations, although I don't know if that's mandatory to get a seat. Evidently this place is pretty popular.  One nice thing is that they do not seat anyone until they open, so there's no additional wait time beyond the waiting for food.  Hostess seemed a little pretentious, but they often our.  Our server was helpful and polite.  No matter what you get, definitely start with the French onion soup, as it is fantastic.  Very little bread, which I enjoyed.  Lots of Gruyere cheese, which added a better flavor than most French onion soup cheese.    I ordered the dungeness crab omelette.  Great choice, although I like a thinner egg for my omelette.  They don't get chintzy with the lobster, as some places do.  It was flavorful with great big chunks.  The garlic spinach and mushrooms was also a wonderful addition. It had some hearty, smoky wheat toast and seasoned potatoes on the side.  My friends got oysters, which looked good although I did not partake.  My friends also ordered the duck confit ragout. It had a poached egg and a delicious potato under it. I had a bite and it was very rich and decadent.  Being the novice foodie I am, I forever have pronounced confit as "con-fit" so don't make that error ("con-fee").  I also learned that confit means that the duck is cooked in its own fat.  Pro tip for those who want to look like they're in the know, unlike me, I guess.  Another friend also got the crispy pork quesadilla.  It was a little shocking to the palate with the unexpected Latin flavor, but very good as well.      All in all, I wish I had a bigger stomach so I could have also tried the brioche French toast or the croque monsieur. Someday.

zaVsilTAuIPNj98a950rLw.review_text: I came here with some friends for drinks and was pleasantly surprised by how late their kitchen is open for food service. So of course we ordered a dessert to split.  We got the pumpkin custard, which I have to say will go down in my personal foodie history as one of the best things I have ever eaten. The custard itself was smooth and sweet in a gentle, subtle way, and it was presented on a plate decorated with - wait for it... root beer maple syrup and a carrot reduction. Garnished on top of the custard were thinly sliced carrots that had been magically transformed into candy brittle, as well as little tapioca things that had been created with lime juice, gelatin, and the marvels of modern culinary science. Amazing.  In other words, I have never before tasted something so utterly creative and original - and delicious. I haven't been to Absinthe for the full dining experience, but based on drinks, dessert, and service, I definitely give it full marks!

OcSqNHpjsLuFk9CsBuk3Kw.review_text: I had a good time when I checked out Absinthe. I went in with the bf and a friend for a quick drink after a show we watched in the area. We were able to get a quick seat, the placed was loud for 11pm. It was filled with business people from the area, hipsters and small groups. I had the pizza, while the bf had the burger and my friend had the gazpacho...All of it was Yum! Great portions, drinks were tasty. They have a whole book of drinks, darks, spirits, you name it.

pSogn5pH3hhbtCyT2Z13Mg.review_text: I'm a bartender so the bar is my favorite seat in the house!!  And the Absinthe bar is rockin' -great cocktail menu which means a fun "show" at the bar!  I love the Sacred Heart and the Galapagos.  On the food side, the Soft Garlic Pretzels are yummy!  Loved the raw oysters.  And the Warm Burrata & Tomatoes is so delicious!  Great cheese selection, amazing burger, and a fantastic atmosphere!!  GO!

zZd48sIIEwNHju7hvSS4bw.review_text: This restaurant never disappoints. The energy, atmosphere,  great staff, and most importantly the food make for a memorable experience.

0l_0KpelMBhHzflxt8PkqA.review_text: So good that we went back the next day for lunch!    I can see Absinthe turning into our go-to restaurant.  For starters, it's a big space relative to other San Fran joints--we didn't feel intimate with the tables nearby.  Then again, we had a primo table by the front window.  Raves for the French onion soup.  Duck and pork confit on the same menu?!!?  The frisee was downright decandent, oozing with duck egg yolk richness.    Lunch the next day included the corned beef sandwich and fresh ground beef burger.  Fresh fried chips and house made pickles were big winners, too.  Not much more to be said after 1100+ reviews, but I felt compelled to give credit where it was due.  Can't wait to get back for brunch, drinks, all of it!

pNIo3qnNGVJZ_mnVcWIoZw.review_text: Wedding reception. Perfect. Our party filled the restaurant and everyone was very happy. Walked from City Hall after very nice civil ceremony. It was just right for the occasion.

S0_FxmbFVahIIbzojRpMSQ.review_text: This place caught my eye while on our way to meet friends at Blue Bottle, and I'm so very glad it did. About a 20-ish minute wait for Sunday brunch around 1-ish without reservations - very nice. Couldn't resist ordering a drink (even after a belligerent Friday night, followed by nursing my boyfriend's 9 hour hangover). Got the Ginger Rogers (pretty much a ginger mojito, very refreshing!). Ordered the duck. I've never been done wrong ordering duck. And yes, it did do me quite good. Two poached eggs on top of duck on top of 2 hash-brownish-medallions? Oy vey vey ohh. BF got the shrimp roll, which I kind of snuffed initially, but it was good! The shimp was barely cooked, fresh and oceany. UHHNN I like it like that! I also got to take a lil nippy-nip at the grilled cheese. mmMUAH! I am so getting that if I ever come back for brunch.  Also, service was pretty legit. Example: my friend got up to go to the restroom and left her napkin on her chair. Our server came by, folded it up all fancy for her and set it back on the table. Real fance-like.  Goodtimes, everybody!

d_jFqEuSL5PIH7QPsJrdyA.review_text: A group of us had brunch here today at the delightful Hayes-Valley spot Absinthe Brasserie. The plush red velvet banquettes and red decor made me think that we had time-warped to Paris. Ah to be in Paris.  For brunch, we started out by sampling a morning bun ($3.50). This pastry was springy with a light dusting of sugar and came with a small dish of strawberry jam. Delicious.  Another good starter was a plate of deviled eggs. Hard-boiled egg halves with bits of smoked salmon and topped with caviar. How decadent this tastes.  The lamb sandwich I chose was thin, tender slices of lamb (not at all gamey) on top of a slice of thick brioche bread, a slice of cheese and sauteed orange and red peppers all topped with a over-easy fried egg. When you stuck your fork into the egg, the yolk oozed slowly over the sandwich. The thin frite-type fries had a spicy Berber seasoning that was reminiscent of BBQ spice. Hearty sandwich and, for sure, a winner.  Another member of my party, J, ordered the classic burger. This was a hefty, soul-satisfying sandwich for a carnivore. The plain frites that came with the burger paled in comparison to the spicy fries. You might need to up the flavor with the ketchup.  C ordered a trout sandwich which she enjoyed. She ate it so fast I can't really describe what it looked like.   For B, the traditional Croque Monsieur (ham and melted cheese sandwich) on sliced levain bread was very hearty. Instead of the side green salad that was on the menu description, the server kindly acquiesced to substitute it with some slices of potato with onion relish. This French version of a ham & cheese sandwich was a hit.  Sunday brunch at Absinthe is bustling. They have very good food and an ideal people watching spot on Hayes Street. You can gaze at the beautiful mural walls and Parisian pictures imagining you're in Paris, enjoy an apertif or mimosa or two, as well as gaze at all the interestingly dressed pedestrians who stroll by.   If you find yourself in this neighborhood or receive an invitation to dine here, do not hesitate. Embrace your inner Francophone feelings and say, "Oui!"

dy_BZmVfkB9Tw1VHx4IQVw.review_text: 5 stars is an under statement! This place ROCKS! Love the location, the vibe and the food but let me tell you ... THE STAFF beginning from valet, host, servers and yes the Chef, all deserve 5 stars!  I attended a wedding rehearsal here in their private dining room and was wow'd the minute I walked in! The about to be newlyweds had an amazing wedding planner who greeted us as well as the staff. The place was meticulously clean and decorated with gorgeous autumn colors and beautiful fresh floral arrangements.  Customized printed dinner menus and a fabulous framed cocktail menu with outstanding hand passed appetizers were also absolute favorite forget me nots.   I had an amazing salad with some of the yummiest caramelized almonds ever, and the grilled pork chop was by far The BEST cut of pork I've ever had! Let's not talk about their Pot de Creme....we could be here all night!! Unbelievable!!  Just amazing!!!  I'd love to come and have dinner again with my hubby he will LOVE it here and so will you. Gotta love the Hayes Valley too ... one could walk off the calories after dinner simply window shopping or boutique and bar hopping,  (if they're open).  Merci beau coup for a lovely evening and overall experience!!  Great experience from beginning to end!

IfHo9BPvVpeuzY8lnJjN-A.review_text: Although I've heard about this place sinc e'07, this is a place I finally got around to checking out and I'm now really into their breakfasts. On top of that, the street is so great so stroll afterwards too. A part of me wishes I lived within walking distance so I wouldn't have to find parking there.

nXsMrhO9c9dO--Jbi5CHYg.review_text: It's a wednesday night and after work I'm getting my haircut at the wonderul oxenrose. I thought it would be a good idea to try out Absinthe since its right down the street. I had only been to Absinthe for brunch about 3 or 4 years ago, so I didn't know what to expect for dinner.   My sister and I are avid watchers of Top Chef and we're fans of Jamie Lauren on the show so we were excited to try out her restaurant. I was finished with my haircut appointment early, so I headed over to Absinthe to have a drink at the bar and wait for my sis.   For a Wednesday evening, they were pretty busy, but as I came to learn, the server said it was actually a really mellow night. The bar was completely packed and the host said I could sit at my table to wait. Personally, I would have rather waited at the bar instead of sitting at my table all alone for more than a half hour, but I understood that they just didn't have the room, so I sat at my table.   After about ten minutes of looking over the drink menu, someone finally came up to me and asked if I wanted something to drink, and only because I was obviously looking around to get someone's attention. Hmmmm... makes me think that if it apparently was a slow night, what service would be like on a busy night? Who knows.   I had the Pegu Club, which was pretty refreshing although not that strong. The cocktail menu was pretty extensive and there was a lot of choice... which almost made it difficult to choose a drink, but I guess I'd rather have more choices than not.   Once my sister arrived, we looked over the menu and decided on 3 different appetizers and one entree to share. The line up: French Onion Soup, Duck Confit, Antipasti platter and the Scallops.   French Onion Soup was delish! Not overly salty and the onions were really sweet. It needed just a tad more bread, since it barely had any, but we just used our table bread as dippers. The Duck confit was tender, a tad on the dry side and salty, but if you ate it with the side salad of ancho cress and apples, then it was perfect. (disclaimer, I really don't like salty things, so it really is just me)  The Antipasti plate was large and really could have fed more people than just the two of us. A lot of selection on different salamis and cured meats with pickled veggies, definitely a go to plate for meat lovers. YUM.   Our last savory course was the scallops.
