Maybe its just me, but every time I order scallops, I'm always under impressed about the amount they give you and the price they charge. We chose the scallops because on Top Chef, Chef Jamie was always getting great reviews of her scallops, so we thought it would be a definite winner. The dish was great, the sunchoke puree and the grilled artichokes complemented the scallops wonderfully. Only caveat is that you get 4. I know, I know... its just me, but I had to be honest.   For dessert we had the warm chocolate banana tart with malted banana ice cream. Perfect way to end our meal. The tart is really decadent and rich and the banana ice cream which the pastry chef, Irene Cotreras, makes in house is absolutely fabulous. I only wish they gave you more ice cream. Does anybody else feel that way? I always feel like the ice cream servings are never enough at every restaurant... haha.... again, its just me.   Overall great restaurant, good meal. We left really satisfied and happy.  Cool place and a great vibe. I'd give it 3.5 stars and will have to try brunch again.

Mwm47OqqtE0iSt3BD6JZZQ.review_text: The service is great, good ambiance, and the food is good.  It's not the best I've ever had in SF, but it was definitely worth what we paid.  The pretzel bites were to die for!

tgwk_yuIpeQDR9rLwUW8Uw.review_text: Okay I feel bad about my last review. This place is yum and has a nice bartender, and i shouldn't have used the see you next tuesday word to describe my former waitress who probably doesnt even work there anymore. sorries! anyways, this place is way improved from the last time i was here and they have strubbes flemish ale which is the best beer ever! yay!

5SBWWScaC4QNql6XkHJPmw.review_text: I totally wanted Jaime to win Top Chef and after eating at her restaurant, I'm even more sure that she was robbed of that title.  My friends and I came here for brunch on Sunday around 11:30am.  The place was packed and we ended up waiting 45 minutes to 1 hour for a table for 5.  But the place gets your name and  number and will call you when the table is ready-- so we walked around and did some window shopping.   We ordered a round of bloody marys which was sooo good!  I also ordered the deviled eggs and corn cakes eggs benedict.  Those were the best things I've ever eaten!  The deviled eggs had smoked salmon, caviar and chives.  My eggs had the perfect balance of ham, hollandaise sauce and corn cake.  Our entire table was oooing and ahhhing as we devoured our meal.  This place was TOTALLY worth the wait and the money (came out to be $35 bucks a person).

SE12F7KiHtaTLxNBBsIPvg.review_text: I like this place! So far I have only been here for brunch (excellent) but Ihave heard great things about dinner so I think that's next on the cards.  For brunch I got the Duck-confit Ragout and husband had the basted eggs.  The Basted eggs were good, perhaps a little too smoky? for me.  The Duck-confit ragout was AMAZING.  Duck was excellently done, the whole dish was just very well put together and extremely enjoyable.  The portion sizes were impressive too - They obviously weren't cafe size, but they were good and filling.  Service was spot on and we had a reservation so thankfully we didn't have to wait at all.  There was a pretty big line waiting for it open, but once it opened everything moved fast. We had 11am reservations and by the time we left close to 12:30pm, the place was packed. It was a difficult getting out.  Mimosas were good - we prefer them a little stronger but nothing worth mentioning.

5vd9a7Xx_LlFfVogN1UsJg.review_text: Boyfriend once bit a woman's breast at the bar here.  In a playful/ drunken idiot trying to flirt way, not a slasher/ date rapist way, at least as he tells it.  She may have a different version.  He and his friend were asked to leave.  So he went to his car and got sick.  Three hours later he was passed out in his ride with his head out the window.  A passing homeless man woke him up, saying "you really should go home."  This was before we met.  It definitely wasn't the food that made him sick.  Absinthe is a great place.  Boyfriend introduced me to it early in our relationship (luckily they didn't ban him for life or anything) and we used to go there often.  He loves all their oysters and I was crazy about their coq au vin.    We went there for the first time in a couple years recently.  Reading the menu, I didn't see the coq au vin.  I assumed I had overlooked it until an exhaustive search of the menu, list of specials, and even the drink list failed to yield results.  I asked the waiter who informed me that the a new chef had taken over nine months ago and both the coq au vin and cassoulet were gone, to the chagrin of many.  I didn't have high expectations after that, but I was happily proven wrong.  Our food was different, but just as good as ever.  Boyfriend had the hamachi.  I was persuaded to try some of the raw fish for only the second time in my life.  I obviously don't love sashimi, but even I could appreciate the complete lack of fishiness and the surprisingly sensual texture of the flesh.  He also had four tiny Olymipa oysters which were great, as usual.  I had the sea bass.  It was served with the skin, which disappointed me.  Sea bass is my favorite fish because it's so un-fishy, but cooking it with the skin on made it way too strong for my taste.  It was what the bass came with that left me so satisfied.  The grilled romaine perfectly underscored the flavor of the fish.  And the carrot and bacon hash was delicious.  I could have made a meal of just that (if there were much, much more), it was so good.    To top it off, the potatoes it came with were nothing short of the best I've ever had.  Not the preparation, which was just a simple sautee in butter, but the potatoes themselves.  They had more potato flavor than I've ever tasted in a potato.  What home-grown tomatoes are to store-bought, those potatoes are to the ones you usually get.  I don't really remember how it was in the past, but on this visit the staff were all great.  The waiter in particular was incredibly congenial, exchanging pie shop recommendations with me and informing us that we could have a half salad (I love when waiters aren't just concerned with their bottom line).  The new menu looked great and someday I'm gonna try their entire cheese tasting menu for $99.    We had a great time and, as far as I know, no breasts were bitten.

K1lkv1Zpnzsl3n08Zv04kg.review_text: Absinthe, a delicious green liquor that seems to warm you and has you seeing fairies. As a restaurant for brunch I felt it having a similar happiness effect. We found this place using the Yelp iPhone app and searching brunch while wandering around Hayes Valley. It was a Sunday and buzzing, but we still managed to snag a table right away walking in at 1pm.  I wanted something different, I mean I can always get my usual 2 eggs over-easy with bacon and toast. It's pretty much the same everywhere, no better, no worse. So I glance at the menu and I see duck confit hash. Yes.  Two perfectly poached eggs sit atop a bed of duck confit hash, two slices of toast and some veges on the side. Maybe it was the bellinis but brunch here was delicious!   My friend also got the french onion soup, which normally I hate because french onion soup always tastes a little sour to me. But it was really good here. The cheese on top was gooey and yet slightly firm on top.   Not to mention that this is the restaurant of Jamie from Top Chef. A great experience. I would definitely revisit to try food from here again

1MYu2Zrf5nlsQIm8JpsVaA.review_text: Best oyster shooter of my life. A most beautiful oyster.

ZP6qLYRA6M0u_37z9FsT0A.review_text: I have been there several times for dinner and late-night snacking.  I do not know why, but it took me forever to make it out to their brunch which I had heard so much about.  I finally made it out to their brunch and wow oh wow.  Thus far, it is in my top 3 favorite brunches in the city.  Yes, I understand that this is a bold statement, but this is an amazing place.  I went with a group of 6 people.  I do not remember if they do not take reservations for that amount of people or if they needed more advance notice to make a reservation, but they said to just show up when they open at 11am.  They easily accommodated us without a problem.  Since a bunch of went to brunch we strategized and ordered a good selection of the breakfast dishes in order to try as much as possible.  We ordered the Croque Monsieur, Ricotta Stuffed French Toast, Duck-comfit Ragout, and the Kruobat Pork Enchiladas.  All of the breakfast dishes were fabulous!  My favorites were the Duck Comfit Ragout and the Pork Enchiladas.  I do not really like enchiladas at all, so this should really say something.  Next time I go back I am definitely ordering that dish.  I also want to try the burger, which I heard was amazing, and the steak frites, because I just love steak frites and I am sure they do it up well.   For drinks, we all ordered Buck's Fizz.  I believe the drink contained fresh OJ, champagne, and grenadine or something.  Delicious!   This is a spacious place.   They have two large rooms.  There is outdoor seating, but barely.  I think there are two-three tables outside, but they only sit 2 people.  After eating brunch, lunch, dinner it is nice to just take a stroll down Hayes Street.  There are so many cute, but expensive, shops.  Depending on what time of day you go, some things to do on a date or with a group is to go to the Biergarten on Octavia between Hayes and Fell and go to Smitten for some yummy fresh ice cream.

HwIzNmTf0_WWWGMkPpBxGw.review_text: This review is purely based on the service we received.  My boyfriend and I were so excited to try Absinthe for a nice dinner on a Saturday night.  We waited 40 minutes for a table and were seated in the middle of the bar area.  As a result, we were pushed all night from people trying to get to the bar.  When we told the hostess, she became defensive.  Instead, we just ordered appetizers and drinks since we didn't have enough room to eat any entrees with so many people around us.  Very disappointing experience.

x_5YM8NvzWOyz-aXAxpwow.review_text: The hubs, our 13 month old son, and I came here for our 6 year anniversary dinner.    Service - 5/5 stars! Wow, they were so nice, friendly, and accommodating to our son's needs. I reserved the restaurant on open table, noting that we have a toddler with us and that it's our anniversary in the comments section.  They had our table ready with a high chair, brought our son a beautiful bowl of fresh fruit (strawberries, nectarines, figs, you name it), and gave us a free anniversary melon sorbet desert! They actually read the comments section!   Food - 5/5 DAMMNNNNNN that sweet yellow brentwood corn soup was good!!!!!!!!!!! Best soup I've ever had out. Everything was good, but this stands out the most to me.   Ambiance - the only reason I give the overall rating a 4/5 instead of 5/5 is because the ambiance could be better.  Granted, we probably didn't help the ambiance for ourselves or for others by bring a child with us to dinner! LOL  However, I would say that the food and service surprised me a lot given the look and feel of the place.  I would give the ambiance 3/5.  Prices - Reasonable for the awesome food you get in return!

L8C7Eta6Fx1-aqUiAiptkA.review_text: Enjoyed the brunch.  The menu has a nice variety.  The raw oysters weren't the greatest.  Not sure if it was the oysters themselves or if it was from the person that shucked the oysters, but they were really gritty.  I kept getting small pieces of shell with my oysters.

2s-svCM3YBu5Iu-6W4_yMA.review_text: Just an amazing place ! The food is delicious and I feel like I am back in Paris ! One of the best restaurants in San Francisco !

LwqpH0H8v0KUzczxo3fkqQ.review_text: A really great lunch/brunch spot - delicious and reasonably priced cheese plate options as well!

c8qfBhYIjvrSy_xCob1onw.review_text: A great place to sit at the bar and watch the Hayes Valley hipsters swan by outside.  Nice vibe and a great place to catch up with an old friend, especially if she looks like the Femme Fatale from a Film Noir.  Great spiced garbanzo beans. Even greater scallops.

30Oz9MupjAVldojMxfrXQg.review_text: A few months back, we decided to TRY Absinthe after many months of THINKING about trying Absinthe.  Like some of the other Yelpers who've commented on this restaurant, we are Top Chef fans so we were intrigued to see what executive chef, Jamie Lauren, had to offer.  So, when we happened to be down at Symphony Hall one Friday night, we decided to give it a go.  We weren't disappointed!  We came by after 10pm and decided to take a table in the bar since we weren't sure how much we'd be eating.  We were immediately impressed with the drink and wine lists - P had a mixed drink with an aged tequila that was super smokey and delicious.  I tried one of the champagne offerings and was pleased.  We ordered spicy fried garbanzo beans and oysters as an app and were amazed by the intense flavors of both, though were surprised at the small size (and number) of oysters served.  We went on to order the house-made hot dog (I know...but Chicagoans are curious when a dog appears on a fine dining menu!).  Simply put, it was amazing!!  I still have cravings for it every now and then.  P didn't think he'd like it because it's not a Chicago dog.  But even he thought it was spectacular.  After this, another round of drinks - red wines for both of us from their extensive house list - and we dared to try dessert.  We chose the most intriguing one:  it consisted of mascarpone, basil and strawberries and was surprisingly delicious.  I only wish the basil flavor had been more intense - to balance out the sweetness of the strawberries.  But the creamy, herby sweetness was well worth it.    The service and ambiance only enhanced the dining experience!  Good attention to detail, cozy, French-inspired decor, attentive but not pushy service and knowledgeable waitstaff are all pluses.    We will definitely be back for more...likely will try a proper dinner meal there since we know what these chefs are doing with apps and dessert!!  And, given the restaurant features locally-grown, seasonal ingredients, it'll be fun to find new "favorites" as the days grow shorter and the rain comes.

mYfgYg0YJ8F_pU14ZY3ktQ.review_text: I've been here for drinks and brunch and each time I was pleasantly surprised. The bartender was super cool and added to the experience. There's a wide selection of drinks and prices aren't too bad.  The food is delectable though and is reason enough to stop by!  I love their fries - super thin, crispy, and tasty. My bf had the duck the duck confit hash and still dreams about it.   What are you waiting for?!  Nothing that's right.

r5yqoB2JH4a2Sye1_KNFww.review_text: Awesome service. Fabulous food. Fantastic ambience. Couldn't be better, I'll be goin back again and again and again!

R4mq1TCh58OPtIxzxS-hXA.review_text: Terrific crowd, good food, and great service. It is loud and lively yet there is a coziness to the place. The coque au vin was good but not comparable to cafe Claude. Nice caesar and great kumomoto oysters.

HC3SCbdNV7hDMkZ_J7tKPA.review_text: I liked the spiced chickpeas - a yummy surprise snack bite before dinner

u9KhzES5reUljwccEyFdJw.review_text: Came here for a dinner party of 13, so naturally the server already had his hands full. We had a set three course meal. Salad for starters, steak for the main course, and the dessert I got was an extremely rich chocolate pudding/moose dessert. Too rich for my taste but still good.  I have to say I am a water snob at restaurants. If I have an empty glass of water I'm hoping it gets filled in a timly matter. ANNND here at Absinthe they were on top of their game!! I think I drank 7 glasses of water so that's a lot to refill and they did a great job ;)

b0fp-eS8_MKTg4tcZsCNqQ.review_text: Came here for an amazing celebratory meal complete with some great cocktails, wine and champagne. Awesome and attentive, but not overbearing service, too. Loved my steak and butternut squash soup. Had an incredible cocoa pot de creme, too. So amazing. Can't wait to go back!  Loved the ambiance, too. Don't miss the pretzels with cheese on the bites menu, too. Probably my favorite thing! Can't wait to go back and get drinks and bar bites.

sn1_vQjCEugokjVpsHS84Q.review_text: Ate here with my Android development team after Google I/O and we had a great time. Our waiter was very helpful and gave us the background on Absinthe. For the most part, we all enjoyed our food. I had the Pierogies with Truffle Butter and Mushrooms. I love anything with Truffle Butter and this dish did not let me down. Great place to meet up with your friends or coworkers for drinks and dinner.  Oh, and don't forget to try the French Onion Soup... it was delish!

TWLjiFruhV2-ukAw1EnVBQ.review_text: Rating:3.5  loved those pretzels! they are really just yummy little garlic rolls. i didn't even need the side of cheese. i could eat a dozen.   my onion soup was very nice. bubbly and cheesy just the way i like it.   decided to get a shared plate (large app) of the mussels & clams to go with my soup which ended being huge. super deal that tasted great.  husband went with the coq au vin which was good but not the best i've had.  nice service and ambiance. i'd return for sure.

zpT7HWE3o77YVfG4S07H9A.review_text: I've been wanting to dine at Absinthe for a very long time now and a couple weeks ago I finally got the opportunity to! A girlfriend had her birthday dinner there and it was simply gorgeous. The place is intimate and elegant- ideal place for a date or a small group dinner. We were seated near the exit at a round table. (Perfect for a group of 6 girls)   They have great selections of cocktail and wine (although I didn't have any for that night, but girlfriends raved about their drinks)  For Appetizers we shared:  -Spicy fried chickpeas: really tasty and reminded me of eating popcorn chicken from Quickly's.  -Hamachi Crudo: the best appetizer of the night!  -Beef Carpaccio: Delicious and fresh!  For entree I had the grilled skirt steak (cooked rare) with a cup of french onion soup gratine. The soup was sooo yummy, but I was fine with the small serving because it gets rich after a while. The steak was so juicy and flavorful that I finished the entire dish!    For dessert we shared the Olive Oil ice cream. Interesting flavor and it turned out to be sweet and refreshing. Perfect dessert to clean the palette and to end the night!

ncIy_qMBJF7QYNDOqQqN6A.review_text: Nine of us had a "family reunion" dinner and we could not have been more pleased with the place.  The bar presented some unique cocktails and the sommelier presented our wine with a flair.  We each ordered different entrees and shared bites with each other around the table - every one was incredibly prepared and presented. The service at the table by various members of the staff was outstanding and we were made to feel very welcome.  Needless to say, it was a great night and we will be back!

zJBGOAEQEbXwcZg6U7vhiA.review_text: the food was not as good as expected and the service was terrible. Will not be going back for the very poor service, from the hostess with her attitude to the waitresses. thank goodness for the busladies who would come around to fill our water as they were the only ones who could get the attention of our waitress for us. not worth it.

cHm5HisPvZ1E03xWoHfXig.review_text: Absinthe - make sure you get reservations. We tried doing a walk in for a table of 2 at 4:30pm, and were told we'd have over an hour and a half wait. Leave it to my best bud to get a reservation here, and boy was it worth it!  Best french onion soup EVER! Sure it comes in a small little cup the size normally reserved for JELLO pudding cups, and costs as much as 6 of them, but it's tasty as could be!  Drinks here aren't shy at all, and very from pleasingly sophisticated to put hair on your chest strong. I guess with the restaurant named after an exotic imported brew steeped in mystery, you can't expect anything other than excellent right?  Other menu highlights from the table included the Braised Beef Cheeks and Slow Cooked Pork Confit. Pork Confit definitely got a solid nod of approval from everyone at the table, being buttery soft in texture. The beef cheeks were similarly moist and soft, but didn't quite have the same appealing flavor as the pork.

cfR6GmRfq6muejlJsL4CqQ.review_text: Hubby and I decided to try this place out because we are huge fans of Jamie from Top Chef!    YAY! - Best French Onion soup EVER - Every dish was pretty much delicious... - Great atmosphere!  BOO! -I was SOOO surprised and bummed when I found a little hair in the sauce part of my lamb shank entree! The hair was black and a little wavy =(    I mean, as gross as it sounds, it was on the side in the sauce, so I just sorta picked it out and continued eating.   haha... the lamb shank was good.... but it was a total downer on the perfect meal.. esp knowing that my dish was def NOT prepared by Jamie.    Jaime is blond! hahah I wonder if I would have felt better if I found a blond hair in my sauce. HAH.

PAx55r6U_kmBMhh2KrDAmQ.review_text: I love brunch where the food is flavorful and not just a pile of fried carbs.. Better still if it comes with a sub-15 minute wait in San Francisco. Check, check at Absinthe on both counts! We were a party of 4 and seated immediately upon arriving. The food was delicious- the best brunch I've had in a long time. I got the Omelette with Mushrooms and Spinach. The meyer lemon zest was a great touch! My friend got the Croque Monsieur - strong gruyere and we also got the French toast. Delicious all round! I'll only take one star away because our table was a little cramped but other than that- loved it!

BdTgpA3C-ZYHOgwswSZJVg.review_text: Went here for my birthday dinner with my fiance during summer time 2010 while visiting the city from Southern Ca. The food and service was really good. Our server didn't rush us at all and was very knowledgeable about the menu. The location of the restaurant was very cute. Would definitely go back on our next visit to SF.

JVL0eReGF-IPtiMypmuqSw.review_text: If you like the intimate feel of a corner booth, and realize that there are only so many corners to go around, rest assured that this place has 'em in and around the dimly lit brasserie. I came here for dinner.  The waiters aren't very talkative, focused on taking your order and subtly refilling glasses and taking dishes as needed giving you ample time to converse, uninterrupted.   PROS: - Aesthetically pleasing, borderline artistic presentation of tasty dishes (ex: the salmon dish, coffee-crusted duck breast) - Assortment of cheese and oyster plates hailing from around CA - Creative cocktails (have to try those next time) - Seamless reservation for night-of, available within the hour on a Sunday night  CONS: - On the pricey side - not picture friendly due to dim lighting (experience-oriented, which I'd ultimately call a "pro")

hUNLXotYIcJJC6IQf0O-uQ.review_text: Amazing French onion soup!! Came here on my birthday, a little crazy but all in all it was an amazing experience!

7xN_4bfFlP-ExM_MjFEiBA.review_text: We ate here before seeing Wicked At the Orpheum. This was my first choice because of location. Walking distance from parking lot on Grove St., and a few blocks to Orpheum.   We started with house cocktails and an order of the little soft Pretzels with cheesy dipping sauce. The cocktails & pretzels were the highlight of the meal.  Then a bottle of Sancerre from the very expansive, import heavy, wine list.  For my entree I ordered the Bacon wrapped Stuffed trout. Served whole, stuffed with artichoke, capers and other goodies, wrapped in bacon, roasted and covered in a buttery sauce. It was delicious however the richness was a little overwhelming. And a side note, don't order this if you mind picking small fish bones out of your mouth. My friend had the coq au vin which she enjoyed, but didn't rave about.  For dessert we had the bergamot tart, and pot de creme. Both were ok.   Excellent service, good food, and great funky french bistro atmosphere, but overall, I wouldn't go out of my way to return. For a $200 meal, I want to leave impressed.

SPNVjOnbzmfvlgabSFVIRg.review_text: There actually aren't that many nice places around here that are open for drinks before 5:00. So Absinthe gets a couple of stars just for that. In addition to about a dozen different Absinthes, the cocktail and wine lists are expansive--and fairly expensive. Most impressive, however, is the way they served my gin (I chose the locally-distilled No. 209) and tonic. The two greatest risks when you order this simple drink are bad portioning and lousy tonic (like the sugar-water that comes out of those dreaded mixer guns). Both pitfalls are avoided here, with our pleasant server bringing to our table a glass of ice, a carafe of gin, and a small bottle of Schweppes tonic water.  You might feel a bit under-dressed if you arrive in jeans and a tee-shirt, but the entire staff will make you feel welcome nonetheless.

swLs5T_tMuY0DSm2hFfYjw.review_text: A blind date took me here. I was excited because as I was talking about the place with a few of my friends, I had heard only great things about this place. So in I went with an appetite and high hopes.  We started off with a drink each: I got something with pear, and my date got the 21 Hayes. Both were delicious; not too strong with lots of bright and contrasting flavors.   My date proceeded to order the Hamachi Crudo for an appetizer, and I got the Absinthe Hamburger with a fried egg and spicy caramelized onions, and he got the ... you know, I don't remember. But I'll post pics.  The Hamachi Crudo was absolutely amazing. I couldn't believe so much flavor could come from such a small, but beautiful piece of sashimi. The balance of sweet and savory was perfect, and the texture of the sashimi was perfectly balanced with the richness of the oil. I could've eaten two plates of that for dinner and would've died and gone to heaven.  The burger was AWESOME! Juicy, flavorful patty. Egg cooked perfectly; had that satisfying moment when you break the yolk and it slowly dribbles down. The bun could have been thinner; it was pretty dense and swallowed a lot of the flavor. And I wish the caramelized onions were cut thinly instead of large chunks. They kept slipping out when I would take a bite, and I eventually gave up and put them on the side. There was just no nice, clean way to eat the burger, and I eventually dissected it into pieces and ate it with a fork and knife. After all, I WAS on a blind date, and didn't wanna look like an animal. The fries were okay; they were cut thinly, and I'm more of a thick, "natural-cut," steak fries kind of girl.  The level of attention to detail, the professionalism from the staff and the ambiance was great. Even though it was slightly dark and formal, it still had a casual feel to it. I saw many people in shirts and jeans, and it was fine.  Will definitely come back to try some of the other entrees. If I were rating on the burger alone, it would be 4 stars, but the Hamachi saves this review. 5 STARS!

Y8adrWFzckrjuC11aAs9Og.review_text: Maybe I'm just easily impressed, but my Valentine's day dinner here was the best I've ever had!   Favorite items included the fried chick peas, french onion soup and the scallops (Chef Jamie made them so much on Top Chef, I figured they had to be good.. and they were delicious). We got the cookie plate for dessert, which was very yummy, but I only really enjoyed 2/4 cookies. The wait staff is very accomodating and honest about their food recommendations. It can get very crowded so make a reservation, try to get into the farthest room for the entrance so you can have a quieter, more intimate, dining experience. You should also try to come early to get street parking (just have a couple of quarters and arrive before 6) and just walk around the area (there's a couple of small, interesting shops) until your reservation.   For the ambiance and quality of food/service, prices here are very reasonable... but I haven't found the time or money to head back. Sigh.

Le74zCxIjVCaA7z_lxofiw.review_text: I had brunch here after reading all of the great reviews.    This was the first time I actually ate food at this restaurant.  I've only come here to drink.    I ordered the Two Eggs Any Style:  Got them poached with a sausage patty.  The patty was ENORMOUS.... and quite tasty indeed.  The potatoes really surprised me.  They were lightly fried potato wedges.  Not too overbearing, but just enough to hit the spot.    I would definitely come back for brunch.

TG0pDlxK33DJofeW0JketQ.review_text: The good - FOOD!  The not so good - portion, price and service  Dine about town this week - they offer it for lunch.  But don't you know that Saturdays and Sundays it's not "lunch" but "brunch".  Where was this mention, no where.  My $7 salad with six leafs of lettuce was awesome, portion size could have been 4x and still would have not been out of line with other SAN FRANCISCO restaurants portion sizes.   The open face sandwich was half a piece of bread with a "scoop" of fish salad, tasted great but $15 again 2x would not have been out of line.   It took 30 minutes between app and main course.  When asked, the kitchen is "busy" at this time 3pm on Sunday.   Our waitress was very nice.  Way too many other places for a $70 bunch without having to leave hungry and waste 2 hours.    Hope this was an anomaly as I won't be back.

OXmLAJElqhG9CPBCYjetjQ.review_text: 'Covetousness is both the beginning and the end of the devil's alphabet - the first vice in corrupt nature that moves, and the last which dies,'  wrote Michel Montaigne in fluent french,  in a real life french castle with french maids and everything.  Alas, I covet the French Onion soup here, even in dreams.    Desire.   Long.   Ache for.  I could ramble on about the cozy location in the undead gentrified core of Hayes Valley-- dark wood and black-clad waitstaff-- the green neon of the sign reflecting off rainpools in the street.   But, the soup.  The first act is foreplay, anticipation:  Each serving arrives in a baked tureen, a golden lid that crackles slightly as it gives under your spoon.   Carmelized onions rush into the curved void in a lucious blend of three stocks.  (I asked the waitress, she would not be more specific than there are three.)  Before you can control yourself,  you're wrapping long strands of Gruyère around your spoon, savoring the rich unami hit of carmelized onion proteins as they hit your brain.  And it's one of the most reasonably priced offerings on the menu.      I've had a selection of their entrees and all are in the good-to-great class;  The place is packed with intimate chatter and dates-in-progress all weekend.     But, when I wake up at 3 AM, starving and well...covetous... it's that soup that's on my mind.

Sp-S4y8rx1xIX3d5VOK0bQ.review_text: Absinthe has something for everyone - late night theater revelers, early dining elderly, date focused lovers, bar fly munchers, etc.  I've occasioned Absinthe as a 'date focused lover' and a 'late night theater reveler' and found myself quite pleased on both occasions!  Dinner in the main dining room can be very romantic, depending on the table you get. We had a cozy booth where we could sit next to each other and look out over the rest of the diners in the room.   Service was exceptional and we were well taken care of through our whole dining experience.   You can't go wrong with the steak (rib eye...yum!) and they have the most wonderful fries!  Dining in the bar area is also fun, and a different experience. We shared a burger and fries along with some spicy fried chickpeas and garlic pretzels. They were open late enough for our visit after seeing a show at Davies. The burger is delicious!  Wonderful drinks, and a nice heavy pour!

A1fZP8vgbXjNcCJ2pAzQDg.review_text: Been dying to try this place out. I've passed by it so many times. My supervisor treats me out to this place. We've come during the DAT event. So I get the lunch menu and choose the butter lettuce salad with vinaigrette, wine sauce mussels, and raspberry sorbet with crunchy caramel cookie on the side. I was pleased with the salad and the dessert. I was disappointed at the portion size for lunch - it was like 8 mussels and a whole bunch of extra greasy fries on top. I think the sauce I had was mostly oil and I didn't taste much of the wine flavor in the sauce. It was an ok experience. The dining area was well lit during the day and it wasn't too noisy. There was sufficient space between tables and the waitstaff was friendly. I had many re-fills of my ice tea and water. Maybe I need to come here for dinner to give this place a real try.   I must say, the crab sandwich looked really good.

kfKbLw9KIHs9PBn5kw6QZw.review_text: I came here for brunch on a typical Saturday noon with friends who were visiting from LA. I was super impressed by the classy yet non-pretentious vibe of the restaurant: simple, throwback decor that takes you back to an earlier decade, diverse menu to appease a variety of palettes, and awesome customer service. Great place to brunch with friends or go on a romantic dinner date.  During brunch, I tried their Duck-Confit Ragout: wild mushrooms, chive-potato cake, poached eggs, béarnaise sauce. AHHHMAZINGGG! Such a clever dish that was essentially a twist on the traditional eggs benedict (potato cake instead of english muffin). The potato cake had a hasbrown-type of crunch to it, which paired so well with the PERFECTLY poached eggs and béarnaise sauce (didn't taste as heavy as hollandaise, IMO). If you ever head to Absinthe for brunch, ORDER THIS DISH. Order their coffee as well! Their coffee is such a bold roast that you really don't need cream/sugar.   I can't wait to return for their dinner+drinks!

OnFjODWzvx_4rCBeAR1e9A.review_text: awesome spot.  date night for gf and me and we've been wanting to go here for awhile.  Great beer and wine selection and we shared the soft garlic pretzels to start, amazing choice and we started on the right foot!  i also ordered the french onion soup which is almost liverpool lil's status in my opinion, very tasty!  GF ordered the hamburger which looked amazing and I decided to try the monkfish, something new.  Glad I did as the fish was perfect and left very satisfied!  Service was excellent and I look forward to coming back

DwPe0S-70WgAf4n7n_lTMA.review_text: I guess I cannot take stars off for not getting a reservation.   My wife thinks they have the best French Onion soup in the world. I like the cheese platters. We all love everything else we consume and always try an absinthe for a treat.  My family likes to have dinner before local events and we have loved this tradition.  The waiters had always been great and pay attention to details.

lKYm3FSl_OrODg21SAL5mw.review_text: The food is spot on. The menu is very limited but the chefs can definitely cook.   These are the items we've tried: 1. Hamachi crudo appetizer, must have!  So fresh, delicate, and tasty.  2. Pate appetizer: portions of pate was decent, but we were expecting foie gras. The pate wasn't very spreadable but the kumquat complimented it very well. Delish! 3. Pork loin: tasty and cooked to perfection. The loin had a nice sear crust, came with a piece of pork belly, and the sauce was flavorful and not overpowering.  4. Arctic char: (my favorite) seasoned well, the fish was moist and delicate. The thin potato crust gave the dish an amazing texture. I usually avoid anything with olives, but the olive tapanade complimented the dish very well. Disliked the green beans; tasted old and fibrous.   5. Mushroom pot pie: truffle and mushrooms, a great combo. The pot pie looked huge, just wished there was more flaky pie crust and less gravy. Gravy could've used more thickening agent and mushrooms for the price of $27.  6. Trout: FYI trout was cooked whole and served with the head on. The trout was nice and fresh. 7. Passion fruit panna cotta:  yummy!!!  Love the tartness of the passion fruit and panna cotta was luscious and creamy.  8. German chocolate cake: looks divine, but too sweet and rich for my tastebuds.    Cons: 1. Parking 2. Service, Slow. Slightly over 3 hr dinner for party of 4 3. Bread was cold and dry; wished it was warm and toasty especially for the long wait.  4. Adding a few more dishes to the menu. Seems like the restaurant are promoting there cheese and wine more than their food.   Overall, it was a lovely experience. The ambiance and decor is nice and modern. The restaurant seated people of all age groups. Just pleasant...  My friends and I have been dining out alot for bday dinners and we all agree that reviews about this restaurant are absolutely true! So glad we came here for my bday!!!  A MUST!!!

x9Jj7iepr2n59Rs2zCxnXg.review_text: Absinthe is a versatile standby for me in Hayes Valley.  On one hand I have done fine dining here with multiple courses and formal service  for a special occasion. The staff are all very attentive and the dining room is very cozy and intimate offering plush booth seating. We put together a fantastic meal with oysters, soup and salad, berbere chickpeas, coq au vin, and the arctic char.  But more often, I visit absinthe to dine in the bar!  If you can find a seat at the beautiful bar you are in for a treat as you can watch all of the great bartenders work. You can also put your name down for one of the small tables in the front of the house. The atmosphere is very lively. Not the place for intimate conversation but good for a fun night out. There they also offer a more modestly priced bar menu where you can enjoy a regular meal and have access to the great cocktails that absinthe is known for.   Overall favorites for me in the bar are the french onion soup, seasonal grilled cheeses, the berbere chickpeas and the cheeseburger.

E0OgqykcWdz-VWye_GXAVQ.review_text: This is a little delayed..but I'm still writing it because I had such a fantastic birthday dinner here!  Made reservations for my birthday, right around the Christmas holiday, and was seated right away. They were pretty packed since it was the holidays but our service was excellent all night.  There is a really nice ambiance in the dining area, and it's super romantic if that's your thing..totally is for me :). I had already looked at the menu a million timesn before coming but it still took me a little while to decide. This is what me and my bf ended up getting:  Country Pate: The rustic pate, overall was a little bland for my taste, but  combined with the marmalade and mustard and bread it was delicious!  Big Woods Blue: I'm a cheese fanatic so I HAD to get a cheese on my  bday! Huge blue fan, so this was a must. It came with some yummy bread and we mixed this with the pate dish.  Chicken entree: just realized that they no longer are serving what I had..but hopefully their current chicken dish is similar! I think all that was different were the sides. I usually don't opt for chicken on special occasions because it can be a little boring, this chicken was AMAZING. Oh so moist and tender! The sweet onion jus paired with the fluffiest polenta I've ever had and yummy veggies were pure bliss.  Bf had the absinthe hamburger which he said was pretty good, but I was too in love with my chicken to try it.  We had the pumpkin custard with streusel and lime for dessert which was also amazing. They aren't serving it now, but I hope it comes back! They put lime on top, which I wasn't really a fan of tho...  2 of the best dinner hours ever spent :)

vYCreVQ8lnoGSkbShMWd_A.review_text: What a ripoff this restaurant is. Food is super expensive with very small portions. Quality is slightly above average. The harried wait staff have little time for anything but to take orders and rush around. Cocktails are ridiculously expensive and not very generous. The place is crowded with all types of mods and yuppies who wait like sheep on the sidewalk for a chance to get a seat at a table. The tables are jammed in together so there is no private conversations, and it is uncomfortable. Why bother? Go over to Sauce -much better food, service and ambience.

560RIjnlTEa8PMAlIQs2XQ.review_text: We didn't eat the food but we did steal a couple bar chairs to consume numerous beverages.  Sorry those without reservations hoping to squeeze in a meal at the bar. You should have planned ahead - your bad! :-p  One of the bartenders was extremely friendly, abundant with facts, provided some unique tastes, and had some crazy mad skills with making cocktails (some of fire!)  Great company, great drinks, and even some hope-he-doesn't-spill-that-and-burn-this-place-­down-with-us-in-it entertainment.  Great fun!

P_29I4dHqrAMDftOXObcaQ.review_text: Having read all the reviews and watching top chef in the past, I thought this place was really gonna be good; boy was I wrong.  Especially for the price, I was pretty disappointed.   Out of everything I tried, the only thing I really liked was the duck confit share plate.  Everything else I tried was ok but not great.  The frisée salad was probably the worst dish of the night.  The salad dressing was bland and on top of that, there wasn't even enough!  The dessert was a real afterthought too.  The blood orange creme brulee was "different" but not in a good way.  Rather than being in a ramekin, it was a ice scoop shaped creme brulee but didn't really have a caramel crust.  Service wise, Absinthe was a real downer as well.  Besides the Maitre D who was very nice, the rest of the wait staff was not very attentive.  The sommelier didn't bother to pour our wine and the waiter rarely even checked on our table.  Finally, this is not a criticism but be aware that this restaurant is very noisy so be prepared to talk very loud or else you won't be heard.

088SkMN7Hjn2vK2MEUfc3Q.review_text: Nice cocktail list ($9 a pop).   Cocktails vary from fruity-fruity to manly-manly, so if you're like me and have zero-understanding about how various liqueurs or non-alcoholic mixers influence the taste of a drink, do ask.  I ended up ordering a really taste gin and lime drink, but then totally puckered up on a really-sweet absinthe and blood orange juice fruit bomb.  Service is excellent.  I could see this place being really crowded during the evenings (I visited on a Saturday afternoon).

_-t8p3YAXLI9s3QHPlLHKQ.review_text: Very impressed.  Great service, food, and location.  Depending on when you go, taking a cab or using the valet might be the way to go.  We had a wonderful Valentine's day meal there.  We started with a couple of the "house cocktails", Perfect Pair and the Ctron Lemonade.    They clearly do not water down their drinks!  Plenty of alcohol in these babies.  I had to have a second one.  These were really good, a bit sweet.   I'm normally a whiskey guy so this was a nice surprise.  For the Appetizers, we had the soft garlic pretzels with the cheddar mornay.  Beleive the other posters, don't miss this!   We also had the crispy skin pork belly.  Wow, seriously good...  Crunchy skin and soft but meat pieces of pork belly with a very simple sauce.    Dinner, Coq Au Vin and Pan Roasted Monk Fish.  Both were tasty, not dry.  The chicken was moist, tender, and brined.  The fish was perfectly prepared.  Texture was firm, almost lobster like, but moist.  My wife loved it.  And we also had the side of mac and cheese, don't miss this either.  Dessert...  What a selection.  We had German Chocolate Cake and the Carmelized Squash Cake.  Both excellent, but i'd definitely go back for the Chocolate cake,  And neither was heavy.  Generous portions of food, well prepared, service outstanding, and nice ambiance.  We were in the back room and it was fairly quiet.  The main room with the bar can get pretty loud.  One of the more enjoyable two hour dinners we've had in a while.

gCezsygXkLpMcAtqoCTm-w.review_text: Went there for lunch before the SF Symphony. Food was very good and service was excellent. Dining room is quite crowded and rather noisy. Overall experience was very good. Several of us had the shrimp roll, others had a hot chicken breast. All were happy. Pots du creme dessert was really good as was the grapefruit sorbet with a tarragon syrup which was rather unique. Good place to go for lunch or dinner when going to something at Davies.   If you want outdoor seating, go next door to their cafe. There is a back patio there. Food at the cafe is some the same, but more sandwiches, salads, and casual fare. They also operate a wine bar up the street too.

z17ukzUllTDF_gPyMdff7g.review_text: UPDATE - Because, well...  why doesn't really matter - I gave Absinthe another try lately. Maybe caught them on a good day, but I don't think so.  Everything had improved and the wait staff was all new (at least since my last visit).  So I'm way-upping my review. From 2 to 4 stars. (and one whole star should be dedicated to the mixed cheese plate. 1 word - Yum-ee. I mostly had an issue with the off-hand staff - the current crop were luverly! Very attentive and made good suggestions and actually seem to like both their job and customers.  We had a great time.  OLD REVIEW:- Lunched there today.  Since when does "decaf" get pronounced with a high-pitched attitude?  Bad waiter makes for a bad tasted in one's mouth (no matter how tasty the pork sandwich!).  Anyway - my companion was unfazed by the rudeness - me, well me too except I am then delivered a burnt espresso.  Ok I know - only a froo froo finds espressos can even be burnt - but it can M'lords & Ladies, it can! (And talk about bad taste in yer mouth! Yeuch!)  Anyway back to Absence of manners!  I should have called him out but honestly - he looked like a wee bruiser!  Pshaw Absinthe, pshaw!

bzcUiumS7Wgpg0r7HQYBMA.review_text: What can I say that hasn't already been said?  The cocktails: the best. The "fame" was delish, we've been on a bellini kick and this was a delicious twist on a fav drink. We sampled a couple others (mostly gin) cocktails, and everything was fab. Just tell the bartender what you like / don't like, and he'll whip you up something unbelievable.   The dinner: already 2 cocktails in before dinner, the food was not likely to be anything other than supremely delicious. Though the veggie options were slim, the option for the night (fried squash) was heavenly. My fiance had the burger, of which he devoured every last morsel.   Too many drinks + such a satisfying meal meant no room for dessert. (though this just means we have a reason to return)  I'm hoping to try the brunch soon!  Make a reservation. Go here. You will NOT be disappointed.

Xf_cqmA3koffoNh4KGOFBg.review_text: Ideally I would give this place a 5 star for the food. But Im bumping it down to a 4 star because of the price. We had several entrees for brunch which were all excellent! The crab omelette and duck confit were exceptional. The french onion soup was very flavorful although a bit on the salty side.

nEl2xgE6EBrIU9axpW_gmA.review_text: just a taste.  before a musical evening at the SF Symphony Naomi G and stopped by for bite to eat and a couple of drinks. events can be a little tricky on a friday night. rushing from work to the show can get a little tight and so a quick stop at absinthe for just a taste is a great way to keep your tummies from grumbling during the performance.   we were quickly seated at an outside table, enjoying the remaining san francisco sunshine. we had handful of oysters to get the evening started. a little sweet and a wonderful little treat. we also shared a delightful beef tartare with a quail egg on top! raw and sinfully delicious. and of course we had to have a couple of signature absinthe cocktails :) bold flavors and packed a punch!   thanks a bunch absinthe. until next time.  cheers

QocP49nZ7Fo-4Rp_QxPuDQ.review_text: eclectic, fabulous, and gorgeous people at the bar and inventive absinthe cocktails. sitting in the window seat on a sparkly night with an expansive wine list, i noticed this on the menu, ""Alcohol is the anesthesia by which we endure the operation of life." - George Bernard Shaw...nope! you got it wrong George! It's the good company, Caramelized Apple Tart Tatin, and alcohol of which we must endure in life! : )

FLe7g1pF5rHiuVX6CmYqog.review_text: Great service, french onion soup is amazing. You got to try the hot pretzels! Superb wines, and the arctic char is very good!

RQdoj8zcU5T8VjYLw3XczA.review_text: With all the good reviews on Yelp, I've decided to give this place a try.  Came here on a Thursday night without a reservation.  Arrive at about 6:30pm and waited at the bar for about 15 mins before we got a table.  About an hour after we were seated, the place filled up.  While waiting at the bar, my friend and I ordered a side of French Fries to munch on and I also got a house lemonade.  I have to say that the house lemonade was quite different.  Never had lemonade with ginger ale.  Pretty good.  As for the French Fries....It's one of the best I've had.  I like shoestring fries!  These fries are fried to perfection.... not soggy with the right amount of crunch.  The smoky tomato ketchup that it came with was ohhhh soooo yummy.  Best ketchup ever!  Before we were able to finish our French Fries, the hostess came and told us that they has our table set.  yay.  After we go to our table, our server came to greet us and took our order.  I started out with the French Onion Soup Gratinee.  I must say that this is the second best French Onion Soup I've had (first place goes to a restaurant in Las Vegas).  This soup has the right amount of spice and the cheese was very tasty and toasted.  My friend had the Beef Tartare and it wasn't as tasty as he like, but overall it was still pretty yummy.  For our entrees, I ordered the Coq Au Vin.  The dish smelled really good when they set it in front of me.  The chicken in this dish was very tender and juicy.   The meat literately falls off the bone.  I would of loved this dish if the chef wasn't so salt happy.  After about 3 bites, the saltiness really kicks in.  This dish is way salty.  My friend ordered the Liberty Duck Confit.  The duck meat was very tender and juicy as well.  It was very tasty, but again the chef was salt happy.  This dish was also way salty.    We ended the meal with Apple Pie Panna Cotta.  This is a pretty delicious dessert and a good way to end our dinner.  To my surprise, the dessert wasn't that sweet, which is how my friend and I liked it.    This place would of gotten better ratings if the food wasn't way salty.  Best dish of the night was the French Fries...

TMr5z8JDuGPc0I-5WfpBMQ.review_text: French onion soup - they use duck broth!  It was surprisingly delicious!    Absinthe burger - soooo good, especially for brunch!   Duck confit - it was cooked to perfection, with the duck tender and tasty and the egg at the right juiciness.

qiPwKC0spUneRV74nxG9Xw.review_text: A little bit of Paris in San Francisco. The food, the ambiance - it's what one needs when they long for a little bit of home. When I think of going somewhere to breathe and enjoy the ambiance, food, and have attentive service - it's Absinthe!

s6xZpSHNteqqsLzuC3Jd8A.review_text: Quite possibly the best French onion soup I've ever had!!! The other dishes are passably good, but no way near as mind-blowing as the soup. The sweetness of the onion is really noticeable with the generous distribution of gruyere taking center stage - a spoonful of melted cheese with every sip, down to the very bottom of the bowl! Lactose intolerant people beware - the amount of cheese might give you major squirts.

AqwTAjoyG5HfhQi2-ab4cw.review_text: Wow, I was completely blown away by this place!! I would rank Absinthe as one of my top three food experiences in the city. The service wasn't great -- the hostess had a worst case of the bitch-face that I've witnessed in a while, our waitress was friendly but absentee and the busboys were ill trained, but the food, wow, the food was fantastic!!  To start things off, Absinthe lived up to its name with an expansive list of creative cocktails. I had the Galapagos, which consisted of kaffir-lime leaf muddled in pepper syrup, Barsol Pisco, lemon-lime and grapefruit juices. I was expecting a bit more lime leaf, which has an extremely distinctive flavor, but the drink was very yummy nevertheless. The boyfriend had a Manhattan and thoroughly enjoyed his beverage. The night was off to a racing start.  The restaurant has a seasonal menu with large plates, small shared plates and eclectic cheeses and raw bar. We decided to play it safe and share the beef tartare, the sous vide pork loin and the burger with gruyere.  The beef tartare, we both agreed, was bar none, the best that we've had the pleasure to enjoy. If you're a fan of steak tartare, this is a must order. Heck, even if you're a bit freaked out by the idea of raw beef topped off by a raw quail egg, this will make you into a believer. The preparation was simple -- violet mustard, green apple, red onion, cornichons and the quail egg yoke, and the flavors welded together in the most wondrous fashion. The beef, I'm guessing, did not go through a meat grinder and was painstakingly chopped by hand. The result was truly worth the effort because it simply melted in your mouth. It was super fresh and didn't have any raw taste to it at all. I can wax poetic about this dish for paragraphs and paragraphs, but you get the idea. Order it!!  Not long after we polished off the tartare and sat starry eyed, still trying to savor the last bits of flavor on our tongues, our entrees arrived on the table. I took stab at the burger while Orin dug into the pork. The burger was juicy and the beef tasted fresh and of obvious high quality. The accompaniments were simple, just lettuce, tomato and onion, between a brioche bun. I would say this was the second best burger that I've had, right behind Gamine. The fries were skinny and crispy. Burger and fries, you can't go wrong.  The pork loin was absolutely fabulous. Even though the meat was sous vide, the chef put it under the boiler to crisp up the skin because it was crunchy. Pork belly is basically a less threatening way to describe bacon, but the meat was slow cooked to perfection and did not taste fatty at all. The carrot puree and the black truffle jus accentuated the sweetness of the pork. All in all, I would say 9 out of 10.   In a quest to exercise caloric austerity, we skipped dessert, not that I'm complaining because we were stuffed to the brim. I saw the table next to us ordered a custardy-looking concoction and they thoroughly licked the jar so I'm assuming it was good. I was so happy to find a restaurant with such a high level of food across the board because our last few date night restaurants were a bit disappointing. Absinthe is well worth the price and a true SF gem. I will definitely be back!!

WoYoY9iKPBrHMnRpJ0IH_A.review_text: Came here for dinner on a Thursday and had no problem getting an OpenTable reservation for 4.  The vibe inside was very French and lively.  Drinks were original and tasty, fried chickpeas and mixed olives were both pretty good snacks.  What set this dining experience apart was the pork chop that the waiter wisely recommended when I was deciding between that and a fish.  The pork chop was probably the best I've ever had.  It had a steak-like appearance and texture, and was more tender than any I've had before.  Also, the chocolate pot de creme was absolutely delicious.  The staff also accommodated my vegan girlfriend with a special mixed plate creation.

KIUeZpqA5DpQZIhcBwQVvQ.review_text: Review for brunch only-  Came to Absinthe after escaping the crazy Pride parade for brunch with friends. After putting in my name with the hostess, I anticipated a 30 minute wait but was quickly surprised when 5 minutes passed and we got our table. The vibe is very french Bistro- small high top tables, loud bustling feel. Their breakfast cocktail list is as long as most places regular lists- I opted for the bloody mary but they had various mimosas that looked delicious too.  Was a bit surprised that the brunch menu was a little underwhelming- at least compared to their dinner options. Not much for someone watching their weight (I have to squeeze into a wedding dress in less than 45 days!!) so I went for standard breakfast fare: eggs & sausage. Had that not been an issue, I would have gone for the french toast.. yumm.  Service was okay, the front of the house was friendly and welcoming. Will be back for cocktails again soon.

-GgfD5R3_QSWgq7DSTdl9g.review_text: I've heard many great things about this place, but haven't had a chance to try it until this week. My boyfriend, parents and I all went to have dinner here on my boyfriend's birthday and it was great! The service was superb, the food was absolutely delicious, especially the sauces, and the atmosphere was perfect.   If you're there, you must try the Mediterranean sea bass. That was pure perfection. I'll definitely be coming here again :)

T81dEo4yH-O9JUQ71-Dgpw.review_text: I went for a late dinner after Cirque and thought it was OK...not amazing like I had hoped.  It bothered me that they sat us right next to another couple when there where plenty of other seating???  I had a reservation???? The oyster shooters where the best part of the meal.  My steak was good but the gratin was all leeks that where undercooked :(  Luckily the drinks and ambiance was good.

zLsX2UaxlanYWp_GLE_rRw.review_text: Bottom line: tasty food, good service, fun atmosphere. An altogether solid place for a meal in SF -- kind of like that go-to corner restaurant in that make believe, romanticized, "Midnight in Paris" world you imagine you'd love to live in.  Pluses: * The snacks. I can't even explain in words how freakishly amazing the Soft Garlic Pretzels are, and the Spicy Fried Chickpeas are addictive.  * The portion size is big. Not just big-for-a-French-restaurant big, but actually large enough to be filling for an average eater. I couldn't even finish my delish Market Vegetable Plate. * Their desserts are really spectacular, if you are into unusual flavors. The Chocolate Pine Nut Mousse with fig marmalade, bay leaf ice cream, and sherry vinegar caramel was unbelievable. Each flavor on its own was amazing, but combining the flavors in different ways for each bite made for a really memorable dessert experience. * Attentive, but unpretentious, service. Our server was friendly and down to earth, but still knowledgeable and professional in that way you expect from a higher end restaurant.  Minuses: * Busy, which makes it slightly cramped and a tad noisy. But, the atmosphere is really part of the fun. * Limited vegetarian options, which I've found it kind of normal for a French restaurant. But, what they do have is perfection.  Absinthe was my go-to restaurant, for both brunch and dinner, for a couple years, but I eventually got bored with the food. This was my first visit since Adam Keough took over as Executive Chef, and the menu once again pulled me in. I'll definitely be back more often, and I recommend it for anyone looking for great food, or just snacks and a cocktail.

SxMl4eI39C0PGaxBOM5X7A.review_text: Shocked I haven't written a review for Absinthe before. When I lived in SF from 2007-2008, I came many times with a friend who lived in Hayes Valley. Absinthe is the kind of place you go when you want to feel a little bit special; when you don't want to feel like an animal at the trough just filling up because you have to. It's an experience, and you'll pay for that experience, so come to terms with that up front.  Step off of the busy main street of Hayes and you're in a classic French bistro. It's a little darker, cooler (or warmer depending on the season), and calmer than where you just came from. The waitstaff is top notch. Starched aprons, genuine smiles, and real manners. The menu is fairly sparse -- which I love because I don't want to spend my whole night deciding -- and everything is fantastic. Simply decide you're in the mood for.   There are always specials but the regular items are great too. I've come for dinner and lunch and had the same experience of feeling taken care of and having a special meal. It's quality time with family and friends which is more important to me than anything. The huge wood bar with mirror and glasses behind is so tantalizing, you'll want a cocktail, and the desserts are incredible. So don't come when you're in a rush. Settle in and let yourself enjoy Absinthe.

aNHWwrDXZ_HqkkHXtomO8w.review_text: A cute French Patisserie   It was a weekend in San Francisco hit by the heatwave. The temperature in San Francisco hit the high seventies and the East bay hit triple digits.   My friends and I took part in the annual San Francisco Bay to Breakers event and wanted to enjoy a delicious brunch together and relax after the race. Our reservations were for 11: 00 am but we were stuck on Muni for over an hour trying to make it to the restaurant. We called the restaurant and asked for them to hold our reservation anticipating that we would only be 15-30 minutes late. Well, when we showed up over an hour late, our reservation was still held and we were seated right away. Kudos!!   We were all super hungry and all of the entrees being served to the tables next to us looked absolutely delicious. We started off with fries, mimosas, and orange juice. The fries were really thin, the size of onion strings and were served with three different sauces: hot mustard, vinegar, and a yummy ketchup mayonnaise type sauce. We scarfed those down super quick, but not so quick that we were not able to enjoy their delicate deliciousness. The orange juice was fresh squeezed (double kudos) and the mimosas were good.   Two of us ordered the wild mushroom omelet, which was served with fried potatoes. Both friends really liked the omelets and the potatoes and were hardly able to finish their meals as the portions were so big (triple kudos). I ordered the crab salad sandwich and my other friend ordered the banana-blueberry souffle pancakes.   My crab salad sandwich was none like I had before. The sandwich was served in a soft baguette with cheese, fresh tomatoes and a light citrus sauce, which is atypical of a crab sandwich, which is usually grilled. The sandwich was a nice surprise because it was so light and flavorful! Perfect for the hot weather. The crab meat was mixed with tiny cubes of different colored bell peppers, which made the sandwich festive. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal!   My friend loved her souffle pancakes too!!   We all gave Absinthe a grade A and would definitely come back again to eat.

AHI4Ew--zYhs0m8npEd65g.review_text: Lovely pre-show dinner and drinks at Absinthe. The food and drinks are phenomenal and would give a strong five-star for the culinary experience.  Dining experience was less strong on the busy Saturday evening, with an overworked bar and forgetful service.  A friend and I met before a 8pm SF Symphony performance, when I was finally able to snag an OpenTable reservation at 5:45pm. It's three blocks to the Symphony entrance and a quick walk over.  We were seated in the back room. I enjoyed a 21 Hayes while I waited for my friend -- refreshing gin, cucumber, Pims cocktail with cucumber slice and pickled onion garnish. Also got delicious warm olives.   I was happy to find someone else who liked super sweet wine, so we had a bottle of reasonably priced Gewurtraminer, yumm. We started with spicy fried chickpeas, which were delicious snacks. She had the mushroom and chestnut soup, very flavorful. The warm brussel sprouts with celery root puree and cippiolini onions were meaty and filling, with fried bacon pieces. I did not realize my friend was a vegatarian, though on the more liberal end of non-meat eaters... She wanted the cornbread stuffed chicken (without the chicken), and the pan-seared scallop with mushrooms (without the scallops), so we split two entrees, with the balance of the protein coming to me. Chicken was good, scallops were great.  I think I won in this deal...  We went with the chocolate pot de creme, super rich and delicious and totally worth it. Went well with the glass of Grand Marnier, which was discussed and never ordered, but came anyway (back to the forgetful service remark). Oh well.  All in $110 per person...

Ha4mOL_9JtmYgn7NvrAu6A.review_text: I've wanted to try this place for a while. It always looks so old world charming. And it really is. The food is fantastic & so is the service. I absolutely ADORED the fact that I was able to walk in with out a reservations and be seated in quick second. Although it was just me.  Anyway, I will most definitely be back but next time on a date or with the 'rents. $45 isn't much when you are kinda down & you feel the need to treat yourself but I only got a drink & an entree. Next time someone else can pay for my luxury.

HRUwQNMcYV2TDsI1sSYqug.review_text: Quality dining experience with friendly, attentive waiting staff.  My girlfriend and I ordered the french onion soup and beef tartare to start. While the soup was out-of-this-world rich and delectable, the beef tartare was a mildly underseasoned and underwhelming appetizer. I think the fruit may have detracted taste from the quality of the beef, but I digress as my culinary knowledge is mediocre at best.  Onwards! To the entrees where we had the Coq Au Vin and the Duck Breast. The Coq Au Vin, in all its buttery glory, had a sultry and velvety Burgundy sauce that seduced my taste buds on its way down. The chicken was tender and moist, the veggies were slightly undercooked, and the crostinis on the side were drenched in butter (pro for me, con for the gf). On the other side of the table, the Duck Breast came in two premium cuts cooked perfectly and with crisped skin wonderfully accented by the coffee crust. The bed of wild rice hash w/ almonds contrasted textures in a delightful way and the spinach was a convenient way to get more fiber into my day's intake. :)  With stomachs bursting yet satisfied and Lion King tickets burning a hole in my pocket, we happily made our way over the Orpheum to conclude date night.

5gZPpRGt_5qFrVc6fR2m5Q.review_text: Absinthe Brasserie is an upscale French restaurant that manages to not be pretentious, deserves major points in my books. A group of friends and I came here for a Sunday brunch and had a great experience.  I found the brunch menu to be rather limited (only 3 egg dishes?) but every dish we ordered was delicious. The Grilled Cheese (I added Bacon) was one of the best I've had before. The Open-Face Leg of Lamb Sandwich was a very creative twist on your average Eggs Benedict. The Pork Enchilada was rather disappointing, which I probably should have expected ordering Mexican food at a French restaurant.   The service was just alright for me, our waitress was not very friendly

CPtzKBAsttRv1wRok-goIw.review_text: I've gone to Absinthe for brunch, and also for drinks and appetizers. AMAZING.   1) Great atmosphere, friendly staff and bartenders. Beautifully chic. Just a great energy in there :)  2) Every single bite was delicious. Cheese selections with pairings on the cheese plate were especially amazing (Fromage de meaux was my favorite, while the Humboldt Fog was my fiance's favorite) . Also, I loved my drink, which was a refreshing concoction containing citrusy-sweet Buddha's hand in it.  3) Always busy, but sitting at the bar was just as nice as sitting at a table.

1y2dLZg2l3dtLc1nzU2qzg.review_text: This is a review for the private room two doors down from Absinthe's main Brasserie and Bar space, where my cousin held her wedding reception this past weekend. The intimate space was perfect for the gathering of family and friends, with beautiful and classy decor, great food, and excellent service.  The staff brought out an endless supply of delicious Oysters, Crab Cakes, and bite-size Croque Monsieur sandwiches. The bartender also mixed some nice cocktails... which were even nicer in the wedding reception setting, when you didn't have to pay whatever this place normally charges.  Our three course dinner was great as well... I went with the Root Vegetable Soup, Atlantic Char, and Chocolate Pot. All delicious and it tasted great when washed down by the Wine we had brought in for the reception, something that the restaurant kindly accommodated us for. Overall, a very nice experience at a beautiful private room nestled down the street from the popular main bar. I would come back to eat and drink in the main dining room for sure!

3b3eaCa7QpU41DJMZN-vug.review_text: The bar at Absinthe is one of my favorites. Primarily for the great location, but also for the solid service and comfortable atmosphere. I keep coming back to this place as a comfortable respite from wandering and window-shopping.  The bar team are excellent hosts, and they are quick to bring patrons into conversation and leave you alone if you're occupied. I'll be back soon!

n6dHhC0xSC9T-l7toDx_iA.review_text: I've been going to Absinthe sine it opened in Jan 1998. The vibe, drinks, food and service are excellent.    Absinthe is a very special place for us.  I had my second dinner date with my now husband there. Having our wedding reception in their private dining room was a must for us. The food and service couldn't have been better.

E0hnzH2Kx50pYjIOhMxfuA.review_text: 7x7 100 Best Things To Eat in SF Before You Die 2013  #36 Soft Garlic Pretzels at Absinthes Bar  Oh Hey, would you look at that, its my 600th Review!!! =)   After Book of Mormon, we decided to head over to Absinthe for a night cap. I glanced over the menu and decided to get some food afterall.  We got the ABSINTHE HAMBURGER: Storm Hill Angus beef, aïoli, baby lettuces, red onion, house-made pickles, french fries and SOFT GARLIC PRETZELS: Vermont cheddar mornay  Burger-bun was over charred, meat was tender but under seasoned, overall a modest burger but nothing to rave about  Pretzels-the best I have ever had! Super soft yet yield a great bite, well seasoned and that sauce is on crack!   For drinks, we ordered a variety to share which included Ginger Rogers, Galapagos, Citron Lemonade, Havana and 21 Hayes)  Ginger Rogers was by far my favorite. The rest were strong and unique but I didn't understand what all the fuss was about their drinks. The balance was lacking and flavors weren't appealing.   Service was good and I liked the ambiance of the place  Overall Thoughts  A+ Pretzels, drinks I'm still not sure what all the fuss is about

PWMRXCXdOG6B_FXe-Lj-JA.review_text: Absinthe originated in Switzerland. However, it is better known for its popularity as an alcoholic drink in late 19th- and early 20th-century France, particularly among Parisian artists and writers. Due in part to its association with bohemian culture, absinthe was opposed by social conservatives and prohibitionists. Charles Baudelaire, Paul Verlaine, Arthur Rimbaud, Vincent van Gogh, Oscar Wilde, and Aleister Crowley were all notorious "bad men" of that day who were (or were thought to be) devotees of the Green Fairy. Absinthe was portrayed as a dangerously addictive, psychoactive drug. The chemical thujone, present in small quantities, was blamed for its alleged harmful effects. By 1915 absinthe had been banned in most European nations and the United States. Although absinthe was vilified,[2] no evidence has shown it to be any more dangerous than ordinary liquor. Its psychoactive properties, apart from those of ethanol, have been much exaggerated. A revival of absinthe began in the 1990s, when countries in the European Union began to reauthorize its manufacture and sale. As of February 2008, nearly 200 brands of absinthe were being produced in a dozen countries, most notably France, Switzerland, Spain, and the Czech Republic.[3] (experpt from en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ab…) Absinthe the restaurant/bar was a nice place to be. Hip, French culture posters adorn the the dimly lit, inviting interior. Having never had Absinthe, if there ever was an opportunity, now was the time. It turned into quite a production, three glass containers, a straddled, perforated cheese wedge thing across the main glass, a sugar cube hovering above that mysterious green liquid. Our friendly server then explained how you are supposed to consume it, drizzling the water across the sugar till it dissolves. The drink itself was strong, but you can dilute to taste, be careful tho, too much and it turns to a white, ugly mess (as opposed to a sexy green) The crowd was cool, younger people and some older with money. It was not too pretentious. Overall a good place if you happen to be in that area.

TpZN51jtAZTu7BjYxTfpjA.review_text: This is easily one of my favorite restaurants ever. The boyfriend and I have walked by it several times due to its proximity to Smuggler's Cove. Everything about Absinthe is beautiful; the adorable sidewalk tables, the dark velvet interior and low lighting. We decided to make reservations for our two year anniversary. When we arrived there was the perfect little corner booth all ready for us. The service was some of the best we've ever had. The timing was impeccable.   We got the garlic soft pretzels, coq au vin, duck breast, baked mac & cheese, and charred cauliflower. Everything was delicious. My absolute favorite though was the charred cauliflower! The drinks were also very good. It was a lot of fun to try drinks with Absinthe in them. The chocolate pot de creme was the perfect finish to an amazing dinner. It was creamy and sweet without being too filling.

xQwp_9V1O71m-ynSgig0nA.review_text: I'm dying to know why people go GAGA over this place. Granted I've only been here once, but I really wasn't that impressed.   Came here with my girlfriends on at Saturday night. Got there around 11pm and was told the wait for a table would be 45mins. That was fine because we figured we could hang out by the bar. Note: Seating for those waiting is NONEXISTENT or if there was any, awkward.   The bartender was difficult to flag down and when did we ordered two drinks: The Galapagos (supposed to be one of their famous cocktails--something top 100 must eats in SF) and their perfect pear. *phew* Their drinks were STIFF. I think one of those could knock a light weight out with one sip. Later on, I ordered a Blood and Sand which was alcohol-taste free, but boy did I feel the pangs of its wrath the next morning. Not cool.   When we were seated, my friends tried the famous $12 dollar hot dog and were extremely disappointed. According to them, it "bland". I stuck with their shoe string fries and didn't think they were bad, but they  definitely aren't as good as Wine Merchant's white truffle parmeasan fries.    I left spending quite a bit and wondering if maybe we should have stayed at Hotel Biron instead; at least they have decent snacks.

0gGcIkHOTDMl_6p5RGnuFw.review_text: We stopped in after taking a stroll through the neighborhood on a shockingly sunny Saturday in early March.   We were seated at a table in the bar area right away. The whole reason of stopping in was so I could experience raw oysters for the very first time and have a nice drink on a beautiful day, Absinthe did not disappoint..    The service was polite, attentive and kind when we asked what type of oysters each one was about 5 times because we couldn't remember.   The Oysters were LOVELY. I can't believe I waited 25 years before having one of these! I loved them, the fresh raw taste of salt and seafood with a bit of lemon so yummy.  My drink was Rise and Shine, it tasted wonderfully refreshing with hints of blood orange and licorice.   I would like to return for a bull meal here someday to get the full experience.   Minus one star for the small bathroom with a weirdly swinging door that nearly smacked me in the face when someone opened it and I was reaching for the handle.

6kWAL8wWRAe17ARc78Ay9w.review_text: My wife ate here four years ago. Her review can be best summarized thusly: "Sucked."  So I never really made the effort to try this place. However, like many in SF, I read Bauer pretty religiously, and he mentioned not too long ago that there had been a chef change, and this change was definitely for the better. So when one of my best buds from SoCal came up to visit, I decided to give this place a shot. My wife demurred, saying she never wished to eat here again - that's how bad of an impression it left on her.  My experience here was the total opposite of hers. It is, likely, a result of the chef change, but the food was fresh and delicious here.  I love beef tartare with all of my heart, and anytime I see it on a menu I have to try it, so we went with that, along with the hamachi crudo, as our appetizers. The crudo was very good, especially with the blood orange on it. I always appreciate citrus, and the flavors blended perfectly here. The tartare was good, but perhaps not as good as I wanted it to be.  For mains, my bud ordered the lamb T-bone, which disappeared not long after the waiter put it down. I did manage to get a taste of it before it was devoured by my friend, and it was perfectly done. My own main was  the skirt steak, one of my favorite cuts, and the skirt here didn't disappoint.   For drinks, my friend got an overpriced and underwhelming glass of absinthe, but the sazerac he ordered later more than made up for that. I also had that sazerac, as well as a mujer verde. Both were pretty awesome, to me.  The one major ding, other than the tartare, was the service. It wasn't bad per se, but the waiter was just kind of a douche. He was kind of inattentive, and also seemed personally hurt that we didn't order any of the specials that he theatrically described to us.  I did try to convince my wife to give it another chance, but she's since become a vegetarian...so I doubt she'd like it.

igFzjYqET1rGWbErZy52SQ.review_text: the duck confit ragu on the brunch menu was phenomenal!!!!!

dSSG5MPKcG5cSpMpyu6r3A.review_text: Came here for a drink with a girlfriend after watching The Little Mermaid ballet at the War Memorial (it was beautiful by the way).  Great spot to go if you're going to the ballet especially since they kick you out 2 minutes after the ballet ends and usually you're still craving a drink.  Nice spot, super snooty looking.  We were dressed nice since we dressed up for the ballet so we fit right in.  Drinks were good... everything you could expect.  So no complaints from me!

D5Ogagbr9-m5wyZlqudALg.review_text: My wife and I have been to Absinthe many times over the years, usually before or after a San Francisco Symphony concert. It's always been really good, although hard to get a table on an event night. We were lucky last Saturday night when a 6:15 slot freed up on OpenTable in late afternoon and I grabbed it. There seems to be a lot of disagreement about whether the place is on the rise or the decline, but this was the best meal we've ever had there.  I had the shellfish stew and it was terrific - a mix of mussels and clams plus a jumbo prawn in a rich broth with red bell peppers. My wife had the butternut squash soup, and while the taste I had seemed a bit sweet she said that the swirled-in mint cream offset that sweetness nicely. She almost always orders coq au vin there, and she said that it was as good as ever and maybe better. I tried a small piece and it may have been the most tender chicken I've ever had.  I ordered the Liberty Farms duck, and it turned out to be delicious.
