The coffee crust worked well, the huckleberry sauce had just the right touch of sweetness, and the "wild rice hash" was the perfect complement. Of top of that, the two slices of duck were thick; each one could have easily been cut in half and been a full portion. I ended up taking half of my entree home to enjoy the next day. We were too full and too rushed for dessert, but the coffee and espresso were outstanding.  Absinthe appears to have some sort of team service set up; most of the dishes were delivered by other servers but then the server who took our order swung by quickly to make sure that all was OK. I still had my stew dish at my place when one of the servers headed toward us with our entrees; she immediately backed off and asked another server to clear our table. Many restaurants would dump the entrees on the table and then worry about making room.  Finally, as one would expect for a restaurant in the Civic Center area, after we let our server know that we had an 8pm Symphony concert she ensured that we made it with some time to spare. Yes, the place is crowded and noisy on an event night, but excellent food and service are more important to me. I'm eager to go back and try more of the menu, but on the basis of this fine dinner and with a lot of fond memories of past meals, five stars is entirely appropriate.

GuNBz3pAXMxfB2SBd5qeuQ.review_text: OMG!! OMG OMG OMG!!! This place is AMAZZZZZING. The cocktails are to die for. I dream about filling a small swimming pool with an amazing cocktail from this place including floaties made of the home made soaked cherry's. I can dive in swim around and then be rescued by the extremely attentive sommelier who will revive me with perfectly cooked scallops and the most scrumptious ribiye I have ever let melt in my mouth.   Sigh...   Oh I will be back.. and when I am there... It will be love...

3VR5vMclctbKWfIho5xqKg.review_text: Came here for a date night on Friday evening.  Had a reservation and we were seated promptly. The service was great - the wait staff was prompt and all of our food arrived in a timely manner. The waitress was happy to let us sit and finish our bottle of wine long after we had finished eating.   The food: the mixed greens salad was fresh and lovely, but I found the gorgonzola mousse to be just a tad overwhelming. The french onion soup was great. My partner got the duck breast, which was good, but I remember it being fantastic the last time I had it, about a year ago. And I had the coq-au-vin, which was delicious, but heavy (to be expected!).   Both of us were too full for dessert.  Overall - love the ambiance and the service and the food is really quite good, just not the best thing I've ever eaten.

ceowV9LSKZEb397yVDqdgA.review_text: My friend and I were celebrating our 10-year anniversary of arriving in Paris for our semester abroad, so of course we wanted to go French. I'm slowly making my way across the French restaurants in the City and Absinthe has been on this list for a while.   It was a Tuesday night, so we had no problem getting a table at 6pm, although there were a lot of people in there already as I think they do a good business with the pre-theater crowd. My friend got stuck in traffic coming up from the south bay, so i was seated for maybe 30 or 40 minutes at the table before she arrived, but service was great from the start. They have a great drink selection, I really enjoyed mine that was made with muddled cucumber, but interestingly, there was no visual sign of cucumber in it.  I started with the pretzels, which are really good. I found the sauce a bit thin, but it was still delicious. The menu is interesting and while normally i wouldn't have any trouble finding any entree to order at a French place, I felt that a lot of what they had included accompaniments that weren't to my preference. So for example, I love duck confit, but this was served over pasta with raisins and mushrooms. So I ended up ordering the corn soup and the mussels/clams appetizer. I really liked both of them, but the mussels dish was definitely on the salty side, or it may have been the crostinis that came with it that left me drinking 5 glasses of water. My friend got the pork tenderloin which I tasted and was really good - not the least bit dry, much more the texture of a steak. The bread they served was good and no desserts jumped out at us. Service was good all along, until the end. it seemed like we were done for a while before our waiter came back to check on us/bring the check.  Overall, I liked the food, but wish they had more traditionally-prepared dishes and definitely a chocolate souffle or something similar for dessert!

29oUfyEL1by67UR-0Si2zg.review_text: Brunch time is the best!  Their drinks are fabulous, especially if you go with the Bloody Mary's.  I had the omlette with crab which was quite good but my husband's croque-monsieur was out of this world.  I can't wait to go back and get it!  Enjoy!  PS Their house coffee is quite good too!

T51Wxd2LnUcUNkYCOGYlZw.review_text: "Absinthe is the aphrodisiac of the self. The green fairy who lives in the absinthe wants your soul. But you are safe with me."-- Dracula  I couldn't agree more, old bat, because Absinthe was absolutely, positively scrumptious. My parents always take me to an expensive restaurant of my choice for Christmas, so, being that I'm fairly poor, I make my choice very. very. carefully.  I had always wanted to go to Absinthe.  The outside metal scrolling reminded me of Paris, and even though I got horrific food poisoning from fish in Paris and almost died and turned various shades of green, WELL, that is another story.  ANYWAY, my GOOD memories of Paris inspired me to choose Absinthe for this Christmas meal, and it was a very. very. wise choice.  My mother, being a food voyeur like myself, wanted to eat a little of everything.  So we ordered several plates. Eleven, in fact.  Each one was delicious and perfectly spiced-- the french onion soup was the best I've ever had.  The bistro fries were delicious.  They could've been a little bit more browned, but tasty nonetheless.  The scallops were like hits of acid (good hits of acid) and the oysters were like ecstasy (and we all know there is nothing wrong with that.)  The piece de resistance was meeting Jamie Lauren, executive chef and Top-Chef contestant.  I got a picture with her, and even though she looks like my 12 year old child in the pic, I couldn't have been more excited.  I tried to bribe her with a beer to tell me the outcome of the show, but it was no-go.  Oh well, I couldn't expect an orgasm after a meal that good.  Wouldn't that be illegal?

IkFjRnnI5trMcwHHl_1Vrg.review_text: Recently had a great experience at Absinthe late on a busy Friday night.  The host was super friendly, as was our waiter. Despite how busy it was, they were very courteous and remembered us when we came back after the 30 minute wait for our table.   We had some late night bites-- and split a salad, which the waiter split into 2 plate AND added an extra fried egg on the second salad - which was a very cool gesture.  While the service was a bit slow, the food was spot-on as were the cocktails.  Definitely like this place for a late night meal/cocktails or brunch.

tjWby32pDVw3tIVA35DxvQ.review_text: SO AMAZING... went tonight foir my birthday, and they accommodated me, and my party of 7 in a cinch!  i had the mary's chicken which was great, but my boyfriend had the pork confit, and it was AMAZING! Not to mention, that my mojito was PERFECT !!!  I LOVE this place SUPER BUNCHES! if you find yourself in hayes valley STOP IN! you wont regret it!

kpqcDNx9EM2tGkXpFn5F_A.review_text: Went to Absinthe on a Sunday morning for Brunch. When we walked in there was at least a 45 minute to one hour wait and we got there soon after it opened for the day. I had heard so much about it that I was willing to wait. Once we came back 45 minutes later, our table was still not ready but luckily 2 seats opened up at the Bar. I love eating at the Bar anyways.   We started off with these amazing deviled eggs that were made with smoked fish...with a tiny dollop of caviar....OMG were they good.   My brother had this amazing open faced breakfast sandwich with a fried duck egg, andouille sausage, raclette (cheese) on top of brioche and I had the Duck Hash with 2 Poached Eggs with a side of ever so fresh arugula.   I have to say this was one of the better brunch's I've ever had, even better than some of the places I have been in Beantown.

6ZkjqYY0TN2x7GRNig5q_Q.review_text: Dropped in here with a friend after a concert at the nearby Davies Symphony Hall; Absinthe has a nice decor as well as a very extensive alcohol menu (nearly 75 pages!) Since I had eaten dinner already, I ended up ordering the spicy fried garbanzo beans ($4); the portion size was pretty small, and they were a little bit overly salty, but they were crispy and still flavorful. I also opted for sparkling apple cider, which was crisp and refreshing. For dessert, my friend and I split an order of their cheesecake - this was perhaps one of the best cheesecakes I've ever had. Unlike the typical bakery or grocery store cheesecake that's exploding with sugar, this cheesecake had much more of a cheese feel to it (I think it was goat's cheese?), and was topped with blueberries and crumbles. It was also a little pricey ($10 for a small piece) but was worth it!  Giving Absinthe four stars here for the wonderful dessert, drink, and decor, but can't really comment on the food outside my order of the fried garbanzo beans.

IaS_4eBj8r1TXDLXeISaHQ.review_text: This is a long overdue review. Friends and I went to Absinthe last summer. Our group of six was comprised of Jamie Lauren Top Chef fans and general absinthe/cocktail fans. We were, in short, impressed. Nothing we drank wasn't the utmost in deliciousness, and nothing we ate wasn't equally tasty.  Although I saved our receipt by which to remember the occasion, I don't remember remember exactly what my companions had. As for me, I had the Ginger Rogers cocktail, which was cool, refreshing and gin-riffic. Along with that, I had some delicious french onion soup gratinee and a mushroom risotto (no longer on the menu). All delicious. All the time.  Not to mention, the service was great. Our waiter was very classy and fleet of foot. He was very knowledgeable about the cheese selections and had some excellent recommendations for the cheese plate we ordered as an appetizer.

xPUjjq1rLRyCkEs8AXmRww.review_text: This place is AWESOME! I saw the pictures and read the menu and was sold that this place should be a good dinner but I was surprised how amazing the food was going to be. It looks like an old bistro but it works well with the food. It was definitely top 5 best places I have eaten in San Francisco. The food was also complemented well with the wine selection.  Food: Steak Tartare- fresh and tasty very very good Country Pate- thick slice of pate with great flavor Pork asobuco- so good it falls off the bone Steak with mash potatoes- cooked to perfection and the potatoes are green, do not worry it is really good  Great place to try and I will be sure to come back again!

DX5hTHjdZmHnUV-7oGnI6g.review_text: jesus h. christ- we hadn't been here in a month of sundays but finally made it back for my husband's 30th birthday.  the november menu is insane!  i seriously am choked up thinking about how delicious and romantic our meal was here.  every little detail is perfect, the server was perfect, the fresh crab and oyster starters were perfect, the scallops- OMG...  the four french 75's i drank- PERFECT.  believe the hype!  or maybe don't because it's already hard enough to get a table...

Cj6fZQf0UzdXDMtGrx6Kbw.review_text: If I could sum up this review in one sentence: Absinthe is an upscale Cheesecake Factory. Our waitress wasn't exceptionally friendly or helpful and the food was good but it wasn't worth the 150 bill.   I started with the French Onion Soup Gratinee which was really onions in a salty broth. For my entree I ordered the 7 oz Grilled Black Angus Bistro Filet with sour cream & leek whipped potatoes. The whipped potatoes were above par by a hair but the beef filet was cooked to perfection and was delicious but it wasn't enough to make me want to go back.

9mE3M39UJ-qB3bcTT19O3A.review_text: We had a surprisingly wonderful early dinner on Saturday night before going to the Ballet. It's a popular choice with theatre go-ers so book early if you want a nice experience before you head to the Opera House or Music Hall.  But they pace your dinner well so that you finish in good time. The menu is somewhat limited, but we had no trouble finding delicious things to order. I can highly recommend the steak and the lamb shank. Both were perfectly seasoned and cooked. H enjoyed the oysters and I the ravioli.  The drinks were also good and the only disappointment was the dessert menu, as we couldn't find anything appealing on it! The restaurant got a little noisy as the night progressed but we were fortunate to have a corner table, and service was excellent.

zaC3L_qy28bMLIvnoMng8Q.review_text: Let me start by saying that the hostess was amazingly sweet both on the phone and in person. She started the experience off on the right foot. The bartender was pretty impressive with his ability to handle the sheer volume of complicated drinks and do so without ruffling even slightly at the sometimes bullish crowd.   Our server seemed a little irritated that we had drinks when we came to the table and the service was a little slow on her end, but not so much that it ruined the experience. We felt a little pressured by her to order drinks from her as well, and we weren't interested.    The food impressed me; I might go so far as to say that the Absinthe burger (with smoked gouda and caramelized onions) might very well be the best burger I've ever had. We also had the bistro filet which couldn't compare to the burger (it needed more flavor), but it wasn't bad; the roasted garlic-whipped potatoes and asparagus that it came with were delicious.   I'll put this on the list of places I look forward to returning to on my next trip to San Francisco.

sILEA5_pp6-wrV2NOhcx0Q.review_text: We were seated quickly based on our open table reservation (took about 5 minutes). Their drinks were absolutely delicious as we tried their tequila, old fashioned, and absinthe. The service was professional and courteous. They also alerted us that we were reaching a drink maximum, so they professionally cut off our alcohol content early on.  As for the food, I was impressed. I've been there for brunch and loved it. For dinner, I ordered the monk fish and also chicken. Both were amazing - not much to go wrong with.   Highly recommended venue for a date or for a business meeting/dinner.

KQFW7_BswaaUPLGjlePfJg.review_text: Bar and restaurant are both worthy of five stars!   My husband and I started out with martini's at the bar.  Martinis were stirred to perfection.    We were then seated at a great spot near the front window.   Upon being seated, we ordered the soft garlic pretzels.  They were out of this world!  For entrees, I had the heirloom squash - delicious!  Husband ordered the potato crusted artic char.  He was quite pleased.  Service was outstanding, food and drink were equally good.  Will definitely return!

B-nMZAVydQK45uPCFKS-4w.review_text: Their maitre'd rocks there.  She always manages to make you feel welcome and squeezes us in every time when we showed up after ballet on a busy night.  Super friendly and helpful staff.  Food and cocktails never disappoint!

_1WjoDk8EF-igBL36BVV_A.review_text: So, I've been a fan of Absinthe since the season of Top Chef where Jamie Lauren was competing.  Of course, when she competed (poorly) in the All Star show, and then defected to Los Angeles, I became an Un-Fan of Jamie.  Traitor!!!  /deepbreath  So, given that I heard there was a new chef, Absinthe has been on my list to re-try.  The meal was just as good, if not better, than before.  The mixed greens salad was fantastic - it not only had nice local greens balanced with a tasty vinagrette dressing, but each bite seemed to be a treasure hunt of other things I like too - a few candied walnuts, a few grapes, a few croutons.    Then came the lamb shank on a bed of polenta.  I usually hate polenta that is anything softer than the consistency of a french fry, but this was amazing - particularly with the lamb shank that fell off the bone.  One other thing to note ... while there's a new chef in town - they kept all of the strengths of the previous menu.  The lamb shank also existed in some form on the previous menu, and some of the fantastic cocktails were there too.  Also of note is that it is so hard to find an interesting desert in SF.  Every French restuarant has a pot de creme, a creme brulee, etc.  They actually had two desserts that were interesting ... the one I had was a butternut squash cake which was absolutely amazing, and different.  The madiera pairing with this was perfect ....

37cpUoM8hlkSQfReIEBd-Q.review_text: This is a very nice place that I could imagine would be a hip spot to take a date.  Instead, I went with my wife after we were stuffed beyond belief from dinner and were just trying to kill time before a movie at the nearby AMC Van Ness. So what else is there to do but eat?  I read about the soft garlic pretzels on 7x7, so i figured we should stop by here to try them.  So as not to look poor/weird, I decided we should order something more than just the pretzels, so we also got the spicy fried chick peas.  The chick peas were very tasty, though once they cool off they get a little too chewy and not very pleasant to eat (I guess that is true with most fried food, but the difference here is probably that these aren't tasty enough like most fried foods that make you want to wolf them down immediately before they get a chance to cool off).  The soft garlic pretzels were indeed worth the walk from the theater and were very delicious. They were nice and hot, slightly crispy on the outside and very soft and chewy throughout. They came with some kind of cheesy dipping sauce that was also addictive and delicious. To give you an idea of how good they are, whenever there is an odd number of items in a dish, I always make polite to pretend to offer the extra one to my wife and she always concedes it to me, which is one of the things I love most about her. However, when I pretended to offer her the 5 and last pretzel here, she gladly accepted the offer.  Service was very nice and polite too, which was surprising since all we ordered was two snacks and a soda.  My only beef is that it was a little pricey for 5 little bites of pretzels. Otherwise, it was a very nice place that I wouldn't mind coming back for to try their main menu of food.

MHg1VFgztmsa517w28ic1g.review_text: I went here with my husband and another couple on a Sunday afternoon to have drinks and share some small plates.  We had to wait about 15-20 minutes for a table because it was super busy. That's ok because we waited at the bar, and had some cocktails, I had a Bloody Mary which was delicious.  When we were seated our waiter quickly brought water and took our order immediately.  We first ordered 15 oysters.... Which were so amazing that we ordered another 15!!! The soft garlic pretzels w/ the dipping cheddar sauce was amazing that we too ordered another one. I don't think I've ever had a better pretzel. The French fries with Parmesan aioli was crispy, shoestring fries which are my favorite. The baked Mac and cheese was creamy yet crispy on the top. The pork meatballs were tiny and a bit spicy but I can handle the heat. We also had a cheese plate with the frommage, cheddar, and blythindale... I'm a fan of soft cheese because I like to spread it on my bread... Seriously once you take a bite, your eyes will roll back into your head. To end the meal, we had coffee and desserts. Us four shared the passion fruit mango mousse w/ carrot cake and the deconstructed Napoleon... Amazing.. Our waiters regularly filled our cups w/ water every time it was low.. I never had an empty glass. Great service, amazing food, a bit pricey but well worth it.

zSLVUcFSpMYFWT7FxT1J6g.review_text: Uninspired. Bromidic. Unattractive.   I'd like to blame my sub-par experience on Dine About Town, but there's simply no excuse for a bland Caesar salad, an over-greased Croque Monsieur, and an unmemorable dessert  :(  My sandwich reminded me of something I once had at Panera Breads - a near death experience.  It also had subtle tones of sandwich meat, cheap butter, and stale bread.  The Caesar salad is romaine leaves (uncut).  I'm assuming there was dressing on it, but I can't really recall.  My favorite part was when I was the first to walk in and waited for a long enough time to wonder if I should leave, when my server greeted me with a, "Hi"....and nothing more.  I sat there wondering if I should feature him or relish in the awkward moment.    Actually, on second thought, my real favorite part of Absinthe was probably leaving tipsy after 3 glasses of wine at 12PM - and it's probably a good thing, or Absinthe may have warranted one less star.

2hJO_PsqV667qzO8rcdpbg.review_text: really great high quality french food. we started with the oysters which were insanely fresh and the french onion soup which was absolutely delicious.   for the entree i got the lamb shank which was extremely tender and wasn't gamey but i wasn't too crazy about the flavor of it. the polenta was really good but super heavy and creamy  the wagyu steak is braised and was also super tender and i liked the flavor of this a lot better. it came with some really freakin bomb mashed potatoes  for dessert we got the corn genoise pastry with buttermilk ice cream. so on point and soo unique and not too sweet and the texture of the pastry was chewy and so amazing. the service was also really good

dMm2Py7a-bmV2Q0Qn_Bfug.review_text: Very pleasant restaurant, which is convenient to the SF Jazz Center, the Symphony, etc. The food was good, but not stellar (if you want something light, the cheese plates and nectarine salad are good bets). Attentive service, and fairly priced for this kind of restaurant.

9la4VjTaSPRvj81dR3Gd3Q.review_text: Their bar and bartenders are enough reason to go.  Ridiculously knowledgeable on all things alcohol.  The last time I was there I not only had some great absinthe I got a fascinating and enjoyable education as well.  Didn't get the bartender's name but this guy made what was already a good night, a great night.  Their cocktails are wonderfully imaginative and worth having even when I find them not suited to my particular taste.  The bar menu is not to be missed.  And if you're a fan of pumpkin soup get there now while it is still on the menu; it is the best I've had.     The  Parisian art nouveau decor is both sexy and comfortable with lush fabrics, deep jewel tones and lightening that heightens the appeal of the good looking colorful crowd.  The corner location with windows on all sides makes it one of those places where you can while away a day or night completely losing track of time.

WFhLq5D_X3voxU0aLFrj7Q.review_text: I really don't think you can go wrong here.  I'd recommend getting the Coq au Vin, and for sure the French Onion Soup.

oo1J2dmkuBPjzjD2kZ2qTw.review_text: Came here after my hubby & I saw Wicked at the Orpheum...it's great b/c it's in walking distance!  They only serve bar food after 11pm, so luckily we came in right at 11and they were great enough to open up the full menu to us.  Thank you, hostess, who seated us *smile*  We started with the spicy fried chickpeas...these were suprisingly YUMMY!  We also had the french fries b/c we saw another table have them and we couldn't resist.  The presentation is awesome and they're so thin, I loved them!  It kinda reminded me of eating those Pik-nik shoestring fried potatoes from when I was a child.  We also had to get the french onion soup gratinee, that was so flavorful and full of cheese.    We couldn't decide on which confit to choose so we ordered both, the duck and pork.  The pork confit came with Anson Mills cheese grits, house made bacon, collard greens, pork jus and the softest slow cooked pork ever.  The duck confit has ras el hanout, roasted grapes, pickled onions, ancho cress, pistachio butter and it all combined so well!    Our server was sooo great, too!  He gave us so much attention and was very knowledgeable of the menu.  Overall, we were so impressed with the food, server, and venue.  We only had one cocktail so we'll definitely have to come back to try more of their really cool concoctions...and of course, choose other items from the menu.

awmRirDC7WWig6R07XZ_oA.review_text: The best burger in SF, better than NOPA's.   (I have not had the spruce burger yet though.)  The meat is so flavorful and non-oily.   The toppings are kind of sorry though so don't order a lot at $1.5 each.

WrHCEpls59Uu4XNXNaK7fw.review_text: Two words: Spanish Coffee. I had this several weeks ago, but the smell still lingers in my mind. Strong, charred, chocolate tones, heavy on the liqueur. It's not on the menu, but you MUST order it.  The food was also good. Beautiful presentation. Good place to wine and dine your loved one. Sit in the back for less noise and a more personable experience. However, sit at the bar and you'll get to see them light your Spanish Coffee afire!  I had the pork chop, which was quite delicious. Great place to have a wonderful evening out, dress up, have some great cocktails. I loved this place!

7TfVV64bpESXSalEuVQurw.review_text: Absinthe never fails to put a smile on my face. The atmosphere is great for catching up with an old friend or just grabbing lunch while in the Hayes.  The service can be lackluster at times, but as long as you have a nice cocktail and good company you won't notice.  My personal favorites at this restaurant are the oysters, French onion soup and sautéed dungeness crab.  As for cocktails, their French 75 is probably my favorite in the world to date and their citron lemonade was on point. Stay away from the nouveau carre (their take on a vieux carre, which I've never heard of... and I'm from NOLA) cocktail. It is pretty bad. Thankfully there are only a handful of cocktails that I didn't like personally... but the nouveau carre was a thumbs down with all my friends.

pxodqdk-GelbKirvXVL_SQ.review_text: My partner and I made it to Absinthe for the first time this past Sunday, for brunch.  We were wowed. Every morsel we ate was delicious. I ordered a Mediterranean lamb tenderloin. It was cooked perfectly and beautifully spiced. The accompanying chickpeas were very good, too, perfectly complementing the lamb. My partner had the pork quesadilla, also out of this world. I regret only having gotten one bite of that. The potatoes that came with it were crispy on the outside, nice and fluffy on the inside.   Two perfect, wonderfully savory dishes. We'll be back. Best brunch I've had in the City in a long time.  The service was excellent, too - pleasant and helpful.  I don't know why it took us so long to get here.

l36ud3agBxzBJ88zIeNVfA.review_text: What's so great about the Green Fairy?  EVERYTHING.  We had an extraordinarily "hallucinogenic" experience at Absinthe Restaurant & Bar Sunday night. The adorable Hayes Valley eatery proved to be the perfect pick for our post theater meal. The interior was romantic and cozy, with warm colors and soft yellow lighting. Plush booths and small tables encourage you to sit back, relax, and enjoy your meal.  Started the night right with the massive drink menu. Page upon page of the finest liquors, spirits, cocktails, and wine. SO much to choose from! Curiosity killed the cocktail question - we had to order Absinthe for the table. Green fairy or not - this sweet liquorice liquor is something worth trying!  Appetizers included cracked crab, french fries with 3 sauces, and house made bread. All were delightful and served in perfect portion size.  Second was the Frisée, baby leeks vinaigrette, house-smoked bacon, fried duck egg, fines herbs, and caviar salad. Prepare to be surprised by this salad - the dressing creates a dish that should not be missed!  For the main course, I ordered the Pan seared local halibut, sunchoke purée, pea leaves, baby carrots, sugar snap peas, sorrel & lemon thyme fumet. It was perfectly cooked and well combined with it's accompaniments. My boyfriend had the grilled whole trout, garbanzo beans, salametto piccante, wilted chard, grilled lemon, herb oil. It was a tasty trout, but definitely not for a dainty diner.... the fish's face was a big part of this plate!  By far the best entree was my mother's order, the Slow cooked pork confit, yellow corn, house made bacon, fava beans, mint, sweet corn sauce. Tender and tasty - it was the most mouthwatering moment of the meal.  There is only one way to end a savory Sunday supper...... by topping it off with something sweet! The Scharffen Berger chocolate Pot de crème is irresistible - a thick, creamy, chocolate bowl of pure bliss.    Service was a huge highlight of the night. The attentive, thoughtful, and knowledgeable staff helped us enjoy every minute of the meal. All of our courses were well timed - we never felt rushed and were able to enjoy each delightful bite. So happy I finally found out what all the "fairy" fuss was about - Absinthe Restaurant and Bar is a San Francisco treat!!

ISJ860z59OPGcuBbo-kjXg.review_text: Absinthe is a French bistro in the heart of Hayes Valley, where my cousin took hubs and I for brunch on our last morning in San Francisco.    This bistro is absolutely superb, the service was excellent, the staff knowledgeable, and totally willing to advise us touristy types about the recommended offerings on the menu.    I ordered the ricotta stuffed french toast with fresh blackberries, blueberries, strawberries, and a dollop of whipped cream with warm syrup on the side.  I have never had better french toast in my life.    My cousin had the biscuits and gravy with grits, and was making love to her food.  The oohs and aahs kinda gave her away.    Hubs had fresh banana and blueberry pancakes with fresh squeezed orange juice.    All of us ooh'd and aah'd our way through our meals, as we sat back and enjoyed each others conversation for a good two hours.    Freshness matters, I cannot say it enough, and San Francisco has got that part of the food market down solid.  This was the best brunch I have ever had.  Thank you for another wonderful meal, oh highly priced city that I dream of affording some day....

3HlJT3LfUFTAw5v_3Fs8CQ.review_text: Easily one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. My pocketbook prevents me from coming here as often as I'd like to, because when I come here I splurge quite heavily on the meal, drinks, dessert and of course the cheese plate. The drinks here are seriously some of the best in the city, especially if you have a predilection toward classic cocktails and variations thereof. I've only come here for dinner (before a movie or a concert or another bar) and so far every meal has made my eyes roll so far back they came up the bottom. I love this place...

7QgJHvGSCndSf-zOsAHf3A.review_text: This is my favorite mid to upscale restaurant in the city. It's a great place to come for a date or with a small group of friends. I have been to Absinthe three times and it has never disappointed. I have ordered drinks, appetizers, entrees, and desserts and each time, everything has been wonderful. Flavors were all there, and the food was cooked perfectly.  On my recent visit, we had the spicy fried chickpeas, lamb kefta skewers, and country pate plate to share as appetizers. I had the local sole as my entree, and the other two in my group had the pork rib eye chop and one of the steak dishes. We also shared the ice cream and sorbet selection as a dessert. As I said before, everything was great. I can't even choose one thing to recommend.   The drinks are mixed well. Service is awesome. They don't do that miniscule portioning like some restaurants in the same price scale do. Really, Absinthe can do no wrong.

ZPXt2X7teIZvRTrcyWbrEw.review_text: I have always wanted to give Absinthe a try, as I have heard very good things about it.  Last week, as a group of us were trekking the streets of Hayes Valley looking for a Sunday brunch spot, we decided to give it a shot.  It was very crowded when we first walked in but the hostess said she would give a call whenever our table was ready.  We walked around a bit and before you knew it she was calling us back.    The meal started off with a mimosa, which was very tasty, but then again you can't really go too wrong with those. The cocktail list sounded AMAZING and I was sad I didn't look at it before I ordered my mimosa. I had originally planned on eating brunchy type food, however, earlier that morning I ran quite a long distance and for some very odd reason my body was craving meat.  Naturally, I went with the hamburger.  I added gorgonzola to it which was quite a good choice.  I was semi disappointed because all that came with it was the hamburger no sides. But the hamburger was very good! Luckily we ordered fries....which were super yummy.  They were very thin and crunchy.  Other people at the table ordered an omelette and sandwiches which they said were good.    The service was par.  Nothing spectacular but no complaints.  Everything came pretty quick from the kitchen and it was all as ordered.   Overall, I would definitely come back to try dinner...I hear that the scallops are to die for!

kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA.review_text: I have not eaten here in years. As I remember they have gone through transitions and changes....and it appears that the new changes are really good. They have a wonderful new chief who has great skills.  The ambiance as always is great: Busy hustle bustle fun. Not too loud not too crazy.  Great wine and cocktail list....come on any restaurant named after that crazy absinthe (and I do mean crazy) has to have great cocktails. Wine list really caters to people that dont want to blow their cash on some crazy priced bottle...prices were pretty reasonable.  Food was really good too. Great fried chick peas, great heart of romaine and very nice coq a vine ( they use mary's chicken which is my fav). Deserts were so so in my opinion.  Service is good fast and efficient. Prices are high but you get a quality product in a quality setting with quality service.

SdZUq1WParOBlYWrxMRlbg.review_text: We have been here twice now and it has delivered every time. We would love to make this a regular dining event location in our local neighborhood.

xMDXFZC0-orsR2ucsdXglg.review_text: Note: I want to review specifically the Carrot Cake Dessert with Lavender Honey Ice Cream. Let me tell you: I was in HEAVEN, and I have had my share of tasty desserts in my life. This was decadent yet refreshing at once, my bf and I shared the dessert, but like a spoiled only child I wanted it all to myself! If you are trying to impress a dessert lover, bring them here!

MjlNTynslY_aLDTfGODuIg.review_text: This review is forweekend brunch.  If you don't want to have to wait in line outside for 60+min, and you want to have a confirmed reservation for brunch on a weekend day, then come here.  The food was just alright, I have definitely had better, but I have also had to wait in line at these other places (except for foreign cinema, great food and they take reservatons)  We order the french onion soup to start, I really dont know what all the hype is about, yes the soup was good, but way too much cheese for my taste, then again i've never had french onion soup prepared that way so maybe thats just the way it is  steer clear of the duck, my friend got the duck confit and I got the brunch roast (which was..you guessed it, smoked DUCK breast with steamed lentils and swiss chard). The confit was a bit dry, it was like eggs benedict with duck. my smoked duck was a bit better, but it definitely wasnt typical brunch fare and still a bit on the chewy and dry side (just a bit though)  the chocolate pot de creme, as you have probably seen from the rest the yelpers, was almost a home run, it was good, chocolately, light, sweet, yummy, but its akin to chocolate mousse you could find at any asian bakery (sorry to be blunt)  the bloody mary olives had pits in them, i have never had them like that in my bloody marys, and its not a good idea, the absinthe sangria was good, and perhaps this place deserve (and probably received) its rave reviews for their bar menu more so than they deserve it for their brunch, i cant comment on the dinner menu  there's a reason why this place takes walk-in's so readily for weekend brunch, there just isnt enough demand for this place, and now i know why

ZcAYyiUSWzD0Xe-djRGxZA.review_text: The new chef is an upgrade & the space is as handsome as ever (haven't been for a while..) However - fifteen bucks for a glass of the house (domestic) Chardonnay...!  No idea of its provenance but it wasn't great and probably highly proftable to the restaurant at one-half that price.

FHbWz5kgIXBcDHdNfCLhNg.review_text: So, the line for Brenda's was too long on a Sunday.  Big surprise.  Good thing there was ABSINTHE!  The hostess took down our names and our numbers!  I L-O-V-E it when restaurants do that!  After 20 minutes of waiting at a local bookstore, we got our call and was immediately sat down.  Five stars for service.  Drinks: My friend got some pear cocktail which was AMAZING I got a Bellini which was perfect in champagne to peach-shit ratio Friend got Sangria. She loved it.   Food: We all got the duck ragout. None of us had leftovers... Amazingly seasoned duck on a bed of mashed potatoes all covered by a golden egg. That's the shtuff!   Great experience overall, but I wish there were more intriguing items on the menu

tROQdDFk3hLq0rMsJptTjA.review_text: Very yummy.  Had the Halibut ... so yummy.  Not a huge amount of food.  But Tasty.    Enjoyed our Irish waiter. He was very nice and attentive.  He asked us if  we were planning on going to a show (we were.)  He kept us on track to make the show with plenty of time.    It was a pricey ... but worth it.

MbfrGVXuPU35K7lwZQEqVA.review_text: My friend and I had been wanting to try this place for a while so when we planned our next dinner date we immediately thought of this place.   We had to go through the effort of making a reservation, even for a Tuesday night, but were seated promptly upon arriving. We immediately spotted the cheese platter and drink menu. We also immediately spotted the prices. A plate of 3 cheeses for $35 and a regular drink $12. I mean we knew what we were getting ourselves into but it was still a bit of a shock when we got our $120 bill and realized we had only ordered an one appetizer, cheese, one entree and three drinks. I would definitely return, but next time with a sugar daddy.   The garlic pretzels are a must and the coq au vin is delectable!

wAs5k7Kb5j0FBxse5Qg2RA.review_text: This is hands down, my new favorite restaurant in SF! Every dish at Absinthe was better than the last and trust me, we tried a bit of everything. Not one person in our group was disappointed with anything they ordered. Here's a quick recap of our meal: Spicy fried chickpeas- delicious little snack to munch on while you wait Soft garlic pretzels- OMG, these were AMAZING. We wanted more, more, more! Maybe order 1 order per person. As good as the chickpeas were, the pretzels blew them out of the water! Potato mushroom leek soup- wonderful soup, very creamy and full of flavor. The large is plenty to share if you intend to pig out like we did. Selection of 3 cheeses- Had the Humboldt Fog, Mt Tam and Fromage de Meaux all 3 of which were wonderful. Again, this is probably ideal to share between at least 3-4 people. We were 3 and were feeling full before our entrees arrived Potato-Crusted Arctic Char- I absolutely loved this dish. thin slices of potato were carefully laid across the top of the Char and baked(?), it tasted like a delicious hash brown on top of fish. I know that might sound weird but it was amazing! I liked that it was served with what was basically a salad which kept the dish from being too heavy Pork Osso Bucco & Coq Au Vin- didn't try either of these though my friends ordered and loved both of these dishes. None of us were able to finish our meals, not for lack of trying but because we needed a tiny bit of room for dessert (it's worth it!) Meyer Lemon Tart- Very lemony, if that's your thing you'll love this dessert, I liked it but I'm not a huge fan of lemon desserts so I didn't eat too much of this one. The rest of the group managed to put it away Vanilla Cheesecake- Delicious, and just the right size. I was half expecting a fat slice a la Cheesecake Factory and was pleasantly surprised to receive the perfect, reduced guilt sized mini cheesecake. The cilantro doesn't add much to this dish but the macadamia nuts on top are amazing. I would try asking for extra macadamia nuts if they allow it to ensure there are some in every bite. Winter Squash Cake- Best dessert by far. I loved everything about the winter squash cake but the brown butter ice cream really holds it all together so be sure to proportion your bites just so :)  Can't wait to come back!!

J2hH0Z0dpa9u3c0Oq9nI_g.review_text: I went to Absinthe with my GB boyfriend for brunch last Sunday afternoon. It was fantastic. The food was incredible and so were the drinks (well, ok, except for Death in the Afternoon, that shit was TERRIBLE). When we jokingly told the waitress that we hated the drink (which, of course, was entirely my boyfriend's fault) she immediately brought us a drink menu and gave us great recommendations on better drinks (those gays love the fruity ones).         Our waitress' name was Kimberly. She was amazing. Seriously, if you go to Absinthe, ask to be seated in her section. And tip big, she deserves it. She was warm and friendly and was not one of those annoying, buzzing waitresses that are running rampant like the plague in Hayes Valley.       Anyway, back to the food: their French Onion Soup is amazing. This was my third time at Absinthe and it was just as superb as the last two times. For my entree I had the Croque Madame with heirloom tomatoes and zee boyfriend "a un steak frites, c'etait tres bien." It was a little pricey but definitely worth the money for a special occasion, which it was.

2lVI6VaBaZMM07Rf1Q2Jkg.review_text: So my bestfriend took his girlfriend here for some drinks on her 21st bday. I have always heard positive things about this place and was looking forward to seeing what this place had to offer. Unfortunately it offers nothing enjoyable. Since there was a larger group of us and we just wanted some drinks and simple fare we made a reservation instead of showing up and taking over the bar.  We arrived and were seated quickly. As soon as our waiter greeted us and found out we just wanted drinks and maybe some light food he sighed in disapproval. Wonderful. After going over their extensive spirit list I found the scotch page. First I ordered a round of Macallan 12 year for my best friend, another mate and I. 10 minutes he comes back and says they're out. No biggie, its a great scotch and these things happen. I then go for the glenmorangie original. More time passes and once again he tells me they are out. Dafuq is this? So I end up ordering a younger scotch and just leave it at that. He brings the girls drinks which I didn't pay much attention to however they claimed that none were remarkable.   The bday girl orders some cheese and olives and I ended up ordering their burger.So after about an hour of of being at the table and having my scotch I get my burger, my horribly expensive, dinkey, dry burger that was ordered medium rare. It wasn't bad, there was just no flavour. I didn't send it back because our wonderful shiney bald headed waiter looked like he wanted to spit in my food because of his disdain for possibly not getting a big tip.   The best part of my meal was their fries...o I'm sorry, pomme frittes. I forgot I had to be pretentious for a bit. Very well cooked, crispey outside and nice and cooked on the inside. It was the only thing that saved my meal.  So the bill comes and the total is $180. We leave a generous $35 tip and leave. Before I do I use the restroom and on the way I walk by him and another employee and he's bitching about the paultry tip we gave him. Needless to say there are many thing I could have done at this point, told him to @#$% off, complained to the manager, asked to see the money that we left and taken the tip back. No, I consider myself a gentleman and just walked out and decided that I would rather spend my money somewhere else in the future. There are many good eateries in the area and I am not missing out on anything by never going to Absinthe again. Cheers.

C6pi4hzwvtlygGfz86TJhQ.review_text: Solid 4 star place. Great drinks- really unique!  food- yummy cheese plate options (though I usually love brie and I didn't love their soft cheese) and great entrees. i had the chicken and it was some of the best chicken i've had in a while!  I really do like this place, though it's not the most spectacular semi expensive restaurant I've been to. As my bf said, "I'll go again if someone else wants to go but there's so many other places to try in the city, and with a budget, I'd rather try the other places."

XztOSkYvbPB02aXtc_rV_g.review_text: One statement could sum up my review: The food was fantastic, the service was not.  This restaurant happened to be right across the inn we were staying at during our get away in the city. He's eaten here before and wanted to try it out again. So we stepped in around 9pm and did not have to wait too long to be seated.   We were seated by the bar, which is probably due to our lack of reservation. The view was quite interesting. Seeing a bunch of drunk people on dates was a sight to see.  Some were nervous, some were doing well but there was one couple making out like crazy. It was entertaining until it became really crude. They were to the point that even I was even grossed out - let's just say my tolerance level is high. Heck, I didn't even bat an eyelash to Two Girls, One Cup.   The waitress didn't really care for us and ignored us most of the time. She even made me feel like I was bothering her the whole time. I'm not very demanding, so I was really surprised by her demeanor. Every time we said thanks, she just looked away. She even rolled her eyes at one point when we asked for our drinks that she forgot to give us. The service was lacking and made the whole experience mediocre rather than spectacular. There was a lot of attitude for no reason, whatsoever.   The food was amazing. It was their saving grace. I ordered the Waygu steak. My boyfriend gave me the go ahead to order mushrooms; I interpreted his permission as to order black truffles. He meant regular mushrooms but he didn't mind that I went all out. The steak was simply mouth watering and the creme fraiche mash potatoes completed it so well. The veggies were amazing and cooked to perfection, all the while the fried onions and black truffle added an additional level of flavor and texture. It was really delicious. We ordered a pot de creme-like chocolate dessert and we were fighting each other for the last bite.   The food is amazing and I will definitely come back for the food and hope for better service.

owUU9IY2Ts-fblF7PBIyyw.review_text: Went here for the 1st time on a Sunday for brunch. Cute place inside and they have outside seating which I liked. We sat at the bar which was a nice feel. I ordered this drink that was in a champagne glass and had grapefruit, champagne, lime and some other ingredients and it was amazing!!!!!!!!! I ordered the Duck Confit Ragout which sits on poached eggs, a chive potato cake and toast on the side, I truly fell in love!!!!!!!! My friend ordered the fruit dish which comes with cream and she really liked it!  It was very busy and there was only one bartender who handled all of the bar and all the drinks for the restaurant and that is why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. I'm not saying it was the bartenders fault because he was doing the best he could. But it would have been nice if he was able to be attentive, especially for the price your paying. Overall great experience and I would go back!

GGZWTwZuhy6u5LvJP0OLNQ.review_text: I really like the ambience, the food, the service.  I had the burger and it was fantastic.  We sat in a corner table and it was very secluded and romantic. Get the burger.
